title: Phys Ed: Does Stretching Before Running Prevent Injuries?
description: Should you stretch before a run? That question, which has prompted countless academic studies, debates and inter-running-partner squabbles, is now at the heart of a notable new study published in August on the Web site of USA Track and Field, the sports national governing body. The study, one of the largest of its kind, involved almost 1,400 runners, from age 13 to past 60, who were assigned randomly to two groups. The first group did not stretch before their runs, while otherwise maintaining their normal workout routine: the same mileage, warm-up (minus any stretching) and so on. The second group stretched, having received photographs and specific instructions for a series of simple, traditional poses, like leaning over and touching toes, that focused on the calf, hamstring and quadriceps muscles. The volunteers were told to hold each stretch for 20 seconds, a technique known as static stretching. The entire routine required three to five minutes and was to be completed immediately before a run.

Schools generally do not allow parents to see any part of a teachers past evaluations, for instance. And there is nothing resembling a rigorous, Consumer Reports-like analysis of schools, let alone of individual teachers. For the most part, parents just have to hope for the best.

title: Now Coveting | Modern Primitives
description: To create their new collection of hyper-masculine curiosities, the glass-blowing studio Esque and the art and design firm No. 1 Son (both based in Portland, Ore.) pilfered ideas from millennia past. Aptly named (Bar)barian, the collaboration was inspired by what Andi Kovel and Justin Parker of Esque call the noble savage: objects that were once made from horn, wood and stone are reimagined in glass and leather. Why serve drinks from an ordinary decanter when you could present (Bar)barians Flagon, a swirling glass vessel that resembles the horn of some mythical beast? Or why not go all out with the Travel Bar: two hornlike glasses, a bone-shaped stirrer and a leather studded case in which to lug them? Just dont go hunting for dinner with the OB-J slingshot. Rendered in wood-colored glass with an inelastic leather strap and fragile handle, its entirely nonfunctional. But thats entirely the point: by allowing utility and convenience to go the way of the woolly mammoth, (Bar)barian has transformed objects from the past into up-to-the-minute pieces of pure decadence.

title: Iraq in the Long Run
description: It was a strange speech that Obama gave last night, but then again it was a strange situation. Has there ever been an American president charged with winding down a difficult war that he opposed from the outset? Richard Nixon wasnt a critic of escalation in Vietnam. Dwight Eisenhower wasnt an opponent of Harry Trumans initial decision to defend South Korea. Teddy Roosevelt, obviously, was if anything more zealous about taking over the Philippines than William McKinley. So Obamas predicament last night was historically unique: He had to cast the wars ending in favorable terms praising the troops, touting the progress weve made toward a stable Iraq without ever answering the polarizing question, was it worth it? Because, one presumes, he still doesnt think that it was.

Hes talking about belonging to a social tribe, as in Williamsburg hipsters or corporate America. title: One Store Scoops Up the Lot
description: VENA CAVA has translated its blend of unique prints, vintage aesthetic and subtle silhouettes into a limited-edition collection for Aqua, the Bloomingdales in-house label. The pieces range from $98 to $198, and include a military jacket, faux fur vest and studded shorts.

title: No Longer Thinking Uniformly
description: THE National Football Leagues design philosophy for womens clothing used to be reduced to a simple formula: Pink it and shrink it. Now female tailgaters or remote-wielding couch potatoes can opt for the stylish N.F.L. Womens Apparel line designed by different licensees. It includes a sheer and fitted Jaguars T-shirt (Touch by GIII, $39.99).

title: Near Kandahar, the Prize Is an Empty Town
description: MEHLAJAT, Afghanistan  When the governor of Kandahar Province came to this town, freshly liberated on Sunday from the Taliban, his armed entourage appeared to outnumber what was left of the population.

title: The Unfinished Tale of an Unlikely Hero
description: DESCRIBING a walk through the garden outside her home in Cleveland Heights, Ohio, after a rainstorm, Joyce Brabner said she was looking for a dry place to sit and talk about how things have been going since the death of her husband, Harvey Pekar, the comic-book writer.

title: Cool It, Film Rival to An Inconvenient Truth, Gets a U.S. Distributor
description: The environmental message of former Vice President Al Gores An Inconvenient Truth is about to get a little competition at American cinemas. On Wednesday, the distributor Roadside Attractions said it had acquired Ondi Timoners documentary Cool It, about the Danish statistician and writer Bjorn Lomborg, for release in the United States, just before that film is to make its make its world premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival.

title: The Cheat: A Hot Tomato
description: The last of the tomatoes are coming in now, wide and cracked, heavy with the captured humidity of passing summer, each one a Neruda poem shedding its own light, benign majesty. It is time to eat them, these sunsets of the season, then put away our flip-flops and face the fall.

title: Smoke-Roasted Chicken Thighs With Paprika
description: 1 tablespoon sweet paprika

title: Updates, on Soldiers and Sons
description: Allison Buckholtzs husband, Scott, is home. She has written here on Motherlode, and on her Slate blog, Deployment Diaries, about holding the family fort in Washington, D.C., with 6-year-old Than and 4-year-old Esther, while he served two tours of duty in Iraq. Today  one day after the official end of U.S. combat operations in that country  she has an essay on Slate announcing Scotts recent homecoming. His newest assignment will be a Navy staff job near home, where, she writes, he will be driving to work every morning and pulling up to the house every evening. The domestic dullness Ive long craved is imminent.

title: From Apple, a Step Into Social Media for Music
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple jumped into the social networking business on Wednesday, introducing Ping, a service built into iTunes that is intended to help users discover new music and, presumably, buy more songs from Apple.

title: Maryland Hostages Safe as Police Kill Gunman
description: Police officers shot and killed a gunman with a history of protesting against the Discovery Channel, the authorities said, ending a nearly four-hour ordeal on Wednesday at the companys headquarters in Silver Spring, Md. The gunman, apparently wearing explosives, had taken two employees and a security guard hostage, officials said.

title: An Oasis Off Londons Beaten Path
description: WITH its picnic tables and chipped folding chairs, Towpath feels as if it should be in a shack on the beach, not on the ground floor of a converted factory in East London.

title: At the Center of the Storm, but Still a Mystery
description: A man without a shadow; a pleasant man with a pleasant family living in a pleasant North London house; a bright, telegenic, yet elusive politician with a smooth facade. This is how a newspaper article in The Guardian famously described Tony Blair long before he became prime minister of Britain in 1997.

title: Courtside: A Tennis Dream Comes True
description: Lauren Herring and her partner earned a wild card to the Open by capturing a doubles title in August. Lauren's father will be watching watching with pride on Thursday.

title: Letter: Portland Is To ...
description: To the Editor: I was amused to read 36 Hours in Portland, Me. (Aug. 22) and find that (wow!) our city offers shops that are more Brooklyn Flea than L. L. Bean; a neighborhood thats like Notting Hill, and a bar more Munich than Maine. While your writer is correct that Portland is much more than the tourist stereotype of lobster, lighthouses and L. L. Bean, it is, blissfully, itself: a singularly interesting place that doesnt need comparisons (foreign or domestic) to illuminate it.

title: At the Open: First Class, Economy and All Business
description: Every few minutes the 7 train lurches into the Willets Point station, and more crowds, speaking in various languages, although clearly not from Queens, form scrums at the doors. They disgorge from the air-conditioned cars and head in the other direction from Citi Field, onto the boardwalk.

title: Letter: Bogs and Bikes
description: To the Editor: I read with much excitement Clifford J. Levys, In Estonia, Jiggling and Bog-Trekking (Aug. 22). My husband and I recently returned from a trip to Estonia that included a full-day mountain bike excursion to Lahemaa National Park. We had limited time in the park, so our guide from City Bikes in Tallinn recommended a coastal route perfect for a leisurely ride.

title: What Were Reading: Help the Poor, Patronize a Sweatshop
Darkness in the Village, Where Lives Were Lost and Saved
description: For almost four months, I had deliberately avoided the intersection of Seventh Avenue and West 12th Street  no easy task when coming and going from Greenwich Village. Since it was impossible to imagine that St. Vinnys was dark, I couldnt bear to confront the evidence with my own eyes.

title: Why Labor Day Is the Best Time to Buy a Car
description: If youre considering buying a new car, you may want to consider buying it this weekend.

title: Azarenka Collapses With Mild Concussion
description: Up went her service toss at the United States Open on Wednesday, and Victoria Azarenka, already wobbly on her feet and down in the first set of her second-round match, 0-4, took a swing and missed completely, the ball bouncing off her back before landing on the steamy surface of the grandstand court.

title: Super Slide Opens in Singapore Airport
description: Who cares about delayed flights when you can pass the time riding a 40-foot-tall, jumbo twister slide?

title: Two Takes on Blood Simple
description: A. O. Scott dissects a scene from the Coen brothers Blood Simple and a scene from its remake, Zhang Yimous A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop.

title: Framing a Statement
description: TRANSLUCENT sunglass frames make a perfect chic-geek statement. A recent sweep of downtown Manhattan stores found, from top, Han sunglasses, $198, at Oak, including 28 Bond Street (Lafayette Street), (212) 677-1293, oaknyc.com; Super sunglasses, $135, at Gargyle, 16A Orchard Street (Canal Street), (917) 470-9367, gargyle.com; and Love Child sunglasses, $15, In God We Trust stores, including 265 Lafayette Street (Prince Street), (212) 966-9010, ingodwetrustnyc.com.

title: Interviews on Water Use Are Thirsty Work
description: Fieldwork Begins

title: Ford Replacing Classic Police Cruiser With an S.U.V.
description: The Ford Motor Company announced on Wednesday the availability of a new Police Interceptor utility vehicle. Based on the new Ford Explorer, the vehicle is meant to complement the front-wheel-drive police sedan based on the Taurus that was introduced this year.

title: Hudson, N.Y.: Where Bands Feel at Home
description: The riverside town of Hudson now boasts a robust grassroots music scene.

title: Burger Kings Post-I.P.O. Stock Price Isnt Royal
description: As Burger King holds talks with prospective buyers, including Brazilian-backed 3G Capital, its worth looking at how the buyout-backed fast food giant has performed since going public again in 2006.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. A clear majority of Americans say Sarah Palin is not qualified to be president. A fact you cant refudiate or frapricate.

title: Cardinals Shopping Leinart
description: The Arizona Cardinals have begun calling teams with quarterback needs to gauge interest in Matt Leinart, the former first-round pick and Heisman Trophy winner at Southern California who has failed on numerous occasions to seize the Cardinals starting job. He now appears to have been supplanted by Derek Anderson, who was released by the Cleveland Browns in the off-season.

title: Afghanistan Official Tries to Ease Depositors Worries About Troubled Bank
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans top bank official tried Wednesday to calm fears of a meltdown at one of the countrys largest financial institutions, while scores of Afghans lined up to empty their accounts and found the bank unwilling to comply.

title: How to Get Loyalty Card Prices Without Loyalty Cards
description: All those loyalty cards you have dangling off your keychain or plumping your wallet? Gone. In their place, smartphone users will have free apps like Key Ring or Cardstar on their cellphones.

title: Courtside: A Tennis Parent Is Ready for the Big Event
description: C. L. Herring remembers the first time his little girl beat him up in tennis.

title: Fuld Says Lehman Could Have Been Saved
description: Richard S. Fuld Jr. told a federal commission that his firm, Lehman Brothers, failed only because the Federal Reserve refused to step in as it did with other firms.

title: Romers Final Washington Dispatch: More Stimulus
description: 6:51 p.m. | Updated  The full text of Ms. Romers talk is now on the White House Web site.

title: An Iraqi Womans Change of Address and New Life
description: Correspondents who covered the war in Iraq are reflecting on their time there and the official end of United States combat operations. Erica Goode was a correspondent in Baghdad in 2008.

title: F.C.C. Seeks More Input on Wireless Internet Rules
description: WASHINGTON  On the Internet, data moves at the speed of light. The Federal Communications Commission, not so fast.

title: Big Interest in Tiny Cars
description: Thousands of people gathered in Crystal Lake, Ill., for the first International Microcar/Minicar World Meet.

title: We Made It Ourselves | Dry Creek Peach Jam
description: If you were one of those children who read Roald Dahls James and the Giant Peach and thought the idea of living inside the giant stone fruit sounded swell, you really ought to get yourself a jar or two, or 14, of Dry Creek Peach jam.

title: Discontent in Baghdad
description: Stephen Farrell reports on growing frustrations among Iraqi citizens as the United States brings an end to its combat mission.

title: Of Two Minds About Books
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Auriane and Sebastien de Halleux are at sharp odds over The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, but not about the plot. The problem is that she prefers the book version, while he reads it on his iPad. And in this literary dispute, the couple says, its neer the twain shall meet.

title: Clinton Heading Back to Arkansas for Lincoln
description: Former President Bill Clinton, who strongly supported Senator Blanche Lincoln in her primary battle this year, is heading back to Arkansas next week to stump for her.

title: Berdych Makes an Early Exit
description: Michael Llodra, a veteran French competitor ranked 35th in the world, upset the Wimbledon finalist, seventh-seeded Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic, 7-6 (3), 6-4, 6-4, in the first major upset of the United States Open mens singles championship.

title: Immigrants Oral Histories Going Online
description: A collection of more than 1,700 recorded oral histories from immigrants who arrived in the United States through Ellis Island will be available free online starting Thursday at www.ancestry.com/immigration. The histories, recorded by the National Park Service starting in the 1970s, are housed at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum and until now have been available only to island visitors.

title: Rangel Joins Muslims in Rally for Downtown Mosque
description: Facing one of the more contentious re-election campaigns of his 40-year career, United States Representative Charles B. Rangel waded into a polarizing debate on Wednesday as he spoke out in favor of an Islamic center and mosque planned near ground zero.

title: O Urban Pioneers!
description: In 1967, my husband and I bought and fully renovated a four-story brownstone on Manhattans Upper West Side, creating a duplex for ourselves and two floors of rental apartments. Despite its Manhattan address, our friends envied neither our money nor our luck; at the time, it didnt take much of either to buy in the neighborhood.

title: Neighborhood Looks
description: San Francisco fashion includes distinctive elements of a local style that seems to be generated by some loopy organic collective impulse rather than an editorial cabal.

title: Beijing Opera Academy of China
description: The Beijing operas popularity is waning among modern audiences but young students still flock to opera training academies.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lahore and Elsewhere
description: Three bombs ripped through a Shiite Muslim procession in the eastern Pakistani city of Lahore on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported, killing 25 people and wounding about 150 others. The explosions appeared to be the latest in a string of attacks by Sunni extremists against the minority Shiites they consider infidels.

title: In Somalia, Battle Ends for Streets of Capital
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The streets of Mogadishu, Somalias besieged capital, were finally quiet on Wednesday, after 10 days of heavy fighting that has claimed more than 100 lives.

title: Hiking New Englands Highest Peaks
description: A look at the height and difficulty level of six New England peaks.

title: E.U. Casts Legal Doubt on French Roma Expulsion
description: BRUSSELS  The legality of Frances crackdown on Roma migrants was thrown into doubt Wednesday when a report from the European Commission said that French law lacked minimum safeguards required by the European Union to protect deportees.

title: Usage Rights for a TV Show Season Pass on iTunes
Airgass Novel Question
description: Airgas has raised a novel question of Delaware law. As I discussed on Monday, Airgas has claimed that Air Products proposed bylaw amendment to move Airgass 2011 annual meeting to January is invalid under Delaware law.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 1
description: A view of the day in sports, including cycling in Italy and the world basketball championships in Turkey.

title: How to Choose and Work With a Mentor
description: AS a small-business owner, you may feel isolated. Without a large organizations resources, you may long for a sounding board for your frustrations and fears or a discreet, impartial adviser with whom to discuss the tactical and strategic challenges of running a company.

title: Harrison Breaks Through in Upset
description: In his first mens singles appearance at the United States Open, the 18-year-old qualifier Ryan Harrison ousted 15th-seeded Ivan Ljubicic of Croatia, 6-3, 6-7 (4), 6-3, 6-4.

title: Ping Fosters Music Discovery, Not Friend Discovery
description: On Thursday Wednesday morning, Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive, showed off a new social network for music called Ping. It runs inside the newest version of Apples iTunes software. Ping also works on the latest software for iPhones and iPod Touches. (Apple hasnt made it available for iPad this time around.)

title: Graphic Content | Thurston Moores Indie Books
description: With publishers looking for ways to capitalize on e-books, starting an independent publishing house may be as foolhardy as investing in Betamax. But thats not stopping Thurston Moore of Sonic Youth. He and the editor/publisher Eva Prinz founded Ecstatic Peace Library (ecstaticpeacelibrary.com, or facebook.com/pages/Ecstatic-Peace-Library/346362294368), which features art, design, photography and poetry books, including Fly Me by Yoko Ono, a limited-edition book and box of kites, each with a kite frame, strings, instructions on flying and a message from Ono.

title: Bieber Fever
description: The teenage pop star performed before an enthusiastic, sold-out crowd at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night.

title: Sampling Dublins Theater Scene
description: A handful of theaters cultivate a small but energized theatrical community.

title: Theater Talkback: Just When You Think You Know Somebody . . .
description: There are some people you feel can never surprise you, you know them so well. Youve spent hours in their company, you know all their little habits, you even hear what theyre going to say before they say it. And then, every so often (and it could be the 20th encounter), one of them does something that knocks you for a loop and you think, I never really knew you at all.

title: How Do You Know When to Trust Your Gut?
description: Weve just published a small-business guide that offers lots of helpful advice about how to find a mentor. But no matter how you find your mentor and no matter how good your mentor is, there will most likely come a time when you have to answer this question: Do I follow the advice Im being given or do I trust my gut?

title: The Tribes of San Francisco
description: San Francisco

title: Your Own Hot Spot, and Cheap
description: Someday, theyll build wireless Internet into every building, just the way they build in running water, heat and electricity today. Someday, we wont have to drive around town looking for a coffee shop when we need to check our e-mail.

title: Carrying the Spear (and Dagger) for a Fading Art Form
description: BEIJING  Watch out for that sword, the rehearsal director shouted. I dont want anybodys head getting cut off because you dont know what youre doing.

title: A Weekend in Silicon Valley
description: The Valleys dozen or so cities are continuing their shift from corporate strip malls to urban hubs.

title: You Never Forget That Star-Struck Encounter With Your Idol
description: Two recent Off Broadway plays  A. R. Gurneys Grand Manner and Jonathan Tolinss Secrets of the Trade  explore what happens when showbiz-besotted fans meet their idols. Sometimes a backstage encounter with a star is life changing; visiting on an off night can be awkward and awe draining. (Mr. Gurneys actual meeting with the actress Katharine Cornell was quite brief, though the play imagines a very different outcome to that encounter.)

title: For the A-Cup Crowd, Minimal Assets Are a Plus
description: IT is commonly assumed that small-chested women feel that natures lottery has left them coming up short. The parade of heaving bosoms in Victorias Secret catalogs not only suggests that bigger is better but also that supersizing with a push-up bra is universally desired.

title: Composers Influences, Side by Side
description: In his 10-part recital series at the Dicapo Opera Theater the pianist Ian Hobson is celebrating the Chopin and Schumann bicentennial year by putting both composers in context. Each recital includes works by one or both, and pieces by others who influenced or were influenced by them. In place of program notes Mr. Hobson has invited David Dubal, the author and pianist, to introduce each work. His comments are highly personalized (what he tells his students, what he likes or finds terrifying about particular pieces) and more than a little hagiographic.

title: Hey, Mr. Restaurant Critic! Open House Edition
description: Given the hardship assignment of spending a few lazy, late summer days basking in the sunshine, watching incredible athletes compete at the highest level and generally soaking up tennis-related atmosphere around the city during the Open, I needed help, so enlisted a trouper to handle one of the more specialized and grueling chores.

title: Donning Sinatras Mystique, From Movie Sailor to Saloon Dandy
description: May you live to be 100, and may the last voice you hear be mine. So went a cocky, wisecracking toast that Frank Sinatra was fond of delivering to audiences in his later concert performances. Those words were heard again during Tuesdays opening-night performance of the well-traveled revue Our Sinatra, at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

title: Conan Unveils Conan
description: Continuing to diminish expectations after his brief Tonight Show run lost the Emmy Award for best variety, music or comedy series to The Daily Show on Sunday night, Conan OBrien revealed the modest title of his coming TBS program in a YouTube video on Wednesday. After a lengthy setup and an attempt at a drum roll that Mr. OBrien, above, acknowledged sounded more like a purring cat, he revealed that the show would be called Conan. Yes, Conan. Thats right, just Conan. In a Twitter message on Tuesday, Mr. OBrien joked that he was prepared to announce the shows title earlier but my lawyers tell me The Return of Nanny McPhee is taken. Conan is scheduled to make its premiere Nov. 8 on TBS.

title: Mens Cosmetics Becoming a Bull Market
description: WHEN cosmetics began disappearing from her bathroom drawer a few years ago, Gretchen Bain, who lives in Merchantville, N.J., knew the culprit.

title: Talent Tops TV Ratings After Obama Speech
description: NBCs Americas Got Talent earned the top ratings on Tuesday after President Obamas live address pre-empted the start of network schedules in some time zones. According to Nielsens estimates, an average of 11.3 million viewers tuned in to Americas Got Talent from 9 to 11 p.m., far more than any other program that night. CBS was second with reruns of NCIS (8.1 million), NCIS: Los Angeles (7.3 million) and The Good Wife (5.1 million); ABC was third with Wipeout (6.5 million), Shaq Vs. (4 million) and Primetime: Crime (3.1 million). Fox averaged 3.6 million for back-to-back repeats of Glee.

title: Michael Douglas Discusses His Cancer on Late Show
description: Michael Douglas said in an interview with David Letterman on Tuesday evening that he had started treatment for Stage 4 throat cancer, and offered cautious optimism that he would recover from it. Appearing on Mr. Lettermans Late Show on CBS to promote his coming film, Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps, Mr. Douglas, above left with Mr. Letterman, said he was given the diagnosis earlier in the summer after seeing several doctors for a nagging sore throat. Asked by Mr. Letterman about the severity of his condition  a Stage 4 cancer is defined as one that has spread to other parts of the body  Mr. Douglas replied: The big thing youre always worried about is it spreading, so I am head and neck. I am above the neck, so nothings gone down, and the expectations are good. Mr. Douglas, 65, said he had completed the first week of an eight-week chemotherapy regimen. When asked by Mr. Letterman if he smoked, Mr. Douglas said he smoked and drank, adding, This particular type of cancer is caused by alcohol and drinking. When asked about his chances for recovery, Mr. Douglas replied: The percentages are very good. I would hate to say, but right now it looks like it should be 80 percent, and with certain hospitals and everything, it does improve.

title: Divisive Artist Returns To MoMA P.S. 1
description: Six months after the performance artist Ann Liv Young was at the center of a divisive performance at MoMA P.S. 1, the museum on Tuesday granted her request to return, Ms. Young and the museum said. Ms. Young announced her return a few weeks ago, but at the time the museum said no such event had been approved. Tuesdays decision followed two meetings with various staff members at MoMA P.S. 1, in Long Island City, Queens, including one with its director, Klaus Biesenbach. Ms. Young is to stage a public performance-lecture there on Sunday, discussing her original February appearance. That February performance involved a confrontation between her and a fellow artist, Georgia Sagri, and was curtailed abruptly when Mr. Biesenbach ordered the electricity shut off. I think its great, Ms. Young said Tuesday afternoon after her second meeting at the museum. The performance-lecture will be at 2 p.m. in the temporary studio that the artist A. L. Steiner occupies in the museum basement as part of the Greater New York exhibition. (Though the event is open to the public, it is a small space.) Ms. Steiner will be present, and so will a security guard. But Mr. Biesenbach wont: hell be traveling.

title: Katy Perry Wafts Her Way To No. 1
description: It took cotton-candy-scented CDs (and a couple of hit songs and a skin-baring video), but Katy Perrys Teenage Dream (Capitol) handily bumped Eminems Recovery (Aftermath/Interscope) from No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. Teenage Dream sold 192,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, taking Ms. Perry to the top of the chart for the first time. Fantasia, who won American Idol six years ago, opened at No. 2 with her third album, Back to Me (J), which sold 117,000, and Recovery fell two spots to No. 3 with 98,000, the first time in 10 weeks of release that its sales have dipped below 100,000. Ushers mini-album Versus (Jive) opened at No. 4 with 46,000 copies sold, and his full-length Raymond vs. Raymond (Jive), which was released in March and reissued last week in a package that included Versus, jumped 12 spots to No. 19 with 20,000 sales. The country group Little Big Town bowed at No. 5 with 42,000 sales of its new album The Reason Why (Capitol Nashville).

title: Ellis Island Oral Histories Online
description: A collection of more than 1,700 recorded oral histories from immigrants who arrived in the United States through Ellis Island will be available free online beginning Thursday at ancestry.com/immigration. The histories, recorded by the National Park Service starting in the 1970s, are housed at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum and have previously been available only to island visitors. They capture moments like Lawrence Meinwalds first glimpse of the Statue of Liberty: It was very early in the morning and we heard this rumbling, he says. My father and I dressed and went to the deck. There were people of all denominations, some on their knees making the sign of the cross, Jews in their prayer shawls as we were passing the Statue of Liberty. The tapes are the latest addition to Ancestry.coms United States Immigration Collection, which has 170 million records including lists of passengers who immigrated by ship to America between 1820 and 1960, more than seven million citizenship and naturalization records, border crossings and passport applications. Ancestry.coms full collection of United States immigration records will be searchable free for a limited period, Thursday through Monday. The Ellis Island Oral History collection will remain free.

title: Revisiting Maxs, Sanctuary for the Hip
description: IF a fiction writer were to sit down and conjure up a Manhattan nightspot where a John Chamberlain sculpture flanked the jukebox and Debbie Harry waited tables, where the earth artist Robert Smithson held court with Waylon Jennings, where struggling artists could cash their checks and pick up their mail, where the New York Dolls and Charlie Rich played (in the same year!) and where an unknown named Bob Marley once opened for a slightly less unknown named Bruce Springsteen, he would probably be scoffed at for fabulist excess.

title: Miranda Lambert Leads Country Nominations
description: Step aside, Taylor Swift: the Country Music Association seems to have a new sweetheart of the rodeo. Miranda Lambert, right, who with Dierks Bentley announced the nominations for the C.M.A. Awards Wednesday on Good Morning America, landed nine nominations in total, more than any other artist this year. Ms. Lambert, the former Nashville Star finalist, was nominated for female vocalist of the year and album of the year (for Revolutions), and picked up two nominations in the single-of-the-year category, for The House That Built Me and White Liar, both of which were also nominated for music video of the year. Ms. Lambert is also a contender for the C.M.A.s top prize, entertainer of the year, along with Lady Antebellum, Brad Paisley, Keith Urban and the Zac Brown Band. Lady Antebellum picked up five nominations in all, including vocal group of the year, single of the year (for Need You Now) and album of the year. The awards ceremony will be broadcast on Nov. 10 on ABC.

title: Phantom Sequel Unlikely For Broadway In Spring
description: It looks increasingly unlikely that Love Never Dies, Andrew Lloyd Webbers sequel to The Phantom of the Opera, will come to Broadway in spring as planned. A spokesman for the production said on Tuesday that Love Never Dies, right, was still set for the Neil Simon Theater in spring, but the London productions director, Jack OBrien, and choreographer, Jerry Mitchell, who were expected to work on the Broadway show, have left to focus on their new musical, Catch Me if You Can, said two Broadway producers who are not involved with either show, but have spoken with Mr. OBrien and Mr. Mitchell. The producers shared the details on condition of anonymity because Mr. OBrien and Mr. Mitchell asked them not to say anything publicly. The producers said their understanding was that a Broadway version of Love Never Dies would not happen this season. Mr. OBrien and Mr. Mitchell did not return messages seeking comment. Love Never Dies opened in March in London to mostly negative reviews. The spokesman for Love Never Dies, Adrian Bryan-Brown, said plans to bring the show to Broadway in the spring were still on, and were just waiting for a date.

title: Send in the Heartthrob, Cue the Shrieks
description: Justin Biebers love isnt of the puppy sort. Instead his songs crackle with the first blush of seduction and power  sweet enough to deceive his youngest fans, and probably their parents too, but absolutely delivered with a devious glint in his eye.

title: Protest Shuts Down Oil Rig off Greenland
description: Greenpeace halted exploratory drilling by a Scottish oil firm off the coast of Greenland on Tuesday after four protesters scaled an oil rig and suspended tents from its underside.

title: Medicating Children
description: Tens of thousands of preschoolers are prescribed powerful anti-psychotic drugs, but some psychiatrists say that pills are a simple solution to a complex problem.

title: Soldiers of Convenience
description: Heavily armed pirate militias, financed with tens of millions of dollars in ransoms, are becoming a factor in Somalias civil war.

title: Whose Side Are You On? It Might Be the Talibans
description: The Taliban try to kill American troops every day.

title: Childs Ordeal Shows Risks of Psychosis Drugs for Young
description: OPELOUSAS, La.  At 18 months, Kyle Warren started taking a daily antipsychotic drug on the orders of a pediatrician trying to quell the boys severe temper tantrums.

title: 2 Charged in MedImmune Insider Trading Scheme
description: Another day, another set of insider trading charges  this time revolving around two buddies accused of illicitly trading in MedImmune.

title: Iraqis Reactions to President Obamas Speech
description: Mosul

title: Shopping With Marc Murphy
description: The chef and restaurateur behind Landmarc and Ditch Plains in Manhattan shopped for picnic gear.

title: In Missouri, Card Playing for a Good Cause
description: BackStoppers is a charity in the St. Louis area that gives financial aid to the families of police officers, firefighters and medical workers who were killed in the line of duty. Bridge did its part to help when Bridge Haven ran a pro-am game on Sunday that raised $3,500.

title: Cardinal, Who Mediated in Belgian Abuse Case, Says He Was Misled
description: PARIS  With the recent release of tapes chronicling the private clash of a family over sexual abuse by a Belgian bishop, the retired cardinal who played a role as a mediator is now distancing himself from his longtime colleague and friend.

title: Mazdas New Concept Car: Not Going With the Flow
description: Mazda rolled out a surprise this week in Milan: a concept car that its design chief says outlines the companys future design language.

title: Brooklyn College Furor Is More Heated Online
description: Reading about it online, you would think that the controversy over this years assigned reading for students new to Brooklyn College would have led to fevered student and faculty protests by now, making the campus the latest to be roiled by the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: How Women Reshaped the Modern Kitchen
description: Counter Space: Design and the Modern Kitchen, an exhibition that opens Sept. 15 at the Museum of Modern Art, will explore the way the kitchen has evolved since the start of the 20th century. Juliet Kinchin (right), the curator of the show, talked about the role women played in designing rational kitchens  including some early ergonomic models  and the symbolism of utensils like Philippe Starcks Juicy Salif Lemon Squeezer.

title: Picnic Essentials
description: SUMMER is winding down, but picnic season isnt over yet.

title: Sales at Intrieurs, Nest Interiors and Desiron
description: Intrieurs is discounting some floor samples (Modenatures Renversant sofa, originally $8,734, is $4,000; Modenatures Teatime daybed in suede, regularly $10,362, is $4,900; the India Song chaise, above, originally $6,190, is $2,490); 228 East 58th Street (Second Avenue), (212) 343-0800, interieurs.com.

title: Ceramics That Seek a Timeless Look

description: The body of a British spy, found dead in his apartment in London last month, had been padlocked into a gym bag and put in the bathtub, officials said Wednesday at the inquest into the mans death, but how he died is not yet certain. The Westminster coroner, Dr. Paul Knapman, said that the body of the missing intelligence officer, Gareth Williams, 30, above, was discovered in an advanced state of decay on Aug. 23. A pathologist found that Mr. Williams had not been stabbed or shot, and that there were no obvious signs of strangulation, said a spokeswoman for the Westminster Coroners Court. A post-mortem exam last week failed to establish a conclusive cause of death. The inquest has been adjourned until next Wednesday.

Negotiations were continuing on the governments offer to give more than a million public employees pay raises of 7.5 percent, double the inflation rate.

title: The Peanut Solution
description: Like most tales of great invention, the story of Plumpynut begins with a eureka moment, in this case involving a French doctor and a jar of Nutella, and proceeds through the stages of rejection, acceptance, evangelization and mass production. The product may not look like much  a little foil packet filled with a soft, sticky substance  but its advocates are prone to use the language of magic and wonders. What is Plumpynut? Sound it out, and you get the idea: its an edible paste made of peanuts, packed with calories and vitamins, that is specially formulated to renourish starving children. Since its widespread introduction five years ago, it has been credited with significantly lowering mortality rates during famines in Africa. Children on a Plumpynut regimen add pounds rapidly, often going from a near-death state to relative health in a month. In the world of humanitarian aid, where progress is usually measured in subtle increments of misery, the new product offers a rare satisfaction: swift, visible, fantastic efficacy.

title: Upper Cuts
description: Whenever it feels like the sky is falling on mens fashion, its warming to remember that one of Beau Brummells London tailors, Meyer & Mortimer, is still dressing the hyper-fastidious. This fun fact is one of hundreds in Bespoke: The Mens Style of Savile Row (Rizzoli), a new tome as handsome as its subject. Up front, the author James Sherwood clears up any uncertainty fogging the much-abused term: To earn the label bespoke a garment must be measured, cut and sewn by hand; the pattern must also be hand-cut. When the pioneers of custom British tailoring took their first orders in the early 1800s, they were for clothes inspired by the honest wardrobe of the English country gentleman. In 1929 Hawkes & Co. did the unthinkable by introducing immediate wear to Savile Row, and by 1948, sales of the firms off-the-peg suits surpassed those of bespoke. Its a trend that has never been reversed, though not for want of trying. In the 90s, Richard Anderson, Ozwald Boateng and Richard James opened shops, forming what Sherwood tags The New Establishment. And Edward Sexton, Spencer Hart and Timothy Everest are currently powering a Row Renaissance. Bespoke is especially good on the crazy language peculiar to the Row. Who knew that a tab is a fussy customer, or a crushed beetle a badly made buttonhole?

Buoyed by the resilience of tech companies, the valleys dozen or so cities, which include Mountain View and Palo Alto, have managed to sidestep the recession, continuing their shift from corporate strip malls to urban hubs. The valley now buzzes with cultural spaces, lively restaurants and a hyper-educated workforce that has no problem keeping up.

Despite their different career paths, both men are visual thinkers and realized that the tools and methods of their respective trades could be used to expand each others worlds. Their joint effort began a few years ago, when Maloof was working on a project involving a meteor crater and recognized that the digital technology that Situs designers use to visualize data could be used to map the crater.

Six years later Zhang Yimou, a star of Chinas rising fifth generation of filmmakers, contributed his own variation on the Postman theme with Ju Dou, his second feature as sole director. And now, for no good reason but with reasonably happy (which is to say grisly) results, Mr. Zhang has honored the unlikely affinity between himself and the Coens with a faithful remake of their first movie, a replica of Blood Simple called (in America) A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop.

Im way too shy to do that, says the 50-year-old, an ex-model himself. The Arkansas native came to New York in the 1980s to pursue painting but gave it up after the bohemian thing got boring. I was just tired of being poor, he says. Rowland went on to create two agencies  Women, in1988, and Supreme, in2000. Both were both known for dispensing with glam in favor of a more eclectic look. At Supreme, the girls looked like Smith students  a little intellectual, a little odd looking, he says.

One hundred and thirty million people, moving between work and family, stoking the engines that drive the machinery of worldwide consumer capitalism. What does that look like? What does it mean?

description: Timex took a trip back to the future to honor its 156-year history of timekeeping by introducing a small collection of watches with inspiration coming straight from its own archives. By recreating period design details like color, typeface and finish, Timex is paying homage to classic watch faces of the 20th century. The 1970s style features that serpentine, expandable, flexible metal watchband that was all the rage. The revolutionary band of interlocking links allows it to be stretched and slid over the hand, providing for one-size-fits-all functionality. Timex is taking a trip back in time to prove its credo that it does indeed take a licking and keep on ticking.

title: T. I. Is Arrested
description: Months after his release from a federal prison the rapper T. I., below, was arrested Wednesday night with his wife in Los Angeles on drug charges, The Associated Press reported. T. I., whose given name is Clifford Harris, was pulled over at a traffic stop in West Hollywood and arrested on charges of possession of a controlled substance. A representative for the Los Angeles sheriffs department told The A.P., Deputies smelled a strong odor of marijuana emitting from the vehicle, adding that a narcotics investigation ensued resulting in the arrest of T. I. and his wife, Tameka Cottle. They were arrested on suspicion of possessing methamphetamines, a sheriffs deputy told The A.P., and released from jail at about 4 a.m. Thursday after each posting $10,000 bail. T. I., who is in the action movie Takers, remains on probation after pleading guilty to federal weapons charges stemming from a 2007 sting operation in which he was caught receiving three machine guns and two silencers that had been bought for him. After his guilty plea T. I. appeared on an MTV reality series, T. I.s Road to Redemption, in which he warned teenagers about the dangers of guns and violence. He was released from an Arkansas prison in December and from a halfway house in March. Under the terms of his release, he was ordered not to commit another federal, state or local crime and not to illegally possess a controlled substance.

title: From Mickey To Murakami In Macys Parade
description: If familiar figures like Kermit the Frog and SpongeBob SquarePants are simply too jejune for you, the organizers of Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade have added two new entrants to their 2010 lineup. Kaikai and Kiki, above, two weirdly cute (or is that cutely weird?) characters created by Takashi Murakami, right, the Japanese Pop artist, are being turned into larger-than-life balloons that will mix it up with the traditional cartoon stars and corporate trademarks for the parades 84th annual run on Nov. 25, its producers said on Thursday. The balloon likenesses of Mr. Murakamis characters will be about 40 feet long when uninflated, and about three stories tall when filled with helium. Mr. Murakami is to be the fourth contemporary artist in recent years to have his work translated to the parade-balloon medium, after Tom Otterness (whose upside-down Humpty Dumpty made its Macys debut in 2005), Jeff Koons (whose inflatable bunny came next, in 2006) and Keith Haring (whose estate contributed to a figure-with-heart balloon in 2008). Asked in a telephone interview if Mr. Murakamis characters might be a bit unsettling for younger viewers, Robin Hall, the parades executive producer said: Fangs are very hot right now, if youve missed this trend. This is an excellent year for Murakami. And these balloons are adorable. They have a charm to them.

title: Talent On Top

According to Nielsens estimates, 10.3 million viewers watched the 9 p.m. elimination episode on NBC, easily making it the most watched show of the night. In the 8 p.m. hour, NBCs Minute to Win It (6.1 million) lagged well behind CBSs Big Brother, which led the time slot with 7.7 million viewers and helped propel CBS into second place over all. ABC was third with its three-hour broadcast of the CMA Music Festival: Countrys Night to Rock (6 million) while Fox finished in fourth place with MasterChef from 8 to 10 (4.7 million).

title: N.E.A. Grants To Theaters

The five grants, provided by the endowments New Play Development Program, will go to About Face Theater in Chicago for Tanya Sarachos Albert Cashier Project; Childrens Theater Company in Minneapolis for Larissa FastHorses Fancy Dancer; Cornerstone Theater Company in Los Angeles for Tom Jacobsons West Hollywood Musical; the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, N.J., for Emily Manns Hoodwinked; and Woolly Mammoth Theater Company in Washington for Danai Guriras Zimbabwe Project. The grants are intended to support American nonprofit theaters working with playwrights on scripts that are in draft stage and show artistic promise. The money is usually used to support readings and workshops for the new plays, research, and expenses incurred in assisting the playwright.

title: Release For Rival To Inconvenient Truth

On Wednesday the distributor Roadside Attractions said that it had acquired Ondi Timoners documentary Cool It, about the Danish statistician and writer Bjorn Lomborg, above, for release in the United States, just as the film is about to make its world premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival. Mr. Lomborg, author of the best-selling book The Skeptical Environmentalist: Measuring the Real State of the World, published in Denmark in 1998, and the follow-up, Cool It: The Skeptical Environmentalists Guide to Global Warming (2007), has argued against what he believes are extreme and alarmist scenarios presented by other environmentalists, and has urged scientists and governments to pursue practical solutions for global warming using the limited resources at their disposal. Roadside Attractions said the film would be released in the fall.

title: Freedom Trains
description: In the winter of 1916, as Americans read the news of unimaginable slaughter in a distant yet rapidly spreading European war, it was easy to overlook stories like the one in The Chicago Defender reporting that several black families in Selma, Ala., had left the South. A popular African-American weekly, The Defender would publish dozens of such stories in the coming years, heralding the good jobs and friendly neighbors that awaited these migrants in Chicago, even printing train schedules to point the way north. Smuggled into Southern railroad depots by Pullman porters, dropped off by barnstorming black athletes and entertainers, The Defender emerged as both cheerleader and chronicler of an exodus that would lead about six million African-Americans to abandon the states of the Old Confederacy between 1915 and 1970. If all of their dream does not come true, it confidently predicted, enough will come to pass to justify their actions.

Yet its investors displayed neither much concern about overpaying nor relief about the deals being dropped. After a decade of scandals, missed opportunities and dismal performance, they may have stopped caring.

title: Pakistan: Lahore Mourns Victims of Bombings
description: With the police on high alert, hundreds of people attended funeral prayers in the eastern city of Lahore on Thursday for the victims of suicide bombers a day earlier. The authorities raised the death toll in the attacks to 31 from around 25 and said more than 280 had been wounded. Zulfiqar Hameed, chief of the Lahore police investigation unit, said no arrests had been made. The explosions on Wednesday singled out Shiite Muslims and set off violent clashes between local police officers and protesters infuriated by the attacks.

description: Vance Bourjaily, a novelist whose literary career, like those of Norman Mailer and James Jones, emerged out of World War II and whose ambitious novels explored American themes for decades afterward, died on Tuesday in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 87.

title: Cammie King, Scarlett and Rhetts Girl, Dies at 76
description: Cammie King, who as a cherubic little girl played the daughter of Scarlett OHara and Rhett Butler in Gone With the Wind, then enjoyed something of a fan following at film festivals, died on Wednesday at her home in Fort Bragg, Calif. She was 76.

Bernanke, who told Congress in 2007 that the subprime mortgage crisis was likely to be contained, said Thursday that he had failed to recognize flaws in the financial system that amplified the housing downturn and led to an economic disaster, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: BP Wary of  Limits on Drilling Imperil Oil Spill Payouts
description: BP is warning Congress that if lawmakers pass legislation that bars the company from getting new offshore drilling permits, it may not have the money to pay for all the damages caused by its oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, Clifford Krauss and John M. Broder report in The New York Times.

title: Harrisburg Expects to Miss a Bond Payment
description: The capital of Pennsylvania has taken a step closer to a possible bankruptcy declaration, warning this week that it was not going to make a scheduled payment of $3.3 million on its general obligation bonds because it did not have the money, Mary Williams Walsh writes in The New York Times.

title: Heavy in Dollars, China Warns of Depreciation
description: China on Friday offered a rare glimpse into its foreign exchange reserves, confirming that they are overwhelmingly allocated in dollars, while a central banker said the mountain of cash could face depreciation risks, Reuters reports.

description: Hes late. He calls to explain. A mix-up, he says, and then, I read all your stories. Pause. You. Are. A. Grrreat. Writer. Another pause. Whats your name? I tell him. He says, Of course it is. I ask what his name is. MY NAME? I. Am. William. Shatner!

description: BankSimple, the not-quite-a-bank provider of front-end services for a number of treasury-focused banks, raised $2.9 million in its first round of funding. First Round Capital, IA Ventures and Village Ventures led the round, VentureBeat reported.

description: The private equity backers of the oil firm Kosmos Energy are considering taking it public in either Britain or United States, which could value the company at around $5 billion, The Financial Times reported.

description: The Oval Office was just redecorated with new furniture, wallpaper and accessories, including a rug woven with quotations. What do you think of the rooms new look? How would you have chosen to decorate it? What quotes do you think should be woven into the rug?

description: Makhteshim Agan Industries of Israel ended talks to acquire a United States firm, Albaugh, for about $1 billion, blaming findings during due diligence, sending its shares lower, Reuters reported.

description: British companies are beating the world in the bond market as investors bet Prime Minister David Camerons efforts to tame the budget deficit will preserve the Britains top credit rating, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Genzymes Termeer Could Sell Company
description: Henri Termeer, a biotech industry pioneer and chief executive officer at Genzyme, is on the verge of losing control of the company he transformed from a start-up in 1983 into a cutting-edge drug maker with $4.5 billion in annual sales, Bloomberg News reported.

description: Abbott Laboratories has called a halt to the sale of its European flu-vaccine unit because of a dissapointing run of initial bids, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: In Istanbul, 8,000 Years of History
description: From the moment you enter the Legendary Istanbul exhibition at the Sakip Sabanci Museum, you are plunged into a dark and moody prehistoric forest, and, sitting on a tree stump, you watch as the Sea of Marmara forms.

description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

description: Todays idea: U.F.O.s slowed down in the popular imagination because those reporting them became less fascinated with speed as it became less alien to them, an article says.

title: Tip of the Week: Where Is That Attachment?
description: If you are mystified over where a spreadsheet or document is  was it an attachment to Gmail or a Google Doc? Gmail Labs has a time-saving solution called Apps Search. To turn it on, log in to your Gmail account on the Web, click the green Labs icon (or click Settings and then the Labs link). Scroll down to Apps Search and click the button next to Enable the features. Then click on the Save Changes button. The search box in the Gmail window now says Search Mail and Docs  and lets you look in both places at once for that elusive file.

description: For the first time since 2005, the Small Business Administration reports that the share of federal contracts going to small business increased over the previous year. But the federal government still fell short of its small-business contracting goals, and longstanding criticisms about how the government keeps score continue to cast doubt on the agencys report card.

description: In an intimate rooftop performance overlooking the Lower East Side, the notorious Justin Bond delivered a string of songs  both originals and covers  accompanied on guitar by the beautiful Nathan Carrera, who wore a dress, false eyelashes and no shoes. The evening came courtesy of the artist Matthu Placek, who in the off hours hosts a monthly salon. The tiny roof lounge brought the audience close enough to feel Bonds breath as he delivered powerful messages about acceptance and the absurdity of discrimination.

title: Another Lengthy Gridlock in China

More than 100 regional police officers manned the road, called the Jingzang Highway, in an effort to break the 75-mile, 10,000-vehicle gridlock, the state broadcaster CCTV reported Thursday.

title: Growth in Jobs Beats Estimates, Easing Concerns

title: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Throwing the Book at Them
description: The second volume of Chis Sweet Home, written and illustrated by Kanata Konami, lands at No. 6 on the manga list this week. It tells the story of a kitten named Chi who finds herself separated from her family of feral cats. Chi is taken in by the family of a young boy named Yohei, but not without risk: Their lease does not allow pets and Chis feral tendencies are no pleasure to be around either.

title: Paradoxes Of Deleveraging And Releveraging
description: Whenever the issue of fiscal stimulus comes up, you can count on someone chiming in to say, Only a moron could believe that the answer to a problem created by too much debt is to create even more debt. It sounds plausible  but it misses the key point: theres a fallacy of composition here. When everyone tries to pay off debt at the same time, the result is contraction and deflation, which ends up making the debt problem worse even if nominal debt falls. On the other hand, a strong fiscal stimulus, by expanding the economy and creating moderate inflation, can actually help resolve debt problems.

description: A few weeks ago, while working as a freelancer at a Manhattan advertising and marketing firm  in a job that was somewhat similar to my old job on the staff at a marketing firm in Fort Lee, N.J.  I got to wondering why so many people were still there after 8 p.m., and why there was a settled air of monotony suggesting that this was the way it was and always would be.

title: The Slog
description: Its easy to get confused by month-month fluctuations in the jobs report. But the bigger picture of the economys performance over the three years is starting to look very consistent. Todays jobs report confirms that. We dont seem to be in a double-dip recession. We do seem to be in a long slog.

description: As a weakened Hurricane Earl moves north, the National Hurricane Center said in its latest advisory, released at 8 a.m. Friday, that weather conditions should improve in the Outer Banks region of North Carolina later this morning.

title: Inside the List
description: GRAND TOUR: This weeks hardcover fiction list offers plenty of armchair travel to exotic locales, from Tudor England (The Red Queen) and Renaissance Siena (Juliet) to the postapocalyptic Four Lands (Bearers of the Black Staff) and post-James Patterson Stockholm (The Postcard Killers). But for sheer geopolitical adventure and scenery  not to mention attack dogs and intestinal parasites  nothing can match the real-life 10th parallel, chronicled by Eliza Griswold in her nuanced account of conflict between Christians and Muslims in a swath of the globe that runs from West Africa to the Philippines. (It enters at No. 14 on the nonfiction list.)

title: Forty Years of the 4077th: Elliott Gould on the Anniversary of MASH
description: Attention, attention: Saturday nights movies at the Walter Reade Theater will include a special showing of MASH, the 1970 Robert Altman comedy that used the Korean War as a vehicle to satirize the Vietnam War. This screening, celebrating the 75th anniversary of the Twentieth Century Fox studio and the 40th anniversary of MASH, and presented by Twentieth Century Fox Home Entertainment and the Film Society of Lincoln Center, will feature a question-and-answer session with the films stars Elliott Gould (who played Trapper John McIntyre), Sally Kellerman (Margaret Houlihan, a k a Hot Lips) and Tom Skerritt (Duke Forrest), as well as Mr. Altmans widow, Kathryn Reed Altman.

title: The End of Tenure?
description: In tough economic times, its easy to gin up anger against elites. The bashing of bankers is already so robust that the economist William Easterly has compared it, with perhaps a touch of hyperbole, to genocidal racism. But in recent months, a more unlikely privileged group has found itself in the cross hairs: tenured professors.

title: My Flesh Is Your Canvas
description: V. I. Warshawski, the hard-headed sleuth in Sara Paretskys series of crime novels, isnt afraid of a little violence, so you can count on her to get into a few good brawls in BODY WORK (Putnam, $26.95). Just dont expect this pugnacious Chicago private eye, who proudly refers to herself as a street fighter, to walk away from any display of violence, including her own, without examining its root causes.

title: Why Are Wages Rising?
description: Average hourly pay for all workers had another nice increase in August. It rose 6 cents, to $22.56, after having risen 5 cents in July. Job growth may have tailed off in recent months, but wage growth for people with jobs has picked up:

title: The Meaning of Man Up
description: The New York Mets lost their closer Francisco Rodriguez, a k a K-Rod, to season-ending surgery on a torn thumb ligament last month. But really the Mets lost him to two simple words: man up. According to The New York Daily News, thats what Carlos Pea, the father of Rodriguezs girlfriend, told him outside the Mets clubhouse, inciting an altercation that led to K-Rod busting his thumb and getting arrested on third-degree-assault charges for good measure.

title: Imagining the Prophet
description: As a leader of alternative medicine who was born in India and raised as a Hindu before opening a wellness center in California, what led you to write your new book, Muhammad, a fictionalized biography of the Muslim prophet?  I had previously written Jesus, and I grew up in an environment where the kids in my school were either Muslim or Jewish or Zoroastrian. New Delhi has a very eclectic mix. There wasnt any animosity. Having said that, my grandparents were prejudiced and Islamophobic. If a Muslims shadow crossedmy grandmothers body  she lived with us  she would go and take a shower.

title: The Back Story
description: Ask anybody about the most meaningful object he owns, and youre sure to get a story  this old trunk belonged to Grandpa, we bought that tacky coffee mug on our honeymoon, and so on. The relationship between the possessions we value and the narratives behind them is unmistakable. Current technologies of connection, and enterprises that take advantage of them, surface this idea in new ways  but they also suggest the many different kinds of stories, information and data that objects can, or will, tell us.

title: App Smart Extra: Create Grocery Lists
description: Thursdays App Smart column gives props to two useful shopping apps, Key Ring and Cardstar, which will store your grocery coupons on the phone and spare you from carrying around loyalty cards for your favorite retailers.

title: Good Fortune, Misfortune
description: I took my teenage daughter and one of her friends, whose father died last year, to my employers annual outing, a Mets game and raffle. The grand prize was a 47-inch TV. Coincidentally, the friend mentioned that her family needed a new TV. As fate had it, she held the winning ticket. She was thrilled. After the game, we took her and the TV to her house. Her mother was delighted but soon phoned to say that since I paid for the tickets, the TV is mine. Is it? STUART ILKOWITZ, LIVINGSTON, N.J.

title: An Adopted Boy Considers His Origins
description: Jonah, our youngest, spent the day in the water again. At 5 hes already an exquisite swimmer, diving for coins our Provincetown neighbors throw into the tide for him to fetch. Now were lying in his bed together waiting for him to fall asleep, and hes thumping my stomach like its a beach ball.

title: A Labor Day Arrangement
description: If youre heading to a Labor Day party this weekend, dont show up empty-handed. Better yet, bring something handmade. Heres an easy, impressive D.I.Y. floral arrangement.

title: Letter: What Is It About 20-Somethings?
description: As I read Robin Marantz Henigs discussion of 20-somethings, I was struck by the sense that the new life stage she was ascribing to this generation could actually be something that adults of all ages experience today: feeling unstable, struggling with ferocious competition for jobs, wondering if our relationships and finances can go the distance. I consider it progress that every young person doesnt feel the need to complete school, leave home, marry and have a child by a certain deadline. There is no one size fits all adulthood. Lets not forget it was the boomers who created the 50 percent divorce rate, who initiated the corporate-casual workplace, who made 60 the new 40. Todays 20-somethings just want what we all want: the opportunity to live life on our own terms and in our own time frames.

title: Screen Test | William Shatner
description: The actor on laughter, Star Trek and getting older.

title: Coordinating Help for a Neighbor in Need
description: Weve all had this experience, havent we? A neighbor or friend is struggling through an illness or a family emergency, so we offer our sympathy and help.
