description: A committee convened by the InterAcademy Council, the association of the worlds leading national science academies, delivered a long to-do list to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on Monday, including steps ranging from limiting the term and policy recommendations of its leadership to fostering more transparency in its machinations and being more careful to describe the science determining the strength, or weakness, of particular conclusions.

title: Science Fiction Chronicle
description: REDEMPTION IN INDIGO  By Karen Lord.  Small Beer Press, paper, $16.

title: Brendan Fraser to Make Broadway Debut in Elling
description: If Daniel Craig could leave the James Bond franchise behind to make his Broadway debut last fall in A Steady Rain, Brendan Fraser certainly can hold off on another installment of The Mummy to make his. Mr. Fraser will appear on Broadway in November in the new comedy Elling, based on the Norwegian novels by Ingvar Ambjrnsen.

title: Up Front: Ander Monson
description: No one medium can contain Ander Monson. Luckily, we live in an age when no one medium needs to.

title: Living in Your Head
description: The conceit of Charles Yus new meta-science-fictional novel, How to Live Safely in a Science Fictional Universe, is a touch wacky. Yus protagonist, a time machine repairman also named Charles Yu, has lived the past decade of his life boxed up in a tiny TM-31 Recreational Time Travel Device. His two companions are TAMMY, the love interest (of sorts), a neurotic, depressed, sexy piece of software, and Ed, a nonexistent yet ontologically valid dog. You might be forgiven for thinking that this setup smells strongly of vintage Douglas Adams. It does. Like Adams, Yu is very funny, usually proportional to the wildness of his inventions, but Yus sound and fury conceal (and construct) this novels dense, tragic, all-too-human heart.

title: With a Nod to His Past, Plant Moves On Again
description: LATE last year, in a Nashville recording studio, Robert Plant, the former Led Zeppelin frontman, had a revelation. He was working on a new solo record, a project he began after scrapping plans for a sequel to Raising Sand, his 2007 album of duets with the country singer Alison Krauss that sold 2.5 million copies worldwide.

title: Never Say Never: Swans Return
description: I SAW just a little bit of a Swans show in 1983, in their early days, during their period of slow-but-alert, theater-of-cruelty music. If I remember right, I had come to CBGB to hear Heart Attack, the fastest punk band I knew, and after that the tempos plunged. Sonic Youth played next: lots of strange tunings, innocently curious. Then came Swans, with violent songs that sounded as if they were barely moving.

title: Hey, Dad, Get With the (3-D) Program
description: THIS is going to be sweet. Soon, very soon, those unappreciative little rotters who 15 years ago were expressing contempt for the television shows that were so important to their parents will be getting the same dissing from their own kids. Thats right, you 20-somethings; youre about to be inducted into the Dinosaur Club.

title: Good Day for Paul Hogan: Crocodile Dundee Star Can Return to U.S.
description: Break out the Vegemite, crank up the Men at Work, and prepare to celebrate the Australian cultural influences of the 1980s: Paul Hogan is a free man. Mr. Hogan, the Australian-born star of the Crocodile Dundee movies, has been granted permission to return to his home in the United States after reaching a deal with Australian tax officials, The Associated Press reported.

title: A Complete Look at a Complex Character
description: THINKING back to the impression Detective Chief Inspector Jane Tennison made when the British crime drama Prime Suspect first reached America in 1992, its easy to focus on strength: the hard set of her jaw as she took on the sexism and cronyism of a London police force that, in real life, had only four female detectives out of a total of about 500 at the time.

title: The Magnificent Seven
description: 1. Whos afraid of Katie Eary? The buzzy London designer, inspired by Irvine Welshs dark, hallucinatory 1995 novel, Marabou Stork Nightmares, has created enormous reptile-print coats, hats with studs resembling teeth and other frightful creations that might haunt your sleep. Go to katieeary.co.uk.

title: Analysis: How Capra Beat Rezai
description: Colette Lewis, over at ZooTennis covering the juniors, has followed the rise of Wednesdays surprise winner, Beatrice Capra, and had some insight into the match:

title: The Early Word: 9.6 Percent
description: The unemployment rate rose slightly in August to 9.6 percent, though the private sector did add more jobs than had been forecast.

title: A Steel Symphony, Pounded Out in Brooklyn
description: As the sun sets over a string of tire repair and auto body shops in Brooklyn, the first jaunty notes of a jangly symphony ring out. The roar of Atlantic Avenue subsides as the music floods these ragged blocks, filling the grease-soaked garages with a breath of island air.

title: Editors Choice
description: FREEDOM,  by Jonathan Franzen (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) Like Franzens previous novel, The Corrections, this is a masterly portrait of a nuclear family in turmoil, with a majestic sweep that gathers every sociocultural morsel of our shared millennial life.

title: Obama to Unveil Plans to Shore Up Economy
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, calling the latest jobs report positive news, said Friday that he planned to unveil a package of ideas next week to shore up the flagging economy, and does not regret his administrations decision to declare this season the recovery summer.

title: To Put Blacks in Pipeline, Possess the Pipeline
description: Richard Williams strolled across the grounds of the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center on Wednesday afternoon. Ever the recognizable figure, he was greeted by men and women, young and old. Some just wanted to say hello, others asked to have their picture taken with him, and others simply wanted to offer his daughters good luck.

title: Paperback Row
description: OPEN: An Autobiography,  by Andre Agassi (Vintage, $15.95.) I hate tennis, hate it with all my heart, and still I keep playing . . . because I have no choice. Pushed by his ferocious father, 7-year-old Andre is forcing himself through another practice. Open, written with J. R. Moehringer, author of The Tender Bar, is one of the most passionately anti-sports books ever written by a superstar athlete  bracingly devoid of triumphalist homily and star-spangled gratitude, Sam Tanenhaus said in the Book Review. The book, he added, is not just a first-rate sports memoir but a genuine bildungsroman, darkly funny yet also anguished and soulful. Agassi and his wife, Steffi Graf, chose not to build a tennis court behind their home.

title: Food Safety Tips for the Budget-Conscious
description: EGGS, lettuce, peanuts, spinach. It seems as if every time we turn around there is another outbreak of a scary foodborne illness.

title: Simian Says
description: Early in Sara Gruens new novel, Ape House, one of the characters gives a mini-lesson on American Sign Language, which, she instructs, is not simply signed English  its a unique language, with a unique syntax. Instead of saying, Yesterday I ate cherries, for example, this character explains that in A.S.L. you might sign, Day-past eat cherries me.

title: Readers Questions on Deep-Ocean Biology
description: After a smooth cruise into San Diego, where Atlantis would be embarking on her next expedition, the science teams went their separate ways, cars brimming with cooler-packed samples. Weve had a couple of weeks to sort things out (a process which involved many brushes with frostbite, as samples were carefully arranged in freezers set at minus 80 degrees Celsius), and we are continuing to design and conduct experiments to tease out the secrets of the Hydrate Ridge ecosystem.

title: For G.M., Four Cylinders May Soon Be Enough
description: With the engine-downsizing revolution sweeping the world, automakers are ruthlessly lopping cylinders from their once-royal V-8s and V-6s. As The Times reported on Aug. 13, small, sophisticated 4-cylinder engines are showing up in the oddest places; in luxury sedans and in once-profligate S.U.V.s, like the redesigned 2011 Ford Explorer

title: Care During Crisis
description: After the floodwaters of Katrina receded, an investigation took place to determine whether health care workers had hastened the deaths of some patients.

title: Roethlisbergers Suspension Reduced to 4 Games
description: Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger will serve a four-game suspension for behavior that led to sexual assault allegations after a March encounter with a college student at a Georgia nightclub last spring.

title: Bringing It All Back Home
description: Whoever it was in 1969 who named the very first Bob Dylan bootleg album Great White Wonder may have had a mischievous streak. There are any number of ways you can interpret the title  most boringly, the cover was blank, like the Beatles White Album  but I like to see a sly allusion to Moby-Dick. In the seven years since the release of his first commercial record, Dylan had become the white whale of 20th-century popular song, a wild, unconquerable and often baffling force of musical nature who drove fans and critics Ahab-mad in their efforts to spear him, lash him to the hull and render him merely comprehensible.

title: The Grand Slam Age Game
description: There was a time when Venus Williams could practice all day, stopping only after she hit the 550 balls that her father threw her from a shopping cart. Last one! she would tell him, excited to have reached her goal.

title: 11 Ways to Use Our Blog This School Year
description: Teachers and administrators often ask us if we have a handout they can give to their colleagues to tell them about The Learning Network.

title: Stormy Weather
description: The narrator of Giles Fodens new novel is a retired meteorologist and Cambridge don looking back on the planning for the invasion of Normandy, when he and a team of scientists struggled to produce the reliable forecast required to choose a favorable D-Day. Henry Meadows is composing this blotted memoir of my wartime days in 1980 aboard a vast, surreal vessel he has helped construct: a sort of navigable iceberg complete with fitness center, library and cinema, not to mention a mosque for the Baluchi workers and the Saudi Arabian sheik who has commissioned the ship as a way of delivering fresh water to the desert. The bizarre comedy of this prologue is nicely set off by the melancholy Meadowss dry, professorial delivery.

title: Vietnam Raids Restaurants Selling Exotic Meats
description: Vietnamese forestry officials seized hundreds of pounds of illegal wildlife fromrestaurants in a popular tourist province this week, in what was one of the countrys largest such enforcement actions.

title: Creating a Safer Kitchen
description: Food scares, like the latest salmonella outbreak and egg recall, often trigger a rethinking in cooking and shopping habits. In todays Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad explores the costs and options consumers face on their quest for germ-free kitchens.

title: Worlds in Collision
description: India, we are reminded ad infinitum, is a land of contradictions. Immense wealth rubs shoulders with unimaginable poverty; soaring modernity with crude tradition; the worlds largest democracy with its most stifling caste system.

title: Niger Responds to Acute Malnutrition
description: Shawn Baker is the regional director for Africa of Helen Keller International. He has spent 25 years living and working in Africa, including nine years in Niger.

title: We Three Things | In My Cups
description: After years of working exclusively in two dimensions, I found myself drawn to the mysterious, nowhere-to-hide realm of the third. My collection of McCoy vases, Poole pottery catalogs and Omega Workshop books was growing out of control, so I thought Id drag the lake of my compulsions and get some mud under my fingernails. Ive taken up pottery. It has only resulted in my becoming even more obsessed, and I see perfect pulling everywhere I look.

title: Marilyn Monroe And The Slump
description: Aha: I forgot that after reading this: Amid Downturn, Divorce and Infidelity Decrease

title: Mariner and the MAC Question
description: Mariner Energy cannot seem to get a break.

title: Airlines Waive Fees for Flights Affected by Hurricane Earl
description: Several major airlines are waiving change fees  and in some cases, price differences  for flights that are affected by Hurricane Earl, through Sept. 4. This morning, the Lede blog posted a graphic and a complete list, of the storm warnings and watches in effect on Friday morning. Here are the changes weve found. If you know of others, please let us know in the comments section below. As the weather progresses, check specific airline Web sites for changes.

title: No. 1 Sleuth
description: Lord Peter Wimsey, Hercule Poirot, Philo Vance, many another  they are like a drooping bouquet of exotically named flowers, withering away in one of subliteratures deserted mansions. Once, during the 20th centurys interwar years, the first great age of detective fiction, they were the genres stars, often equipped with comical verbal tics or curious sideline interests, but always abiding by the ironbound conventions of classic crime fiction. Their work demanded more ratiocination than roughhouse and, in the end, a gathering of all the murder mysterys many suspects in the country house library, where the gentlemanly investigator reveals the killers always surprising identity.

title: Jennifer Shalant and Luke Groskin
description: THE rock hyrax, a relative of the elephant that resembles an obese gerbil, is not likely to inspire romance. But for Luke Groskin and Jennifer Shalant, who work at the Bronx Zoo, the small creature played a part in starting their relationship.

title: How to Pep Up a Cheap PC
description: About a year ago I bought a cheap Dell: a $600 desktop packaged with a 20-inch LCD screen. Budget computers like this typically dont have a discrete graphics card, which is necessary for advanced graphics like 3-D gaming. My Dell came with AMD HD 4200 integrated graphics  and an open PCI Express (PCIe) slot for a future upgrade to a discrete graphics card.

title: Weekend Competition: The Dog Ate My Excuse
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to submit excuses they have heard, or given, that seem too outlandish to be true (perhaps because they are).

title: Hannibal Rising
description: Other battles are perhaps just as famous  Thermopylae, Waterloo, Gettysburg  but the aura of Cannae, where Hannibal obliterated the largest army the Roman Republic had ever put into the field, is unmatched. The battle is unparalleled for its carnage, with more men from a single army killed on that one day, Aug. 2, 216 B.C., than on any other day on any other European battlefield: something like 50,000 Romans died, two and a half times the number of British soldiers who fell on the first day of the Somme.

title: A Child Psychiatrist Responds
description: Dr. Mary Margaret Gleason, a child psychiatrist at Tulane University, took questions from readers on our Prescriptions blog on Thursday, as part of a discussion concerning an article published in The New York Times about a young boys misdiagnosis and medications.Dr. Gleason had treated the young boy, Kyle Warren, and works at an early treatment center for children with mental health issues and their families. (Watch a related video on Kyle, his family and Dr. Gleasons take on the issue.)

title: Sunday Shopping Linked With Less Happiness
description: How do you spend your Sunday? For many, this traditional day of rest and churchgoing has become a day to shop, but it may be taking a toll on happiness.

title: Kaufman & Hart Delayed
description: Cross the revival of You Cant Take It With You off the list of Broadway shows for this fall. The producer Elizabeth I. McCann, who had announced she would mount the show in November, said on Thursday she was now aiming for a spring opening for this 1936 comedy by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart about the loopy Sycamore family. The production was supposed to have a pre-Broadway run at the Huntington Theater Company in Boston this month, but that was canceled in the spring, a Huntington spokeswoman said, because Ms. McCann and her producing partners were not able to complete the deal with enough lead time for the theater. With the Huntington run off, Ms. McCann said in an interview, her director on the production, Anna D. Shapiro, a Tony Award winner for August: Osage County, took on other projects that would keep her busy through the fall.

title: Lost Tribe
description: I must have terrible luck. Im an American Jew who, from time to time, has  like the characters in Joan Leegants Wherever You Go  found my way to Israel. But unlike her characters, Ive never managed to stumble upon small sculpture galleries nestled behind lemon trees. The muezzins havent sounded for me at perfect poetic moments. And, though Ive been approached by good-looking Israeli men with motorcycles, none seemed motivated by a burning desire to talk politics.

title: TimesCast | September 3, 2010
description: In today's Timescast, a better than expected jobs report, dancing with the dead in Madagascar and a new telecommunications robot.

title: Open Mike: Ladies and Gentlemen, Start Your Engines
description: After being the second Serbian man in a row to win the last match of the day in Arthur Ashe Stadium, Novak Djokovic, who beat the German Philipp Petzschner, 7-5, 6-3, 7-6, told reporters after his second win of the tournament that he was starting to get into a rhythm.

title: Words Cannot Express
description: Is language first and foremost an artifact of culture? Or is it largely determined by human biology? This issue has been argued back and forth for a couple of centuries with no clear resolution in sight. Guy Deutschers 2005 book The Unfolding of Language placed him firmly in the pro-culture camp. Now, in his new book, Through the Language Glass, he examines some idiosyncratic aspects of particular languages that, in his opinion, cast further doubt on biologically based theories of language.

title: Turkey May Let U.S. Equipment Pass
description: ISTANBUL  Turkey, which in 2003 damaged relations with the United States by refusing to allow Americans troops to invade Iraq via its southeast border, has agreed in principle to allow the United States to move technical and logistical military equipment through the country as part of the withdrawal from Iraq.

title: Weekend Fare
description: On Saturday, a swath of 46th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues becomes the epicenter of the Brazilian Cultural Parade and Festival from 1 to 6 p.m. Besides a festive parade, bands, samba dancers and the annual pageant, there will be food, particularly typical dishes of northern Brazil, like moquecas (a seafood stew) and vatapa (peeled black-eyed peas formed into a ball and deep-fried).

title: In the Forest of Instruments, Signs of Evolution
description: At this summers classical music concerts, you could of course find a healthy array of violins, trumpets and cellos. But amid the familiar strings and brass have sprouted some odd instruments and strange adaptations of standard ones.

title: Ghost, Come Back Again
description: A boarding school in the British Isles. Reverent children huddle in a gloomy chamber, watching as one of their fellow students assays a devilishly difficult trick. The boys hand trembles. And then  success! A jet of fire, a cold and beautiful purple-blue enchantment, fills the ancient tower with an indescribable illumination.

title: From Hiding, Indonesian Defends Free Expression
description: JAKARTA  Hiding out with a two-year jail sentence hanging over his head and vigilantes vowing to track him down, the editor of Indonesias defunct version of Playboy magazine, Erwin Arnada, insists he was never in the pornography business.

title: Rodriguez to Face Pettitte in Rehab Session

title: Punkd, Iraqi-Style, at a Checkpoint
description: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi reality television program broadcast during Ramadan has been planting fake bombs in celebrities cars, having an Iraqi army checkpoint find them and terrifying the celebrities into thinking that they are headed for maximum security prison.

title: Endless War
description: In 1947, Hanson W. Baldwin, the hawkish military correspondent of this newspaper, warned that the demands of preparing America for a possible war would wrench and distort and twist the body politic and the body economic . . . prior to war. He wondered whether America could confront the Soviet Union without becoming a garrison state and destroying the very qualities and virtues and principles we originally set about to save.

title: Unhappy Days
description: Art historians tell us that photography revolutionized painting. Suddenly there was a better way of recording the physical appearance of things, and artists had to discover new purposes for brush and pigment. But for those living through the revolution, the process must have seemed more gradual. Long after the Impressionists and Cubists and Futurists, there must have been serious portraitists who continued to earn a living depicting brides on their wedding day or businessmen made good.

title: Vegetarian Recipes for Barbecue Season
description: If your Labor Day plans include a picnic or barbecue, be sure to check out Martha Rose Shulmans latest installment of Recipes for Health, which offers flavorful options for vegetarian eaters. She writes:

title: Immortal Beloved
description: Paul Valry said that a poet is like a man who carries huge weights up to a roof and drops them all at once on the head of a passer-by. With her first novel, This Must Be the Place, Kate Racculia has climbed to the highest roof and dropped the heaviest weights she could carry. Witness her ambitious premise: a 32-year-old photographer, on the brink of a nervous breakdown after the accidental death of his wife, flees his home in California for a boardinghouse in Ruby Falls, N.Y.  all because of a mysterious postcard, written 16 years earlier, found among his wifes belongings and addressed to her childhood best friend but never sent.

title: Copy That: A Response
description: In my essay for The Stone, The Third Replicator, I argued that new replicators can piggy-back on older ones. This happens when the product of one replicator becomes copying machinery for the next replicator, and so on. Memes appeared, I wrote, when humans (a product of genes) became capable of imitating, varying and selecting a new kind of information in the form of words, actions, technologies and ideas. The same thing is happening now, I argued, with a new replicator. Computers (a product of memes) are just beginning to be capable not only of copying but of copying, varying and selecting digital information. This means the birth of a new replicator  temes, or technological memes.

His blog, Carrying a Cat by the Tail, contains the daily musings of a man still learning to leave behind the organized structure of his former life and adjust to the unpredictable chaos of life with four boys and two girls (ages 7 to 17), three dogs, four cats, a turtle and a guinea pig.

The fees, often imposed by co-op boards as a percentage of either the selling price or profit, have generally been borne by sellers. But now, in a weaker real estate market, there are signs that more buyers are being asked to shoulder the burden.

title: A Day to Dance or Weep?
description: ON the morning of her 40th birthday, Dana Foote woke up to blue skies and indulgent plans: a massage, a facial and a party with friends at a favorite Italian restaurant in her Greenwich Village neighborhood. She dropped off her young son and daughter at school and was chatting on the sidewalk with a few other mothers when a plane flew overhead, noticeably loud and low. A few minutes later, a school official came out to report that a plane had crashed into the World Trade Center. And Ms. Foote arrived home just in time to see the second plane crash, from the terrace of her apartment.

description: The latest New York Times poll was based on telephone interviews conducted Aug. 27 through 31 in New York City with 892 adults, of whom 195 lived in Manhattan and said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.

title: Pictures of the Day: Havana and Elsewhere
description: Fidel Castro, the former president of Cuba, wearing his green military cap and clothing like the commandant of old, spoke before the Cuban public on Friday, warning of the threat of nuclear war. Reuters reported that Mr. Castro, 84, made his speech from the same steps of the University of Havana where 60 years ago he stirred fellow students to political action in the beginnings of the revolution that eventually put him in power in 1959. About 10,000 people, mostly students, filled the steps and nearby streets to listen to the man who led Cuba for 49 years before an intestinal illness prompted his resignation as president in 2006.

title: More on the Virgin MiFi
description: Thursday in The New York Times, I reviewed the MiFi from Virgin Mobile. Its a pocketable, portable Wi-Fi hot spot, which ensures that you and up to four other people can get online almost anywhere you go. Anywhere in Sprints 3G network, that is.

title: BMW Gives a Teasing Glance at 2012 1 Series M Coupe
description: A red fender, an alloy wheel and a front headlamp were just about all the visible hints at what lay underneath the car cover shrouding a 2012 BMW 1 Series M coupe, but it was enough for members of the BMW Car Club of America to appreciate.

title: A Song of Ancient Love, Spun in Modern Isolation
description: At home in Europe, the Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas has emerged in the last 15 years or so as one of contemporary musics most original thinkers. Trained in modernist enclaves like Darmstadt, Germany, and Ircam, the electronic music center in Paris, Mr. Haas saw past dogma and schematics to forge a fresh, uncompromising style rooted in primordial force and visionary intensity. A growing tally of notable performances and prestigious commissions attests to the visceral grip of his sound.

title: 40 Years After MASH, Gould Reflects on an Era
description: Attention, attention: Saturday nights movies at the Walter Reade Theater in Lincoln Center will include a special showing of MASH, the 1970 Robert Altman comedy that used the Korean War as a vehicle to satirize the Vietnam War. This screening, celebrating the 75th anniversary of the 20th Century Fox studio and the 40th anniversary of MASH, and presented by 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment and the Film Society of Lincoln Center, will feature a question-and-answer session with the films stars Elliott Gould (who played Trapper John McIntyre), Sally Kellerman (Margaret Houlihan, a k a Hot Lips) and Tom Skerritt (Duke Forrest), as well as Mr. Altmans widow, Kathryn Reed Altman.

title: G.O.P. Poised to Control 30 Governor Seats
description: Republicans are on track to control approximately 30 governor seats after the Nov. 2 election, according to the FiveThirtyEight gubernatorial forecasting model. And they are likely to do particularly well in the swing states of the Midwest.

title: No, Facebook Places Is Not Tracking You
description: Facebooks Places feature, which went live two weeks ago, lets Facebook users tag themselves and others as present at specific locations on Earth, such as a frozen yogurt shop or a Lady Gaga concert. The feature has incited a panic among some users who misunderstand how it works.

title: Brendan Fraser to Make His Broadway Debut
description: If Daniel Craig could leave the James Bond franchise behind to make his Broadway debut last fall in A Steady Rain, Brendan Fraser, above left, certainly can hold off on another installment of The Mummy to make his. Mr. Fraser will appear on Broadway in November in the new comedy Elling, based on the Norwegian novels by Ingvar Ambjornsen. Mr. Fraser and, above right, Denis OHare (Take Me Out, televisions True Blood) are set to play a mismatched pair of roommates navigating the shoals of friendship, work and women. Also cast are Jennifer Coolidge (the film Best in Show) as the love interest of Mr. Frasers character and Richard Easton (The Coast of Utopia, The Invention of Love) as the poetry mentor to Mr. OHares character. Doug Hughes (The Royal Family, Doubt) will direct the play, which had a popular run in London. The production is scheduled to begin preview performances at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Nov. 2 and open on Nov. 21.

title: Brother Is Biggest on a Late-Summer Night
description: CBS topped the ratings on Thursday night as an elimination episode of Big Brother and two crime-show repeats earned the largest audiences in prime time. According to Nielsens estimates, which were subject to more revision than usual because of pre-emptions of network schedules in several cities by live football broadcasts, Big Brother delivered a strong 10.6 million viewers at 8 p.m. while CBSs CSI and The Mentalist drew 9.8 million and 8.5 million viewers at 9 and 10. ABC earned a second-place finish, garnering its best ratings at 9 for a new episode of Rookie Blue (7 million) and another 6.8 million at 8 for a rerun of the game show Wipeout. At 10, ABCs NightlinePrime drew 5.2 million viewers, finishing behind not only CBSs rerun but also NBCs repeat of Law & Order: SVU (5.7 million). NBC was third, and Fox ranked fourth.

title: California Lawmakers Approve Stolen-Art Bill
description: California lawmakers have given final approval to a bill that would extend the time in which people can sue museums to recover what they believe are stolen works of art. A spokesman for Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said he had not decided whether to sign the bill, which would give people six years to file a claim instead of the current three. The legislation, approved this week, grew out of cases in which time became a factor in litigation involving art looted by the Nazis. California once had a law that set no time limit on such claims, but it was struck down as unconstitutional by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals this year. Without that law, courts have generally held that the statute of limitations governing stolen art begins when the claimant discovers the works whereabouts, or when they should have discovered it with reasonable diligence (because the work, for example, was posted on a museums Web site or featured in an exhibition). Under the new legislation, which governs claims against museums, galleries and auction houses, plaintiffs are freed from any reasonable-diligence provision and the clock does not start until plaintiffs have gathered enough information to evaluate whether they have valid claims. The California Association of Museums has described the bill as unnecessary, unfair, unconstitutional and disruptive of property rights.

title: Good Day for Paul Hogan: He Can Return to U.S.
description: Break out the Vegemite, crank up the Men at Work and prepare to celebrate the Australian cultural influences of the 1980s: Paul Hogan, above right, is a free man. Mr. Hogan, the Australian-born star of the Crocodile Dundee movies, has been granted permission to return to his home in the United States after reaching a deal with Australian tax officials, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Hogan was served with a departure prohibition order by the Australian Tax Office last month when he traveled to Sydney for his mothers funeral. He has been investigated by Australian officials who say he put film royalties in offshore tax havens, a charge he denies, and Mr. Hogan has said he cannot afford to pay even 10 percent of his tax bill, though he did not say what amount he owes. A lawyer for Mr. Hogan said in a statement Friday that after a cordial and cooperative meeting with tax officials, an agreement had been reached. While the commissioner and Mr. Hogan remain in dispute on more general taxation issues, Mr. Hogan continues to protest his innocence and denies any wrongdoing, the statement said, according to The A.P. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Woo Gets Lifetime Prize at Venice Film Festival
description: After facilitating the dispersal of countless bullet casings via the slow-motion shootouts he pioneered in his films, John Woo, below, was rewarded Friday with an estimable piece of metal that he gets to keep: the Venice Film Festival gave its Golden Lion award for lifetime achievement to Mr. Woo, the director of Hong Kong action movies like Hard-Boiled and The Killer and Hollywood blockbusters like Mission: Impossible II, The Associated Press reported. In its citation, the festival praised him as an innovator of the contemporary language of cinema, but Mr. Woo said, I wouldnt say that I have much contributed to film society, even though I made several good films. He said he hoped his future work would provide a bridge between the good things of the West and the East, so we can further our mutual knowledge and build a strong friendship. Following the historical Red Cliff, set in Chinas feudal period, Mr. Woos latest film is Reign of Assassins, a martial-arts movie showing out of competition in Venice.

title: Yank! Wont Reach Broadway This Season
description: A Broadway production of the musical Yank!, a gay love story set during World War II, has been postponed until the fall of 2011, a spokesman for the producers said. The spokesman, Rick Miramontez, said that the musicals creators wanted more time to overhaul the shows book and that the director on board, David Cromer (Our Town), had several competing projects to schedule. Mr. Miramontez said fund-raising for the production, which is expected to cost about $5 million, had not been a problem. With music by Joseph Zellnik and book and lyrics by David Zellnik, who are brothers, Yank! revolves around two young soldiers whose friendship turns into romance during the war. The musical drew mostly good reviews during an Off Broadway run at York Theater Company in the winter, when it was one of several musicals and plays in New York that featured gay love stories. Mr. Miramontez said that Mr. Cromer and Bobby Steggert (above, a Tony nominee for Ragtime), who starred in the Off Broadway production, remain committed to a Broadway production of Yank! and that Mr. Cromer was working on the show virtually every day.

description: Bargemusic is celebrating the end of the summer, as it has in recent years, with a Labor Day Festival that began on Thursday. Actually, it is not so much a festival as an installment of the barges Here and Now contemporary-music series, to be repeated four times through Sunday. But even as Bargemusics increasingly eclectic programming goes, this was an extravagant show. It began with new music for traditional Japanese instruments, touched on a handful of modern and avant-garde styles, and ended with a jazz set.

title: A Physician Examines His Novels
description: BUSSUM, the Netherlands  When Hans Keilsons first daughter was born, in 1941, he was in hiding in the Netherlands. A Jewish doctor from Germany who had published a novel in 1933 and seen it banned months later, he fled the Nazis in 1936, when he was forbidden to practice medicine. The Nazis soon occupied the Netherlands too, and the woman who became his first wife, a German Roman Catholic, pretended the childs real father was a German soldier.

Her words reduce American playhouses to an unforgiving, haiku-esque collection of phrases: Four walls. I cannot take them. Were prisoners here. The hell of the life.

title: Reading, Watching and Sleeping Sports
description: The sportscaster Warner Wolf, 72, wakes up most mornings at 4 a.m. to prepare for his air time; Sunday is an exception. He has been in the business for some 50 years, and settled in 2004 at WABC Radio, where he is now the sportscaster for Imus in the Morning; he also has his own show on Saturdays on ESPN Radio in New York. During football season, which starts this week, he spends Sundays glued to the television at his home on the Upper West Side. The rest of the year, he might go to a matinee with his wife, Sue. ALEX VADUKUL

title: Going Qubcois Before Going West
description: Marooned on a lonesome block, at the corner of 21st Street and 49th Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, the M. Wells diner serves a Qubcois take on short-order cooking: from crab and egg hash to pickled pork tongue. Opened this summer and offering, for the moment, breakfast and lunch but no dinner, it is housed in a restored chrome structure, and its menu, greasy spoon-wise, is printed on a place mat. Were sort of in the middle of everywhere and nowhere, said Sarah Obraitis, who owns the place with her husband, Hugue Dufour, meaning that customers include surprised construction workers (Buckwheat what?), iPod users and, one day last week, a couple of shaggy dudes from Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

The Venice Film festival is already underway, the Toronto International Film Festival is looming and, in the meantime, there is Telluride, which opens Friday night and lasts through the long weekend.

title: China: Another Traffic Jam on the Jingzang Highway
description: Yet another gargantuan traffic jam has gripped the freeway that links Inner Mongolias coal fields to metropolitan Beijing, possibly exceeding a blockage that drew global attention last month, Chinese media reported. More than 100 Inner Mongolian police officers staffed the road, the Jingzang Highway, in an effort to break the jam, which stretched for 75 miles and involved 10,000 vehicles, the state broadcaster CCTV said Thursday.

title: Afghanistan: Close Monitoring of Troubled Bank to Resume
description: The Afghan bank under severe threat of collapse was closed, as usual, on Friday, the national day of rest. The countrys banking system will reopen on Saturday, and observers will closely monitor the number of creditors who try to withdraw their assets from Kabul Bank in anticipation of an increasing financial crisis that Khalilullah Frozi, one of the banks two largest shareholders, has said could lead to its collapse.

title: Iran: Opposition Beginssatellite Television Channel
description: Iranian opposition activists have started a new satellite TV channel, RASA TV, from Belgium as an alternative to Irans increasingly state-controlled media. The channel is also available online. One of the channels organizers, Ebrahim Nabavi, said in an interview with Radio Free Europe that the goal was to break the governments monopoly on information and fight censorship in Iran. The opposition leader and cleric Mehdi Karroubi appeared on the channel and praised it on Thursday, just hours before pro-government crowds surrounded and attacked his house, clashing with his bodyguards and preventing him from attending the annual Jerusalem Day rally on Friday.

title: On Television, Hoping to Stand Out in a Crowded Field
description: If you watch the United States Open, the 11 oclock news, Law & Order repeats or just about anything else in the coming days, you will likely find yourself watching something else: campaign advertisements from the five Democrats running for attorney general.

title: A Coaching Philosophy Informed by Lifes Trials and Brushes With Mortality
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  The mementos in Mike Londons office provide a rough sketch of his career: photographs, souvenir footballs, the 2008 N.C.A.A. championship ring he won as the coach at Richmond, the image of the rotunda on the University of Virginia campus.

title: On an Avenue Far From Sesame Street
description: I smiled all the way through the Gateway Playhouses sweet, naughty, hilarious, absolutely first-rate production of Avenue Q. Except when poor Kate Monster was stood up at midnight on the Empire State Buildings observation deck. But then the penny that she threw down to the street hit Lucy the Slut in the head, knocking her out, and I was laughing again. (Lucy the Slut totally deserved it.)

title: 30 False Fronts Won Contracts for Blackwater
description: WASHINGTON  Blackwater Worldwide created a web of more than 30 shell companies or subsidiaries in part to obtain millions of dollars in American government contracts after the security company came under intense criticism for reckless conduct in Iraq, according to Congressional investigators and former Blackwater officials.

title: A Harmonic View of Nature, in a Cultural Tangle
description: Wouldnt it be nice if we could all live peacefully on this continent, engaging with nature in our myriad ways? History has not unfolded that way, of course. But you wouldnt know it by visiting Engaging With Nature: American and Native American Artists (A.D. 1200-2004) at the Montclair Art Museum.

description: GOLD HILL, Ore.  When four dams on the Rogue River here were scheduled for removal, environmentalists predicted many benefits: more salmon and steelhead swimming upriver to spawn; more gravel carried downriver to replenish the riverbed; more rafters bobbing along 57 miles of newly opened water.

title: Celldex Loses a Partner in Brain Tumor Treatment
description: Pfizer is pulling out of an agreement with Celldex Therapeutics to finance the development of an experimental brain tumor vaccine, Celldex said Friday. The vaccine, called rindopepimut, is no longer a strategic priority of Pfizer, which will return the rights to the therapy to Celldex on Nov. 1, Celldex said. The treatment is in the second of three stages of testing generally required to win regulatory approval. Pfizer licensed rights to the product in 2008 from Celldex for as much as $440 million, plus royalties. If approved, the brain cancer vaccine could have $450 million in peak annual sales and come on the market in 2013, Joseph Pantginis, an analyst at Roth Capital, said in May. Celldexs chief executive, Anthony Marucci, said the company would need to raise more money to pay for late-stage testing but would not need another partner. Shares of Celldex, based in Needham Mass., fell $1.25, or 26 percent, to $3.53.

title: H&R Block Dismisses Concerns About Mortgages
description: H&R Block told investors to ignore speculation that it faced a surge in costs tied to its defunct mortgage business. Concern about potential losses tied to buybacks of home loans is not based on fact, and reserves to protect the company against claims are adequate, the chief executive, Alan M. Bennett, said Thursday during a conference call about fiscal first-quarter earnings. The call included repeated queries about claims, which have totaled more than $680 million. H&R Block originated mortgages through January 2008, and some were sold to become part of mortgage-backed securities. The companys mortgage buyback liability remains within our reserved expectations, and we continue to view related reserves as adequate, the chief financial officer, Jeffrey T. Brown, said. H&R Block reported a loss from continuing operations of $127.6 million, or 40 cents a share, for the three months ending July 10, compared with $130.6 million, or 39 cents, in the same period last year. Its net loss narrowed to $130.7 million from $133.6 million. Shares of H&R Block, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., rose 73 cents, or 6 percent, to $13.30.

title: Louisiana: Blowout Preventer Is Removed
description: BP on Friday removed the damaged blowout preventer from atop the companys stricken oil well in the Gulf of Mexico in preparation for the final plugging of the well, the government said. Thad W. Allen, the retired Coast Guard admiral who leads the federal response to the spill, said in a statement that the preventer  the roughly 500-ton safety device that failed in the Deepwater Horizon blowout in April  would be brought to the surface on Saturday. It will be replaced by a blowout preventer better able to handle any pressure increases that might result when a relief will is used to pump mud and cement into the well after Labor Day. The damaged blowout preventer will eventually be taken to shore and will be in the custody of investigators looking into the cause of the accident.

Brees was transcendent in the Super Bowl, and the Saints led the league in points last season. They also topped the league in scoring differential, despite a defense that finished 20th in points allowed. Smith is surrounded by plenty of talent, including tight end Vernon Davis and the emerging receiver Michael Crabtree. Do not look for Smith to finally get to use the spread offense he prefers, though. Singletary wants to be an old-school, smash-mouth team  he defined that style as a player  and the Niners upgraded their offensive line in the draft to that end. Their schedule will not make it easy  they also play a home game in London and play the Cardinals twice late in the season  but the Niners should get above .500 for the first time since 2002, and that may be enough to win the division.

Nestled in a high mountain valley surrounded by jagged, soaring peaks, Telluride, a former mining town, frequently upstages the movies on its screens, at least as far as sheer visual sublimity is concerned.

description: Hurricane Earl menaced the eastern seaboard in the last few days from Okracoke, N.C., to Nantucket, Mass. Almost exactly 50 years ago, Hurricane Donna devastated the Atlantic Coast, killing 116 people, mostly in Puerto Rico, pictured above. An article in The Times from Sept. 11, 1960, reported on the fate of Humacao, Puerto Rico:

title: At Michigan, a Day of Record Numbers
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  No matter how he approached his analysis of Saturdays 30-10 loss to Michigan, Connecticut Coach Randy Edsall kept coming back to Denard Robinson. After watching Robinson, a sophomore, break the Michigan record for rushing yards in a game by a quarterback with 197 in his first start, Edsall declared Robinson not just the difference in the game, but the difference on his team.

title: Prime Number
description: 77.8: The average temperature in New York City for June through August, making it officially the hottest summer on record, according to the National Weather Service. The period passed quietly, without a cataclysmic event, like a mass blackout.

title: Taming the Wild Tuna
description: IN the wide expanse of the wild ocean, there is perhaps nothing more wild than the worlds largest tuna  the giant Atlantic bluefin. Equipped with a kind of natural GPS system that biologists have yet to decode, the bluefin can cross and recross the Atlantics breadth multiple times in the course of its life. Its furious metabolism enables the fish to sprint at more than 40 miles an hour, heat its muscles 20 degrees above ambient, and hunt relentlessly at frigid depths in excess of 1,500 feet.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Hoping to Dust Off a Crown Unworn Since 1967
description: ST. LOUIS

title: Leinart, With Career Full of Disappointment, Is Now Without Team
description: Four years ago, Matt Leinart stared into space, his megawatt smile dimmed by a 90-minute tumble through the draft, leaving him contemplating the twist in a klieg-lighted career that had included two college national championships and a Heisman Trophy. Leinart would almost certainly have been the first overall pick if he had left Southern California a year earlier, but on that day at Radio City Music Hall in New York, he could only drop his head into his hand when the Arizona Cardinals finally plucked him from his anxiety with the 10th overall pick.

title: Prosecutors Detail Abuse in Brooklyn Girls Last Days
description: Two days after the bruised, emaciated body of a 4-year-old girl was discovered in a Brooklyn apartment, new information from officials emerged about her life and death as her mother on Saturday made her first appearance in court to face criminal charges.

title: Day and Snedeker Lead After Second Round at Deutsche Bank
description: NORTON, Mass.  Brandt Snedeker, who missed the cut last week at the Barclays, shot his way to a tie at the top of the Deutsche Bank Championship on Saturday with a 64 that was the best score in a windswept second round at the T.P.C. Boston. It was the latest example of how where theres life, theres hope could be the working theme for the PGA Tours FedEx Cup playoffs.

title: Yelling Bedbug in a Crowded Festival
description: Last week, the Toronto International Film Festival dodged a bullet  or a Tweet, to be exact fired by a film critic claiming that one of its major theatrical venues had a bedbug problem, according to The Globe and Mail newspaper. The news ricocheted around the film community, appearing on news and gossip sites like The Hollywood Reporter and Perez.Hilton.com. Not exactly the kind of publicity festival organizers had in mind  not when the event pulls in more than $162 million in revenue for the city. Bringing in the bedbug experts, organizers announced in Tweets that the theater had received a clean bill of health from city officials. With the rumor mill running at the speed of Twitter, it took days to set the record straight and avert potential disaster.

title: Few Visitors in Boise, to Broncos Chagrin
description: The first month of a college football season is filled with teams from lesser-known conferences traveling to play teams from powerful ones. They are known as guarantee games, in which the road teams receive a guaranteed paycheck and often a guaranteed loss.

title: L.S.U.s Dual Threat Puts on a Show
description: ATLANTA  It seems like a risky move for a team to use its star cornerback, an All-American candidate no less, as a kick returner. But Louisiana State is doing just that with Patrick Peterson, exposing him in the open field to gunners on coverage teams and opening up the possibility that his knees could be wrecked.

title: N.F.L. Preview: N.F.C. North
description: Watching Favre-a-thon 2010 unfold, the Packers might have stifled a giggle. They should not even pay attention. Green Bay is a Super Bowl-caliber team no matter what Favre does because General Manager Ted Thompson made the right bet at the right time on Aaron Rodgers, who is one of the top five quarterbacks in the league and looked particularly sharp in the preseason. If his line does not get Rodgers killed, the way it nearly did early last season, the offense will again be one of the most productive in the N.F.L. (The Packers were third in points scored last season.) The defense was seventh in points allowed, and although Al Harris and Charles Woodson are among the best cornerback tandems in the league, they are each at least 33 and injuries are taking a toll. Harris (knee) is on the physically unable to perform list and unavailable for at least six games. The best news for the Packers is that the schedule offers a relatively easy first six games before they play the Vikings, the Jets and the Cowboys in a row. After a bye, they face the Vikings, the Falcons and the 49ers.

title: Forcier Unhappy After Not Playing for Michigan
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Michigan may have found this years starting quarterback and lost last years in a matter of hours Saturday.

title: The Fans Cheer Loudly, but Blake Goes Quietly
description: A gusting wind that could have been mistaken for an ill wind was sending stray wrappers and napkins zipping through the air like Frisbees. But this was no picnic ground with a storm coming in. This was Arthur Ashe Stadium, the place where James Blake has played some of his most meaningful and convincing tennis, the place where he was honored for his perseverance and fortitude on the opening night of this United States Open.

title: Dropping Jaws and Stopping Conversations in a Test-Drive
description: For the past three weeks I have been baby-sitting a robot. It is not your traditional looking robot  if there is such a thing yet  but looks like an extra-large lollipop on wheels.

title: The Boss Is Robotic, and Rolling Up Behind You
description: SACRAMENTO  Dr. Alan Shatzels pager beeped at 9 on a Saturday morning. A man had suffered a stroke, and someone had to decide, quickly, whether to give him an anticlotting drug that could mean the difference between life and death.

title: Democrats Plan Political Triage to Retain House
description: WASHINGTON  As Democrats brace for a November wave that threatens their control of the House, party leaders are preparing a brutal triage of their own members in hopes of saving enough seats to keep a slim grip on the majority.

title: College Football Replay: Sept. 4
description: Images from the first Saturday of the college football season.

title: Short-Handed Tar Heels Rally but Fall Short
description: ATLANTA  North Carolina Coach Butch Davis has been under scrutiny for days for a scandal involving academics and agents that has rocked his program. Some words used to describe affairs in Chapel Hill were humiliation and embarrassment. There have been calls for Davis to step down and for the program to regain a balance between academics and athletics.

title: Rock Bottom? France May Not Be Done Digging
description: It turns out all of us were wrong. Things could get worse for France.

title: What to Watch on Sunday at the Open
description: Ukraine versus Spain usually means two guys anchored to the baseline blasting ground strokes at one another for hours on end  but not Sergiy Stakhovsky and Feliciano Lopez.

title: Aronian Leads Shanghai Masters
Vows: William & Kim
description: Born half a world apart, it was the opera that brought William Ferguson and Kim Smith, both singers, together in Melbourne, Australia.

title: Sounds of Africa Take Over Londons Stages
description: Fortunate in having one of Europes most vibrant African communities, London has long been a great place to hear music played by African musicians from all over the world. And for the last seven years, Londoners have been able to count on the London African Music Festival to organize an exciting and varied program of concerts and workshops, some of them free, all over the city.

title: A Voice From the Next Offshore Oil Frontier
description: On Thursday, Interior Secretary Ken Salazar had a meeting with the only people outside the gulf region whose waters had been opened to offshore oil exploration. He was in Barrow, Alaska, the capital of the North Slope Borough, where people have the same conflicted feelings about the oil industry as residents of the gulf states do. The energy industry centered in Prudhoe Bay is the economic engine of the North Slope, helping preserve the Inupiat culture, but it also presents a potential threat to that culture. Mayor Edward Itta of the North Slope Borough e-mailed answers to our questions about these conflicts. (The transcript of the exchange has been edited and condensed.)

title: Whats Your Threshold for Wrong Charges?
description: I check my checking and credit card account statements nearly every day to make sure there are no fraudulent charges. For me, no amount is too small to fight  whether its the $300 in fraudulent debit card charges I noticed last month or more recently, a $10.95 travel center charge I realized I mistakenly made.

title: What to Watch at the Open on Sunday, Junior Edition
description: If you want a humbling experience, head out to the field courts Sunday as the U.S. Open junior championship begins and try to pick out the next Ryan Harrison, Melanie Oudin or Beatrice Capra. Two years ago, you would have found Americas current sweethearts all playing in obscurity, in front of hundreds, not thousands, of people in the juniors tournament.

title: Attack Shows Lasting Threat to U.S. in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Insurgents mounted a coordinated attack on one of the main military commands in Baghdad on Sunday, briefly drawing fire from American soldiers, an event that underscored the ambiguity of the American militarys role in Iraq.

title: N.F.L. Preview: A.F.C. East
description: It has been a long time since their rival in New England did not enter the season as the A.F.C. East favorite, but the Jets may engineer a hostile takeover. If the new cornerback Antonio Cromartie can return to his 2007 form and Darrelle Revis ends his holdout, the Jets will have the best secondary, and the best defense, in football. The first-team offense struggled in the preseason; Mark Sanchez still makes too many mistakes, and the offensive line looked spotty. But the surprise was how much life appeared in LaDainian Tomlinsons legs. The real issue is that with so many big mouths and big egos, the Jets have raised expectations wildly and made themselves a target. In a closely bunched division, how well all those big names work together may determine whether the Jets are a well-publicized boom or bust.

title: Open House, Day 7: Why Dont Doubles-Loving Fans Watch Live Doubles?
description: Michael Kimmelman, the Timess chief art critic, and Gerry Marzorati, editor of the Sunday Magazine, are covering the Open from uncommon perspectives. Each morning, they discuss whats happening. Join the conversation  or ask a fan-oriented question  by sending in a comment.

title: Follow the Open via Twitter, Sunday Edition
description: Gerry Marzorati, one-half of the Open House duo, is covering the United States Open via Twitter. Now that Sundays sessions are over, go directly to gerrynyt.

title: Governor Forecasts: Understanding the Model
description: Our gubernatorial projections took a little longer than I expected. The original idea was that we could just take our Senate model, tweak a few of the parameters, and be ready to go. Indeed, our gubernatorial forecasting model shares a lot of the Senate models DNA. The basic blueprint of taking a robust average of polls, supplementing them with some demographic information and then using them to project the final standing of the candidates remains the same.

title: Sunday Word: Its All Political
description: With just over two months before the midterm elections, party leaders are solidifying their strategies and rallying their troops.

title: N.F.L. Preview: A.F.C. North
description: The Ravens spent the off-season shoring up their offense, handing quarterback Joe Flacco the best receiving corps he has had by adding Anquan Boldin and Donte Stallworth, who recently broke his foot but is expected to return in October. Combine them with running back Ray Rices explosiveness, and the Ravens have real scoring potential  a good thing after they managed only 3 points against the Colts in the playoffs last season. That would usually be enough to make the Ravens a Super Bowl favorite without reservation.

title: Analysis: How Nadal Can Win in New York
description: The United States Open title has eluded Rafael Nadal, who, like Bjorn Borg before him, dominated the European clay-court season and was able to adapt to grass and win Wimbledon a few short weeks later. I would argue that Borgs feat was the tougher one to accomplish because the grass back then played faster, the bounces were unreliable and there were also many serve-and-volleyers who reveled on the slick, low-bouncing grass, John McEnroe chief among them.

title: Mideast Leaders Hopeful After Opening of Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Palestinian and Israeli leaders expressed satisfaction and hope on Sunday in their first public utterances after the opening round of Middle East peace talks in Washington last week.

title: The Brooklyn Griffin Finds a Perch
description: Perched high above an industrial stretch of East Williamsburg, a menacing robot nine feet high and seven feet wide surveys the street below, watching cars steal past graffitied factory buildings as if they were prey. Its fierce head sways and dips when a wooden rudder protruding from the back of its neck catches the breeze.

title: Rodriguez Returns to Yankees Lineup
description: Alex Rodriguez returned to the Yankees lineup Sunday for the first time since Aug. 20, but Nick Swisher missed his third consecutive game.

title: True to Erratic Form, Murray Tumbles Out Early
description: The dire forecasts  weather and otherwise  that were supposed to rattle the United States Open field seemed to pass Sunday with little of the expected doom and gloom. The wind, which had turned Saturday into a mess, calmed by Sunday afternoon, and all seemed well until Andy Murray, the tournaments version of Eeyore, took the court.

description: Ive had a couple of conversations lately with people who follow politics and public affairs, but arent that close to the economic discussion  and Ive discovered that there are two comforting delusions still out there.

description: I was going to post this later, but I thought maybe we all needed some cheering up.

title: N.F.L. Preview: A.F.C. West
description: When will the rest of the A.F.C. West give the Chargers a run for the division title? Not this year. For all the off-season turmoil  whither Vincent Jackson and his holdout?  San Diego has the most talent by far. The passing game, even without Jackson, is deep and explosive and figures only to get better now that teams have to pay attention to Ryan Mathews instead of LaDainian Tomlinson, who led the 31st-ranked rushing offense last season. Still, you get the feeling the window is about to close on this team. Several big names, like linebacker Shawne Merriman and returner Darren Sproles, are in their contract years, and the Chargers simply cant keep racing through the regular season (they won their final 11 games in 2009 and have one of the easiest schedules this season) only to collapse in the playoffs. Last seasons lackluster playoff loss to the Jets might be pinned on Norv Turners insistence on giving the ball to Tomlinson, but the excuses, and the Chargers dominance, are running out. San Diego should win the division again with ease, but every other team is aggressively trying to improve in the meantime.

title: Double Eagle Lifts Singh Into Contention
description: NORTON, Mass.  For the second time in two years, a player has scored a double-eagle on the second hole at T.P.C. Boston during the Deutsche Bank Championship. Using a 5-iron, Vijay Singh holed his shot from 230 yards on the 567-yard par 5, which is a dogleg right. Singhs shot was nearly all over water as the second green is fronted by a large pond.

title: Afghan Government Moves Toward Seizing Assets of Troubled Banks Shareholders
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government took steps on Sunday toward seizing the properties of major shareholders of the troubled Kabul Bank, as perturbed crowds and national security forces surrounded the central branch of the bank, the countrys largest.

title: In the Heat of Camp, the Hunger of Faith
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  For Minnesota Vikings defensive back Husain Abdullah, the most important clock inside the Metrodome was not the one keeping time for his teams recent preseason game with the Seattle Seahawks. Another, showing the time of day, held greater significance for him and for the Vikings training staff.

title: Lessons of the Summer Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  Christopher Nolan proved there is always room at the multiplex, even in swimsuit season, for a smart, original story. Will Ferrell bounced back. Michael Cera fell flat. Animation was the No. 1 genre. Sorry, Sex and the City ladies: Its over.

description: The Nevada senior quarterback Colin Kaepernick had a devastating fastball when he pitched for Pitman High School in Turlock, Calif. He threw a pair of no-hitters, and in 2009 he was drafted by the Chicago Cubs even though he had not played organized baseball for three years.

title: N.F.L. Preview: A.F.C. South
description: Eight of the last 11 Super Bowl losers failed to qualify for the playoffs the next season. Get serious. As long as Peyton Manning is upright, the Colts are a Super Bowl contender. Bill Polian, the Colts president, has surrounded Manning with superb talent, so much so that Indianapoliss 2007 first-round draft pick, Anthony Gonzalez, could be the odd man out in a fabulous group of receivers. The offensive line has gotten much bigger with the hopes of establishing a ground game, but how much does that really matter? Manning threw 571 passes last year and was a coachs decision from leading Indianapolis to a likely undefeated regular season. The defense, which allowed fewer than 20 points a game, should be better in Year 2 under Larry Coyer because Bob Sanders, a supremely gifted safety, is healthy again. The only problem the Colts face is that the expectations are so high, if they dont win it all, the season will be a huge disappointment. They will reach at least the A.F.C. championship game.

title: Former H.P. Chief May Move to Oracle
description: Mark V. Hurd, who was forced to resign as Hewlett-Packards top executive last month after an investigation into a sexual harassment charge found that he had manipulated his expenses, is in talks with Oracle about a top executive position there, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: Rodriguez Back in Lineup, but Other Concerns Persist
description: The Yankees winning streak ended at a season-best eight games Sunday with Alex Rodriguez taking a called third strike.

title: A Bronx Film School Tale
description: It was just after the long Fourth of July weekend when the Ghetto Film School assembled its 2010 fellows at its headquarters in the South Bronx, a few floors above offices of the state parole division. Introductions were made, and then the 21 teenage students eagerly took possession of high-definition video cameras and began learning how to make movies.

title: Going to Extremes to Seek Dramatic Accuracy
description: The critics, the financial backers, the friends and the family of cast and crew came to see Paul Weitzs comedy Trust, but one more interested observer needed to weigh in, and she wasnt there to judge which lines got the biggest laughs.

title: Mystery and Evidence
description: There is a story about Bertrand Russell giving a public lecture somewhere or other, defending his atheism. A furious woman stood up at the end of the lecture and asked: And Lord Russell, what will you say when you stand in front of the throne of God on judgment day? Russell replied: I will say: Im terribly sorry, but you didnt give us enough evidence.

description: SARA BAREILLES

title: War Intrudes on a Mans Bucolic Idyll
description: Tom McCarthys much ballyhooed first novel, Remainder, was an oddly ingenious book that read like the work of an extremely precocious philosophy student who had read a lot of Robbe-Grillet, Sartre, Camus, Philip K. Dick and Georges Perec.

title: Mom-Stepmom Two Step
description: Instead of Bollywoods usual steal this movie ethos, We Are Family, a go-for-broke weepie produced by Karan Johar, gives screen credit where screen credit is due: to the writers of the Hollywood film that its based upon, Stepmom (1998), with Susan Sarandon and Julia Roberts.

description: Do you fancy yourself as an analyst? If so, you are East, in four spades. South leads a low heart. How can you make the contract?

description: At what point, in the name of entertainment, is it acceptable to just give up on trying to develop an original, nuanced perspective on history and instead merely embrace the clichs inherited from earlier media?

description: The unexpectedly deep plunge in home sales this summer is likely to force the Obama administration to choose between future homeowners and current ones, a predicament officials had been eager to avoid.

description: PUZZLE NOTES  Who would have thought there were enough phrases starting with SATURDAY NIGHT to weave a theme around them?

title: Body Language, Translated and Remixed
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y.  The first time Iggy and the Stooges played a concert was July 1972. They had a new guitarist, James Williamson, and had changed their name from the plain Stooges.

title: After Offense Puts on a Show, the Mets Talk of Bowing Out
description: CHICAGO  Perhaps it was just a cruel taunt from the fates, but on their most productive day in five years, the Mets finally conceded that their hopes of reaching the playoffs are over.

title: This Time the Trouble Isnt Wicked Stepsisters
description: The performer-writer Ann Liv Young belongs to the movement in the arts that was labeled Sensation in the 1990s. She performed Snow White naked, apart from a Disney mask on her face, while heavily pregnant. Dildos and masturbation have been part of her theatrical fare. At MoMA P.S. 1 in February she insulted a fellow artists work (accompanied by urination and masturbation) until management turned the lights off on her. And on Friday and Saturday she performed a one-woman Cinderella at the Issue Project Room in Gowanus, Brooklyn. In this, as an outspoken and trashy Southerner called Sherry, she converses with members of the audience (sometimes in a quarrelsome way) and also urinates and defecates onstage.

title: Arena Full of Fans Caught Brazilian Fever and Had to Sing Along
description: Brazils top pop singer, Ivete Sangalo, boldly courted a wider audience with a concert on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. According to the promoters, Caco de Telha Entertainment, she was the first Brazilian musician to headline the Garden; the show was videotaped for her next live DVD. (She recorded a previous live DVD and CD, Multishow ao Vivo: Ivete no Maracan, at a Rio de Janeiro soccer stadium, so the Garden was comparatively intimate, even on the weekend of New Yorks Brazilian Day festival.)

title: All Tomorrow's Parties
description: Photos from the music festival in Monticello, N.Y.

title: Hearing Spring as Summer Fades
description: NEW LEBANON, N.Y.  There were both chamber music staples and rarities on Saturday night at the Tannery Pond concert hall here, a barnlike structure built by Shakers in 1834 and now an acoustically fine and charmingly rustic performance space.

title: Seiji Ozawa Greeted Warmly on Return to Podium
description: It was not exactly the return he had hoped for, but the conductor Seiji Ozawa scored a triumph of a limited sort at the Saito Kinen Festival in Matsumoto, Japan, on Sunday afternoon as he returned to the public stage for the first time since surgery for esophageal cancer in January. He opened a program of the festival orchestra (he was supposed to have led all of it), conducting the first movement of Tchaikovskys Serenade for Strings. Then, because he was experiencing sciatic problems that recurred as a byproduct of the surgery, he stepped aside to let a younger conductor, Tatsuya Shimono, take over. When Mr. Ozawa, right, took the stage, he was greeted as warmly as the politest of audiences could manage: no standing, no cheering, but loud, sustained applause. Half standing, half sitting, he delivered brief remarks from the stage, explaining his difficulties, apologizing for being unable to do more and promising to be back next year. Then he conducted the movement, mostly standing and with typically vigorous gestures. The orchestra, obviously charged up for the occasion, delivered a searingly intense performance. Rhythmic clapping broke out after the concert, directed at Mr. Ozawa in the audience, and he half ran to greet Mr. Shimono and the players onstage.

title: Writing Spice Girls Story
description: The Spice Girls have a saucy writer for their musical story. Jennifer Saunders, the creator, producer and star of the tart British comedy Absolutely Fabulous, has been hired to write the book for the musical, Viva Forever, Playbill reported. It will be a modern fable of camaraderie, love and loyalty based on the songs of the Spice Girls, according to a statement from one of the shows producers, Judy Craymer. Ms. Craymer, who brought the musical Mamma Mia! to Broadway in 2001, has been developing the production with a former manager of the band, Simon Fuller. Im thrilled and terrified at the same time, Ms. Saunders said in the statement. My daughters grew up with the Spice Girls; I had to write the book for them as well as myself.

title: Footnote
description: The actress and playwright Lisa Kron (Well) is set to host the 2010 IT Awards, which recognize the achievements of Off Off Broadway theater. Among those to be presented with awards in Cooper Unions Great Hall on Sept. 20 are the playwright Lanford Wilson (Talleys Folly), who is being honored in the artistic achievement category, and the New York Neo-Futurists, an ensemble theater group that presents the series of original short plays Too Much Light Makes the Baby Go Blind. The group will receive the Caffe Cino Fellowship Award.

title: Dioguardi Leaves Idol
description: The songwriter Kara DioGuardi is leaving American Idol, the Fox singing competition, after only two seasons, setting the stage for an announcement this month about a new judging panel. One judge, Randy Jackson, is apparently still tied to the show. An overhaul of Idol is under way ahead of its 10th season, and the leading contenders to replace the departed Ellen DeGeneres and Simon Cowell are Jennifer Lopez and Steven Tyler. I felt like I won the lottery when I joined American Idol two years ago, Ms. DioGuardi, above, said in a statement late Friday. But I feel like now is the best time to leave Idol. Her departure had been rumored since late July, when Ms. DeGeneres left. But in mid-August her father, Joseph J. DioGuardi, a Republican who is running for Senate in New York, said there had been silence from the producers. She read it the way you did and I did, he said in a television interview. In fact, her disappointment is that thats the way shes being treated, and she feels thats not proper.

title: Jersey Shore and Disney Enjoy Ratings Success
description: Heading into the Labor Day weekend, the summer cable telecasts Jersey Shore and Camp Rock 2 were the two television standouts, surpassing offerings on the broadcast networks. The sixth episode of the second Jersey Shore season, on MTV, had a series-high rating on Thursday, with 6.5 million total viewers. The series has been steadily gaining audience this season, and it is firmly the summers most popular show among viewers 12 to 34. On Friday night it was the Disney Channels chance to crow. Its original movie Camp Rock 2: The Final Jam, starring Demi Lovato and the Jonas Brothers, drew eight million viewers, enough to qualify as the No. 1 cable movie of the year. The original Camp Rock in 2008 averaged 8.9 million viewers.

title: Blairs Book Is Greeted With Anger in Dublin
description: The former British Prime Minister Tony Blair was greeted by a barrage of plastic bottles, flip-flops and eggs at the first public reading of his new book on Saturday in Dublin. Witnesses told Agence France-Presse that more than 200 demonstrators were on hand to protest Mr. Blair, left, and his involvement leading up to the 2003 Iraq war, chanting antiwar slogans and holding signs that read Blair lied, millions died and Lock him up for genocide. In the book, which recounts his time as prime minister, from 1997 to 2007, Mr. Blair defended his decision to go to war but wrote that he did not anticipate the nightmare that followed. Mr. Blair was separated from the crowd by a security barrier and was not harmed. Four people were arrested and charged with public offenses, the police told Agence France-Presse. Several hundred others lined up at a back door of the bookshop to await their turn to meet Mr. Blair and have their copies signed. Antiwar activists have threatened to protest Mr. Blairs next book signing, scheduled for Wednesday in London.

title: Kanye West Tries Twitter to Explain His Actions
description: The rapper and producer Kanye West posted a series of messages on his Twitter account on Saturday morning in yet another attempt to explain his behavior at last years MTV Video Music Awards, where he grabbed the microphone from Taylor Swift and suggested that the prize for best female video should have gone instead to Beyonc Knowles. In numerous posts published across just a few hours, Mr. West recounted some of the abuse he had taken from the public. People tweeted that they wish I was dead, he wrote. No listen. They wanted me to die people. I carry that. I smile and take pictures through that. Mr. West also defended his actions: Whos seen the play Wicked? Ive seen it 4 times! Other than loving the music acting and costumes ... its my story!!! The Wicked witch of the west basically is so convicted to tell her truth when she does it she is outcasted by society and turned WICKED. And he criticized members of the news media for demonizing him. But in the end, Mr. West wrote, I take the responsibility for my actions, and he offered Ms. Swift this message: I wrote a song for Taylor Swift thats so beautiful and I want her to have it. If she wont take it then Ill perform it for her. After taking a break from the public for much of the past year, Mr. West has begun returning to the spotlight, announcing plans for a new album this fall and accepting MTVs invitation to perform at this years awards show on Sept. 12.

title: In Blue Ridge Mountains, a Steady Climb to the Top
description: The Virginia Tech football teams success has become a rite of autumn in Blacksburg, with victories accumulating as consistently as the foliage that falls over the Blue Ridge Mountains. The Hokies have reached a bowl game each year since 1993, and only Ohio State and Florida have more wins since 1995.

title: Retiring Fed Official Considers More Bank Action
description: WASHINGTON  The former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, who retired last week after 40 years at the central bank, says that the economy is in a slow slog out of a very deep hole, and that the Fed should consider additional stimulus unless the recovery shows signs of decent progress.

title: Adopt a Firehouse
