title: A Ramadan Drumbeat Is Sounded in Queens
description: It was just past 4 the other morning when Mohammad Boota pulled his Lincoln Town Car into a service station on an industrial stretch in Long Island City, Queens, and bounded out  a typhoon of embroidered fabric, good cheer and unusual urgency.

title: Provocative Artist Returns to MoMA P.S. 1
description: No one could have turned out the lights at the performative discussion between the provocative performance artist Ann Liv Young and the artist A.L Steiner at the sunlit MoMA P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens, on Sunday afternoon. But, as it turned out, the mood of the discussion couldnt have been less like its subject: Ms. Youngs fraught and much-discussed appearance at P.S. 1 in February that ended with the museums director, Klaus Biesenbach, ordering the power shut off in the middle of the performance.

title: For G.O.P., Tea Party Wields a Double-Edged Sword
description: Christine ODonnell, running in Delaware to be the Republican nominee for the Senate seat once held by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., is a perennial candidate with a history of financial problems, including unpaid taxes and a home in foreclosure. Representative Michael N. Castle, her opponent in the primary, is a veteran congressman and former governor who has won statewide elections more than 10 times.

title: Trouble in the Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Responsibility for Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Stumbling Through Race, Padres Search For Swagger
description: SAN DIEGO  Adrian Gonzalez sauntered through the Padres expansive clubhouse Sunday morning in shorts and flip-flops, clutching a steaming cup of coffee. Not far away, Ryan Ludwick sat in a chair while Scott Hairston shaved his head with electric shears. Several players sat at their lockers, engrossed in their laptops or iPads. Heath Bell sat at his, fast asleep.

title: From the Other Side of Ground Zero, Anti-Muslim Venom
description: The Internet evangelist Bill Keller moved toward the dais in tiny, quick steps on Sunday, exhibiting the anticipation of a man ready to address a crowd. Roughly 60 people stood before him in a hotel meeting room in Lower Manhattan, temporary quarters of his Christian center, his response to the mosque planned for an empty building nearby.

title: Some See a Ploy as Craigslist Blocks Sex Ads
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Craigslist, by shutting off its adult services section and slapping a censored label in its place, may be engaging in a high-stakes stunt to influence public opinion, some analysts say.

title: Even Hit Like Kick-Ass Can Seem Like Miss at Debut
description: LOS ANGELES  In early April, as Lionsgate prepared to release Kick-Ass, the movie capital buzzed that the film looked to be a smash hit. Lionsgate had acquired it for just $15 million, and surveys that track audience interest projected a $30 million opening weekend.

title: Suicide Attack Kills 3 Soldiers in South Russia
description: MOSCOW  A suicide bomber drove a car packed with explosives into a military installation in a Muslim region of southern Russia early Sunday, killing three soldiers and injuring more than 30 others, officials said.

title: School Aid to New York State
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadway Is Busy, With Pedestrians, if Not Car Traffic
description: It is Manhattans most famous thoroughfare, known around the world for its theater marquees and giant Macys. It has come to symbolize the outsize aspirations and swagger of New York.

title: Before Dawn, Sounds of a Ramadan Ritual
description: Mohammad Boota, who is New York Citys foremost  and perhaps only  Ramadan drummer, is exploring new territory where he can awaken the faithful.

description: As a young professional tennis player, Dick Norman used to watch the older men who played doubles, who hung on deep into their 30s, who clung to the vagabond style of tennis lifers.

title: Uncommon Path Led Russias Coach All Over the World
description: ISTANBUL  At a cafe in St. Petersburg, Russia, in 2004, David Blatt realized he had found a new home. He had just accepted a job as the head coach of Dynamo St. Petersburg and was putting together a practice plan with an assistant.

title: Floods in Pakistan Carry the Seeds of Upheaval
description: THATA SIAL, Pakistan  When the governor of Punjab Province arrived recently in this small town with truckloads of relief goods for flood victims, his visit was as much a political mission as a humanitarian one. His message to the hundred or so displaced people gathered under an awning was that the government was there for them.

title: After Big Shots All Around, Days Lead Holds at One
description: NORTON, Mass.  The way the roars reverberated through the trees and across the golf course at T.P.C. Boston on Sunday, it almost sounded as if Tom Brady and the Patriots were pouring on the points up the road in Foxborough. But all this exuberance was generated by a day of chip-ins, hole-outs, back-nine 30s, eagles and double eagles at the Deutsche Bank Championship  where Jason Day, Brandt Snedeker, Luke Donald, Steve Stricker, Phil Mickelson and a host of others put on an extraordinary show in the PGA Tours FedEx Cup playoffs.

title: Our Infrastructure Woes
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Apple Faces Many Rivals for Streaming to TVs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Steven P. Jobs introduced Apples first iPod in 2001, it held more music and was easier to use than the handful of rival products already in the market. But it had a big shortcoming: it worked only with Macintosh computers, then less than 3 percent of the PC market.

title: In Britain, Labour Politicians Call for New Look at Scandal
description: LONDON  Senior opposition politicians are calling on the government to respond to renewed accusations that Downing Streets chief communications officer, Andy Coulson, encouraged reporters to illegally intercept messages from the cellphones of public figures when he was editor of The News of the World.

title: Anger Is Not the Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Thin Line for Group of Muslims in Egypt
description: CAIRO  One by one, the guests at the Muslim Brotherhoods annual Ramadan iftar banquet strode to the rostrum. A whos who of Egypts opposition began hectoring the Islamist group. The Brotherhood, they said, by far the most muscular and influential of Egypts dissident organizations, should withdraw from the coming parliamentary election that would most certainly be rigged by the authoritarian government.

title: How to Tell if Apple Falters
description: When should investors sell Apple shares? The groups push overseas and into the business market still holds promise, as does the steady stream of gadgets, like the updated Apple TV introduced by Steven P. Jobs last week. Apples trajectory should continue for some time, so its stock, which has gained more than 40 percent each year for the last five, looks attractive at 15 times estimated 2011 earnings. But no company can grow sales at that pace forever. While it may sound premature or even churlish to do so, we offer some strategic cues that could act as warning signs for investors that Apples growth is slowing.

title: The Next Afghan Election
description: In less than two weeks, Afghanistan will elect a new parliament  a chance to show that the country is making progress. Unfortunately, the odds of success may not be much better than they were last year, when a presidential election, marred by violence and widespread fraud, left Afghans and the international community questioning the legitimacy of Hamid Karzais victory.

title: Labor Day, Now and Then
description: Labor Day has been around for a surprisingly long time, longer than Mothers Day, longer than Fathers Day, and almost as long as the official celebration of Washingtons Birthday.

title: Nadal Has No Problem Riding Federer-Endorsed Vans
description: What drives Rafael Nadal, the mens top seed in the United States Open? In his trips to and from Flushing Meadows, it has been a shuttle van with a likeness of his main rival, Roger Federer, the five-time Open champion who endorses the company that is supplying the tournament with cars.

title: Iranian Woman Said to Be Lashed Over Photo
description: LONDON  A mix-up over a photograph led to a sentence of 99 lashes for the Iranian woman whose earlier death sentence by stoning from Iranian authorities caused an international outcry, a lawyer for the woman said Sunday.

title: Follow the Money to the Floor
description: Three House members got word the other day that investigators have recommended that the ethics committee delve into their fund-raising from Wall Street donors  lucrative labors that happened to coincide precisely with some big votes on reforming Wall Street. Five other members were cleared in the same inquiry, raising the question of exactly what it might take to violate the Capitols notoriously porous rules about political fund-raising.

title: 23 Accused of Coup Plot in Bahrain
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Bahraini officials announced on Saturday that they were charging 23 people, most of them activists from the Shiite majority, with coordinating a violent campaign to overthrow the minority Sunni government.

title: Lottery Numbers
Unsolved Coal Ash Problem
description: In December 2008, a gigantic storage pond belonging to the Tennessee Valley Authority near Kingston, Tenn., effectively burst at the seams, spilling a billion gallons of mainly toxic coal ash from a T.V.A. power plant into surrounding lands and rivers.

title: Two-Time Champion and Part Jersey Girl
description: Kim Clijsters made short work of Ana Ivanovic on Sunday for her 18th straight victory spanning five years at the United States Open, the tournament at which she happens to have won her only two Grand Slam titles. There has not been such home-court advantage at the National Tennis Center since John McEnroe.

title: Changing Guard, Now Missing a Known Name
description: John Isner and Sam Querrey share several things in common. They are tall; they are young; and with Andy Roddick and James Blake already eliminated from the United States Open, they have been given the brightest of stages to present themselves as the leading men in the next generation of American tennis.

title: Some Newspapers, Tracking Readers Online, Shift Coverage
description: In most businesses, not knowing how well a particular product is performing would be almost unthinkable. But newspapers have always been a peculiar business, one that has stubbornly, proudly clung to a sense that focusing too much on the bottom line can lead nowhere good.

title: Dead Join the Living in a Family Celebration
description: AMBOHIMIRARY, Madagascar  With fanfare befitting a parade, the shrouded remains of 17 bodies were removed from the family crypt, some sprayed with expensive perfume, others splashed with sparkling wine. Five brass bands took turns belting out cheerful melodies, and each emerging corpse was lifted onto the shoulders of its own set of revelers. The celebrators then joyously trotted about, dancing with the bones of the dead.

title: 1938 in 2010
description: Heres the situation: The U.S. economy has been crippled by a financial crisis. The presidents policies have limited the damage, but they were too cautious, and unemployment remains disastrously high. More action is clearly needed. Yet the public has soured on government activism, and seems poised to deal Democrats a severe defeat in the midterm elections.

title: Memories Translate Well for Lendl
description: You see, ya cant please everyone, so ya got to please yourself.

description: Listening to Kyle Pope, the editor of The New York Observer, discuss how he wants to re-energize his newspaper sounds a lot like someone describing a Broadway show or a television series that has run a little past its prime.

title: American Muslims Ask, Will We Ever Belong?
description: For nine years after the attacks of Sept. 11, many American Muslims made concerted efforts to build relationships with non-Muslims, to make it clear they abhor terrorism, to educate people about Islam and to participate in interfaith service projects. They took satisfaction in the observations by many scholars that Muslims in America were more successful and assimilated than Muslims in Europe.

title: Weary Ogilvy Figuring Rest Will Improve His Numbers
description: NORTON, Mass.  Geoff Ogilvy was talking about what he called the mysteries of golf. Minutes earlier, he had almost chipped in for eagle on the 18th hole. When he knocked in a 1-inch birdie putt to go to 12 under par after three rounds of the Deutsche Bank Championship, he was in contention for a PGA Tour victory for the first time in nearly eight months.

Among the dead were nine police officers, eight civilians and two children, local and provincial authorities said.

title: Stosur Wins Third-Set Tiebreaker in Wee Hours
description: Fifth-seeded Samantha Stosur of Australia and 12th-seeded Elena Dementieva of Russia battled for 2 hours 38 minutes before Stosur emerged at 1:35 a.m with a 6-3, 2-6, 7-6 (2) victory in the fourth round. In the third set, which took 1 hour, 16 minutes, Dementieva sprinted out to a 3-0 lead, but Stosur would not go down, eventually saving four match points. In the Monday-morning tiebreaker, Stosur took the first three points, thanks to three unforced errors by Dementieva. Read Thomas Kaplans report on the match.

title: Slow Learners and Good Teachers
description: One of the objections thats often raised to using test scores in teacher evaluations is that students are not randomly assigned to teachers. A teacher may be assigned a large number of troubled students because she is especially good at helping such students. Comparing her students test scores to those of an honors class obviously wouldnt be fair.

description: Michael Kimmelman, the Timess chief art critic, and Gerry Marzorati, editor of the Sunday Magazine, are covering the Open from uncommon perspectives. Each morning, they discuss whats happening. Join the conversation  or ask a fan-oriented question  by sending in a comment.

description: Virginia Tech has reached a bowl game in 17 consecutive seasons, the third-longest active streak in the nation. Over that time, the Hokies have played in three Orange Bowls and three Sugar Bowls, one of which was the 1999 national championship game.

title: Obama Offers a Transit Plan to Create Jobs
description: MILWAUKEE  President Obama, looking to stimulate a sluggish economy and create jobs, called Monday for Congress to approve major upgrades to the nations roads, rail lines and runways  part of a six-year plan that would cost tens of billions of dollars and create a government-run bank to finance innovative transportation projects.

title: Blade Runners
description: Maybe its because I spent so much of my childhood rampaging through the woods pretending to be one of Robin Hoods outlaws or the last Mohican, but I think of old-fashioned knives (the sort youd use to survive in the wild rather than slaughter rival drug dealers) as being noble rather than scary.

title: For E. B. Whites Willow Tree, Chapter Ends
description: In the 1940s, when E. B. White, the author and columnist for The New Yorker, looked out of his back windows onto the private Turtle Bay Gardens along East 48th Street in Manhattan, an old but picturesque willow tree commanded his view.

description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The chairman of the Central Bank of Afghanistan promised Monday to lend the embattled Kabul Bank as much as it wants to stave off a collapse, even as he continued to insist that the bank was solvent.

description: Andy Murrays four-set loss to Stanislas Wawrinka on Sunday came as terrible news for fans of the Scottish players all-court counterpunching style. But fans of Rafael Nadal, another speedy counterpuncher, can now breathe a little easier.

title: Potential for Double-Dip Recession Seems Small
description: Over the last few months there has been an increase in the concern and discussion over a possible double-dip recession, particularly after unemployment reports over the summer showed that the nation was shedding tens of thousands of jobs. However, a key element lacking in the talk of double-dip recessions is what actually caused past recessions  that is, what are the primary reasons an economy slows to the point where its growth contracts for at least two quarters  followed by an analysis of whether those conditions exist in the current economic environment. And judging from a variety of indicators, the potential for a double-dip recession seem small.

title: Follow the Open via Twitter, Monday Edition
description: 7:05 p.m. | Updated Gerry Marzorati, one-half of the Open House duo, is covering the United States Open via Twitter. Now that Mondays day session is all but over, go directly to gerrynyt to read his 140-character descriptions of the sights, sounds and matches of the Open.

title: Dispatch | Wales Watching
description: Long the neglected sibling of England and Scotland, Wales is finally starting to come into its own. With some of Britains lushest scenery, a growing foodie movement and more castles than Starbucks and McDonalds branches combined, the wee country  its just 160 miles long by 60 miles wide  resembles some sort of real-life Brigadoon. Prince William, living in North Wales while he trains to become an R.A.F. helicopter pilot, has already been spotted with Kate in Snowdonia National Park, and come October, the global media will descend on Newport, just northeast of the capital of Cardiff when golfs prestigious Ryder Cup is played here for the first time.

title: The Early Word: Labor Day
description: In a Labor Day speech today in Milwaukee, President Obama will call for a $50 billion investment in transportation projects to boost the economy and public confidence, White House officials said.

title: Lacking Money and Leadership, Push for Taliban Defectors Stalls
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A $250 million program to lure low-level Taliban fighters away from the insurgency has stalled, with Afghans bickering over who should run it, and international donors slow to put up the money they had promised.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Melvin and Howard'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at "Melvin and Howard," the strange and possibly true story of Howard Hughes and his will.

title: Timeless | Days of Thunder
description: The 57 Thunderbird is elegant, sporty  its a gentlemans sports car, says Evan Yurman, the design director of mens jewelry and watches for David Yurman, not to mention a vintage car buff. Evan, who is the son of David Yurman, might very well be describing the companys brand-new Classic 1957 Limited Edition watch, a sporty, elegant and, yes, gentlemanly timepiece that was inspired by cars from the 50s and the Thunderbirds instrument panel in particular. I drive these kinds of cars a lot, and Im always staring at the speedometer to see where Im at, he says. For Yurman, the 50s were the golden era of American design, and not just in the automobile industry. I tip my hat to it and hope I can only add to this legacy. When it comes to cars, however, its ultimately whats under the hood that gets him revved up: he loves the 57 T-Bird for its beauty more than its brawn. It is a cruiser, a cream puff, says Yurman, who instead owns a 66 Bel Air and a 69 Ford Mustang. I go for the one where some guy in the factory said, Lets make this car as fast as we can.

title: Analysis: How Youzhny Knocked Off Isner
description: Mikhail Youzhny used superb anticipation to read John Isners powerful serve in his impressive four-set win. As Isner tossed, Youzhny would shade to his right or his left, picking up the direction of the serve seemingly before Isner made contact. He wasnt guessing, but the veteran Russian was picking up subtle cues that allowed him to get his return back in play.

title: Black Swan Gives Telluride Another Surprise
description: TELLURIDE, Colo. The second Sneak of the Telluride Film Festival  the surprise appearance of a big-deal movie, usually making its North American debut, in a previous blank slot in the schedule grid  was Darren Aronofskys Black Swan, a backstage melodrama that often plays like a horror movie. It popped up Sunday, along with Mr. Aronofsky himself, making his first visit to this festival en route from Venice, where Black Swan opened last week and where his previous film, The Wrestler, won the top prize two years ago.

title: 9 Years After 9/11, Public Safety Radio Not Ready
description: WASHINGTON  The inability of most firefighters and police officers to talk to each other on their radios on Sept. 11, 2001, at the World Trade Center  one of the most vexing problems on that day nine years ago  still has not been completely resolved.

title: End-of-Summer Stir-Fries
description: We finally got our heat wave last week in Los Angeles, albeit for only a few days. I decided that rather than light the oven I would cook everything as quickly as I could on top of the stove. With the bounteous end of summer produce at my local farmers markets, it was a perfect week for stir-frying.

title: Ask the Cook About Healthful Stir-Frying
description: The new cookbook by the food writer Grace Young, Stir-Frying to the Skys Edge, was the inspiration for this weeks Recipes for Health from Martha Rose Shulman. When it comes to stir-frying, I have a guru, the cookbook author Grace Young, Ms. Shulman writes. Her new cookbook is the ultimate guide, whether youre a beginner or a chef.

title: Stir-fried Succotash With Edamame
description: While weve still got corn and peppers aplenty, make this Asian version of the American classic succotash. I love the combination of sweet and seared flavors in this dish.

title: The Fifth Set: A Thinking Mans Endurance Test
description: There were the gusts that turned the ball toss on serves into an act of faith and then there were the sudden shifts of momentum. Sam Querrey, the last American man standing in the United States Open, did his best to weather both, but in the end was swept away. He lost in the fourth round to Stanislas Wawrinka of Switzerland in a five-set match at Arthur Ashe Stadium that alternately captivated and crushed the partisan crowd.

title: Patrick McEnroe Resigns as Davis Cup Captain
description: Patrick McEnroe announced his resignation as the American Davis Cup captain on Monday, effective after the United States teams next match, against Colombia in Bogota Sept. 17-19. McEnroe said he wanted to concentrate on his work with the young player development program he leads for the United States Tennis Association, as well as his television commentary and spending more time with his family.

title: The Best of Two Bands at All Tomorrows Parties
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y.  Altar is the project-name of the American duo Sunn O))) and the Japanese trio Boris, convened in front of five enormous stacks of amplifiers. By the end of its show Sunday night at All Tomorrows Parties, it had grown to 10 members; a singer, Jesse Sykes, drifted in and drifted out. There were no rhythms, just drum beats that ended before they really started, like arrested lead-ins to a great song. There was a duet between bowed cymbal and bowed double-bass, and frequent use of a large gong.

title: The Claim: The Days Events are Incorporated Into That Nights Dreams.
description: THE FACTS In the world of sleep research, dreams are something of a black box. But one tidbit that scientists have discerned is the peculiar but predictable pattern in which dreams tend to occur.

title: Topical Gel Catches Up With Pills for Relief
description: When I strained a back muscle playing tennis not long ago, my doubles partner, who happened to be a doctor, pulled a tube of cream from her gym bag and told me to rub it on.

title: Desert Roads Lead to Discovery in Egypt
description: Over the last two decades, John Coleman Darnell and his wife, Deborah, hiked and drove caravan tracks west of the Nile from the monuments of Thebes, at present-day Luxor. These and other desolate roads, beaten hard by millennial human and donkey traffic, only seemed to lead to nowhere.

title: Risks: Asleep, and Helping to Keep the Weight Off
description: Children under 5 who do not get at least 10 hours of sleep at night are almost twice as likely to be overweight or obese later in childhood, a new study reports. And naps during the day dont count.

title: Iran Remains Defiant, Nuclear Agency Says
description: WASHINGTON  Three months after the United Nations Security Council enacted its harshest sanctions yet against Iran, global nuclear inspectors reported Monday that the country has dug in its heels, refusing to provide inspectors with the information and access they need to determine whether the real purpose of Tehrans program is to produce weapons.

title: Prevention: Surgery Sharply Reduces Risk of 2 Cancers
description: About 1 in 400 women carry genetic mutations that put them at high risk for breast and ovarian cancer. For these women, doctors may recommend prophylactic mastectomy and oophorectomy, or removal of the ovaries  even before there is any sign of cancer.

title: Monfils Advances to U.S. Open Quarterfinals
description: Gal Monfils was already popular at the United States Open before this tournament, as a talented but enigmatic player who has embraced the New York atmosphere and tries to engage the fans during his matches. It has not hurt his image that he showed up this year with an outfit that made him look as if he had wandered onto the court fresh off a stroll in the surrounding Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, nor that he has powered his way into the quarterfinals.

title: On Birds of Many Colors, Lice Dress the Part
description: Camouflage in nature is nothing new. A wide variety of animals, like rabbits, birds and deer, are cryptically colored to blend in with their background and guard themselves from predators.

title: Forget What You Know About Good Study Habits
description: Every September, millions of parents try a kind of psychological witchcraft, to transform their summer-glazed campers into fall students, their video-bugs into bookworms. Advice is cheap and all too familiar: Clear a quiet work space. Stick to a homework schedule. Set goals. Set boundaries. Do not bribe (except in emergencies).

title: Weight Problems May Begin in the Womb
description: You may think you know why Americans continue to get fatter and develop obesity-related diseases. But the explanation may start long before people have an opportunity to eat too much of the wrong foods and exercise too little.

title: The Hair of My Chin
description: Q. If I tweeze out the single hair that grows from a facial mole, will it cause cancer, as my friend insists?

title: South Africa Unions Strike Suspended
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  South Africas trade unions Monday suspended an almost  three-week-old strike by hundreds of thousands of government workers that had closed schools and hamstrung ambitious new efforts to expand urgently needed medical services in the regions richest but most inequitable economy.

title: Surviving by Disguising: Natures Game of Charades
description: One bright October morning, Fabiano Calleia, a researcher with the Federal University of Amazonas, was out in the lowland rainforest of Manaus, Brazil, tracking his usual group of eight pied tamarins as the small, dark monkeys with their dapper white shrugs grazed on the fruits of a fig tree. Suddenly the breakfast calm was shattered by the distinctive sound of a baby tamarins cry  a series of short, sharp whistles, like a boiling teapot doing Morse code.

title: Nostrums: A Bit of Marijuana Is Found to Ease Pain
description: People with chronic pain who took just a puff of marijuana three times a day got some mild pain relief and, with rare exceptions, did so without getting high, a Canadian study reports. (Yes, they inhaled.)

description: A new automated test for drug-resistant tuberculosis gives accurate results in two hours instead of four to eight weeks, scientists said last week, and public health officials greeted the news enthusiastically, saying it could greatly speed up diagnosis.

description: ISTANBUL  When the United States plays Angola in basketball, it is impossible not to recall Charles Barkley. During the Dream Teams march of domination in the 1992 Summer Olympics, Barkley had a memorable moment in a pregame news conference.

title: In Feast of Data on BPA Plastic, No Final Answer
description: The research has been going on for more than 10 years. Studies number in the hundreds. Millions of dollars have been spent. But government health officials still cannot decide whether the chemical bisphenol-A, or BPA, a component of some plastics, is safe. The substance lines most food and drink cans, and is used to make hard, clear plastic bottles, containers and countless other products. Nearly everyone is exposed to it.

In a Fight for a Tree, Ants Thwart Elephants
description: Campers know the pesky feeling of ants crawling up and down their arms and legs.

description: The Times's Karen Crouse talks about how players react to playing a match that lasts five sets.

description: In hospitals, there is a special kind of communication among doctors and nurses, an essential skill not easily learned. Ive come to call it the Rattle.

description: As students around the country go back to school and hit the books, scientists are offering new insights into the best ways to study and learn, reports Benedict Carey in the Science Times Mind column. He writes:

title: Putin, Citing Roosevelt, Hints at a 3rd-Term Bid
description: MOSCOW  For months, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin has done nothing to dampen speculation that he is seriously considering a bid to return to the presidency in the 2012 election. On Monday night, he offered another hint at his plans by referring to the political career of a former president of a different country: Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: Tate Modern Expansion Is the Cost of Success
description: LONDON  When the Tate Modern opened here 10 years ago it was the first new national museum built in Britain in 100 years and the first museum in London devoted solely to modern art. A hulking brick building that was a former power station on the south side of the Thames River at Bankside, a slowly gentrifying area just opposite St. Pauls Cathedral, the $208 million museum captivated the art world and made a city better known for its stuffier, historic collections into an international mecca for new art.

title: In Japan, a Frail Ozawa Conducts Only One Tchaikovsky Movement
description: MATSUMOTO, Japan  As classical music lovers in New York and New England fret over the fitness of James Levine to start a demanding season at the Metropolitan Opera and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, grave concern over the health of another peripatetic maestro has spread to three continents. Like Mr. Levine, Seiji Ozawa has had a series of ailments in recent years, including pneumonia, shingles, sciatica and, this year, cancer of the esophagus.

title: Courtside: Understanding the Fifth Set
description: Karen Crouse, who wrote Monday about the psychology behind the fifth set, discusses this concept further for The Timess U.S. Open video series Courtside.

title: A Musical Question: Does a Quartet Sound Different in the Dark?
description: Michel Galante, the director of the Argento Chamber Ensemble, has had a longtime fascination with the music of Georg Friedrich Haas and has included his works in his groups programs for the last several years. And as the musical force behind the Moving Sounds Festival, which opened on Thursday, he unleashed a torrent of Mr. Haass work in New York last weekend.

title: Beach Reads Finished, Its Time for the Big Books
description: If summer is the sleepy season in book publishing, the fall always seems to make up for it.

title: How Colombia Meets America, but Not Quite
description: The stories in Patricia Engels striking debut collection are like snapshots from someones photo album: glimpses of relatives, friends, lovers and acquaintances, sometimes posing, sometimes caught by the camera unawares. There are portraits of Latinos in suburban Gringolandia, and portraits of young drifters in Miami, 16 of them sharing a single apartment, mattresses crammed together on the floor like it was war times. Theres a skinny 16-year-old boy who always wears faded jeans and a white button-down shirt that looked like it only got washed in the sink, a high school mean girl who develops a fatal case of anorexia, a womanizing pot dealer who becomes the narrators best friend and a Colombian beauty queen who comes to America and is forced into prostitution.

title: Air Products Raises Airgas Offer to $65.50 a Share
description: 6:00 p.m. | Updated Air Products and Chemicals on Monday raised its takeover offer for Airgas to $5.48 billion in cash, as it pressed forward with a proxy fight over the Airgas board of directors.

title: Postracial Vigilantes in a World in Peril
description: We are separatists, not supremacists, the sedately spoken businessman says. We are God-fearing patriots. And in a time when black radicals are in power in this country, we are desperately trying to remind our citizens of their founding beliefs.

title: Frustration Simmers but Doesnt Boil Over in Loss
description: A. J. Burnett has a temper. Earlier this season, Burnett had to leave a Yankees game because he pounded his hands bloody on a clubhouse door after a frustrating inning.

title: A Game Thats So Out of Hand That Perez Gets to Pitch
description: WASHINGTON  Half Street, which leads to the center-field gates of Nationals Park, turns into a carnival before most Washington Nationals games. Vendors line the sidewalks, and there is a patio with live music and free-flowing beer.

title: Parades and Politics Across the Nation
description: Midterm races are gaining momentum in Delaware, Illinois and Arizona.

title: Tasty Vegan Food? Cupcakes Show It Can Be Done
description: Many people equate a vegan diet with deprivation, thinking that recipes prepared without eggs, butter, meat or other animal products are certain to be tasteless and boring.

title: A Rallying Cry Amid Attack Ads in Delaware
description: DOVER, Del.  Steve Bentz, a compact man sporting a blond flattop and a blue beer party T-shirt, was thrilled to meet Christine ODonnell, a conservative running for the Senate, over the Labor Day weekend.

title: In Arizona, Corn With Politics on the Side
description: CHINO VALLEY, Ariz.  The hugely popular Corn Dinner here is in its 64th year, and Carrie Zambrano, as the organizer, sends out invitations to political candidates far and wide offering them the opportunity to serve. Party label means not a thing to her with 6,000 cobs to sling in one night.

description: NAPERVILLE, Ill.  From a tiny booth at a festival here, a radio station host gave Representative Mark Steven Kirk, the Republican candidate for Senate, a moment to make his pitch between plugs for free massages and the corn dogs being sold a few booths away.

title: Always in Its Element, No Matter the Weather
description: With summer on the wane and autumn on the way, Natures where you want to be. And theres no more bracing or reposeful place to find it than Storm King Art Center, one of the countrys premier outdoor sculpture parks, set on 500 acres of wide-open meadow and woodland in Mountainville, N.Y., about an hours drive north of Manhattan.

title: Storm King Wavefield
description: Maya Lins outdoor installation in Mountainville, N.Y., is rows of rolling hills that change with the light and the season.

title: After Tough Year, New Yorks Haitians Gather
description: The sun rose over the tireless Haitian rara musicians and the throng of ecstatic fans who followed them. A shimmying mother pushed a stroller. A man on roller skates danced into his seventh hour. Two police officers sipped coffee. The fans chanted, The day is coming.

title: Provocateur Returns to P.S. 1, but Not to Provoke
description: No one could turn out the lights at the performative discussion between the provocative performance artist Ann Liv Young and the artist A. L. Steiner at the sunlit MoMA P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens, on Sunday afternoon. But as it turned out, the mood couldnt have been less like its subject: Ms. Youngs fraught and much-discussed appearance at P.S. 1 in February that ended when the museums director, Klaus Biesenbach, ordered the power shut off.

title: War and the City: The Gyre
description: This is the second of a five-part series, War and the City, by the Iraq war veteran Roy Scranton, chronicling his path from youth to soldier to civilian writer in New York City. To read from the beginning, go to the first installment, March Song.

title: Variations on a Theme of International Terrorism
description: Book to stage to screen is a familiar path, but the journalist Lawrence Wright has found a new variation: from a thick nonfiction book to a one-man Off Broadway show to an HBO documentary. Along the way the material, which began with the Pulitzer Prize-winning Looming Tower: Al-Qaeda and the Road to 9/11 in 2006, has been reviewed and otherwise written about often enough that you may feel you know it, even if you havent read the book or seen the show.

title: Movies, Mountains and High Hopes
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.  If what we hear from down on the plains is true, and film culture is dying, said the Australian director Peter Weir, up in the mountains here to present his latest movie, The Way Back, then perhaps this place can become a kind of Machu Picchu of cinema. Not a ruin, of course, but a fortress and a shrine, a sacred spot where embattled traditions can survive in troubled times.

title: After Antiwar Protest, Blair Cancels Appearance
description: The former British prime minister Tony Blair has canceled the next book signing of his new memoir, A Journey, which was scheduled for Wednesday at Waterstones bookstore in London, The Associated Press reported. After antiwar demonstrators threw plastic bottles, eggs and flip-flops at Mr. Blair on Saturday as he entered a Dublin bookstore, he said he did not want to further inconvenience the public with the inevitable hassle caused by protesters. Dominic Myers, the managing director of Waterstones, said the cancellation was a matter of regret.

title: Art Critics Pan Museum and Dylan Exhibition
description: Bob Dylans latest exhibition of paintings was panned by Danish art critics after its opening on Saturday at the National Gallery in Copenhagen, Agence France-Presse reported. When we talk about music, Bob Dylan is one of the great Picassos of the 20th century, but this is not the case for his painting, the reviewer for the daily newspaper Berlingske Tidende wrote of Mr. Dylans Brazil Series, a collection of 40 acrylic paintings  including The Argument, below left  inspired by his travels in the cities, slums and countryside of Brazil, as well as eight drawings done specifically for the museum. Several other publications also criticized Mr. Dylans talent, and the museum, known in Denmark as the Statens Museum for Kunst, for picking the show because of the artists commercial appeal instead of the artistic value. Karsten Ohrt, the museums director, defended both, saying that Mr. Dylan was a quality painter and that his work interested Danish painters and art collectors. The exhibition runs through Jan. 30.

title: Footnote
description: The writer, director and producer Tyler Perry has announced a release date of Nov. 5 for his film version of Ntozake Shanges play For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide When the Rainbow Is Enuf, Variety reported. Lionsgate is producing this adaptation of the play of poems about love, sex, abortion and rape, with a screenplay by Mr. Perry and a cast including Whoopi Goldberg, Phylicia Rashad, Anika Noni Rose, Loretta Devine, Kerry Washington, Janet Jackson, Kimberly Elise and Macy Gray. The original stage production eventually made its way to Broadway and was nominated for a Tony award for best play in 1977.

title: High Hopes For Poussin Sale at Christies
description: Christies in London is expecting a big sale of a painting by the French master Nicolas Poussin at a December auction. Christies said it was expecting the painting, Ordination, above, one of a set of seven 17th-century works by Poussin depicting the sacraments, to sell for between $23 million and $31 million at the old masters and 19th-century Art auction on Dec. 7, Reuters reported. That high estimate was based on last years old masters sale, when a drawing by Raphael sold for $47.9 million and a painting by Rembrandt went for $33.2 million. The seven paintings in the Poussin series were sold to the Belvoir estate of the Dukes of Rutland in the late 18th century. Of those works Penance was destroyed by a fire, and Baptism was acquired by the National Gallery of Art in Washington in 1946. The five remaining  Ordination, Confirmation, Eucharist, Extreme Unction and Marriage  have been on loan to the National Gallery in London since 2003. In a statement the estate said the sale proceeds would go to the restoration and long-term preservation of Belvoir Castle and Estate.

title: James Cameron Plans Protest Film In 3-D
description: The director James Cameron has announced plans to make another 3-D film about an indigenous tribe trying to preserve its land. Unlike his Oscar-winning Avatar, however, this film will be a documentary about the Xikrin-Kayap tribe in Brazil and its attempts to stop the construction of the Belo Monte hydroelectric dam, which is to be built near tribal lands on the Xingu River, a tributary of the Amazon, Agence France-Presse reported. Construction of the dam, which is to be the worlds third largest, will require the flooding of 200 square miles of the Xingu River basin. Opposition groups say the flooding will displace about 12,000 people and destroy the fishing industry, but the Brazilian government maintains that the lands will not be harmed and that it is taking environmental issues into consideration. In an interview Sunday in the newspaper Folha de So Paulo, Mr. Cameron said that when the Xikrin-Kayap leaders asked for his help, he could not turn away. I want to take a 3-D camera to film how they live, their culture, he added. Mr. Cameron has made previous trips to Brazil to show his support and has already made a short film about the issue, which will be included on the forthcoming Avatar special-edition DVD. Work on the dam is scheduled to begin late this year or in early 2011.

title: Germany: Deal Reached to Extend Nuclear Power Use
description: Reversing a popular decision to shut down 17 aging nuclear power plants by 2025, Germanys coalition government agreed on Sunday to extend their use by up to 14 years, news services here reported on Monday. The decision, if approved by Parliament, would upend a plan adopted in 2002 that was opposed by energy producers, but supported by a public wary about an accident. The proposal would allow plants built before 1980 to remain open 8 additional years, while newer plants would be able to continue for 14 more years. Chancellor Angela Merkel hailed the plan, saying it would allow Germany the time to develop renewable resources. The deal also calls for reactor operators to pay billions of dollars in new taxes and fees to help finance a fund for renewable energy, news agencies reported.

title: Britain: Strike Disrupts Subway Service in London
description: The 3.5 million riders on the London Tube faced disruptions on Monday when, at 5 p.m., as many as 10,000 subway drivers, station workers and engineers staged the first of a series of 24-hour strikes over employment cuts. Mayor Boris Johnson called in 100 extra buses and a 500-berth boat that will carry 10,000 people along the Thames River to help commuters.

title: Who Should Provide Anesthesia Care?
description: Can a highly trained nurse deliver anesthetics as well as a physician who has specialized in anesthesiology, or does the nurse require close medical supervision? That issue emerges from two recent studies and from Californias decision last year to join 14 other states in freeing the nurses from a federal requirement that they be supervised by a physician. Colorado seems poised to join the group.

description: NEWARK  Shortly after landing at Malcolm X Shabazz High School as a Teach for America recruit, Dominique D. Lee grew disgusted with a system that produced ninth graders who could not name the seven continents or the governor of their state. He started wondering: What if I were in charge?

title: Do Daughters Cause Divorce?

Parents of three girls, for instance, are 10 percent more likely to split than are parents of three boys. And, they found, an unmarried couple is more likely to marry if they learn their unborn child will be a boy than a girl.

He also compared the book (narrated by a time-machine repairman who lives with a virtual dog and a neurotic piece of software) to the work of Douglas Adams. Like Adams, Monson wrote, Yu is very funny, usually proportional to the wildness of his inventions.

In the end, Sharapova hit 32 clean winners, but her 36 unforced errors gave Wozniacki enough of a margin to pull ahead in each set.

title: Clubhouse Confidential
description: Gay Talese left the prime real estate to his colleagues. Let other reporters write stories that would land their bylines on the front page. That meant covering the news. For Talese, the news was never the story.

title: Sons of Captain to Carry On Deadliest Catch
description: The two sons of Capt. Phil Harris, a fisherman whose death was documented on Deadliest Catch last season, will remain on the series in future seasons.

title: Mens Group Gets Men Talking
description: Whats on your minds today, gentlemen? Paul Heron, a social worker, asked the circle of men. Thats the way he convenes most Wednesday afternoon gatherings of the Riverdale Senior Services centers mens group.

title: At the Asian Feastival in Queens
description: As with so much in life, you get what you pay for in food festivals. Or feastivals.

title: Many Kinds of Universes, and None Require God
description: Stephen Hawking, the most revered scientist since Einstein, is a formidable mathematician and a formidable salesman. I want my books sold on airport bookstalls, he has impishly declared, and hes learned how to put them there.

title: Bonds: Higher Returns Equal Greater Risk
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Prasada Capital.

title: Critic of Russia Security Gets Reprieve
description: MOSCOW  For more than two years, the mayor of a Siberian village was held in a pretrial detention center after she filed complaints against the successor agency to the Soviet-era K.G.B. Finally freed on bail this summer after her case began attracting attention, she was unexpectedly given a further reprieve on Tuesday.

title: A New Theory on the Origin of the Lewis Chessmen
description: The Lewis Chessmen are the most famous and important chess pieces in history. They have a long historical and scholarly record, part of which is that they were made in Norway roughly 800 years ago. But now two Icelandic men are challenging that belief and trying to prove that the pieces came from their country.

title: The Goldman Contender for the HSBC Job
description: John L. Thornton, the former co-president of Goldman Sachs, is considered to be among the possible leading candidates to replace Stephen Green as chairman of HSBC

title: What Were Reading: More on the Skills Mismatch
$600 Billion
description: Oy, it seems that another out-of-context quote of mine is being used to claim that I thought the Obama stimulus plan was just dandy. So: back in 2008, I wrote this piece in which I called for stimulus of 4 percent of GDP, or $600 billion. Didnt we get that, and more?

title: State Gains Would Give Redistricting Edge to G.O.P.
description: The midterm elections are being closely watched to determine whether Republicans will have a majority in Congress for the next two years. But it is the outcome of a lower-profile battle over state legislatures that could strengthen the Republican Party for a decade.

title: Leader of the Pack
description: They treated me like an invisible man, Bruce Davidson told me. I was a shadow.

title: N.F.L. Continues to Adjust Position of Umpire
description: The N.F.L. sent a memo to teams Tuesday outlining what it hopes will be the final tweaks to the umpire move to the offensive backfield. The move has provoked criticism, particularly from the Indianapolis Colts, because of concerns that the move slows down hurry-up offenses.

title: TimesCast | September 7, 2010
description: Today, the politics over President Obama's latest attempt to stimulate the economy, hundreds of looted Iraqi artifacts are returned to Baghdad, and controversy over the health risks of BPA.

title: The College Essay as an Early Memoir
description: Last weekend, I participated in a weekend writing workshop. In a sun-filled room overlooking the Berkshires, I sat amid 30 or so other writers for two days, as we talked, listened, read and practiced the art of memoir writing.

title: Seeking Your Back-to-School Admissions Questions
description: The end of Labor Day weekend is the unofficial beginning of the college admissions season  as high school seniors contemplate pushing the button on early and rolling applications, and juniors start to compile lists of colleges and draft essays.

title: Kazan Documentary, With Scorsese Pedigree, Will Come to TV, DVD and Theaters
description: Wider audiences will soon have an opportunity to weigh in on a Martin Scorsese documentary about the filmmaker Elia Kazan, which has already drawn attention at the Venice and Telluride film festivals.

title: Ads Urge Wineries to Stick a Cork in It
description: The Portuguese cork industry, backed by the Portuguese government, is undertaking an American-style campaign with a green twist.

title: Listening To The Bond Market  Or Not
description: Stan Collender has been getting sort of, well, shrill over the way in which austerity enthusiasts told us that we had to utterly obey what the bond market was saying when interest rates were rising, but are telling us to ignore the market now that rates are very low.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of Havas, promoted two executives to managing partners. They are Tom Guerin, executive vice president and executive director, and Neela Pal, executive vice president and global director for brand and business strategy.

description: Q: (Reader)

title: Q&A: Christmas in Mexico for Two
description: My boyfriend and I want to take a vacation to an international urban destination over Christmas break (late December/early January). We were thinking of Turkey, but a quick scan of airfares showed high prices (more than $850). And I read that winters in Turkey are cold. Would you suggest some places that we should consider?

title: Yesbuttery
description: Portmanteau term denoting agreement tempered by a contrary view.

title: Woods Was the Easy Ryder Cup Pick for Pavin, Fowler the Final One
description: With the New York Stock Exchange as a backdrop, the United States Ryder Cup captain, Corey Pavin, rounded out his 12-man team Tuesday with three blue-chip choices and one initial public offering with some real potential.

title: Enterprise Deal Simplifies Complex Family Tree
description: Enterprise Products Partners, one of the nations biggest pipeline operators, said on Tuesday that it would buy Enterprise GP Holdings in a deal valued at more than $8 billion, simplifying the corporate structure of the group founded by the late billionaire Dan Duncan.

title: On Bikes, Skinny Dipping and Rude Neighbors
description: A Car Accident, and a Debate Over Bikes (Again)

title: If There Is Interest, Children Will Learn
description: Thats the lesson of this TED talk from Sugata Mitra. Mr. Mitra conducts experiments in which he plants computers in poor villages in the developing world, without instruction or supervision, and watches what happens.

title: The Start-Ups Chicken-and-Egg Dilemma, Part 2
description: Thanks to all who shared their knowledge with in-depth assessments of the issues presented in She Owns Its case study, Getting Started: The Chicken-and-Egg Question. Commenters explored numerous angles in their advice for Fran Gunsaulis, the owner of Oh Baby Foods. Some popular suggestions: find an investor, stay independent, ramp up e-commerce, raise prices and drop the delivery service  or at least forget about franchising for now.

title: TimesCast: Obamas Economy Jump-Start
description: On todays TimesCast, Associate National Editor Marcus Mabry discusses President Obamas latest effort to stimulate the economy with Sheryl Gay Stolberg, White House correspondent.

title: Reactions to Obamas Business Tax Write-Off Proposals
description: 2:09 p.m. | Updated

title: Paladino, Insider, Runs Against Establishment
description: As he wages an insurgent campaign for governor of New York, Carl P. Paladino has styled himself as the anti-establishment candidate bent on reforming a state government that he says needs someone who can take out the trash.

title: Inside Out | Necessary Luxuries
description: In an interview last week for a blog called A Lovely Being, I was asked what advice I had for someone who was doing up her first apartment. The question made me think about decorating my own first apartment, the things that I did then, which pieces have faded from memory and which ones I still love.

title: The Boston Post Road: A Path Through History
description: Shoppers looking for a bargain along Connecticuts heavily developed Route 1 corridor may not realize it, but their wheels are turning on historical ground. According to Eric Jaffes absorbing new book, The Kings Best Highway, the road that is now cluttered with gas stations, outlet shops and fast-food restaurants was in the 17th century a narrow wilderness trail, and the traveler making the round trip between New York and Boston would probably want to budget a month for the journey.

title: Is BPA Safe? Europe Also Seeks Answers
description: European health officials seem to be in the same boat as those in America who are having trouble deciding whether the chemical BPA, or bisphenol-A, is safe.

title: Follow the Open Via Twitter, Day 8
description: 11:08 p.m. | Updated  Gerry Marzorati, one-half of the Open House duo, is covering the United States Open via Twitter. Now that all the matches (except Nadal-Lopez) have concluded, go directly to gerrynyt to read his observations.

title: Spitzer, Once Dubious, Now Supports Cuomo
description: Eliot Spitzer, who last spring expressed strong reservations about Andrew M. Cuomos qualifications to be his elected successor as governor, now says he will vote for him.

title: The 2 Deal Makers Who Share Oracles Presidency
description: The hiring of Mark V. Hurd (pictured) as Oracles newest co-president arises in part from the former Hewlett-Packard chiefs close friendship with the tech titan Lawrence J. Ellison.

title: Looted Iraqi Artifacts Returned
description: Stephen Farrell reports from Baghdad on the return of Iraqi artifacts that were looted.

title: Hes O.K.: Rocky Horror Creator Given Residency in New Zealand
description: Talk about your celluloid jams: at the start of the summer, Richard OBrien, the author and composer of the cross-dressing cult classic The Rocky Horror Show (and its midnight movie incarnation, The Rocky Horror Picture Show) applied for residency in New Zealand, where he planned to retire to the coastal town of Katikati. But like a statuesque man-monster climbing a small replica of the RKO Pictures tower, the British-born Mr. OBrien, 68, was shot down: New Zealand immigration officials said he did not meet the criteria, which include being age 55 or under and having a job offer.

title: Hussein Kalashnikov Returned to Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  This chrome-plated Kalashnikov AK-47 assault rifle, with a pearl hand grip and receiver, was manufactured by an Iraqi weapons factory which produced personalized assault rifles for Saddam Husseins family and friends. Bearing a tiny image of the dictator near the sighting mechanism, it was looted after the 2003 invasion and has been returned to Iraq along with hundreds of other items, as Steven Lee Myers reports.

title: Looking at Hamas and Seeing the I.R.A.
description: As international attention focused on efforts to turn swords into plowshares in the Middle East, Gerry Adams, who convinced the I.R.A. to lay down its weapons and embrace politics, revealed on Monday that he had been engaged in the secret talks that led ETA, the Basque separatist group, to declare a cease-fire this week. The announcement came via a videotaped message.

title: Quote Unquote | Trash and Vaudeville
description: Ke$ha tells MTV how she acquired her ridiculous wardrobe. I understand she raids dumpsters for her clothes, but are they dumpsters behind a Halloween store?

title: Edge Lost, Querrey Cannot Catch Up
description: Early in his fourth-round United States Open match against Stanislas Wawrinka, Sam Querreys serve looked like an unstoppable weapon. Querrey strolled around his side of the court as if he were ready to extend his run as the last American man in the American Grand Slam.

title: Iraqi Treasures Return, but Questions Remain
description: BAGHDAD  Iraq announced on Tuesday the return of hundreds of looted antiquities that had ended up in the United States, even as a senior official disclosed that 632 pieces repatriated last year and turned over to the office of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki were now unaccounted for.

title: G.I. Deaths Are First for U.S. After Combat Missions End
description: BAGHDAD  Two American soldiers were killed and nine were wounded on Tuesday when a firefight erupted inside an Iraqi Army base north of Baghdad, American and Iraqi officials said. They were the first American casualties since President Obama declared an official end to the United States combat mission in Iraq a week ago.

title: Debate in House Race Stirs Big Passions for a Small Audience
description: It sounded a lot like amateur hour as a long-awaited radio debate began on Tuesday between Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, the nine-term incumbent from Manhattan and Queens, and her challenger in the Democratic primary, Reshma Saujani, a 34-year-old who was a lawyer for a hedge fund.

title: Saturday Night Live Cast Adds Four and Loses One More
description: Saturday Night Live has finalized its cast for the coming 36th season of the NBC late-night sketch series, hiring four new featured players while dropping a performer who was added to its ensemble last year. The information was provided by a person with firsthand knowledge of planning at Saturday Night Live but who was not given permission by NBC to speak on the matter.

title: H.P. Sues Hurd Over His New Job at Oracle
description: Hewlett-Packard on Tuesday sued Mark V. Hurd, its former chairman and chief executive, one day after he joined rival Oracle as co-president.

title: Trying to Unravel an Unsolved Murder, Surrounded by Living Reminders
description: His name is Carlos, and he lives in Woodhaven, Queens, with his parents, and he has a child. Thats about all Martha Mora knows about the man.

title: H.P. Sues Its Ex-Chief in New Job
description: Hewlett-Packards tumultuous breakup with its former chief executive Mark V. Hurd may soon warrant its own reality TV show.

title: Courtside: 'Open House'
description: Gerry Marzorati and Michael Kimmelman are covering the nooks and crannies of the Open. A report from the second week of the tournament.

title: School of Rap | Big Easy Edition
description: The fifth anniversary of Hurricane Katrina did not go by quietly last month, but a candidate for this years most unlikely benefit record may have been overlooked  a forgivable failure of marketing on the part of Michael Patrick Welch, the New Orleans teacher who recorded and produced the album.

title: Blast Strikes Pakistani Police Area
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A powerful blast ripped through a residential compound for police officials and their families in Pakistans restive northwest on Tuesday evening, killing at least 18 people, including women and children, officials said.

title: Chicagos Mayor Daley: Ive Done My All
description: 5:35 p.m. | Updated  Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago said Tuesday that he would not run for re-election when his term expires next year, an announcement that could have implications from the Windy City to the White House.

title: Shirov Wins Shanghai Masters
Flea Theater Invests in a Permanent Home
description: With small theater companies across New York struggling to make rent or renegotiate leases in a difficult economic climate, executives of Off Off Broadways Flea Theater said on Tuesday that they have purchased a building downtown to create a new home, concluding that buying instead of renting was necessary for its survival.

title: Street Cred vs. Green Cred
description: When it comes to environmental degradation, those who live and work in the open air are more exposed than most. Someone strumming a guitar for tips on the sidewalk or reading tarot cards at the curb or operating a pedicab cannot help but breathe in the pollution in the air.

title: Letter: Another Taste of the Fair
description: To the Editor: Nothing wrong with reminding readers of the book, musical and movie State Fair in Life Spins On, But the Midway Still Beckons (Aug. 29), but for a more contemporary account, the author might have referred us to the David Foster Wallace essay Ticket to the Fair, reprinted as Getting Away From Already Being Pretty Much Away From It All in the collection A Supposedly Fun Thing Ill Never Do Again.

title: Letter: The Way It Was
description: To the Editor: Regarding the article Nothing Boutique About It (Aug. 15): There are few places in the world that have the Greenbriers old-time elegant ambience. In managements attempt to please the regulars while also attracting the masses, the Greenbrier may be losing much of its uniqueness and charm. Whats wrong with timeless traditional?

title: Potashs Chief Speaks Out on BHP Bid
description: William Doyle, the chief executive of the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, hasnt been shy about dismissing BHP Billitons nearly $40 billion takeover offer for his company.

title: Migrant Berry Pickers Complain of Conditions in Sweden
description: The image of migrant workers freezing, living in squalor or demanding better pay and conditions is not typical in Sweden.

title: European Official Calls for Backing Building Projects
description: In his first State of the Union speech, Jos Manuel Barroso, the European Commission president, called Tuesday for the creation of bonds to initiate infrastructure projects and tackle unemployment.

title: More Evidence for Store Brands
description: Earlier this year, I wrote a Bucks post about how consumers are increasingly opting for cheaper store-brand groceries and I shared my own anecdotal evidence that some store-brand products are just as good as their name-brand counterparts.

title: "Zombieville"
description: The first "Zombieville" commercial from the Truth campaign that appeared during "The Real World: New Orleans."

title: Youzhny Moves Into Quarterfinals
description: Despite hitting 40 unforced errors, five more than his opponent, Mikhail Youzhny of Russia worked his way into the United States Open mens quarterfinals with a steady, four-set victory over Tommy Robredo of Spain, 7-5, 6-2, 4-6, 6-4.

title: Elite or Expansionist? Soho Clubs Want to Be Both
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  Nick Jones, the founder of Soho House, a chain of members-only clubs that includes an outpost here, knows about exclusivity. Last winter, after he found the New York Soho House too crowded, he cut several hundred members from the rolls, sacrificing revenue to maintain the cachet his company depends on.

title: Following the Opens Eighth Day
description: Gerry Marzorati, one-half of the Open House duo, is covering the United States Open via his smart phone, mostly through Twitter but also through live-blogging. To read his updates from Tuesday, click on Read More. You can also go to gerrynyt.

title: Critics Picks Video: Melvin and Howard
description: This week, A. O. Scott explores the American Dream and its paradoxes with Jonathan Demmes Melvin and Howard. The film tells the story of Melvin Dummar (Paul LeMat), a working man, who finds Howard (Jason Robards) in the desert after a motorcycle accident and gives him a ride into town. Howard turns out to be the reclusive billionaire Howard Hughes, who leaves Melvin a significant inheritance in his will. The movie asks questions about the complexities of our relationship to money and Mr. Scott calls it an affectionate, authentic portrait of a typically contradictory American character. Have you seen Melvin and Howard? Please share your thoughts.

title: Who Hates Making School Lunch?
description: Jennifer Rosenstrach loves dinner. Loves it so much that Rosenstrach, a freelance writer and editor, has created a Web site, DinneraLoveStory.com, devoted to helping parents figure out how to get family dinner on the table. Loves it so much that she has kept a journal of what she has eaten for dinner every night for 12 years. (You can read Susan Dominuss column about that dinner journal here.)

title: Streaming Your Entire Computer to a Television
description: If you want to watch Web-enabled video on your television, you could buy a number of gadgets that will hook up directly to your TV set. But most of these contraptions offer only a narrowhallwayof content and dont allow full access to the Internet or a Web browser.

description: Behind the scenes at the chef Daniel Humms four-star restaurant.

title: Jesse Owens Dies of Cancer at 66; Hero of the 1936 Berlin Olympics
description: Jesse Owens, whose four gold medals at the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin made him perhaps the greatest and most famous athlete in track and field history, died of lung cancer yesterday in Tucson, Ariz. He was 66 years old.

title:
Young Black Leader Dies in Detention in
South Africa, Raising Fears of New Unrest
description: East London, South Africa, Sept. 13--Steven Biko, probably the most influential young black leader in South Africa, died while in police detention last night, allegedly after a hunger striker, and there were fears that his death could increase racial tension.

title: Sin, the Hot New Government Revenue Strategy
description: A few months ago, I wrote about increasing popularity of sin taxes, which many states were levying or at the very least increasing in order to scrape together more money.

title: Fashion Week Preview | Siki Im
description: Theres no lack of cultural references in the architect turned mens wear designer Siki Ims life  he was born in Cologne, Germany, to Korean parents; had a classical German education; studied at Oxford; and now lives in New York. So when the Ecco Domani Fashion Foundation award winner sets out to create a symbolic mash-up, hes got the chops to do it. His collections make tongue-in-cheek literary references, blur the lines between masculine and feminine attire, and even manage to slyly subvert Savile Row tailoring. Not bad for someone who says he got into fashion by accident. The Moment stopped by Ims studio recently for a preview of his spring 2011 collection, which hell unveil in a presentation tomorrow night.

title: Leadership, Personal Courage, Devotion to Troops Won for Pershing Affection of Nation
description: John Joseph Pershing, Commander in Chief of the American Expeditionary Force in the first World War, entered the military service--in which he was to rise to the summit of distinction--almost by accident, for he was planning to be a lawyer when he saw the announcement of an examination for admittance to West Point which changed his career.

title: Rabin and Arafat Seal Their Accord as Clinton Applauds 'Brave Gamble'
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- In a triumph of hope over history, Yitzhak Rabin, the Prime Minister of Israel, and Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the P.L.O., shook hands today on the White House lawn, sealing the first agreement between Jews and Palestinians to end their conflict and share the holy land along the River Jordan that they both call home.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 7
description: A view of the day in sports, with the world wresting championships in Moscow and the world basketball championships in Istanbul.

title: Margaret Sanger Is Dead at 82; Led Campaign for Birth Control
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 6--Margaret Sanger, the birth control pioneer, died this afternoon of arteriosclerosis in the Valley House Convalescent Center. She would have been 83 years old on Sept. 14.
Moscow, Monday, Sept. 14--The Soviet Union hit the moon with a space rocket early this morning.

title: Packaging Is All the Rage, and Not in a Good Way
description: SEATTLE  Doug Herringtons office at Amazon.com suggests that he is particularly bad at getting items out of their packages. Along his wall, there is a Philips Norelco shaver still in its plastic clamshell casing, coffee pods in their retail display containers and a bottle of Tide inside a box.

title: Minority Businesses Struggle to Secure City Contracts
description: Businesses owned by women and members of minorities still struggle to secure city contracts, despite nearly five years of legal mandates and targeted goals set by the city, says a new City Council report [pdf  see also below].

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Yes, Pakistan leads the report again on Tuesday, with photographs by Carl De Souza, Damir Sagolj and Asif Hassan, because the news is unrelenting and almost unrelentingly bad. After scathing criticism that they were unprepared for the disaster and inept in their initial response, Carlotta Gall reported, government officials, ministers and even President Asif Ali Zardari are crisscrossing flood-affected areas of the country in a frantic effort to ease public anger and despair. Pakistani officials, diplomats and aid workers warn that while civil unrest has so far been averted, the aftermath of the worst-ever flooding in Pakistan could destabilize the country in the months to come and aggravate the already deep regional, sectarian and class fissures.

title: Okie to Beatle: Kennedy Center Honorees
description: WASHINGTON  Oprah Winfrey said her initial reaction to being told she was a 2010 Kennedy Center honoree could be summed up in two words: Wowie gazowie. Merle Haggard? He compared being named an honoree to a nice kick in the stomach.

title: The Battle for Stuyvesant Town
description: The fate of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village rests on the interpretation of one clause in a legal agreement.

title: How Blame Bush Plays in Midterm Polls
description: Invoking George W. Bushs name and linking him to Republican candidates in the 2006 and 2008 elections was certainly good strategy for Democrats  he was actually in office during those years and was a deeply unpopular president.

description: Images from Tuesdays matches at the United States Open in Flushing Meadows.

description: How do you spell independent in Florida?

title: Inquiry Into Paper for Bank Notes
description: De La Rue, which helps make paper currency for 150 countries, said Tuesday that the British authorities had been called in to investigate deliberately falsified tests on paper used to make bank notes.

title: Bank Panel Nears Deal On Tighter Regulations
description: Regulators from the worlds largest economies appear close to agreement on tightening rules intended to prevent future financial crises, prompting renewed warnings from the banking industry that economic growth could suffer if institutions were required to raise more capital to insulate against market shocks.

title: Britain Backs New E.U. Oversight Plan
description: BRUSSELS  Britains chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, on Tuesday endorsed a variety of new watchdog agencies to supervise financial activities across the European Union.

title: Send Us Your Back-to-School Photos
description: As the 2010-11 school year begins in New York City on Wednesday morning, we invite you to submit your photographs from the first day. Parents, show us your kids, their teachers and your fellow parents as pencils are sharpened, new backpacks donned and tales of summer camp recounted. Teachers, share the scene around your classroom and in your schools hallways.

title: Homes for $875,000
description: A seven-bedroom English tudor in Kansas City, Mo., a two bedroom bungalow in Sarasota, Fla, and a three-bedroom town house in Washington.

title: Maersk to Use Cleaner Fuel in Its Hong Kong Shipping
description: HONG KONG  Aiming to reduce noxious fumes in one of the most densely populated parts of Asia, the Danish shipping giant Maersk Line said Tuesday that its ships would switch to low-sulfur fuel when at berth in Hong Kong  a move it hopes will help quicken regulation in Asia.

title: Notes From the Underground | Black Cracker
description: At a party hosted by Original Plumbing, a quarterly magazine devoted to transsexual male culture, at the Bell House in Gowanus, Brooklyn, Black Cracker (n Ellison Glenn) took the stage by storm, unleashing a barrage of rapid-fire lyrics to thick bounce tracks. Included was a lament on his lack of cash flow in which he talked about his Metrocard or quarters since he cant afford an unlimited.

title: Top-Seeded Womens Doubles Team Ousted
description: The top-seeded womens doubles team of Gisela Dulko of Argentina and Flavia Pennetta of Italy fell in surprisingly easy fashion to Vania King of the United States and Yaroslava Shvedova of Kazakhstan.

description: WASHINGTON
