title: Who Needs the Gastrotourists?
description: TWENTY years ago, when Fifth Avenue in Park Slope could still be called marginal in the pages of The New York Times, Michael Ayoub opened Cucina there, on the corner of Carroll Street. The restaurant was an elegantly casual Italian trattoria that managed to charm both a burgeoning population of young brownstoners with jobs in Manhattan and the neighborhoods old guard of professional-class Brooklynites.

title: Assemblyman Voices Concerns About New Voting System
description: Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky said on Tuesday afternoon that he had asked the Justice Department to assign observers to New York City for next weeks primary election because he was concerned that the use of a new voting method might result in voter confusion and disenfranchisement.

title: HSBC Chairman Joins British Government
description: LONDON  Stephen K. Green is stepping down as chairman of HSBC to join the British government as minister for trade and investment, the bank said Tuesday.

title: Kazan Documentary to TV, DVD and Theaters
description: Wider audiences will soon have an opportunity to weigh in on a documentary by Martin Scorsese, above, about the filmmaker Elia Kazan, which has already drawn attention at the Venice and Telluride film festivals. On Tuesday representatives for Mr. Scorsese said that A Letter to Elia, a documentary directed by Mr. Scorsese and Kent Jones about Kazans life and career, would be shown on PBSs American Masters series on Oct. 4, and included in the Elia Kazan Film Collection boxed set that 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment will release on Nov. 9. The documentary will be screened at the New York Film Festival this month with Kazans feature America, America. The boxed set will contain 15 Kazan films, including 5  A Tree Grows in Brooklyn, Viva Zapata! Man on a Tightrope, Wild River and America, America  that have not been released on DVD. The films will also be shown theatrically; dates and sites will be posted at lettertoelia.com.

title: Godard Wont Pick Up His Honorary Oscar
description: Lest the distinction of an honorary Academy Award contradict his reputation as a film-making provocateur and feisty founding member of the French New Wave movement, Jean-Luc Godard has found a way to have his cake and eat it too: He will not appear in person to accept the award at a ceremony in November, but will probably send a colleague to receive it, The Australian reported. In a brief interview, Mr. Godard, 79, above, told The Australian that he had received a letter from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences notifying him of his honorary Oscar. Though Mr. Godard did not answer additional questions, Anne-Marie Mieville, his wife and collaborator, said he was put off by the fact that the award would be given out at an event held several months before the Oscars ceremony. He just told me, Its not the Oscars, Ms. Mieville said, adding that Mr. Godard would not travel to the United States for the occasion. Hes getting old for that kind of thing, she said. Would you go all that way just for a bit of metal?

title: Booker Prize Shortlist Is Announced
description: Six authors, including Tom McCarthy for his novel C and Emma Donoghue for Room, were named on Tuesday to the shortlist for the 2010 Man Booker Prize for Fiction, the most prestigious literary award in Britain. The other finalists are Peter Carey for Parrot and Olivier in America (Faber & Faber), Damon Galgut for In a Strange Room (Atlantic Books; Grove/Atlantic), Howard Jacobson for The Finkler Question (Bloomsbury) and Andrea Levy for The Long Song (Headline Review; Headline Publishing Group). Mr. Carey, who is Australian, has won the prize twice, in 1988 and 2001. The winner is to be announced on Oct. 12. Each shortlisted author will be awarded 2,500 (about $3,800), and the winner will receive 50,000, about $76,600.

title: Sons to Carry on Deadliest Catch
description: The two sons of Capt. Phil Harris, a fisherman whose death was documented on Deadliest Catch last season, will remain on the series in future seasons. The Discovery Channel said on Tuesday that it had signed a new contract with Josh and Jake Harris, who had worked as deckhands on their fathers boat, the Cornelia Marie, one of several boats featured on that popular reality series. The final episodes of the series last season showed the sons reacting to their fathers stroke and eventual death. Discovery said the Harrises would expand their participation on the show and ultimately increase their experience on the sea with the hopes of becoming captains. It did not specify the terms of the contract.

title: Saturday Night Live Adds Four and Loses One
description: Saturday Night Live has finished casting its 36th season, hiring four new featured players while dropping a performer who was added to its ensemble last year. The information was provided by a person with firsthand knowledge of planning at Saturday Night Live but who was not given permission by NBC to speak on the matter. Jenny Slate, above left, who finished her freshman year at Saturday Night Live in the spring, will not have her contract picked up for a second season, the person said. Will Forte, who performed on and wrote for Saturday Night Live for eight seasons, recently announced that he was departing. The new featured performers this coming season, the person said, will be Taran Killam, above right, an actor and comedian who has appeared on the sketch shows Mad TV and Nick Cannon Presents: Wild N Out and the comedies Scrubs and How I Met Your Mother; Paul Brittain, a performer from the iO Improv Theater in Chicago; Vanessa Bayer, also of iO in Chicago; and Jay Pharoah, a comedian and impressionist. Saturday Night Live will have its season premiere on Sept. 25. Amy Poehler, the S.N.L. alumna and Parks and Recreation star, will be the host, and Katy Perry will be the musical guest.

title: Few Words and a Whole Lotta Pictures
description: In the mythology of rock, Jimmy Page is the great guitar wizard, hurling Led Zeppelins thunder and fire down from the mountaintop. Its an image that the band cultivated, of course, but it wouldnt have stuck if it werent for Mr. Pages skill, finesse and imagination, which made him one of the most influential guitarists in history.

title: The Strange Web Genius of Sean Parker
description: His career as an Internet guru began with being interrogated by federal agents while in high school. Now the Web entrepreneur Sean Parker is about to be portrayed on the big screen by Justin Timberlake.

title: Are Scanners Worth the Risk?
description: THE next time you go through security at the airport, you might be told to empty your pockets, put your hands over your head and stand still while an X-ray machine looks for anything hidden under your clothing.

title: An Outkast Out There by Himself
description: Outkast is gone but not forgotten. Or maybe its forgotten but not gone. Thats more like it, actually. The group  perhaps the most important in Southern rap history, and certainly the most popular  doesnt cast the shadow it did 10 years ago, or even 5. Its home city, Atlanta, has evolved styles at the rate of one or more a year, and increasingly its possible to see Outkast  consisting of Big Boi and Andre 3000  only in a rearview mirror.

title: Collarinis Play Restarts Discussion of His National Affiliation
description: While Andrea Collarini moves through the boys singles draw at the United States Open, discussion is jump-starting again about his move earlier in the year from the Argentine tennis association to the United States Tennis Association.

title: Orlandos Newest Attraction Is Medical
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Just off State Road 417, a five-minute drive east from Orlando International Airport, a 650-acre parcel of land is fast becoming a $2 billion medical campus, including a medical school, research laboratories and hospitals.

title: Lethal Woman With Weapons Is Out for Covert Vengeance
description: Ancient mythology is full of beautiful female warriors who kill men without remorse and in high style. So is modern mythology. Not long ago Russian soldiers in Chechnya and South Ossetia were scared silly with improbable tales of Baltic mercenaries, blue-eyed, ice-blooded snipers sometimes known as White Stockings.

title: Southwest Potatoes
description: Mark Bittman makes a side dish inspired by airplane food, with potatoes, black beans and corn.

title: Ireland Takes Control of Dolphins From Parcells
description: Bill Parcells, the former Giants and Jets coach who has rebuilt five franchises as either a coach or a general manager, will no longer run the Miami Dolphins. On Tuesday, the team abruptly announced in a two-sentence statement that Parcells, who in one season turned a one-win team into the American Football Conference East champion, would remain with the club as a daily consultant but that Jeff Ireland, his protg, would assume full control over all aspects and decisions relating to the team and its support staff.

title: Will Boise State Reach the B.C.S. Final?
description: LANDOVER, Md.  With a little more than two minutes left in Monday nights game, Boise State seemed headed to a loss against Virginia Tech that would inevitably energize the skeptics. The 10th-ranked Hokies had the ball and a four-point lead. The third-ranked Broncos had two timeouts and a prayer. But after a defensive stop, a punt and one more memorable drive, Boise State emerged with a 33-30 victory.

title: Art Team Represents U.S. at 2011 Venice Biennale
description: The artistic team of Jennifer Allora and Guillermo Calzadilla will represent the United States at the 2011 Venice Biennale. The duo, who have been working together since 1995 and live in San Juan, P.R., were chosen by the Federal Advisory Committee on International Exhibitions, a group of arts professionals organized by the National Endowment for the Arts to advise the State Department. Their work explores relationships among art, politics and international identity through performances pieces, sculpture, photography and sound-and-video. This will be the first time a collaborative, rather than a single artist, will represent the United States and the first time that a combination of performance and installation will occupy the pavilion. The Indianapolis Museum of Art was selected as the commissioning institution for the 2011 United States pavilion and Lisa Freiman, chairman of the Indianapolis Museum of Arts contemporary art department, will be the commissioner. She will organize the exhibition, which will include six new works by the collaborative team developed specifically for the United States pavilion, a 1930s Palladian-style structure designed by the architects Delano & Aldrich.

title: British Police May Question Downing Street Adviser on Phone-Hacking

title: In a Golden Land, but Grateful for Brass Rings
description: Terriers, a cop show beginning on Wednesday on FX, is the joint effort of Shawn Ryan, creator of The Shield, the bleak treatise on police corruption, and Ted Griffin, the writer of Oceans Eleven, the jaunty examination of high-end fraternal thievery. And the series feels precisely like the love child of these two seemingly inconsistent sensibilities. Terriers has a genetic disposition at once vaguely melancholy and eccentrically sprightly, but the good mood always seems to prevail. This is a welcome love child, one we are eager to embrace rather than put up for adoption.

title: Special Grand Jury May Get Fatal Police-Shooting Case

title: Southwest Potatoes, With Cheddar, Corn and Patience
description: I PLAYED with these potatoes years ago, tinkering with a distinctively Southwest combination of jalapeos, corn, black beans, chili powder and so on. I have angels that have taken my hand and walked me around New York, says the 34-year-old, newly-minted jewelry designer, citing the Lower Manhattan fixtures Paul Sevigny (she spent last Christmas with his family) and Aaron Bondaroff, whom she met soon after she decamped from Milan in 2007.

description: KHAN YUNIS, Gaza  Tough-looking ambulance drivers in this central Gazan city are drawing images of their fears with crayons. title: Obama Is Against a Compromise on Bush Tax Cuts

description: CAIRO  One of Egypts most prominent opposition leaders, the Nobel laureate Mohamed ElBaradei, has issued the strongest call so far for a blanket opposition boycott of parliamentary elections this fall.

title: China: Redevelopment Plan Scrapped for Historic Beijing Neighborhood
description: Beijing officials have shelved a much-attacked plan to redevelop the Gulou Drum Tower neighborhood, a warren of alleys and small homes dating from the Qing and Ming dynasties, into a tourist spot with high-end stores, The Beijing Times reported. The alleys, called hutongs, are among the few historic residential areas that have not been demolished in the citys rush to accommodate a fast-growing population and capitalize on ballooning land prices. The redevelopment plan called for the hutongs and the old Drum Tower, a Beijing landmark, to accommodate a new museum of timekeeping, a high-end underground shopping center and parking. Most residents had been awaiting an order to move out. The newspaper quoted an unidentified city official as saying the so-called Time Cultural City is a thing of the past, but said the neighborhoods future remained unclear.

title: Mozambique: Government Reverses Major Increase in Price of Bread
description: The government has decided to reverse a major increase in the price of bread that helped set off deadly riots last week in a nation where poverty is widespread, Planning Minister Aiuba Cuerenei said Tuesday. He said that a subsidy would allow the price to be set at the previous level. Higher global prices for wheat had contributed to the governments previous decision to raise the price of bread.

title: Bedbugs Bad for Business? Depends on the Business
description: Recent reports that bedbugs have infiltrated office buildings, movie theaters and stores in New York did not come as a surprise to Wes Tyler, general manager of the Chancellor Hotel on Union Square in San Francisco.

title: Building on Faith
description: AS my flight approached America last weekend, my mind circled back to the furor that has broken out over plans to build Cordoba House, a community center in Lower Manhattan.I have been away from home for two months, speaking abroad about cooperation among people from different religions. Every day, including the past two weeks spent representing my country on a State Department tour in the Middle East, I have been struck by how the controversy has riveted the attention of Americans, as well as nearly everyone I met in my travels.

title: The Bears and the State of Housing

title: South Africa: Fraud Charges Against Journalist Withdrawn
description: After reviewing the evidence gathered by state investigators, the National Prosecuting Authority said Tuesday that charges would be withdrawn against a journalist for the Sunday Times, Mzilikazi wa Afrika, who was arrested last month on fraud charges just days after he was a co-author of an article that laid out what it described as a questionable property deal between South Africas police chief and a politically connected businessman. Prosecutors left the door open to refiling the charges if new evidence comes to light. The newspaper had described the arrest as an attempt at intimidation, and its editor said Tuesday that the police chief owed Mr. wa Afrika an apology.

title: Marshaling Fashions Troops
description: YOU might not be seated next to Daphne Guinness in the front row at the Narciso Rodriguez show, or overhear Madonna and Lady Gaga chatting backstage at Badgley Mischka. But at this years New York Fashion Week, which starts on Sept. 9 at Lincoln Center, lucky members of the public will be able to glimpse new looks by designers like Marchesa and Jason Wu, just like a certain Chanel-clad fashion editor.

title: Russia: Chess Federation Chief Steps Down as Regional Leader
description: The controversial leader of a mostly Buddhist region in southern Russia, who has gained international attention for his prominence in world chess, said in a statement on Tuesday that he was stepping down after 17 years in power. The leader, Kirsan N. Ilyumzhinov, said he would not seek re-election as the leader of Kalmykia when his term ends in October, citing President Dmitri A. Medvedev, who has called for long-serving regional leaders to be replaced. Mr. Ilyumzhinov, who has also been president of World Chess Federation since 1995, said he would devote more time to promoting chess. He has been locked in a bitter fight for reelection to the chess federation with Anatoly Karpov, a former world champion, who has accused him of mismanagement and corruption.

title: Britain: One-Day Strike Cripples London Subway
description: Londons subway system was crippled by a strike on Tuesday by maintenance workers, signalers, station workers and some drivers who were protesting plans to cut 800 workers in stations around London. The workers say the plan will compromise public safety, but Mayor Boris Johnson called it moderate and sensible. Service on most lines was sporadic, with huge crowds at bus stops as commuters tried to get to work. The unions say they will hold more strikes in October and November.

title: Alms for the Rich and Powerful

The program has undoubtedly been of benefit to many teenagers, but deeper pockets have benefited as well. Comcast, the cable company, has given generously to the foundation, prompting Representative Elijah Cummings, a Democrat from Baltimore, to urge the Federal Communications Commission to approve Comcasts proposed merger with NBC. His charity even wrote its own letter to the F.C.C., saying it supports the merger in part because Comcast gives it money.

title: Forced Labor
description: A conspiracy indictment was brought last week against a Los Angeles company, alleging forced labor on a chilling scale. Six contractors are accused of a scheme to hold 400 workers from Thailand in virtual slavery on farms in Hawaii and Washington State. The Justice Department says it is the largest human-trafficking case ever brought by the federal government. Just as disturbing is how familiar the accusations are.

The result is that four big corporations control it now: JBS, Tyson Foods, Cargill and National Beef Packing. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack wants to try again, and we fully support him. In fact, wed like to see him go much further.

title: Keeping Track of the Kids

Theres also a sizable gobbet of Nutella, its nutty richness meant to evoke pralines  and by extension New Orleans, and by further extension the wild time you might have in New Orleans but are now presumably having in Brooklyn. The cases in which we are most drawn to philosophy are precisely the cases in which we feel as though there is something pulling us toward one side of a question but also something pulling us, perhaps equally powerfully, toward the other.

description: LAFAYETTE, La.  In a quiet suburb of this oil town, there is a spacious brick house with all of the shades drawn. title: Saudi Time

Now that they have begun, though, both sides will try to avoid being the one that scuttles them  and not only to avoid the wrath of the United States. It is because one senses that after all these years of stop-and-start peace talks  where someone declares this is the year of decision, and if these talks fail the peace process is dead and buried  this time it might actually be true. If these talks fail, with 300,000 Israeli settlers already living in the West Bank, and with Hamas becoming ensconced with its own government in Gaza, talk of a two-state solution will enter the realm of fantasy.

It argued before the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit that a lesser court order was sufficient. Writing for the majority, Judge Dolores K. title: Phys Ed: How to Fix a Bad Tennis Shoulder
description: For a study published a few years ago in the British Journal of Sports Medicine, researchers at the High Performance National Training Center in Argentina X-rayed the shoulders of 18 elite older tennis players, both men and women. Each of the 18, between the ages of 51 and 75, had at one time played professionally, and all were still active in tennis, as either competitors or teachers. None had experienced any unusual shoulder pain or problems. But when radiologists reviewed the players X-rays, they found signs of osteoarthritis, or loss of joint cartilage, in a third of the players dominant shoulders (generally the right). Shoulder X-rays from an age-matched group of Argentines who didnt play tennis turned up arthritic changes in only 11 percent of the group. With understandable circumspection, the authors, operating under the auspices of the Argentine Tennis Association, concluded that years of intensive tennis practice may be a predisposing factor for the development of mild degenerative articular changes in the dominant shoulder. Playing tennis, in other words, might be gnawing away at the joint.

title: Godard Watch, Day 2: Maybe Hell Pick Up His Oscar After All
description: As plot twists go it may not be quite as dramatic as Jean-Paul Belmondo painting his face blue and tying dynamite to his head in Pierrot le fou, but Jean-Luc Godard has told the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences he may indeed appear in person to receive an honorary Oscar in the fall.

title: Group Says Booster Seats Are Improving
description: Booster seats are better this year than they were last year at making lap and shoulder belts correctly fit children 4 to 8 years old, better restraining these children in a crash, evaluations by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety have found.

title: Investor Fears Force Split-Up of Irish Bank
description: The European bank panic that rattled markets around the world last spring may have subsided, but the experience has left investors and analysts jumpy about the prospects of more Greek-style bank bailouts.

title: Goldman Banker Named Glaxo C.F.O.
description: GlaxoSmithKline, the British pharmaceutical giant, said on Wednesday that Simon Dingemans, head of the European M.&A. business at Goldman Sachs, would become its new chief financial officer.

title: Seeking Designated Buyer
description: DEREK JETER has spent his entire Major League Baseball career as a New York Yankee. But with his contract up at the end of this season, his life might be in for some adjustments. For now he is making at least one big change, selling his New York apartment.

title: 3-D Glasses Outside the Theater
description: Moviegoers have been trained to treat 3-D glasses as disposable products. When the movies over youre supposed to chuck the glasses into the bins sitting outside the theaters.

title: Doubles Roundup: Mens Quarterfinals
description: Two Countries Advance to Semifinals

title: The Vogue Show
description: Credit is due to Anna Wintour and her staff for organizing a large-scale runway show in the plaza of Lincoln Center on Tuesday night that, for 1,500 ticket-buying guests who paid $25 to $400 for a seat, quite accurately portrayed what the actual experience of attending Fashion Week is like on the inside: You had to wait around in the 81-degree heat for an hour and a half before the start of the show, which lasted exactly 15 minutes.

title: Open House: Where Are the Inspiring Matches in the Womens Draw?
description: Gerry Marzorati: Morning, Michael. Im a little groggy this morning, having stayed to the end last night, which was early this morning. I was with a friend from work, and shed come to see Rafa  like all the women seated around us, actually. There was a moment when he took off his shirt and toweled himself and  O.K., it wasnt exactly Las Vegas Bachelorette Party

title: Rex Ryan: Bringing It Big
description: Late spring in Florham Park, N.J., under a cloudless sky on a bright green lawn lined for football. Its too hot, theres only one lonely shade tree, and Rex Ryans latest diet isnt working out. The New York Jets head coach is up over 345 again. Across the way from Ryan is his most valued employee, the magnificent cornerback Darrelle Revis, who is so frustrated about his salary that he sometimes seems undone. Living in Ryans attic back at the house is Ryans best friend since his Oklahoma youth, Jeff Weeks, the Jets outside linebackers coach, who is going through a divorce. Down on the farm in Kentucky, Ryans father, the pioneering defensive coach Buddy Ryan, has been ill with diverticulitis, while out in Cleveland, Ryans twin brother, Rob, is coordinating the defense for Browns Coach Eric Mangini, who had Ryans job until he was fired for what holdover Jets delicately call negativity. That, at least, will never be Ryans problem. How great is this! he cries, looking around. My life is perfect.

title: CNN Makes It Official: Piers Morgan Will Replace Larry King
description: CNN said Wednesday that Piers Morgan would take over for Larry King next January, putting an end to speculation about one of the most prized time slots in television.

title: Clan Planned Philippine Massacre Over Dinner, Witness Says
description: MANILA  The clan accused of orchestrating the Philippines worst political massacre  also considered the single worst killing of journalists on record  plotted the attack over a family dinner, a longtime housekeeper testified Wednesday at the start of a long-delayed trial here.

title: What Were Reading: Lying Pants
Early Word: Midwest Pitch
description: President Obama swoops down in Cleveland today to sell his policy prescriptions for strengthening the economic recovery. Jackie Calmes writes that Mr. Obama will take a partisan (yet personal) tone as he pitches a centrist batch of tax cuts and new spending. Though the proposals are unlikely to be approved by Congress before Novembers midterm elections or in the lame-duck session that follows, they provide Democrats an agenda as they head into the home stretch of this election season.

title: Britains Mercury Prize Goes to the XX
description: The XX, a British trio that dresses all in black and plays stark, hushed songs about stifled desire, has won the Barclaycard Mercury Prize for its album XX. The Mercury, a 20,000 prize (about $31,000) for the best album by a British or Irish act, is voted on by a small group of journalists and music industry professionals, and is regarded as one of Britains most prestigious music awards. In the past it has gone to PJ Harvey, Talvin Singh, Pulp and Portishead, but was criticized last year when it was won by Speech Debelle, a little-known London rapper who was soon dropped by her record company.

title: Halal Foods Expand Reach in France
description: NANTERRE, France  For years, Anissa Benchamacha bought her meat in a parking lot, from vendors hawking near-expired products to Muslims eager to find food that met their religious requirements.

title: Hellman & Friedman to Buy Associated Materials
description: Hellman & Friedman,  the private equity firm, agreed on Wednesday to buy Associated Materials, a maker of homebuilding products, from its current private equity owners for about $1.3 billion in cash.

title: Back to School: New York Times Resources for STEM
description: As your school year gets underway and you start planning ahead for the semester, here are some ways to use The New York Times use this year with your science, health, mathematics and technology students. Please see also our ideas for all subjects and for social studies and history. And check back tomorrow for more ideas for language arts and fine arts.

title: Barbour to G.O.P.: Keep Your Foot on the Gas
description: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi admonished his fellow Republicans on Wednesday not to measure those curtains just yet.

title: Maj. Gen. Israel Tal, Israeli Military Strategist, Is Dead at 85
description: JERUSALEM  Israel Tal, who as one of Israels most influential military strategists designed and developed its main tank, the Merkava, refashioned battleground doctrine and served as an adviser to prime ministers, died Wednesday. He was 85.

title: Frito-Lay Adds Electric Trucks to Its Fleet
description: Frito-Lay North America announced on Wednesday that it would field a fleet of 176 battery-powered delivery trucks made by Smith Electric Vehicles. In the first wave, five each will be operated in New York City, Fort Worth and Columbus, Ohio. Six will be in Canada.

title: The Architecture Biennale | A Last Look
description: If you happen to be in Venice this week for the Film Festival, a quick hop over to the Giardini is also highly recommended. The public park at the tip of the lagoon, overlooking the Lido, is host to most of the national pavilions of this years Architecture Biennale, which runs through Nov. 21. Perhaps the best way to tour the pavilions is to plunge straight in, literally, at the Polish Pavilion, which won the Golden Lion for National Pavilion in 2008.

title: To Go Where Compact Fluorescents Cannot
description: Mention new lighting technology and what leaps to mind is probably a compact fluorescent curlicue. Shaped like a soft ice cream cone, it is viewed as a replacement for the ubiquitous 60-watt incandescent light bulb, which looks almost like it did 90 years ago.

title: How Much to Put in Your Emergency Fund
description: Updated | Sept. 8, 2010

title: In Blair Memoir, Is It the Queen or The Queen?
description: 1:40 p.m. | Updated

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Rob Sheffield
description: Rob Sheffields most recent memoir is Talking to Girls About Duran Duran: One Young Mans Quest for True Love and a Cooler Haircut. Hell be D.J.ing at the Bell House in Gowanus this Saturday at 8 p.m. as part of the Brooklyn Book Festival.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Rob Sheffield
description: Rob Sheffields most recent memoir is Talking to Girls About Duran Duran: One Young Mans Quest for True Love and a Cooler Haircut. Hell be D.J.ing at the Bell House in Gowanus this Saturday at 8 p.m. as part of the Brooklyn Book Festival.

title: China and Japan Bristle Over Disputed Chain of Islands
description: BEIJING  Despite recent efforts to tamp down territorial disputes, China and Japan are jostling elbows over one of their thorniest such conflicts: control of a tiny, uninhabited island chain in the East China Sea.

title: No Cameras Allowed for S.C. House Debate
description: Most candidates are eager to get their faces on television, especially when the airtime is free and they will have a chance to deliver their messages unfiltered.

title: Connecticut Senate Hopefuls Focus on a Town of Independents
description: NEW HAVEN  The people in nearby East Haven are accustomed to seeing sandpipers, seagulls and ducks touching down in their town on Long Island Sound. This year they have come to recognize a new breed of visitor: candidates for United States Senate.

title: A 20-Race Season in 2011, and Ferrari Escapes With a Fine
description: 12:49 p.m. |Update

title: A 20-Race Season in 2011, and Ferrari Escapes With a Fine
description: 12:49 p.m. |Update

title: Orientation Week Is Over for Penn State Freshman
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Last Saturday, Rob Bolden became the first freshman quarterback to start a season opener for Penn State in 100 years. That was the easy part. Now, the hard part.

title: Sweating Your Way to Success
description: The most important book Ive read over the past six months is Matthew Syeds Bounce. Teddy Roosevelt once said that in this life we get nothing save by effort. Syed shows how trenchant Roosevelt was.

title: TimesCast | September 8, 2010
description: Today, BP blames several companies for the Gulf oil spill, New York schools open trying to do more with less, and Eric Wilson speaks with six designers about the changing fashion industry.

title: Park51, Parker Spitzer and Parking Those Sex Ads
description: Construction of Park 51 has yet to begin, but online the Islamic community center is up and running with a new Web site, a blog (with one post so far) and a fairly active Twitter account.

title: Iran Lifts Sentence of Stoning for Woman
description: TEHRAN  An Iranian official has confirmed that the government halted the sentence of death by stoning of a woman convicted of adultery, but he reiterated that she was still facing accusations of murder.

title: The Insider | Michael Nevin
description: Michael Nevin is founder and editor in chief of The Journal, a curated art and culture quarterly that began in 1999 as a photocopied snowboarding zine. He is also the director of the Journal Gallery, situated in a converted garage on North First Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, next to the magazines office. Entry 29 of the journal is about to hit newsstands with a few surprises, including a supplement created by Nate Lowman titled Lifes a Beach and Then You Die. The accompanying exhibition, Wish You Were Here, goes up at the gallery on Sept. 16.

title: An Argument Against Taking (and Retaking) the SAT and ACT
description: I recently received an e-mail from a father who said that his daughter had taken the SAT and ACT, and was contemplating retaking both exams. Should she? With the hope that this might prove a teachable moment for readers of The Choice (and me), I farmed the question out to Gwyeth Smith Jr. He is a longtime college counselor, now in private practice, who is the main character in David Marcuss book Acceptance: A Legendary Guidance Counselor Helps Seven Kids Find the Right Colleges  and Find Themselves (recently published in paperback by Penguin.) Mr. Smiths answer follows the question.  Jacques Steinberg

title: What It Takes to Be a Good Mayor
description: David Brooks: Gail, in this sour season, let us pause to praise famous men. I was hoping to get you to talk about some politician who is doing an outstanding job. As for me, Im going to gush about Richard M. Daley, who has decided not to run again as mayor of Chicago.

title: Caseys Mystery Bidder Raises New Questions
description: The market has been abuzz over the last 24 hours with speculation over the new mystery bidder for Caseys General Stores  and whether this offer is real.

title: Google Speeds Queries With Instant Results
description: Those who find Googles search engine to be impossibly slow will welcome Google Instant, an upgrade to the companys search results that it unveiled Wednesday.

title: U.S. Says Killings Wont Affect Iraq Mission
description: BAGHDAD  The killing of two American soldiers by an Iraqi soldier at a military base north of Baghdad was a deliberate act but would not undermine the new American mission to advise Iraqs security forces, the American military said in a statement on Wednesday.

title: Massachusetts Gubernatorial Rivals Battle in Debate
description: In a four-way race that appears to be tightening, Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts, a Democrat, and Charles D. Baker, the Republican nominee, leapt into attack mode Tuesday in the races first televised debate, which also included two other challengers.

title: Reader Photos From the First Day of School
description: So far today weve collected dozens of your photos from the first day of school in New York City (and several places outside of New York, too). Please keep sending them, using this simple upload form. We have published an initial gallery of your submissions and will be updating it throughout the day.

title: Crisis Past, Obama May Have Missed a Chance
description: WASHINGTON

title: Bryants Life and Death Cast a Shadow Over Paterno
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Joe Paterno unofficially started his 45th season as the Penn State football coach with a request at the teams media day in August that caused an eruption of laughter and made him smile.

title: Survivor
description: What if the future were a giant reality television show in which children were pitted against each other in an elaborate fight to the death, in which politics, war and entertainment had finally become indistinguishable? This is the question raised by Suzanne Collinss brutal and absorbing Hunger Games trilogy, and answered in the much anticipated final installment, Mockingjay.

title: Soldiers Halt Workers at Kabul Bank
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  On Wednesday, the last business day before a national holiday, state security forces punched and pushed back hundreds of governments workers trying to storm the central branch of the embattled Kabul Bank to claim their monthly wages.

title: Capturing the First Day of School
description: Readers photographs of children in New York City and elsewhere as they head back to the classroom.

title: Sorrow Wears and Uses Us
description: In an essay about his friendship with Norman Mailer, written in early 1961 at the peak of his eloquence, James Baldwin recalled his reaction to the news that Mailer was running for mayor of New York. Baldwin initially dismissed the rumor as a joke, until it became hideously clear that it was not a joke at all. I was furious. I thought . . . youre copping out . . . Its not your job.

title: Officer Resigns, Then Pleads Guilty to Manslaughter
description: An off-duty police officer who struck and killed a woman in Brooklyn in 2009 pleaded guilty in Brooklyn Supreme Court on Wednesday to second-degree vehicular manslaughter. According to the terms of the plea agreement, the officer, Andrew Kelly, will serve 90 days in jail and receive five years probation.

title: Your Pets Back-to-School Blues
description: Back-to-school season is a time of transition for the whole family, as parents and children begin to adjust to a new routine. But as the ASPCA reports, its also a difficult time for pets, who have grown accustomed to some extra attention during summer vacations and excursions to parks and beaches.

title: Rooms With a View
description: The novel of braided, alternating stories, perfected by David Mitchell, is a narrative daisy chain designed to tease readers by a process akin to coitus interruptus. One story stops, another begins, then a third, then more, then its back to the first and so on. Novels like this suggest hidden connections between disparate sets of characters, although the spectacle of sheer juxtaposition  of incongruous stories slyly interpolated  is also part of their appeal. Sometimes major characters in one story become secondary characters in others. Or unexpected events ripple through the separate sections, providing an accidental link. To give their narrative centrifuge a provisional stability, novelists sometimes employ a framing device. Why not, for example, set ones alternating stories in  of course!  a hotel? In this manner, a technique as old-fashioned as the 1932 film Grand Hotel merges with the postmodernism of Mitchells Cloud Atlas.

title: Jay Alfords Moment as a Giant
description: Its not easy to pull off one of the biggest upsets in Super Bowl history. A catch like David Tyrees helps.

title: Perfect Children
description: Among the many astute touches in The Widowers Tale is the fact that the action takes place within the orbit of two educational institutions looming large in the minds of todays affluent, consumerist parents: an exclusive progressive preschool and Harvard. If we can somehow shepherd our children through the first and then into the other, the communal fantasy goes, theyll land safely in some dreamy sphere of the elite, where theres no suffering, no strife, no failure, where the workers are invisible and all the real estate is light-filled. This energized, good-humored novel, Julia Glasss fourth, smashes through that illusion, beginning as satire, becoming stealthily suspenseful and ending up with a satisfyingly cleareyed and compassionate view of American entitlement and its fallout.

title: Fashions New Home
description: A multimedia tour of Fashion Weeks new setting.

title: Media Stacking
description: Using two (or more) forms of media simultaneously  for example, surfing the net while watching television.Revealing that more than half of Britons use another type of media while watching television, Andrew Laughlin wrote for Digital Spy:

title: Ireland Moves to Split Up Troubled Anglo Irish Bank
description: The Irish government, bowing to market fears that its escalating banking losses might cause it to default, said Wednesday that it would split the Anglo Irish Bank into two entities, one of which would eventually cease operations, The New York Timess Landon Thomas Jr. reported.

title: Keeping a Different Kind of Score in the N.F.L.
description: Each N.F.L. season promises so much: 256 games, most of them meaningful, many of them close; breathtaking highlights, last-second touchdowns, 50-yard field goals in the snow, fourth-down gambles, goal-line stands, end-zone celebrations, post-celebration penalties, and television close-ups of the quarterbacks intense stare as he prepares to hand off in the fourth quarter of a 52-3 game.

title: Ask Matt Bai: Obamas Missed Opportunity
description: As he presents a new element of his plan to revive the economy, President Obama is already faced with the reality that voters have, fairly or not, decided that his first big effort, the $800 billion package enacted right after he took office, was a qualified failure, and that anything tagged as further stimulus will be cast by Republicans as throwing good money after bad.

title: Childrens Books You (Might) Hate
description: Last week, while writing a guest post about something completely different, Josh Tyson mentioned in passing that he liked to read the book The Giving Tree with his two-and-a-half-year-old son. That led many of you to use the comments to make it clear that you really, really do not like that particular book.

title: One Kind of Folks
description: It seems only fitting, 50 years after the publication of To Kill a Mockingbird, that a Vietnamese-born author who came of age in the United States has written a Southern novel with an Asian-American protagonist who likes to cite Harper Lee. I was the towns pariah, but no one was allowed to tell me so, says Linh-Dao Nguyen Hammerick, called Linda, the piercingly eloquent narrator of Monique Truongs second novel. In Boiling Springs, Linda remarks of her hometown in rural North Carolina, I was never Scout. I was Boo Radley, not hidden away but in plain sight.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 8
description: A view of the day in sports, including a victory by Serbia at the world basketball championships.

title: Game Excerpt: Medal of Honor
description: Some of the most popular cultural depictions of America's current wars happens to be in video games.

title: Unsentimental Education
description: Graham Greene once said that writers should keep a chip of ice in their hearts. Its sound advice, with exceptions. Despite her generous portrayal of her troubled family life, Liz Murray succeeds as an author. Few parents would seem to have been more deserving of contempt than the ones who raised her.

title: Seoul-Searching With Tory Burch
description: When Tory Burch was last in Europe, she came armed with a voice recorder, which she used to capture her observations. The designer then traveled to Seoul, South Korea, to open her new boutique in Cheongdam-dong. (Its like the South Korean Rodeo Drive.) Once there, she handed off the voice recorder to the filmmaker Van Neistat (of viral video fame), who gave himself the unusual task of pairing Burchs commentary on her European jaunt  about cypress trees in Tuscany, a sunset over the Seine  with scenes from Seoul. The seemingly awkward conceit comes off cleverly, but it did leave us wondering what Burch thought of Seoul itself. The city is very international and progressive, she says. I loved everything from the chic women to the interesting architecture. Walking into the Leeum museum was so exciting  there were three spider sculptures by one of my favorite artists, Louise Bourgeois. The stores are also fantastic, like Boon, Mue and 10 Corso Como. I definitely want to go back. There is so much more Id love to see.

title: A Life in Nepal
description: Samrat Upadhyays fiction has tended to be small in scale, charting the infinitesimal tremors of middle-class angst. That his characters happen to live in Katmandu instead of, say, Bloomington, Ind.  where Upadhyay, who was born and raised in Nepal, now makes his home  is at times almost incidental. Those Led Zeppelin days are over, friend, a Nepali wife chides her husband in Buddhas Orphans, Upadhyays new novel. You need to get a job so we can start thinking about a child. The fretting, the obsessive nostalgia, the muffled ache: its all distressingly familiar. We have scaled the roof of the world and met ourselves.

title: A New Web Service Offers Restaurant Discounts
description: Over on the Bits blog, Claire Cain Miller writes about a new site that is offering discounts to restaurants in several major American cities.

title: Otherwise Occupied
description: Military novels that stint on the shells a-bursting and the guns a-rat-a-tatting tend to be positively prickly with black humor, filled with the kind of jocular cutting-contest rituals that occur between salvos in the field. Either the bodies mount, or the sarcastic asides do.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. John Boehner vying for speaker of the House. Hell be a lot less tan if he gets a more demanding job.

title: The View From the Drivers Seat
description: One day in 1917, Henri Matisse persuaded his son to drive him into the country in the family car. He set up his easels and painted a view of the road and trees, seen through the windshield and out the car windows. He established a tradition of viewing the world from the car, whose latest flowering is visible in a show of photographs.

title: Clinton Speech Offers Policy Overview
description: WASHINGTON  It was not quite as lofty as Madeleine K. Albrights description of the United States as the worlds indispensable nation, but Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton came close to channeling her predecessor on Wednesday in declaring a new American moment.

title: Fed Report Finds Signs That Growth Is Slowing
description: The United States economy showed widespread signs of slowing, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday, though modest growth continued from mid-July through the end of August.

title: Atonement
description: Early in Darin Strausss first novel, Chang and Eng, a historical tale about conjoined twins born in Siam in 1811, Eng awakes to find that Chang has died in the night. Then I too am done, Eng thinks. The two mens lives have been entwined almost beyond imagining, and one cannot survive without the other. Eng clings to his dead twin, then dies himself. It is impossible not to think of this moment, which appears once at the beginning and again near the end of the novel, when reading Strausss new memoir, Half a Life.

title: Carlyle Hires Head of U.S. Equity Opportunity Group
description: The Carlyle Group >said Wednesday that it had hired Rodney Cohen as the head of its new United States equity opportunity group, which will focus on investments in small to mid-sized companies.

title: Molly Shannon Joins Promises, Promises
description: You always knew that Mary Katherine Gallagher was going to make it to Broadway one way or another. That overeager Catholic schoolgirl and aspiring entertainer may remain in semiretirement, but Molly Shannon, the Saturday Night Live alumna who portrayed her (along with characters like Sally OMalley and a parody version of Ann Miller) on that program, is slated to make her Broadway debut in Promises, Promises, the musicals publicists said on Wednesday. Ms. Shannon will take over the role of the barfly Marge MacDougall from Katie Finneran on Oct. 12; Ms. Finneran, who won a Tony Award for her portrayal of that character this year (and who is pregnant with her first child), will leave the production after Oct. 10. The leads of Promises, Promises, Kristin Chenoweth and Sean Hayes, will remain in the show through Dec. 26, when Ms. Shannon will also depart; no permanent role has yet been found for Ellen DeGeneres.

title: Networking
description: When I first heard that the Department of Homeland Security had brought in a group of science fiction writers to brainstorm new ways that terrorists might attack America, something changed for me forever. I realized this was one of the first news stories I had ever totally believed  in part because it was like something from fiction. Even if it hadnt happened yet, it could happen, and therefore probably would. In a late-capitalist marketplace where you can buy or sell almost anything, including artificial islands in Dubai (Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt apparently bought one in the shape of Ethiopia), nothing feels impossible. And in a world where fiction is becoming indistinguishable from reality, as the philosopher Baudrillard suggested, the flow of truth goes both ways. Its just as likely that fiction will come true as it is that the truth will turn out to have been fiction all along.

title: Carlsen vs. the World
description: Magnus Carlsen, the 19-year-old Norwegian who is the top-ranked chess player, will play a game against the world on Friday via the Internet. Carlsen will be making his moves from the Cooper Square Hotel in Manhattan.

title: As the Smoke Cleared
description: The morning of Sept. 11, 2001, found me on my stoop in Bostons South End, waiting for a ride to work. One minute I was enjoying the sunshine, worrying about the logistics of moving house. Then the first plane struck the north tower of the World Trade Center and my entire frame of reference lurched. What I dont quite remember is how that painful, personal moment connected to Americas national experience in the aftermath of the attacks  and to what many saw as the erosion of civil liberties, unnecessary wars and the willingness to scorn allies and international institutions.

title: The 38th Parallel
description: Bruce Cumings is a historian at the University of Chicago; the author of several books, including a doorstop two-volume history entitled The Origins of the Korean War; and a gifted controversialist. He distills his work in his new primer, The Korean War, which is dedicated to the memory of the South Korean president Kim Dae-jung, who promoted a sunshine policy with the North.

title: Prison Raid in Nigeria Releases Hundreds
description: DAKAR, Senegal  More than 700 inmates in the northern Nigerian city of Bauchi were freed Tuesday night in a daring raid by well-armed attackers on a prison where members of an Islamist sect were being held, authorities and witnesses said Wednesday.

title: Paradise Lost
description: A green and fecund island, barely 20 miles off the east coast of Africa, Zanzibar for centuries represented gratified desire. For voyagers across the Indian Ocean its safe harbor was a refuge after a long journey. The vast Chinese trading fleet led by the eunuch Zheng He moored at Zanzibar in the early 15th century to exchange its silver for African gold. For Vasco da Gama, who landed there in 1499, beginning 200 years of Portuguese domination, it was an island of repose for men slaughtering their way across the Eastern seas.

title: Buffalo Hunting
description: In the innocent, pre-Rugby days of the early 60s, there was nothing ironic or fashiony about a free-hanging dartless suit or the kind of heathery saddle-shoulder Shetland crew neck beloved of John Cheever. Buffalo, N.Y., alone had maybe 15 family-owned mens-wear shops selling what a certain three-hankie film would universally popularize as the preppy look. By the time Ralph Lifshitz paid a sales call on OConnells, the only pre-Love Story haberdasher still operating in the Queen City, he was already the tie designer Ralph Lauren, and you have to assume he was paying attention.

title: Conspiracy Theorem
description: Not so long ago, before Swedes and vampires ruled the best-seller list, readers snapped up thrillers with plots so gaudy their authors risked confinement hearings. The Da Vinci Code, The Rule of Four and their imitators sold millions of copies. Why? Maybe for the simple reason that were all conspiracists at heart, seeking hidden explanations for the puzzle of the world around us.

title: Blue Book May Be on the Block
description: Whats the Blue Book value?

title: A Fashion Week Debut, Seven Weeks in the Making
description: THREE years ago, a fashion event for Monique Pan meant stowing her best jewelry samples into an antique white box and hauling it to the Times Square offices of Vogue in the off chance that editors there might like her earthy, eco-friendly bracelets and necklaces.

title: Latin Grammy Nominations Announced
description: Juan Luis Guerra, Alejandro Sanz, Jorge Drexler and Mario Domm lead the nominations for the 11th annual Latin Grammy Awards, announced on Wednesday morning in Los Angeles. Those veteran musicians received four nods apiece (Mr. Domm, a producer and songwriter from Mexico, shares three of his nods with his band, Camila), and will face one another  along with some newer faces  in most of the major categories.

title: Trouble in the Monkey House
description: When Harvard announced last month that it had found the psychologist Marc Hauser solely responsible for eight instances of scientific misconduct, the news generated front-page headlines and streams of schadenfreude-laced commentary in the blogosphere. Hauser, an expert on human and animal cognition, is a star of the Harvard faculty and the author of scores of scientific papers, as well as the book Moral Minds (2006), a popular study of the evolutionary underpinnings of human morality. The irony of that last part  and of the title of Hausers book-in-progress, Evilicious: Why We Evolved a Taste for Being Bad  wasnt lost on some observers.

title: At New Site, No Runway Jostling
description: NEW YORK FASHION WEEK begins its run at Lincoln Center on Thursday after 17 years in Bryant Park  so expect to see disoriented fashion editors in treacherous shoes teetering about the Upper West Side.

title: Final Sealing of Gulf Well Is Delayed Again
description: The final sealing of BPs stricken well in the Gulf of Mexico has been delayed again, the government said Wednesday, as engineers worked to better understand the wells condition.

title: In the Trenches: War Horse
description: For centuries, the most glorified fighting  often reserved for officers and noblemen  was mounted combat.

title: In the Trenches: The War to End All Wars
description: If World War I were a movie, it would be panned. The lead characters motivations are unclear. Nothing happens for long stretches of time, and when it does, the carnage puts Mortal Kombat to shame. A year or two could be cut. And that resolution at Versailles feels like a heavy-handed setup for a sequel.

title: Eurofile | Going Wild in the Baltics
description: Though any reference to Estonian cooking generally draws a blank stare from even well-traveled gourmets, Alexander, one of the best and most interesting new restaurants in Europe right now, is found on the tiny and stunningly beautiful Estonian island of Muhu, a two-hour drive south from Tallinn, the countrys capital. Its still rather confidential, but a gastronomic awakening is occurring in the countries that surround Europes other great sea, the Baltic, which has long been dismissed as a region of marginal culinary interest by a world besotted with everything Mediterranean.

title: Where the Future Stars May Be
description: THE fashion calendar is glutted with scores of young hopefuls jostling to make their mark during New York Fashion Week. Some will attain the brief but glorious life span of a butterfly, spreading their wings for a season or two, while others will demonstrate formidable staying power. Among the more than 100 designers showing their spring-summer 2011 collections at Lincoln Center and elsewhere around town are a handful of strikingly inventive talents who have caught the eye of influential insiders.

title: Strange New World
description: An exuberant imagination can be one of a childs best companions. Sometimes it can be too much of a good thing, though, brimming not only with fantasies and inventions but also with worries and worst-case scenarios. Few things make a childs imaginings go into overdrive like the first day of school, as Antoinette Portis delightfully captures in Kindergarten Diary.

title: Deepak Chopras Muhammad to Be Released Early as E-Book
description: Muhammad, Deepak Chopras fictionalized biography about the life of the Prophet Muhammad, will go on sale early in e-book form, weeks ahead of the print books publication date of Sept. 21.

title: ArtsBeat: Deepak Chopras Muhammad to Be Released Early as E-Book
description: Muhammad, Deepak Chopras fictionalized biography about the life of the Prophet Muhammad, will go on sale early in e-book form, weeks ahead of the print books publication date of Sept. 21. HarperCollins, the books publisher, said it had authorized Amazon and other e-book retailers to sell the book beginning Wednesday, trying to meet demand for the book since the national conversation has turned to Islam and the planned community center and mosque near ground zero. Read more at ArtsBeat

title: Obama, in Rally Mode, Steps Up Jabs at G.O.P.
description: CLEVELAND  Seeking to rally his struggling party for the final weeks of the midterm election, President Obama delivered his most partisan speech of the campaign so far on Wednesday, casting Democrats as fighters for the middle class and Republicans as protectors of millionaires and billionaires and special interests.

title: Childrens Bookshelf
description: SCHOOL!  Adventures at the Harvey N. Trouble Elementary School.  Written by Kate McMullan.Inspired and illustrated by George Booth.  Feiwel & Friends. $12.99. (Ages 6 to 9)

title: Hey, Mr. Critic!
description: The mailbot brought restaurant questions from Alberta this week, from eastern Connecticut and the wilds of parenthood. As ever, I did my best to give good advice. Send me your questions and follow along on Twitter.

title: Study Shows Drop in Credit Card Use
description: Consumers are using credit cards less than in the past, at least according to data just released from Javelin Strategy and Research.

title: On Clean Energy, China Skirts Rules
description: CHANGSHA, China  Until very recently, Hunan Province was known mainly for lip-searing spicy food, smoggy cities and destitute pig farmers. Mao was born in a village on the outskirts of Changsha, the provincial capital here in south-central China.

title: Your Very Own $400,000 Robot
description: Regular readers of Bits will know about my love of robots. In short, Ive always wanted to own one, but so far each experience with them has fallen a little short of my robotic expectations.

title: Seoul-Searching With Tory Burch
description: A new short by the filmmaker Van Neistat tied to the opening of the Tory Burch flagship store in Seoul.

title: Up Front: Dani Shapiro
description: The novelist and memoirist Dani Shapiro reviews Half a Life, Darin Strausss account of being behind the wheel in a fatal car crash as a high school student.

title: Clean Energy Entrepreneurs Face More Obstacles in U.S.
description: With erect posture and clear gray eyes, Chuck Provini still looks like the Marine who graduated from the Naval Academy in 1969 and was repeatedly decorated for bravery in Vietnam.

title: Code World
description: There are many stories Tom McCarthy chooses not to tell in C, his tour de force new novel encompassing the short life of one Serge Carrefax, born at the turn of the 20th century on a rural English estate. Serges father, a manic tinkerer with early wireless technology, runs a school for the deaf but seems oblivious to his own deaf wife, Serges mother, whos so blinkered on opium (supplied by a mute gardener who grows the poppies himself) that she nearly lets Serge drown in a creek at age 2. Serges beloved older sister, Sophie, becomes sexually involved with a friend of their fathers and winds up committing suicide at 17  possibly after having an abortion. Serges relationship to Sophie is preternaturally close, with incestuous overtones, and her death severs his only real human connection. But these dramas are merely suggested, their shadowy outlines ignored, sublimated or flat-out denied by those involved; Sophies self-poisoning is deemed an accident.

title: Trip to Army Hospital Turns Into Mets Controversy
description: WASHINGTON  Carlos Beltran hit a sacrifice fly on Wednesday to provide the Mets with a third of their offense in a sleepy 3-2 matinee victory against the Washington Nationals. But what he did the day before may provide a better window on his relationship with the team.

title: Are Films Bad, or Is TV Just Better?
description: FOR as long as anyone in the movie world can remember (which may be only 20 years or so, but never mind), the fall season has been marked by a sober kind of excitement. The commercial entertainments of summer give way to more ambitious fare, and the grown-up segment of the audience goes back to the theaters looking for stirring performances, complex storytelling, important themes and big emotions. Thats the theory, anyway.

title: The Saints Have Taken Steps to Avoid a Letdown
description: The N.F.L. will throw one more parade for the New Orleans Saints on Thursday night, a brightly colored pageant meant to usher in a new season. The Saints will host a rematch with the Minnesota Vikings, whom they vanquished in overtime in the N.F.C. championship game, and provide a final joyride into the sunset for the feel-good story of last season.

title: Zvonareva Overcomes Kanepi to Reach Semis
description: It was the shriek versus the shout. The Wimbledon finalist Vera Zvonareva of Russia powered her way into the womens semifinals with a hard-fought victory over Kaia Kanepi of Estonia, 6-3, 7-5.

title: Zvonareva and Wozniacki Adjust and Advance
description: While her classmates in Moscow ease into the new school year, Vera Zvonareva is grinding through her tennis exams at the United States Open. The tournaments pass-fail format used to be a trial for Zvonareva, who had a hard time accepting any score short of perfection.

title: Kramnik Wins Second Spot in Bilbao Final Masters
The Beads Show Her the Way
description: I ALWAYS say everything finds its own place, said Lori Goldstein, the stylist who for decades has helped create the look of Versace campaigns and the photo shoots of Annie Leibovitz and Steven Meisel. In her approach to fashion, she has kept an open mind when facing a rack of clothes, letting the look of each outfit come together naturally.

title: Central Bankers Spurred to Complete New Regulations
description: FRANKFURT  The drama in Ireland has added urgency to efforts by central bankers and bank regulators to agree on global rules designed to prevent future crises.

title: The Insider | Helping Immigrants Navigate City Government
description: Name: Fatima A. ShamaTitle: Commissioner of the Mayors Office of Immigrant Affairs.Age:  37Hometown: Born and raised in the Bronx.

title: New Parents at Risk for Depression
description: Both mothers and fathers face an increased risk of depression after the birth of a child, and remain at some increased risk well into a childs adolescence, a new British study shows.

title: Hey, Theres a Lady Present
description: THE fashion stylist Annabel Tollman can rattle off a litany of reasons not to like this seasons 1950s-style box-frame handbags. Theres something decidedly starchy about them, she began.

title: Delicious Ways to Love Downtown Los Angeles
description: DOWNTOWN Los Angeles has been reviving for the better part of 20 years.

title: A Revived Restaurant Scene in Los Angeles
description: New eateries are keeping diners downtown.

title: The Thoughtful Roar of the Housing Bears
description: I was a housing bear for a long time. And Im not exactly bullish now. But I am a bit less bearish than some other real estate watchers. Theyre making some thoughtful arguments today about why we should expect home prices to soon fall more.

title: Swishers Homer and Posadas Test Results Brighten Yanks Afternoon
description: Even though he was trying to protect a one-run lead, Baltimore Orioles closer Koji Uehara was bold enough to throw a first-pitch fastball to the Yankees Alex Rodriguez in the bottom of the ninth inning Wednesday afternoon. Rodriguez lashed a single. Nick Swisher made a mental note.

title: Shopping With Luke Ives Pontifell
description: The founder of Thornwillow Press searched for bookends that are both functional and aesthetically pleasing.

title: For This Musical Couple, Its Simply a Matter of Chemistry
description: Heaven.

title: Florida Pastor Says Koran Burning Still On
description: Updated | 6:31 p.m. Terry Jones, the pastor of a tiny Florida church that has garnered worldwide attention for its plan to burn more than 200 copies of the Koran, told reporters on Wednesday that, as of this time, we have no intention of canceling. He added, we are not convinced that backing down is the right thing, so on Sept. 11 we will continue with our planned event.

title: Pictures of the Day: On a Chinese Oil Rig and Elsewhere
description: Two oil workers were missing and more than 30 others were rescued from a rig off Chinas northeast coast that was damaged in a storm on Wednesday, the BBC reported. Helicopters and rescue boats searched for two people who fell from the platform, which was listing at a 45-degree angle in the Shengli oil field, operated by Sinopec, which is the second-largest in China. Sinopec said no oil has been spilled and that powerful waves generated by Typhoon Malou were the likely cause.

title: In Season 9, iPods Still Get High Ratings
description: CUPERTINO, Calif.  At a special press event today, Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive, unveiled a new lineup of iPod models, just in time for the holiday season. The diminutive iPod Shuffle still has no screen and is still made of brushed aluminum, but it now has _____ and comes in _____ colors. Apple tinkered with the proportions of the iPod Nano, too, adding _____ and redesigning the _____. The popular iPod Touch also received a makeover; its thinner now, and gains new features like a _____ and a _____. All models now offer better battery life and greater storage capacity.

title: Panel Urges Tougher Offshore Regulation
description: Regulators who are supposed to police offshore oil and gas drilling are spread too thinly, poorly trained and hampered by outdated technology, according to a study by an Interior Department review board appointed after the BP oil disaster in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Views of Health Care Economics From a C.E.O. Named Bush
description: In the world of health care innovation, the founder and chief executive of Athenahealth has an outsize name. In part, thats because his name is Jonathan Bush, and he is the nephew of one former president and the cousin of another. But its also because his company has mastered the intricacies of the doctor-insurer relationship and become a player in the emerging medical records industry.

title: The View From Madison Square Park
description: Dan Hoffmann might normally eat his take-out lunches behind his desk at Grey Global Group, an advertising agency, but on a sunny Wednesday afternoon the week after Labor Day, he got an added bonus to go with his food: a side of tennis.

title: Night of a Thousand Labels
description: Expect a frenzy of big-name designers, cocktails and limited-edition stuff from cool designers at the second coming of Fashions Night Out on Friday. Check out a full guide to where you can drink, spend and gawk.

title: ZumoCast Offers a Personalized Cloud
description: So you want to take a video that is sitting on your computer and watch it on your iPad or iPhone. It shouldnt be too difficult, right?Yet the options available fromApple, the company that makes the software and hardware for those devices, can either be very expensive or very slow.

title: Is the Health Care Plan a Good Thing?
description: In a conversation published today, Jonathan Bush, founder and chief executive of Athenahealth, wades into the argument over whether the health care overhaul enacted into law this year is good for small business.

title: A Conversation: Fashion's New Generation
description: Six emerging fashion designers talk with Eric Wilson about developing their businesses in New York City.

title: Think Youve Seen It All? You Have
description: THE time has come for Broadway to erect its own Statue of Liberty. I envision it overlooking Duffy Square and maybe having the face of Angela Lansbury. But those details can be worked out later. The important thing is that this monument offer the same kind of hope to the disenfranchised of show business that the original did to immigrants coming to Ellis Island. Give me your flops, your has-beens, the plaque on it might read. Your dimming stars yearning to shine once more. Send these, the tarnished, tempest-tossed to me.

title: Elizabeth Jenkins, Woman of Letters, Dies at 104
description: Elizabeth Jenkins, a novelist whose biographies of Jane Austen, Lady Caroline Lamb, Henry Fielding and Elizabeth I established her as one of Britains foremost women of letters, died on Sunday in Hampstead, London, where she had been in a nursing home for several years. She was 104.

title: Way Back Machine | The L.I.R.R. Reaches Manhattan
description: Day Long Throng Inspects New Tube, trumpeted the headline in The New York Times.

title: Web Slinger Is Poised to Cast Net
description: NEW YORKS newest Spider-Man lives by himself in an imposing glass tower high above Times Square. Its a long way from Peter Parkers Queens. But then again, so is Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, the high-octane Broadway musical directed by Julie Taymor, with music by Bono and the Edge and aerial technology designed by a member of Cirque du Soleil. For now Reeve Carney, the newly installed Spidey, can still walk unnoticed from his sparsely furnished apartment to his six-day-a-week rehearsals. But by the time the much-delayed, much-ballyhooed show  said to be the most expensive in Broadway history  opens at the Foxwoods Theater on Dec. 21 (previews begin Nov. 14), that may not be possible.

title: When the Familiar Becomes Special
description: In his Theater Talkback on the ArtsBeat blog, Ben Brantley, chief theater critic of The Times, asked readers to recall revelatory performances that changed the way they thought about familiar characters. Here are some edited responses:

title: A Writers Long Journey to Trace the Great Migration
description: ATLANTA  To finish The Warmth of Other Suns, her magisterial new history of the black migration in America, which carried millions of Southerners northward or westward, Isabel Wilkerson had to complete a sort of reverse migration. She began writing the book in Chicago, where she was the bureau chief for The New York Times, and finished it more than a decade later in a house in the Virginia Highland neighborhood of Atlanta. Ms. Wilkerson moved here in 2001, for reasons unconnected to the book, and immediately discovered, she said this week, that she needed to be here, only I didnt know it.

title: Following the Action at the Open
description: Gerry Marzorati, one-half of the Open House duo, is covering the United States Open via his smart phone and Twitter. You can follow his observations about Novak Djokovics victory over Gael Monfils, 7-6 (2), 6-1, 6-2, earlier Wednesday by clicking Read more or go directly to gerrynyt.

title: Peek Returns to Banking With New Job at Barclays
description: Jeffrey M. Peek, the chief executive who built up the CIT Group, only to see it nearly capsize during the financial crisis, has returned to his investment banking roots with his latest job.

description: Metallica and the Dave Matthews Band you expect to be giants of the Billboard charts. But Disturbed?

title: Court Dismisses a Case Asserting Torture by C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Wednesday ruled that former prisoners of the C.I.A. could not sue over their alleged torture in overseas prisons because such a lawsuit might expose secret government information.

title: Fashions Night Out in Pictures
description: Fashions Night Out is like a mix between New Years Eve and Halloween, says Ina Bernstein, the proprietor of the popular INA designer consignment shops. Now you can add opening night at the International Center of Photography to the mix. At a number of stores around town, A-list photographers will be hanging impromptu shows with work that connects to the freshly unpacked fall collections hanging on the racks.

title: Courtside: The Wind Factor
description: Christopher Clarey on how the wind has and will continue to play a role at Arthur Ashe Stadium during the U.S. Open, and a look ahead to the semifinals match between Venus Williams and Kim Clijsters.

title: At This School, Misfits Make Up the Student Body
description: Paul Murrays Skippy Dies is a luxuriantly eccentric novel set in Seabrook College, a Dublin school that is a magnet for teenage misfits. One Seabrook boy keeps a collection of naturally occurring hexagons. Another grills his religion teacher on whether Jesus having been resurrected from death qualifies him as a zombie. A third spends much of his time mesmerized by a video game, imagining himself as you, Djed, an ordinary elf from the forest as he tries to save his elfish world from the grip of demons. Its easy to see why he prefers this version of reality to the gloomier one that Seabrook offers.

title: For Douglas Holtz-Eakin
description: Holtz-Eakin: GOP Too Focused On Cocaine Of Sarah Palin To Rule

title: When the Shah of Iran Took the Pictures
description: Newsha Tavakolian, 29, has been covering Iran for Polaris Images since 2001 and has freelanced for The Times since 2004. She discussed coverage of last years political upheaval in Covering Tehran (June 17, 2009) and shared her photographs of women singers in A Quiet Song, With Feeling (June 11, 2010). Her conversation with Amanda Rivkin has been edited and condensed.

title: Courtside: The Wind Factor
description: Christopher Clarey, who wrote about how the wind has and will continue to play a role at Arthur Ashe Stadium during the U.S. Open, breaks down the topic further and looks ahead to the semifinals match between Venus Williams and Kim Clijsters.

description: THEY are not exactly a New York Six.
