description: Thanks to everyone who sent in photographs from the first day of school in New York (and New Jersey and Paris and Greece and Florida). Click or drag above to explore the complete gallery. Well add photos through Thursday morning, so you may continue to submit your images Wednesday evening using this form.

title: Three Tips on Using Google Instant
description: On Wednesday, Google introduced a major change to the way its search engine delivers results. Results now appear while you are still typing your search query. If you keep typing, Googles results change to match.

title: Kim France Out at Lucky; Brandon Holley of Yahoo Takes Over
description: Kim France, the editor who invented Lucky magazine in 2000 alongwith James Truman, who wasthe Cond Nast editorial directer at the time, has left the magazine. She was replaced by Brandon Holley, who worked at Cond Nast in 2007 until Jane, the magazine she was editing, was closed. Since then, Ms. Holley has been working as editor in chief of Shine, Yahoos site for women.

title: Federal Agency Sues LED Bulb Maker
description: Even as lighting companies report advances in LED technology, consumers are being warned that some LED lighting products do not live up to the hype.

title: Soap Suds by Day, Political Drama by Night
description: Ta Delgados inoperable brain tumor may have been a teary story line this summer for fans of the character on One Life to Live, the ABC soap opera, but the protracted how-many-days-have-I-got death scenes could not have come at a better time for Florencia Lozano, who portrays her.

title: Ah, Hamlet, I Thought I Knew You Well
description: There are some people you feel can never surprise you, you know them so well. Youve spent hours in their company, you know all their little habits, you even hear what theyre going to say before they say it. And then, every so often (and it could be the 20th encounter), one of them does something that knocks you for a loop, and you think, I never really knew you at all.

title: Obamas Economy Speech in Ohio
description: The following is a transcript of President Obamas speech about the economy in Parma, Ohio, as provided by the White House:

title: Talent Takes Lead
description: The Top 10 Americas Got Talent acts and the guest performer, Enrique Iglesias, helped lift NBC to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday as 12.3 million viewers tuned in to that reality show from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. No other prime-time program came close, though CBSs NCIS rerun did lead the 8 p.m. slot with 9.9 million viewers. CBS placed second overall, broadcasting repeats of NCIS: Los Angeles at 9 (8 million) and The Good Wife at 10 (5.6 million). ABC was third with back-to-back episodes of Wipeout, a new one at 8 (8 million) and a rerun at 9 (5.6 million), followed by a low-rated installment of ABCs Nightline Prime at 10 (3.3 million). Fox placed fourth.

title: Mercury Prize Adds to Trios Incredible Year
description: The XX, a British trio that dresses all in black and plays stark, hushed songs about stifled desire, has won the Barclaycard Mercury Prize for its album XX. The Mercury, a 20,000 prize (about $31,000) for the best album by a British or Irish act, is voted on by a small group of journalists and music industry professionals, and is regarded as one of Britains most prestigious music awards. In the past it has gone to PJ Harvey, Talvin Singh, Pulp and Portishead, but was criticized last year when it was won by Speech Debelle, a little-known London rapper who was soon dropped by her record company. The nominees this year  who also included Paul Weller, Corinne Bailey Rae, Villagers, Mumford & Sons and Laura Marling  were seen as more populist, and the XX expressed surprise that it won. Weve had the most incredible year, and it has just felt like every day weve just woken up to something incredible we just werent expecting,  Oliver Sim, the XXs bassist, said when receiving the award on Tuesday. It has felt just like a haze.

title: Mixed Results as NATO Drive on Kandahar Begins
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  The white flags of the Taliban no longer fly from neighborhoods in Kandahar City, as they did in some areas only two weeks ago, replaced instead by the red, black and green Afghan colors.

title: Giving an Error the Boot
description: Q. My Windows XP computer wont start up and gives me an unmountable boot volume message. Can this be fixed or is the hard drive shot?

title: Wait, Godard Just Might Pick Up Oscar After All
description: As plot twists go it may not be quite as dramatic as Jean-Paul Belmondo painting his face blue and tying dynamite to his head in Pierrot le Fou, but that films director, Jean-Luc Godard, has told the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences that he may indeed appear in person to receive an honorary Oscar this fall. Mr. Godards wife, Anne-Marie Mieville, had previously told The Australian newspaper that her husband would not travel to the United States to receive the award, which is to be presented at a November event that is separate from the Academy Awards ceremony on Feb. 27. He just told me, Its not the Oscars, Ms. Mieville said. But The Hollywood Reporter said the academy had received a cordial, handwritten note from Mr. Godard, the pioneering French New Wave director, indicating that he might make the trip. The academy told The Hollywood Reporter that Mr. Godard graciously thanked the organization for the honor, and described himself as the fourth musketeer alongside Francis Ford Coppola, Eli Wallach and Kevin Brownlow, who are also receiving honorary awards. The note, the academy said, indicated that, schedule permitting, he would come to Los Angeles.

title: Genentech Scientist to Lead Rockefeller University
description: The No. 2 research official at Genentech will become the next president of Rockefeller University, in the first departure from the companys top scientific ranks since its acquisition by Roche in March 2009.

title: Chopras Muhammad Released Early as E-Book
description: HarperCollins approved the early release of the e-book version of Muhammad, Deepak Chopras fictionalized biography about the Prophet Muhammads life that is to be published in printed form on Sept. 21. The books publisher authorized Amazon and other e-book retailers to begin selling the book on Wednesday, trying to meet demand for it because of the debate over a planned Muslim community center and mosque near the World Trade Center site in Manhattan. It was the first time that HarperCollins had placed an e-book for sale before the print edition  in this case weeks ahead of the print books publication. Dr. Chopra, above, an Indian-born guru and advocate of alternative medicine, has written other so-called teaching novels about the founders of world religions, including his best-selling books Buddha and Jesus. Books spark conversations, Michael Morrison, the president and publisher of HarperCollinss general books division for the United States and Canada, said in a statement. And in this case a national conversation has erupted.

title: Familiar Faces Lead Latin Grammy Nominees
description: Juan Luis Guerra, Alejandro Sanz, Jorge Drexler and Mario Domm, far left, lead the nominations for the 11th annual Latin Grammy Awards, announced on Wednesday morning in Los Angeles. Those veteran musicians received four nominations apiece (Mr. Domm, a producer and songwriter from Mexico, shares three of his with his band, Camila), and will face one another  along with some newer faces  in most major categories. Up for album of the year are Camilas Dejarte de Amar; A Son de Guerra by Mr. Guerra, from the Dominican Republic; Paraso Express by Mr. Sanz, a Spanish singer-songwriter who has 14 Latin Grammys under his belt; Cardio by Miguel Bos, also from Spain; and Y. by Bebe, above right, a young Spanish singer who is up for two prizes. (Other nominees for two awards: the reggaetn star Daddy Yankee.) For record of the year, which recognizes a songs performers, Mr. Sanz (Desde Cuando) is up against Camila (Mientes), the Brazilian singer Maria Bethnia (Tua), the Spanish singer Buika (Se Me Hizo Fcil) and Mr. Drexler, an Uruguayan singer-songwriter, for his Una Cancin Me Trajo Hasta Aqu. The Latin Grammys ceremony will be on Nov. 11 at the Mandalay Bay in Las Vegas, and broadcast live by Univision.

title: Caseys Mystery Bidder: 7-Eleven
description: 7:12 p.m. | Updated The New York Times has more.

title: Disturbed, at No. 1 Again, Earns Rare Distinction
description: Metallica and the Dave Matthews Band you expect to be giants of the Billboard charts. But Disturbed? A metal band from Chicago that is led by David Draiman, above, and has sold 11 million albums worldwide, Disturbed can now, with the success of Asylum (Reprise), its new CD, claim a rare chart distinction: along with Metallica and the Dave Matthews Band it is the only other rock band to have four consecutive releases go to No. 1. Asylum sold 179,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, beating out hits by Eminem and Katy Perry. Vol. 35 of the Now Thats What I Call Music! compilation series, with songs by the Black Eyed Peas, Lady Gaga, Justin Bieber and 17 others, opened at No. 2 with 105,000 sales, and Eminems Recovery (Aftermath/Interscope) holds at No. 3 in its 11th week out with 93,000. Ms. Perrys Teenage Dream (Capitol), last weeks chart-topper, fell to No. 4 with 88,000, a 54 percent drop from its first-week sales. The American Idol alumna Fantasia fell three spots to No. 5 with her third album, Back to Me (J).

title: Naomi Campbell: Model, Citizen
description: I HAVE a past, Naomi Campbell said on Tuesday. Im not proud of my past, some of the circumstances I was in. Ive said that a hundred times. But I admit to my past. I own it. I dont deny it. Denial is a very bad thing.

title: How a Captive Reporter Used Twitter
description: A Japanese journalist who was released this week after being held captive in Afghanistan for five months explained on Tuesday how he had managed to post two updates on Twitter from the phone of one of his captors.

title: Nearly 5 Jobless Workers Per Opening in July
description: There were slightly fewer than five unemployed workers for each job opening in July, according to a new Labor Department report. Once again, thats a better ratio than what the economy showed earlier this year, but it still indicates persistent softness in the American labor market.

title: G.M. Makes a Play for Buyers and Investors
description: LORDSTOWN, Ohio  With its coming public stock offering as a backdrop, General Motors on Wednesday rolled out the Chevrolet Cruze, its most earnest attempt at building a compact car that Americans might buy because they like it  not simply because it is cheap.

title: The Guardians of Americas Front Lawn
description: WASHINGTON  Representatives of the National Museum of African American History and Culture filed into a meeting room here last Thursday to discuss alternative designs for their proposed new building on the National Mall.

title: Piers Morgan to Step Into Larry Kings Shoes
description: Piers Morgan will take over for Larry King in January, CNN announced on Wednesday, putting an end to the summer-long speculation about one of the most prized time slots in television.

title: Trouble in the Heartland
description: As Bruce Springsteen, who is currently the subject of a special exhibit at Clevelands Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, sang in Badlands, theres trouble in the heartland. And a lot of political action as well, which could bode well for the Buckeye States bid to land the 2012 Democratic National Convention.

title: The Father of Modern Architectural Minimalism
description: How is a multimillion-dollar NoHo penthouse like a monastery, or a Calvin Klein store like a state-of-the-art racing yacht? They have been wiped clean of thingness (as the writer Bruce Chatwin might have said) by John Pawson, the father of modern architectural minimalism. Now 61, the British architect  who slept on a white hammock at boarding school and once spent 24 hours in a Japanese monastery, thinking he might like to be a monk  has a new monograph, John Pawson: Plain Space. Written with Alison Morris and out next month from Phaidon, it presents 30 startlingly minimal and gleaming white projects: boats, abbeys, houses and even a cricket pavilion. A show of the same title opens Sept. 22 at the London Design Museum, which Mr. Pawson has been hired to redesign.

title: Bookends
description: LUKE IVES PONTIFELL, 42, founded Thornwillow Press 25 years ago, when he was a teenager  and with his wire-rimmed glasses, suspenders and striped tie tucked into high-waisted khakis, he looks the part of someone who has devoted his life to books.

title: Fending Off the Weeds With Newsprint
description: THE garden suffered through another heat wave last week: day after day in the high 90s and no rain. (Didnt I say that a few weeks ago?) Hurricane Earl roared up the East Coast, without a drop falling on our garden in Maryland.

title: On a Mission to Save Cruise Ship Dcor
description: MOORPARK, Calif.

title: Armoires Made From Fallen Birch Trees
description: Old farmhouses and urban lofts have one thing in common: a lack of closet space. With that in mind, the Sawkille Company, a new store in Rhinebeck, N.Y., is offering a sustainable storage solution, appropriate for country or city: a white birch-bark armoire.

title: Panasonics Streamlined Massage Chair
description: Panasonic has been making massage chairs since 1969, but people using those chairs put them in the basement or in the office, said Walter Taffarello, the group marketing manager for the wellness group at the Panasonic Corporation of North America. Not in the living room.

title: A Mirror Framed in Copper
description: Genesis, a new mirror from the textile designer Maya Romanoff, is framed in thin oxidized copper squares inlaid in basswood.

title: Design Firm Turns Dinnerware Into Works of Art

title: Sales at Moss, Crate & Barrel and McGuire

The brave thing is how Goran Paskaljevic, the director and (with Genc Permeti) writer, chooses to end the film: short of either a happy ending or a tragic one, in the same sort of limbo that this part of the world seems to inhabit perpetually.

Not surprisingly, the battle to procure these black beauties has resembled handbags at dawn. The reaction has been quite exciting, says Hermss C.E.O., Robert Chavez. title: Filmmakers Tread Gently on Authors Dystopia
description: MARK ROMANEKS Never Let Me Go, which opens Wednesday, is the latest in the seemingly unstoppable, self-replicating tradition of films about cloning. It goes without saying that most of them look alike. But if youre unfamiliar with the book on which its based, Kazuo Ishiguros luminous novel of the same name, or if you want to be surprised this time by some unusual genetic modification, you might want to stop reading right here. Thats because this movie deviates from the standard Hollywood premise that clones are by definition evil, debased versions of their originals. It also deviates from the lesser convention that clones, like the monstrous replacement 8-year-old in Godsend or the Arnold Schwarzenegger duplicate in The Sixth Day, must be named Adam.

title: Mexico: Reporters Fall Victim to Crackdown on Drug Trafficking
description: More than 30 journalists have been killed or have disappeared in the nearly four years since Mexico began a bloody crackdown on drug trafficking organizations, an advocacy group reported Wednesday. Most of the crimes remain unsolved, the report by the New York City-based Committee to Protect Journalists said, and are often marked by shoddy investigations. Several news organizations, it said, have resorted to not reporting on drug-related crime and corruption for fear of running afoul of drug kingpins, who have planted operatives in newsrooms and corrupted some journalists. The report recommended strengthening laws against attacks on free expression.

They are right to be worried. But this week, at least, voters were given a clear choice about the direction the country can take in November and beyond.

title: Britain: Premiers Father Dies
description: Prime Minister David Camerons father died Wednesday shortly after the British leader joined other family members at his hospital bedside in Toulon, France. His father, Ian Cameron, 77, had suffered a stroke while on vacation. Mr. Cameron flew to France after learning of his fathers condition Wednesday morning. The trip caused him to cancel an appearance in Parliament, where he was expected to face questioning over the role of his communications director, Andy Coulson, in a cellphone hacking scandal. In a television interview this spring, Mr. Cameron said he had been inspired by his father, who, though born with a severe deformity in both legs that led eventually to their amputation, played competitive tennis as a youth and had a successful career as a stockbroker. My father is a huge hero figure for me, because hes an amazingly brave man, Mr. Cameron said. To have a disability in the 1930s and 1940s, a different age, was really tough, but he never let it affect him in any way.

title: War Games
description: Unless you regard something like Iron Man as a film about Afghanistan, the movies inspired by Americas contemporary wars have consistently been box-office flops. Even The Hurt Locker grossed only $16 million in theaters. Video games that evoke our current conflicts, on the other hand, are blockbusters  during the past three years, they have become the most popular fictional depictions of Americas current wars. Last years best-selling game was Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, which opens in Afghanistan; it was a sequel to a multimillion-selling 2007 game that features an American invasion of a nameless Middle Eastern country. Modern Warfare 2 has made Avatar-like profits for its studio, Activision. On the day the game was published in November, it sold nearly five million copies in North America and Britain, racking up $310 million in sales in 24 hours. By January of this year, the games worldwide sales added up to $1 billion.

Mr. Suellentrop notes that the Modern Warfare series, unlike films on the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan that have failed to draw a sizeable audiences in theaters, has demonstrated that players have an appetite for games that purport to connect them to the wars their college roommates, or their sons, might be fighting in.

title: Alabama: Execution Set for Man Whose Competency Is Questioned
description: A man whose lawyers contend he received inadequate legal counsel during sentencing and should have been classified as mentally retarded is scheduled to be executed Thursday. In January, the United States Supreme Court upheld the death penalty for the man, Holly Wood, 50, who confessed to shooting his ex-girlfriend while she slept. Defense lawyers argued that a court-appointed lawyer with less than a year of trial experience failed to tell jurors during sentencing that Mr. Wood is not mentally competent to be executed. His I.Q. has been found to be well below 70, the score that experts often consider the border for mental retardation. But Alabama, like many states, considers other factors, including performance tests and employment history in evaluating competence.

title: Study Questions Impact of Fourteenth Amendment
description: A repeal of the Fourteenth Amendment, which guarantees citizenship to anyone born in the United States, would cause big increases in the population of illegal immigrants in the country, said a report published Wednesday by the Migration Policy Institute, a nonpartisan research group. Using statistical projections, the report showed that the number of illegal immigrants could grow by 2020 to 14 million  about 3 million over the current estimate of 11.1 million  if citizenship were denied to children born in the United States who have at least one parent who is an illegal immigrant. By 2050, the population could reach 24 million, according to the projection, by Jennifer Van Hook, a professor of demography at Pennsylvania State University. Proponents of the repeal have argued that it would reduce the number of illegal immigrants by discouraging them from coming to this country to give birth.

description: Households and corporations alike are refinancing their loans in droves to take advantage of interest rates that seem impossibly cheap. But those same low rates come with a flip side, driving down the income of retirees and others who live off their savings, Graham Bowley writes in The New York Times.

title: Five Hours Back (and Forth) to School
description: After Neidaly Cruzs school, the New York Harbor School, moved from Brooklyn to Governors Island this summer, her commute grew to two and a half hours from 45 minutes.

title: BP Spill Report Hints at Legal Defense
description: BP spent months this summer trying to contain the gusher of oil on the floor of the Gulf of Mexico. Now the company is trying to contain the legal and financial fallout from the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon, and on Wednesday it released the results of an internal investigation that mostly pointed fingers at other companies, Ian Urbina writes in The New York Times.

title: News Quiz | September 9, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Indian-Pakistani Team Reaches Doubles Final
description: With the hope of promoting peace between their nations, the doubles team of Rohan Bopanna, from India, and Aisam-Ul-Haq Qureshi, from Pakistan, achieved two remarkable firsts Wednesday at the United States Open.

title: David Dortort, Bonanza Creator, Dies at 93
description: David Dortort, a television writer and producer whose idea to create a western drama based not on shoot-em-ups but instead on the travails of a loving family resulted in Bonanza, one of the most popular shows in history, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 93.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra Gets Some Financial Aid
description: The financially troubled Philadelphia Orchestra says it has received $4 million from the William Penn Foundation to help pay for its operations, and another half-million toward an intensive strategic planning process. The orchestra, which recently emerged from a leadership vacuum, is struggling to finance its activities. To deal with major shortfalls it established what it calls a recovery fund, which  with the William Penn gift  now amounts to $12 million in donations and pledges. The foundation describes itself as dedicated to improving the quality of life in the Greater Philadelphia region.

title: Clive Donner, 1960s-Era Film Director, Dies at 84
description: Clive Donner, who helped define the British New Wave with films like The Caretaker and Nothing but the Best and directed the emblematic swinging 60s film Whats New Pussycat?, died on Tuesday in London. He was 84.

title: G.M. Makes a Play for Buyers and Investors
description: With its coming public stock offering as a backdrop, General Motors on Wednesday rolled out the Chevrolet Cruze, its most earnest attempt at building a compact car that Americans might buy because they like it  not simply because it is cheap, Nick Bunkley reports in The New York Times.

title: Saints and Vikings Together Again for N.F.L. Opener
description: The Favre Indecision may sound like a Robert Ludlum novel, but it is really the story of the Vikings off-season. Brett Favre is back in the Vikings huddle after Faux Retirement IV, but the Vikings have major questions that go beyond Favres gimpy ankle. Their receiving corps is thin in the wake of Sidney Rices injury, their big-name offensive line looked like a colander during the preseason, and the superstar running back Adrian Peterson is coming off a three-fumble performance in the Vikings 31-28 loss to the Saints in the N.F.C. title game. Despite his age and eroded approval rating, Favre retains the power to relegate the defending champion to the second paragraph.

title: Shares Rebound as Concern on Portugal Debt Subsides
description: Indexes on Wall Street resumed their rally Wednesday after a successful auction of Portuguese government debt eased concerns about Europes financial system.

title: Fed Report Finds Signs That Growth Is Slowing
description: The United States economy showed widespread signs of slowing, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday, though modest growth continued from mid-July through the end of August, Christine Hauser reports in The New York Times.

title: F.S.A. Fines Goldman Over Abacus Investigation
description: The British securities regulator said Thursday that it had fined Goldman Sachs 17.5 million, or nearly $27 million, for failing to disclose the Securities and Exchange Commissions investigation into the synthetic collateralized debt obligation known as Abacus.

title: Health Plan Wont Fuel Big Spending, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  A new government study says President Obamas health care law will have negligible effects on total national health spending in the next 10 years, neither slowing nor fueling the explosive growth of medical costs.

title: Smartpen Maker Livescribe Raises $39 Million
description: Smartpens are looking like a smart move at Livescribe. The company announced it has raised $39 million in a third round of funding to further build the market for its Echo and Pulse smartpens, which have tiny computers inside them, VentureBeat reported.

description: An influential United States banking regulator raised concern on Wednesday about the risk of exposure the government is taking on in the mortgage market and urged more stringent standards for underwriting mortgages, Reuters said.

title: Can Kno Bring Tablets to the Classroom?
description: Kno, the maker of an coming digital textbook tablet, announced Wednesday it has secured $46 million as part of an equity and debt round, VentureBeat reported. Andreesen-Horowitz was the lead in the round, with Silicon Valley Bank and TriplePoint Capital participating.

description: Test your literacy skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues with sentences from two Opinion pieces and a blog post: Attacking Social Security, Rage and Floods in Pakistan and Numberplay: Hanging Over the Edge.

title: Lloyds Agrees to Sell Crest Nicholson Stake to Varde
description: Lloyds has agreed to sell its stake in the home builder Crest Nicholson to the American investment company Varde, continuing to shed noncore assets and refocus on its core lending activities, Reuters reported.

description: UBS has hired two bankers to join its team serving ultrahigh-net-worth individuals Singapore, the bank said in an internal memo, Reuters reported.

description: Norway, which has amassed the worlds second-biggest sovereign wealth fund, says Greece wont default on its debts, Bloomberg News reports.

title: S.E.C. Calls Proposed Citi Settlement is Fair
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has defended its proposed $75 million settlement with Citigroup, saying the penalty reasonably accounted for the seriousness of the banks alleged misconduct, Reuters said, citing a document filed in court on Wednesday.

title: Philippines Leader Faults Police Over August Siege
description: MANILA  The Philippine government acknowledged for the first time on Thursday that some of the Hong Kong tourists killed aboard a hijacked bus last month here may have been hit by police fire.

title: Car Bomb Explodes in Market in Restive Region of Russia
description: MOSCOW  A car loaded with explosives detonated in a central market in Russias restive North Caucasus region on Thursday, killing at least 16 people and wounding as many as 100 in what the authorities said was most likely a suicide attack.

title: Approval of Share Offering Weighs on Bank of China
description: Bank of Chinas Shanghai-listed shares languished on Thursday, reflecting lingering concerns over the health of the sector after the bank obtained regulatory approval for an $8.8 billion share placement in Hong Kong and Shanghai, Reuters reported.

title: Thursdays Matchup: Vikings at Saints
description: The Favre Indecision may sound like a Robert Ludlum novel, but its really the story of the Vikings off-season. Brett Favre is back in the Vikings huddle, but the Vikings have major questions that go beyond Favres gimpy ankle. Their receiving corps is thin in the wake of Sidney Rices injury, their big-name offensive line looked like a colander during the preseason, and the star running back Adrian Peterson is coming off a three-fumble performance in the Vikings 31-28 loss to the Saints in the N.F.C. title game. Despite his age and eroded approval rating, Favre retains the power to relegate the defending champions to the second paragraph.The Saints are as unassuming as Super Bowl winners get. Minor scandals nip at their heels (Reggie Bushs Heisman trophy is being melted by the N.C.A.A. and recast as a Yoke of Shame), but the most succulent story to stick to the team has been Sean Paytons affinity for fruit-flavored gum. Get me Juicy Fruit  not (bleeping) Spearmint, Payton yelled at the assistant Adam Bailey at the Super Bowl; you can picture Payton later channeling Joan Crawford in Mommie Dearest and bludgeoning Bailey with a carton of Dentine.

title: Singapores G.I.C. Starts $3 Billion I.P.O.

description: Few events could so completely satisfy an escapist fantasy of a life lived in luxury than the Biennale des Antiquaires. Now in its 25th decadent year, the festival brings together exceptional antique art, jewelry and furniture at the glorious Grand Palais from Sept. 15 to 22. Art dealers, collectors, jewelers and anyone curious about great art can wander exhibitions as refined as the objects on display. And expect crowds: the last Biennale drew about 80,000 people.

description: Craig Henderson of Bellingham, Wash., which is about 90 miles north of Seattle, planned to drive his home-built car from the Canadian border to Mexico without stopping for fuel. Before leaving on Aug. 29, hed carefully calculated that his streamlined car could travel the more than 1,400 miles on 14 gallons of diesel.

title: On Our Radar: An Asian Carp Czar
description: The Obama administration appoints an Asian carp czar to oversee the federal response to keeping the invasive species out of the Great Lakes. When it comes to the Asian carp threat, we are not in denial. We are not in a go-slow mode. We are in a full attack, full-speed-ahead mode, says Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois. We want to stop this carp from advancing. [Chicago Tribune]

First, Terry Jones, the Florida pastor who set the world on edge with plans to burn copies of the Koran on Sept. 11, said Thursday that he had canceled his demonstration because he had won a promise to move the proposed Islamic center near ground zero to a new location.

title: Longtime Fans
description: Once the signature accessory for Karl Lagerfeld, who reportedly used them to ward off cigarette smoke, the fan  or ventail, as it is known in French  arguably reached its fashion zenith around the heyday of Oscar Wildes Lady Windermere. But fears of appearing dmode never stopped Raphalle de Panafieu from toting one around. I always carried fans my father brought back from his trips to Asia, recalls de Panafieu, who, along with Elose Gilles, recently bought the long-dormant French fan maker Duvelleroy. They were bamboo throwaways, very simple. But they never left my purse.

Fields of corn, potatoes and other crops can be seen dotting land that would otherwise be semi-desert, and the spray from some types of irrigation systems creates perfect circles of green in these parched landscapes.

title: A Chinese Advocate Is Freed, but Stays Under Surveillance
description: BEIJING  A blind, self-taught lawyer imprisoned by the Chinese authorities in 2006 after years of exposing government abuses was freed Thursday and confined to his home in Shandong Province, surrounded by guards and watched through closed-circuit surveillance cameras.

title: For Snooki, a Day at the Beach Becomes 2 Days of Community Service (and a Fine)
description: President Obama may say from time to time that he has no idea who Snooki is, but Judge Damian G. Murray of Seaside Heights Municipal Court in New Jersey certainly seemed to recognize her. On Wednesday he handed Nicole Polizzi, the diminutive Jersey Shore star better known as Snooki, a $500 fine and a sentence of two days community service after she pleaded guilty to disturbing people at a New Jersey beach on July 30, The Associated Press reported. From the bench Judge Murray called Ms. Polizzi a Lindsay Lohan wannabe and invoked a few lines from Animal House, telling her, Rude, profane, obnoxious and self-indulgent is not the way to live your life. A lawyer for Ms. Polizzi told the judge she was under the influence of some alcohol when the incident occurred, during taping for a coming third season of Jersey Shore.

title: Open House: Should a Roof Be Built Over Ashe?
description: Gerry Marzorati:  Good morning, Michael. I thought talking about weather conditions incessantly was something you only did if you were an airline pilot or a wedding planner but, No! You do it when you toss a small, fuzzy ball in the air and try to strike it cleanly as it descends. At one point yesterday, I watched poor Gal Monfils watch one of his tosses end up completely out of his reach  nearly halfway to the service line. Maybe thats what led him to try the most ridiculous  and thoroughly entertaining  shot Ive ever seen: A splay-legged jump tweener facing the net from the baseline. Hes too young to have watched A.B.A. games, right?

title: Bob Dylan in America

title: Sean Wilentzs History Bob Dylan in America
description: Theres a reason the title of Sean Wilentzs Bob Dylan in America makes it sound like a semesters worth of American Studies. Theres also a reason that a flipped version of the title, America in Bob Dylan, could be a college course with the identical curriculum. And Mr. Wilentzs book actually contains the following marvel of rhetorical pedantry: What does America tell us about Bob Dylan  and what does Dylans work tell us about America?

title: Living Together, Aging Together

One day wed buy it and create the Montclair Old Newspersons Home, taking seats on the co-op board so we could approve as residents only people we actually wanted to live with. title: Maybe Parents Do Understand? Will Smiths Daughter Gets a Record Deal
description: Its always nice to see the music industry make room for a talented newcomer. On Wednesday, the Roc Nation entertainment company announced that it had signed a recording deal with the 9-year-old pop singer Willow Smith, whose debut single, Whip My Hair, has become a viral sensation after hitting the Web earlier this week. In a news release, Roc Nation said that Willow Smith, who is the sister of the Karate Kid actor Jaden Smith and  oh, yes  the daughter of the superstars Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith, will shoot her debut video in Los Angeles later this month. Jay-Z, the Roc Nation founder and president, said in a statement, Its rare to find an artist with such innate talent and creativity at such a young age. Willow is about to embark on an incredible journey and we look forward to joining her as she grows in all aspects of her career.

title: Photos of the Moment | Chadwick Bell
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

title: Visiting Ground Zero, Asking Allah for Comfort
description: Nearly every Sept. 11 since Sept. 11, Hadidjatou Karamoko Traor has made sure that her three children were dressed in their best clothes, and taken them from their tidy brick home in the Bronx to the pit where the World Trade Center stood, and where her husband, their father, worked and died.

title: TimesCast | September 9, 2010
description: Today, Brian Stelter and David Carr on a Florida pastor's planned Koran burning, a report from a bare knuckle Ohio house race and the Obama administration's efforts to spur U.S. manufacturing.

title: Look Over There! Yes, Its  a Celebrity!
description: Last week, Jan Benzel, a culture editor at The Times, wrote about seeing celebrities in New York as part of her New York Send-Off series of posts related to her departure for Paris. She hit a nerve. Dozens of City Room readers sent in reports of their own sightings. Here are some of our favorites:

title: Q&A: A Family Christmas in Puerto Rico
description: Q.

title: It Takes More Than Passion
description: Thanks for the great comments to my last post. Several of the comments made me stop and think about my own situation and experiences. While some very important lessons were passed along, I feel the need to offer a little context on some important subjects.

title: Theater Talkback: Childrens Theater the Right Way
description: This summer ArtsBeat has been inviting members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. So far our guests have tackled the topics of comedy, ethics, dont ask, dont tell, immigration and how to define a hit show.

title: Richard Chai Gets the Week Off to a Slick Start
description: This post marks the debut a new series, Fast Fashion, in which Eric Wilson will be sharing his first impressions of some of the latest runway shows.

title: SAP Looks to Benefit From the Oracle Tempest
description: To most in the technology industry, Larry Ellisons latest adventure  the rapid-fire hiring of Mark V. Hurd, ousted Hewlett-Packard chief executive, and the resulting Silicon Valley fireworks  is entertainment.

title: Analysis: How Federer Conquered the Wind and Soderling
description: At 3-3 in the first set of their quarterfinal match last night, Roger Federer broke Robin Soderling with three smart shots into the wind, the last a breathtaking inside out forehand drop shot on break point that died in the wind for a winner. Before that, Soderling had been in control, holding serve easily and nearly breaking Federer twice.

title: The Surgeons Pact With the Patient
description: The patient, in her late 50s with failing kidneys, had come to the hospital for what she and her doctors thought would be a simple procedure preparing her for dialysis. But instead of returning home the next day, the woman ended up in the hospital for nearly half of my internship. Her procedure went awry, she landed in the intensive care unit, and over the course of the next six months she returned at least a dozen more times to the operating room, all failed attempts to right what had gone so terribly wrong.

title: Charlie Rose Joins the Legion of Honor
description: PARIS  Charlie Rose was made a knight in the Legion of Honor on Thursday in a ceremony at the French Finance Ministry. Christine Lagarde, the finance minister, lauded Mr. Rose as a great journalist, interviewer and friend of France. Mr. Rose, 68, declared himself a longtime devotee of Paris and singled out for special thanks Martine Frank, the widow of the photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson; and the heart surgeon Alain Carpentier, who performed what Mr. Rose said was life-saving open heart surgery in 2006. Both were among a cluster of friends gathered to fete Mr. Rose; others included the French philosopher Bernard-Henri Lvy, the political analyst Dominique Moisi and the director Danile Thompson.

title: Consenting to Surgery and More?
description: When a patient signs a surgical consent form, is he or she agreeing to more than just surgery?

title: More Doors Open in Rome
description: GAINING entry to Romes archaeological sites is never a sure thing. Long affected by collapses, paltry budgets and red tape, historic sites must often limit access, even to places that have been recently restored at great expense. But this fall, many sites are revealing themselves anew, extending their hours and opening up areas that had been shuttered to the public.

title: Planned Koran Burning Drew International Scorn
description: Before a Florida pastor canceled his plans to burn copies of the Koran on Sept. 11, the international outcry intensified Thursday, drawing vocal condemnations from world leaders and touching off angry protests in corners of the Muslim world.

title: Wireless Goes Strapless | iPad Clutches
description: No doubt, the iPad has caused quite a stir. (If you dont have one, you want one.) While some of us may be waiting for the next gen before diving in, a handful of fashion designers are already outfitting their iPads in the chicest of cases  no Swarovski bedazzling necessary. The iPad suits our needs: its practical, versatile and mobile, says Oscar de la Renta, who is smitten with his device and has already designed a pearlized taupe clutch for his well-wired fans. All casing aside, what are de la Rentas latest apps? I recently downloaded Netflix and Pandora, he says. I hope I am the first person to create a Bizet station. You may not have created your own Carmen channel, but surely you can be an early adopter of the first iPad clutches and get a head start accessorizing the holiday seasons must-have gift.

title: 36 Hours in Charleston, S.C.
description: CHARLESTON still has its cannons aimed at Fort Sumter, where the Civil War began, and has elected the same mayor, Joseph Riley, since 1975. It even has some of the countrys most aggressive historic preservation. But that doesnt mean this charming Southern city has nothing new to offer. There are new galleries on Broad Street, and a festoonery of restaurants, bars and boutique bakeries have transformed the once-struggling design district on upper King Street. Charlestonians, governed by laws of hospitality as incontrovertible as those of gravity, cannot help themselves from sharing their new finds, even if you are from off, as those who grew up on this once swampy peninsula refer to outsiders.

title: A Weekend in Charleston, S.C.
description: Though still historic, this charming Southern city has plenty of new offerings.

title: Barnes & Noble Urges Holders to Reject Burkle
description: Barnes & Noble, the object of a proxy battle by the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle, sent shareholders a letter urging them to vote for its board nominees and to reject Mr. Burkles candidates, Reuters reports.

title: Hotel Review: Babuino 181 in Rome
description: BASICS

title: Vain Glorious | Flowerbomb Turns Five
description: Last night, Viktor & Rolf hosted an intimate gathering of beauty editors and a smattering of models  Erin Wasson, Shalom Harlow, Elisa Sednaoui  to commemorate five years since launching its first fragrance, Flowerbomb (an occasion famously celebrated with a Grace Jones performance in March across the pond). The soiree was held in a Grove Street town house that looked quite like the tuxedo-jacket-clad designers Amsterdam headquarters and featured a huge Flowerbomb bottle replica in pink flowers.

title: Solar Dreams and Reality at the White House
description: A bio-fueled road trip from Unity, Maine, to the nations capital is aiming to press President Obama to put solar panels back on the White House. President Jimmy Carter had installed the first set of panels in 1979, but they were removed during the Reagan administration. Students from Unity College and allied climate campaigners, most notably Bill McKibben, are toting a treasured artifact owned by the school  one of the Carter-era solar hot water panels  to make the point.

title: U.S. Forces Take Ship From Somali Pirates
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  In a predawn raid with helicopters hovering nearby, 24 American Marines scaled aboard a hijacked ship in the Gulf of Aden on Thursday, arrested the nine pirates on board and freed the ship  all without firing a shot, the American military said.

title: A Cook Talks About Woks and Stir-Fries
description: The cookbook writer Grace Young recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers questions about stir-fries and wok cooking. Ms. Youngs new book, Stir-Frying to the Skys Edge, was recently published by Simon & Schuster.

title: Fast-Food Deal on a Fast Track
description: 3G Capital wants the Whopper now.

title: Deutsche Bank Said to Weigh Stock Sale
description: Deutsche Bank has begun approaching other banks about a potential stock sale that could raise as much as 9 billion euros, or $11.4 billion, Bloomberg News and The Financial Times reported on Thursday, citing unnamed sources.

title: Algae Blooms Were Not Red Tide, Officials Say
description: Yes, that stuff floating in the water last week was reddish, but no, it was not red tide. Nor was it toxic, environmental officials from New York and New Jersey said on Wednesday.

title: A.P. Wouldnt Have Shared Images of Koran Burning
description: Though a fringe pastor in Gainesville, Fla., has suspended plans to burn Korans, The Associated Press wire service said Thursday that it would not have shared any images of a Koran being burned.

title: A Challenge to Florida Beach-Driving Tradition
description: NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla.  Sandy Fletcher, a bartender with a dark tan at the Breakers beachfront restaurant here, remembers seeing the commotion in July. Lifeguards had stopped the usual flow of Sunday traffic on the hard sand. Sirens blared. We knew it was something bad, she said. Cellphones started ringing. Then they said it was a 4-year-old.

description: DECLINE and the erosion of the American dream infuse public discourse, so its inevitable that a streak of pessimism courses through the best new fall shows.

title: Inside the List
description: GOD CONFUSION: Tony Blairs memoir, A Journey, may have zoomed to No. 3 on the hardcover nonfiction list, but another Englishman has been hogging most of the headlines, or the flattering ones anyway. (Heres NPR: Tony Blair Cancels London Book Signing, Reluctant to Dodge More Shoes, Eggs.) After advance excerpts of Stephen Hawkings new book, The Grand Design(written with Leonard Mlodinow), appeared on both sides of the Atlantic, the Internet went wild with the news that Hawking had declared God dead after all, or at least unnecessary for setting off the Big Bang. (For good measure, he also declares that philosophy is dead.)

title: IndyCar Series Drops Watkins Glen From 2011 Schedule
description: Although the Izod IndyCar Series has gained traction recently, picking up television viewers, sponsors and participants, Randy Bernard, its first-year chief executive, said that he would announce several major changes to the 2011 schedule Friday in Milwaukee.

title: 4 Iraqi Prisoners Escape U.S. Custody
description: BAGHDAD  Four of the most dangerous prisoners in Iraq escaped overnight on Wednesday from American custody in a heavily fortified prison on the edge of Baghdad, an embarrassing security breach that led to an intensive manhunt, American and Iraqi officials said Thursday.

title: Above the City at Night, the Call of the Wild Is Heard
description: No matter how urbanized New Yorkers like to think we are, the reminders of our natural world are constant. Canada geese, raccoons even skunks have brushed up against humans recently in a somewhat rude manner. Or at least it was rude to us.

description: A view of the day in sports, including world championship action in basketball, judo and wrestling.

title: G.M. Ventures Invests $3.2 Million in Battery Company
description: A Michigan lithium-ion battery developer, which is working on new technology the company says can give electric cars greater range, plans to announce on Friday that it has received $3.2 million from General Motors Ventures. G.M. said the new batteries could eventually end up in the companys cars.

title: In West Virginia Race, Double Negatives
description: Gov. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia aired his first television commercial in his bid for the states open Senate seat on Wednesday night and it wasnt one of those fluffy biography ads.

title: Fashions Night In
description: Ever wonder how clothing designers dress their homes? The Council of Fashion Designers of America and Assouline are publishing American Fashion Designers At Home. Written by Rima Suqi, a contributor to T and The New York Times, the coffee-table book ($65, which benefits the CFDA Foundation) looks at the homes of 115 CFDA members, from heavyweights like Diane von Furstenberg and Kate Spade to relative newcomers like Band of Outsiders Scott Sternberg. The interiors, which range from luxurious  like Eva Chows gold-leafed Los Angeles living room or Tory Burchs opulent, surprisingly conservative Manhattan apartment  to industrial-funky, like Rachel Comeys Long Island weekend house, may seem glamorous to those of us on the outside looking in. But as Suqi points out, even fashion designers are not immune to the pitfalls of decorating or renovating. They have nightmare contractors, too.

title: Ron Bloom Is Obamas Manufacturing Emissary
description: Not since Ronald Reagan has an American president spoken so emphatically about the importance of manufacturing. Weve got to go back to making things, Barack Obama says, embedding that view in his oratory. Yet manufacturings presence in the American economy continues to shrink, defying the administrations attempts to reverse that trend.

title: A Ray of Sunshine in Every Bite
description: In my neighborhood it is known simply as the muffin shop, and it is the muffin shop, though that is kind of a shame because the real name, Blue Sky Bakery, is just so right.

title: Obamas Missed Opportunity: Answers From Matt Bai, Part I
description: 6:44 p.m. | Updated In his Political Times column on Wednesday, Matt Bai asserted that President Obama had missed an opportunity to rally the public behind his long-term initiative to restructure the economy. He is answering readers questions about the presidents approach and other top political issues this week.

title: After Fire, Phillips Collection Seeks Donations Via Texting
description: Small donations via text message raised millions of dollars for Haitian earthquake victims. Are museums next? The Phillips Collection in Washington on Thursday announced a campaign to solicit $5 and $10 donations via text message to raise money for repairs to its building after a fire on Sept. 2. No artwork was damaged, but the museums offices were harmed.

title: The New Season
description: The fall television season brings a full serving of new crime fighters and comedies.

title: More Children Being Raised by Grandparents
description: The number of American children being raised by their grandparents rose after the recession began, according to a report from Pew Social Research.

title: A Year in MP3s
description: Last September, my best friend, Susan, told me that I didnt make enough music anymore. She was right; between 1996 and 2003, I put out a new record every year, played a few shows a month and did quite a bit of composing, mostly for solo musicians or small ensembles Id met over the years.

title: Toronto Film Festival Heads Downtown
description: TORONTOThe change is palpable, as the giant annual film festival here shifted its weight downtown, toward its new Bell Lightbox center in the entertainment district and away from the high-toned hotels and eateries of Yorkville. Good-bye Four Seasons, hello, Hooters, the Fox and Fiddle, and the Canadiana Backpackers Inn. All are a stones throw from the Scotiabank Theater, now a primary screening place for festival films. This reporter stopped into a restaurant just across the street from the Lightbox on Wednesday night, thinking to have dinner. The hostess pointed toward a nicely situated four-top near the window, and even cleaned up half of it. Oh, O.K., she said, on being asked if the dirty glass and tableware might disappear from the other half as well.

title: Fiddler Up His Sleeve: Lin-Manuel Mirandas Wedding Surprise
description: We werent able to make it Sunday to the wedding of Lin-Manuel Miranda and Vanessa Nadal (our invitations must have gotten lost in the mail or something), but the good folks at Broadway.com have posted this video of what was surely a highlight of the post-nuptial celebration: a wedding toast delivered by Mr. Miranda, the creator and composer of In the Heights, and his new father-in-law. It gradually turns into a family performance of Bock and Harnicks To Life, with lyrics modified for the occasion. Make sure you stick around for the choreography  youll be totally kvelling.

title: A Clip From Score: A Hockey Musical
description: What goes together better than musical numbers and Canadas national sport? The Toronto International Film Festival will be celebrating both when it opens Thursday night with Score: a Hockey Musical. The film, directed by the Toronto-based filmmaker Michael McGowan, tells the story of a teenage hockey player (Noah Reid) and features Olivia Newton-John, along with a variety of Canadian personalities. The above clip gives a taste of the movies approach to the sport.

title: Turkey Channeled White Shadow as Basketball Caught On
description: ISTANBUL  The heyday of the television series The White Shadow was three decades ago, but Ken Howard, who played its main character, is still recognized on the street. American men who were in their teens in the late 1970s and early 80s will lock eyes with him, smile and utter the same greeting: Hey, Coach.

title: Fashion Week Preview | Prabal Gurung
description: In a T Magazine exclusive, Prabal Gurung gives us a sneak peek at his spring/summer 2011 collection before it is shown on the runway at New York Fashion Week this Saturday. If youre wondering what the springboard for the collection is, Gurung mentioned on the day of his recent T video shoot that he has been more than a little obsessed with the protagonist in the coming Maggie Betts documentary and with Tilda Swintons bougie turn in I Am Love. Its a study in the power of femininity, Gurung said, but not in a clichd way. I like the nuanced  and, you know, a really powerful woman can say so much with a nod or simply a word or two. All the women I love have that quiet strength.

title: Keeping a Summer Tradition, Despite Risks
description: Despite pleas from parents whose children have been killed by cars on the beach to ban the practice, driving on the sand remains a favorite activity on some Florida beaches.

description: After voting for George W. Bush in 2004, Tuscarawas County in Ohio went for President Obama four years later. Republicans are counting on regaining support in areas like this.

title: Jos Manuel Carreo to Retire
description: Jos Manuel Carreo, the veteran American Ballet Theater dancer, has announced he is retiring in August 2011. A special farewell evening for Mr. Carreo, who joined the company as a principal in 1995, will take place on June 30 at the Metropolitan Opera House and will feature a special performance of Swan Lake with Mr. Carreo in the role of Prince Siegfried, dancing opposite Julie Kent as Odette and Gillian Murphy as Odile. Mr. Carreo, who was born in Cuba, joined the English National Ballet in 1990 and the Royal Ballet in 1993. With American Ballet Theater, he has danced many roles, including the title character in Apollo, Albrecht in Giselle, Des Grieux in Manon and Solor in La Bayadre. In a 2000 review of La Bayadre Anna Kisselgoff wrote: Mr. Carreo as Solor, the warrior who leaves Nikiya to marry Gamzatti, the rajahs daughter, plumbs his role with depth and brilliance. He was a sensitive hero, troubled but commanding. Following his retirement from American Ballet Theater, he plans to continue performing as a guest artist.

Men in Blue Without Shades of Gray

A police officer tackled the man almost immediately.

description: With just a few weeks to go until Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps hits theaters, theres a lot to talk about: the portrayal of the financial crisis, accurate or not; the acting; the symbolism. (And the cameos!)

title: The Tale of Two Umudugudus (Villages)
description: It is difficult to account for the many effects on a community of having access to a clean and consistent supply of drinking water. Through a comparison of two umudugudus (villages), one with an improved source of water and the other without, I will try to document some of the themes that have occurred to me thus far. But before I begin this analysis I want to give a brief comparison of the two umudugudus.

title: Christian Siriano on the Spice Route
description: One of the joys of Fashion Week is when designers leave little notes along the front row seats explaining their inspirations for the season. Christian Siriano, at his 2 p.m. show (view complete runway show), included a photo that showed the feet of one of his models. There was also a description of the shoes he had designed for Payless, inspired by African, Indian and Chinese influences mixed with measures of elegant opulence.

description: Around Town

title: Jazz At Lincoln Center Heading To Cuba
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center announced on Thursday that it would send its in-house band, the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, to Cuba next month. The trip is a first for the organization, which has increasingly stressed the Cuban aspect of jazz, and was facilitated by the Cuban pianist Chucho Valds as part of a cultural exchange under the auspices of the Cuban Institute of Music, an agency of the Cuban Ministry of Culture. Mr. Valds, with his own band, already has New York concerts scheduled at Jazz at Lincoln Centers Allen Room on Oct. 22 and 23. We have been fantasizing about this for a long time, said Adrian Ellis, the organizations executive director, who noted that the Mellon, Ford, Rockefeller and two other smaller foundations came up with the money to pay for the trip once the band had secured approval from the United States government. The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, led by the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis, above, will perform concerts of different kinds in Cuba Oct. 5-9, with large and small ensembles, as well as a Jazz for Young People performance.

title: Art Collection To Be Sold
description: Max Palevsky, a founder of the computer-chip giant Intel, who died in May, collected art, lots of it. Christies will be selling his collection  more than 250 works ranging from antiquities to Impressionist, modern and contemporary art  in a series of auctions beginning in New York next month. The entire group is expected to bring $53 million to $78 million. Some works will be auctioned at Christies important Impressionist and modern art auction in New York on Nov. 3. Among them is Fernand Lgers Cup of Tea, above, a 1921 painting depicting a voluptuous woman posed against a geometric background, which is estimated to fetch $8 million to $12 million. The sale will also include works by Egon Schiele and Giorgio Morandi. More works will be auctioned the following week, on Nov. 10, at the New York postwar and contemporary sale, including a classic Pop image by Roy Lichtenstein, Girl in Mirror, from 1964, which is estimated to bring $3 million to $4 million.

title: U.S. Pressures I.M.F. to Expand Role of Growing Economies
description: WASHINGTON  In a move that has met with resistance in Europe, the United States is pushing to reduce the Continents influence over the International Monetary Fund and grant more of a say to economies outside of Europe that are growing and leading the global recovery.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra Gets Some Financial Aid
description: The financially troubled Philadelphia Orchestra says it has received $4 million from the William Penn Foundation to help pay for its operations and another half-million dollars toward an intensive strategic planning process. The orchestra, which recently emerged from a leadership vacuum, is struggling to finance its activities. To deal with major shortfalls it established what it calls a recovery fund, which  with the William Penn gift  now amounts to $12 million in donations and pledges. The foundation describes itself as dedicated to improving the quality of life in the Greater Philadelphia region.

description: A year after a disastrous 27 percent decline that prompted layoffs, salary freezes and a halt to some campus expansion, the Harvard endowment on Thursday reported a solid 11 percent increase in its $27.4 billion portfolio for the fiscal year ended June 30.

title: U.S. Basketball Team Advances to Semifinals
description: ISTANBUL  Chris Collinss legs bounced with nervous energy as he listened to The Star-Spangled Banner before the United States played Russia on Thursday in the quarterfinals of the world basketball championships.

title: Mantello Will Act For One Night
description: Joe Mantello, the Tony Award-winning director, will perform onstage for the first time since his run as an actor in the 1993-94 Broadway production of Angels in America, in an Oct. 18 benefit reading of Larry Kramers play The Normal Heart, in which Mr. Mantello will play the central role of Ned Weeks. Mr. Mantello, who won his directing Tonys for Take Me Out and Assassins, signed up for the reading of the landmark play about gay men and AIDS after having a conversation this winter with its director, Joel Grey, whom Mr. Mantello directed in the musical Wicked. Also in the ensemble cast for the reading at Broadways Walter Kerr Theater are Victor Garber, Jason Butler Harner, John Benjamin Hickey, Michael Stuhlbarg  and Patrick Wilson. The producer Daryl Roth is mounting the reading to raise money for two caregiver groups, Actors Fund and Friends in Deed.

title: Field Of talent Narrows While Top Model Weakens
description: As Americas Got Talent pared its top 10 contestants down to four, the results episode of that NBC reality show ranked No. 1 on Wednesday night, attracting a solid 11.9 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. That was enough to propel the network to first place for the night. On CW, the debut of the new cheerleading comedy-drama Hellcat gave the network something to shout about, drawing three million viewers and improving slightly on the premiere of Americas Next Top Model (2.9 million), whose ratings were down slightly from the seriess premiere last fall. CBS finished in second place for the night, and Fox was third with a two-hour installment of MasterChef (5.7 million). ABC ranked fourth with comedy reruns.
