title: Case Study | Beach-Plum Loco
description: Im back up in Cape Cod, feeding what has for several years been a smoldering mania for beach plums (prunus maritima), with an eye to making not jelly but rather a homemade liqueur I stumbled onto quite coincidentally. I happened to be here while researching an article on sloe gin a number of years back. I learned that sloe berries are a type of wild plum, the fruit of a shrub called a blackthorn tree that grows in hedgerows in England. The English have never been able to cultivate them, and the fruit  being mostly pit surrounded by a thin pulp that is equal parts bitter, sour and astringent  is used, when it is used at all, for making sloe gin. Its macerated in the strongest gin available, and sugar is added to the final result to create a homespun liqueur.

title: U.N. Flood Relief Official Says She Will Seek More Money
description: NOWSHERA, Pakistan  The top United Nations emergency relief official visited a camp for monsoon flood victims in this northwestern district on Thursday and said she would soon be seeking more aid money beyond the $460 million sought in the initial global appeal for help.

title: Navigating Tangiers Labyrinth
description: Outside of the ancient medina, the Moroccan city shows signs of modernity.

title: Lost in Tangier
description: AT midday in July, the Tangier medina was a ghost town. With shadows reduced to slivers, even in the narrowest of the ochre alleyways, residents retreated to lunch behind thick wooden doors or to relax inside their antique silver shops. It was hot and still, despite the occasional breeze from the Mediterranean, and only fools dared venture out  fools, that is, like me.

title: New Yorks Historical Homes for Autos
description: Among the very ambitious garages built in New York after 1900, some are still hard at work. But preservationists, by and large, take them as much for granted as everybody else.

title: Iran to Release Detained U.S. Hiker
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Iran plans to release Sarah E. Shourd, one of the three American hikers detained last year and accused of spying, Iranian officials said Thursday.

title: At Hangar 17, Pieces of Ground Zero
description: Panoramic photographs from an 80,000-square-foot hangar at Kennedy Airport where artifacts from Sept. 11, 2001, are being held.

title: For the Car, and Far From Pedestrian
description: CONSIDER the lowly garage, usually placed somewhere between the tenement and the outhouse as a fit subject for architectural appreciation and historic preservation. But public garages, which appeared in the early 1900s, often rose to respectable, even exciting, heights.

title: A Raucous Reflection on Identity: Jewish and Feminine
description: Dont be put off by the yawn-inducing title of the Jewish Museums Shifting the Gaze: Painting and Feminism. The show is a puckish, punchy look at the womens art movement, one that takes as much inspiration from Marcia Tuckers Bad Girls survey of 1994 as it does from more comprehensive, conventional shows of feminist art.

title: Glamour Revives Port of Batumi
description: AN illuminated tower soars above the clear Black Sea and the mist-covered Caucasus mountains surrounding the port town of Batumi, Georgia. Its night lights flood the skyline, revealing a new building that contrasts with the 19th-century facades of the old town and casting a warm glow over a palm tree-lined promenade of strolling lovers and giggling families. The majestic structure  the tallest on the seas coast  calls to mind a mosque, a library or a museum.

title: Sheraton Expands Footprint in China
description: Sheraton Hotels & Resorts is embarking on a wave of expansion in China, opening 8 hotels there by years end, which brings its 2010 total to 11. It plans to add 26 more in the next four years, far beyond its average of 4 per year.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: Art

title: An Israeli Oasis as a Passage to Ancient Times
description: THERE are many reasons not to travel overseas with small children, and, as far as I can tell, only one reason to do so. Unfortunately for my children, whod probably be just as happy to stay home, that reason is what keeps me slogging through the less glamorous parts of motherhood. When you travel you get the chance to prove to your children that life is at least as interesting as their bedtime stories. And if you can get them to believe that, then you can believe it too, at least for the duration of the trip.

title: If the Condo Fits, Then Buy It
description: WELCOME to fashion week,  la real estate! Our first fashion maven to trot down the runway will be Rita Magli, the creative director at Bruno Magli in the 1990s, back when her husband, Morris Magli, was at the companys helm. But rather than bags and stilettos, we will be showcasing Ms. Maglis new apartment. Happily for those with a poetic sensibility, the condominium is in a building that was once one of the largest shoe stores in the world.

title: The Creative Set Heads East in Beirut
description: The Mar Mikhael district is benefiting from a spillover from the hot Gemmayzeh neighborhood.

title: Dante Enters New Realm, Sothebys 10th Floor
description: The line between auction houses and art galleries keeps blurring. It is no longer unusual for Sothebys and Christies to take over entire galleries. Sothebys did it in 1996, when it bought the Andr Emmerich Gallery. Christies followed, taking over Hall & Knight in 2004 and then Haunch of Venison three years ago. Like dealers, both companies also do much business selling works of art for clients privately. Now Sothebys is encroaching on dealer territory yet again but in a slightly different way. This month it is opening Divine Comedy, an exhibition of some 75 works organized around the theme of Dantes epic poem.

title: Maybe He Sold in Search of Better Acoustics
description: WHAT do you expect the home of a metal band rock star to look like? If youre thinking black walls, skull-shaped door knobs, or at least something really, really loud, then youre out of luck  at least in the case of James Shaffer, the guitarist for the band Korn.

title: In the Present and Still Dance-Ready
description: Forget where youve been, Kele sang as he started his set at Webster Hall on Wednesday night with Walk Tall, the song that also starts his solo album, The Boxer (Glassnote). Cut your ties to the past and wave it goodbye. But he was smart not to take his own advice.

title: Betaworks and The Times Plan a Social News Service
description: Something is stirring deep within the technology incubator Betaworks: A personalized news service called News.me that is being developed in collaboration with The New York Times.

title: The Most Generous Countries on Earth
description: The United States is the fifth most-generous country on earth, tied with Switzerland, according to a new ranking fromGallups World Giving Index.

title: Deep Under Brooklyn, the Tours Will Resume
description: Bob Diamonds staying in Brooklyn, where hell continue his subterranean tours of a 19th-century railroad tunnel beneath Atlantic Avenue, and redouble his latest efforts to create a trolley line from Red Hook to Downtown Brooklyn.

title: Backstage at Fashion Week | Christian Siriano
description: The divinely scandalous designer Christian Siriano, who caused a flap this week with his comments about Brooke Shields and Haylie Duff, discusses the collection backstage.

title: Recapping Hard Knocks, Episode 5: King Revis
description: My apologies if I seem distracted, but I was woken up by the news of three-time Super Bowl champion Tom Bradys car accident.

title: Aggression on Wheels, With Bruises as Badges
description: AS a child of the 1970s, I spent a number of birthday parties in striped tube socks and bright white roller skates, whizzing around a place called Skate Country in New Orleans. I loved the freedom of doing figure eights to Olivia Newton John or couples skating to the Bee Gees. But when I entered the Hunter College gym this spring for the Gotham Girls Roller Derby home season opener, I instantly knew it was going to be so much better than Skate Country. On one side was a roaring crowd and on the other a line of the toughest-looking women in short shorts I had ever seen.

title: A Plug-In Electric for Hyundais Home Market
description: Hyundai introduced its BlueOn electric car on Thursday at a news conference in Seoul, South Korea. The automaker, which has experienced phenomenal growth in recent years, reportedly hopes to catch up with rival Japanese manufacturers who have a big head start in hybrid and plug-in electric vehicles.

title: Video and Latest Updates on Koran Burning Cancellation
description: Note: This post has been updated several times to reflect developments.

title: At Lower East Side Tenement Museum, Lectures and Opera
description: If youre reading this, theres a good chance youre overworked and underpaid. But dont let it get you down. Instead get some perspective from the trials and tribulations of the 19th-century factory workers of the Lower East Side. In what was once a tenement built in 1863, the Lower East Side Tenement Museum offers a series of free lectures, readings and panel discussions about the lives of its former residents and their contemporaries. On Wednesday Philip Dray talks about his book There Is Power in a Union: The Epic Story of Labor in America, accompanied by scenes from the Downtown Art theater troupes Waistmakers Opera, a musical depicting one of the first strikes by female workers in America. (108 Orchard Street, at Delancey Street; 212-982-8420, tenement.org; the series is free unless otherwise noted, but reservations are requested: events@tenement.org.)

title: Nobodys Fool
description: Images from a new exhibition of works by Yoshitomo Nara, at Asia Society Museum.

title: Where the Sidewalks End, and the City (Really) Begins
description: THE city as poem, art piece, happening, living theater: New Yorkers have all experienced their own versions, and the leaders of the conceptual walks that make up Elastic City want to create new ones.

title: Stem Cell Financing Ban Ends, for Now
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court here ruled Thursday that federal financing of embryonic stem cell research could continue while the court considers a judges order last month that banned the government from underwriting the work.

title: A Chance to Be Tim Gunn
description: Its a slightly surreal experience seeing the Project Runway finale at New York Fashion Week live, as hundreds of people did this morning at Lincoln Center. You have the immediacy of the event  the lights, the cameras, the booming techno music straight out of a gay disco in the 1980s, the celebrities (Jordin Sparks sitting two rows away, a rumored Britney Spears somewhere in the house). But what you miss is the shows most important element: the judges commentary.

title: For Pelosi and Markey, an Oil Sands Mission
description: Representatives Nancy Pelosi of California and Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts are in Canada this week to learn and listen about oil sands development there. The two Democrats are getting an earful from Canadian officials as well as from Canadian environmental groups on the pluses and minuses of importing oil from Alberta.

title: The Mystery of a Face, Up Close
description: Its startling how very little happens in Selective Memory, and how slowly. And then how many meanings unfold. This mixed-media work, which opened on Wednesday at the Chocolate Factory, is radical in that words primary sense: pertaining to or going to roots. Its a close-up study in perception: of a woman and, in particular, her face. It starts clinical, grows poetic and ends romantic.

title: A Ray of Sunshine in Every Bite
description: In my neighborhood it is known simply as the muffin shop, and it is the muffin shop, though that is kind of a shame because the real name, Blue Sky Bakery, is just so right.

title: Running Away From the Circus
description: Has Joaquin Phoenix lost it? That question began raging through the chattersphere in late 2008 and early 2009, especially after the actor showed up on the Late Show With David Letterman and didnt jovially sell the goods. Beefed up and scruffy-faced, wearing sunglasses and undertakers basic black, he didnt play to the crowd, flatter the host or flack for his latest film, Two Lovers.

title: Now Accessorizing | Fright Collar
description: No, these arent the faces of harried magazine editors during fashion week. The jeweler Eddie Borgo, who is up for this years CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund award, based his Horror Collar on the Mayor of Halloween Town in Tim Burtons 1993 film, The Nightmare Before Christmas. His wild mood swings made his cone head spin around from a happy face to a scary one, Mr. Borgo explains. Its a figurative representation of a two-faced politician. The silver-plated brass and crystal necklace is $500 at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
description: Muhammed Muheisen of The Associated Press depicts Ramadan by showing the shadow of a Palestinian youth in the West Bank reading verses of the Koran following an early morning prayer service. At almost the same time, Rosh Hashana was being celebrated in Ukraine (Slide 2).

title: Cuddling With Little Girls, Dogs and Music
description: Feeling a tad museum-phobic? Cowed by expanses of immaculate white walls? Whipsawed by hermetic, aloof artworks? If so, Asia Society has the cure. It is Yoshitomo Nara: Nobodys Fool, a homey, user-friendly exhibition that can feel like a little piece from somewhere over the rainbow.

title: Takeover Bid Shines Spotlight on Crucial Player in Potash
description: OTTAWA  It is hardly a household word like, say, the oil cartel OPEC. That is why Canpotex, an organization with a corner on Canadas potash production, used to go about its business in nearly complete obscurity.

title: Fashion Moments
description: In and around Lincoln Center during the first day of New York Fashion Week.

title: Fischers Paternity Test Released
description: Marilyn Young, the Filipino woman who said that her daughter, Jinky, was the child of Bobby Fischer is pressing ahead with a claim to his estate, though DNA tests have shown that Mr. Fischer was not Jinkys father.

title: New Lives, New Deaths, New Challenges
description: RETAIL sales of video games have dipped slightly in 2010, but the overall quality delivered by the interactive entertainment industry has never been higher. Major titles like Red Dead Redemption, God of War III, StarCraft II, Mass Effect 2 and Heavy Rain have already established this year as a watershed for consumers who plunk down the $60 that most top games cost these days.

title: A Wild Trip From Bathroom to Gallery
description: THE story of how of Dan Colen landed his first major show at the Gagosian Gallery sounds a bit like an art-world version of one of the Disney tales that sometimes show up in his painting.

title: Lost In Translation
description: Ah  I see that my last post was too elliptical, mainly thanks to jet lag; people arent quite getting my point.

title: Bank of England Leaves Rate at 0.5% on Signs of Slowing
description: The British central bank held steady Thursday on its benchmark interest rate amid new warnings that the recovery among major economies appeared to be losing steam faster than anticipated.

title: A Smooth-Talking Texas Two-Timer
description: AMY LIPPMAN can pinpoint the moment in the pilot script for Lone Star,Foxs new drama about a young, charming Texas con man named Bob Allen (James Wolk), when she knew this was a television series worth joining. In a hotel bar, a flirtatious beauty invites Bob up to her room, but he politely informs her that he has a couple of reasons for turning her down. What the audience knows and the woman doesnt is that Bobs living a double life, married to the daughter of an oil baron in Houston and living in small-town Midland with a second sweetheart whom he will soon  spoiler alert  also wed, and that hes deeply in love with both of them.

title: Where Even Robert Redford Has to Work to Sell His New Film
description: TORONTO

title: Aggression on Wheels
description: You may get some bruises with rough-and-tumble roller derby, but youll also find camaraderie and a place to work out your hostilities.

title: Building an Art of Virtuoso Ambiguity
description: The superb five-decade survey of drawings by Gerhard Richter opening at the Drawing Center in SoHo on Saturday is, without even trying to be, an event. Its the first career overview of Mr. Richter in the United States since the much-praised 40 Years of Painting at the Museum of Modern Art in 2002. It presents seldom-exhibited work, most of it abstract, in a medium that would seem a natural adjunct to his painting.

title: The Dark Side of Cushnie et Ochs
description: It was hard to keep your eyes off the shoes on the runway of Cushnie et Ochs, the young label of the designers Carly Cushnie and Michelle Ochs. Were they stigmata shoes? Spikes have been big in footwear for a while, thanks to the glamazon stilettos that Christian Louboutin made for Rodarte, but these, by Alejandro Ingelmo, looked downright terrifying. They had a long, roughly three inches long, spike pointing up from the toe and another coming out of the back of the heel.

title: Video: Uneasy Voters in Ohio
description: Tuscarawas County voted for George W. Bush in 2004 but became one of just five counties in Ohio that Barack Obama flipped four years later. Interviews with residents now suggests the president might not have as much luck if he were on the ballot this year. Administration initiatives simply have yet to be felt on the ground.

title: Giants Get a Visit From Odierno
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Standing amid the Giants in their blue practice jerseys and red-trimmed helmets Thursday was a visitor in a uniform of a different sort. He wore camouflage fatigues.

title: Rock n Rolls Killer Meets Broadways
description: FRESH off a matinee performance of Million Dollar Quartet, Levi Kreis ran a nervous hand through his pompadour as he stood in the living room of a hotel suite high above Times Square on Wednesday. Mr. Kreis, the actor and musician who plays Jerry Lee Lewis in that Broadway musical, seemed unsure of how to comport himself when the suites primary occupant arrived. First he propped himself between two chairs, like a sprinter waiting for a starting pistol. Then, half-reverently and half-jokingly, he got down on one knee, which was the position he was found in when the real-life Mr. Lewis entered the room.

title: Now Showing | The Graceful Dead
description: People dealt with death differently in the 19th century, says Eva Ulz, the curator of Memento Mori: The Birth and Resurrection of Postmortem Photography at the Merchants House Museum. People looked forward to a reunion in heaven. Creating portraits was considered a precursor to that heavenly reunion. They shouldnt be thought of as creepy.

title: Random Transformations
description: An interactive look at the work of Dan Colen, who explores the role of chance in the making of art.

title: Betaworks and The Times Plan Social News Site
description: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

title: Should Bushs Heisman Be Taken Away?
description: Earlier this week, Yahoo Sports reported that Reggie Bush was expected to have his Heisman Trophy taken away by the end of the month. This stems, of course, from the N.C.A.A.s determination that Bush committed multiple violations during his Heisman-winning 2005 season at U.S.C., including accepting cash, gifts and other benefits. Bush would become the first winner to be stripped of his Heisman.

title: Excerpt: 'No Ordinary Family'
description: The new ABC series follows a family that is suddenly endowed with superpowers.

title: Caseys Confirms Talks With 7-Eleven
description: Caseys General Stores on Thursday confirmed that 7-Eleven was the mystery bidder with whom it has been having discussions on a deal as Caseys tries to sidestep an unwanted offer from Alimentation Couche-Tard.

title: Bid Puts Spotlight on Crucial Player in Potash
description: It is hardly a household word like, say, the oil cartel OPEC. That is why Canpotex, an organization with a corner on Canadas potash production, used to go about its business in nearly complete obscurity.

title: Prabal Gurung | First Look Challenge
description: Play high-fashion stylist and put together looks with the images from Prabal Gurungs spring/summer 2011 collection, below. (Be sure to use at least three looks from the new collection.) Two lucky winners will be chosen by the designer and announced on Sept. 14. Each winner will receive a ticket to Prabals next New York show in February 2011 and a tour of his garment-district studio. The winning sets will also be showcased on The Moment, Polyvore and on our Facebook page. Full contest details can be found at http://www.polyvore.com/cgi/contest.rules?id=204817.

title: Aboriginal Teenagers Australian Road Trip
description: Theres nothing I would rather be/Than to be an Aborigine/And watch you take my precious land away, go the words to the politically barbed singalong that rings out in Bran Nue Dae, a deceptively slap-happy Australian pop fable set in the late 1960s.

title: Excerpt: 'Outsourced'
description: The new NBC comedy is about a call center in India.

title: Movements Expanded and Redefined
description: ONE thing about art objects: they never shut up.

title: Excerpt: 'My Generation'
description: The new ABC mock-documentary series revisits a group of high school graduates 10 years later.

title: Globetrotting While Staying Close to Home
description: Last year, for whatever reason  the economy, accidents of scheduling  our encyclopedic museums fell short on global mojo. Across the country ambitious shows of non-Western art were scarce. When this happens, history gets stalled; we get small. In the most culturally interconnected time ever, familiarity with the art of the rest of the world, which means exposure to other ideas and values, just makes practical sense: it keeps us in the cosmopolitan loop, makes us full citizens. When the art isnt there and in clarifying contexts, we drop back on the learning curve when we should be moving ahead.

title: Final: Saints 14, Vikings 9
description: The Fifth Down will be providing live analysis and perhaps some sarcastic asides during tonights N.F.L. season opener between the Minnesota Vikings and the New Orleans Saints.

title: Apple Gives App Developers Its Review Guidelines
description: Apple, which keeps a tight lid on its products and inner workings, is loosening up a little.

title: Optimism Breeds Opportunity
description: FOR those who care about Architecture with a capital A there will be plenty of new buildings to consider in the coming year, many of them showing off an unexpected optimism amid a trying global economy.

title: ARM Mounts Next Offensive Against Intel
description: With its latest product release, the chip designer ARM may find it tough to maintain its tradition of understated British talking points. It would seem that some pomp and circumstance has been put on order.

title: Enshrining an Extraordinary Poet of the Keyboard, Quirks and All
description: The Canadian pianist Glenn Gould, who died at 50 in 1982, has been a figure of fascination since he burst onto the classical music scene, with startling virtuosity and an unusual brand of flamboyance, in the 1950s. His interpretations of the piano repertory  the work of Bach in particular  were fresh and provocative, and his self-presentation was both matinee-idol charismatic and winningly odd. As Goulds celebrity grew, some of his peculiarities became as famous as his playing. He insisted on sitting in a special low-slung chair, so that his long arms seemed to angle upward to the keyboard. He wore scarves, gloves and overcoats in all kinds of weather. He rambled charmingly in interviews and hummed loudly onstage.

title: German Banker Resigns Amid Outcry
description: STUTTGART, Germany  Heading off a potentially embarrassing public fight, Germanys central bank announced Thursday that it had agreed to part ways on amicable terms with Thilo Sarrazin, the author of a recently released book on immigration that caused a storm here by accusing Muslims of refusing to integrate and of dumbing down German society.

title: Dal, Richter and Houdini in Chains!
description: Dates and touring sites are subject to change.

title: Big Plans, Big Spaces in Los Angeles
description: THE two newest buildings on the Los Angeles County Museum of Arts 20-acre campus were designed by Renzo Piano, the Italian architect who has in recent years become one of the go-to guys for museum expansions. The first building, the Broad Contemporary Art Museum, drew a lot of advance coverage in the news media before its unveiling in 2008, in part because of the unrealized hope that its patron, Eli Broad, would give part of his blue-chip collection to the museum to coincide with its opening. But while that building  a major exhibition space for contemporary work  has done a lot to raise the museums profile, the response to its design has been mixed.

title: Copley Rubs Elbows With the Ancient Olmecs
description: THIS fall the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, will open its long-awaited $345 million wing for Art of the Americas. Designed by the English firm Foster & Partners and appended to the museums east end, the four-story structure extends the original 1907 Beaux Arts buildings low profile but dispenses with the neo-Classical columns, capitals, entablatures and whatnot in favor of severe, rectilinear blocks: a central glass atrium  12,184 square feet under a 63-foot ceiling  flanked by granite and glass pavilions containing 53 galleries.

title: Chinese Food, the Wines of Germany, and a Debate
description: BERLIN  As this country continues its uneasy dialogue about integration, spurred on by an anti-immigrant book written by an executive of the central bank, the restaurant owner Jianhua Wu is busy selling wine, promoting wine, eagerly and enthusiastically sampling and sipping wine. Not just any wine, but German wine.

title: Portraits Shed Light Through Gay Prism
description: ALTHOUGH museums are generally thought of as progressive, gay-theme shows are almost unheard of at the countrys biggest art institutions. This fall a particularly unlikely one will break with that tradition: the august National Portrait Gallery, part of the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Germany: 2 Charged With Spying
description: Two Libyan men, identified only as 42-year-old Adel Ab. and 46-year-old Adel Al., have been charged with spying on members of Libyas opposition in Germany, the federal prosecutors office in Karlsruhe said. They have been in custody since their arrest in May. Adel Ab. is suspected of having worked as an officer for the Libyan secret service, overseeing a network of informal collaborators who systematically spied on Libyan opposition members living in Germany and Western Europe. The other man is suspected of spying on exiled opposition members on behalf of Adel Ab., who paid him for the information.

title: Nadal Wins to Reach a Familiar Open Rung
description: The United States Open semifinals have been a New York stop sign for Rafael Nadal until now, a signal he has been too weary or too harried to ignore.

title: Betting on $2 Billion Sale: Will the Market Blanch?
description: The 15-story building that covers an entire block north of the meatpacking district looks more like a brick fortress than a sleek Park Avenue office tower.

title: Tigers Continue to Play Spoiler vs. White Sox
description: Colby Rasmus hit two home runs, Albert Pujols and Skip Schumaker also homered, and Adam Wainwright bounced back from a three-run first inning to lead the St. Louis Cardinals past the Braves, 11-4, in Atlanta on Thursday. Atlanta dropped a game behind idle Philadelphia in the National League East with its sixth loss in eight games.

title: The Month That Squeezes Democracy
description: Thursday was the first day of Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year. Saturday is the anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Neither event is a boon to democracy as it is practiced in New York.

title: Professional Seducer Finally Meets His Match
description: It is up to the wiry, pint-size French heartthrob Romain Duris to carry Pascal Chaumeils Heartbreaker, an overlong mlange of romance and slapstick that looks and sounds more American than French. (That is not a compliment.)

title: A Sneak Peek at the New Season of Glee
description: The making of TVs best seriocomic musical dancefest spectacular.

title: Pentagon Plan: Buying Books to Keep Secrets
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Department officials are negotiating to buy and destroy all 10,000 copies of the first printing of an Afghan war memoir they say contains intelligence secrets, according to two people familiar with the dispute.

title: Turn On, Tune In, Drop By
description: For devotees of Rudolph Schindlers architecture, the 1934 Buck House in Los Angeles is a pure expression of his mature Modernist style. Essentially a whitewashed house of cards built around a central garden, the Buck House features custom-designed components, including shelving, lighting and door hinges. A complex series of clerestory windows punctuates its cantilevered roof, balancing light and mass, exposure and privacy. The Buck House is an urban oasis, where life is meant to be lived in uncluttered serenity. To leave it untidy would be inappropriate. To make a mess would be almost criminal. But this is exactly what the current residents, the artists Justin Lowe and Jonah Freeman, have done.

title: Revealing Little, and Hoping It Will Make Viewers Want More
description: LOS ANGELES

title: The Story Behind a Wikipedia Entry
description: James Bridle founded a Web site called Booktwo in September 2006 to investigate, analyze, catalog and debate the future of literature and the publishing industry. Over the years the site has been home to some interesting debates over literature and its transition from paper to screens.

title: Padres Win and Lose With the Best
description: Not too long ago, the National League West race seemed all but over. On Aug. 25, the Padres won their 76th game, giving them a comfortable six-and-a-half-game lead over the San Francisco Giants. For many fans, it was time to start thinking about postseason pitching rotations. But on Sunday, 11 days later, San Diego was still stuck at 76 wins, having lost 10 consecutive times, and its division lead over the Giants had shrunk to a single game.

title: A West Bank Enclave Is on Edge
description: ARIEL, West Bank  When a group of Israeli artists recently refused to perform in the new theater at this large Jewish settlement, local residents reacted with a mixture of hurt and defiance.

title: Alls I Know . . .
description: Jan Conaway writes: The first time I heard someone say Alls I know is . . . was in the 1980s. As I'm sure you have noticed, this annoying expression has since become more and more prevalent, and I realize there is no hope that it will disappear. Do you know where alls actually originated?

title: Dissidents Claim Iran Is Building a New Enrichment Site
description: WASHINGTON  A dissident group that had previously revealed the existence of several hidden nuclear sites in Iran claimed Thursday that it had evidence that the country was building another secret uranium enrichment plant.

title: France: Calls to End Expulsions
description: The European Parliament urged France and other European states on Thursday immediately to suspend all expulsions of Roma. The resolution was nonbinding but stung French officials. Immigration Minister Eric Besson, left, in Bucharest for talks with Romanian authorities, said it was out of the question for France to suspend the deportations of foreigners who had stayed beyond their visas. The European Parliament has exceeded its prerogatives, and we are certainly not going to comply with a political diktat, Mr. Besson said. France has been asking Romania and Bulgaria to do more to integrate their Roma populations using European aid money. Also in Bucharest, European Minister Pierre Lellouche said that France will call for commitments on police and judiciary cooperation, the fight against human trafficking and integration of Roma in Romania, as part of a national emergency plan spanning 2010-2013.

title: Britain: Phone Hacking Inquiry Approved
description: The House of Commons on Thursday approved a new parliamentary inquiry into the journalistic use of phone hacking, the practice of illegally intercepting cellphone messages, moving the matter to the Standards and Privileges Committee, which is to meet on Tuesday. Lawmakers in Parliament attacked the practices of tabloids in general and, in particular, those of News of the World, the News International-owned tabloid whose use of phone hacking several years ago has touched off a current furor. Tom Watson, a Labour member of Parliament, said lawmakers should stop being scared of the news media. The barons of the media with their red-topped assassins are the biggest beasts of the modern jungle, he said. They have no predators, they are untouchable, they laugh at the law, they sneer at Parliament, they have the power to hurt us and they do so with gusto and precision.

title: This New House
description: With the world quickly using up its fossil fuels and driving itself further toward irreversible climate change, its easy to fall into despair about the future of domestic life. Cheap energy, land, water and building materials have made the last century of American homebuilding a story of ever-expanding luxury. Arguably, all of these will become scarce and expensive over the next 50 years. Will our childrens homes be anything as comfortable and expansive as our own?

title: South Africa: Murder Rate Falls to Lowest Level Since Apartheid
description: Long plagued by violent crime, South Africa saw its murder rate decline by 8.6 percent over the past year to its lowest level since the end of apartheid. The number of murders has fallen to 16,834 in the past year, from 26,877 in 1995-96. Crime statistics released Thursday also showed a 10.4 percent drop in street robberies, and a 6.8 percent decline in carjackings, while home robberies rose 1.9 percent. The murder decline was singled out by police officials. Of all the crimes, this is the one category you cannot easily cheat, Police Minister Nathi Mthethwa said. In other words, the fact that such a crime is counted based on the actual bodies makes it more reliable." He said greater police visibility on the streets and support from communities had helped lower crime rates.

title: Palin Taps an Atlantic Grizzly
description: The Mama Grizzly club has a new member.

title: Its Late Summer, and the Phillies Are on the Move
description: PHILADELPHIA  It is nice to have options, in your wardrobe and your pitching staff. Just ask Ruben Amaro, the general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Alaska Senator Could Announce Revived Candidacy
description: Just a few weeks ago, Joe Miller was casting Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska as part of a broken Republican establishment, an emblem of everything he wanted to fix about Washington. At one point, he even accused the Republican Party organization that backed her, the National Republican Senatorial Committee, of trying to skew the results of the Alaska primary on her behalf.

title: Pettitte Rescues His Reputation With Stability
description: Trenton

title: Tackling the Economy, and the Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: In Chicago, the Legacies of the Two Mayors Daley
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Is Struggle for Kuchar; Playing Isnt
description: LEMONT, Ill.  As befits his newfound stature as the golfer to spend the most time in or around the lead, Matt Kuchar has had plenty to say all year about the consistent run of good form that has lifted him to the top of the PGA Tour money list and the FedEx Cup points list.

title: Paperbacks Are Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Pregnant, but Not What She Expected
description: Hideaway, a French drama with lulling quiets and an undertow of emotional violence, gets off to an unpromising start with two addicts doing what they do best, nodding out and shooting up. The woman in bed, Mousse (Isabelle Carr), is sleeping or passed out, her hair spilling around her head. Her lover, Louis (Melvil Poupaud), is playing the guitar, his dirty fingers finding the notes as a cigarette burns between his lips. But hes barely more animate and he soon fades, this time for good. Done in by a bad fix, he dies less than 11 minutes into Hideaway, upending Mousses life and perhaps our expectations for this story.

title: Somewhere Man
description: Back in 1994, in the afterglow of his first big role  playing the doomed fifth Beatle, Stuart Sutcliffe, in Backbeat  Stephen Dorff did what any self-respecting young actor might do when the checks start coming in. He moved into the Chateau Marmont. I had some money and I didnt have a place to live, Dorff, now 37, explained during a recent stopover in Manhattan. So I said, You know what? Im checking into the Chateau.  He toasted his 21st birthday with a wild party in one of the four bungalows. The premiere bash for Backbeat was held in its famous garden, where 700 guests, including Pia Zadora, Tori Spelling and Keith Richards, jockeyed for chicken skewers and face time with the newly minted star. Life at the Chateau was grand  for a while. It got to the point where my business manager called and said, Stephen, you need to take a movie or get a job, cause youre out of money. And I said, O.K., I guess Im moving out.

title: In Adding Book Section, the Journal Bucks Trend
description: In the last few years, newspapers including The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune and The Boston Globe have ended their freestanding book review sections.

title: Highway Stars
description: Its Saturday, 7:15 a.m., and a thick June fog blankets San Francisco Bay. Mister Mort is wearing a blue bandanna fastened with a beaded Native American bolo clasp, a T-shirt with a solid pattern of tiny American flags and a pair of vintage camouflage pants. This whole outfit is flea market, he assures me, clearing his black hair from his brow as he settles into the back seat of a black 2004 Toyota Tacoma pickup. His buddy Jay has one hand on the steering wheel, the other cupping an iPhone. Beneath a vintage L. L. Bean chamois button-down, he wears a threadbare Black Flag T-shirt. The look is complemented by a ships lanyard bracelet and an anchor tattoo on his ring finger as well as his newest body ink  the words old salt printed beneath his right bicep. I have an unhealthy fascination with maritime themes, he says as he guns the engine for the start of another in a series of weekend style-hunting rambles they refer to as Jay and Mister Morts Truck Bed.

title: Lazios Ties to Banking Industry Haunt His Bid for Governor
description: In 2008, JPMorgan Chase had a problem. A bill that threatened the profits of its lucrative credit card business had the potential to gain momentum in Congress. But the bank had a stable of lobbyists on its payroll ready to plead its case, including a well-connected rainmaker, former Representative Rick A. Lazio.

title: Combat Game Goes Too Far for Military
description: LEAVENWORTH, Kan.  Sgt. First Class Brian Hampton knows it is just a video game. But the details are unnervingly familiar: the uniforms, the weapons, even the military bases and desert towns where the action is set. Each time Sergeant Hampton, a veteran of the war in Afghanistan, plays, his heart rate spikes, his breathing quickens and his muscles tense.

title: Arrests in Bahrain: The Governments View
description: To the Editor:

title: Read the Report
description: Iran has spent the last four years ignoring the United Nations order to stop enriching uranium. And far too many of the worlds major players have spent the last four years ignoring Irans defiance.

title: Man Tied to Missing Art Is Charged With Fraud
description: The case of a portrait by a 19th-century French painter that supposedly disappeared after a night of drinking by the man who had it took another twist on Thursday.

title: A Sooner State Story of Better Family Unity Through Wrestling
description: The schmaltzy sports movie Legendary is a kind of contemporary answer to the old Charles Atlas ad in which a 97-pound weakling develops muscles and triumphantly punches out the bully at the beach. Here, he is Cal Chetley (Devon Graye), a bookish 135-pound Oklahoma high school student taunted by his classmates, who lives with his salty widowed mother, Sharon (Patricia Clarkson).

title: The Effort Is the Prize
description: An earlier post highlighted the evidence that in many arenas, purposeful practice is the key to high performance. In other words, top performers in complex fields like medicine, math and chess become that way through repeated and focused practice that builds their skills until their performance seems almost super-human  rather than being born with highly exceptional skill.

title: U.S. Urges Iraqis to Try New Plan to Share Power
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is encouraging a major new power-sharing arrangement in Iraq that could retain Nuri Kamal al-Maliki as prime minister but in a coalition that would significantly curb his authority.

title: Transcript: Vice President Biden on Progress and Lingering Threats in Iraq
description: Following is a transcript by The New York Times of an interview with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. after his meetings in Baghdad and the change of mission ceremony at Camp Victory on Sept. 1. The questions by Michael R. Gordon are paraphrased. [Read the accompanying story by Michael R. Gordon and Anthony Shadid on the Obama administrations push for a power-sharing arrangement to end the political stalemate in Iraq.]

title: Unrequited Passion on the Cusp of 30
description: Another wedding movie, another 90-plus minutes of half-baked suspense wondering whether the bride- and groom-to-be will go through with the ceremony or back out at the last second. There you have the outline of The Romantics, a formulaic rom-com with an Ivy League pedigree and a higher-than-average SAT verbal score.

title: A Rock Impresario Gambles on Spider-Man
description: Nearly a hundred feet above the stage of Broadways Foxwoods Theater, Michael Cohl wrapped his right hand around one of the cables that will soon fly actors over the audience at the musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark. For a moment Mr. Cohl, the accidental producer of the most expensive show in Broadway history, was on top of the theater world, and appropriately so: he is the money man who after years of delays has sent Spider-Man airborne. Thanks to him, theatergoers will get to see for themselves if it soars, or falls to earth.

title: Fair Courts at Risk
description: The nature of state judicial elections has changed dramatically in recent years, and not for the better.

title: Elite Field Taking Shape for Fifth Avenue Mile
description: The two-time Olympic medalist Bernard Lagat will be joined by his fellow Olympians Leonel Manzano and Nick Willis; the defending champion, Andy Baddeley of England; and the American mile record-holder Alan Webb in the Fifth Avenue Mile on Sept. 26, the New York Road Runners announced. The womens field will include last years champion, Shannon Rowbury; the past champions Sara Hall and Carmen Douma-Hussar; as well as Molly Huddle, the American record-holder at 5,000 meters, and Kalkidan Gezahegn of Ethiopia, the world indoor champion in the 1,500.

title: Secret Tape Has Police Pressing Ticket Quotas
description: For nearly every New Yorker who has received a summons in the city  caught at a checkpoint monitoring seat-belt use, or approached by a small army of police officers descending on illegally parked cars  quotas are a maddening fact of life.

title: On a Brooklyn Street, a Simmering Feud and a Violent Death
description: With a songbirds voice, a tart tongue and, occasionally, an iron fist, Patricia Wilson stood sentry over her patch of Brooklyn for nearly two decades, a town crier who saw everything and never shrank from a fight.

title: Making Prisons Safer
description: Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. has spent nearly 15 months weighing new mandatory rape prevention policies for federal prisons and state correctional institutions that receive federal money. The policies, which are due this fall, need to be as tough as possible.

title: Lennons Fave; Do You Know Him?
description: In 1968, when asked to name his favorite American rock group, John Lennon replied Nilsson, which was of course not a group at all but a Brooklyn-born, Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter named Harry Nilsson. To casual browsers in the pop-culture past, Nilsson, who died in 1994 at 52, is perhaps best known for a song he sang but did not write  Fred Neils Everybodys Talkin, from the film Midnight Cowboy. Those with longer, more detailed memories will also recall a wonderful animated childrens movie called The Point! and a lot of great songs, including one (Youre Breakin My Heart) that married a bouncy tune to a profane kiss-off more than a quarter-century before Cee-Lo came up with more or less the same idea.

title: Court Rejects a Citys Efforts to Restrict Immigrants
description: A federal appeals court on Thursday upheld a lower-court ruling striking down ordinances adopted by the City of Hazleton, Pa., that banned illegal immigrants from renting housing or being employed there.

title: E.P.A. to Study Chemicals Used to Tap Natural Gas
description: The Environmental Protection Agency sent letters to nine drilling companies on Thursday requesting detailed information about the chemicals contained in fluids used to crack open underground rock formations in the hunt for oil and natural gas.

title: The Frozen War in Korea
description: Chosin, a documentary about the two weeks of fighting around the Chosin Reservoir that became the emblem of the brutality and privations of the Korean War, is an inside job. The director, Brian Iglesias, and his co-writer, Anton Sattler, are former Marines, and the film was supported by a web of veterans and Korean War legacy groups. It consists almost entirely of American survivors of the battle  the Chosin few  talking about the surreal horrors they experienced.

title: An Invisible Chief Justice
description: The Pew Research Center asked people this summer to identify the current chief justice of the United States from among four possibilities: John Roberts, Thurgood Marshall, John Paul Stevens and Harry Reid. Only 28 percent correctly picked Chief Justice Roberts. The late Thurgood Marshall came in second, with 8 percent. Fifty-three percent could not make a selection, answering dont know.

title: Gentle Annie Folds Her Hand
description: Of all the ways to socialize in the city, for Annie Ettinger, nothing beats flashing four of a kind at a table of obsessive poker players. She raked in $150 with that hand at one of her countless all-night poker games in roaming illegal dens across the last 70 years.

title: Budget Woes Hit Defense Lawyers for the Indigent
description: OZARK, Mo.  Some public defenders in Missouri say the stressed state budget is interfering with their ability to provide poor defendants with their constitutional right to a lawyer.

title: After 3 Skip Hospital Visit, 3 Others Work as Volunteers
description: When three Mets helped volunteers fill care packages near ground zero for the crew of the U.S.S. New York on Thursday, there were no questions about which teammates were not there.

title: Scott, Star in New York With Jets, Cant Put Ties to Baltimore Aside
description: Jets linebacker Bart Scott will never forget the seven seasons he spent in Baltimore. The Ravens were the first team that believed in him, the only team that offered him a chance at a workout.

title: Ipod Redux
description: David Pogue looks at iPods over the years and reviews this year's iPod Shuffle and iPod Nano.

title: A Violent Homage to Genre Films
description: With its deliberate clumsiness, its seemingly random juxtapositions and a handmade look achieved through slavish attention to film stock, lighting, fashions and furnishings, Frankie Latinas Modus Operandi bears a greater surface resemblance to the 1960s and 70s genre films to which it pays homage than Quentin Tarantino and Robert Rodriguezs Grindhouse did.

title: A Late-Life Relationship
description: Is there an age limit for meeting cute? Apparently not, because Nik Fackler has his lead characters do it in Lovely, Still, and they are played by Ellen Burstyn, now 77, and Martin Landau, 82.

description: PUZZLE NOTES  In honor of this 1995 platinum rap hit and this 2009 Grammy winner, Ive resurrected an earlier Squares cartoon, now in living color.

description: A renegade pastor and his tiny flock set fire to a Koran on a street corner, and made sure to capture it on film. And they were ignored.

title: Retrieving Hostages in Brazil
description: A fly-on-the-wall documentary that plays like Cops, only with fewer drunks, Sequestro (Kidnapping) follows the day-to-day operations of the anti-kidnapping division of the So Paulo Police Department in Brazil.

description: FRANKFURT  Sometime next year, budget-conscious Germans will climb aboard a bus in Frankfurt and make a trip that has been unheard-of for decades.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  After last season, the Giants running backs had scar tissue, both visible and unseen. The teams normally strong rushing attack slowed because of sore knees and ankles. That, in turn, wounded the Giants pride.

title: Alienation in Farm Country
description: At the heart of The Afterlight, a minimalist mood poem to loss and alienation, a tiny songbird flutters in a wooden cage. Its presence, like the looming solar eclipse, warns us of heavy-handed metaphors but not of the intoxicating beauty with which they will be expressed.

description: The United States has stepped up pressure to prevent Europe from charging foreign airlines for greenhouse gas emissions when they take off and land there.

Bishop, a four-term representative in a part of Long Island with deeply conservative pockets, had become perilously identified with his partys liberal wing.

title: The Overscheduled Child
description: In Race to Nowhere, the first-time filmmaker Vicki Abeles tries to condense a Hydra-headed problem  Americas overstressed, overscheduled, overcompetitive school kids  into a single, clear narrative. The bad news is that she doesnt entirely succeed; the good news is that she and her co-director, Jessica Congdon, admirably convey the complexity of the issue with considerably more compassion than prescription.

title: What She Saw: A Lifes Dispatches
description: The career of Ruth Gruber  reporter, photographer, civil servant, memoirist, humanitarian  is remarkable, and not only for a woman of her generation. Not that the indefatigable but mild-mannered Ms. Gruber, now 98, would trumpet its singularity; to her it probably simply makes sense, given the aspirations of her youth. But Ahead of Time, a graceful documentary portrait directed by Bob Richman, illustrates just how extraordinary her life has been.

title: Saints Score, Then Sputter, in an Opening Victory
description: NEW ORLEANS  The evening started with a giant inflatable Lombardi Trophy being wheeled across the field on a Mardi Gras float. Before the Super Bowl banner had even stopped fluttering in the draft, it looked as if the New Orleans Saints, after waiting more than 40 years for their first championship, would make another title their plaything. The Superdome was shaking, Drew Brees was passing and it was as if the repeat button had been pushed on the Saints magical season.

description: Public schools across the nation, many facing budget shortfalls, have been charging students fees to use textbooks or to take required tests or courses.

title: Thomas Guinzburg, Paris Review Co-Founder, Dies at 84
description: Thomas Guinzburg, an editor and publisher who helped create The Paris Review, the enduring lion of American literary magazines, and who later became president of Viking Press, the publishing house founded by his father, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: The Publics Change of Heart
description: Since his election, Barack Obamas approval ratings have slid steadily  as they often do for presidents during their first term  presenting a sharp contrast to the last election season. Just two years ago, most Democrats did all they could to associate themselves with Mr. Obama. During the midterms, however, Republicans are using his name as ammunition against their opponents. If so, what have you heard from adults or older friends or relatives about what those days and weeks were like?

title: QR National Set for $2.8 Billion in Loans Before Listing
description: QR National, Australias largest transport and logistics business, will likely agree to about 3 billion Australian dollars ($2.8 billion) of loans from as many as 10 lenders next week ahead of a planned share listing, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

description: The largest brokerages in the United States say a provision in the regulatory reform legislation passed in July could hurt their lucrative sales of shares in initial public offerings, Reuters reported.

title: Sanofi Stands by Previous Genzyme Offer
description: Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker,poured cold water on reports it had raised its offer for Genzyme, saying it was sticking to its bid of $18.5 billion, or $69 per share, Reuters reported.

title: Shanghai Pharma Plans $1.2 Billion Hong Kong I.P.O.
description: Shanghai Pharmaceuticals, the Chinese partner of Roche Holding, said Wednesday it planned to raise at least 8 billion yuan ($1.2 billion) through a public share offering in Hong Kong to fund acquisitions, Reuters reported.

title: Nomura Expanding Into North America
description: In its bid to become a top global brand, the Japanese investment bank Nomura is steadily expanding into North America, setting up offices in Houston and Toronto this month and employing a team of natural-resource bankers, The Wall Street Journal reports.

title: Trichet Says E.U.s Profligate Members Should Lose Vote
description: Jean-Claude Trichet, president of the European Central Bank,has suggested a punishment for members of the euro zone that contravene the financial laws of the region, a temporary ban from political decision-making in the region, The Financial Times reported.

title: AIA Said to Sign Distribution Deal With I.C.B.C.
description: AIA, an Asian arm of American International Group, has signed a distribution deal with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, affirming its position as Chinas top foreign life assurer as it prepares for its November scheduled initial public offering, The Financial Times reported.

title: Dubai World Finalizes Restructuring
description: Dubai World, the emirates state-run investment arm, said Friday that 99 percent of its creditors had agreed to the terms for restructuring $24.9 billion worth of debt, less than a year after the troubled conglomerate spooked global markets when it stopped paying interest on loans accumulated before the financial crisis.

title: Judge Reinstates eBays 28.4% Craigslist Stake
description: A judge on Thursday reinstated eBays28.4 percent stake in Craigslist, but allowed the classifieds site to keep eBay off its board, Reuters reported.

title: Fashionably Bad Teeth
description: Todays idea: Fashion has fallen for the gap  as in teeth, an article says. In an age of digitally and cosmetically assisted perfection, flawed chompers, not to mention scars and tattoos, denote authenticity.

title: Korean Pension Fund Eyes Woori Finance Stake
description: National Pension Service, South Koreas biggest investor, said it was open to teaming up with Hana Financial Group or joining others to buy a stake in Woori Finance Holdings, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Afghan Protests Against Koran Burning Turn Violent
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A fringe Florida preacher may have suspended his Koran-burning, but word reached Afghanistan too late for 24-year-old Muhammed Daoud. He was shot to death during a protest outside a NATO base in western Afghanistan, according to Afghan officials.

description: In the Securities and Exchange Commissions investigation into the fall of Lehman Brothers, scrutiny has turned to an accounting maneuver that artificially lowered the banks debt levels, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Craft Brews in the Land of Vino
description: Italys flourishing craft brew scene has so seized the capital that its tempting to predict that beer may soon eclipse wine as the Roman drink of choice. In the past 15 years, a smattering of small producers based primarily in the north has grown into a strong crop of more than 250 small microbreweries representing every national region. Names like Birra del Borgo, Birrificio Italiano and Le Baladin have gained international acclaim, and there are plenty of other noteworthy producers to look out for and no shortage of places in Rome where you can find their beers.

title: Tip of the Week: Time Travel in Windows 7
description: The clock in the Windows 7 task bar gives you the time of day when you click on it, but youre not stuck with just one time zone. To add more clocks, go to the Start menu, choose Control Panel and click on Clock, Language and Region. Next, click on Date and Time. (You can also click in the time in the Taskbar to open up the clock and calendar display and then click on Change date and time settings.)

title: Nokia Turns to Microsoft for New Chief Executive

OBrien writes.

title: Oops At The OECD
description: Regular readers may recall that back in May I fulminated about the OECD Economic Outlook. The Paris-based OECD is Conventional Wisdom Central; and in May, it dutifully relayed the conventional wisdom that advanced nations should start cutting spending and, even more remarkably, raising interest rates right away. As I pointed out, this made no sense even in terms of the OECDs own forecasts, which said that unemployment would remain very high and inflation very low for years to come.

title: British Decline

Thats not an attack on David; everyone does it  although I might point out that the reason so many smart kids go into finance, not manufacturing, is that the pay is much better.

title: Now Online | T Mens Fashion Fall 2010
description: Whether you fancy yourself a rugged individual, or simply want to dress like one, this is your season, and our fall mens issue is here to guide the way. It starts with our cover star, Stephen Dorff, who in the course of his career has played a Beatle, a vampire, a transvestite, and in Sofia Coppolas upcoming film, Somewhere, an actor whose career is on cruise control but whose life is about to veer into a ditch. Elsewhere in the issue, Jim Lewis visits the legendary photographer Bruce Davidson, whose Brooklyn Gang series from the 50s still clicks today; Holly Brubach revisits the work of Gay Talese, the man who practically reinvented sports writing; and David Knowles hops in a truck with Mister Mort and Jay Carroll in search of great American style. And speaking of trips, Steve Pulimood drops in on the artists Justin Lowe and Jonah Freeman as they transform an icon of modernist design into a swinging LSD safe house.

title: JPMorgan and UBS Said to Test BlackBerry Rivals
description: JPMorgan Chase may soon let employees use iPhones for corporate e-mail, making it an alternative to Research in Motions BlackBerry for the first time, two people familiar with the situation told Bloomberg News.

title: No Ticket Quotas? A Tape Suggests Otherwise
description: Officially and forever, the position of the New York Police Department has been that there is no such thing as quotas and that any driver who complains of receiving a summons only because officers are forced to write a certain number of tickets per day or week or month is simply trying to shift blame.

title: Coffice
description: Portmanteau term used in South Korea to describe how coffee houses are used for work, study and socialising.(Coff[ee] + [Off]ice.)

title: E.P.A. Meeting Stalled by Security and Cost
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has been on something of a listening tour lately, holding public meetings around the country where stakeholders concerned about hydraulic fracturing can share their thoughts with the agency.

title: Indus River Outsider
description: Some weeks ago I flew from New York to Islamabad, Pakistan, to experience summer in the country where my parents were born and where I lived as a child. I love summer in Pakistan: the mangoes, the monsoon and, this year, Ramadan, the mystical month of the Islamic calendar, all came in August. A week after I landed, the monsoon clouds arrived, but this time the Indus River swelled and burst its banks: my vacation coincided with the largest natural disaster in Pakistans history.

title: East Side of Manhattan, 8:02 A.M.
description: A five-alarm fire swept through the neighboring one-story buildings housing the Frontier diner and Byblos restaurant on East 39th Street at Third Avenue overnight; 12 firefighters and 2 emergency medical workers sustained minor injuries.

title: Living to Be a Parent
description: Remember Maslows Hierarchy of Needs? You learned about it in your intro psych course: a neat and tidy pyramid, with fulfillment of physiological needs at its base, then things like safety, love, belonging and esteem stacked on top, all capped by self-actualization.

title: Is Greed Still Good?
description: On the one hand, you make lefty documentaries, like your recent admiring portrait of the Venezuelan president Hugo Chvez, and on the other you make Hollywood blockbusters like your new Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps. Do you see Wall Street as a vehicle for making money?  Its a vehicle for people who are mathematically inclined and love to make money.

title: For Those Who Fall in Love Too Easily
description: Therefore marriage is not to be entered into unadvisedly or lightly, but reverently, deliberately  Marriage Ceremony from The Episcopal Book of Common Prayer

title: Hearing Things
description: I have seen the future of rock and roll, and its merch. Of course, band-branded merchandise has been a major part of the music business, big and small, for years. The Ramones sold more T-shirts than albums (and you can buy a T-shirt that says so). And box sets for superfans have become increasingly elaborate and pricey artlike objects. But merchandise is gaining momentum, and its not hard to imagine a time when a fan buys a sculpture, home dcor item or other tangible good and gets the music as a kind of free soundtrack accompaniment.

title: Debt Be Proud
description: Big bond offerings from Hewlett-Packard and Home Depot swelled U.S.investment-grade debt issuance to its highest weekly total since May 2008, Thomson Reuters data shows.

title: New Malick Film, The Tree of Life, Will Finally Live on Screen
description: Its the cinematic equivalent of seeing Halleys Comet twice in a lifetime: it looks as if moviegoers will actually be getting a new film from Terrence Malick in a mere six years since his previous release. Fox Searchlight announced that it had acquired The Tree of Life, the latest film by Mr. Malick, an auteur unencumbered by conventional measurements of time and who took a 20-year hiatus between his features Days of Heaven (in 1978) and The Thin Red Line (in 1998).

title: Engineering Terror
description: They say they believe in freedom and share our values. They say a few bad apples shouldnt bring down judgment on their entire kind. Dont be fooled. Though they walk among us with impunity, they are, in the words of Henry Farrell, a political scientist at George Washington University, a group that is notoriously associated with terrorist violence and fundamentalist political beliefs.

title: Sharing Medication
description: I work for a nonprofit organization that sometimes provides limited funds for our clients prescriptions. An impoverished client hoped we could fill his prescription for antiseizure medication. We could not because of a lack of money. I take the same drug, same strength, for a different and more minor condition and usually have extra at months end. I am tempted to anonymously share my drugs  illegal and possibly dangerous, but considering his suffering, is it really wrong? R.I., PONTIAC, MICH.

title: Resources | World Religions
description: Updated: Oct. 2013

title: The Publics First Peek at Lincoln
description: At last, humans, sampling hors doeuvres and sipping prosecco, finally walked in that alien-looking, wedgelike building under the curvy lawn roof at Lincoln Center.

title: The Heat of the Night
description: Im still having those fevers, the voice over the telephone reported casually. Its been a month. Should I be worried? Dr. John Henning Schumann, an internist and a close friend of the caller, was worried. His college friend often asked him medical questions and had mentioned a viral illness a few weeks earlier. If it never went away  that was concerning. Schumann told him to see his doctor immediately.

title: In The Long Run, Some Of Us Are Very, Very Confused
description: Brad DeLong has some fun with Megan McArdle acting as if using present values to compare costs at different dates were some weird leftist idea. But it actually gets funnier: she asserts that

title: Open House: Windblown Ashe and Rooting for Kim or Venus
description: Gerry Marzorati: Morning, Michael. Well, Rafael Nadal made quick work of Fernando Verdasco, who did not play badly. Note to parents: Want your son to grow up to be someone who can play tennis in a wind tunnel? LOTS of soccer. Its the FOOTWORK, stupid. Rafa, for instance, stormed the net last night with little, little steps  and not only got there but made tiny, last-second, microclimatic adjustments. And unlike, say, Stanislaw Wawrinka or Mikhail Youzhny, he did not dump his resulting volleys into the net.

title: Letters: Women Who Hit Very Hard
description: Dewey Nickss photo essay is both beautiful and a very concise demonstration of why Serena Williams is the best womens tennis player in the world. Stosur and Jankovic look balletic, Clijsters looks serious, Dementieva and Zvonareva look glamorous. But Williams looks as if she has exactly one thing in mind: to use that tennis racket to sweep everyone out of her way.

title: An Interview with Darin Strauss
description: Darin Strauss discusses his new memoir "Half a Life."

title: Letters: You Are What You Speak
description: Guy Deutscher continues a tradition of blaming Benjamin Whorf for the strong linguistic determinism hypothesis (language constrains thought). But Whorf never made that claim. He argued for the weak version  that language influences thought. After several paragraphs attacking a straw-man Whorf, Deutscher also writes about the weak version, which is plenty interesting in itself.

title: Complaint Box | Summer Deep-Freeze
description: My wife and I just spent 10 days on holiday in New York City. It was our first visit to New York  actually, our first visit to the United States. We had a wonderful time. There is only one issue I would like to comment on: air-conditioning.

title: Letters: Can Preschoolers Be Depressed?
description: Despite her admirable developmental perspective, Pamela Paul fails to consider the effect of a sociocultural context that utterly ignores the developmental needs of 3- to 5-year-olds. When small children are expected to sit still, follow a schedule, even learn the alphabet  when curiosity, movement and nonconformity earn a frowny face  why are we surprised that so many feel sad, guilty and unworthy? No other culture treats children this age as we do. No wonder so many American kids are unhappy.

title: Letter: Taking Stock
description: Roger Lowenstein does a terrible disservice to investors by comparing the paltry 2.58 percent real yield on bonds with the 8.5 percent earnings yield on stocks. This is like comparing apples to oranges and implies that stocks are cheap and can achieve far better returns than bonds.

title: App Smart Extra: Great Art for the iPad
description: Apps can greatly enrich the museum experience, as this weeks App Smart column points out. But what if youre in the mood to browse some art from the friendly confines of your living room?

title: Letter: The Right Stuff
description: As a fact-checker from the mid-70s, I loved reading Heffernans Aug. 22 column. The phone was my best friend for checking everything from a managers name and title to a quotation from Jimmy Carters mom. And it was amazing how much writers would depend on the fact-checking process to clean up their lazy reporting. Now whatever I read on the Internet, I question. One ofmy best sources along with the very good fact-checking sites is Snopes.com. Its a godsend for those pesky viral opinion e-mails that everyone takes for fact.

title: Friday Reading: Evidence of Ticket Quotas
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE WARMTH OF OTHER SUNS: The Epic Story of Americas Great Migration,  by Isabel Wilkerson (Random House, $30.) This masterly account of the exodus of blacks from the South between 1915 and 1970 explores parallels with earlier European immigration.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE GROUND TRUTH: The Untold Story of America Under Attack on 9/11,  by John Farmer (Riverhead, $16.) Whether through unprecedented administrative incompetence or orchestrated mendacity, the American people were misled about the nations response to the 9/11 attacks, writes Farmer, who was senior counsel to the 9/11 commission. His study of newly available transcripts from federal agencies refutes later claims by Dick Cheney and Paul Wolfowitz that the military was ready to shoot down United Airlines Flight 93 before it could hit Washington; in fact, the plane had already crashed by the time the Northeast Air Defense Sector learned of its hijacking. No one told us anything, one military pilot recalled.

title: Netflixs Missed Connection
description: Last Friday, Netflix shut down the social network features on its site. Surprising? Not really. Be honest: when was the last time you or anyone you knew ever referred to the community features on Netflix?

title: Bell Canada to Retake Control of Canadian TV Network
description: QUEBEC  Despite an unhappy experience in the media business, Bell Canada, the telecommunications company, said Friday that it would retake control of CTV, the countrys largest private television broadcaster.

title: Peter Som: Over the Rainbow
description: Peter Soms prints have the intensity of Murano glass, which is pretty intense for a 9 a.m. fashion show. Purple, orange, silver  and thats just in one jacket, ladies.

title: The Early Word: White House News Conference
description: President Obama is scheduled to hold a news conference this morning at the White House where he is expected to announce that Austan D. Goolsbee will succeed Christina D. Romer as head of the White House Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Obamas Missed Opportunity: Answers From Matt Bai, Part II
description: 4:33 p.m. | Updated In his Political Times column on Wednesday, Matt Bai asserted that President Obama had missed an opportunity to rally the public behind his long-term initiative to restructure the economy. He is answering readers questions about the presidents approach and other top political issues this week. The first set of replies came yesterday.

title: Archbishop Bans Pop Music at Funerals
description: On Thursday in Australia, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Melbourne announced a ban on the playing of pop music at funerals, which, he said, are not to be described as a celebration of the life of the deceased.

title: Live-Blogging Obamas News Conference
description: President Obama held his first full-scale White House news conference in three months and the first of the fall campaign season. He announced his promotion of the White House economist, Austan D. Goolsbee, to succeed Christina Romer as chairman of the presidents Council of Economic Advisers, and also addressed other issues of the day, including the Middle East peace talks and the debate over extending the Bush tax cuts.

title: A Belated Debate on Modified Beets
description: While genetically modified crops have been the focus of pitched battles in Europe for nearly a decade, they have slipped into Americas fields and onto its tables with hardly a peep. Although the technology was only developed in the 1980s, more than three-quarters of the nations corn, soy and sugar beets are now genetically altered. The figure is close to zero in many European countries.

description: Iman, the legendary model turned multihyphenate, kicks off the Morning T series of video interviews with Ts online director, Horacio Silva.

title: Nikon Adds Three Coolpix Shooters
description: Nikon has announced three new Coolpix point-and-shoot cameras: the P7000 for demanding photographers, a midrange S8100 with a 10X zoom, and a slick touch-screen S80.

title: What Does Nokias New Chief Mean for M.&A.?
description: Nokias announcement Friday that it had chosen a senior Microsoft manager to become its next chief executive has provided fodder for debate in deal land, with analysts speculating on where Stephen Elop could take the cellphone maker that would rival Google and Apple in the smartphone sector, and whether a tie-up between Microsoft and Nokia would be possible.

title: British Artists Protest a Possible Cut in Government Funds
description: The Tate Modern museum, the planned site earlier this week for a launch party for Tony Blairs memoir that was canceled in fear of protests, became the site of a different demonstration on Friday when artists gathered in front of the museum to rally against possible government cuts to arts spending, The Associated Press reported.

title: Bell Canada Retakes Control of TV Network
description: In an unanticipated reversal, Bell Canada, the telecommunications company, said Friday that it would retake control of CTV, the countrys largest private television broadcaster, The New York Timess Ian Austen reported.

title: Parenting, and the Meaning of Life
description: So begins my latest essay in The New York Times Magazine this weekend. Its a look at the most interesting of questions  what is our purpose here? And also at the more practical ramifications of the varied answers to that question. Is it our biological goal to become the best version of ourselves that we can be? Or is it to raise children to be the best that they can be? Or perhaps these are one and the same?

title: White House Spurns Solar Panel
description: Bill McKibben, an environmental campaigner from Vermont with a flair for showmanship, was rebuffed Friday morning in his effort to get the White House to reinstall one of the solar panels that President Jimmy Carter had placed on the White House roof.
