description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: White House Puts Off Solar Enthusiasts
description: The Put Solar On It team of activists and Unity College students reached the White House today (actually the Old Executive Office Building) and was politely rebuffed after stating their case for putting solar panels back on the White House roof.

title: Ravens Stress Getting Ball Into End Zone, Not Just Keeping It Out
description: Westminster, Md.

title: Guilty Plea in Fraud by Adviser to Stars
description: Kenneth I. Starr, the New York investment adviser who once counted Hollywood celebrities like Al Pacino, Martin Scorsese and Sylvester Stallone as clients, pleaded guilty on Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to charges that he diverted tens of millions of dollars of his clients money to pay for his lavish lifestyle.

title: Lincoln Restaurants First Course
description: Thursday night, to celebrate the debut of New York Fashion Week and the 50th anniversary of the nations largest arts center, actual food was served  and actually consumed  for the first time at Lincoln, the $20 million, 150-seat new high-end restaurant housed in an alien-looking, wedgelike building at Lincoln Center. Our colleague Glenn Collins was there and has the story in Diners Journal.

title: The Smile of an Arkansas Quarterback Makes His Transfer Look Easy
description: College football is littered with quarterbacks who transfer and find their new destination just as unfulfilling. Changing universities could have been a cheerless path, too, for Arkansas quarterback Ryan Mallett, but he had something to go along with his immense skill: his smile.

title: Week 2 College Football Matchups
description: In any other sport its ridiculous to claim that anything that happens in the second week of the season can win or lose a championship. But college football is not like any other sport, and the second week of the season features some of the biggest games of the year. Ohio State puts its national championship hopes (and Terrelle Pryors Heisman hopes) on the line as a tough and hungry Miami team comes to the Horseshoe in a rematch of the 2003 national championship. Last years national champion Crimson Tide hosts Penn State in a matchup that may be a little more lopsided, but features two of the nations most recognizable programs. Speaking of recognizable programs, how about Florida State traveling to Norman to take on Oklahoma? Oh, and theres also Notre Dame hosting Michigan. Then like a cherry on top, we get an intriguing SEC East tilt between Georgia and South Carolina.

title: Weekend Competition: Define Education
description: This weekend, to mark the new academic year, Schotts Vocab is soliciting definitions of education:

title: Getting a Guide for the Jungle of Individual Health Policies
description: THE new health law will be a boon to self-employed individuals, who typically pay more for insurance than those covered by group plans. But they will have to wait: the much-anticipated health insurance exchanges, which will provide an easy way for consumers to compare plans and offer federal subsidies to those who qualify, arent scheduled to go live until 2014.

title: BP Hirings at Barclays: Building Up an Energy Team
description: Barclays Capital has hired seven sales executives from BP, in a move meant to bolster its energy trading business in North America, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

title: Reaction to Judges Ruling on Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: A federal judge in California ruled Thursday that the dont ask, dont tell policy toward gay members of the military is unconstitutional. As John Schwartz reports, Judge Virginia A. Phillips of Federal District Court struck down the rule in an opinion issued late in the day. The policy was signed into law in 1993 as a compromise that would allow gay and lesbian soldiers to serve in the military.

title: Zvonareva Knocks Off Wozniacki to Reach Final
description: Russias 26-year-old veteran, Vera Zvonareva, shook off four broken strings to surge to a victory over top-seeded Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark, 6-4, 6-3, on Friday to enter the womens singles finals at the United States Open, her second successive final in the worlds four most important championships.

title: Using a Broker to Buy Health Insurance
description: Consumers who are shopping for their own health insurance have the option of hiring a broker  someone who will, free of charge, help you price and compare various plans, as explained in todays Patient Money column.

title: Starr Pleads Guilty to Fraud Charges
description: 1:43 p.m. | Updated The New York Times has more on Mr. Starrs guilty plea.

title: Wary Coronation
description: A SWEATY June night in Tennessee was one more milestone for Kings of Leon: headlining a major American rock festival in their home state. On June 10 they topped the bill at the Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival in Manchester, about 54 miles from where the band members grew up, in Franklin. Kings of Leons band members are the three sons of a preacher named Leon Followill  Caleb, Nathan and Jared Followill  and their cousin Matthew Followill; they are now based in Nashville.

title: TimesCast | September 10, 2010
description: Scott Shane on a new report that warns of homegrown terrorist threats, reaction from Kabul to a Florida pastor's wavering plans to burn the Koran and an Arts and Leisure fall preview.

title: Casting a Spell of Rattle and Ether
description: THE jury is still way out on Salem. A young threesome from Michigan  Jack Donoghue, John Holland and Heather Marlatt  the band makes an alluring sound: the synthetic rhythm-rattle of Southern hip-hop crossed with the amniotic floatiness of 1980s electronic pop.

title: Roger Ebert Gives Thumbs Up to New At the Movies Series
description: The balcony is reopened: less than a month after the final episode of At the Movies, the long-running cinema criticism show, was broadcast, Roger Ebert said he would bring back a version of the series that will be shown on public television next year.

title: Dispatches From the Edge of the Sonic Frontier
description: THE history of Western classical music is rife with forgotten side roads, populated by composers and styles overlooked, marginalized or otherwise neglected. The Propensity of Sound, a five-concert series that the Issue Project Room in Gowanus, Brooklyn, will mount in late September, follows one such unfamiliar path. Presented in collaboration with the British experimental-music magazine The Wire, the series will focus on three groundbreaking composers: Pauline Oliveros, Eliane Radigue and Laurie Spiegel.

title: A Lawsuits Miscues, and Public Defenders Misgivings
description: One of the more interesting revelations stemming from the arrest Thursday of Thomas A. Doyle on charges of fraud related to a 19th-century portrait was the existence of numerous inaccuracies in a lawsuit filed a week earlier related to the same painting.

title: Video of Fire in San Francisco Suburb
description: As my colleagues Anahad OConnor and Liz Robbins report, a fire killed four people and destroyed dozens of homes after an explosion fueled by a ruptured gas line tore through a San Francisco suburb Thursday night.

title: Ristretto | Coffee Cart
description: On Tuesday, Eleven Madison Park reopened after a week of minor renovations and a substantial overhaul of its approach to fine dining. The restaurant also rethought coffee. It now has a dedicated barista working a La Marzocco in the back, as well as tableside coffee service: if you so desire, your meal will end with the spectacle of coffee prepared on a siphon or Chemex set up on a cart wheeled across the restaurants terrazzo floor.

title: Two Tributes For Mahler
description: IT is somehow fitting that Mahler, with his proclivity for excess, should have two commemorative years in a row: the 150th anniversary of his birth in 2010 and the 100th of his death in 2011. Not that he needs them.

title: Visions of India, Plum Fairies And a War
description: NO matter how much dance you see, and no matter how much you travel to see dance, there is always great dancing of which youve seen all too little. At two performances by the Indian dancer Madhavi Mudgal, an exemplar of the Odissi idiom, she struck me as an artist of a classical purity to be ranked with the most refined and luminous Western dancers, Mikhail Baryshnikov and Kyra Nichols. Ms. Mudgals lyricism was reminiscent of Margot Fonteyns; the connection of eyes, head and arms conjured up vast and eloquent arcs, in subtly eloquent interplay with the rhythm of her lower body.

title: On Roofs and Walls, Theyre Honoring Trisha Browns Work
description: TRISHA BROWN cant be boxed in. Since the 1960s and 70s her daredevil, articulate vision of dance has come to life on walls, rooftops, rafts, tree trunks and ceilings. She has accumulated movement  the art of building one action on another to create a sensual chain of motion  conquered opera and choreographed works so magnificent that even she has admitted to having love affairs with them. (Glacial Decoy and Set and Reset lead the pack.) She is one of the most important American artists, not just of her time but also beyond.

title: How to Get Your Children to School
description: School is back in session. And depending where you live, youve had days or weeks to get back in the routine. Which means you are probably still foundering around every morning trying to get out the door, right?

title: Isnt It Early For City Ballet? Not This Year
description: IN New York the cultural new year begins in September with a sudden feast of dance (and every other art form) after the summer famine. But since the New York City Ballet took up residence at Lincoln Center in 1964, its fans  and who isnt one?  have had to tough it out until late November, the beginning of the companys winter season. And even then there was an avalanche of Nutcrackers to get through before the gloriously dense repertory programs, with Balanchine and Robbins favorites and eagerly awaited new works and debuts, began in early January.

title: Well-Traveled Baton On Mets Guest List
description: WHEN Fabio Luisi conducted Strausss Elektra at the Metropolitan Opera in December, he illuminated startling subtleties in his exciting interpretation of the score. Performances of Bergs Lulu and Humperdincks Hansel and Gretel during the Met season also revealed his talent for taut, nuanced music making in varied repertory.

description: Jim ONeill, the Goldman Sachs economist best known for coining the BRIC acronym, has been named chairman of the firms asset management business.

description: Take an audio-guided tour, via an interactive map, of the Colosseum, the Forum and the Jewish Ghetto.

title: A Wee Taste of Europe: Will Americans Bite?
description: THERE are two types of small cars in America. First, there are the bare-bones, price-is-the-entire-object ennui-boxes. These are the cars you end up driving when you stubbornly resist the $2-a-day upgrade at the rental counter.

title: A Conductors Herculean Schedule
description: TWO of the most anticipated events of the new season are coming right up, and they both involve James Levine.

title: Tribute in Light Will Keep Shining, This Year and the Next
description: Most New Yorkers may not know exactly where they come from or who turns them on and off. But almost everyone in the New York region who has gazed into the night sky on Sept. 11 in recent years has come to expect to find twin beams of bluish-white light reaching from Lower Manhattan heavenward.

title: The 3,000-Mile Oil Change Is Pretty Much History
description: I STILL remember learning from my father how to carefully remove a dipstick to check the oil level in our cars. It was drilled into me  along with turning off the lights when you left a room and clearing the plates off the table after dinner  that oil needs to be changed every 3,000 miles or so.

description: Farmers markets are overflowing with vegetables, making it the perfect time to heat up the wok and stir fry, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

description: We canvassed the latest in medical literature and consumer magazines so you dont have to.

title: Hip-Hops New Medium for Choice Words
description: It was early last Saturday morning, or perhaps very, very late the previous night, when the stream of emotional posts began appearing on Kanye Wests Twitter feed: The media tried to demonize me, I felt the recession from the ownership side, Im ready to get out of my own way, Im sorry Taylor.

title: Pentagon Loosens Restrictions for Press in Guantnamo
description: The Pentagon has agreed to revise some of the rules that have restricted what journalists are free to report on from Guantnamo Bay,resolving a conflict that peaked in May when four reporters were expelled from the naval base there.

title: The Bakers Apprentice: Peach or Apple Pie
description: Emily Weinstein is learning to bake with the food writer and cookbook author Dorie Greenspan. This week, Sarabeth Levine, of Sarabeths Kitchen, steps in as a special guest instructor, per Dories suggestion. She is an expert in all things pie. Dorie will return next week.

title: Answering the Sirens Call in a 71 Plymouth
description: GLENN SOKOLOFSKY, perhaps the closest thing New York City has to a curator of police car history, recently recounted an interesting story about the New York Police Departments early patrol cars.

title: Chinese Bond Purchases
description: Regular readers may remember that Ive spent more than a year trying to knock down the idea that the United States dare not get tough with China, because we need them to keep buying our bonds; as I wrote way back in May 2009, given the fact that were in a liquidity trap, a decision by China to buy fewer of our bonds would actually be doing us a favor  it would weaken the dollar, and help our exports.

title: Celebrity Finance Adviser Pleads Guilty
description: Kenneth I. Starr, the onetime investment adviser to the likes of Al Pacino and Sylvester Stallone, has pleaded guilty in federal court in Manhattan to charges that he diverted tens of millions of dollars of his clients money to pay for his own lavish lifestyle. Read more in the Business section.

title: Concerns About Dengue Fever Rise in India
description: NEW DELHI  Indian health officials have struggled to allay domestic concerns about dengue fever even as the country scrambles to finish construction projects in time for the Commonwealth Games, which will take place here in less than a month.

title: The Anatomy of a Breakup
description: BEFORE we met, my partner had changed names from a female-sounding one to a male one, and by the time we were together, everyone we knew either called him by this new name or spoke of him with male pronouns. He identified himself as a transgender man, woman to man. It wasnt until two years after we began dating that he decided to have his breasts removed.

title: Beckham Returns, Without the Pomp
description: CARSON, Calif.  As Landon Donovan was leaving a small group of reporters at the edge of the practice field Thursday, exiting stage left, he caught a glimpse of David Beckham, who had emerged after working out in the gym, ready to take his place.

title: Courtside: The Hawk-Eye Effect at the Open
description: The whistles and catcalls that in the past accompanied questionable line calls at major tennis events have now been largely replaced by a new sound: an almost involuntary and collective Waaaaoooooh.Call it the Hawk-Eye sound effect. Once criticized as a technological wet blanket that would slow down the game, the Hawk-Eye system, with its 10 cameras and ability to virtually replay any challenged shot, is now a new source of entertainment. As the animated ball retraces the shot trajectory, all eyes transfix on the screen to see if it was in or out, and by how much. The closer the ball is to the line, the louder the audience expresses its amazement.Its important to show the fans and the players quite how close it is, said Luke Aggas, tennis operations manager for Hawk-Eye Innovations.

title: New Malick Film Set For Next Year
description: Its the cinematic equivalent of seeing Halleys Comet twice in a lifetime: it looks as if moviegoers will actually be getting a new film from Terrence Malick, below, in a mere six years since his previous release. Fox Searchlight announced that it had acquired The Tree of Life, the latest film by Mr. Malick, an auteur unencumbered by conventional measurements of time and who took a 20-year hiatus between his features Days of Heaven (in 1978) and The Thin Red Line (in 1998). Fox Searchlight described The Tree of Life as a chronicle of a Midwestern family in the 1950s and a son (who is played as an adult by Sean Penn) who is trying to resolve his relationship with his father (Brad Pitt). Though the movie has been rumored as a possible entrant in several 2010 film festivals and even a late-breaking qualifier this year for the Academy Awards, Fox Searchlight said it would release The Tree of Life in 2011. It will be Mr. Malicks first feature since his (relatively recent) film about Capt. John Smith and Pocahontas, The New World, in 2005.

title: Carreo To Retire
description: Jos Manuel Carreo, above, the veteran American Ballet Theater dancer, has announced that he is retiring in August 2011. A special farewell evening for Mr. Carreo, who joined the company as a principal in 1995, will take place on June 30 at the Metropolitan Opera House and will feature a performance of Swan Lake with Mr. Carreo in the role of Prince Siegfried, dancing opposite Julie Kent as Odette and Gillian Murphy as Odile. Mr. Carreo, who was born in Cuba, joined the English National Ballet in 1990 and the Royal Ballet in 1993. With American Ballet Theater, he has danced many roles, including the title character in Apollo, Albrecht in Giselle, Des Grieux in Manon and Solor in La Bayadre. After his retirement from American Ballet Theater he plans to continue performing as a guest artist.

title: Ebert Gives Thumbs Up To New at the Movies
description: The balcony has reopened. Less than a month after the final episode of At the Movies, the long-running film criticism show, was broadcast, Roger Ebert, right, said he would bring back a version of the series that will be shown on public television next year. In an announcement on his blog at the Web site of The Chicago Sun-Times, Mr. Ebert said the new series, called Roger Ebert Presents At the Movies, would start in January and will have as its hosts Christy Lemire, film critic of The Associated Press, and Elvis Mitchell of NPR and a former film critic for The New York Times. In a statement, Mr. Ebert said the revival of the series was the rebirth of a dream. Mr. Ebert, who lost his lower jaw to throat cancer, said he would appear in segments on the new At the Movies, using a computerized voice but would not debate his co-hosts.

title: Look Out for the Diaoyu Islands
description: Tensions have erupted over some barren rocks in the Pacific that you may never have heard of, but stay tuned  this is a boundary dispute that could get ugly and some day have far-reaching consequences for China, Japan, Taiwan and the United States.

title: British Artists Protest Possible Cut In Funds
description: Artists gathered in front of the Tate Modern museum in London on Friday, to rally against possible government cuts to arts spending, The Associated Press reported. Britains coalition government has proposed a budget that could cut arts spending by as much as 25 percent, as it seeks to reduce a substantial budget deficit. A petition circulated by a British organization called Save the Arts and which has been signed by prominent British artists like Damien Hirst, Anish Kapoor and David Hockney, counters that radical cuts to current levels of arts funding will decimate what has been one of the U.K.s chief success stories over the past 20 years, and will bring an end to the U.K.s reign as a global capital for culture. A final decision on the cuts is expected next month.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: The observance of Id al-Fitr in the Middle East, Africa and Asia opens Fridays report. Reuters documented the Subdued Id in Pakistan in a video and in photography by Morteza Nikoubazi (Slide 4). And look what Muhammed Muheisen of The Associated Press does with light  again (Slide 2).

title: Phillips Collection Seeks Donations via Texting
description: Small donations via text message raised millions of dollars for Haitian earthquake victims. Are museums next? The Phillips Collection in Washington on Thursday announced a campaign to solicit $5 and $10 donations via text message to raise money for repairs to its building, above, after a fire on Sept. 2. No artwork was damaged, but the museums offices were harmed. Ann Greer, the director of communications and marketing, said the museum was already planning a give-by-cell campaign and had developed the mechanism for it before the fire broke out. At that point, she said, we had people who were asking how they could help, and this seemed to us to be an easy way that they could do it, also at giving levels that people could afford. A $5 or $10 donation can be made by texting phillips5 or phillips10 to 20222 and then following the prompts.

title: Flea Theater Invests In a Permanent Home
description: Executives of Off Off Broadways Flea Theater said they had purchased a building downtown to create a new home, concluding that buying instead of renting was necessary for its survival. The Flea, a well-regarded TriBeCa theater known for the 9/11 play The Guys and productions of A. R. Gurney works, bought a two-story office building at 20 Thomas Street last December for $5.3 million, according to the artistic director, Jim Simpson. Crains New York Business first reported the sale. Mr. Simpson and the Fleas producing director, Carol Ostrow, said in an interview that they were now in the quiet phase of a capital campaign to raise money to create at least two theaters within the 5,600-square-foot building. They said they planned to announce the fund-raising goals of the campaign next year  they declined to disclose the numbers  and added that they did not herald the purchase of the new building because they had wanted to announce the new home in tandem with the capital campaign. . They said for the foreseeable future the Flea would continue to produce shows in its current White Street space.

title: N.F.L.S. Opening Game Scores For NBC
description: The official kickoff of the National Football League season on Thursday night scored an impressive start in the ratings for NBC. Although final figures were not immediately available on Friday, preliminary estimates for the game between the New Orleans Saints and Minnesota Vikings were the highest in 13 years for any regular-season professional football game in prime time, and overnight ratings were up by nearly 30 percent from last years season opener, which drew 20.9 million viewers. CBS was second on the night with a new installment of Big Brother (7.7 million). ABC was third and Fox was fourth.

title: Soothing and Easy, Turning Intricate
description: From a distance the music of Rosetta Trio can seem demure and untroubled. Its palette consists of acoustic bass and two guitars, one acoustic and one electric: a companionable setup, made even more so by the temperament of the players. There isnt much call for showboating in the groups material, though theres usually room for improvisation. Listen casually, a bit distractedly, and you might mistake it all for soothing pleasantry.

title: An Intimate Setting for Appealing Sounds
description: As occasional chamber-music series in Manhattan go, the Movado Hour at the Baryshnikov Arts Center is a hard one to beat. True, its offerings are limited to a handful scattered throughout the season. But for five years now, Pedja Muzijevic, the music director for the center and a versatile pianist of broad, eclectic tastes, has presented some of the worlds finest singers, instrumentalists and ensembles in this series of casual, free concerts.

title: Progress in Twilight
description: A twilight view of the World Trade Center site taken Thursday evening shows 1 World Trade Center (with two cranes at top), now one-third of the way up to its 1,368-foot height, and the diaphanous 7 World Trade Center, to the immediate right, which was finished in 2006. In the right foreground is an area between the No. 1 subway line and Church Street, where two more skyscrapers and the PATH station will go.

title: Creamed Corn Thats Much Too Good to Share
description: THERE are a thousand and one ways to prepare summer corn, but all I did this year was cream it.

title: Court Denies Class-Action Status in Lilly Drug Case
description: Eli Lilly & Company won reversal of a ruling that had granted class-action status to a suit by pension funds, unions and insurers that claimed improper marketing of Zyprexa, its schizophrenia treatment, raised their costs.

title: Wilpon Leaves Hospital Flap to the Players
description: Days after three Mets skipped a team trip to visit wounded war veterans at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, Jeff Wilpon, the teams chief operating officer, declined to rebuke the players, saying that any discontent that stemmed from their absence should be worked out in the clubhouse.

title: Couche-Tard May Raise Offer for Caseys
description: Alimentation Couche-Tard, the Canadian convenience store operator, said late Friday that it would consider raising its unsolicited offer for Caseys General Stores once again and it asked Caseys to postpone its annual meeting on Sept. 23 for two to three weeks in order to complete a full and fair sales process.

description: Every dance needs a room of its own, and the choreographer Anna Sperber has a great advantage in this regard: Naomi, her newest piece, sits in the Brooklyn sky like an urban treehouse.

title: Pervasive Abuse Found in Belgian Church
description: BRUSSELS  Sexual abuse of children reached all parts of Belgiums Roman Catholic Church, and it drove at least 13 victims to kill themselves, a report released Friday said.

title: Biker Fox
description: Jeremy Lambertons sometimes amusing documentary Biker Fox is many things: a portrait of an idealist preaching a gospel of bicycling, loving nature and helping ones fellow man; a study of anger management, or the lack thereof; an examination of someone unaware of his own acute loneliness.

title: The Global Sports Forum With Christopher Clarey: U.S. Open Edition
description: Christopher Clarey, International Herald Tribune/The New York TimesWith Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal still in the mix, this should be a remarkable final weekend at the US Open. To mark the occasion, Ive brought together some of the worlds leading tennis writers for a special edition of the forum. We have Philippe Bouin, who has covered more than 100 Grand Slam events for LEquipe in France. We have Neil Harman, a leading voice of the sport in Britain for The Times of London. We have Juan Jose Mateo, who has chronicled Nadals rise and reign for El Pais in Spain. Well focus on Rafa and Roger and the business end of the mens tournament, beginning with Saturdays semifinals between Nadal and Mikhail Youzhny and between Federer and Novak Djokovic. Lets start with the man whose country actually has a player left in the mens tournament.

title: On With the Bickering in a Fairy Tale
description: Its easy to take pleasure in the dancing and music that occur in Art/Family/Our Lives, subtitled I Ka Nye (You Look Well). Nora Chipaumire and Souleymane Badolo are both remarkable dancers, with stylistic differences that make for more than one lively dance dialogue onstage. Their musical colleague Obo Addy

title: Former President Clintons Busy Dance Card
description: Trying to capture some momentum in Ohios Senate race, Lt. Gov. Lee Fisher, the Democratic candidate, has called in reinforcements this weekend  former President Clinton, who has proven to be a popular presence for Democrats on the campaign trail this year.

title: Weekly Pick Em: Second-Week Bonanza
description: While the opening week of college football brought with it all the requisite excitement of another season beginning, this weekend unquestionably features a better group of games. Most of the action comes out of the conference, notwithstanding an intriguing SEC matchup. Penn State and Alabama renew a rivalry, one that has conjured up memories of Joe Paterno coaching against Bear Bryant. Two first-year coaches (Florida States Jimbo Fisher and Notre Dames Brian Kelly) face big challenges, with the Seminoles traveling to Oklahoma and the Irish hosting a Michigan team that looked extremely dangerous in beating Connecticut in the season opener. But the marquee game on Saturday looks to be Miami at Ohio State. The Buckeyes Terrelle Pryor and the Hurricanes Jacory Harris are two of the most exciting quarterbacks in the country. Expect the winner of this game to vault right to the top of the Heisman discussion. But, enough talk. Lets get on with the picks.

title: Resident Evil: Afterlife 3D
description: Eight years, three movies and now a third dimension have added little to the video-game-derived saga of Alice (Milla Jovovich), scourge of zombies and lust object of teenage boys. In Resident Evil: Afterlife 3D, our well-armed heroine is now on her fourth attempt to best the dastardly Umbrella Corporation and rescue remnants of spandex-clad humanity from the slobbering victims of the deadly T-Virus.

title: Sept. 10, 2001
description: Lucas Roman was not photographing for the ages. He was simply making a keepsake of his arrival in New York, where he was beginning a new life in film production. There was only one better spot from which to capture the citys sweep than the observatory of the Empire State Building, where he stood on the night of Monday, Sept. 10, 2001. And that was from Windows on the World, atop the World Trade Center, where he was headed the next morning.

title: Not-So-Great Moments in Diplomacy, Drunken Toast Edition
description: When Sha Zukang, the most senior Chinese official at the United Nations, rose to make a toast to Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon last week, his colleagues were no doubt aware of the fact that he has a history of making undiplomatic remarks.

title: ContemporAsian
description: Four divergent perspectives, encompassing the literary and almost mystical, are on view in the Museum of Modern Arts ContemporAsian series, presenting shorts from Thailand, Malaysia, South Korea and China through Thursday. While its spotlighted auteurs may be largely undiscovered stateside, that status is likely to change.

title: Continuing Coverage of a Question Mark
description: Sept. 11 anniversary specials have been such a television staple since 2002 that by now they constitute their own small genre. This weekend, however, TV is largely sticking with coverage of the ground zero memorial ceremony (and any associated protests of the planned Muslim community center nearby) on Saturday morning, perhaps mindful of the excess we can expect for the 10th anniversary next year.

title: In Vastness of Toronto, Small Films Take Root
description: TORONTO  A recurring wonder of this citys vast, industrial-strength annual movie festival is that the frailest of flowers, personal film, still sprouts here.

description: This week the Giants and the Jets will open the regular season at their new $1.6 billion stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Russia: Medvedev Defends Level of Political Freedom
description: President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Friday defended the level of political freedom in Russia, trying to refute criticism that the Kremlin had suppressed opposition. Mr. Medvedev, who pledged when he took office in 2008 to promote more liberal policies, suggested at an international forum that Russia had made strides given that the Soviet Union fell only two decades ago. I categorically do not agree with those who maintain that there is no democracy in Russia, that it is ruled by authoritarian tradition, he said. He added, Russia, without a doubt, is a democracy. Yes, it is young, immature, imperfect, inexperienced  but it is democracy. We are at the very beginning of the path.

title: India: Dengue Fever Concerns
description: Health officials are struggling to allay domestic concerns about dengue fever as India scrambles to finish construction projects in time for the Commonwealth Games, scheduled to being Oct. 3 in New Delhi. India is expecting 8,000 athletes, and delays and accusations of corruption have marred preparations. The outbreak is a concern partly because the athletes quarters will be near a breeding ground for the mosquitoes that spread the disease. Some countries have issued travel warnings, while The Mirror reported in Britain that the head of Englands delegation had told team managers that athletes could withdraw over health concerns. Dr. Chusak Prasttisur, of the World Health Organization, said the worst could be yet to come. Dengue in India will peak in coming months, he said. But K. Sujatha Rao, the health secretary, said that the number of cases in New Delhi this year was no higher than usual.

title: Britain: Minister Paid Detectives
description: A junior justice minister in Prime Minister David Camerons government has admitted that he paid private detectives to investigate Conservative party colleagues he suspected of being sources for newspaper articles claiming he had made excessive parliamentary expense claims. The minister, Jonathan Djanogly, 45, said he acted following malicious allegations last year, when dozens of members of Parliament were embroiled in an expenses scandal. He said he hired the detectives to try to find out the sources that said that he had improperly claimed more than $20,000 in cleaning costs for his home 75 miles north of London, and a similar sum for gardening costs. Mr. Djanogly repaid claims ruled improper, amounting to $38,750. But before the reimbursement, private detectives posing as reporters interviewed prominent Conservatives in his Huntingdon parliamentary constituency and reported their findings to Mr. Djanogly. Calls for the ministers resignation were rejected by a spokesman for Mr. Cameron, who said the prime minister continued to have full confidence in him. With hindsight, I can see that I may have overreacted, Mr. Djanogly said.

He splits his time between San Jose and this booming coastal metropolis, running his $6 million a year computer chip-making company.

Ditto the Chanel blouse with the keyhole neckline and the gold Chanel watch and the gold Chanel necklace and the gold-studded Chanel bracelet. title: For the Love of Orange Juice
description: Ed Koch  the former mayor of New York and a one-man octogenarian media empire  is a busy guy. Between his radio show (The Voice of Reason, Friday nights on Bloomberg Radio), his punditry (HuffPo and New York Press) and his movie reviews (The Villager, Yonkers Tribune), theres not a lot of time left over for leisurely Sunday mornings. In fact, Mr. Koch, 85, who lives in Greenwich Village, gets up at 6:30 a.m. every Sunday  or a little earlier, about two minutes before the alarm goes off, it never fails  and, more or less, gets right down to work. ALAN FEUER

title: The New Plan for Army? Going Old School
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  In his second year as Army football coach, Rich Ellerson has an office that looks comfy and lived in. He ought to feel at home. There are Ellersons all around. His fathers 1935 West Point cadet portrait rests on one wall of the office. On a facing wall is a picture of the 1962 Army football team that his brother John captained. Another brother is also a West Point graduate.

title: As Colleagues Keep Their Distance, Rangel Finds a Re-election Ally in Bloomberg
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel finds himself shunned by some of his colleagues as he battles for re-election amid accusations that he committed numerous violations of House ethics rules. But Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is not only supporting Mr. Rangel, he is urging New Yorkers to do so, too.

title: Pentagon Eases Some Rules on Guantnamo Coverage
description: The Pentagon has agreed to revise some of the rules that have restricted what journalists are free to report on from Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, resolving a conflict that peaked in May when four reporters were expelled from the naval base there.

title: Study Cites Drone Crew in Attack on Afghans
description: A Predator drone pilot played down two warnings about the presence of children before military commanders ordered a helicopter attack that killed 23 Afghan civilians traveling down a road in February, an Air Force investigation has found.

description: After Tom Brady signed his new contract Friday afternoon in the owner Robert Krafts office, the two talked about how fortunate Brady was to walk away from a car accident Thursday shaken but unharmed.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE P.S. 185 PLAYGROUND, the citys newest schoolyard, is decidedly old-school, with spaces for skelly, boxball, red light-green light, ace-king-queen and running bases. This revival of old New York City street games is an initiative of the schools principal, Kenneth Llinas, 61, who played them as a child in Flatbush.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Iran on Friday postponed the release of an American woman who has been detained along with two friends for more than a year, in an abrupt shift that suggested divisions within the Iranian government.

title: Kuchar Fights Off Illness for Share of Lead
description: LEMONT, Ill..  With his strength and tournament lead both slipping away, Matt Kuchar turned things around on the inward nine Friday, birdieing four of the last eight holes to retain a share of the lead with a one-over-par 72 in the second round of the BMW Championship.

title: Sept. 11, 2010: The Continuing Human Damage
description: The 9/11 atrocity continues to scar tens of thousands of citizens who pitched in as cleanup volunteers and emergency responders in the toxin-laden clouds at ground zero, the Pentagon and rural Pennsylvania. Ordinary citizens, neighborhood residents and responders heedless of overtime worked side by side for weeks in New York City, many eventually developing grave illnesses that are disrupting lives and careers.

title: German Identity, Long Dormant, Reasserts Itself
description: BERLIN  As a youth in the 1950s, the film director Volker Schlndorff tried to hide his German origins by learning to speak unaccented French. This summer, his daughter painted German flags on her cheeks and joined crowds of thousands on the Kurfrstendamm, a historic avenue, waving their black, red and gold banners to celebrate the countrys World Cup victories.

description: A FEW weeks ago, at the insistence of the Securities and Exchange Commission, New Jersey agreed never again to fraudulently hide its underfunding of the states public pension system. description: After imprisoning three Americans for more than one year, Iran raised and then dashed hopes that it would release one of them, Sarah Shourd, on Saturday. All three should be freed. Shane Bauer, Joshua Fattal and Ms. Shourd have lived lives of fear and depravation in Tehrans infamous Evin prison for far too long.

description: WASHINGTON  President Obama signaled on Friday that he was close to choosing a director for a new consumer bureau, but an array of top jobs that will be crucial to shaping economic policy and financial regulation for the rest of his term remain unfilled.

title: Candidates Scented Mailing Says Albany Stinks
description: There could be a surprise waiting in your mailbox this weekend, courtesy of Carl P. Paladino, a Republican candidate for governor. Not the front of the brochure, which states that Something really stinks in Albany. Nor the back, which features images of tarnished Democrats like Gov. David A. Paterson, former Gov. Eliot Spitzer and former State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi.

title: Bloggingheads: Stimulus, Part II
description: Annie Lowrey, left, of The Washington Independent and Peter Suderman of Reason debate President Obama's new spending plan.

title: Reactions From Afghanistan
description: Afghan responses a Florida pastor's wavering plans to burn Korans on the ninth anniversary of the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001.

title: A Judge Lauded as No-Nonsense and Scholarly
description: As a judge in the busy federal courthouse in Riverside, Calif., Virginia A. Phillips has presided over a rich and varied parade of cases through the years.

title: Surviving on Italian Tradition
description: A couple of decades ago, the New York region was awash in Italian bakeries  the kinds of places that serve delicious minipastries; moist, springy cakes; and sometimes even a great cup of coffee. Today there are far fewer such establishments, but one of the best, the 51-year-old Caff Trento, is still going strong.

title: Chock Full oNuts Returns to Manhattan. But Is That Salmon on the Menu?
description: Back in the 1950s and 60s, New York City was studded with Chock Full oNuts coffee shops, homegrown institutions where the budget-minded could sidle up to the lunch counter for a freshly prepared meal. But the restaurants  once nearly as ubiquitous as the Checker cabs that inspired their yellow-and-black decor  were all but gone by the early 80s, leaving faded memories and eventually some smaller cafes and kiosks bearing the company name.

title: A Mission to Stay Close to the Farm
description: IT has been almost four years since the Flying Pig on Lexington moved from the Mount Kisco train station into the space last occupied by the sophisticated Caf Antico. With the new restaurant came the rustic spirit of the farm, with a somewhat predictable dcor involving a large number of pig images and figurines. But the heart of a restaurant is in the kitchen. This one employs freshly harvested and organically cultivated vegetables, as well as products from livestock raised humanely at Cabbage Hill Farm, which is the restaurants owner and its major supplier. A few other similarly committed farms also supply the restaurant.

title: A Blend Bright and Smooth
description: Producers who blend wines believe the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. That principle governs the Long Island Merlot Alliances 2007 Merliance, a composite.

title: Yankees Take Cautious Approach With Posada
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Jorge Posada said his previous concussion came in September 2007, when Eric Hinske barreled into him during a bone-jarring collision at the plate. That night, he was taken to the hospital for a CT scan, which came back negative. But Posada played the next day, and the day after that, and the day after that, too.

title: Santanas Season Will End in Surgery
description: Season-ending shoulder surgery is ominous enough for any athlete and potentially devastating for an ace like Johan Santana, the veteran Mets left-hander.

title: Accent on the Nautical, From a Lover of Sailing
description: A LOVE of sailing led Bernie DelBello to buy the restaurant Fiddleheads last year with a partner, Michael Ventre, in boat-loving Oyster Bay.

title: Followed by a Loyal Following
description: There could have been any number of reasons Lovin Oven, a 46-seat cafe in Frenchtown, was mobbed during a recent Sunday brunch.

title: A Real Diner, Seasonal and Local
description: WHEN the readers of Edible Jersey magazine gave the owners of a South Jersey diner a Local Hero Award, I added the restaurant to my list of places to try. But when friends came back from a visit there, excited about the everyday use of local products, I called for reservations.

title: A Robot Called Girlzilla
description: Members of a girls' club build a 14-foot robot.

title: Nokia Chooses a Microsoft Officer as Its New Chief Executive
description: BERLIN  Nokia, the leading maker of mobile phones, replaced its chief executive, Olli-Pekka Kallasvuo, on Friday with the head of Microsofts business unit in a bid to turn around the companys struggling smartphone lineup and stop a decline in American market share.

title: Supporting the Farmers, and the Hungry
description: IT was one of the twice-a-week half-price wine nights at the River Tavern in Chester. The bar was standing room only, and very little of that. While dipping fresh tortilla chips into the excellent made-to-order guacamole, we asked the waiter whether he thought the half-price gambit on Mondays and Tuesdays was responsible for the evenings crush. Yes, he said, but Wednesdays, when cocktails are on sale, were even busier.

title: Japan Plans Intervention to Stem Rise in the Yen
description: TOKYO  The Japanese government is gearing up to intervene in global currency markets to curb a strengthening yen, Prime Minister Naoto Kan said Friday, signaling an effort to limit further damage to Japans export-led economy.

title: Among 9/11 Families, a Last Holdout Remains
description: In the nine years since Sept. 11, 2001, the legal claims for people who were injured or killed in the attacks have almost entirely been resolved. Thousands of victims and families entered a special compensation fund created by Congress and were paid more than $7 billion; a much smaller group chose to file lawsuits, which have been settled over time for about $500 million.

title: Savory, Wood-Fired and Local
description: Stanziatos Wood Fired Pizza is not your standard pizza joint. For one thing, there is the wood-stoked oven, its hearth visible right as you enter. Add to that the crispy-thin, pleasingly chewy crust, made in part from imported Italian flour, and youre well on the way to a memorable pizza experience.

title: Two French Automakers Start to Repay Government
description: PARIS  Renault and Peugeot Citron, the French automakers, said Friday that they had begun to repay, ahead of schedule, the billions of euros in government aid they received to help them through the financial crisis and recession.

title: Parking Rules for Id al-Fitr
description: Because of Id al-Fitr, the festival marking the end of Ramadan, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Saturday and Sunday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Houston Scrambles After Blaze That Destroyed Voting Machines
description: HOUSTON  Arson investigators have been called in to scrutinize a fire that destroyed the warehouse where all of Harris Countys voting machines were stored. The blaze left county officials scrambling to find enough equipment to hold an election in the nations third-most-populous county.

title: U.S. Open Photo Replay: Sept. 10
description: Images from Fridays matches at the United States Open.

title: Found History in Velvet and Satin
description: Some of the rich history behind the stash of skullcaps at the Bialystoker Synagogue on Manhattans Lower East Side.

title: Chamber of Commerce Accused of Tax Fraud
description: WASHINGTON  With a war chest rivaling that of the Republican Party itself, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce has emerged in the last year as perhaps the Obama administrations most-well-financed rival on signature policy debates like health care and financial regulation.

title: Typical Day for Mets: More Trouble and Another Loss
description: An excruciatingly long day for the Mets produced a string of new items for the clubs growing list of mishaps and misadventures.

title: Sports Replay: Sept. 10
description: A view of the day in sports, with action on the mats, on the track and in the water.

title: Eli Lilly Wins Court Ruling in Zyprexa Case
description: Eli Lilly & Company won reversal of a ruling that had granted class-action status to a suit by pension funds, unions and insurers that claimed improper marketing of Zyprexa, its schizophrenia treatment, raised their costs. A federal appeals court in New York threw out a September 2008 ruling by Judge Jack B. Weinstein of United States District Court in Brooklyn. He had said the plaintiffs, which included unions, pension funds and insurance companies, could pursue as a group claims that Lillys Zyprexa marketing caused them to pay more for the drug than it was worth. The plaintiffs were seeking $6.8 billion in damages. The appeals court reversed that decision, finding that the link between marketing Zyprexa to doctors and the injury claimed by the payers was attenuated.

title: Profit Falls at Smith & Wesson as Gun Sales Slow
description: The Smith & Wesson Holding Corporation, the gun maker, said its quarterly earnings fell by about half as sales of firearms declined. The company issued a quarterly forecast that fell short of Wall Street expectations. Smith & Wesson said it earned $6.2 million, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter, down from $12.4 million or 21 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales in the period, which ended on July 31 and was the first quarter of Smith & Wessons fiscal year, fell 6.7 percent, to $94.9 million from $101.7 million. For the second quarter, it expects to break even with sales in a range of $97 million to $102 million. The forecast fell short of a profit of 11 cents a share and sales of $111 million expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. The company, based in Springfield, Mass., reported results after the close of trading Thursday, and on Friday its stock fell 31 cents, or 8 percent, to $3.65 a share.

title: On Fashions Night Out, Normal Hits the Streets
description: Fashions Night Out, now in its second year, may be responsible for several things: marking the unofficial start of fall fashion, bringing New York Fashion Week to the masses and demonstrating once again the power of Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue and the person most responsible for getting hundreds of retailers throughout the city to turn their stores into party spaces for a night.

title: After Ruling on Gay Policy, New Questions for Obama
description: WASHINGTON  In many ways, the ruling on Thursday by a federal judge that found the dont ask, dont tell policy toward gay and bisexual members of the military unconstitutional is good news for the Obama administration.

title: Juan Mari Bras, Voice for Separate Puerto Rico, Dies at 82
description: Juan Mari Bras, a leading advocate for Puerto Rican independence who took his fight to Congress and the United Nations, died Friday at his home in Rio Piedras, a suburb of San Juan. He was 82.

title: Irwin Silber, Champion of the Folk Music Revival, Dies at 84
description: Irwin Silber, a founder and the longtime editor of the folk-music magazine Sing Out!, who was one of the prime movers behind the folk-music revival of the 1950s and 1960s and, on a famous occasion, treated Bob Dylan to a public scolding for abandoning his political songs, died on Wednesday in Oakland, Calif. He was 84.

title: Bent Larsen, Chess Grandmaster, Dies at 75
description: Bent Larsen, a Danish-born chess grandmaster who was a perennial challenger for the world championship during the 1960s and 70s, died on Sept. 9 in Buenos Aires, where he had lived for many years. He was 75.

title: What to Watch on Saturday at the Open
description: Kim Clijsters has an opportunity tonight to do what no woman has done since 2001: successfully defend her United States Open title. Shell face Vera Zvonareva, who dispatched the No. 1 seed Caroline Wozniacki in straight sets on Friday.

title: G.O.P. Takes Aim in Indiana
description: It was a safe bet that Representative Joe Donnelly, Democrat of Indiana, was nervous about his re-election when he starting broadcasting television ads last month trying to distance himself from his party leaders. He was among the first Democrats to run an ad criticizing Speaker Nancy Pelosi and President Obama.

title: Big Spending, Not-So-Big Results
description: Despite breaking Californias campaign spending record and running thousands of ads since the June 8 primary, recent polls show that Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor, is still neck and neck with her Democratic opponent, Jerry Brown, who just this week broadcast his first television and radio ads. Ms. Whitman, the former C.E.O. of eBay, has spent $100 million, mostly her personal fortune, while Mr. Brown has spent less than $1 million through the beginning of August. Ms. Whitmans best chance of winning in November rides on whether she can capture the vote of independents, who make up a fifth of all registered voters in California. In 2006, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, a Republican, won after taking more than half of the independent vote.

title: Homers by Cruz Cost Yankees a Lead, Then Game
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Yankees bus was supposed to depart Rangers Ballpark at 12:50 a.m. Saturday morning, but it was already 12:55 and one very important passenger had yet to board. Its waiting for you, Derek Jeter was told, as he walked out of a clubhouse that had emptied quickly, and with little spoken, after 5 hours 12 minutes of ragged baseball ended with a 6-5 loss to the Texas Rangers in 13 innings.

title: Guide to N.F.L. Defenses, Part 6: The 46 Defense
description: Jene Bramel writes for Footballguys.com. You can also follow him on Twitter and reach him at bramel@footballguys.com.

title: Barn Finds Crash the Antique Car Party
description: The cars on display at the seventh-annual Fairfield County Concours dElegance in Westport, Conn., this weekend will mostly be pristine, but one sorry grouping will resemble the far back row in a used car lot. These cars are barn finds, and the upscale event (held on the grounds of a hunt club) made a special effort to find and display them among the million-dollar showpieces.

title: Ravens Stress Getting Ball Into End Zone, Not Just Keeping It Out
description: Westminster, Md.

description: Brian Jones is a studio analyst for CBS College Sports Network. He can also be seen every Tuesday night during the season as part of The Tony Barnhart Show at 9 p.m. and Inside College Football at 10.

description: Mackenzie Soldan has some schoolwork to get to this weekend, but she might be a little preoccupied by her first experience at the United States Open.

title: A Champ Has Rivals, but No Equals
description: Esther Vergeer of the Netherlands will take to the court Sunday afternoon in a United States Open final and, if her previous 395 matches are any indication, she will win.

title: Arroyos Leg Kick Reaches Back to 86
description: As the Mets play out the schedule of another forgettable season, their younger fans might not realize just how dynamic, and influential, their team was in the mid-1980s. For proof, they can look at three stars of today.

title: Time in a Basket
description: LIKE most synagogues, the Bialystoker Synagogue, on the Lower East Side, keeps a stash of skullcaps in the foyer, for anyone who forgot to bring one. In a tattered wicker basket, under a collection of limp nylon kippot and forgettable leather circles, lies a layer of shimmering velvet and satin yarmulkes in gaudy pinks, lemons, baby blues and golds.

title: At a Memorial Ceremony, Loss and Tension
description: Updated, 12:19 p.m. | Thousands of relatives of the 9/11 dead gathered in a park near ground zero on Saturday morning for the ninth annual reading of their names as a nation debated whether a mosque and Islamic community center should be built near ground zero and a president pleaded for religious tolerance.

title: Learning the Ropes
description: Orly Genger discusses her jewelry designs and what led to her success.

title: Open House: Great Expectations (and Theater) for a Nadal-Federer Final
description: Gerry Marzorati: Morning, Michael. We all know what today is about. Today is about Rafael Nadal beating Mikhail Youzhny, then Roger Federer beating Novak Djokovic. This way we New York tennis fans get to have OUR Fed-Rafa final, just like all those other people have had in THEIR Slams. Today, in effect, is about the promise of great tennis TOMORROW.

title: Sneak Peek | Tauba Auerbach for Ohne Titel
description: Science, art and fashion come together in the latest collaboration between Ohne Titels Flora Gill and Alexa Adams and their friend, the first-time jeweler and longtime artist Tauba Auerbach. The accessories, which will make their debut this weekend on the Ohne Titel runway, were the result of much experimentation  with shapes, geometry, problem solving and visual equations, even a science lab. Our creative processes are similar and both very technical, Gillsays. It made sense since our work shares a sleekness combined with underlying hand-wrought elements. Contorting acrylic tubing around colorful enamel chords, Auerbach created a spiraling sculpture-like necklace and chose polished lucite and elastic bracelets. I wanted to use a lot of clear material so that I could make big pieces that wouldnt be too dominating, she says. I thought it would be interesting to see the clothes through the jewelry, and to make certain parts of the pieces like the elastic on the bracelets appear suspended in the air around the models wrists. I chose Lucite because it was durable and I could form it myself. Our hypothesis? Well see bold graphics, wisps of bright orange and red alongside a looser silhouette with a play on sheer fabrics.

title: Two Killers, No Filler: Jerry Lee Lewis Performs With Million Dollar Quartet
description: After Levi Kreis, the Tony Award-winning star of Broadways Million Dollar Quartet, made the pilgrimage to the hotel suite of Jerry Lee Lewis, it was only fair that Mr. Lewis return the favor. On Friday night, Mr. Lewis, the last surviving principal member of a legendary 1956 jam session that also included Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash and Carl Perkins, came to the Nederlander Theater to play three encores with his Million Dollar Quartet counterparts. Video of Mr. Lewiss performance (which we hear also drew former President Bill Clinton, his daughter, Chelsea, and her husband, Marc Mezvinsky, to the theater) appears above. Is this the first time that two Jerry Lee Lewises have shared the same piano?

title: Day Of Infamy
description: Not much to say  except that its really sickening to see how an atrocity perpetrated against all people of good will has been appropriated as a partisan rallying point. When I wrote my first post-9/11 column, I got a lot of angry mail for reporting that partisan exploitation had already started; How can I tell that to my young son? demanded one irate father.

title: Fashion Ties | Orly Gengers Artful Accessories
description: Orly Genger is an artist with strong ties to fashion. Literally. Using only her fingers as tools, Genger crochets chunky yarn and heavy industrial elastic into monumental geometric forms that evoke the seemingly contradictory traditions of minimalist sculpture and womens handicraft. In her collaborations with the jewelry designer Jaclyn Mayer, she transforms her signature forms into stunning statement necklaces that interweave metal with radiantly colored rope. This season, the Genger-Mayer team is creating runway accessories for Victoria Bartlett and Lela Rose. Here, Genger discusses her fashion designs and what led to her success.

title: Pastor Cancels Burning of Koran
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Terry Jones, the controversial pastor, said on Saturday that neither he nor his church would follow through on plans to burn copies of the Koran. In an appearance on NBCs Today show, Mr. Jones said repeatedly and emphatically that the event, originally scheduled to coincide with the anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, was canceled and would not take place at any time.

title: NYRB
description: Ah  forgot to link to our article in the New York Review. It came in long, so it has been broken into two parts; Part II coming soon.

title: One Model To Rule Them All
description: Not really  but as we approach the second anniversary of Lehmans fall, a few thoughts on how to think about macroeconomic policy.

title: Saturday Word: Nine Years Later
description: The White House and Republicans  keenly aware of the political capital at stake with the midterm elections less than two months away  used their Saturday addresses to honor the lives lost during the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks nine years ago and promote the ongoing fight against terrorism. At the same time, President Obama and Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona, who gave the Republican weekly remarks, dealt subtle jabs to their opponents in Washington.

title: Seeking Passion in Toronto
description: TORONTOIts not too frequent that one would find Bill Murray, Mickey Rourke and Megan Fox in a room together, let alone a film, but there they all were, at the Toronto premiere of Mitch Glazers Passion Play. Somewhat of a passion project for Mr. Glazer, the film has made a 20-year journey from script to screen. My hair was jet black when I started this thing, Mr. Glazer said at the premiere. And Ms. Fox, who plays a woman with wings in the fantasy-drama, was three when the script first began to make its way around Hollywood.

title: A Post 9/11 Parenting Moment
description: On this day, dark with memories, Larissa Kosmos reflects on what has changed  and what has not.

title: Succession Gives Army a Stiff Test in Egypt
description: CAIRO  When a boiler at Military Factory 99 exploded in early August, killing one civilian worker and injuring six, a group of employees called a strike to demand safer working conditions, as they are entitled to do under Egyptian law.

title: Attendance Dips at the Open
description: More than 640,000 tennis fans attended the United States Open in the first 12 days of the tournament, according to the United States Tennis Association. At least 60,000 more are expected over the final weekend.

title: N. Korea Suggests Family Reunions
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In a surprise gesture of reconciliation that could ease tensions on the divided Korean Peninsula, North Korea proposed to South Korea on Saturday that they arrange reunions of families separated by a war six decades ago.

title: Acrostic: Back at the Ranch
description: ACROSTIC NOTES  Theres a nice smattering of clues and answers relating to the subject of todays acrostic. F, K, Q and X have a definite tie-in, but what do you think about B, O and T?

title: Nadal Dismantles Youzhny to Reach Final
description: Rafael Nadal jumped into the sunshine and jabbed both fists into the crisp September air, allowing a joyous grin to escape for a brief moment. He crushed the 12th-seeded Russian Mikhail Youzhny, 6-2, 6-3, 6-4 in the first mens United States Open semifinal, and celebrated one hurdle now behind him.

title: China and Tibet
description: Lodi Gyari, the Dalai Lamas representative in Washington, has a good op-ed in the South China Morning Post (by subscription only). In particular, he makes two points that I think Beijing just doesnt get. First:

title: Runway Beauty | Rag & Bone
description: Gucci Westman and Guido Palau imagined the spring makeup and hair (respectively) of the Rag & Bone downtowner as a bit of an afterthought following a rainforest adventure. The inspiration, Westman explained backstage, was a combination of a real girl whos gone on a trip and Peter Lindbergh girls of the 80s. To wit, she used a taupe shadow (from Revlons Multi Use Palette in Suede Rhapsody, available next month), cream blush (Revlon Berry Flirtatious) and Revlon Colorburst Lipstick in Fashions Night Pout, which will only be available via the brands Internet giveaways. Most fascinating was Westmans treatment of the brows: she brushed them through with Elizabeth Arden Eight Hour Cream and set them with Brilliant Diamant, a hairspray that she picked up in Paris. (We only have one bottle to share between us! she said.)

title: On Sept. 11 Anniversary, Rifts Amid Mourning
description: The ninth anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, was marked on Saturday by the memorials and prayer services of the past, but also by events hard to envision just a year ago  heated demonstrations blocks from ground zero, political and religious tensions and an unmistakable sense that a once-unifying day was now replete with division.

title: A G.O.P. Leader Tightly Bound to Lobbyists
description: WASHINGTON  House Democrats were preparing late last year for the first floor vote on the financial regulatory overhaul when Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio and other Republican leaders summoned more than 100 industry lobbyists and conservative political activists to Capitol Hill for a private strategy session.

title: Alonso Carries Ferrari to Pole, at the Italian Teams Home Race
description: MONZA, Italy  The qualifying session was interesting in more than just a few ways. For the first time since 2008 there is a Ferrari on the pole position, and the fact that it happened here in Monza for the Italian Grand Prix is not just special, it is magical. That it was Fernando Alonso who got it, while Felipe Massa took the third-fastest time was also certainly a nice feeling for the Spaniard who has been under fire so much since the team orders fiasco, where he has been accused of taking points for free from Massa.

title: Disappointment for a Favorite

But perhaps unsurprisingly, the clear favorite of the crowd was Ryder Hesjedal, a Canadian who finished seventh in this years Tour de France. Hesjedal, who rides for the American-backed Garmin-Transitions, offered a dramatic break from the field in the final laps of the 176.4-kilometer race, which featured two tough climbs and many tricky descents. But ultimately his fans were disappointed. Thomas Voeckler, a French rider usually known for long and unsuccessful solo moves, staged a short solo break on the uphill finish for the victory. The race marked the arrival of the International Cycling Unions ProTour in North America, a race series that that is restricted to the worlds top teams. A second ProTour race will be held in Montreal on Sunday. title: Runway Grooming | Duckie Brown
description: At Duckie Browns runway show yesterday, American Crew, the mens grooming brand, unveiled Curl and Boost, a new collection of specialized styling aids developed specifically for thinning and curly hair. Paul Wilson, the companys artistic director, created two distinct looks to demonstrate the lines versatility. While manipulating a models thick, curly locks, Wilson said that the first style, which was sleekly molded and sculpted close to the head, showed off shorter, groomed, tamed and really shiny hair. To sharply contrast that look, he created a second style that sported full, lived in, dry-textured hair. A tandem exercise in style extremes, the models hair complemented Duckie Browns spring fashions, which ranged from tailored trousers in muted tones to eye-popping bug print shirts. The Curl and Boost system, which is comprised of Curl Control (tames rough, unruly hair), Curl Construct (defines and shapes curls), Boost Powder (mattifies and builds texture), and Boost Cream (lifts thin hair to new heights), sell for $17.95 each and will be available at authorized American Crew salons beginning in January 2011.

title: Books, at a Price

He was obsessed with having the very best, The Guardian reports, and willing to pay for it. Now, 55 years after his death, some of his collection will be sold. There is a Shakespeares First Folio, a volume of 36 plays published in 1623; a cache of letters from Elizabeth I to the jailer of Mary, Queen of Scots; and a John James Audubons Birds of America, valued at $6.2 million to $9.2 million. The oversize book, with 435 hand-colored prints, was first bought by an early paleobotanist, Henry Witham. Of that transaction, Audubon, who died in 1851, wrote: I determined in an instant that this gentleman was a gentleman indeed. ... We all talked much, for I believe the good wine of Mr. Witham had a most direct effect.

Mr. Gates appears in the film, and, with his wife Melinda, heads a foundation that has invested heavily in improvements to education. But his aw-shucks manner couldnt hide the fact that some of the proposals he tossed off on stage at the Winter Garden theater here were volatile stuff. Were investing in building these evaluation systems, Mr. Gates said. He was referring to systems that would evaluate the performance of public school teachers, with an eye toward ending the current tenure system under which many teachers now work, and providing a way to weed out the worst teachers, while, perhaps, rewarding the best. He also mentioned, at least twice, changes to teacher pension systems.

title: The Daley Legacy, Inescapable
description: Trying to sum up the legacy of Mayor Richard M. Daleys more than two decades in office in one neat snapshot is impossible. Mr. Daley is as complicated as the city he oversees. He is quick to anger, surprising, emotional; exceedingly loyal to some and ruthlessly business-like to others; parochial, yet overly sensitive when criticized for it. While he was in office, great strides were made. Mr. Daley oversaw a city that transformed its economy, making Chicago the vibrant hub of the Midwest. He remade the citys front yard with Millennium Park, and showcased the city with a victory celebration after helping a Chicagoan win the highest office in the land. And he was ready to show it off on a global stage with an ambitious bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics. But there were also stunning setbacks. Moves like the middle-of-the-night takeover of Meigs Field solidified a reputation as a bully and autocrat. There was the humiliating Olympics loss  elimination in the first round of the International Olympic Committees voting process  and the privatization missteps. Recent high-profile crime in otherwise-stable neighborhoods undermined the good news of relatively lower crime rates. And now he leaves a financial mess for his successor. Most assuredly, Mr. Daleys success as mayor will be debated for years. What follows is a look at his legacy in five areas  politics, education, crime, race and business  that will most likely frame Chicagoans discussions about the eventful mayoralty of Richard M. Daley. JIM KIRK

title: Runway Beauty | Alexander Wang
description: It seems like Alexander Wang took in a showing of the Tamra Davis documentary, Jean-Michel Basquiat: The Radiant Child, which premiered this summerbackstage at his spring 2011 collection, the late artist was the most cited reference by makeup artist Diane Kendal, hairstylist Guido Palau, and Nonie Creme, co-founder of nail polish brand Butter London. Wangs downtown gallerina was clad in sheer fabrics, optic white denim and wide-cut pants, paired with a no-look look that had beauty editors scratching their heads. There isnt really much makeup today, said Kendal with a wry grin. She bleached brows by applying Wella Wellite Powder Lightener with a makeup brush to keep the girls looking coolwith the exception of Agyness Deyn, who apparently wasnt up for a color change. And on the rest of the face? Just concealer where needed and moisturizer. We wanted the skin to look shiny. Over at the hair station, Palau said he didnt want hair color to stand out and get in the way of the identity of Wangs new-age traveler woman. To make the look uniform, he mixed Fullers Earth Claya cosmetic clay often used in DIY skincare recipes and that is also the main ingredient in popular 1940s hair powder Minipoowith white pigment and slicked the concoction through the hair. The resulting look was futuristic on models (including runway vets Karen Elson, Omahrya Mota and Karolina Kurkova), but in reality would look like someone in the middle of undergoing a double process (perhaps to emerge as the grey-haired woman seen earlier today at Cynthia Rowley). The nails, filed to a rounded shape, also appeared peculiarly half-done: manicurists applied one coat of Butter London Nail Foundation Flawless Basecoat followed by two coats of the brands Matte Finish Topcoat. The overall effect was certainly a look, and indeed, one best pulled off by a young art star, down to the late-breaking addition of faux rose gold septum rings.

You used to be able to see the World Trade Center from the seats on the barge in Brooklyn, through the huge picture window that overlooks the East River and Manhattan. title: The Noises of Modern Life, Ending in a Bombardment
description: Approaching the work of Ryoji Ikeda, you risk becoming so mired in the what and the how that you can lose sight of something more pressing: the why. Since the mid-1990s Mr. Ikeda, a Japanese composer and multimedia artist now based in Paris, has fashioned music that explores and exploits aural perception by manipulating sounds at the outermost edges of what many listeners would term agreeable: extreme high and low frequencies; split-second variations in intensity, direction and duration; barely perceptible sounds; assaultive bursts of digital noise.

His sold-out show at the Beacon Theater on Friday night delivered rapturously on that promise, with something else besides. Conceived as an 80th birthday celebration for Mr. Rollins, the concert found him in high spirits, in strong form and, for a generous stretch, in rare distinguished company. It was an evening worthy of an American master, and primarily because he made it so.

description: BAGHDAD  American military units fired on insurgents while supporting Iraqi troops northeast of the capital on Sunday, Iraqi officials said. It was the second such episode since the United States declared an end to its combat operations in Iraq less than two weeks ago.

title: A Particularly Poor Weekend at the Box Office
description: The first weekend after Labor Day is typically the movie industrys slowest of the year, as young audiences return to school, but the last three days were particularly weak. Despite sharply higher ticket prices, a lack of new releases left the North American box office down 11 percent for the weekend compared with the same period last year. The only fresh studio title in the market, Resident Evil: Afterlife 3D, was by far the most popular movie, selling about $27.7 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. This sci-fi movie, the fourth in a franchise, also opened strongly overseas with $45.5 million in sales. Constantin Film spent about $60 million to make Resident Evil: Afterlife 3D; Sony Pictures Entertainment bought the distribution rights. Sonys crime thriller Takers was second with about $6.1 million for a new domestic total of $48.1 million. The American, a Focus Features release starring George Clooney, tumbled to third place with $5.9 million ($28.3 million total). Machete (20th Century Fox) was fourth with $4.2 million ($20.8 million total). Drew Barrymores Going the Distance (Warner Brothers) was fifth with $3.8 million ($14 million total).

title: Sofia Coppola Takes Golden Lion in Venice
description: The director Sofia Coppola, above, was awarded the 67th Venice Film Festivals Golden Lion prize for best film on Saturday, The Associated Press reported. Somewhere, Ms. Coppolas drama about a Hollywood star who realizes how empty his life is after reconnecting with his 11-year-old daughter, stars Stephen Dorff (Public Enemies) and Elle Fanning, younger sister to Dakota. The festival jury was unanimous in its decision to award the prize to Ms. Coppola, said the director Quentin Tarantino, who served as this years jury chairman. This film enchanted us from its first screening, he said. The movie covers familiar territory for Ms. Coppola. Her widely praised 2003 film, Lost In Translation, shared similar themes, and Ms. Coppola spent much of her childhood moving around with her father, the director Francis Ford Coppola. Among the other prizes given out on Saturday were the Silver Lion, for best director, and the Osella, for best screenplay, both of which went to lex de la Iglesia of Spain for his movie Balada Triste de Trompeta (A Sad Trumpet Ballad). A special jury prize was given to Jerzy Skolimowski for his film Essential Killing, which also earned Vincent Gallo (The Brown Bunny) an award for best actor.

title: Tony Awards Stay at Home on CBS
description: CBS has extended its agreement with the Broadway League and the American Theater Wing to televise the annual Tony Awards ceremony, which honors theater professionals for distinguished achievement on Broadway. CBS has announced that a three-year agreement, through 2013, will keep the Tonys with the network, which has been broadcasting the ceremony since 1978. The Tony Awards telecast earned CBS two Emmy Awards this year, one in the special-class category and another for outstanding writing for a variety, music or comedy special. Next years show is to be televised in June. The awards were first held at the Waldorf Astoria on April 6, 1947, after being founded by the American Theater Wing as a tribute to Antoinette Perry, an actress, producer, director, and secretary and board chairwoman of the American Theater Wing throughout World War II.

title: 2 Hollywood Newcomers Welcomed With Movies
description: The actress Noomi Rapace, above left, who portrayed Lisbeth Salander in the Swedish film adaptations of Stieg Larssons Millennium book trilogy, has been signed to play the lead female character in the coming movie Sherlock Holmes 2, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The Warner Brothers picture will bring back Robert Downey Jr. in the title role, along with Jude Law as Dr. Watson, with Guy Ritchie directing. Filming is expected to begin later this year. ... Christina Hendricks, above right, the more than capable office manager of Sterling, Draper, Cooper, Price on the television show Mad Men, has collected a bundle of new roles in movies. She has been cast in the romantic comedy Life as We Know It, with Katherine Heigl and Josh Duhamel; Hisako Matsuis biographical film Leonie; and alongside Adrien Brody and James Caan in Detachment. Now Ms. Hendricks has landed a role in Drive, a new independent film adapted by Hossein Amini (Killshot) from the James Sallis novel, Variety has reported. She will join a cast including Ryan Gosling, Carey Mulligan, Albert Brooks, Bryan Cranston and Oscar Isaac. Nicolas Winding Refn will direct this thriller about a Hollywood stunt man involved in a heist gone wrong. title: The N.F.L.s Worst Rule: Going to the Ground
description: N.F.L. Rule 8, Section 1, Article 3, Item 1: Going to the ground. If a player goes to the ground in the act of catching a pass (with or without contact by an opponent), he must maintain control of the ball after he touches the ground, whether in the field of play or the end zone. If he loses control of the ball, and the ball touches the ground before he regains control, the pass is incomplete. If he regains control prior to the ball touching the ground, the pass is complete.
