title: New York Fashion Week | The Cline Factor
description: As the New York spring collections began, just five days ago, the main question on the minds of fashion editors was how much Cline would there be on the catwalks. We knew it would be in the audience  that stripe-y tunic dress with zip shoulder (so Agns B and yet so not) is ubiquitous at Lincoln Center, as are the wide-leg pants, the khaki shirt with gold zipper pulls, the soft square tote. But how much of the Cline designer Phoebe Philos tailored conceptualism, her hand with stripped-back superhot sportswear, would find its way into American clothes remained to be seen. We  fashion editors  all remember the Marni-fication of the industry a decade ago. We know very well what one cool brand can do to womens closets. And, lets face it: sportswear is the hallmark of American fashion. Bringing Cline back is like lugging coal to Newcastle.

title: Teaching a Toddler to Curse
description: I was well into my 30s before I heard my mother utter a four-letter word. My children will not be waiting that long. I have never been one to curse constantly, and when I became a parent, I cleaned up my language even more, at least for a while. As my sons entered their tweens and then their teens, though, and it became clear that they knew far more bad words than I did, I loosened my tongue a bit. It began to feel Pollyanna-like to tell them, Those are not nice words, or even, We dont curse, and my message instead became, We dont curse in certain situations. Like in front of your teachers. Or your grandmother (even though I now know she knows those words). Or at a job interview. And, as one who uses words for a living, I tried to stress that curses are lazy. They are a unimaginative default in a language that has so many more interesting possibilities.

title: Sugar and Vice
description: Thin lips, button noses and beady eyes are all it took for Yoshitomo Nara to create the passive-aggressive brats and eagerly menacing pups that catapulted him to international art stardom in the 1990s. In serious need of love, they simultaneously attract and repel, typifying the culture of twisted cuteness endemic to Japanese manga comics. But the real revelation in Nobodys Fool, the Asia Societys arresting retrospective of the artists two-decade career, is how much he was influenced by punk bands like the Ramones  and the cover graphics of 1960s rock albums. His own collection of vintage King Crimson, Geoff Muldaur, Norman Greenbaum and Carole King albums anchor the museum-wide show, where his pyromaniac girls and orphaned dogs appear in lonely wooden shacks. One of them replicates his drawing studio at home  and is as endearingly angst-ridden as his art.Nobodys Fool is on view through Jan. 2, 2011, at Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue.

Check it out.

title: Molires House Makes Room for Stanley
description: PARIS  The gilded and red velvet Salle Richelieu is the most hallowed stage of the Comdie Franaise, the three-centuries-old acting troupe. It has survived war, fire, political turmoil and financial difficulties, but only now is it encountering its very first American play.

title: Capturing the Atom Bomb on Film
description: From 1945 to 1962, the United States military detonated hundreds of nuclear bombs in the atmosphere. George Yoshitake, 82, speaks about his experiences documenting the explosions and their destructive effects.

title: Quote Unquote | Front Row Fodder
description: Penn Bagdley tells New York Magazine his purpose at Fashion Week. Yup, thats about right.

title: Runway Beauty | Victoria Beckham
description: You wouldnt expect to see Victoria Beckham wearing bright purple eyeshadow, so it was a bit of a surprise to see models wearing it in her presentation yesterday. (Another departure for the sexy star turned real-deal designer: the number of floral prints in the collection.) Using Lancme products, Charlotte Tilbury created a dewy face, sans blush  a nice break from the contoured looks seen at Altuzarra and Thakoon  and added a thick layer of LAbsolu Rouge lipstick in pinky-beige Rich Cashmere followed by gobs of clear gloss. This was punctuated by the aforementioned indigo shadow, a blend of Lancme Color Design shadows in Trendy and Drama  perfect shade names for a former Spice Girl. As if that wasnt enough color, nails were painted with a bubblegum pink from Butter London. Didier Malige slicked models hair behind their ears (a style also seen at Cynthia Steffe, where Avons Tippi Shorter was going for Virgin Suicides-meets-Marcia Brady) and added a few crimps around the nape of the neck, held in place with Frederic Fekkai Sheer Hold Hairspray.

title: Robot Invasion Welcomed in Japan
description: TOKYO  Could it be that the Japanese view of robots as friendly helpers  and not as the rebellious, violent machines that populate much of Western science fiction  is rooted in the Shinto religion, which blurs the boundaries between animate and inanimate? To the Japanese psyche, this theory goes, a humanoid and sentient robot may simply not feel as creepy or threatening as it does in other cultures.

title: In Basketball, Danger of Head Trauma
description: During basketball practice last year, 12-year-old Nicole Dehart was shooting the ball when a defender tried aggressively to block her shot. The two players made contact, and Nicole hit the floor headfirst.

title: Health Dividend Seen in Deeper Emission Cuts
description: Health advocates said Monday that adopting more ambitious targets for cutting greenhouse gases could save health programs up to 30.5 billion euros ($38.7 billion) in expenditures each year in the European Union.

title: Critics Picks Video: Donnie Darko
description: This week, A. O. Scott takes a look at Richard Kellys cult film Donnie Darko (2001), about a tormented young hero, played by Jake Gyllenhaal, who may or may not be a schizophrenic time traveler with a giant, evil-faced rabbit friend named Frank.

title: The Bomb Chroniclers
description: They risked their lives to capture on film hundreds of blinding flashes, rising fireballs and mushroom clouds.

title: Shia LaBeoufs Trip Down Wall Street
description: TORONTO  Known better for managing Transformers than commodities, Shia LaBeouf takes on a very different screen challenge in the Oliver Stone update to Wall Street, Money Never Sleeps. He plays a proprietary trader in a relationship with the daughter (Carey Mulligan) of Gordon Gekko (Michael Douglas). Here, Mr. LeBeouf discusses the intense preparation that went into building his character, including meeting with members of the financial world and doing some trading of his own.

title: Christmas Is Coming; Elf Cast List Is Ready
description: The holiday season just starts earlier and earlier every year, doesnt it? On Monday the team behind the Broadway musical Elf unwrapped the names of the two remaining principal cast members for that yuletide-theme production: Sebastian Arcelus, above, who plays Bob Gaudio in Broadways Jersey Boys and has also appeared in Wicked and Rent, will step into the formidable tights of Buddy, the oversize North Pole denizen originally played by Will Ferrell in the 2003 film Elf. Amy Spanger, above, of Broadways Rock of Ages and The Wedding Singer, will play Jovie, a department store worker in need of some Christmas cheer, a role played in the movie by Zooey Deschanel. The cast will also include George Wendt (Cheers) as Santa. Elf will be directed and choreographed by Casey Nicholaw (The Drowsy Chaperone), with songs by Matthew Sklar and Chad Beguelin (The Wedding Singer) and a book by Thomas Meehan (Hairspray, The Producers) and Bob Martin (The Drowsy Chaperone). It is to begin previews at the Al Hirschfeld Theater on Nov. 2 and open on Nov. 14.

title: Football Ratings Up
description: The first Sunday Night Football game of the season catapulted NBC into first place in the ratings for the night, earning what appeared to be the highest ratings ever for a Sunday Night Football broadcast. Although final audience figures were not available Monday, preliminary overnight estimates for the game were nearly as high as they were for Thursdays season opener, which attracted 27.5 million viewers, the largest audience for a regular-season game broadcast in prime time in 14 years. Fox ranked second on the night, largely due to an overrun of its afternoon football coverage, which meant that more than 17 million viewers were tuned in to the network during the 7 oclock hour. Following it, Fox broadcast reruns of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 (4.9 million). CBS was third, earning 8.2 million at 7 for 60 Minutes and 6.7 million at 8 for Big Brother but lower ratings at 9 and 10 for repeats of Undercover Boss (4.8 million) and CSI: Miami (5.3 million). ABC finished in fourth place with reruns followed by The Gates, at 10 (2.1 million).

title: From Spain, Big Reds That Are Well Balanced
description: RIBERA DEL DUERO is a paradoxical region, ancient yet thoroughly modern. Its wines embrace the mainstream characteristics that seem so popular around the world. They are plush, opulent, flamboyantly fruity and powerfully oaky. Yet while some unavoidably stray into the homogenized international style, the best remain identifiably Spanish.

title: British Museum Receives $38.5. Million Donation
description: John Sainsbury, the former head of a British supermarket chain, and his brother Simon, have donated $38.5 million toward an expansion of the British Museum, according to The Guardian newspaper and Reuters. The gift is one of the largest private cultural donations ever made in Britain and comes at a time when arts institutions there are bracing for an expected 25 percent cut in state financing when the government announces the results of a spending review on Oct. 20. The British Museum is building a $360 million wing, designed by Richard Rogers, to house temporary exhibitions and a conservation center. The government has pledged roughly $35 million toward it.

title: I, Claudius Radio Serial: Bring Your Own Togas
description: For American viewers of a certain impressionable age (and some old enough to know better), the original television mini-series I, Claudius was an eye-opening introduction to public broadcasting: a BBC-produced toga party, first shown in the United States in 1977, teeming with ancient Roman soap opera, orgies, nakedness, snakes and even naked snakes. (It also had the unforgettable performances of Derek Jacobi, right, as the title character and stammering emperor-to-be, and John Hurt as the utterly insane Caligula, just to prove we werent watching only for the naughty bits.) Now I, Claudius is heading back to the British airwaves in a new version that will feature Mr. Jacobi, but for which youll have to supply your own steamy pictures. BBCs Radio 4 will produce a new serial adapted from Robert Gravess historical novels to be broadcast starting in November, The Guardian reported. This time Mr. Jacobi will play the role of the emperor Augustus (portrayed in the original television adaptation by Brian Blessed), and Claudius will be played by Tom Goodman-Hill. An American air date for the series has not been announced.

title: Invisible Dog, Off Leash and Reimagined
description: Serendipity can strike at any time. In the 1970s a World War II veteran named George Zorbas took a trip to Europe and returned with a novelty concept that became a runaway hit: the invisible-dog leash. As a visual prank, it fit perfectly in the era of the pet rock. He brought the loopy idea back to his factory in Brooklyns Boerum Hill neighborhood, where he already produced belts and jewelry, eventually employing as many as 150 people to churn out thousands of the stiff leashes and empty collars, 24 hours a day.

title: Invisible Dog Art Space
description: A French theater director has transformed an abandoned belt factory into a neighborhood arts hub in Brooklyn.

title: Vatican Library Restored; 1.6. Million Volumes Await
description: The Vatican Library, which houses one of the worlds most important collections of manuscripts (above, a reading room), will reopen on Monday after a three-year, $12 million renovation, much to the relief of academics around the world. Msgr. Cesare Pasini, the prefect of the library, said at a news conference on Monday that he was happy to alleviate the anxiety of the many scholars who had written to him since the library closed in July 2007, cutting off access to its 1.6 million volumes, including 75,000 manuscripts. The renovations were both structural  involving the reinforcement of foundations and floors  and technological.

title: Crucial Work Remains in Rewriting Bank Regulations, Officials Say
description: BASEL, Switzerland  Stock markets cheered new regulations announced this weekend that were intended to prevent a recurrence of the financial crisis, but central bankers cautioned Monday that officials still must forge agreements to limit short-term bank risk and deal with institutions considered too big too fail.

title: A123 Opens Michigan Battery Plant, With Federal and State Aid
description: A123 Systems, an electric car battery supplier to Fisker Automotive and BMW, among other companies, opened its new 291,000-square-foot lithium-ion battery plant in Livonia, Mich., on Monday, financed in part by a $249 million federal stimulus grant from the Energy Department.

title: Good Sign In Toronto For Smaller Films
description: Yes, there are deals at the Toronto International Film Festival. Anne Thompson, a blogger who works with IndieWire, notes that the Weinstein Company sent a thrill through the Creative Artists Agency party on Sunday night with its purchase of Dirty Girl for a reported $3 million. That comes with the announced purchase of Super, a super-crime-fighter spoof, by IFC Entertainment. Dirty Girl is from the writer-director Abe Sylvia, Super from the writer-director James Gunn. The sales are a good sign for smaller films that depend heavily on the festival for their shot at becoming, well, large.

title: Joaquin Phoenix Returning To Lettermans Show
description: The physical form of Joaquin Phoenix, left, is headed back to David Lettermans Late Show  will he bring his mind this time? On Monday press representatives for the show said that Mr. Phoenix, the living art experiment and occasional star of films like We Own the Night and Walk the Line, would be a guest on Mr. Lettermans program on Sept. 22. Its the first time that Mr. Phoenix has been booked on that show since his notorious appearance on Feb. 11, 2009, when he gave Mr. Letterman a largely nonresponsive interview that became a viral sensation and left viewers wondering whether Mr. Phoenix was playing an elaborate prank on the host and his audience. CBS said it would repeat Mr. Phoenixs earlier Late Show interview on Thursday in anticipation of his Sept. 22 appearance, in which hell be promoting his documentary, Im Still Here, which chronicles a year in which Mr. Phoenix said he was retiring from acting to pursue a career as a rapper.

title: A 1988 Commission, Revisited on an Anniversary
description: The American String Quartet is celebrating its 35th anniversary this season, and the Manhattan School of Music, where it has been in residence for 26 of those years, is giving a party in the form of a three-concert retrospective, with two performances at the school and one at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Scorecard | Tom Ford Wins!
description: Minimalism isnt the only revenant from the 90s this New York fashion week. As Scorecard looks on over the shoulders of the G100 of top editors who attended Tom Fords cocktail-party-cum-Oscars-of-catwalk extravaganza for his new womens line Sunday, we surmise that Fashion with a capital F is back, too. (No photos were allowed into cyberspace  how very like the premillennial Gucci era!)

title: From Organ Loft, Sounds of Buxtehude and Bach
description: The organist and choral conductor Kent Tritle may be the only musician with more job titles and a busier schedule than Valery Gergiev. As the director of Music Ministries at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue, he oversees more than 400 services with music each year. As the music director of Musica Sacra and the Oratorio Society of New York, he routinely conducts insightful performances of repertory from Renaissance Masses to works by living composers. He is on the faculties at the Juilliard School and the Manhattan School of Music; he is the organist of the New York Philharmonic.

title: Ravens Defeat Jets, 10-9
description: All off-season, the Jets were bold and brash, broadcasting to whoever would listen that they were destined to become champions. But they did not resemble the championship football team that the players and the coaches had made themselves out to be.

title: Sure, Those Beards Remain, But Their Music Has Legs, Too
description: ZZ Tops show at the Beacon Theater on Sunday was all base line. Not bass lines  there were those, too, and very steady  but an unbroken rumble of authority, an adherence to rules and a celebration of them. If you are the kind of person who likes to use a suspect and imprecise and maybe impossible term about music, then go ahead, because this was, more or less, a perfect concert.

title: Lionsgate and Televisa Unite on Films
description: LOS ANGELES  Lionsgates African-American-focused film business, anchored by Tyler Perry titles, has become a gold mine for the studio. Movies with predominantly black casts that tell stories rooted in black culture  surprise!  bring out a sizable black audience.

title: Toyota Plans 6 New Hybrids for 2012
description: DETROIT  Toyota plans to introduce two electric vehicles in the United States and six hybrid cars worldwide by the end of 2012, a company executive said Monday.

title: Times Appoints Ad Vice President
description: The New York Times announced Friday that Kerrie Gillis had been named a vice president for advertising.

title: 3 Is a Crowd, but 6 Is a Reality Show
description: Attention, New Yorkers: if you should see the Carpio sextuplets  in the park, on the street, in the subway, whatever  do not make eye contact or in any way pay them notice.

title: Hedge Fund Group Defends High-Frequency Trades
description: The Managed Funds Association, the hedge fund industrys main lobbying group, is urging federal regulators not to crack down on high-frequency trading, Bloomberg News reports. The group contends that proposed new rules, in response to the stock market flash crash on May 6, would increase costs for all investors and make markets less liquid.

title: Gone Digital: Music Man Stays in Game
description: In 1997, when Richard Gottehrer started his digital music company, the Orchard, he already had a long and distinguished rsum on the creative, sexy side of the music business. As a Brill Building songwriter, he had helped write My Boyfriends Back and I Want Candy; later, as a producer of Blondie and the Go-Gos, he brought the girl-group sensibility into the punk age.

title: Grassley Not Looking for Twitter Cure
description: Dont worry, Iowa. Senator Charles E. Grassley will probably survive his run-in with Twitter just fine.

title: The Backlash
description: Chapter One: The Cassandra of Lower Delaware

title: After Negotiations, Israel Emerges on Twitter
description: MADRID  Israel has acquired the user name @israel on Twitter, the microblogging Internet service, from the Spanish owner of a pornographic Web site, in an unusual transaction intended to help Israel exercise more influence over its image.

title: Atomic Cinematographers
description: James Gorman and William Broad discuss declassified films made of atomic bomb tests between 1945 and 1962.

title: Michael Bastian: In the Navy
description: Michael Bastian is a designer who seems to delight in casting his shows each season with a different archetype from the man-on-man adult film archives of Falcon Studios. Lets see, there was that lumberjack show last season, and the lacrosse players show for Gant, another on camo warriors last year and then, on Monday, a fairly soft-core collection that included models who were hired because they fit the Navy Seal aesthetic. (Read: Ripped, and not just a little hairy.)

title: Boehner Plays Central Role in Democratic Ad
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats are again stepping up their effort to elevate Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio into a symbol of the Republican Party virtually equivalent to the elephant. And in doing so, they are executing a strategy intended to do more than just provide President Obama and his party with a convenient punching bag.

title: A Shoo-In Struggles in Massachusetts Race
description: BOSTON  For more than a decade, Republicans in Massachusetts have been rooting for Charlie Baker to run for governor. The timing seemed perfect when Mr. Baker, a turnaround expert who was a whiz-kid aide to two governors in the 1990s, decided to challenge Gov. Deval Patrick this year.

title: A Cultural Shift in the Jobs We Seek?
description: To the Editor:

title: As Giants and Jets Open Their Stadium, Empty Seats Stand Out
description: The opening of any new sports stadium is usually accompanied by an A list of celebrities, Air Force jets flying overhead and a sold out sign at the ticket office.

title: Racial Disparity in School Suspensions
description: In many of the nations middle schools, black boys were nearly three times as likely to be suspended as white boys, according to a new study, which also found that black girls were suspended at four times the rate of white girls.

title: Glamorously, Tom Ford Is Back
description: The morning after Tom Fords first womens show in six years, on Sunday night, editors who had been among the 100 invited guests looked at one another and, with a little shake of the head, smiled and said, That was amazing, wasnt it?

title: After 9/11/10: Voices in Favor of Building Bridges
description: To the Editor:

title: My Police Ticketing Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Cup Race Is Taking Different Direction
description: After an acrimonious Americas Cup duel earlier this year between the billionaires Larry Ellison and Ernesto Bertarelli in which the Americans prevailed using a trimaran and space-age wing sail, it was announced Monday that the next Cup races would be contested under an independent governing body and in the most modern of sailing craft, 72-foot-long wing-sailed catamarans capable of reaching 30 knots.

title: Confessing to Crime, but Innocent
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Eddie Lowery lost 10 years of his life for a crime he did not commit. There was no physical evidence at his trial for rape, but one overwhelming factor put him away: he confessed.

title: When Medical Students Meet Real Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Floods Stunt Pakistani Fight Against Insurgents
description: KALAM, Pakistan  The destruction caused by the recent floods and the huge relief effort undertaken since by the Pakistani Army have forced it to alter plans to combat Taliban and Qaeda militants, Pakistani military officials here said.

title: A Walk Along Stones Wall Street
description: You know, half the people in this place could be prosecuted.

title: Trial Starts in a Robbery That Ended With 3 Dead
description: NEW HAVEN  The morning she would die, Jennifer Hawke-Petit was calm as she stood at the tellers window at a bank in Cheshire, Conn. She said that she needed to withdraw $15,000 because men were holding her family hostage at their home and that no one should call the police.

title: Consumer Candidate May Avoid a Vote
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is considering appointing the legal scholar Elizabeth Warren to run a new consumer bureau on a temporary basis to avoid a potentially bruising confirmation battle in the Senate, according to people who have been briefed on the search.

title: The Return of a Stumbling Eagle Raises Concerns
description: After all of the N.F.L.s promises that players concussions have been and will be handled more carefully than ever before, it took only one Sunday for a clearly concussed player to return to a game.

title: For Many, Washroom Seems to Be Just a Name
description: BOSTON  The next time a man hands you a hot dog after making a run to the restroom and the concession stand at an Atlanta Braves baseball game, be careful: there is a good chance he did not wash his hands, according to a report released Monday by a group that sends spies into public restrooms in the name of science.

title: Oprah Offers Audience Trip to Australia
description: Perhaps Oprah Winfrey has finally found a way to top her Pontiac car giveaway.

title: Earthbound at the Country Club
description: Only afterward did I realize that the invitation for Tommy Hilfigers show was a plastic swatch of privet contained in a clean white box. Perfect, I thought.

title: For Female-Aphrodisiac Makers, Effort at Parity
description: A WOMAN in her early 40s pops up on the TV screen. Women are starting to talk about something they have been feeling for a long time, she says, wanting more sexual satisfaction.

title: A Beninois Priest Seeks New Respect, and New Practitioners, for Voodoo
description: COTONOU, Benin  This is not about secretive mutterings in the dead of night or freakish eccentrics, explained Dah Aligbonon Akpochihala, an eminent voodoo priest who has taken to the airwaves to preach the old messages of faith, fidelity and obedience integral to his religion. It is about bringing a younger generation on board.

title: Oprah Winfrey Blesses a New Show, on Home Design
description: Oprah Winfrey, who is closing down her talk show after 25 years to build her own cable network, kicked off her final farewell season on Monday with an extravaganza of old faces and new prizes. Among other wonders, she told members of her studio audience that she would take all 300 of them with her to Australia, along with her pal John Travolta, who is to fly the Qantas Airways jet (hes a pilot and a Qantas goodwill ambassador). Cue screaming.

title: The Scene: Day Five
description: Photos from the fifth day of New York Fashion Week.

title: New Ads to Try to Build Public Support for Gay Marriage
description: Advocates for same-sex marriage in New York, in a major departure from their strategy of lobbying political insiders, will begin making a direct appeal to ordinary voters in a series of commercials featuring Hollywood actors, fashion designers and civic leaders.

title: Civil Rights Photographer Unmasked as Informer
description: ATLANTA  That photo of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. riding one of the first desegregated buses in Montgomery, Ala.? He took it. The well-known image of black sanitation workers carrying I Am a Man signs in Memphis? His. He was the only photojournalist to document the entire trial in the murder of Emmett Till, and he was there in Room 306 of the Lorraine Hotel, Dr. Kings room, on the night he was assassinated.

title: From School Files of an Earlier Era, Faces Looking to the Future
description: Even before school started last week, proof of its imminent reality began to arrive in the mail: teacher assignments, supply lists, free-lunch forms, releases.

title: Ayatollah Speaks of Plot to Abuse Koran
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, delivered a fiery address on Monday accusing the United States government of orchestrating desecrations of the Koran by right-wing American Christian groups last weekend, Iranian state news agencies reported.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,263 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Fans for Generations Choose Couch Over the 50-Yard Line
description: For Judy Staubo, football and family were the perfect Sunday mix, and the Giants were the beloved unifying thread. Six tickets on the 50-yard line were a treasured legacy to her, her children and grandchildren.

title: Biotech Company to Patent Fuel-Secreting Bacterium
description: A biotech company plans to announce Tuesday that it has won a patent on a genetically altered bacterium that converts sunlight and carbon dioxide into ingredients of diesel fuel, a step that could provide a new pathway for making ethanol or a diesel replacement that skips several cumbersome and expensive steps in existing methods.

title: From Giants Blue to Jets Green in 746 Easy Steps
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The blue pieces of turf from the Giants end zones were being swapped for the green of the Jets. Workers cleaned the empty seats and aisles. Four computers hummed in the Oz-like control room, displaying all manner of information about New Meadowlands Stadium, including the temperatures inside the suites and surveillance video of the loading dock.

title: Drug for Irritable Bowel Achieves Goals in Trial
description: An experimental drug can reduce abdominal pain and increase bowel movements in people with irritable bowel syndrome, a condition that affects millions of Americans, the drugs developer said Monday.

title: Everyones Really Mad; Almost Mad Enough to Vote
description: You might think that the mood this political season is being set by the likes of Glenn Beck or Sarah Palin or even that nobody pastor in Florida who outlasted his prescribed 15 minutes. You would be wrong. The guiding spirit this fall is the Bronx-born Paddy Chayefsky.

title: In Iraq, Clearer Image of U.S. Support
description: WASHINGTON  American forces provided extensive support to the Iraqi military in a recent operation north of Baghdad, illustrating the risks that United States troops still endure in their new advisory role there.

title: George C. Williams, 83, Theorist on Evolution, Dies
description: George C. Williams, an evolutionary biologist who helped shape modern theories of natural selection, died Wednesday at his home in South Setauket on Long Island, near Stony Brook University, where he taught for 30 years. He was 83.

title: Zimbabwe: Health Workers Released on Bail
description: Six health workers with a California-based Christian AIDS charity, who are accused of failing to register and practicing without the supervision of a pharmacist, were each released on $200 bail Monday. The four Americans, one New Zealander and one Zimbabwean had been jailed since Thursday in Harare. (Their lawyer had earlier erroneously identified the New Zealander as an American). They are scheduled to return to court on Sept. 27.

title: Primary Tuesday
description: Tuesday is Primary Day in New York State. Polls in New York City are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Voters statewide will decide the Republican candidates for governor and United States senator, and the Democratic candidate for state attorney general. There are also races for numerous Congressional and state legislative offices. Voter information is available from the State Board of Elections at www.vote-ny.com or by calling 1-800-FOR-VOTE (1-800-367-8683); and from the City Board of Elections at www.vote.nyc.ny.us or by calling 1-866-VOTE-NYC (1-866-868-3692). Voters who have problems can visit Election Protection at www.866ourvote.org, or call 1-866-OUR-VOTE (1-866-687-8683).

title: G.O.P. Braces for More Discontent in Primaries
description: As the long and turbulent primary season of the midterm election campaign drew to a close on Monday, the Republican establishment was placing its confidence on hold and bracing for the prospect that voters in yet another state would send a message of defiance to party leaders in Washington.

title: Stars Make the Final Grasp for Candidate Recognition
description: Holy rat race!

title: Barbara Holland, Defender of Small Vices, Dies at 77
description: Barbara Holland, a writer whose humorous essays sang the simple pleasures of drinking martinis, cursing and eating fatty foods, and who wrote an evocative best-selling memoir of her childhood and adolescence in the Washington suburbs, died on Sept. 7 at her home in Bluemont, Va. She was 77.

title: 3-D Printing Spurs a Manufacturing Revolution
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Businesses in the South Park district of San Francisco generally sell either Web technology or sandwiches and burritos. Bespoke Innovations plans to sell designer body parts.

title: Desktop Manufacturing
description: 3D printers let designers make three dimensional objects by just hitting "print" on their computers.  New businesses, like custom prostheses, are taking advantage.

title: If These Walls Could Talk
description: The living room has long been the basic set of the American sitcom, from I Love Lucy to Everybody Loves Raymond. Most of them are unmemorable, transitional spaces; every front door seems to open directly onto a generic sofa. Many of them are all but repeated from show to show (quick: whats the difference between the living rooms on Raymond and King of Queens?). Theyre invariably decorated in a neutral palette, acting as a quiet, passive backdrop to the action.

title: Harold Gould, Character Actor, Dies at 86
description: Harold Gould, a widely recognizable character actor in film and television who specialized, especially late in his career, in playing suave, well-dressed gentlemen in popular sitcoms, died Saturday in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 86.

title: Riders Try to Fight Higher Fares but With Less of Their Old Fire
description: For two years running, thousands of indignant New Yorkers have gathered at public hearings to loudly protest higher fares for the citys buses and subways, and for two years running, the higher fares have gone through.

title: Determination and Hard Work Distinguish Defender for Rapids
description: You will not find the name Kosuke Kimura on any list of statistical leaders in Major League Soccer. But if you check his biographical information, you will discover that Kimura, a right-side defender for the Colorado Rapids, owns a singular distinction: he is the only player in M.L.S. history born in Japan.

title: Foreign Stimulus
description: THE debate over Arizonas controversial immigration law and Congresss passage last month of another border security bill gives the impression that the only problem with our immigration policy is its inability to keep people from entering the country illegally. Not so. The country has an antiquated, jerry-built immigration system that fails on almost every count. The good news is that there is a way to replace it that will promote economic growth while reducing the flow of illegal workers.

title: N.Y. Voters Are More Hopeless Than Angry
description: Uprising. Revolt. Judgment day. These are the words on the lips of aspiring insurgent candidates across New York, Republicans and Democrats alike, who have campaigned for months on hopes that a wave of voter anger will carry them to victory and upend the entrenched political establishment in Albany.

title: USA Track Dismisses Executive in Charge
description: The midpoint between Summer Olympics is usually considered the least dramatic year in track and field. With no outdoor world championships on the schedule (they are held in odd years), athletes nurse injuries or reduce their competitive schedules to rest weary bodies.

title: Its a Busy Day for Voters as They Narrow the Fields
description: A battle for the soul of New Yorks Republican Party. A wide-open field of Democratic attorney general prospects. A rare opportunity to kick out, or at least send a message, to an embattled congressman. A chance to upend the State Legislature.

title: Buyout Firms Sales May Top Purchases
description: Are buyout barons becoming sellout barons?

title: Yale Plans to Create a College in Singapore
description: Yale University announced on Monday that it was planning to create a liberal arts college in Singapore that would be financed entirely by the government there and could, in time, establish a new model for higher education in Asia.

title: Correction
description: Re this post, it was General Jack D. Ripper, not Colonel Bat Guano, who had the thing about bodily fluids. Hey, when Im wrong, I admit it.

title: Pondering Their Losses During Wait for Winner
description: The postponement of the United States Open mens final until Monday was already costing many people money.

title: Imam Talks Compromise on Islamic Center
description: The imam working on the planned Muslim community center near ground zero said Monday he was open to all options to resolve the fierce dispute surrounding it, while possibly provoking the projects opponents by declaring that the site, two blocks from the former World Trade Center, was not hallowed ground.

title: Rockies Seem to Save Best for Last
description: DENVER

title: Drug List Appeal Is Again Rejected
description: An appeals court ruled Monday that federal prosecutors illegally seized drug testing information for more than 100 baseball players who tested positive for steroids in 2003. The United States Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled, 9-2, that the authorities could not keep the tests.

title: Cubas Public-Sector Layoffs Signal Major Shift
description: MEXICO CITY  In perhaps the clearest sign yet that economic change is gathering pace in Cuba, the government plans to lay off more than half a million people from the public sector in the expectation that they will move into private businesses, Cubas labor federation said Monday.

title: Biden, the Go-To Democrat
description: As a former senator, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is intimately familiar with the Senate expression that there are show horses and workhorses. When it comes to the 2010 campaign season, Mr. Biden is definitely a workhorse.

title: The Swat Valley, After the Flood

title: France: Replacement Directive Omits Word Roma
description: Following revelations that French officials had been ordered to specifically single out ethnic Roma in an continuing security campaign, Interior Minister Brice Hortefeux on Monday signed a replacement directive in which the word Roma does not appear. The ministry gave no explanation for the change, but humanitarian groups and opposition politicians had denounced prior Interior Ministry documents, made public last weekend, as racist and potentially illegal. Amid international outcry, Immigration Minister ric Besson, above, had made repeated assurances that no French measures had been aimed specifically at the Roma. On Monday, Mr. Besson said he had not been aware of the Interior Ministry order to the contrary. In August, the French government began publicizing the destruction of illegal Roma camps and the ensuing deportations.

title: Powerful Union Supports Bid to Legalize Marijuana

title: Swisher Seeks an Answer for His Injury

On the same day Brett Gardner received a dose of good news  a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed only inflammation in his right wrist and nothing structurally wrong  the Yankees made plans to send Nick Swisher into an M.R.I. tube on Tuesday to learn why the bone bruise on his left knee has not gotten better.

title: Britain: Smuggling Accusations Prompt Investigation

The accusations are said by the BBC to have originated with Afghans working for the British military. The extra procedures include the increased use of drug-sniffing dogs at the principal airfields used by aircraft that carry troops, equipment and casualties to Britain from Afghanistan, the officials said. We are aware of these allegations, a Defense Ministry spokeswoman said. Although they are unsubstantiated, we take any such reports very seriously.

The lawyer, Masoud Shafie, was quoted as saying that Swiss officials, who represent American interests in Iran, were making the plea for officials to reduce the bail for the hiker, Sarah E. Shourd. title: More High School Students Than Ever Took the SAT Last Spring
description: The number of graduating high school students who took the SAT climbed to 1.55 million last spring, a record figure that represents an increase of 1.2 percent, or nearly 18,000, over 2009, the College Board said Monday. The board, the nonprofit organization that oversees the college entrance exam, emphasized the impact of a rigorous high school curriculum on student performance. It said students who took four years of English and three or more years of math and science scored, on average, 151 points above those who did not. (A perfect score on the three-part exam is 2400.) But the National Center for Fair & Open Testing, a critic of the SAT, noted a decline in overall scores since 2006, when the federal No Child Left Behind testing mandates went into effect. When those figures are aggregated by race or ethnicity, the average scores of Asian-Americans climbed 36 points over that period, according to the Fair Test analysis, while those of black and Puerto Rican students fell 14 points, and those of white students decreased by 2 points.

title: Louisiana: Work on Well Resumes
description: BP said Monday that it resumed drilling of a relief well that is intended to put the final plug in its stricken well in the Gulf of Mexico. The company said that the crew of the Development Driller III rig began drilling again after technicians installed a device called a lockdown sleeve at the top of the stricken well on the seabed. The sleeve will keep a seal in place, preventing further leakage of oil and gas, if pressure inside the well increases during the final plugging operation. No appreciable amount of oil or gas has leaked for nearly two months. Company officials have said it will take about four days for the relief well to intercept the stricken well. After that, the final plugging operation, which will involve pumping mud and cement into the stricken well, should take about a week.

title: Letter: Can Preschoolers Be Depressed?
description: As a nutritionally minded health care provider, I believe Pamela Pauls story (Aug. 29) on preschool depression was incomplete. I am amazed at how little attention nutrition receives in the clinical setting and at what a tremendous disconnect there is between what we know and what is practiced. There are now dozens of studies in the medical literature showing how deficits in specific nutrients such as essential fatty acids (omega-3 fats) contribute to depression, attention-deficit disorders, bipolar disorder and impaired cognitive development. Many mental-health experts do not properly understand or acknowledge the key role nutrition plays in brain functioning, especially regarding the developing brains of children. Until we realize that it is impossible for a brain to function properly when it is starved of essential nutrients largely absent from our Western, packaged diets, our mental-health treatments will remain incomplete.

title: Stijl Standing
description: In 1927, Mies van der Rohe designed the innovative concrete-and-steel Weissenhof apartments in Stuttgart, Germany, which would become a landmark of International-style architecture; that same year, Gerrit Rietveld built the so-called chauffeurs house (above), a little-known but remarkably similar building in his hometown of Utrecht, the Netherlands, which leaked and had to be redone shortly thereafter. Trained as a cabinetmaker, Rietveld  an early member of the de Stijl movement known for his Red-Blue Chair and Schrder House  suffered many such disappointments in a career of more than 45 years. But a new retrospective at Utrechts Centraal Museum illustrates how his groundbreaking ideas had a much broader impact than is generally acknowledged. In Holland you have this feeling that maybe he was a genius but he wasnt a good architect, says Ida van Zijl, the curator of Rietvelds Universe, which opens Oct. 20 as part of the Netherlands Rietveld Year. People dont realize how many works he made and how experimental they were. The exhibition puts his furniture and architecture on an international scale, comparing it with Marcel Breuer, Le Corbusier and van der Rohe as well as showing its influence on contemporary designers. In a room dedicated to the Red-Blue Chair, the real thing will sit alongside a video of Maarten Baass charred homage.

Counter Culture
description: This week, the hottest thing cooking at the Museum of Modern Art will be Counter Space: Design and the Modern Kitchen. The show, which opens Wednesday and runs through March 14, 2011, explores the 20th-century evolution of this pivotal room and its ongoing redesign as a barometer of a changing society. Drawn entirely from MoMAs own collections, Counter Space comprises more than 300 works, including design objects, architectural plans, posters, photographs, archival films (including one that shows the motion-study pioneers Frank B. and Lillian M. Gilbreth, of Cheaper by the Dozen fame, and nine of their children), prints, painting and media works. Included are an image of a 1931 kitchen, designed by Lilly Reich, that looks as if it had been completed yesterday, and a tape of the famous 1959 kitchen debate between Richard Nixon and Nikita Krushchev. The exhibition also explores the role of the kitchen in feminist critiques and art movements like Surrealism, Pop Art and Fluxus.

title: Japanese Awards Honor Loren and Pollini

The awards, which recognize lifetime achievement in areas of the arts not covered by the Nobel prizes, come with a cash prize of roughly $169,000. The other winners this year are the Italian painter Enrico Castellani and the Japanese architect Toyo Ito. The association also named the Asian Youth Orchestra as the winner of its annual Grant for Young Artists award, which comes with approximately $56,000. The Praemium Imperiale awards were created in 1988 to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Japan Art Association and to honor its longtime honorary patron, Prince Takamatsu, who died in 1987. The awards will be bestowed in a ceremony in Tokyo on Oct. 13.

title: The Real Balabustas of Tel Aviv
description: Its not only men who are fanning the flames of Tel Avivs hot dining scene. Recently female chefs have started taking over the citys normally testosterone-fueled kitchens and bakeries. (There are at least three new cupcake shops owned by the ladies.) Tamar Cohen-Tzedek opened Cucina Tamar (HaTsfira 10; 011-972-3-639-0407; entrees about $17 to $26) two years ago, and its now one of the top Italian spots in town. When I decided to open a restaurant, I didnt think, Oh, Im doing this in a mans world, she says. I just did it. So did Einav Berman, who turns out plates like tomato tarte Tatin at her new restaurant, Asif (Lilienblum 18; 011-972-3-516-5198; entrees $16 to $31). At her home kitchen in the Florentin quarter, the American transplant Rima Olvera (above) cooks up a dinner feast for 14 guests every month ($125). And at Joz ve Loz (Yehuda HaLevi 51; 011-972-3-560-6385; entrees $10 to $22), Niva Eshed heads a team of four women chefs (plus one guy) who serve Mediterranean fare like chicken liver ravioli with horseradish sour cream. The designers beauty dream team  Franois Nars, Redkens Guido Palau and Elisa Ferri for Creative Nail Design  didnt disappoint. (Not that they could have: Arnold mentioned there was a six-hour beauty test the night before.) We kept a few of the iconic things from the 70s, like no eyebrows  were bleaching all the brows, Nars said backstage. Then a dark, reddish-brownish matte lipstick, a little bit of shiny, peachy color on the cheeks to give them a healthy look and deep forest green on the eyes with Vaseline on top. A spring shade from Creative Nail called Perfectly Bare blended with mattifying top coat was applied to nails to blank them out, according to Arnold, mimicking the treatment of the brows. Toes, however, were painted a dark red. Marc wanted deep, dark, shiny berry toes, Arnoldsaid. When he saw Bloodline, he was like, Thats it! Models were given one of four side-parted, texturized hairstyles ranging from Marcel waves to major Biba-esque frizz, depending on their natural hair type. Marc hates hair extensions, Palausaid. We wanted to capture that period, the decadent loucheness of the 70s supermodels. You know, that kind of woman who reeks of perfume. Ah, but would it be Daisy, Lola or even Bang?

title: Arctic Sea Ice Continues Its Summer Slide
A Modest Plan to Save the Tigers
description: Most of the estimated 3,500 tigers that still roam the wild live in 42 relatively contained enclaves in India, Sumatra and Far Eastern Russia, with a smattering in Malaysia, Thailand and Laos. But those so-called source sites are losing ground to development, forestry and poaching and must be protected to save the tigers from extinction, according to a new paper from a group of conservationists, academics and government officials.

title: Deciding Not to Screen for Down Syndrome
description: Amy Julia Becker is expecting her third child in January. She is 32 years old, and her age, plus the fact that her first child was born with Down syndrome, magnifies her odds of a chromosomal abnormality in this pregnancy, leading her doctors to suggest prenatal testing. In spite of the odds  or perhaps because of them  and her husband have declined the tests. In a guest post today, she explains why.

title: A Smorgasbord at a Delancey Street Shop
description: This homey little storefronts name, Fisk, means fish in Swedish. Thats almost all you need to know. Annika Sundvik, above, who owns it with her husband, John Lavelle, sells all sorts of fish and seafood, fresh and cured, and almost all in Scandinavian style. Tiny smoked Norwegian shrimp, homemade gravlax, peppered mackerel, smoked herring, pickled baby octopus and several roes, including lumpfish, wasabi and seaweed, are listed on a blackboard, along with fresh seafood like cod and lobster. Some cheeses, including Vasterbotten; produce like potatoes, beets, cabbage and onions; and pantry products, like lingonberry cordials and packaged flatbreads, are also sold. The couple, who own White Slab Palace, a restaurant and bar next door, are gradually adding prepared foods, like smorrebrod (open-faced sandwiches).

title: Ketchup With a Pedigree

It comes in a squat jar from which the ketchup can be easily spooned, and though it delivers spice and sweetness in moderation, like Heinz, it is much thicker and has a lustier tomato taste. The spicy version is ruddier and hotter. Brown sugar, agave nectar and honey are the sweeteners.

title: Growing Up in a Hush, With the Ultimate Identity Crisis
description: The limits of beauty or, more rightly, the uses of visual beauty are revealed in the adaptation of Kazuo Ishiguros highly regarded dystopian novel Never Let Me Go. Directed by Mark Romanek, this coming-of-age story involves three British friends who are raised with others of their kind in a group home that proves more Orwellian than Dickensian. In time, they timidly make their way into the world, which turns out to be crueler than most of us would, I suspect, like to believe. Though here cruelty is done so prettily and with such caution that the sting remains light, giving the entire enterprise the aspect of a tasteful shocker.

title: Met Opera Plans a Baroque Pastiche
description: They called it a pasticcio  pastry  a mishmash of arias by different composers, sometimes given new texts and often chosen by the singers. The practice of throwing together an opera from snippets, also called a pastiche opera, was standard operating procedure from the late-17th to late-18th centuries: a practice unthinkable in our age of textual authenticity.

title: A Pay Model for Essays Taken From Itunes
description: If a song on iTunes sells for 99 cents, how about a literary essay? On Tuesday, Scribner began publishing 69 essays by Chuck Klosterman, the pop culture and sports writer, available individually from retailers like Amazon, Apple and BN.com for 99 cents each. Nearly all the essays, which include Fargo Rock City, for Real and All I Know Is What I Read in the Papers, have appeared in print books before. But Scribner is hoping that people who have become accustomed to buying songs individually might do the same for stand-alone literary works. It will also publish digital collections of Mr. Klostermans essays  Chuck Klosterman on Rock and Chuck Klosterman on Sports, for instance  for $7.99 each.

title: David Foster Wallace Archive Is Opened
description: Fans and researchers now have the chance to page through the papers of the novelist David Foster Wallace, below. The Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas, Austin, which acquired manuscripts of his books, stories and essays in March, officially opened the archive on Tuesday. It includes material from Wallaces own library, including marked-up copies of novels by Don DeLillo and others. Wallace, whose 1996 book, Infinite Jest, won widespread acclaim, committed suicide in 2008 at 46. A posthumous novel called The Pale King is expected out next year.

title: Cirque Du Soleil Plans To Play Radio City
description: To the extent that whimsical Canadian clowns can be described as sober people, a chastened Cirque du Soleil disclosed the details on Tuesday of a new show it plans to bring to Radio City Music Hall next summer. The announcement follows the commercial failure of another Cirque show (Banana Shpeel) this year at the Beacon Theater, which was supposed to be the Montreal-based companys beachhead in a wider expansion into New York. The Radio City show, which does not yet have a title, will be a $50 million production that returns to the time-tested Cirque brand of acrobatic spectacle, like Wintuk, above. It will employ a cast of more than 70 and be directed by the filmmaker Franois Girard (Thirty Two Short Films About Glenn Gould; Silk). The creators hope the show will run for at least four months, starting in June, and return annually for four years. There is only one way to succeed in New York, by becoming a citizen of New York City, Daniel Lamarre, the chief executive of Cirque du Soleil, said in a telephone interview. We have to earn our citizenship. Cirque described the show as taking place in an abandoned theater where a magician has lost his love and with her, his magic has disappeared. Seeking her return, the magician is plunged into a world inhabited by surreal creatures.

title: Exhibition of Haitian Art
description: An exhibition of Haitian painting, sculpture and works on paper  including Salnave Philippe-Augustes Birds and Flowers, a detail of which is shown above  will be on view at Affirmation Arts at 523 West 37th Street in Manhattan from Oct. 1 to Nov. 24, the gallery said on Tuesday. The exhibition, Saving Grace: A Celebration of Haitian Art, is being organized by a historian of Haitian art, Grald Alexis, and will feature works from the Nader Gallery in Port-au-Prince, as well as others being lent by artists and private collectors in Haiti, Canada and the United States. Many of the best-known artists of the Haitian Renaissance, including Hector Hyppolite, Clestin Faustin, Wilson Bigaud and Prfte Duffaut, will be represented. The Nader Gallery survived the earthquake that devastated Haiti in January, but a private museum owned by the same family, and which housed some 12,000 works of art, was destroyed. Two paintings included in the exhibition, Hyppolites Pot de Fleurs and Faustins Beau Rve, were pulled from the wreckage and restored by art conservators working in a lab set up in Port-au-Prince by the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Japanese Honors for Sophia Loren
description: Sophia Loren, below, the pianist Maurizio Pollini and the sculptor Rebecca Horn are among the five winners of the 2010 Praemium Imperiale arts awards, the Japan Art Association said on Tuesday. The awards, which recognize lifetime achievement in areas of the arts not covered by the Nobel Prizes, come with a cash prize of roughly $169,000 each. The other winners this year are the Italian painter Enrico Castellani and the Japanese architect Toyo Ito. The association also named the Asian Youth Orchestra as the winner of its annual Grant for Young Artists award, which comes with approximately $56,000. The awards will be bestowed in a ceremony in Tokyo on Oct. 13.

title: CBS Takes Monday
description: Reruns on CBS topped network television ratings on Monday night, outperforming ABCs finale of Bachelor Pad. According to Nielsens estimates, CBSs comedies Two and a Half Men and The Big Bang Theory were once again the highest-rated shows in prime time, earning an average of more than eight million viewers in the 9 p.m. hour. ABC and NBC finished in a virtual tie for second place on the night. Although ABCs two-hour conclusion of Bachelor Pad (5.8 million) edged ahead of NBCs rerun of Americas Got Talent from 8 to 10 (5.4 million), ABCs Dating the Dark (3.5 million) trailed NBCs Dateline (4.4 million) at 10. Fox was fourth. On Sunday the MTV Video Music Awards drew an average of 11.4 million viewers, more than any other cable broadcast this year.

title: Regents to End Injunction on Museum Art Sales
description: In a surprise development in the battle over whether museums should be allowed to sell art to cover operating costs, the New York State Board of Regents on Tuesday approved the expiration of emergency regulations regarding such deaccessioning on Oct. 8. Those rules, which enjoined such sales, have been in effect since 2008. After hearing views from museums statewide, there was no consensus on the efficacy of those emergency regulations, David Steiner, the states education commissioner, said in a statement. Thus, those regulations will be allowed to expire, allowing the prior regulations regarding museum collections to once again take effect. Last month the board indicated it planned to make the emergency regulations permanent, in part because a bill addressing the issue had stalled in the Legislature. This removes a substantial obstacle to the monetization of art held in the public trust and to the transfer of art from public hands to private hands, said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, who led the drafting of the bill.

title: Ratify the New Start Treaty
description: After 21 Senate hearings and briefings, the Foreign Relations Committee is scheduled to vote on Thursday on the New Start treaty. The first nuclear arms control agreement with the Russians in nearly a decade, it calls for both sides to reduce their deployed warheads modestly to 1,550 from 2,200. The treaty also will ensure that each country has continued insight into the others arsenal, with inspections and exchanges of information.

title: Fishing at the Base of the Pyramid
description: Perhaps the most abundant remaining source of wild protein on the planet is krill, a tiny crustacean that lives in Antarctic waters. It is fed upon by nearly every Antarctic species, including whales, penguins, seals and many kinds of fish. The species with the greatest appetite for protein is humans. That harvest has now increased enough to start worrying ecologists.

title: With That Guy as ...
description: By scanning earths television broadcasts long after we are gone, other civilizations will be able to make certain judgments about human society. How among untold billions of lives, a few were deemed worthy of repeated and copious observation. Milton Berle, Mary Tyler Moore, Ted Danson, Oprah Winfrey, Simon Cowell: Truly these were giants of the species.

title: Russia: Fire Destroys Church Near Ravine Where Remains of a Czar Were Found
description: The main church at a monastery near the site where the remains of Czar Nicholas II and his family were dumped was destroyed in a fire on Tuesday. Officials said they had not determined the cause of the fire at the wood church at Ganina Yama, on the outskirts of Yekaterinburg, a city in the foothills of the Ural Mountains, where the familys remains were found in a ravine in 1979. The monastery, which consists of seven churches, draws people from around the world who come to pay homage to the czar and his family.

title: Vermont: Missionaries Aide Extradited in Smuggling Case
description: A former adviser to the American missionaries who were detained for attempting to remove children from Haiti after the earthquake there was extradited from the Dominican Republic to the United States this week, officials said. Jorge Puello, 32, faces charges in Vermont of smuggling migrants from Canada to the United States. He has also been accused in El Salvador of running a prostitution ring. Mr. Puello portrayed himself as a lawyer but was later discovered to be an international fugitive.

title: Britain: Scotland Yard Renews Phone Inquiry
description: A lawyer for Sean Hoare, a former News of the World reporter who has said he was involved in a phone hacking scandal, said that Mr. Hoare had been questioned by detectives about whether Andy Coulson, the newspapers editor at the time, had asked him to hack phones. Mr. Coulson, now the communications director for Prime Minister David Cameron, has denied knowing anything about the hacking. After several former employees said in an article in The New York Times Magazine that phone hacking had been widespread under Mr. Coulson, Scotland Yard said it might reopen an investigation. Mr. Hoare appeared to be the first person to have been questioned in the new inquiry.

title: Unthinkable Has Occurred: Jets and Giants Dont Sell Out

title: Gonzalez, the Rockies Rising Star, Is at Home in Denver

It underscored just how anonymous Gonzalez still is, chasing a playoff berth and a Most Valuable Player award  and even, perhaps, a Triple Crown  while cheerfully hawking tacos on Rocky Mountain cable.

title: France: Senate Passes Bill on Facial Veils
description: The French Senate on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a bill barring women from wearing the full facial veil anywhere in public. If the law is approved by Frances constitutional council, it will go into effect next spring and set a range of fines for women, including tourists, who wear the full veil. It also provides criminal penalties for those who force women to wear it. The vote was 246 to 1, with many abstentions from left-wing legislators; the bill passed the lower house in July.

They had something in common with a look that is familiar to millions of women, the gray corporate suit worn over a pink blouse, but these seemed to be distant descendants. They looked like more modern and liberated cousins.

Walt Spanglers elaborate set is dominated by an impressive wooden structure suggesting the expansive reach of an old tree. On the platform provided by one of the sturdier branches, two excellent musicians supply bluegrass music, evocatively used to add emotional coloring to various scenes. Live music is a rare and appealing luxury at a modest Off Broadway production like this.

title: Phys Ed: Can Exercise Make Kids Smarter?

The researchers were hoping to learn more about how fitness affects the immature human brain. Animal studies had already established that, when given access to running wheels, baby rodents bulked up their brains, enlarging certain areas and subsequently outperforming sedentary pups on rodent intelligence tests. But studies of the effect of exercise on the actual shape and function of childrens brains had not yet been tried.

title: Voters Deliver a Reminder to Republicans (and Pundits)

Nevertheless, we try to be pretty careful. For instance, we had assigned a 25 percent likelihood that Joe Miller would defeat the Republican incumbent, Lisa Murkowski, in Alaska, as happened. We had also assigned small likelihoods to a number of other outcomes that did not come tofruition, like J.D. Hayworth ousting John McCain in Arizona (Mr. McCain won by 24 points) or Chet D. Traylor unseating David Vitter in Louisiana (Mr. Vitter won by 81).

But well cut him some slack: by correctly identifying the title of that Pierre Boulle novel turned David Lean film, Mr. Craig, a 33-year-old graduate student at the University of Delaware, set a new one-day earnings record on Jeopardy!, winning $77,000 at the end of Tuesdays broadcast, The Associated Press reported.

title: Iraqi-U.S. Raid Near Falluja Leaves 7 Dead

title: Kensal Rising
description: Londons bohemian vanguard has found a new home base in the twin neighborhoods of Kensal Rise and Kensal Green. The traditionally Portuguese district of Victorian row houses north of Notting Hill is home to buzzy gastropubs and incognito celebrities  Sophie Dahl and Jade Jagger live here  and the rents are still cheap enough that pioneering shop owners are hanging out shingles on Chamberlayne Road. Victoria Brotherson, the florist behind Scarlet and Violet (76 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-969-9446), sells vintage cut-crystal vases and chipped enamel pitchers alongside English blooms like cornflower and nigella. I thought I was just going to have a little workshop, she says. I was taken by surprise that we were that busy. In her wake, two vintage furniture stores, Howie & Belle (52 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-964-4553) and Circus Antiques (60 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-968-8244), have opened among the bookies offices down the street. And a 10-minute walk away in Kensal Green, Retrouvius (2A Ravensworth Road; 011-44-208-960-6060)is the brainchild of the designers Adam Hills and Maria Speake, a space stocked with repurposed architectural salvage. Theres quirky drinking and dining, too: besides the Chamberlayne Pub and Steakhouse (83 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-960-4311) and the wine bar Miros (75 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-203-235-0003), the gastropub Paradise by Way of Kensal Green (19 Kilburn Lane; 011-44-208-969-0098) serves seasonal and organic dishes and a beloved sticky toffee pudding. It doubles as a lounge and performance space that may hide in its warren of rooms a burlesque show, a wedding or even the singer Lily Allen.

Thanks to the Stuffy photo submission system, The Times can run these requests for user photos on a regular basis, and I generally remain unaware of them. In this case, though, my colleague and I were testing out a general traffic monitoring screen were calling the big board. At that moment, a web producer placed a Flash promo in the center well of the NYTimes.com home page. The promo pulled a data file directly from our application servers instead of using a static version saved to the Content Delivery Network.

title: Touring Act
description: Sometimes forces beyond our control  rock bands, bloggers, fashion people  anoint a new epicenter of cool. Marfa, Tex., and Reykjavik, Iceland, had their moment, and now its Lisbons turn. The Walkmen named their latest album after the city. (J. Crew chimed in too, shooting a catalog there.) Hamilton Leithauser, the frontman, said the band traveled to Portugal while they wrote Lisbon: Everything just worked there. The rest of Europe doesnt work as well for us  our horn players quit in Germany. The results are 11 songs that range from explosive anthems (Angela Surf City) to lonely dirges (Stranded). Lisbon also marks the Walkmens debut on Fat Possum Records, based in Oxford, Miss., another drowsy town ripe for aesthetic reclamation any minute now.

title: Are You Hip to Hipmunk?
description: In 2003, I was at a book signing when a skinny 14-year-old boy came up to meet me. He was engaging and social, and said he was an amateur programmer and offered up his services as an assistant to writing my computer how-to books. I thought, Aww, what chutzpah for a ninth grader!  and forgot all about it.

description: More than a dozen families in Susquehanna County, Pa., filed a lawsuit late Tuesday against the Southwestern Energy Production Company, asserting that a succession of releases, spills and discharges of combustible gases, hazardous chemicals and industrial wastes from the companys nearby drilling sites had contaminated their drinking water and made them sick.

title: Band Name Costs New Pornographers a Gig in Michigan
description: When the members of the New Pornographers chose their band name, they probably took it for granted that most listeners would understand they produced bouncy guitar- and synthesizer-driven indie rock for a living, and nothing more salacious than that. But the joke did not play well at Calvin College in Grand Rapids, Mich., which has canceled a planned concert by the New Pornographers on the basis of the groups name, The Grand Rapids Press reported.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Say Delaware Upset Hurts Senate Hopes

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A clash between anti-American protesters and the Afghan police injured 35 police officers and 12 civilians here on Wednesday, as each side accused the other of indiscriminately firing shots.

description: The house of Bill Blass, after sitting out Fashion Week for a few seasons while its new owners retooled the business, introduced a small spring collection Wednesday morning by the designer Jeffrey Monteiro. On a stage in a black tent at Lincoln Center, Mr. Monteiros models wore a range of cocktail suits, graphically embroidered vests and a selection of red dresses, one of which was made of a loose knit.

title: Necklace Worn by Diana Goes on the Block
description: Lot 65 at an auction scheduled for Sept. 24 in New York  on the block just after a police motorcycle that trailed John F. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963, and just before Clark Gables medical bracelet  is a necklace that was worn once by the original owner. And also a pair of earrings that glimmer with diamonds and South Sea pearls.

title: Last Night in Delaware
description: For a decentralized, essentially leaderless movement (the best efforts of Dick Armey and Jim DeMint notwithstanding), the Tea Party has cut its swath through the Republican primary season with a great deal of strategic savvy. Beginning with Pat Toomey and continuing through Marco Rubio and Rand Paul, Sharron Angle and Joe Miller, the candidates propelled to victory by Tea Partier enthusiasm have often given the national Republican Party heartburn, but none of them have been clearly un-electable and if this fall is as good to the G.O.P. as its shaping up to be right now, most of them will probably end up winning. Whereas in those races where the rightwardmost candidate (to borrow William F. Buckleys phrase) couldnt possibly win a general election, the Tea Party hasnt gone all in: Thus Carly Fiorina rather than Chuck DeVore is the Republican nominee for the California Senate, John McCain rather than J.D. Hayworth is the nominee in Arizona, Mark Kirk is the nominee in Illinois, etc.

title: Asked & Answered | D.A. Pennebaker and Chris Hegedus
description: Best known for The War Room, the 1994 documentary that went inside Bill Clintons campaign hub in Little Rock, Ark., D.A. Pennebaker and Chris Hegedus have been co-directing since the mid-70s. Next year, their work will be the subject of a retrospective at the Museum of the Moving Image. Their latest production, The Kings of Pastry, makes its theatrical debut at Film Forum. Bon apptit. The movie takes viewers to Lyon, France, to follow the Alsatian pastry chef Jacquy Pfeiffer, the co-founder of Chicagos French Pastry School, as he vies for Frances most prestigious trade award, the M.O.F. (Meilleurs Ouvriers de France, or Best Craftsmen of France). Held every four years, the grueling competition is the artisanal equivalent of the Olympics  or rather, it makes Top Chef look like a slumber party. In a way, Hegedus says, television cooking shows have spoiled us for the possibilities of true drama in the kitchen.

title: Salvos Fly as Ethanol Ruling Nears

Coalitions have lined up  on one side, the corn farmers and ethanol producers, and on the other, the oil refiners, auto companies, manufacturers of gasoline-powered equipment and companies that use corn to raise livestock.

In 2009, she was an intern for The Associated Press in Berlin and Jerusalem. Her conversation with Amanda Rivkin has been edited and condensed.

title: Reggie Bushs Spin Move

Is it really possible to be the first person to give back a Heisman Trophy  just ahead of it being pried from your hands by the Heisman Trust after having obliterated N.C.A.A. rules  and paint yourself as a noble, selfless teammate and role model? Of course it is! If youre Reggie Bush.

title: The Nutsiness of Politics
description: Gail Collins: David, I am in Alaska, where people seem to be cheering Tuesday nights Tea Party triumphs in Delaware and New York. Well get to those in a moment. I wanted to mention first the subjects that are really on peoples minds here  the filming of a Drew Barrymore movie in Anchorage and the mass migration of the walruses to the shores of the northwest. The movie was drawn here by tax credits and has been accompanied by an explosion of beautiful young women in the downtown area. The walruses seem to be fleeing global warming. Everyone is enthusiastic about the migration of beautiful young women, but the attitude toward a mile-long stack of walruses along the coast is more mixed.

title: Paladino Promises a Relentless Attack Against Cuomo
description: BUFFALO  Fresh from having romped to a lopsided victory in the Republican primary for governor, Carl P. Paladino vowed Wednesday to attack Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo like General Patton, saying he would exploit Mr. Cuomos immaturity and his ego.

title: Ayotte Declared Winner in New Hampshire
description: 5:09 p.m. | Updated

title: W.T.O. Said to Find Improper Subsidies for Boeing

description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: Beer Garden Radar
description: It seems as if beer gardens are opening around every corner of New York. Now theres a iPhone app to make sure you dont miss that turn.

description: 1. Her Dockers Slim Fits Are On Fire: Tea Party scores upset in Delaware primary with Christine ODonnell, who told opponent, This is not a bake-off, get your man pants on.
