description: If you consider yourself an avid N.F.L. fan and lifes events somehow impaired your ability to closely track last Sundays opening day marathon, you may well suffer from L.C.S., or lame cellphone syndrome.

title: Eagles Handling of Head Injury Draws Spotlight
description: On Sunday afternoon, more than 28 million people were watching Foxs national broadcast when the Philadelphia Eagles Stewart Bradley rose woozily, stumbled and then collapsed onto the turf. The Fox announcers Joe Buck and Troy Aikman expressed concern and even horror. Players waved frantically for medical assistance.

title: When Autistic Children Become Adults
description: Today, one in 110 children is estimated to have some form of autism spectrum disorder. But back in 1943 there were a total of 12. That was when the first article about a condition unlike anything reported so far appeared in a medical journal. A boy named Donald T. was called Case 1  the first child given a diagnosis of autism.

title: A Baby Photo Becomes an Internet Meme
description: SOMETIME back in 2000, Allen S. Rout, a systems programmer from Gainesville, Fla., posted a few photos of his 5-month-old son, Stephen, on his personal Web site. They were the kind of photos that every parent takes, but one in particular stood out: Stephen wearing a pair of red overalls, smiling in a crib. Were really blessed, Mr. Rout wrote as the caption. Stephen is an amazingly happy baby.

title: Can You Run a Company From Jail?
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Brazen or Subtle, Mining the Past
description: NEW YORK has always been a knockoff kind of town, but to state that outright is to risk fashion heresy. Marc Jacobs, after all, has declared repeatedly that its fine  indeed modern  to sample the work of his predecessors, thereby giving implicit permission to rafts of his peers to pay homage to the past.

title: Russia and Norway Agree on Boundary
description: MOSCOW  Russia and Norway resolved a long-running boundary dispute in the Arctic Ocean on Wednesday that may help open a portion of the frozen sea to offshore oil and gas development.

title: Steve Martin Creates Steve Martin Bluegrass Prize
description: Hey, kids: Steve Martin wants to give you $50,000! Theres just one catch: youre going to have to get really good at bluegrass music first.

title: Man Is Accused of Sex Crimes Against 5 Women
description: Updated, 3:23 p.m. | A man claiming to be a French journalist whom prosecutors accused of preying on sophisticated women was charged Wednesday with various sexual crimes, including rape and forcing a woman to give him oral sex.

title: Lehman Sues Canadian Bank and Others for $3 Billion
description: Lehman Brothers, which filed for bankruptcy exactly two years ago, has sued Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and dozens of other defendants to recover more than $3 billion of which it said it was deprived because of the bankruptcy filing.

title: The Rise and Fall at New York Fashion Week
description: One thing we have learned so far from the New York spring runways is that waistlines are rising and hemlines falling, and heaven help those with stubby legs. To address the latter first: in nearly every collection (and certainly every strong collection) the preferred length is midcalf, with a welcome whiff of the 70s (Marc Jacobs), the 90s (Narciso Rodriguez) or whatever we call this decade (Rodarte). Its an elegant silhouette to be sure, and even made the color-blocked kids at Marc by Marc Jacobs look refreshingly polished and just plain new.

title: If Eagles Can Miss Concussion, What Hope Is There for Youth Players?
description: In the wake of the Eagles latest misstep involving a players concussion  sending linebacker Stewart Bradley back into Sundays game minutes after his injury after failing to diagnose him properly  The Timess Alan Schwarz asked a crucial question in a news analysis on Wednesday:

title: Geithner to Signal Tougher Stance on China Currency
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is moving to take a harder stance on the Chinese governments trade and currency policies, with anger toward China rising in both political parties ahead of midterm elections.

title: Cities With the Most Home Price Cuts
description: Updated | Sept. 15, 2010

title: Despite Struggles, Entrepreneurs Find Ways to Give Back
description: The economic slowdown that started in 2008 affected just about every aspect of Gumas Advertisings business  including the companys long-time support for charities in the San Francisco area. In good times, we did not have to scrutinize our charitable giving or employee perks, said John Gumas, the companys president. But in these economic times, weve really had to think through what we could afford to give and still be able to make a difference.

title: From the Roof, to a Battery, to the Grid
description: In the garage of Peter Rives San Francisco home is a battery pack. It is not connected to Mr. Rives electric Tesla Roadster sports car, but to the power grid.

title: No. 1 Planet for Alien Tourists
description: Earth (The Book) is a mock textbook by writers for The Daily Show With Jon Stewart  or the authors of the popular television program The John Daly Show, as they put it in a fake Wikipedia blurb on the books back cover. It is conceived as a handy guide for extraterrestrials who arrive on this planet after humanity has become extinct, in case those extraterrestrials want to know what theyre missing. It explains everyday details about how we live(d), from our use of the fork (a way to hurt food one last time before eating it) to our wearing of pants. We put these on one leg at a time, it says. You may require a different approach.

title: Its Demand, Stupid
description: Ive said this before, but Catherine Rampell has a very nice chart making the point: if you ask businesses  as opposed to their lobbyists  what their problem is, you find no hint of the stories the usual suspects are telling you about government interference, political uncertainty, etc.. Businesses arent hiring because of poor sales, period, end of story:

title: Citi Scoops Up UBS Energy Bankers
description: UBSs investment banking division has sustained a heavy blow as nearly its entire energy banking team in Houston has defected to Citigroup.

title: On the Road: Analyzing Citizen Science Reports on Roadkill
description: Overview | What can we learn from animals that have accidentally been killed as a result of human activity? In this lesson, students use a map to navigate local roads from the perspective of a common animal. Then they analyze geographic data collected from animals killed in motor vehicle collisions and propose ways to reduce them. They learn how to analyze the layers of data included in interactive maps, think critically about the data and apply what they have learned to suggesting ways to improve roadway safety for wildlife.

title: DeMint: We are Going to Win in Delaware
description: Senator Jim DeMint, who has been a champion of Tea Party candidates throughout the nation, said that Christine ODonnells victory in the Delaware Republican Senate primary was proof of a nationwide mobilization of voters in favor of smaller government and that the partys future hinged on embracing candidates like Ms. ODonnell and rejecting any moderates who might be willing to vote with Democrats.

title: Quick-Change Artist | Lindsey Wixson
description: The model Lindsey Wixson of Marilyn Model Management gets reinvented eight times.

title: Sara Bareilles Tops Billboard Chart
description: Sara Bareilles, whose single Love Song became a ubiquitous hit two years ago, reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week with her second release, Kaleidoscope Heart (Epic). Her new album sold 90,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, beating out Eminem, Katy Perry, Disturbed and several new releases. It was the best week of album sales in Ms. Bareilless career so far  her first release, Little Voice, peaked at No. 10 and has sold a total of 997,000 copies to date. But her album sales are still dwarfed by the success of Love Song, which has had 3.2 million digital downloads.

title: Reporting Abroad and Cotton Underwear
description: Mort Rosenblum is one of those legendary journalists who has been everywhere and done everything, mostly with gunfire in the background. So its fitting that he has just written a guidebook to global reporting  and the big problem is that there arent that many young journalists being dispatched to foreign capitals any more. Given the financial constraints, most news organizations (the Times is a major exception) prefer to cut back on overseas coverage.

title: A Triple Bill at City Ballet
description: The company opened a rare fall season on Tuesday.

title: Color Anxiety? Dont Bite Your Nails
description: SEATED near a colleague at Lincoln Center this week, I found myself glancing at her fingertips, which were lacquered in a brooding gray that made my own paler tint seem hopelessly wan. Overcome with the kind of envy only Fashion Week inspires, I ran off in pursuit of that gunmetal shade from Chanel, only to find that it had vanished, supplanted in stores by a range of new pigments  slightly creepy riffs on purple with evocative names like Paradoxal (Chanel), Belle de Nuit (YSL) and Marrow (Butter London).

title: The Valhalla Machine
description: THE Rhinemaiden descended by a cable to the floor of the Metropolitan Opera stage. She extended her body just in front of a hollow beneath part of the set for Wagners Rheingold. Slowly, inexorably, the edge of a 45-ton structure tilted down toward her.

title: Does Fashion Make Good Theater?
description: SHOULD the scramble to get into a fashion show bring to mind the desperate crowds clamoring to board the last choppers out of Saigon?

title: Have You Found Creative Ways to Give Back?
description: Weve just published a small-business guide to giving back even when your company is struggling. Written by Jim Witkin, it offers a variety of suggestions. During slow times, for example, Larry OToole (above), founder of Gentle Giant movers, has committed his people and vans to doing pro bono work. At the same time, hes also managed to develop some important business relationships.

title: In Midtown, Igloos Are Hot
description: THE temperature in Midtown hovered at 101 degrees on an airless day in August. Meanwhile, inside the Jade Igloo, a dome-shaped sauna at Juvenex, a Korean-style spa on West 32nd Street, the thermostat registered 174. The igloo, with its cavelike stone facade, can comfortably accommodate 15, but perhaps because of the mercury reading, on that particular early afternoon, it was hot only for me.

title: Boeing Plans to Fly Tourists to Space
description: Boeing said Wednesday that it was entering the space tourism business, an announcement that could bolster the Obama administrations efforts to transform the National Aeronautics and Space Administration into an agency that focuses less on building rockets and more on nurturing a commercial space industry.

title: Dominos to Customer: Mea Culpa
description: Dominos Pizza is known for delivering pizza. Now its delivering a pizza executive.

title: How I Saved My Company: Sea Lake Yacht Sales
description: Two years ago, Vince Morvillo, who owns Sea Lake Yacht Sales, a dealership in Houston, was hit by a one-two punch. First, Hurricane Ike, a Category 4 storm, struck Texas, doing terrible damage. At a time like that, said Mr. Morvillo, the thought of buying a yacht is pretty low on the priority list. And then came the recession.

title: Remembrances of the Enigmatic Froggy
description: My article about F. Gwynplaine MacIntyre that appeared in last Sundays Metropolitan section prompted a flood of e-mail from readers who related their own encounters with Mr. MacIntyre, also known as Froggy.

title: Shutters Aflutter at New York Fashion Week
description: The move to Lincoln Center seemed as good an occasion as any to discover whether the New York shows were, well, good shows.

title: Photos of the Moment | Rodarte
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

title: Finding Missing Music in iTunes
description: Q. I added some songs from a U.S.B. drive to my iTunes library the other day, but when I went to transfer the files to my iPod, iTunes showed an exclamation point next to the song titles and nothing transferred. Whats wrong?

title: Pattern and Degradation
description: A large solo exhibition by the artist Rob Pruitt fills 13,000 square feet of space at Gavin Browns Enterprise in the West Village and at a neighboring gallery, Maccarone.

title: XIX, the Hot New Bar in NoLIta
description: CANT get in? Well, then, it must be hot. That must explain why XIX, a new subterranean bar in NoLIta, tracked down Disco, the infamous doorman from Bungalow 8, to work its door. It was a bloodbath the other Thursday. Strapping tennis players from the United States Open? Nope. Three guys from Brooklyn? Not a chance. Rejects from the Kenmare up the block? Rejected again.

title: What Were Reading: The Economics of Being a Model
Election Results Bode Well for Change in Albany, Koch Says
description: Edward I. Koch has spent the past several months crisscrossing the state yelling, Throw the bums out! and branding state legislators enemies and heroes of government reform.

title: Rethinking Investments After a Flight to Security
description: SHAKEN by what seemed to be an earthquake in the worlds financial markets two years ago, millions of retirees fled to safety, shifting their holdings into savings accounts, Treasury bills, money market funds or certificates of deposit. Now they are suffering the aftershocks: with short-term interest rates well below 1 percent, their assets are not producing enough income for daily living expenses.

title: Thailand's Sin City Reaches for Respectability
description: If Las Vegas is Sin City, Pattaya is a bear hug from Lucifer himself. And yet, amid the back alleys jammed with bars, there are signs of change.

title: A Giants Concussions Begin to Add Up
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants have immediate concerns about how they will compensate for the loss of the versatile tight end Kevin Boss as he recovers from his third concussion since 2008. But the issue could resonate longer than this week.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: In southern Afghanistan, United States Marines took steps to ensure peaceful parliamentary elections on Saturday (Slides 1 and 2), while in Kabul, dozens were injured in anti-American protests widely believed to have been organized by candidates trying to gain political clout.

description: An event designer shopped for accessories that make the most of desserts.

description: A view of the day in sports, from the waves of Denmark to the outfield walls in Seattle.

description: From Floyd Norris at Notions on High and Low Finance:

title: A Night to Ring Up Some Good Will
description: STYLISH revelers may have flooded the stores and streets of New York on Sept. 10 for the second year of Fashions Night Out, but for most shops the evening was more about brand building than racking up sales.

title: But Can Their Moms Tell Them Apart?
description: THE two young men faced each other aggressively, as if about to fight. They thumped their chests, and grunted. Then their stares turned tender. They drew near, as if to kiss.

title: On the Colombian Coast, Natural Beauty, Gritty Charm
description: ITS not called the Parque de Los Novios  Park of the Newlyweds  for nothing. Young couples lock arms as they stroll past rows of freshly planted flowers. A Sinatra love ballad sung in Spanish echoes from a corner dive bar. Aside from a few mustachioed, sombrero-clad men playing a board game, it seemed as if everyone on this breezy August evening was on a romantic sabbatical.

title: Santa Marta is Ready for Tourists
description: The Colombian city is leaving its gritty past behind.

title: A Weekend in Rio de Janeiro
description: There will always be sunshine and Carnaval, but these days, Rio has a lot more to strut about.

title: A New Leader Brings Along Some Old Favorites
description: NEWARK  Music directors typically use their first official concert in the position to make a statement about their interests and programming ideas. When Jacques Lacombe opened the New Jersey Symphony Orchestras fall season at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here on Tuesday, this charismatic new conductor revealed his tastes with an affable smorgasbord of popular works and a new piece.

title: A Hesitancy to Restore Those 401(k) Matches
description: TWICE in the last decade  in 2002-3 and 2008-9  thousands of companies suspended or shrank their 401(k) matching contributions to save money during economic downturns.

description: Some observations from a first-time attendee at New York Fashion Week.

title: Susan Lehman Is Named Twelves New Publisher
description: Susan Lehman, a communications executive, editor and lawyer, has been chosen to replace Jonathan Karp as publisher and editor in chief of Twelve, a tiny, well-regarded imprint of Grand Central Publishing. Her appointment was announced Wednesday.

description: Photos from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.

description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Skye Parrott.

title: Sticking to One Tune, but Not Stuck
description: Winding down his first set at Cornelia Street Caf on Tuesday night, Jon Irabagon blew his tenor saxophone in blasts and gales, decelerating the tempo but hardly losing steam. Just under an hour earlier, he had lurched into a lesser-known standard, backed in spartan form by bass and drums. His set consisted solely of that single tune, which he subjected to the jazz equivalent of a brutal interrogation. The performance was trancelike, glowing with intellect, but the main impression it left was of pure physical expenditure.

title: Boot Camps for the Retired or Soon to Be
description: BY Saturday afternoon, Dorothy Butcher was calling herself Dorothy the Brave.

title: Is Walking Away from Your Mortgage Acceptable?
description: While there has been much debate about the ethics of walking away from a burdensome mortgage, the majority of Americans still believe such behavior is unacceptable, according to a report from Pew Research Center.

title: For the Fierce of Foot
description: DESIGNED by Raphael Young, the Jaws over-the-thigh-high boots ($1,975)are not for the shy or the diminutive. And it helps to have a partner to take them off. In Paris, where Mr. Young just opened a boutique, women wear these boots with a tunic or denim mini-shorts. Available at Seven New York boutique, 110 Mercer Street (Spring Street); (646) 654-0156. A Web site, raphaelyoung.com, is scheduled to go live on Oct. 1.

title: iPad Couture, At a Price
description: With New Yorks fall Fashion Week in full swing, its only natural that the well-dressed, iPad-toting clotheshorses seek out something special to protect their tablets from the touchy-feely hands and fingers of admirers.

title: Boutique Publisher Names New Chief
description: Susan Lehman, a communications executive, editor and lawyer, has been chosen to replace Jonathan Karp as publisher and editor in chief of Twelve, a tiny, well-regarded imprint of Grand Central Publishing. Her appointment was announced Wednesday.

title: Jewelry Born of Childs Play
description: DANNIJO jewelry is run by two sisters, Danielle and Jodie Snyder, who learned how to do wirework by playing with their fathers medical tools in Jacksonville, Fla. The line started in 2008 and is available online at Dannijo.com.

title: Fences Make Good Neighbors? This One Has Its Doubters
description: In her new documentary for HBO, The Fence, Rory Kennedy takes just over a half-hour to demonstrate that the border fence between the United States and Mexico is a political boondoggle that kills migrants but doesnt keep them out of the country.

title: Looking Hot When Its Cold
description: SNOWS up! Moncler, the Italian brand that makes puffy jackets chic, has a new flagship store in SoHo at 90 Prince Street (at Mercer Street); (646) 350-3620; moncler.com. Thom Browne, who collaborated on the Moncler Gamme Bleu line, translates the Alpine look to the city with a plaid hoodie jacket and a down-filled blazer (from $1,100, up to $9,000 for a beaver jacket).

title: Baubles and Bags to Customize
description: WENDY NICHOL, whose satchel bags and spiky jewelry are sold at chic stores like Colette, now has a store of her own in SoHo, at 147 Sullivan Street (Houston Street); (212) 431-4171; wendynicholnyc.com. The store has an on-site studio, where clients can customize designs and select pieces of leather.

title: An Operatic Persona, Cut Down to Size
description: Paulo Szot smolders. With his sultry bedroom eyes, pencil-line mustache and enigmatic half-smile, this Polish-Brazilian baritone is every inch the traditional Latin lover projecting the compressed heat of a boudoir bandit.

title: Proofiness
description: In my opinion the State Department, which is one of the most important government departments, is thoroughly infested with communists.

title: A Social Mash-Up During New York Fashion Week
description: The fashion show season seems to have brought back the social scene that was once a standard feature of Manhattan night life.

title: A Penitent Reflects on the Wilderness
description: Rob Pruitt  who last week opened a gargantuan solo exhibition inspired by the Amish tradition of Rumspringa, the period during which some teenagers sow wild oats before they reach the age to join the church  is not the first artist you might think of when you think Anabaptist. You might go way down the list before getting to Mr. Pruitt, 46, a gleefully tricky purveyor of trash culture who is known for making paintings of pandas and of Paris Hilton, who has fashioned an eternal-flame monument from a bar table and a Bic lighter, and who once held an extremely brief gallery show composed solely of a long floor mirror bisected by a line of real cocaine, which was ingested by visitors.

title: Leaps and Bounds of At-Home Season
description: A season seldom passes at New York City Ballet without Peter Martins, its ballet master in chief, seizing the chance to drink onstage to the health of someone or other. This has become one of the companys latter-day gimmicks.

title: In Reader Comments, a Lens Onto 9/11s Altered Meaning
description: As City Room live-blogged the 9/11 ceremony held near ground zero for victims relatives, the reader comments that poured in were, for the most part, moving and mournful, and tinged with hope. They were long on memories and condolences, and short on politics. Many were shiver-inducing in their poetry and gentle empathy.

title: High-Tech Wizardry at the Met
description: Images of rehearsals for the Metropolitan Operas new production of Wagners Ring cycle.

title: A City Gets Its Groove Back
description: IM a rock n roller, Nur Khan said recently, nervously spinning a Lazaro Diaz bracelet of black diamonds around his tattooed wrist. We all know what happened to New York, the promoter added, citing a well-rehearsed litany: AIDS, night-life crackdowns, bottles-and-models bars, the Crash and, then, the Slump. Rents went up and pushed out the artists, hedge-fund types came in and creativity died, Mr. Khan said. I swear to God, he added with Scarlett OHara fervor, Its my mission to bring it back.

title: Marchesa: The Red Carpet That Never Ends
description: At 3:30 p.m., the steps of the Chelsea Art Museum were cluttered with black-clad-clipboard-bearing publicists looking down on an obscene crowd of people who wanted to see the spring Marchesa collection.

title: Sara Bareilles Tops Billboard Chart
description: Sara Bareilles, whose single Love Song became a ubiquitous hit two years ago, reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week with her second release, Kaleidoscope Heart (Epic). Her new album sold 90,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was the best week of album sales for Ms. Bareilles, right, to date in her career; her first release, Little Voice, peaked at No. 10 and has sold a total of 997,000 copies. But her album sales are still dwarfed by the success of Love Song, which has had 3.2 million digital downloads. Eminems Recovery (Aftermath/Interscope) is No. 2 with 81,000 sales. With a 12-week total of 2.5 million sales, Recovery is gaining fast on Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) as the best selling album of the year. Also this week, Now Thats What I Call Music! Vol. 35 fell one spot to No. 3 with 63,000, Katy Perrys Teenage Dream (Capitol) is No. 4 with 59,000, and last weeks chart-topper, Disturbeds Asylum (Reprise), fell to No. 5 with 57,000. Among the contenders for the top spots next week: Linkin Park, Brandon Flowers of the Killers, Robert Plant and Weezer.

title: 'The Vanilla Ice Project'
description: The opening sequence of a new series on the DIY Network starring Robert Van Winkle, the rapper known as Vanilla Ice.

title: Gordon-Levitt Announces Plans for New Show
description: After Inception, weve come to expect a certain degree of inscrutability from all of Joseph Gordon-Levitts projects. But his latest venture may take the totemic cake. On Oct. 28 Mr. Gordon-Levitt, the (500) Days of Summer star who has been lately turning up at downtown Manhattan clubs to sing Lady Gaga covers, will bring the festivities to Town Hall in Midtown, where he and other artists will perform at Joseph Gordon-Levitt and the hitRECord.org Fall Formal. The event grew out of hitRECord.org, the Web site and production company where Mr. Gordon-Levitt invites Internet users to work with him on video and art ventures. Money raised by the show will finance more projects. The show will present some of his collectives short films accompanied by live narration and music, as well as traditional stage acts. Mr. Gordon-Levitt, above, said the show would absolutely feature performers from other film projects with which he is closely associated. Were not telling any secrets yet, he said. Well be dropping those little news cupcakes between now and Oct. 28.

title: Unfinished Wallace Novel Gets Cover and Release Date
description: Little, Brown & Company revealed the jacket art for The Pale King, an unfinished novel by David Foster Wallace that it will publish next year. In a news release the publisher said that the novel, with a cover designed by Mr. Wallaces widow, Karen Green, is set in an I.R.S. tax-return-processing center in Illinois in the mid-1980s, and tells the story of a crew of entry-level processors and their attempts to do their job in the face of soul-crushing tedium. Michael Pietsch, the publisher of Little, Brown and the novels editor, said in a statement that the book takes agonizing daily events like standing in lines, traffic jams, and horrific bus rides  things we all hate  and turns them into moments of laughter and understanding. The statement went on to say, Although David did not finish the novel, it is a surprisingly whole and satisfying reading experience that showcases his extraordinary imaginative talents and his mixing of comedy and deep sadness in scenes from daily life. Little, Brown plans to release The Pale King on  when else?  April 15.

title: Record Set On Jeopardy!
description: By correctly naming The Bridge on the River Kwai as the title of the David Lean film based on the similarly titled Pierre Boulle novel, Roger Craig, a 33-year-old graduate student, set a new one-day earnings record on Jeopardy!, winning $77,000 at the end of Tuesdays broadcast. Mr. Craig went into the Final Jeopardy round with $47,000 and wagered $30,000 in the category of Literary and Movie Title Objects. (The clue for which Mr. Craig provided the correct question was, The inspiration for this title object in a novel and a 1957 movie actually spanned the Mae Khlung River.) Mr. Craig and toppled the previous one-day winnings record of $75,000 set by Ken Jennings, who won the game show 74 times in 2004.

title: Steve Martin Creates Bluegrass Prize
description: Hey, kids: Steve Martin wants to give you $50,000! Theres just one catch: Youre going to have to be really good at bluegrass music. Mr. Martin, the actor, comedian and polymath, has established the Steve Martin Prize for Excellence in Banjo and Bluegrass. The award, which he described on Wednesday as a mini-MacArthur grant, will give $50,000 annually to an individual or group for outstanding accomplishment in the field of five-string banjo or bluegrass music. The award is intended to help performers pay for their instruments and raise awareness about the music. Sometimes when you mention money, Mr. Martin said, you automatically catch peoples ear. The award, which is determined by a board that includes Mr. Martin and musicians including Earl Scruggs, Pete Wernick, Tony Trischka and Bla Fleck, will be given in its inaugural year to Noam Pikelny, the banjo player for the band Punch Brothers.

title: West Side Story to Close Jan. 2
description: The producers of the Broadway revival of West Side Story said on Wednesday that the production would close at the Palace Theater on Sunday, Jan. 2, 2011, after 27 previews and 748 regular performances.

title: Redfords Film Is Picked Up
description: The Conspirator, Robert Redfords independently produced picture about the hanging of Mary Surratt after Abraham Lincolns assassination, has a home. Lionsgate and Roadside Attractions said they acquired rights to distribute the film in the United States. They plan to release it next spring. Mr. Redford, right, was among dozens of filmmakers who showed their films at the Toronto International Film Festival, which continues through Sunday. The Conspirator, which was financed by the American Film Company and had its debut with a gala presentation in Toronto, was among the higher-profile films to be acquired at the festival, as the deal-making picked up steam. Separately, the Weinstein Company said that it had acquired Submarine, a coming-of-age comedy from the first-time director Richard Ayoade.

title: Pakistanis Ask What a Lynching Means
description: The family of two teenage brothers who were beaten to death last month in Pakistan, after they were mistaken for criminals by an enraged mob, asked that a court-ordered post-mortem be delayed until a new medical expert can be appointed to the case, the Pakistani newspaper Dawn reported.

title: Talent Stays Strong as Season Starts
description: Americas Got Talent and the second season debut of Parenthood lifted NBC to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday. According to Nielsens estimates, 14.3 million viewers tuned in to that talent competition at 9 p.m., more than any other program during the night. At 10, NBCs Parenthood remained in the lead, earning a solid 7.7 million viewers and outperforming CBSs Fashions Night Out (3 million) and the ABC News special Final Witness (4.8 million). CBS placed second overall with repeats of NCIS (10.5 million) and NCIS: Los Angeles (8.2 million), while ABC broadcast back-to-back episodes of Wipeout (6.8 million). Fox was fourth with repeats of Glee (4.6 million), while CW, in fifth place, drew the networks most Tuesday-night viewers in a year, garnering 2.2 million for the eighth-season premiere of One Tree Hill and 1.7 million for Life Unexpected.

title: Detoured by 9/11 Attack, 4,000-Year-Old Tablets Make It Back to Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  The unlikely journey of 362 cuneiform clay tablets and plaques began in ancient Iraq as far back as 2030 B.C. title: Leaving the Land of a Thousand Hills

I leave the field with many research-type questions  more than when I entered. For example, how do we actually measure this complex activity known as water access in subsistence communities? I am also left wondering about the relationship between social inequality and environmental disparity, and the social impact that technological changes might bring about in these subsistence communities.

In an often nefarious business such as acting, someone who, as Jordan writes, showed up on time, knew his lines, worked cheap and always answered his phone should be revered, especially when he consciously took demeaning jobs (ridiculous game shows or poorly written serial dramas) because he knew he had to put food on the table for his family. Preventing malnutrition is the vastly preferred solution and is possible through strategies that include improving household feeding practices, increasing access to healthy affordable foods and strengthening health and sanitation services.

His announcement on Wednesday stole attention from a rally by a leading competitor in his own party, the former military dictator Ibrahim Babangida. title: Varnette Honeywood, Whose Art Appeared on Cosby Show, Dies at 59
description: Varnette P. Honeywood, an artist whose brilliantly colored collages, paintings and prints presented a warm, upbeat picture of black American life and whose paintings were prominently displayed in the living room of the Huxtable home on The Cosby Show, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. She was 59.

title: Jim Winner, Developer of the Club Antitheft Device, Dies at 81
description: Jim Winner, a businessman who developed and marketed the Club, the popular antiauto theft device, died Tuesday afternoon in an automobile accident in Clarion County in western Pennsylvania. He was 81 and lived in Hollywood, Fla., and Clark, Pa.

So while you ponder whats gotten into Cesc Fabregas and how the best player in the world can take one of the worst-looking penalty kicks youll ever see, lets take a look back at which teams look to be the ones to beat after their opening games in the group stage.

title: Support for Higher Tax on Wealthiest
description: Amid heated debate in Washington over the fate of the Bush-era tax cuts, there is strong support for the Obama administrations proposal to allow the tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans to expire at the end of the year. However, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll finds the public does not expect that to happen if the Republicans win control of Congress in November.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 10 through Sept. 14 with 990 adults throughout the United States, including 881 who said they were registered to vote.

title: News Quiz | September 16, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Ally, Once GMAC, Could Turn Profit for U.S. Taxpayers
description: Ally Financial, the recipient of more than $17 billion in American aid, may be able to repay its bailout in full with a profit for taxpayers if General Motors is right about the value of its stake in the auto lender, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Wall St. Critic to Run Consumer Agency
description: Elizabeth Warren, who conceived of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, will oversee its establishment as an assistant to President Obama, an official briefed on the decision said Wednesday evening, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: Japans Move on Yen Lacks Global Support
description: Japans decision to intervene in currency markets to weaken the yen and shore up its export-driven economy could be only the first step in a long battle  one made more difficult because Japan, unable to find support among its trading partners, must go it alone, Hiroko Tabuchi writes in The New York Times.

title: Online Woes Plague Chase for 2nd Day
description: Computer problems prevented millions of Chase customers from gaining access to their accounts over the banks Web site for a second day on Wednesday. Even after access was restored, complaints persisted as the rush of customers logging on to the site bogged down the companys computers, making service spotty.

title: S.E.C. Defends Exemptions in New Law
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is fighting attempts by some lawmakers to repeal a provision in a new law that gives the commission greater ability to block public disclosure of material it gathers from financial and investment firms, Edward Wyatt writes in The New York Times.

title: Columbias Endowment Posts 17% Return
description: Columbia University said on Wednesday that its endowment performed far better than some other large schools and better than the major stock market indexes in the latest year, posting a 17.3 percent return on its investments.

title: California: Higher Penalties proposed for Pipeline Violations
description: Federal penalties for safety violations along the nations pipelines would more than double under legislation proposed to Congress on Wednesday by Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood. He cited last weeks natural gas pipeline explosion that killed four people and destroyed dozens of homes south of San Francisco as well as recent pipeline failures in Michigan and Illinois in making his announcement. Under the proposed legislation, maximum fines for safety violations resulting in deaths, injuries or major environmental damages would increase to $2.5 million, from $1 million. The legislation would also finance an additional 40 federal safety inspection and enforcement personnel.

title: U.S. Adopts Tougher Stance on China
description: The Obama administration is moving to take a harder stance on the Chinese governments trade and currency policies, with anger toward China rising in both political parties ahead of midterm elections, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

I love that I have a $10,000 dress and a $40 shoe, says the 24-year-old.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking to expand its powers to demand more financial disclosure from cities, states and municipal-debt issuers, a commissioner with the S.E.C., Elisse Walter told The Wall Street Journal in an interview.

title: How Concerned Are You About Where Your Food Comes From?
description: There have been many articles in The Times recently about so-called factory farming and the controversial animal confinement and safety monitoring methods the farms employ. Major livestock producers argue that a direct link between these farms and human illnesses, like salmonella and E. coli, has not been proved, but many medical and health experts disagree. How much are you aware of news about food safety, like this summers egg recall? How important is this issue to you in general? Do you care about where your food comes from and the conditions under which it was produced? Why or why not?

title: In Britain, Pope Criticizes Response to Abuse Crisis
description: GLASGOW  Pope Benedict XVI arrived Thursday in Scotland, offering his strongest criticism yet of the Roman Catholic Churchs handling of the sexual abuse crisis. He said that church leaders had not been sufficiently vigilant or sufficiently swift and decisive in cracking down on abusers.

description: Actividades de Construccion y Servicios, the Spanish building company, is set to make an all-share takeover bid for its German counterpart Hochtief, in which it already owns a 30 percent stake, according to a statement on the Web site of the Madrid stock exchange, which suspended ACSs shares on Thursday.

Democrats were projected to control the governorships in an average of 19.5 states.

description: My most recent ShortCuts column discussing how often you need to change the oil in your car - and stating that the need to change your oil every 3,000 miles is largely a myth  elicited a great deal of reader response. description: As anyone living in the Midwest can tell you, gasoline prices have been mighty high in recent days. Since a pipeline operated by the Canadian company Enbridge ruptured last week outside of Chicago, the second such incident concerning an Enbridge pipeline in the Midwest this summer, prices at the pump have spurted up as much as 30 cents a gallon around much of the region.

title: Sondheim and Company Christen the Stephen Sondheim Theater
description: Im deeply embarrassed, Stephen Sondheim said Wednesday evening at a ceremony to officially light the marquee of the Broadway theater renamed in his honor. Thrilled, but deeply embarrassed.

Carolina Herrera Bez, the daughter of the designer Carolina Herrera, is doing exactly that as the creative adviser for CH Carolina Herrera, a casual lifestyle brand that is rolling out 18 boutiques this year. The first New York City boutique, which sells everything from silk dresses to cashmere travel blankets, opened earlier this month.

title: When Possessions Lead to Paralysis
description: David J. Ekerdt, who directs the gerontology center at the University of Kansas, has a knack for digging into aspects of aging that most of us register only in passing. Ive been a fan since I read his work on the busy ethic, a phrase he coined to describe our attitudes towards retirement.

title: The Early Word: Geithner and Schapiro on the Hill
description: Economy on the Hill: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner will tell House and Senate lawmakers today that China has kept the value of its currency, the renminbi, artificially low to help its exports and has largely failed to improve the situation, as it promised to do in June. The Timess Sewell Chan has the details.

description: Dashiell Hammett could have written this tale: a missing painting turns up on the street  or did it?  and a complicated case gets even weirder. The painting, Corots Portrait of a Girl, was reported lost, prompting all manner of accusations. But the doorman who found it in Manhattan said he had no idea what it was. William K. Rashbaum of The Times tries to unravel the mystery, but the story ends up prompting even more head-scratching questions. Did you ever watch The Maltese Falcon and at the end say, huh? Well, its kind of like that.

description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. title: Tech Talk Podcast: The Digital Life
description: On this weeks Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein chats with Nick Bilton, the lead writer for the Bits blog, about his just-published book, I Live in the Future and Heres How It Works. Mr. Bilton, formerly a researcher in the research and development labs of The New York Times, sees digital streams of information becoming increasingly personalized. People want not only content, he says, but also an online experience  and theyre willing to pay if the price is right.

title: U.S. to Sell G.M. Stake Over Time

title: MTV  Yes, MTV  Wants Your Financial Aid Ideas
description: As the stern proctor of the hardly hip SAT exam, the College Board would seem an odd recipient of prominent attention on MTV. It is difficult to imagine a scantily clad, lip-synching Katy Perry  to say nothing of Snooki or the Situation  rolling on a beach with a No. 2 pencil and a bubble sheet.

title: Thursday Reading: A Downside to Having Lots of Stuff
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: 36 Hours in Rio de Janeiro
description: WITH the World Cup coming in 2014, followed by the Olympic Games two years later, Rio de Janeiro is thinking outside the beach. The historic port area is undergoing an extreme makeover, and museums by such vanguard architects as Santiago Calatrava and Diller Scofidio + Renfro are in the works. A long-anticipated bullet train to So Paulo seems to be finally happening, while the city is making strides (albeit fitful ones) tackling the problems of its notorious favelas. Indeed, there will always be sunshine, thongs and Carnaval, but these days, Rio has a whole lot more to strut about.

title: Derek Jeters Emmy-Worthy Performance
description: As Ben Shpigel reported in Thursdays Times, Derek Jeter admitted he was acting Wednesday night when he pretended to be hit by a pitch in the Tampa Bay Rays 4-3 victory over the Yankees.

title: Twains Nicaragua, 144 Years Later
description: IT was June, the height of the Nicaraguan rainy season, and the sky was thick with clouds. Our small boat cut south through the wind-churned Pacific, rounding one bend, then another. The looming hills were green with shrubby trees and coastal grasses; where they met the water, layers of rock folded like cake frosting into the ocean. Soon a wide bay opened up and the surf-and-sand boomtown of San Juan del Sur came into view. Structures lined the beach in Jolly Rancher shades: apple green, lemon yellow, watermelon pink. At the bays northern edge, large houses climbed a steep hillside toward a towering statue of Jesus.

title: Limas Hidden Ateliers
description: WALK along Jr. Julio Victor Aguirre, a peaceful street in Lima, Peru, and youll pass a sky-blue home with white-trimmed windows that open out to catch fresh sea breezes. What you wont know until you step inside this 19th-century house is that it also is the atelier of a top Peruvian fashion designer  one of a number of old buildings in the city that have been turned into boutiques, with plenty of style inside but little splashy signage outside. And many are putting the spotlight on the designs of indigenous people.

description: BASICS

title: Buenos Aires: National Treasure in a Cone
description: IN Palermo, a residential neighborhood of Buenos Aires, an elegant specialty store called Persicco doles out a confection called chocuquinna. Inspired by a popular Argentine birthday cake, it has a sweet dulce de leche base balanced with hints of cream cheese and laced with chocolate chunks of what could be described as a cross between a crunchy cookie and a spongy cake. This version comes in a particular sort of serving dish  an ice cream cone.

title: Restaurant Review: Sorveteria Cairu in Belm, Brazil
description: Belm sits at the mouth of the Amazon River both literally (on the delta where millions of gallons pour into the Atlantic every second) and figuratively  it is the prime destination for travelers seeking out the regions bafflingly unfamiliar cuisine.

The boys wanted to move on from the last season, where the hair was kind of bed head, said Hanlon, who used Frederic Fekkai Coiff Oceanique Touseled Wave Spray to create an unfinished French twist with what can only be described as a rattail hanging out the back. I thought about when I was a kid on the school bus and a girl would fall asleep against a condensated window, and shed get off with her hair all mish-moshed up. The look paired perfectly with the minimal makeup by Kendal, which was simply cheek contour (M.A.C. Pro Sculpt Powders) and a strong, square brow. Were not even using any concealer, because we like natural discoloration around the eye, she said. The clothes this season are much more ladylike, so they wanted to keep their signature girl  very model-looking and tough. title: Seeing Things | Studio Visit: Pae White
description: I recently visited the artist Pae White in her Los Angeles studio, where she was busy working on a new exhibition for the Power Plant in Toronto. The exhibition, which opens on Oct. 9, will feature a number of her recent tapestry works as well as a new commissioned tapestry called Sea Beast. White has called the show Material Mutters because, she explained, its about the exploration of process and the material is doing the talking. Smoke has been a recurring motif in her work lately, and she has been exploring ways to capture its elusive qualities in various media, including a series of carved paper works that she was finishing for the Toronto show. Because smoke moves so rapidly and changes form so quickly, White likes the way the image of something so immaterial contrasts with the physicality of fabric. Its one material trying to understand another and it turns the fabric into something other than itself, she said. At the Whitney Museums Biennial this spring, her monumental digitally woven tapestry Still, Untitled was a showstopper.

title: City Opera Chairwoman To Resign
description: Susan L. Baker, a former Goldman Sachs executive who oversaw the ill-fated and short-lived hiring of Gerard Mortier as general manager of the New York City Opera, is stepping down as the companys chairwoman, City Opera said Thursday. Her place will be taken on Dec. 16 by Charles R. Wall, a former tobacco company lawyer who served on the board from 2001 to 2008. In a brief statement that came with the announcement Ms. Baker gave no reason. A City Opera spokesman said Ms. Baker was not immediately available to comment. Ms. Baker, who has held the job for seven years, will remain on the board. She championed the hiring of Mr. Mortier, an iconoclastic Belgian opera impresario who also served as artistic director, after meeting him at a dinner. He joined the company in February 2007 but worked out an agreement under which he would continue to serve in his previous job of running the Paris National Opera. Mr. Mortier pushed for the renovation of City Operas Lincoln Center home, now the David H. Koch Theater, which was closed for the 2008-9 season. The closing contributed to a financial nightmare for the company, which only last season began a modest comeback. In November 2008 Mr. Mortier quit even before formally taking over, saying the budget he was handed fell far short of what he was promised.

title: West Side Story Revival To Close
description: The producers of the Broadway revival of West Side Story said Wednesday that the production would close at the Palace Theater on Sunday, Jan. 2, after 27 previews and 748 regular performances. The show, directed by Arthur Laurents, who wrote the book for the original 1957 production, opened in March 2009 to mostly positive reviews. Though it recouped its $14 million investment, the production has struggled in recent months at the box office. Following West Side Story at the Palace Theater will be the new musical Priscilla Queen of the Desert, based on the 1994 movie about three Australian drag queens.

title: Sondheim And Company Christen Sondheim Theater
description: Im deeply embarrassed, Stephen Sondheim said Wednesday evening at a ceremony to officially light the marquee of the Broadway theater renamed in his honor (above). Thrilled, but deeply embarrassed. Mr. Sondheim, 80, the composer and lyricist of musicals including A Little Night Music, Into the Woods, Company and Sweeney Todd, was joined outside the soon-to-be-former Henry Millers Theater on West 43rd Street by his fellow Broadway luminaries Patti LuPone, Nathan Lane and John Weidman, as well as the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, and executives from the Roundabout Theater Company, which operates the theater. Addressing a crowd of Broadway industry veterans and fans of his work, Mr. Sondheim explained the source of his embarrassment. Partly because Ive always hated my last name, he said. It just doesnt sing. After his speech Mr. Sondheim pulled a switch at the front of the stage, and an illuminated version of his signature flickered and came to life (without a still-missing dot in the letter i that has apparently gone into one of Mrs. Lovetts pies).

title: The Beast Eyes Broadway
description: We dont remember things working out so well when they tried to fit King Kong onto a New York stage in that classic 1933 film. But circumstances might turn out better for Global Creatures, the Australian production company behind animatronic touring shows like Walking With Dinosaurs. It is aiming to bring a King Kong musical to Broadway as soon as 2013. Carmen Pavlovic, the chief executive of Global Creatures, said the project, which has been authorized by the estate of the King Kong co-director Merian C. Cooper, and whose creative team will include the director Daniel Kramer, the book writer Craig Lucas (Prelude to a Kiss) and the composer Marius de Vries (Baz Luhrmanns William Shakespeares Romeo + Juliet), will feature a robotic Kong (above) that can fit in the notoriously narrow wings of a Broadway theater. At heart the show will be a musical. King Kong doesnt suddenly grab a microphone and sing a song to Ann Darrow, I promise you, Ms. Pavlovic said. But if you think about the story and the character of Ann, and her background as a performer, and sailors on a ship, and Anns relationship with Kong, theres plenty of opportunities within the story itself, where music naturally fits.

title: Michael Jacksons Mother Sues Promoter Over His Death
description: Michael Jacksons mother has filed a lawsuit against the promoter of his planned concerts last year, saying that the company, AEG Live, failed to supply medical equipment or to monitor his personal doctor properly, Reuters reported. In her suit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court on Wednesday, Katherine Jackson seeks unspecified damages and says that the promoter is responsible for the actions and inactions of the doctor, Conrad Murray, and that it put its desire for massive profits over Jacksons health. AEGs representations to Jackson were false, the suit says, because in reality AEG was merely doing whatever it took to make sure that Michael Jackson could make it to rehearsals and shows, and AEG did not provide a doctor who was truly looking out for Jacksons well-being. A lawyer for AEG, Marvin S. Putnam, said in a statement that the lawsuit is inaccurate, unsubstantiated and meritless. On June 25, 2009, three weeks before he was to begin a series of 50 comeback shows in London, Jackson died from an overdose of powerful sedatives, and the Los Angeles medical examiner has ruled his death a homicide. Dr. Murray, who was not named in Katherine Jacksons suit, has pleaded not guilty to charges of involuntary manslaughter in the death.

title: Winfrey And Franzen Reconcile
description: It appears that Oprah Winfrey and Jonathan Franzen have kissed and made up. Nearly a decade after their public literary feud, Ms. Winfrey has selected Freedom, Mr. Franzens new best-selling novel, as her next book-club pick, according to booksellers who have seen early copies of the book. The selection is expected to be announced on Fridays Oprah broadcast. In 2001 Mr. Franzen offended Ms. Winfrey when he suggested in interviews that some of her book club picks were middlebrow, and that being chosen by a book club  as his novel The Corrections was  could turn off male readers. He apologized, but was promptly uninvited to appear on her television show. In an interview with The Star Tribune of Minneapolis-St. Paul last month, Mr. Franzen was asked about the prospect of Ms. Winfreys choosing Freedom for her next book club selection. I would be happy if she did, he said.

title: For Whom the Glass Is Always Half-Empty

The religiously efficient Hemingway didnt bother wasting his terse lyricism on descriptions of drinks, usually just listing the kinds and quantities instead. title: Separation Anxiety
description: Emma Donoghues remarkable new novel, Room, is built on two intense constraints: the limited point of view of the narrator, a 5-year-old boy named Jack; and the confines of Jacks physical world, an 11-by-11-foot room where he lives with his mother. We enter the book strongly planted within these restrictions. We know only what Jack knows, and the drama is immediate, as is our sense of disorientation over why these characters are in this place. Jack seems happily ensconced in a routine that is deeply secure, in a setting where he can see his mother all day, at any moment. She has created a structured, lively regimen for him, including exercise, singing and reading. The main objects in the room are given capital letters  Rug, Bed, Wall  a wonderful choice, because to Jack, they are named beings. In a world where the only other companion is his mother, Bed is his friend as much as anything else. Jack, in this way, is a heightened version of a regular kid, bringing boundless wonder and meaning to his every pursuit.

Which explains the mix of tomboyish cuts (long-john trousers) and girlie glamour (pleated leather skirts)  adorable and completely wearable wardrobe additions. We like.
