This minimalist indie with a title appropriate for a Judd Apatow comedy, is a smart seriocomic playlet with some emotionally harsh moments, although it refrains from plumbing its subject in agonizing depth.

title: Coming Out of Wall Streets Closet
description: Wall Street has never been particularly hospitable to outsiders.

title: Recession Creates an Opening for Democrat in Texas
description: HOUSTON  A few months ago, Texas political consultants thought that a Democrat had about as much chance of winning statewide office as a donkey would have of winning the Kentucky Derby. Those odds seemed to grow longer as the anti-tax, anti-government movement known as the Tea Party gathered more followers.

title: Jets Revis Is Slowed by Injury
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The name alone on the injury report surely gave Jets fan shivers on Thursday. There he was  under limited participation in practice  Darrelle Revis, the All-Pro cornerback, with a hamstring injury.

title: Learning to Swim in the Deep End of Lifes Pool
description: With his round, bulky middle and stubby limbs, his pink face and soft features, Jack (Philip Seymour Hoffman) resembles nothing so much as a giant baby. This impression is reinforced by his apparent inability to tackle some simple tasks of urban adult life.

title: Hedge Fund Managers Set Up for Next Acts
description: James J. Pallotta, a legend of the hedge fund industry, is calling a do-over.

title: Cartoonist in Hiding After Death Threats
description: A cartoonist in Seattle who promoted an Everybody Draw Mohammed Day last spring is now in hiding after her life was threatened by Islamic extremists.

title: Jewish Prayers Are Modernized in New Book
description: During the Jewish Days of Awe, culminating with Yom Kippur, many Conservative Jews will be turning the pages of a prayer book that no longer regards God as awesome.

title: Leaving an Agency Giant to Start a Boutique
description: FASHIONISTAS and fans of late-night television have Coco, and now Madison Avenue has Co  or, to be precise, Co:.

title: German Lawmaker Insults Polish Diplomat
description: BERLIN  A leading conservative German legislator insulted a distinguished Polish diplomat on Thursday, exposing tensions between two countries still trying to overcome centuries of mistrust and enmity.

title: Silence Follows Initial Concern for a Dazed Player
description: Immediately after the Philadelphia Eagles Stewart Bradley staggered to the Lincoln Financial Field turf while attempting to stand on Sunday, Fox provided the right replays and its announcers said all the right things. But Fox could have added more to the story.

title: Roma, on Move, Test Europes Open Borders
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  This city is full of stark, Soviet-era housing blocks, and the grimmest among them  gray towers of one-room apartments with communal bathrooms and no hot water  are given over to the Roma population.

title: Contemplating Life With Less Outdoor Smoking
description: Six people enjoying an afternoon in New Yorks Bryant Park discuss Mayor Bloombergs proposed ban on smoking at city beaches, parks and plazas.

title: Temporary Halt to Triple-Murder Trial Over Concerns on Defendants Health
description: NEW HAVEN  The judge at a triple-murder trial temporarily halted testimony on Thursday and sent the jury home for the weekend after defense lawyers reported that the defendant had had what appeared to be a seizure.

title: Republican Group Sees Big  Legislature Gains
description: Republicans, who seem to be pretty confident about the midterm elections on a congressional level, also are feeling pretty good about their prospects back in the states.

title: Security Concerns Loom Ahead of Afghan Vote
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans parliamentary elections on Saturday could determine whether a viable opposition remains in the legislature, but turnout  and the legitimacy of the second election in a year  hangs in the balance as voters fear waning security and brace for fraud.

title: F.D.A. Panel Urges Denial of Diet Drug
description: A federal advisory panel on Thursday recommended against approval of a new diet pill, the latest setback in efforts to develop treatments for the nations obesity epidemic.

title: Cuomo Takes Queries on Rival, but Doesnt Answer Them
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic candidate for New York governor, on Thursday made his first public appearance since Carl P. Paladino won the primary this week to become Mr. Cuomos Republican challenger.

title: How to Reduce the Trade Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: When Citizens (Gasp) Are the Smoking Police
description: Would you mind putting your cigarette out?

title: Tutors Made to Measure
description: On a summer afternoon, Isabel, a math tutor with long chestnut-colored hair and hoop earrings, sat in the lower-right corner of my computer screen as I wrestled with geometry problems. When I answered correctly, Isabel gave me a quick congratulatory smile. When I rushed, randomly guessing at perimeters of triangles and rectangles (geometry was never my favorite), Isabel, inferring from the speed of my keystrokes, wanted to know if I was bored. Was it because of the last problem? Did I want to choose the level of the next problem? I think that more important than getting the answer right, she said in words reminiscent of many a high-school teacher, is putting in the effort and that we can all be good in math if we try.

title: Dial-a-Class
description: For the past few years, Andreas Haralambou has performed the same ritual. Can I have a cellphone? he asks his dad. When youre older, his dad says.

title: Anytime, Anywhere
description: Karen Cator, director of the office of education technology at the U.S. Department of Education, says she thinks of online learning this way: If students have their own computer, it can travel with them from home to school. There can be software programs that help the student, or there can be an online teacher, but the technology can also augment a teacher in a face-to-face classroom.

title: Online Curiosity Killer
description: My older son , at 9, has spent 3.2 percent of his life on the Internet. I made that statistic up, though it sounds plausible. Whats certain is that he has spent at least three hours on the Internet, because I saw it with my own eyes, last spring, when third grade culminated with an assignment to research rain-forest animals. His animal was the anaconda, and the Internet assisted him in writing a highly factual report that touched on the snakes habitat (semiaquatic), prey (occasional goats and ponies) and size (freaking huge).

title: A Textbook Solution
description: The most complicated form in print media is the textbook, Josh Koppel of ScrollMotion explained to me. You have a 1,000-page math text with 10,000 more pages of homework assignments. Youve got the graphic side, the text side, notation, assessment, remediation. And we need to make this all live well digitally without being subtractive.

title: Hacks Into Hackers
description: Last spring, Nick Bilton, an adjunct professor at New York University (and a New York Times blogger), and his technology class stashed sensors all over their floor at the Tisch School of the Arts: on elevators, in hallways, outside bathrooms, in the lounge and in classrooms. They let the sensors collect data for about 36 hours and then rounded them back up.

title: Studying in Disguise
description: For a class in a doctoral program in psychology, we have been studying underserved and marginalized groups. For one project, our instructor required us to spend an afternoon walking in the shoes of a member of such a group  examples include a homeless person requesting money, an overweight person shopping for clothes, a same-sex couple visiting a wedding store. Is it ethical to falsely assume such an identity even for academic purposes? NAME WITHHELD, LOUISVILLE

title: Achieving Techno-Literacy
description: This past year my wife and I home-schooled our eighth-grade son. One school day, he and I decided we would make fire the old way  out of nothing but plant materials and our own hustle. Our son watched a seemingly endless series of instructional survival videos on YouTube as part of his research. He chose the bow method based on our physics class about friction. He then constructed a bow from a branch in the woods, carved a stick for the spindle and added a fiber string. It was mighty tough going. We spent hours refining the apparatus. He was surprised by the enormous amount of bodily energy required to focus onto a very small spot, and how a minuscule, nearly invisible bit of fuel, once sparked, can quickly amplify into a flame and then a fire. Chemistry, physics, history and gym all in one lesson. And, man, when you are 13 years old and Prometheus, its exhilarating!

title: The Pen That Never Forgets
description: In the spring, Cincia Dervishaj was struggling with a take-home math quiz. It was testing her knowledge of exponential notation  translating numbers like 3.87 x 10 into a regular form. Dervishaj is a 13-year-old student at St. Johns Lutheran School in Staten Island, and like many students grappling with exponents, she got confused about where to place the decimal point. I didnt get them at all, Dervishaj told me in June when I visited her math class, which was crowded with four-year-old Dell computers, plastic posters of geometry formulas and a big bowl of Lego bricks.

title: Does the Digital Classroom Enfeeble the Mind?
description: Adding to an already rich life, my father decided in middle age to become an elementary-school teacher in a working-class neighborhood in New Mexico. To this day, people who run grocery stores and work on construction sites, and who are now in late middle age themselves, come out when Im visiting to tell me how Mr. Lanier changed their lives. Go up to any adult with a good life, no matter what his or her station, and ask if a teacher made a difference, and youll always see a face light up. The human element, a magical connection, is at the heart of successful education, and you cant bottle it.

title: Drill, Baby, Drill
description: The word drill has come to define bad teaching. The piercing violence that drilling evokes just seems not to belong in sensitive pedagogy. Good teachers dont fire off quiz questions and catechize kids about facts. They dont plop students at computers to drill themselves on spelling or arithmetic. Drilling seems unimaginative and antisocial. It might even be harmful.

title: The 8-Year-Old Programmer
description: Our society thinks of computer programming as lucrative, therefore it must be hard and dull, says the leader of the Kodu project, Matt MacLaurin. He says software development should be like a fourth-grade art class: explore, create, discover.

title: The School of Hard Drives
description: This interview is for a special issue on education and technology, so let me start by asking you about computers in classrooms. As the secretary of education, do you think every kid in America needs a computer?  I think every student needs access to technology, and I think technology can be a hugely important vehicle to help level the playing field. Whether its in an inner-city school or a rural community, I want those students to have a chance to take A.P. biology and A.P. physics and marine biology.

title: Jobs Recovery in City Outpaces State and U.S.
description: The job market in New York City continued to recover more strongly than in the rest of the state and the nation through the end of the summer, according to figures released Thursday by the State Labor Department.

title: Outdoor Recreation Chain Will Open Store in SoHo
description: Yosemite. Denali. SoHo?

title: Twins Gardenhire and Anderson Say: Just Throw Strikes
description: CHICAGO  The news clipping came to Ron Gardenhire this season, yellowed and creased, sent by a fan to his home in Minnesota, where he manages the Twins. It was a feature on Gardenhire from a local paper in Virginia, written in the 1980s while he played for the Tidewater Tides, then the Mets Class AAA affiliate.

title: At 103, a Judge Has One Caveat: No Lengthy Trials
description: WICHITA, Kan.  Judge Wesley E. Browns mere presence in his courtroom is seen as something of a daily miracle. His diminished frame is nearly lost behind the bench. A tube under his nose feeds him oxygen during hearings. And he warns lawyers preparing for lengthy court battles that he may not live to see the cases to completion, adding the old saying, At this age, Im not even buying green bananas.

title: A Take on Faith and Capitalism
description: Bizarre and beautiful, disturbing and droll, The Temptation of St. Tony wonders what it means to be a good man. Kicking off with a quotation from Dantes Inferno, this delirious sophomore feature from the Estonian filmmaker Veiko Ounpuu observes Tony (Taavi Eelmaa), a triumphantly depressed middle manager. Dissatisfied with his adulterous wife and a boss who orders him to sack all his factory workers, Tony descends into a midlife crisis that manifests itself as a series of increasingly hilarious, horrific visions.

title: Untaxed Cigarettes Are Sold on Reservation, Mayor Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Thursday that an undercover investigation showed vendors on a Long Island Indian reservation sold large quantities of cigarettes on which the required taxes had not been paid.

title: Once Wary, Obama Now Relies on Petraeus
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama descended into the White House Situation Room on Monday for his monthly update on Afghanistan and Pakistan, the new top American military commander, Gen. David H. Petraeus, ticked off signs of progress.

title: Dismissal of Torture Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiat Shareholders Approve Plan to Split the Company
description: The Fiat Group gained approval from shareholders on Thursday to spin off its industrial business from its automotive unit, a move the company hoped would lead the stock market to view the two halves more positively than the whole.

title: Reviews Are In on Jeters Role as a Hit Batsman
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  About 1,200 miles Off Off Off Broadway on Wednesday night, Derek Jeter polished his acting chops, convincing an umpiring crew that a pitched ball struck his left arm when, as he later acknowledged with a smile, it did no such thing.

title: Obama Again Attacks Funding Ruling
description: President Obama on Thursday night revived his attack on a Supreme Court decision allowing corporations to spend unlimited sums to influence elections: Free-spending businesses, he said, are making an insidious power grab even as most of the attention in this election year is on grassroots populism.

title: Chief of Unit With Recalls to Exit J.&J.
description: A longtime senior executive at Johnson & Johnson in charge of the consumer products division is leaving the company early next year, signaling a shake-up after a troubling series of recalls, including of childrens Tylenol, tarnished the companys reputation in the last year.

title: Preventing Prison Rape
description: To the Editor:

title: 30 Years Later, Freedom in a Case With Tragedy for All Involved
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss.  A little after 10 oclock on Thursday morning, it was all up to Phillip Bivens. Just like that. The judge adjourned the hearing and Mr. Bivens, standing in a red jumpsuit in the corner of the courtroom, could all of a sudden do anything he wanted. After 30 years in prison, he was not sure what that was.

title: Fashion Week Winds Down
description: Well, this is it, the last show of New York Fashion Week: Gwen Stefanis L.A.M.B collection shown at Lincoln Center. It was probably scheduled that way just so that newspapers and bloggers could publish the headline, Fashion Week Goes Out With a L.A.M.B.

title: E.U. to Ratify First Free-Trade Deal With Asian Partner
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union said Thursday that it would sign a sweeping free-trade agreement with South Korea, its first with an Asian trade partner.

title: At Harvard, Protest Over Honorees Remarks About Muslims
description: BOSTON  Some Harvard University faculty members and students are objecting to a plan to honor an alumnus and editor of The New Republic because of a blog post he published this month that said Muslim life is cheap.

title: Feeding the World
description: To the Editor:

title: The Character Actor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Feud Between Airbus and Boeing Has Given Neither Side a Clear Advantage
description: After years of hearings, millions in legal bills and political posturing on both sides of the Atlantic, the dispute over aircraft subsidies is, in many ways, back where it started five years ago.

title: Report Says Drilling Ban Had Little Effect
description: WASHINGTON  The moratorium on deepwater oil and gas drilling imposed after the BP accident has had only modest impacts on jobs and on the Gulf Coast economy, the Obama administration said in a report issued Thursday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Sharpe Complaint Dropped
description: The woman who accused Shannon Sharpe, the CBS Sports football analyst, of forcing her to have sex with him and threatening her has dropped her complaint in Fulton County Superior Court in Georgia. She had been granted a temporary restraining order against Sharpe that is no longer in effect. This week, Sharpe took a leave from CBSs The NFL Today to deal with the case and a coming hearing. He will rejoin the program Sunday.

title: How the United Arab Emirates Sees Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Selecting Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: Reader Photos of the New York Storm
description: Readers sent in their best shots of the storm in the New York City area.

title: Dont Enforce Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: For almost a generation, the argument against allowing gay men and lesbians to serve openly in the military rested heavily on the claim that they would damage the morale and readiness of Americas armed forces.

title: For Yahoo, Finding Value in Asian Parts
description: Yahoos resistance to selling its Asian businesses is futile. The Internet company lacks direction. Its stock now trades at about half the $31-a-share offer from Microsoft that it spurned two years ago. Revenue has stagnated. And theres friction with its partner in China. Yahoo would be worth more carved up and refocused.

title: Brazil: Presidents Chief of Staff Resigns
description: President Luiz Incio Lula da Silvas chief of staff resigned Thursday amid an ethics scandal that threatened to damage the presidents chosen candidate to succeed him in the countrys election next month. Erenice Guerra, left, who took over as chief of staff this year so that Dilma Rousseff could run for president, had come under growing pressure to step down over allegations that she participated in a scheme to receive kickbacks for public works contracts. Ms. Rousseff has not been linked directly to any wrongdoing. Despite allegations that she condoned Ms. Guerras conduct, Ms. Rousseff is leading by a wide margin in polls ahead of the Oct. 3 election.

title: The Recessions Awful Impact
description: The Census Bureaus latest report on poverty and health insurance coverage is bleak. With millions of Americans out of work, it could hardly be otherwise.

title: Iraq: American Airman Killed at Base
description: An American airman was killed on Thursday and a soldier wounded while detonating seized explosives at Balad, a sprawling military base north of Baghdad, the American military said in a statement. The death was the third so far this month, which began with President Obamas formal declaration of the end of the American combat mission, and the 49th this year. Nearly 50,000 American troops remain in Iraq in advisory and support roles that nonetheless remain risky.

title: A Summer-of-Awakening Fable
description: In The Girl, a languid summer-of-my-awakening movie from the Swedish director Fredrik Edfeldt, an abandoned child discovers alcohol, anatomy books and chronic constipation. Only the last requires an intervention, but not even an enema subdues the films resourceful heroine (the admirable Blanca Engstrom), a deceptively meek 10-year-old whose parents have jetted to Africa to tend to the welfare of other peoples children.

title: A More Democratic Turkey
description: Turkey, already the Muslim Middle Easts sturdiest democracy, fortified its freedoms in a referendum on Sunday, with 58 percent of voters approving a package of constitutional amendments meant to end army meddling in civilian politics. That overwhelming yes vote showed that Turks are fed up with ultimatums and coups and want elected politicians fully in charge.

title: St. Johns Lands Second Top Recruit
description: St. Johns Coach Steve Lavin got another significant lift with the commitment of Jakarr Sampson, a 6-foot-8 wing player considered to be one of the top-25 high school players in the nation. Sampson played at LeBron Jamess former high school, St. Vincent-St. Mary in Akron, Ohio, before transferring for his senior season. He picked St. Johns over Louisville, Baylor and Tennessee and will enroll at St. Johns after this school year.

title: Ballerinas Take a New Approach: Talking
description: Hark! They speak!

title: Protecting the Capitals School Reform
description: After virtually guaranteeing his election as mayor of Washington by winning a bitter Democratic primary fight, Vincent Gray tried to reassure wary middle-class voters by promising not to turn back the clock to when the city government was known primarily for corruption, cronyism and inefficiency.

title: Japan: Foreign Minister Resigns
description: Japans foreign minister, Katsuya Okada, said Thursday that he would resign as part of what was expected to be a broad reshuffling of cabinet and party posts by the newly re-elected prime minister, Naoto Kan. Mr. Okada will take over the governing Democratic Partys No. 2 job of secretary general, in one of the first major changes made by Mr. Kan since he fended off a challenge by the partys power broker, Ichiro Ozawa, this week.

title: How Not to Build It
description: The Vulkano box, which lets you record TV shows and watch them on devices other than your own television,  is nowhere near ready for prime time, David Pogue concludes.

title: Democrats Reach Out to Hispanics on Immigration Bill
description: Democrats decision to put forward legislation that would grant legal status to some students who are illegal immigrants is meant to bolster support among an important voter group going into the midterms and beyond: Hispanics, the largest minority in the country.

title: Friday: Self-Evident Truth
description: BROWN CROSSWORD WEEK continues.

title: Using DDT to Fight Malaria
description: Dr. D. Rutledge Taylor is serious about rehabilitating the reputation of the pesticide DDT so that it can be used more widely in the developing world to battle malaria.

title: Limiting Lundqvist, or at Least Trying To
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Rangers may not know what to expect this season, but they do know one thing: their workhorse goalie, Henrik Lundqvist, will be playing less.

title: Long Ignored by the Mets, Perez Is Now an Option
description: Oliver Perez has pitched only three times in the last 54 days and has not started a game since May 14, which demonstrates more than anything the Mets could say about where he fits in their plans.

title: Informer in Bomb Plot Describes His Two Lives
description: In federal court on Thursday, it was hard to tell which was more mysterious and intriguing  a government informers cover story, or his actual life. And sometimes, it was hard to tell where one ended and the other began.

title: California: Plaintiffs Propose Ban in Suit Over Policy on Gays
description: The group challenging the dont ask, dont tell law regarding gays in the military has proposed a court order barring the Pentagon from enforcing the law and requiring it to halt all investigations or discharge proceedings related to the law and its regulations, which infringe the fundamental rights of military personnel. Judge Virginia A. Phillips of Federal District Court declared on Sept. 9 that the 1993 law is unconstitutional, and called for the Log Cabin Republicans, the plaintiffs, to file a proposed judgment and permanent injunction by Sept. 16. The Department of Justice, which defended the law, has a week to submit objections.

title: A Look Inside Prisoners Lives
description: This film is designated as a Critics' Pick.

title: Palin Stumps for Others as Her Support Dips
description: With the Republican primary season in the books, and her field of endorsed candidates either heading off to the general election or going back to the drawing board, Sarah Palin is stepping up her presence on the campaign trail to help Republicans raise money. She appeared with Rand Paul on Thursday in Louisville, Ky., where he is locked in a competitive race for the United States Senate. She is scheduled to be the headliner at the Republican Party of Iowas annual Reagan Dinner on Friday evening.

title: The Backlash Myth
description: Many of my liberal friends are convinced that the Republican Party has a death wish. It is sprinting to the right-most fever swamps of American life. It will end up alienating the moderate voters it needs to win elections.

title: New Review in Anthrax Inquiry
description: The investigative arm of Congress will conduct its own review of the Federal Bureau of Investigations scientific work in concluding that Bruce E. Ivins, an Army scientist, mailed the anthrax letters that killed five people in 2001. Colleagues of Dr. Ivins, who killed himself in 2008, have questioned the bureaus finding. The review, to be conducted by the Government Accountability Office, will begin after an anthrax study by the National Academy of Sciences is completed this year. At the F.B.I.s request, an academy panel has been looking at the genetic and chemical analysis of the powder and other work on the case by the F.B.I. and its consultants. Representative Rush Holt, Democrat of New Jersey, who has long sought an independent review of the work, praised the G.A.O.s decision.

title: Whitman Gives Generously to Herself
description: Attention big-spending politicians: Meg Whitman, the Republican gubernatorial candidate in California, has you all beat.

title: The Tax-Cut Racket
description: Nice middle class you got here, said Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader. It would be a shame if something happened to it.

title: A Models Diary
description: Picture Me seems surprised to learn that models are painfully thin, permanently tired (which tends to happen when you dont eat), relentlessly objectified and finally disposable. They fear the effortlessly skinny 12-year-olds jostling for their jobs and the predatory photographers who place them in what one model delicately terms compromising situations. And then theres all that walking.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The H.I.V. Epidemic in Washington
description: Washington has long seemed like the federal governments illegitimate child, denied statehood and degrees of autonomy. Congresss neglect extends to the citys H.I.V. epidemic, a situation made agonizingly clear in Susan Kochs quietly unblinking documentary, The Other City. The title derives from Washingtons split personality: as the illustrious home of politicians and monuments, and as a metropolis with the highest H.I.V. infection rate in the country.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,411 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: They Had Great Character
description: Los Angeles

title: It Takes a Village to Raise a School
description: WHILE Americans are right to be alarmed by the rising numbers of roadside bombs and suicide attacks in Afghanistan, we cant overlook a more subtle campaign that has been a key element of the Talibans strategy for years: disrupting access to schools.

title: Record Heat Means Refunds From Con Ed
description: Try this equation: The hottest spring and summer in New York Citys history plus the highest consumption of electricity on record equals refunds for Consolidated Edisons customers.

title: Soxs Wilting Season Takes Death Blow from Twins
description: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Elections Show Hurdles for Charter School Backers
description: They were the candidates of riches, flush with hundreds of thousands of dollars from Wall Street investors who believed in the promise of charter schools.

title: New Libraries Offer New Way of Learning
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: De Blasio Seeks Answers on Voting Snarls
description: Intensifying the pressure on the citys Board of Elections, Bill de Blasio, the public advocate, is demanding a detailed accounting of the problems that plagued the primary voting on Tuesday, as well as information about how poll workers were recruited and the training materials used to prepare them.

title: Daley, Even as Lame Duck, Retains His Populist Appeal
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley walked with a bodyguard from Daley Plaza to City Hall on Tuesday afternoon, almost a week after announcing he will not run for a seventh term, and the political regulars noticed a change in his behavior.

title: Nearby Oil Spill Highlights Hazards in Areas Pipelines
description: The oil that leaked from a pipeline beneath a warehouse complex in suburban Romeoville for four days was equivalent to only several hours worth of what leaked from the BP gusher in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Cuomo on Debates, E-Mails and Whether Hes an Insider
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic nominee for governor of New York, on Thursday morning held his first news conference since Carl P. Paladino was elected to be his Republican opponent. He took close to three dozen questions on his views of Mr. Paladino, voter anger, the rest of the Democratic ticket and his own platform  but still managed to avoid offering many clear or detailed answers.

title: A California State of Fashion
description: The number of times one heard the statement the 90s are back during New York shows is a reminder of how potent minimalism is in American fashion. It did seem to make a return, in a variety of forms  from the abundance of white fabrics, some of them sheer, to loose and often floor-sweeping dresses and skirts that had little detail. Some of the minimalist designers, like Francisco Costa of Calvin Klein and Narciso Rodriguez just seemed to express themselves with greater precision. Mr. Costas paneled dresses and coats seemed to hover between firm structure and airy volume.

title: Transparency Emerges as Theme in Museums Shows and Design
description: Ren de Guzmans office is a little more exposed than it was a couple of weeks ago.

title: Predictors Predictions Miss Close to Home
description: Bruce Bueno de Mesquita has been dubbed the next Nostradamus, after the 16th-century French apothecary whom some have credited with the ability to predict coming world events.

title: U.C. Proxy Voting Skirts Review Guidelines, Documents Show
description: The University of California, which prides itself as a leader on social and environmental issues, voted against hundreds of shareholder resolutions designed to promote human rights, environmental sustainability and efforts to fight discrimination, a review of U.C.s voting record shows.

title: Bloggingheads: Inequality in America
description: Timothy Noah, left, of Slate and Mickey Kaus of kausfiles debate social and income inequality.

title: Jon Stewart Plans to Rally Against Extremism
Jon Stewart Plans to Rally Against Extremism
description: Jon Stewart announced his much-awaited big announcement on Thursdays edition of his late-night program, The Daily Show. He plans to stage a rally in Washington to counter what he identified as extremists on either side of the political spectrum.

title: Jon Stewart Plans Washington Rally
description: Bill Carter reports on Media Decoder how Jon Stewart is planning a march in Washington against extremism on both sides of the political spectrum.

title: Jon Stewart Plans Washington Rally
description: Bill Carter reports on Media Decoder how Jon Stewart is planning a march in Washington against extremism on both sides of the political spectrum.

title: Expo in Shanghai Raises Questions About Fair in Bay Area
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: John Freeborn, British Fighter Pilot, Dies at 90
description: Seventy years ago, John Freeborn was one of the Royal Air Forces leading fighter pilots, acclaimed for his exploits off Dunkirk and in the air above English villages during the Battle of Britain.

title: Documenting the Storm
description: Images by Times readers of a violent storm on Thursday and its aftermath.

title: Word of the Day | ethnic
description: ethnic \eth-nik\ adjective/noun

title: All About Deflowering
description: The Virginity Hit takes a device  or a style, if youre feeling generous  thats become familiar in horror movies and applies it to the teenage sex comedy. The story, about the last of a quartet of high school buddies to lose his virginity (and thereby win the privilege of a ceremonial bong hit), is presented in the guise of amateur videos that are being posted on YouTube. When the on-screen high jinks are sufficiently embarrassing, the videos go viral.

title: Edward Norton as Good-Bad Twins
description: Who doesnt love a good-twin/bad-twin story? Or, in the case of Leaves of Grass, a dandy new film written and directed by Tim Blake Nelson, a straight-twin/stoned-twin story?

title: Countrywide Suit Cleared for Trial
description: Angelo Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial, lost a bid to have a government lawsuit on claims he misled investors about risks tied to subprime lending thrown out of court.

title: Wolves in Love
description: From far down the animation pecking order, where Pixar, DreamWorks and Studio Ghibli are only rumors, comes Alpha and Omega, the first in a series of films produced by Lionsgate and the Mumbai-based Crest Animation. This talking-animal tale  the title refers to the strata of wolf society, which are broken down in the name of true love between an alpha female and an omega male  has old-fashioned backgrounds that occasionally achieve a touch of grandeur, but thats about the best that can be said for it.

title: News Quiz | September 17, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: City Workers Clear Debris in Aftermath of Fierce Storm

title: Up Front: Julie Myerson
The Violence of Bereavement
description: Few writers are as energetic and prolific as Joyce Carol Oates, but reading her also requires a particular kind of energy. Ive always been unsettled and exhilarated by her work. Hers is an intensely truthful, explicitly emotional yet sometimes nightmarishly heightened world. For just the same reason, Im often left exhausted by it as well. Sourland, her latest collection of short fiction, begins and ends with stories featuring graphic and violent sexual encounters, and the tangle of tales that lie in between explore emotional, physical and sexual hazard in all its forms. Bedtime reading this isnt.

Numbers dont lie, and they brook no argument. Theyre the best kind of facts we have.

title: The Age of Citation
description: Imagine that this essay began not with the sentence youre reading, but with the following observation, attributed to Wittgenstein: A picture held us captive. And we could not get outside it, for it lay in our language and language seemed to repeat it to us inexorably. A little oblique for an opening gambit, you might think, but presumably it will pay off shortly. Imagine further, however, that the Wittgenstein quotation was immediately followed by quotes from Simone Weil, the Upanishads and the Hungarian poet Gyorgy Petri. At this point, you might find yourself wondering, O.K., when is the actual author going to actually give me something he actually wrote?

title: Straw Into Gold
description: In the summer of 2009, the atrium of the Museum of Modern Art in New York was the site of a remarkable installation by the conceptual artist Song Dong. Its title, Waste Not, referred to a Communist government slogan exhorting the Chinese people to cope with their near-constant shortages and privations by practicing a vigilant form of salvage: nothing durable, however worn or dubious its utility, should be discarded. Song Dongs mother appears to have followed the directive with unusual zeal, and after his father died in 2002, Song Dong decided her grief might be assuaged if she collaborated with him on a project that would alchemize into art the vast heaps of detritus she had accumulated over decades of state-encouraged hoarding. The result  an ingeniously arranged labyrinth of pens, cookware, buttons, magazines, clothing, shoes, plastic bottles, toys  was powerfully affecting. Walking through the grid of ribbons, buttons, toothpaste tubes, combs and gramophones was a challenge to consider how much our possessions say about us, how eloquently the humblest domestic artifacts communicate the joys and sorrows of family life, and how we can never save enough to protect ourselves from the inevitability of loss.

title: The President Dead
description: The sad announcement came at 11 o'clock last night that President Garfield had breathed his last at 10:35, thus putting an end to the long weeks of suffering he has endured. His condition yesterday, aside from a slight rigor in the early morning, was apparently more favorable than it had been on Sunday, and his surgeons and attendants, though realizing the fact that he was in an extremely critical state, were inclined to hope that he might grow better after all. At a few minutes after 10 o'clock last night, however, the sufferer complained of a severe pain in the region of the heart and almost immediately became unconscious. Dr. Bliss, who was hastily called, at once announced that he was dying, and Mrs. Garfield and the consulting surgeons were summoned. Within 15 minutes President Garfield had drawn his last breath and the sorrowful intelligence was being sent with lightning speed throughout the country. Everywhere, notwithstanding the lateness of the hour, the bells were tolled as a mark of respect and sorrow for the long-suffering, patient, and heroic President.

As practiced by the jaundiced Holmes, restraint was often a shrug of the shoulders: lawmakers, in his view, were predisposed to foolishness, and the Constitution entitled them, in most cases, to be fools.

title: The Metafictional Club
description: Before taking up a novel like Scarlett Thomass Our Tragic Universe, with its playful and portentous fixations on riddles, paradoxes and Zen koans, it may be helpful to engage in a few preliminary thought experiments. Is a seed placed in a pot and covered with dirt and water a flower? Is an assortment of bread, meat, cheese and condiments piled on a plate a sandwich? And is a sequence of fictional events, populated by characters and imbued with subtexts and recurring themes, a novel? In the abstract we cannot know, but in specific cases we should be able to answer conclusively. So how is it that this lively and thoughtful book possesses all the requisite elements of the thing it wants to be, and is so self-aware of what its components should be, yet lacks the essential spark that would make it a satisfying work of literature?

I was inspired by Kiki de Montparnasse  she matched her eye makeup to her outfits, he said. Its an old-fashioned idea, but a quirky one too. title: Hall of Mirrors
description: The Chilean writer Roberto Bolao has to be one of the most improbable international literary celebrities since William Burroughs and Henry Miller, two writers whose work Bolaos occasionally resembles. His subjects are sex, poetry, death, solitude, violent crime and the desperate glimmers of transcendence that sometimes attend them. The prose is dark, intimate and sneakily touching. His lens is largely (though not literally) autobiographical, and seems narrowly focused at first. There are no sweeping historical gestures in Bolao. Yet he has given us a subtle portrait of Latin America during the last quarter of the 20th century  a period of death squads, exile, disappeared citizens and state-sponsored terror. The nightmarish sense of human life being as discardable as clay permeates his writing.

Jesse Owens, at the 1936 Olympics in Berlin, discredited the Aryan-supremacy subtext that would underlie World War II. Jackie Robinson integrated baseball and, more important, modern American society. Muhammad Ali transformed the attitude of black athletes and made them a political force. Marvin Miller razed the century-old system of indentured servitude, leading to the zillionaire fiesta that is modern free agency.

title: Solomons Travels

His prose is impish and subtle enough to bear comparison with Italo Calvino and Georges Perec, even if he lacked their scope. Saramago was a Communist. He believed there was a new totalitarianism of multinational companies. To be a Portuguese Stalinist well into the 21st century means youre simply not living in the real world, the critic Harold Bloom has said. True enough. Yet when Saramago picked up his pen, a richer world was made.

The novels protagonist, Oedipa Maas, looks down a slope, needing to squint for the sunlight, onto a vast sprawl of houses which had grown up all together, like a well-tended crop, from the dull brown earth, Pynchon writes, and she thought of the time shed opened a transistor radio to replace a battery and seen her first printed circuit. The ordered swirl of houses and streets, from this high angle, sprang at her now with the same unexpected, astonishing clarity as the circuit card had. The architectural system unfolding in front of her held, according to Pynchon, a hieroglyphic sense of concealed meaning.

Short of Manhasset, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph M. Schlafer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph Church.

description: So she got the job. What should she do with it?

description: I know that everyone looked at this weeks schedule and became sad. No blockbuster national championship rematches. Only one meeting of ranked teams (Iowa at Arizona). No one game to really hang your hat on.

title: Ribolla Gialla and a Breg From Josko Gravner
description: Its been a busy week for the wine trade here in New York, where myriad tastings and winemaker visits have set the city a-buzzing more than usual. One of the highlights for me was the opportunity to taste two new whites from Josko Gravner, easily one of the most idiosyncratic and fascinating winemakers in the world.

title: Together for 10 Years and Still Totally Committed
description: Ten years ago the Bad Plus came together in a warm rush of camaraderie and with a clear grasp of novelty. Here was a jazz piano trio with the heart and gall of a stadium rock band, grappling wryly but directly with anthemic covers and its own scarcely less anthemic originals. The group was brash and clever, its crooked sincerity often mistaken for smug acidity. A debate arose in jazz circles over the entitlements of such a group, what it meant and whether it deserved what it got.

title: Bank Leaves Childs Play Behind
description: One of the most-talked-about advertising campaigns  for a financial institution, anyway  is ending.

title: A Home Filled With Mementos From the Civil Rights Movement
description: Marcia Young Cantarella lives in a Classic 6 on the Upper West Side in which the presence of her father, the late civil rights leader Whitney M. Young Jr., is felt in almost every room.

title: Meet the In-Law
description: My brand-new sister-in-law left her e-mail account open, so I read her messages to see what she had to say about me. Well, it wasnt pretty. She used an expletive to describe me to one friend, and called me a high-maintenance pain to another. Im not sure where her animosity comes from. I know I violated her privacy, but Id still like to discuss her anger. I want a loving relationship, but my feelings are so hurt I dont know if I can pretend ignorance. What do you think?

title: New York Fashion Week | Emily Jerome
description: Resort collections may be a passing thought as spring quickly engulfs the fashion-conscious, but that doesnt mean designers have all tired of wild cruise prints. Take the nascent Los Angeles designer Emily Jerome, whose Jerome label sells at Ron Herman, L.A., and is worn by Mamie Gummer, Jessica Collins and Catherine and Allison Pierce of the Pierces, among others. Not that you have to be a celebutante to wear it, but wallflowers need not apply. The Jerome girl is a little bit of everything  the rocker, bohemian and a tad flamboyant at times, Jerome said via phone while working on her first look book (shot by Eric Ray Davidson) at the Chinati Foundation in Marfa, Tex., with Jessica Joffe. If the backdrop and the artful multiculti prints look familiar, its because the estate belongs to Donald Judd, Jeromes godfather and a collector of ethnic textiles and African masks. My prints this season derive from Christmas tree worms and ancient, ritual shoulder clothes from Bhutan, Jerome said. You can take the girl out of Marfa.

title: Diving Deep to Reach the Surface
description: AFTER three fruitless years of online dating, I went to an acupuncturist and lay down before needles. Id left the love of my life because he did not want children and had hoped to meet someone else quickly enough to have my own. Now, at 41, I was still single and paying a stranger to burn mugwort on my back.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 17
description: A view of the day in sports, which included Davis Cup tennis in France.

title: Tracking a Tag
description: The graffiti artist Momo surreptitiously painted his name across Lower Manhattan.

title: Fun With Rental Bikes in Paris and London
description: Writing on the London Review of Books blog, Jon Day points out that Londons new fleet of rental bikes have provided a fresh canvas to Situationist guerrilla teams intent on undercutting the ads they carry for Barclays Bank.

description: Writing on the London Review of Books blog, Jon Day points out that Londons new fleet of rental bikes have provided a fresh canvas to Situationist guerrilla teams intent on undercutting the ads they carry for Barclays Bank.

title: Fete Accompli | Umas Boating Party
description: On a drizzly Sunday night, while most of the citys boldface names were sucked into the teeming nexus of Fashion Week, Uma Thurman took her first slippery steps down a metal ramp at Chelsea Piers and climbed aboard the Manhattan. The city seemed encased in a wet, almost scary gloom, and inside the cabin, all the windows were fogged up. Everyone worried about visibility. It wasnt just because the boat  one of those wooden 1920s-style commuter yachts from the upmarket Circle Line alternative Classic Harbor Line  was to sail past famous sights: the Statue of Liberty and the Brooklyn Bridge. It was because this private cruise for 34 was being guided by Ken Burns, the documentarian who has made important films about both landmarks.

title: Getting Ready for the Afghan Vote
description: The Times's Adam B. Ellick and Afghan Times Reporter Sangar Rahimi discuss Afghan parliamentary candidates.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Its said that the eye is bigger than the stomach. Appetite, curated by the Herb Lubalin Study Center at The Cooper Union, explores the influence of design in the food industry in a free exhibition at 41 Cooper Gallery, 41 Cooper Square (East Seventh Street). The exhibition opens at noon on Saturday and runs through Oct. 9. The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, has also opened a food-themed exhibition: Counter Space: Design and the Modern Kitchen. It explores the transformation of kitchen design in the past century and how it played a role in womens lives and consumerism. It runs until March 14.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Its said that the eye is bigger than the stomach. Appetite, curated by the Herb Lubalin Study Center at The Cooper Union, explores the influence of design in the food industry in a free exhibition at 41 Cooper Gallery, 41 Cooper Square (East Seventh Street). The exhibition opens at noon on Saturday and runs through Oct. 9. It explores the transformation of kitchen design in the past century and how it played a role in womens lives and consumerism. It runs until March 14.

title: When Fantmas Held All of Paris in His Criminal Thrall
description: A GIGANTIC figure, wearing the elegant evening clothes of the Belle poque, steps out of the horizon line and straddles the city of Paris, one foot ready to crush the Louvre. With an air of ennui, he stares out from behind a black mask, cupping his chin distractedly in his left hand, while his right arm extends behind him, clutching a knife tipped with blood.

title: A Fond Farewell to As the World Turns
description: As the World Turns, the CBS soap opera with more divorces in its history than, surely, the entire city of Reno, ended for good on Friday after 54 years on television and a prior life on radio. At this commemorative moment it is worth pointing out that a number of now-famous actors appeared on the series including Meg Ryan, Julianne Moore, Steven Weber and Marisa Tomei. Amazingly enough, the last three appear together in this scene of love gone brutally, badly and tediously wrong: Not only does this clip egregiously fail to suggest the talent of Julianne Moore in Vanya on 42nd Street; it fails to telegraph the talent of Steven Weber in Wings.

title: Insuring the Risks of College Life
description: In this weeks Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan discusses the many risks that college students face and how proper insurance can help reduce any potential damages.

title: Insuring the Risks of College Life
description: In this weeks Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan discusses the many risks that college students face and how proper insurance can help reduce any potential damages.

title: Weekly Pick Em: Lacking in Marquee Value, Not Intrigue
description: At first glance, this Saturdays schedule seems like a comedown from last weeks. No Oklahoma-Florida State, no Ohio State-Miami, no Notre Dame-Michigan. In fact, there is only matchup between ranked teams this Saturday (No. 9 Iowa at No. 24 Arizona). But it would be remiss to think that the lack of marquee games means Saturday holds little intrigue. Several ranked teams will face serious early-season tests, some of them in hostile environments (just ask Texas Coach Mack Brown how much hes looking forward to going into Lubbock to play Texas Tech and its new coach, Tommy Tuberville). Eighth-ranked Nebraska will not only be up against Jake Locker, but it will have to contend with the always intimidating atmosphere in Washington. Florida State returns home after getting blown out at Oklahoma last week, but the Seminoles dont get much of a break when they host Brigham Young. Two A.C.C. teams, Georgia Tech and North Carolina, that have already seen their seasons go in a different direction than they wanted them to, play a game that is already critical for each. And Al Golden, the coach who has turned Temple around and is sure to be mentioned for some high-profile jobs at the end of the season, will see how his Owls fare against Connecticut of the Big East. What this weekend lacks in marquee value, it makes up for in intrigue. And that means that there is plenty of room for error when picking the games. As always, if you agree with the picks, disagree with them or simply find them laughable, feel free to chime in.

title: The Video Q | Gaspar No on Enter the Void
description: Lots of people ask me, Why do you need to show explicit sex in your movies?  said the French-Argentinian film director, Gaspar No. And as he explains in this weeks video interview, its because when I have sex, its explicit. Life is graphic.

title: William S. Macklowe
description: Mr. Macklowe, 42, is the chief executive of the William Macklowe Company, a new venture that will focus on real estate acquisitions, strategic lending and investment.

title: The Six-Room Scrapbook
description: THE Upper West Side apartment that is home to Marcia Young Cantarella, a longtime educator and a onetime dean at Princeton University, is rich with the presence of the two men who have loomed largest in her life.

title: A Rift Over Transit-Housing Plan
description: FOR the last few years, developers, planners and politicians have been emphasizing the need for transit-oriented developments  multifamily housing clustered near train stations  as a solution to suburbias woes, a way to keep young people on the Island and to provide affordable housing.

title: A Cool Summer for Housing
description: THE fall real estate season is under way, and the school of hard realities is in session.

title: Looks Like a Condo, Acts Like a Hotel
description: ROOM service on demand from a celebrity chef. A maid to make the bed with fresh linens every day and leave a chocolate on your pillow at night. An 11,000-square-foot spa an elevator ride away. All yours with the purchase of a luxury condo.

title: Morris Heights, the Bronx
description: MORRIS HEIGHTS was not first, second or even third on the list of neighborhoods where David Klaw and his fiance, Jill Sunderland, considered buying a house.

description: AS buyers like Sandip K. Agarwala have discovered, opting for new construction these days can be hazardous to your nerves.

description: RENTING a house in the Hamptons used to mean committing to the whole summer. And once Labor Day arrived, the market shut down until the snow melted and beach lovers started thinking about the ocean again.

description: LEW ALTFEST knows how clients will react when he tells them they shouldnt refinance their mortgages.

description: The firefighter had his power saw ready on Friday to cut up a massive London Plane that had crashed the night before across 84th Place in Middle Village, Queens, its crown landing over Frank Sodas 1989 Grand Marquis.

title: House Forecast Update: Embracing the Uncertainty
description: In contrast to our prognosis for the United States Senate, where the chances of a Republican takeover dropped sharply this week because of the outcome of the Delaware primary, our forecast for the House of Representatives shows relatively little change from last week.

title: Above Forest Hills, 12:22 P.M.
Audi Film Crew Injured in Pikes Peak Helicopter Crash
description: Four people were injured, one seriously, when a helicopter crashed while filming an Audi test on Pikes Peak, west of Colorado Springs, Colo.

title: Pictures of the Day: Mozambique and Elsewhere
description: The pictures are off the immediate news but add graphically to our knowledge of Mozambique. Goran Tomasevic of Reuters has transmitted pictures of gold prospectors panning on rented land. In The Gold Slaves of Mozambique (March 24, 2008), Spiegel Online described the prospectors lot:

title: Election Eve in Marja
description: MARJA, AfghanistanMarines here in this Helmand Province battleground say they expect the Taliban to try to attack polling sites for Saturdays Parliamentary elections with gunfire and rocket-propelled grenades and so have spent much of the week devising security plans.

title: ODonnell Takes to the National Stage
description: Christine ODonnell took the stage at the annual Values Voters Summit to the tune of Journeys Dont Stop Believing, and for a little over 18 minutes, she spoke to the true believers.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  How much does it cost to buy an Afghan vote?
