description: ANNE MURPHY says she likes living at the Solaire, a rental building in Battery Park City, because it allows her to feel environmentally virtuous.

title: Tracking Sea Ice in the Arctic
description: This week the National Snow and Ice Data Center in Colorado issued a preliminary estimate of Arctic sea-ice volume for the year. The numbers will not become final until October, but the early calculation is that the summer minimum extent for Arctic sea ice hit its third-lowest level in the modern era, a bit above 2008 and somewhat above the record low of 2007.

title: Prabal Gurung Video | First Look Challenge Winners and Finalists
description: After 1,786 people played fashion stylist with looks from Prabals spring/summer 2011 collection, 25 finalists were chosen from the lot. Heres a look at the entries that made the cut, in Polyvores video, above, and the two winners, below:

title: Mattingly to Replace Torre at Dodgers Helm
description: LOS ANGELES  As the Dodgers wilted this summer  as Matt Kemp continued to make mental mistakes, as Andre Ethier could not shake out of his funk, as Manny Ramirez was not going to ride to the rescue  Joe Torre called more meetings than at any time in his long career as a manager.

title: Toyota Bolsters Scion Lineup
description: Toyota announced recently that it would be adding two models to the Scion portfolio. The new entries include a restyled tC coupe and a diminutive four-passenger urban car called iQ.

title: Texas Democrat: I Stood Up to Obama, Pelosi
description: Representative Chet Edwards isnt the first Democrat running in a moderate or conservative district to air an advertisement distancing himself from party leaders like President Obama and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

title: Ford to Sell Canadian-Built Edge in China
description: Ford will try to help satisfy Chinas thirst for S.U.V.s by exporting the Canadian-built Edge to that rapidly expanding market. The Edge was first shown in Asia at the Beijing Auto Show in April, and it is appearing this week at the Chengdu Auto Show.

title: Murkowski Can Win as Write-In
description: The Hotline reports that Alaska Senator Lisa Murkowski, who was defeated in the Republican primary last month by Joe Miller, will run for the Senate as a write-in candidate against Mr. Miller and the Democratic candidate, Scott McAdams.

title: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 17
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the primary election, the ninth anniversary of 9/11 and a ferocious storm.

title: Notes From a Young American in Congo: Caffeine!
description: Do you drink that every day? For two dollars?

title: Fte Accompli | T Magazine Toasts Sally Singer
description: The flash storm last night cleared just in time for the party at the Spotted Pig to welcome Ts new editor, Sally Singer. Hosted by the New York Timess publisher, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., and Janet Robinson, the companys president and chief executive officer, the event drew a veritable whos who of the fashion, media and entertainment industries, including Maggie Gyllenhaal and Peter Sarsgaard, Brad Goreski, Anna Wintour, Grace Coddington and the designers Olivier Theyskens, Donna Karan, Prabal Gurung, Joseph Altuzarra and Jason Wu, among others. Our favorite sighting of the evening, however, was Courtney Love, who sat in a corner for a while, reading a book. No word on what she was reading.

title: A Way With Balanchine (and With a Talking Dancer, Too)
description: New York City Ballet is presenting no fewer than 27 works during its inaugural fall season, 10 of them during this opening week. By world ballet standards, this is astonishing. Here, nobody even remarks on it. On Wednesday night four of George Balanchines ballets re-entered the repertory, and suddenly the eye, the ear, the mind and the imagination were again all full.

title: Almond-Apricot Granola Bars
description: Mark Bittman makes a flavorful granola bar, no baking required.

title: Opposites on Every Count, Kindred Souls in Many Ways
description: In cinematic terms  and this is only one way to absorb the fullness of Raimund Hoghes spare choreographic vision  Sans-Titre would be a black-and-white movie. In the work, a collaboration with the Congolese choreographer Faustin Linyekula, the German-born Mr. Hoghe explores the idea of being, as the titles translation reveals, without papers. White lights illuminate a black stage. Mr. Linyekula wears white; Mr. Hoghe appears in black.

title: The World of Robbins: Sinuous Dreams and Complex Geometry
description: Articulate and charming, the ballerina Jenifer Ringer is a perfect representative for New York City Ballets opening-week policy of having principal dancers introduce the evenings ballets. On Thursday night at the David H. Koch Theater, she spoke about her experience dancing in the Jerome Robbins works on the program: Interplay, Opus 19/The Dreamer, The Four Seasons. She particularly loves her entrance in the Spring section of The Four Seasons, she told us, because of the way the icy blue light of the winter section changes to the warm pink glow of Spring.

title: Scientists React to a Nobelists Climate Thoughts
description: 7:14 p.m. | Updated Earlier today, I wrote about the way internal filters can influence how scientists perceive and convey risks (in this instance, risks of human-driven climate change) and how the public weighs scientists views. As I stressed, what social scientists call cultural cognition is only one factor shaping perceptions of phenomena revealed by science.

title: A Hands-On Approach to Entertaining His Fans
description: Trey Songz looked out into the Beacon Theater audience on Thursday night and saw a meal half eaten. In between audience screams, he shared his philosophy. The first thing I do when I see a lovely face, he said, stopping for effect. I imagine the faces we would make if we ever made love.

title: Sunday Preview
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: The Illusion of Pension Savings
description: Earlier this year, Illinois said it had found a way to save billions of dollars. It would slash the pensions of workers it had not yet hired. The real-world savings would not materialize for decades, of course, but thanks to an actuarial trick, the state could start counting the savings this year and use it to help balance its budget.

title: Scorecard (Mens Edition) | N. Hoolywood Wins!
description: Dont worry, guys: Scorecard hasnt forgotten about you. We may just have been a little distracted this week  what with the womens wear whiteout and all  that we forgot to mention: New York suits have done a 180 and the consensus (in the critical community anyway) is that not-so-streamlined conceptualism reigns.

title: F.D.A. Postpones Rule on Breast Cancer Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration appears to have postponed an expected decision on whether to revoke the approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer.

title: Forget What You Know of Twain, Then Delight in Your Rediscovery
description: Mark Twains heroes tend to land in unexpected places: caves, locked cabins, long-gone eras, the Czars palace, a Tasmanian jungle, Southern drawing rooms. Whether its Huck Finn floating on a raft with an escaped slave or Hank Morgan thrust into the court of King Arthur, they are generally good-humored about their quandary and come out in pretty decent condition, tossing off a few wisecracks, learning a few things, maybe even making a fortune.

title: Spotlight Glows Brightly in Toronto
description: TORONTO  Years ago, back when branding was a word many of us still associated with cattle, the Toronto International Film Festival was known as the festival of festivals, a reference to its identity as an event that gathered hits and misses from more prestigious festivals.

title: G.O.P. in Florida: Unauthorized Expenses Cited
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Gov. Charlie Crist on Friday was drawn into the ongoing financial scandal with the Republican Party of Florida after the party released an audit that says that the party spent thousands on the cost of trips to New York City and Walt Disney World that included Crist, his wife and her family.

title: Medical Talk, With Antipasti and Pasta on the Side
description: At this Italian restaurant on Madison Avenue between 97th and 98th Streets, the appeal of eating local has nothing to do with the provenance of the food. Opened in February and with Salvatore Fraterrigo as the executive chef, Tre Otto was carved out of an old dress shop by Lauren and Louis Cangiano, who live around the corner. He comes from a family that ran Italian specialty supermarkets for decades on Staten Island and in Brooklyn; she is a real estate agent. With exposed-brick walls, dark-wood furnishings and a menu including casual starters and composed entrees, the place has quickly found a following among residents  of both the neighborhood and medical variety  at the crossroads of Carnegie Hill and East Harlem, near Mount Sinai Medical Center. On Wednesday, that following included a group of medical professionals talking shop.

title: A Bit Lazy, a Bit Productive
description: Thom Filicia, the interior designer of Queer Eye fame, continues to stage home dcor interventions as the host of Tacky House and Dress My Nest on the Style Network. Mr. Filicia, 41, who also has a home furnishings line, lives in SoHo with his companion, Greg Calejo, a publicist, and two dogs, Paco and Foxy. Every other weekend, they head upstate to Skaneateles, where Mr. Filicia is renovating a 1907 lake house.

title: A New Look at Koch Elevates His Legacy
description: AN unscientific survey of scholars a decade ago ranked Edward I. Koch 15th among Americas worst mayors. Having received 14 negative reviews and 6 positive ones, he fared better than two of his 19th-century New York predecessors (Fernando Wood and A. Oakey Hall), but nonetheless found himself sandwiched between two of his nemeses, Abraham D. Beame (14th) and John V. Lindsay (16th).

title: Granola Bars, Unwrapped
description: GRANOLA is one of those foods that is assumed to be inherently good for you, so logic suggests that granola bars are, too. Sadly, that is not necessarily the case: if youve ever looked at the label on a granola bar, you know it can contain anything from corn syrup and corn flour to chocolate chips and added coloring. Nothing that will make you sick (at least not immediately), but not exactly health food.

title: Thousands of Trees Killed by New York Tornadoes
description: As National Weather Service officials declared Friday that two tornadoes had indeed swept into New York City on Thursday, some tree-lined streets in Brooklyn and Queens looked -- at least from the air -- like Lego masterpieces that angry children had done their best to sweep aside.

title: Stalled, Shafted, Mystified
description: A serviceable burst of high-end hokum, Devil classes up a flimsy, religion-themed plot (by M. Night Shyamalan) with the kind of limber cinematography only someone like Tak Fujimoto can deliver. Circling wildly within the films main set  a stalled elevator car  or hurtling up and down an empty shaft, Mr. Fujimotos camera is as giddy as a tween at a Justin Bieber concert.

title: Making Your Own Granola Bars
description: Mass-produced granola bars are more like candy bars than the health food theyre advertised to be. But you can make your own, with real ingredients, and theyre super. See this weeks Minimalist column.

title: In Court, Echoes and Ghosts
description: NEW HAVEN

title: A Writers Struggles, on and Off the Page
description: Her feminist war cry of a play, For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/ When the Rainbow Is Enuf, is Ntozake Shanges signature work, produced on Broadway in 1976 when she was in her 20s. Now 61, her speech and movements slowed by a series of minor strokes but her intensity undimmed, Ms. Shange is having another moment, or two, this fall.

title: Now Serving | Austin Eats
description: With its deep roots of Tex-Mex, breakfast tacos and barbecue, Austin, Tex., has always been considered a foodie town. Some recent additions have elevated the state capitols profile in the world of the flavorful and the fabulous. Here are some of the latest offerings worth checking out.Uchiko, 4200 North Lamar, Suite 140; (512) 916-4808. Tyson Coles newest venture features one of his trusted chefs, Paul Qui, at the helm. The similar Japanese influences that inspired Cole at Uchi (not surprisingly, Uchiko means offspring of Uchi) can be found on the menu, as well as new inventions. During a recent dinner, the highlights included a tasty koviche, a ceviche of fresh diver scallops prepared with tomatillo, kalamata olives and black lime; and the ao saba, a grilled Norwegian mackerel with a delightful convergence of flavors that included bluefoot mushroom, onion and juniper huckleberry. For dessert, try the stunning sweet-corn sorbet.

title: The Best Two Women Could Do
description: Jenna Glazer and Elise Bacolas werent looking for the loves of their lives when they met 11 years ago. Both 27, they had each recently ended a big relationship, and felt no rush to start another. But, introduced by a mutual friend outside a bar, they hit it off. Ms. Bacolas gave Ms. Glazer a lift home, and they talked until nearly dawn.

title: 2011 Cadillac CTS Coupe
description: The CTS Coupe is the first four-seat Caddy coupe since the senior-centric Eldorado.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,412 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Thursday:

title: Murkowski Will Run as Write-in Candidate
description: A top Republican official in Washington said Friday that Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska has informed the partys leadership that she intends to run as a write-in candidate for re-election despite losing the Republican nomination in the primary earlier this month.

title: An Artists Alfresco John Hancock
description: The thin orange line of paint traces a winding path though downtown Manhattan neighborhoods like SoHo, Greenwich Village and the Lower East Side. Uneven and wandering, the stripe runs up major avenues and across narrow streets, sometimes prominent, at other times so faint and worn that it is barely visible.

title: James Levine Says Hes Ready to Work Again
description: In his first detailed comments about his latest health problem, James Levine said he underwent a 10-hour monster operation in April to correct curvature of the spine and spinal stenosis, an exceedingly painful condition that compresses the spinal cord.

title: Two Rockies Share Link to Manning Brothers
description: When the Colorado Rockies held their fantasy football league draft last month, it was no surprise who Seth Smith, the outfielder who was once the backup to Eli Manning at the University of Mississippi, wanted as his quarterback.

title: At Wagner, Player Has College Football Career After Pro Baseball
description: Nick Doscher has returned to Staten Island, his home, and he has settled in as the 23-year-old starting sophomore quarterback at Wagner College, whose leafy campus sits like a tiara atop Grymes Hill. On Saturday, the Seahawks will play Cornell at home, a good test for both teams.

title: Borat Star To Play Freddie Mercury
description: Now that vrit-style comedies that try to present themselves as documentaries have been made totally pass, Sacha Baron Cohen has decided its time for a transition to the less controversial turf of the biopic. Mr. Baron Cohen, above left, the British comedian and star of Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan and Bruno, is planning to portray Freddie Mercury, above right, the frontman of the rock band Queen, who died in 1991, in a feature, the films producers said Thursday night. In a news release, the production company GK Films said it had signed Mr. Baron Cohen for an untitled drama focusing on the era surrounding Queens performance at the 1985 Live Aid benefit concert. The screenplay is by Peter Morgan, the Frost/Nixon playwright and writer of historical films like The Queen and The Last King of Scotland. The films producers, who also include TriBeCa Productions and Queen Films, did not indicate whether Mr. Baron Cohen would actually sing such demanding Queen songs as We Are the Champions or Bohemian Rhapsody. But he did get a chance to show off his throat  in more ways than one  in Tim Burtons film version of Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street. GK Films said production would start next year.

title: City Opera Chairwoman Explains Her Departure
description: Susan L. Baker, who is ceding the job of chairwoman of the New York City Opera, said the move was just part of good governance and had nothing to do with the companys difficult chapter involving the 2008 resignation of its general manager Gerard Mortier. Heavens, no! she said late Thursday in a telephone interview. Ms. Baker was chairwoman during Mr. Mortiers hiring and quick resignation, which was widely viewed as a debacle in the opera world. Im a great believer in chairs not overstaying, Ms. Baker said. So I put in place a committee sometime over the course of the past year to really commence a process for finding a new leader. That new leader, as reported, will be Charles R. Wall, a former board member who recently retired as vice chairman of Philip Morris International. Ms. Baker said that she would stay active on the board, but that she and Mr. Wall still had to talk about her specific role. Ms. Baker declined to talk about the Mortier chapter. Im not interested in getting into that discussion, Ms. Baker said.

title: Nicole Kidman To Return To Broadway Next Year
description: The Academy Award-winning actress Nicole Kidman plans to return to Broadway in the fall of 2011 to star in a revival of the Tennessee Williams play Sweet Bird of Youth, to be directed by David Cromer (Our Town), a spokesman for the production said on Friday. Ms. Kidman, left, was last on Broadway, in her debut, in the 1998-99 season production of David Hares play The Blue Room. That show drew mixed reviews but was a very tough ticket to come by, given Ms. Kidmans star appeal. In Sweet Bird, Ms. Kidman will play Alexandra Del Lago, the faded, often-drunk movie star going around with the gigolo Chance Wayne; no word on who will play Chance. The original 1959 production on Broadway starred Geraldine Page as Alexandra and Paul Newman as Chance, who also starred in a film version; a 1975-76 revival, the last on Broadway, starred Irene Worth and Christopher Walken. Scott Rudin (last seasons Tony Award-winning Fences, the coming musical Book of Mormon) will be producing. The production and Ms. Kidmans casting were reported in The New York Post.

title: Promises, Promises Will Close In January
description: One of Broadways biggest commercial hits of the year, the Sean Hayes-led revival of the musical Promises, Promises, will close on Jan. 2, the producers announced on Thursday night. The decision to close the show only nine months after opening is another reminder of the premium that producers put on star casting on Broadway  and the high costs and unpredictability of recasting. Beth Williams, one of the lead producers, said in a phone interview on Friday that the producers considered recasting, started putting lists together, but we didnt think there was a way to replace Sean and Kristin Chenoweth and ensure extending the shows financial track record as well. In a statement, the producers said they expected to recoup their original capitalization cost  they would not say how much it was, but it was at least in the high seven figures  and turn a profit for their investors, especially as the show heads into the lucrative holiday season. The show has grossed more than $25 million since opening in April. Its leading man and woman  Mr. Hayes (an Emmy Award winner for Will & Grace), above, and Ms. Chenoweth (Wicked, a Tony winner for Youre a Good Man, Charlie Brown)  are under contract only through the end of the year, and they were not re-upping. Katie Finneran, who won a Tony as Marge MacDougall, will pass on the role to Molly Shannon next month. A touring version of this production of Promises, Promises is now being discussed, Ms. Williams said.

title: Egyptian Newspaper Admits Doctoring Photo
description: On Friday, the editor of a newspaper owned by the Egyptian government admitted that a photograph published this week in its pages had been altered to make it seem as if Egypts president, Hosni Mubarak, had led, rather than followed, a group of world leaders walking in to a media event at the White House last week.

title: Law & Order: UK Coming to BBC America
description: NBC and its partners started remaking Law & Order for British audiences more than a year ago, and now those episodes are heading back to the United States, where they started. BBC America said Thursday that it would import Law & Order: UK beginning next month, with the premiere set for a Sunday, Oct. 3, at 10:30 p.m. Other episodes will be shown on Friday nights at 9. Law & Order: UK is the first foreign English-language iteration of the long-running crime series. It is produced by NBC Universal, Wolf Films and a British production company called Kudos Film and Television. The producers recycled scripts from the original Law & Order, set in New York, to retain the grittiness of that series, the BBC said. But the episodes were adapted to reflect the legal system in Britain. Dick Wolf, the executive producer of the Law & Order empire, told BBC News last year that legally, the biggest difference here was the wigs. He added, The law is not really that dissimilar.

title: Viewers to Apprentice: Youre Tired
description: After three seasons with celebrity contestants, a recession-themed 10th edition of The Apprentice, with Donald Trump, below, made its debut on Thursday with nonfamous contestants whose lives have been hit hard by the economic downturn. Also suffering: the shows ratings. According to Nielsens estimates, NBC drew just 4.7 million viewers for the premiere, the lowest ratings ever for an episode of the franchise and a decline of almost 4 million from the series most recent premiere in March (8.3 million). NBC ranked third for the night over all. CBS earned a first-place finish, and ABC was second with lineups of repeats. CW edged past Fox to place fourth with The Vampire Diaries (3 million) and Nikita (3.4 million).

title: Scorecard | Calvin Klein Collection Wins!
description: And curtain! As New York fashion weeks marquee actors take their bows in the citys newest Theatre and Stage, Scorecard notes in the final reductive tally that theres no way American fashions perennial practitioner of architectural minimalism, Calvin Kleins Francisco Costa, wouldnt beat themall in the square the circle game.

title: Hot Tea, Cool G.O.P.
description: When is a party not a party, but instead a marine echinoderm? The answer is, according to National Journals invaluable Jonathan Rauch, when its a Tea Party. The tea party began as a network, not an organization, and that is what it mostly remains, he explains. This is a coordinated network, not a hierarchy. There is no chain of command. No group or person is subordinate to any other. The tea parties are jealously independent and suspicious of any efforts at central control, which they see as a sure path to domination by outside interests  Lava is a pretty good analogy. Ask the activists to characterize their organizational structure, however, and usually they will say it is a starfish.

title: A Vision of a Place for All Faiths
description: Imagine Yom Kippur 2016: a steady stream of Jews file into a gleaming 13-story building two blocks from ground zero. Maybe one peeks inside the mosque on the buildings ground floor to see whether a friend from her Turkish cooking class is there, then heads up to the third floor, where glass cases display artwork from Western and Middle Eastern artists on the theme of, oh say, fractured identity.

title: For Amy Ryan, Inspiration Found Around the Corner
description: WHEN Im in L.A., I am terribly alone and bored, the actress Amy Ryan said as she bounded down the stairs to catch the Q train to Brooklyn. I need the pulse of New York City. I like to steal.

description: In Cardiff, Wales, on Thursday, the United States regained the Buffett Cup, taking an insurmountable lead over Europe, with 18 boards to be played. The final result was 109 to 89.

description: A physicist and his wife, who both once worked at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, were arrested Friday and charged with a criminal conspiracy to help Venezuela build an atom bomb.

description: The Social Innovation Fund, a federal program to encourage the expansion of promising nonprofit projects, on Friday released the names of independent reviewers involved in helping it award $50 million in grants, taking a further step to address criticism of its transparency.

description: The City of New York said Friday that it would not hire a new class of firefighters using proposals laid out by a federal judge, who had ruled that the test used to screen Fire Department applicants discriminated against African-Americans and Hispanics.

description: ITS not often that the Suffolk County Historical Society in Riverhead hosts an art exhibit, said Wallace W. Broege, the historical societys director. But Helen M. Kroeger & Otto J. Kurth: The Anchorage Studio and Peconic Bay Impressionism fits in, he said.

description: Right-clicking on a file and choosing the Send To menu in Windows 7 gives you several options, like sending the file to a mail recipient or compressing it into a ZIP archive. If you want even more choices about where you can send the selected file, hold down the Shift key while right-clicking. An extended version of the Send To menu appears, with options for putting the file in the Documents, Music and other folders.

description: LONDON  Naomi Minegishi, 21, a Japanese woman who lived in China for 10 years, recently took a job with the London property broker Felicity J Lord.

description: Nearly two years after Citigroup received a second government bailout and was ordered by regulators to shrink, the bank agreed on Friday to sell its student lending business in two parts, to Discover Financial Services and the lender Sallie Mae.

description: In his short life, Ousmane Coulibaly, a 19-year-old high school senior in Manhattan, has seen plenty of adversity. He grew up poor in Mali, was estranged from his family at 13 and has lived on the street there and in New York. An illegal immigrant, he is staying in a homeless shelter while he tries to graduate and obtain a special immigration status reserved for young people who have been abandoned or abused.

At a 1962 Phantom V Landau Rolls-Royce, covered in mirrors, that looked like a disco ball on wheels. At Liberaces collection of candelabras, rings, capes and boots.

Bush.

The artist Fritz Haeg has transformed the museums formal front lawn into a more rustic-looking fruit and vegetable garden. And inside the building is a cornucopia of small exhibitions, many devoted to artists who live or work in the area.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The killing of an exiled Pakistani politician in London shut down most of Pakistans largest city, Karachi, on Friday as the police contained unrest and moved to prevent wider violence.

description: ON a recent drizzly afternoon in Bushwick, Brooklyn, members of the Bushwick Food Cooperative gathered beneath a tent in a ramshackle backyard to claim their share of the weekly harvest. They picked through crates of cilantro and rosemary from a rooftop farm in Long Island City, Queens, and examined pastured eggs from an Amish farm cooperative in Pennsylvania.

description: THE 63 photographs that Michael Anthony lent to the American Labor Museum in Haledon for its exhibition Allied Textile Printers have not only personal meaning but also historical value.

title: Charges Dropped for 3 Accused of Planning to Riot
description: Prosecutors have dropped charges against three of seven people accused of organizing a dangerous criminal gang and planning to disrupt the 2008 Republican National Convention in St. Paul with a host of unorthodox tactics. The case, which focused on an anarchist group called the R.N.C. Welcoming Committee, was widely regarded as the marquee criminal prosecution to emerge from the convention.

title: Tech Firms Said to Be in Talks to Settle Inquiry Over Recruiting
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A number of Silicon Valley companies including Apple, Google and Intel are in advanced negotiations with the Justice Department to avoid facing charges that they violated antitrust laws by agreeing not to poach employees from each other, according to two people briefed on the negotiations.

description: CHICAGO  On a gray, damp morning this week, the home of Nancy Faust, White Sox organist, was alive with the sound of ring tones.

title: An Aura of Romance, Wine Not Included
description: YOU might wonder, as I did, how a tiny place like Amerigo Restaurant in Norwalk could survive without a liquor license. But Amerigo has been going strong since 1999. The keys to its success are its excellent Italian cuisine and the fact that its owners encourage patrons to bring their own wine. In many ways, dining at Amerigo is less like visiting a restaurant and more like being a dinner guest in the home of a very good cook.

title: The Corner Stall Office
description: MY friend Michael was facing a dilemma earlier this summer. He was running late at work; he was overdue to meet a friend; he needed to return the phone call of an important client, a Broadway legend, as he described her. So he did what many people do these days. He multitasked. He slipped into the lavatory; he dialed his client.

description: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Benjamin Zimmer of The New York Times discuss the language of "Mad Men."

The jersey was purchased on eBay for $7, but for Mr. Haavisto, who began collecting N.B.A. replica jerseys when he was 8, the rarity and historical significance of Mr. Abdul-Raufs make it an invaluable collectors item.

description: ROMAN ROTH recalled that when he joined Wlffer Estate Vineyard in Sagaponack as its first winemaker in 1992, you would call up a three-star restaurant in Manhattan and say, Long Island wine and they would throw the phone down. Literally, clunk.

title: Markets Seek to Eliminate Stub Quotes
description: NYSE Euronext, Nasdaq OMX Group and Bats Global Markets asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to eliminate stub quotes, or bids and offers as low as pennies or as high as thousands of dollars provided by market makers. Stub quotes are placeholders provided by market makers to satisfy a regulatory obligation to submit both bids and offers. On May 6, during the so-called flash crash, companies like Accenture tumbled to a penny as traders pulled out of the market, leaving fewer bids in order books.

title: Two Different Worlds
description: I didnt notice much when a terrific storm slammed into parts of New York City on Thursday evening. I was working at my computer in a quiet apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. The skies darkened and it began to rain, and I could hear thunder. But thats all. I made a cup of coffee and kept working.

title: A Day About the Farm
description: In early October, when pumpkins turn from green to orange and cornstalks rustle in the wind, Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture, in Pocantico Hills, will mount its seventh annual Harvest Fest to raise money for farm camp scholarships, school programs and training for young farmers.

title: Defeated Alaska Senator to Run Write-In Campaign
description: Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, who lost her states Republican primary last month to a Tea-Party-backed conservative, announced late Friday that she will run as a write-in candidate in the general election.

description: ONE of my favorite dishes at River City Grille in Irvington is the petit filet mignon, cooked just as ordered and served with fresh peas and crunchy fries (substituted for mashed potatoes without any problem). Another is the Thai beef, marinated in ginger, soy, garlic and hoisin sauce, pan sauted and served with nicely dressed noodles in peanut sauce.

description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is preparing to seek Congressional approval for a huge arms sale to Saudi Arabia, chiefly intended as a building block for Middle East regional defenses to box in Iran, according to administration and Pentagon officials.

description: DES MOINES  Sarah Palin delivered what she called a quick woodshed moment, criticizing Karl Rove and other leading Republicans here Friday evening for failing to rally behind some of the partys newest crop of nominees by suggesting that some of the candidates cannot be elected in November.

description: BROWN CROSSWORD WEEK concludes.

title: Mr. Geithner and China

So it was good to hear Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner speaking out this week on Capitol Hill, warning that an undervalued Chinese currency makes it more difficult for goods and services produced by American workers to compete.

title: Ducking for Cover Before the N.R.A.
description: The Obama administration still has not nominated a director for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. That can only be seen as a dangerous homage to the National Rifle Association, whose legions of Congressional sycophants undoubtedly are just waiting for the cue to trash whomever the White House chooses. Thats still no excuse.

description: The Obama administration has made many pledges of transparency and openness, but neither of those fundamental principles were anywhere to be seen when the Pentagon opened its first military trial at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, under President Obama. What we did see were intolerable limitations on journalists covering the trial  or at least trying to cover it.

title: Dark Comes
description: I dont go looking for the places of deep comfort on this farm. They call out to me. Why does the mounded hay in the horses run-in shed look so inviting? Why does the chicken house  warm and tight and brightly lit  feel like a place where I could just settle in? I climb the ladder to the hayloft and the barn cat watches me warily from his redoubt in the hay bales. I feel like getting my sleeping bag and joining him.

title: Brooklyn Malls Try to Limit Youth Loitering
description: It is afternoon in Brooklyn, and school has just let out. Swarms of teenagers crowd the sidewalks, looking for a place to socialize. But near Downtown Brooklyn, at the entrances to the Atlantic Terminal mall, there is no hanging out at one popular meeting spot. Students are met by security guards, who block their path, ask questions and check IDs.

title: Circling Manhattan (Bring Extra Socks)
description: WALKING the High Line? Thats cute. The length of Central Park? Bucolic. The marathon? Try adding six miles. Circumnavigating Manhattan is the ultimate and extreme city walking tour and promises the seemingly impossible: a path less traveled on an overly trodden island. Half sightseeing tour, half endurance test, the journey at Manhattans edge takes you into the shadows of 19 bridges, through as many parks and past art installations, city landmarks and 360 degrees of ever-changing views.

title: Texas: Voting Machine Fire Remains a Mystery
description: A warehouse fire that destroyed most of Harris Countys voting machines last month broke out in a back room used for classes and storage, but trained dogs found no traces of a flammable liquid in the spot where it started, investigators said Friday. Fire marshals have not ruled out arson, but it may take months to reach a conclusion, said Patrick Trahan, a spokesman for the Houston Fire Department. Since the blaze, election officials in the nations third-largest county, which contains Houston, have been scrambling to buy or to borrow enough machines to hold the election in November, prompting many in political circles to speculate a saboteur might have been behind the fire.

title: Palin the Front-Runner?
description: According to a bipartisan chorus  right, center-right, and liberal  the victory of Christine ODonnell in Delawares primary proves that the race for the Republican nomination in 2012 is no longer wide open, because Sarah Palin is officially the front-runner. This strikes me as bunkum for many of the reasons that Ramesh Ponnuru and Daniel Larison discuss, and especially for this one: It is extremely unlikely that the political landscape in the winter and spring of 2012 will resemble the political landscape in the autumn of 2010. Even setting aside the unpredictability of economic developments, foreign-policy crises, and everything else that could shift the ground beneath our feet, the reality of having a more empowered Republican Party in Washington and a weaker President Obama in the White House will almost certainly work profound changes on the countrys mood  and yes, in the mood of the Republican base as well. (Its hard to be quite so fired up and furious about socialism when Washington is mired in gridlock, and its hard to be quite so outraged at RINO perfidy when youve kicked a lot of the RINOs out of office.) The temper of conservative politics in the fall of 1994, the off-year election cycle that most resembles this one (it was a year, as Rich Lowry notes, when a former homeless man defeated the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee), bore little resemblance to the temper of conservative politics in 1996, when Bob Dole cruised to the Republican nomination over more base-pleasing candidates like Pat Buchanan and Phil Gramm. And while its likely that the Tea Parties will lend a greater resilience to the present anti-establishment spirit, 12-t0-18 months of divided government will almost certainly have a dampening effect on the impulses that carried Christine ODonnell to victory.

title: The Patch
description: Urban farming is the latest Bay Area trend everywhere except downtown Sonoma, where city crops have been harvested for more than a century. Only about a block from Sonoma Plaza and across from Vella Cheese on Second Street East is The Patch, a 140-year-old, six-acre farm yielding Mission figs from century-old trees and Goldie heirloom tomatoes, as seen on farm-to-table menus at Barndiva in Healdsburg.

title: Hits Few and Far Between, Mets Prospect Keeps Battling
description: Lucas Duda and his father, David, talk regularly about hitting. The elder Duda has taught Lucas since he was a boy, from Little League through the professional ranks. Even when the two are separated by thousands of miles, they chat on the phone about the way to hit a baseball properly.

description: For as long as there have been cyclists in the city, there have been pedestrians who have viewed them as a dangerous menace.

description: In Gregory Wattss 13 years as a San Francisco police officer, he has arrested countless drug dealers. But only recently did he begin to notice that many of them resembled his grandparents.

title: 3 Protesters Are Killed in Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI  The death toll in the restive region of Kashmir continued to rise on Saturday, with at least three more protesters being killed, including reports of security officers firing on a crowd that had defied the curfew to march in the funeral procession of a young boy.

title: For Thome, Nothing Adds Up to a Ring
description: CHICAGO  For a man who swings so ferociously, like a lumberjack with a hammer ringing the bell at a county fair, Jim Thome is all soft edges. He keeps his hair short, and his ears stick out, and he looks you in the eye when he talks. He nods and smiles a lot, often repeating things, earnestly, for emphasis. He is 40 and built like a mountain, yet somehow he seems like a boy.

description: VENICE  Legend has it that the Bridge of Sighs, which connects the Palazzo Ducale here to an ancient prison, got its name because it gave convicts on the way to serve their sentences a last glimpse of the limpid lagoon.

description: Second baseman Luis Hernandez, up from the minor leagues and trying to establish a name for himself, earned at least a footnote in Mets history with a singular moment of pain and gain Saturday afternoon when the Mets lost, 4-2, to the Atlanta Braves at Citi Field.

description: PITTSBURGH  An art gallery sent crews into the cramped basement of a die-hard Steelers fan to box up his vast and eccentric collection of black-and-gold paraphernalia.

title: With Torre on Market, Who Should Mets Pursue as Manager?
description: Don Mattingly, who will take over the Dodgers next season, would have been an intriguing choice as manager of the Mets if for no other reason than the consternation it would have caused Yankees fans if Mattingly had then gone on to win a World Series ring in Queens.

title: Stitching a Life From the Scraps of Others
description: About 300 Warao people live by Venezuelas sprawling trash dump Cambalache, combing it for food, clothing and scrap metal.

title: Left Behind in Venezuela to Piece Lives Together
description: CIUDAD GUAYANA, Venezuela  The first scavengers one sees in Cambalache, a sprawling trash dump on this citys edge, are the vultures. Hundreds drift through the veil of smoke that rises from the refuse each day at dawn.

title: Missouri Tells Judges Cost of Sentences
description: ST. LOUIS  When judges here sentence convicted criminals, a new and unusual variable is available for them to consider: what a given punishment will cost the State of Missouri.

title: Manfred Gans Is Dead at 88; Combed Wartime Europe for His Parents
description: He was 16 when his parents sent him to England, fearing for his life as a Jew in Nazi Germany, and when war broke out he clamored to join the British armed forces. Finally he was accepted, his fluency in German earning him a spot with a secret commando unit. And with that, Manfred Gans set off on a mission: to find his parents.

title: Americas Cup Reunion Revels in 12-Meter Era
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  With their multihulls and carbon-fiber bodies, the new Americas Cup boats are light and lightning fast. But it is their predecessors, the sleek 12-meter yachts used from 1958 to 1987, that warm the hearts of veteran sailors. More than 700 people, including 250 sailors, gathered last week at the waterfront home of the New York Yacht Club for their first reunion, three days of racing and a backward glance at what many call the golden age of sailing.

title: An Appointment With the Cable Guy?
description: Anyone who has ever wasted half the day waiting for a cable TV technician who showed up late or not at all will find satisfaction in the contract that New York City is close to finalizing with the cable companies. The consumer protection provisions are long overdue and timely, given that Time Warner Cable and Cablevision are now providing not just television but Internet access and telephone service as well.

title: Pitchers Path to Major League Debut at 30 Was No Pipeline
description: The Kansas City Royals used two pitchers against the Oakland Athletics on Monday. The starter was Luke Hochevar, and the reliever was Bryan Bullington. They each began their professional careers as the No. 1 overall pick in the draft.

title: Longtime Official, Hobbled by Bad Knee, Plans a Comeback
description: An envelope containing the N.B.A.s referee schedule arrived in Steve Javies mailbox the other day, as it has every September for the last 25 years. This one felt different.

title: Blacks Debate What Is Next in the Wide-Open Mayoral Race
description: The last time anyone not named Daley had a legitimate shot at being elected mayor of Chicago, the city was an emotional tinderbox. Residents and politicians were still reeling from the sudden death two years earlier of Harold Washington, Chicagos first black mayor, and the racially charged council wars that raged during his administration.

title: Huskers Young Quarterback Upstages Locker
description: SEATTLE  Nebraska Coach Bo Pelini said he could not predict how the redshirt freshman quarterback Taylor Martinez would perform in his first start in a hostile environment.

title: A Spruced Up, More Profitable 18 Holes, but Still ...
description: The Park District hired new management last year, hoping to improve the shabby condition of its six golf courses.

title: Florida Beats Tennessee but Still Has Long Way to Go
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  Moments into his postgame news conference Saturday, Florida Coach Urban Meyer seemed to pause and consider the uneven play of the 10th-ranked Gators. He said he understood that his team, which is dotted with freshmen, redshirt freshmen and first-time starters, had not come together yet.

title: With Torre Available on Job Market, the Mets Manuel Knows the Score
description: In a light moment Saturday before the Atlanta Braves beat the Mets, 4-2, at Citi Field, Manager Jerry Manuel discussed Joe Torre, the Dodgers manager, who is choosing to leave his job.

description: U.S. Soccer announced on Friday that the mens national team would play South Africa in an exhibition game on Nov. 17 in Cape Town. The friendly will take place three years to the day after the Americans first trip to South Africa, and it will be their fourth trip to the country in the last 36 months.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Last Wednesday night, Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter pretended to be hit by a pitch and was awarded first base in a 4-3 loss to the Tampa Bay Rays. Although many people in baseball considered his act a shrewd maneuver, many readers viewed it less positively. Here are some of their responses:

title: Haunted Man of the Cloth and Pioneer of Gay Rights
description: The death this month of Seymour Pine, the vice officer who in June 1969 led a police raid on the Stonewall Inn in Greenwich Village, unwittingly galvanizing the gay rights movement, is a reminder that history has its forgotten actors, too. For every star in the history of gay rights  think the politician Harvey Milk, or the comedian Ellen DeGeneres  there are many more bit players, people whose names do not even make the credits.

title: The Mechanisms of a Controlled Trial
description: In the United States, the Food and Drug Administration must approve an experimental drug like PLX4032 before it can be marketed. The process involves several stages, including laboratory and animal studies; controlled clinical trials for safety and effectiveness; and F.D.A. review. The trials are in four phases:

title: New Drugs Stir Debate on Rules of Clinical Trials
description: Growing up in Californias rural Central Valley, the two cousins spent summers racing dirt bikes and Christmases at their grandmothers on the coast. Endowed with a similar brash charm, they bought each other matching hardhats and sought iron-working jobs together. They shared a love for the rush that comes with hanging steel at dizzying heights, and a knack for collecting speeding tickets.

title: G.O.P. Insider Fuels Tea Party and Suspicion
description: WASHINGTON  In the days leading up to the Delaware primary, Sal Russo hosted a radio fund-raiser, organized a political rally and pressed the case with reporters that Christine ODonnell was the Tea Partys choice for the United States Senate. He also set off what he calls a money bomb, pouring at least $250,000 into television and other advertisements promoting the little-known candidate.

description: The day in college football.

title: Sabathia Reaches 20 Wins for the First Time
description: BALTIMORE  No one has been better the past year at pitching at home than C. C. Sabathia. And he might as well have been pitching at Yankee Stadium on Saturday considering how many Yankees fans packed into Camden Yards.

description: Cornwall, England, is a mecca for retirees and second-home owners.

description: A three-bedroom, four-story town house in the Ixelles Neighborhood of Brussels is on the market for 850,000 euros ($1 million).

description: A condo in downtown Nashville, a house in Boise, Idaho, and a house in Pittsburgh.

title: Q. and A. With Rick Cerone
description: After being drafted by Cleveland out of Seton Hall University in 1975, Rick Cerone played catcher for eight teams, including the Yankees and the Mets, in 18 major league seasons. He brought minor league baseball back to his birthplace in 1998 as the owner of the Newark Bears. Last month, Cerone, 56, participated in a golf tournament to benefit the Sean Kimerling Testicular Cancer Foundation, which works to raise awareness of the importance of early diagnosis and treatment. Kimerling, who died of the disease in 2003 at age 37, was an anchor for WPIX and a pregame announcer for the Mets.

title: Obama Rallies Congressional Black Caucus
description: WASHINGTON  For seemingly every occasion where two or more Democrats gather these days, President Obama plays the role of commander in chief for his partys get-out-the-vote operations, and Saturday nights gala benefit for a Congressional Black Caucus foundation was no different.

description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass.

title: Girardi Comments After Another Guthrie Pitch Hits a Yankee
description: Joe Girardi is none too pleased with the Orioles right-hander Jeremy Guthrie, and it is not the first time.

title: Dissonance on Green Detergents
description: As I note in a Sunday article about the new, low-phosphate dishwasher detergents, consumers are not always thrilled about the performance of environmentally friendly cleaning products. But such products have been gaining acceptance, mainly because of health concerns. Many states and local governments have passed laws requiring the use of these products in schools and other government institutions. Labor unions representing janitors and housekeeping staff have meanwhile begun to push for language in their contracts to also require less toxic products.

title: Vows: Laina & Nelson
description: Laina Vlasnik agreed to date Nelson Yip if he'd draft a list of the top 10 things to do in New York.  He obliged, and on their first date she concluded she'd found someone delightfully different.

title: Philippine Troops Kill Wanted Militant
description: MANILA  Military officials said Sunday that Philippine troops had killed a top Islamic militant who had helped plan and carry out the kidnapping of three Americans and 17 Filipinos from a popular resort in 2001.

title: Joining the Two-Wheelers in Prague
description: Not so long ago, riding a bike through the streets of Prague was what many locals deemed a death wish. There were few bike lanes and the idea of cyclists rights, as in most post-Communist capitals, was an alien concept. This is all exactly what makes the Critical Mass ride through Prague, to be held on Sept. 25, unique in comparison to some other mass bike rides in cities that have long embraced a pedal-to-work culture.

title: All the Group Buying Deals in One Place
description: With so many group buying sites out there now, it can be hard to keep tabs on all the deals available. Luckily, aggregation sites will now put together, and even sometimes sort through, these collective buying coupons for you from the likes of Groupon and others.

title: The Sorrow And The Self-Pity
description: Everywhere you look these days, there are terrible stories. I live in a very sheltered world, yet I know young people just out of college who cant find jobs, men in their late 50s who have lost their jobs and cant see how theyll ever find another, families barely scraping by and terrified by what might happen if anyone gets sick.

title: Dozens Dead After Baghdad Car Bombs
description: BAGHDAD  Two powerful bombs ripped through the capital, and one hit the western city of Falluja on Sunday, killing at least 35 people and wounding more than 100. It was one of the worst days of deadly mayhem since the American military declared an official end to its combat operations in Iraq nearly three weeks ago.

title: Taiwanese Tourists Shot in New Delhi
description: NEW DELHI  Two armed assailants riding a motorcycle opened fire on a tourist bus parked outside of New Delhis most famous mosque on Sunday, in an attack that comes as the city prepares to host the Commonwealth Games in two weeks.

title: A Seneca Indian Connects With His New York Roots
description: Into a hotel suite of white wine, gray hair and Oxford shirts, the ponytailed Seneca entered in his bright red duck cloth frock, knitted strips tied around his beaded leggings and a broad medal across his chest inspired by the one George Washington gave his great-great-uncles uncle, Red Jacket.

title: After Afghan Vote, Complaints of Fraud Surface
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The farmers in Nagahan, a village in Kandahar Province, lined up early to cast their votes on Saturday, but there were no ballots and no ballot boxes, making the election seem a cruel joke.

title: Cloud Computing Hits Snag in Europe
description: BERLIN  In the world of ideas, cloud computing has the potential to revolutionize the way people work.

title: Wallace Turner, Pulitzer Prize-Winning Reporter, Is Dead at 89
description: Wallace Turner, who shared a Pulitzer Prize for exposing corruption in Portland, Ore., as a reporter there, and who later illuminated the inner workings of the Mormon Church while covering the American West for The New York Times, died Saturday in Springfield, Ore. He was 89 and lived in Eugene.

title: U.S. Says BP Well Is Finally Dead
description: The federal government declared BPs Macondo oil well dead on Sunday, nearly five months after it blew out of control, unleashing an environmental calamity in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Two Lives, Two Loves, One Con Man
description: Big Love, an HBO series about a Mormon mnage  quatre, opened minds to the notion that a man can manage three wives. But it was a reality show, The Bachelor, that trained viewers to believe that a young man can be passionately in love with two women at the same time.

title: Missing Religious Group Found Alive in California
description: PALMDALE, Calif.  The frantic search began after police issued an alert: Members of a cult on the edge of the Mojave Desert had disappeared, leaving behind handwritten notes that raised fears they had planned a mass suicide.

title: The Sunday Word: Third Party?
description: As the primary season comes to an end, Washington is trying to make sense of how the Tea Party fits into a two-party town.

title: Ahmadinejad Wants Release of Iranians Held in U.S.
description: One of the three American hikers held in Iran for 13 months on spying charges arrived in the United States on Sunday as the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, said that the United States, as a humanitarian gesture, should now release eight Iranians whom he said were illegally arrested.

title: Consumer Spending and the Economy
description: The U.S. economy is predominantly driven by consumer spending, which accounts for approximately 70 percent of all economic growth. But if consumers are to continue to drive the economy, they must be in a sound financial position; if they become overburdened with debt, they are not able to maintain their position as the primary driver of economic growth. To that end, consider the following table which shows the total amount of household debt (all consumer loans and mortgages), total nominal gross domestic product, total nominal disposable personal income, the ratio of household debt to G.D.P. and the ratio of household debt to total disposable personal income. All numbers are in billions:

description: The tech blogs were abuzz Sunday with a report in TechCrunch that Facebook is secretly building a phone.

title: Michigan State Coach Has Heart Attack
description: Michigan State Coach Mark Dantonio had a heart attack late Saturday, shortly after the Spartans thrilling overtime victory against Notre Dame.

title: E.U. Laws Shielding Journalists Sources Limited
description: PARIS  In January 2008, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France declared his intention of protecting reporters from having to disclose the names of their sources  a safeguard that many journalists say is necessary for free media to thrive.

title: Rat Race America
description: Brad DeLongs post on Todd Henderson, the already-infamous whining Chicago professor who appears to be near the 99th percentile but feels poor, is worth reading for more than the takedown. Brad isnt the first to make this point, but his discussion of how rising inequality at the top  a fatter right tail in the income distribution  makes the objectively rich feel poor is exceptionally fine:

title: Bailing Out the Big Guys, Posthaste
description: In the epilogue to his new book, Overhaul, Steven Rattner tallies up the bill for the government assistance that spared General Motors, Chrysler and their financial subsidiaries and automotive suppliers from ruin.

title: Torre and Mattingly to Attend Steinbrenner Ceremony
description: BALTIMORE  Joe Torre is scheduled to attend the monument dedication to George Steinbrenner at Yankee Stadium before Monday nights game against Tampa Bay, his first visit since a bitter split after the 2007 season ended his successful 12-year run as manager. General Manager Brian Cashman said last week that Torre was welcome anytime.

title: Newsweeks Howard Fineman to Join The Huffington Post
description: Howard Fineman, one of the more recognizable pundits on cable television and a correspondent for Newsweek for 30 years, is leaving the magazine to become a senior editor at The Huffington Post.

title: Pope Ends British Trip With Beatification
description: BIRMINGHAM, England  A day after drawing both adoring crowds and the largest protests of his papacy, Pope Benedict XVI wrapped up a historic and contentious four-day visit to Britain on Sunday, moving a Catholic convert one step closer to sainthood and recalling the valor of Britons during the Second World War.

title: Protesters Return to Bangkok Streets
description: BANGKOK  Antigovernment protesters returned to the streets here on Sunday in a large but short-lived demonstration that underlined the persistent divisions in Thailand four months after a military crackdown.

title: Swedish Anti-Immigration Party Claims Seats
description: STOCKHOLM  Sweden became the latest European nation to see a breakthrough for populist right-wingers Sunday, when the anti-immigration Sweden Democrats won their first parliamentary seats in elections that failed to produce a clear outcome.

title: Live Analysis: Jets Beat Patriots, 28-14
description: They looked deflated. The faith in their quarterback seemed to be wavering. Their coach was on the verge of becoming the butt of jokes around the N.F.L. But the Jets were never defeated, and they displayed their resolve against the rival New England Patriots.

title: After Six Decades, Paterno Is Year to Year
description: With a 24-0 victory over Kent State on Saturday, No. 23 Penn State won its 500th game since Joe Paterno joined the staff as an assistant coach in 1950. That is a long time and a lot of games, but Penn State does not have a succession plan in place for the 83-year-old Paterno.

title: Surfboards, Harmonies and Sheet Metal
description: Nymph

title: Five Dead in German Hospital Shooting
description: BERLIN  A woman opened fire Sunday in a hospital in Germanys Black Forest in the south of the country, killing four people and seriously wounding several others before fatally shooting herself, German officials said.

title: Mets Showing Signs of Pluck, if Not Improvement
description: Luis Hernandez hobbled into work Sunday on crutches with a medical boot on his right foot to protect his broken big toe. His season is over but the reason for it may linger in Mets lore.

title: Ask an Expert About Melanoma
description: In her ongoing series in The New York Times, Amy Harmon describes the promise and challenges of new drug testing for melanoma, the most deadly form of skin cancer. Todays story, New Drugs Stir Debate on Rules of Clinical Trial, describes two cousins who developed the lethal cancer; only one could take part in an experimental drug trial.

title: At the Buffett Cup in Wales, a Defensive-Signaling Show
description: The third Buffett Cup, contested between Europe and the United States last week in Cardiff, Wales, featured several excellently played and defended deals. The one in the diagram exhibited signaling that makes defense more accurate.

title: The Meat Eaters
description: Viewed from a distance, the natural world often presents a vista of sublime, majestic placidity. Yet beneath the foliage and hidden from the distant eye, a vast, unceasing slaughter rages. Wherever there is animal life, predators are stalking, chasing, capturing, killing, and devouring their prey. Agonized suffering and violent death are ubiquitous and continuous. This hidden carnage provided one ground for the philosophical pessimism of Schopenhauer, who contended that one simple test of the claim that the pleasure in the world outweighs the painis to compare the feelings of an animal that is devouring another with those of the animal being devoured.

title: For ODonnell, Rewinding to the 90s
description: Christine ODonnells opponents are going to the videotape, and there is plenty of it.

title: Estate Of Confusion
description: Digby finds another hard-working, wealth-creating salt of the earth type complaining about the possibility of higher taxes: Ben Stein. I think I need a drink.

title: City Critic: A Ceremony, Not Marriage
description: At the Manhattan Marriage Bureau, a lesbian couple experiences the new individual commitment ceremony offered to those registering for domestic partnership.

title: The Kisses, the Bites, the Humor of Rodgers and Hart
description: An insomniacs fantasy of a dream lover hovering over your bed night after night; a prayer for true love that is answered by the sudden appearance of the perfect mate; a mystical moment of romantic dj vu: those are experiences described in Dancing on the Ceiling, Blue Moon and Where or When, three of the most famous songs by Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart. To hear Karen Akers sing them in her revelatory Rodgers and Hart show, Dancing on the Ceiling at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, is almost like listening to them for the first time.

title: Monday: Longevity
description: We have a special behind-the-scenes feature below, but first, todays record-setting puzzle.

title: A Pair of Travelers, Saving London Puzzle by Puzzle
description: Remember edutainment?

title: The Sailor Who Fell Into Grace With the Wig-Wearing Nymphs
description: A questing hero, a cigarette-smoking ballerina, a grove of white-wigged nymphs and a corps de ballet of Louise Brooks look-alikes populate the deliriously strange, funny world of Alexei Ratmanskys Namouna, a Grand Divertissement  perhaps the oddest and most delightful ballet to pop up in recent memory.

title: Pettitte Provides the Good News in Losing Effort
description: BALTIMORE  Around the Yankees, the word playoffs is not taboo, even with a berth yet to be clinched this year. They fully expect to be playing beyond September  through October, to be precise  which is why Manager Joe Girardi did not flinch Sunday morning when asked whether three starts were sufficient for Andy Pettitte to round into postseason form.

title: Snapshots of One Dancers Life Give a Glimpse Into an Art Form
description: Jrme Bel is a French choreographer who doesnt create steps. Instead he lets others do that for him, whether its the dancers whose stories he shapes in documentary-like accounts of their lives or the singers whose words he converts into a literal physicality.

title: Snippets of Sensation, Clanging Violence and Raging Solos
description: Carrie Aherns dance installation SeNSATE, originally shown at the Brooklyn Lyceum, began as a collaboration with Nietzsche scholars. Now in residence at the Vault at 14 Wall Street, the underground bank vault where it was first created, the only obvious point it shares with Nietzsche is a sense of nothingness. In the case of this performance, presented by Ms. Ahern and the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, that is hardly a good thing.

title: 'SeNSATE'
description: Images from Carrie Aherns dance installation at an underground bank vault in New York.

title: Anxiety Wrapped in Gleaming Pop and Lam
description: Kevin Barnes, the Lady Gaga of indie rock, didnt stint on polymorphous spectacle when his band, Of Montreal, began its two-night stand at Terminal 5 on Friday night. His seven backup musicians were all dressed in white, while dancers appeared as fish-headed robots, skulls, angels in silver bikinis, faceless checkerboard-skinned aliens and, at one point, a blond dragon for Mr. Barnes to ride.

title: A Sitcom With More Than Empty Calories
description: Statistics from The Journal of the American Medical Association tell us that two-thirds of men and women in this country are overweight or obese, and this figure doesnt even account for the legions of perpetual dieters who merely consider themselves too big. Much of television, by design or effect, strips away at the confidence of the very heavy  what is left of it after the world has had its way. Series like Desperate Housewives or Cougar Town flaunt the radical thinness of middle-age women; competitive reality spectacles like The Biggest Loser perceive obesity as laziness, suggesting that it can be combated and self-esteem improved by the simple application of free-market principles.

title: The Heart That Beats, Heats, Chills and Whips
description: Sometimes a kitchen is just a kitchen, but not often. If a house is a machine for living, as Le Corbusier said, then the kitchen is its engine. If that machine is seen as a living organism  a house that is a home  then the kitchen is its heart and brain.

title: 'Counter Space'
description: Images from a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

title: New CDs
description: SANTANA

title: The Song Remains the Same, but the Breed of Cop Has Changed
description: One of the longest-running crime shows on television, Hawaii Five-O, the remake of which begins on Monday, had its debut in 1968 and did not make its exit from American living rooms until the end of the Carter administration. The rich cinematography offered provocative incentives for leaving the mainland, which, in the shows imagination, thieves, swindlers, hit men, loonies and dropouts were doing in droves, turning Hawaii into a modern Wild West that required especially rigorous law enforcement.

title: Wedding Bells Thwarted by Bothersome Conspiracy
description: The Event, which begins Monday on NBC, is in some part a series about a young couple just starting out, but to describe it that way would be like calling 24 a drama about an unusual number of traffic hassles occurring during a single day. As the series unfolds, Sean (Jason Ritter), a rumpled but well-meaning romantic, and Leila (Sarah Roemer), an earthy blonde, are about to become engaged, except that  and here I quote from NBC press materials with verbiage I could not surpass  their futures are on a collision course in a global conspiracy that could ultimately change the fate of mankind. Couples counseling is unlikely to provide solace.

title: As Killings Mount in Houston, Marshal Dons Cowboy Boots and Starts Running
description: Chase may be the ideal title for a series from the Jerry Bruckheimer Television factory, with its suggestion of relentless propulsion and no time to stop and think. The pilot episode on Monday night on NBC opens with a shot of the pounding feet of the shows star, Kelli Giddish, and spends its first three and a half minutes tracking her as she runs down a bad guy, disrupting a ceremonial cattle drive along the way.

title: The Town Enjoys a Strong Opening
description: The Town, Ben Afflecks robbery thriller, walked away with a stronger-than-expected $23.8 million in ticket sales over the weekend, enough to make it an easy No. 1 at the North American box office. Mr. Affleck (above, in the film with Rebecca Hall) directed, acted in and was a writer of The Town, which Warner Brothers backed with an aggressive marketing campaign. (An Oscar push is next.) Easy A, a teenage comedy from Sony Pictures Entertainment, was second, with about $18 million in sales, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. Devil, a horror entry produced by M. Night Shyamalan and distributed by Universal Pictures, finished third, with $12.6 million. Sonys Resident Evil: Afterlife 3D plummeted to fourth place in its second weekend, selling about $10 million in tickets for a new domestic total of about $44 million. Rounding out the Top 5 was Alpha and Omega, an animated movie that Lionsgate has marketed to very young children, with about $9 million in sales.

title: Organizers Dissolve the New York Collegium
description: The New York Collegium, a period-instrument band that sometimes performed with a chorus, acknowledged in a news release signed by two of its directors on Saturday what had become apparent over several seasons: that it would no longer function as an independent entity. The Collegium, whose Web site still lists the English early-music specialist Andrew Parrott as its music director, gave its first concert in early 1999 and performed series through the 2006-7 season. The name has since surfaced almost solely in connection with an annual workshop, the Clarion-Collegium Week, instituted in 2008 and shared with the Clarion Music Society. That society, founded in 1957 by the period-instrument pioneer Newell Jenkins, who died in 1996, has been revivified under Steven Fox, its artistic director since 2005. The Collegium will dissolve and continue its legacy under the umbrella of the Clarion society, the release said. The directors, evidently speaking for the full board, pointed to the Collegiums successes, but added, We nevertheless believe that the current economic environment will not support the sustainability of an independent Collegium. Clarion, they said, has made clear its intention to add several Collegium directors to its board, to continue the Clarion-Collegium Week and to maintain a relationship with Mr. Parrott.

In June Mr. Whitfield was said to be cancer-free, and the second season was tentatively scheduled to make its debut in September 2011. The new diagnosis has upended that plan. Our hearts and prayers are with Andy and his family during this difficult time, Chris Albrecht, the chief executive of Starz, said in a statement. Andy is not only an incredible actor whose portrayal of Spartacus made an indelible impression on Starz audiences, he is also an amazing human being whose courage, strength and grace in the face of adversity have inspired all of us.

title: Guggenheim Narrows YouTube Video Entries

The shortlist of 125 films  by students, video artists, photographers, filmmakers, composers, video-game programmers, a chess champion, an improv comedy troupe, an electronic music producer, a rock band and a hip-hop group  will be on display in kiosks at the Guggenheims museums, as well as on the YouTube channel. title: Frank Zappa Bust Unveiled in Baltimore
description: There will come a time, Frank Zappa sang, when everybody who is lonely will be free to sing and dance and love. And there will come a time, he vowed, when you can even take your clothes off when you dance. Until then, the city of Baltimore has found a more traditional way to honor Zappa, the genre-bending avant-garde rock musician who was born in Baltimore and died in 1993, with a bust in his likeness that was dedicated there on Sunday, The Associated Press reported. In a ceremony timed to the 25th anniversary of Zappas Senate testimony, at which he compared the labeling of explicit records to censorship, and attended by Zappas widow, Gail, his sons, Dweezil and Ahmet, and daughter Diva, as well as Baltimores mayor, Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, a bust of the mustachioed, pony-tailed Zappa was unveiled atop a 12-foot pole outside the Southeast Anchor Branch of the Enoch Pratt Free Library. It isnt very large, but the bust is a replica of a similar sculpture in Vilnius, Lithuania. The duplicate was donated to Baltimore by the Lithuanian nonprofit organization ZAPPART. Hed be wildly amused by this, Gail Zappa told The A.P., because of the absurdity of these guys in Lithuania coming up with this phenomenal sculptor who normally does busts of Stalin.

title: Even Silence Has an End
description: Painfully, I tore myself away from the light, turned on my heels, and plunged into the thick matted darkness. It had begun to rain again. It was difficult to walk; every other step I tripped. I had my hands out in front of me to avoid obstacles. I couldnt see a thing. I hadnt managed to get hold of a machete, but I did have a flashlight. The risk involved in using it was as great as the fear that prevented me from using it. I went slowly into this threatening space and told myself I would switch it on only when I couldnt take it anymore. My hands collided with wet, rough, sticky surfaces, and I expected at any moment to feel the burn of some violent poison. The storm was raging. I could hear the thundering of the rain pounding on the canopy of vegetation that for a few more minutes would protect me. I expected the fragile roof of leaves to yield and open under the weight of water at any moment. The prospect of the flood that would soon submerge me made my situation all the more distressing. I no longer knew whether it was raindrops or my own tears that were flowing down my cheeks, and I hated to have to drag along this relic of a sniveling, shivering child, when I knew that I couldnt allow myself any weakness.

title: The Peace Dividend
description: On a crisp morning in Sarajevo, the filmmaker Danis Tanovic breezed through the front door of Delikatesna Radnja wearing designer sunglasses and a newsboy cap. There are something like 1,300 cafes in Sarajevo, each embodying a unique ambience and clientele  Zlatna Ribica (the Goldfish) has a speakeasy aesthetic and serves a famed Mexican coffee; Kino Bosna is a converted movie theater known for its live music, rakija (a local fruit brandy) and unabashed seediness. The Delikatesna Radnja, with floor-to-ceiling windows that face the Miljacka River and the mountains beyond, caters to the theater and film crowd. Tanovic, who directed No Mans Land, winner of the 2002 Oscar for best foreign language film, is something of a celebrity here. While the waiter prepared macchiatos for us, Tanovic chatted up customers at nearby tables. With his heavy eyelids and tendency to speak out of the side of his mouth, he resembled a younger, stockier Robert DeNiro. He seemed to know everyone in the room.

title: Why Generic Ballots May Underestimate Democrats

The generic ballot, as of last week, pointed toward a Republican lead of 7 or 8 percentage points among likely voters, according to our estimates. Local polls are a little bit less straightforward to read because you have to make a lot of adjustments for polls that are (i) partisan, (ii) bad, or (iii) both. But in general  while there is a lot of variance from district to district  the local polls seem to point toward a House vote that would be about evenly divided.

title: The Place | A Guide to Marrakesh, Part Two

However, La Porte dOr, in the thick of the souks, is the real deal. Marc Jacobs, Tom Cruise and Edgar Kauffman, who picked up carpets for his Fallingwater house, have all shopped here. The staff will guide you through a vast selection  kilims from the Glowa tribe, carpets made from 400-year-old silk  and pass on valuable tips. (Lambs-wool rugs wont shrink; a double-knotted weave lets you restore holes.) The shop also ships. 115 Souk Semmarine; 011-212-524-44-54-54.

Like most rechargeable batteries, the one in the Volt will slowly lose its abiltiy to store energy, though; G.M. will give the battery a warranty for eight years and 100,000 miles, although it says it should last 10 years.

title: The Bugs You Can Eat
description: In most cultures outside of North America and Western Europe, tiny many-legged creatures are a delicacy, and an important source of protein, Jeff Gordinier writes in a report on a five-course Mexican feast featuring insect cuisine last Saturday in Brooklyn. Here in the United States they represent the growing realm of gastronomic spelunking. For omnivores who want to take it to the next level, Tom Turpin, a professor of entomology at Purdue University, offers information on three common bugs you can easily buy, prepare and cook.

But as Marcel Duchamp discovered in 1919, sometimes drawing a mustache on the Mona Lisa (or a copy of it) is exactly the right thing to do, and it may be that having the right artist paint the right mustache can yield some insight about the lady with the faint smile.

description: WASHINGTON  The White House said Tuesday that Lawrence H. Summers, the chief architect of President Obamas economic policy, would leave at the end of the year, continuing an exodus of top-level advisers at a time when voters are expressing deep dissatisfaction with the presidents stewardship of the economy.

title: Theater Renovation Welcomed as a Gain for Arts in Brooklyn

description: THE opening of a palatial new boutique on the priciest stretch of Madison Avenue during a downturn, when so many storefronts have papered their windows, raises questions. Who are these people? Are they from an alternate dimension where there is a parallel, but separate, economy? Can they fly?
