title: Nutritious Chips: Not an Oxymoron
description: The Rorschach allure of the dark, leafy shapes have you admiring the crisp kale chips before you nibble. Thin and glazed with various seasonings, they not only are snack worthy and packed with nutrients, but they also can be used for dipping or as a salad topping or a garnish for all sorts of dishes, like baked fish or even soups. Amy Hamberry and Joe Orr make them by dehydrating kale in their Brooklyn plant, where some magic makes than taste fried. They come in three flavors: spicy miso, vegan cheese and, my favorite, Bombay curry, which I would certainly serve with an Indian dinner.

title: At the Latest Food Complex, Dim Sum Gets Into the Mix
description: Ed Schoenfeld and Jeffrey Chodorows FoodParc, the citys latest food complex, cuts straight through the new Eventi Hotel and will lead to a spacious park, which will open to the public in October. For now, only the indoor section, with a futuristic design by Syd Mead, is open. At RedFarm Stand, the dumpling master Joe Ng (above) is fashioning inventive shumai, some served on skewers; potstickers; assorted egg rolls, including one filled with Katzs Deli pastrami; salads; and seared short rib on a bun. Opposite is a bar, and nearby Fornetti features flatbreads with various toppings, including salad. The 3 Bs refers to bacon, burgers and beer and is where the food also includes grilled cheese, bacon optional. The Press is a coffee and juice bar that also sells newspapers.

title: Gastronomes Await Modernist Cuisine
description: THE wait for the 30-hour cheeseburger just got a little longer. The dish, which takes more than a day to prepare, calls for a short-rib patty to be slow-cooked in a vacuum pack, then dunked in liquid nitrogen before it is deep fried. It is among more than a thousand recipes in Modernist Cuisine, a cookbook whose publishing delay, announced on Sept. 15, set off a collective sigh among gastronomes.

title: Doctors Orders: Eat Well to Be Well
description: OAKLAND, Calif.

title: New Wonjo Restaurant
description: IF you judge by appearances, New Wonjo Restaurant is the same Koreatown standby it was when it was just plain Wonjo. Its still open 24 hours a day, and the menu is still the size of a ledger. As always, runners thread through the busy upstairs dining room carrying braziers of glowing coals for the in-table grills in what must be one of the most unsafe, if exhilarating, opening acts to a meal youll find in Midtown.

title: El Bulli and a Meal for the Ages
description: MORE than a year ago, before anybody had the slightest inkling that a potential closing was in the offing, I achieved the unexpected coup of a reservation at El Bulli, Ferran Adris temple of avant-garde dining in Spain.

title: Oil With Flavor You Can See
description: The bottle of Esperanto Oil holds a jumble of spices, whole and crushed, that give it a ruddy color and a bright, complex flavor, heightened by cumin and fennel. Drizzle it on fish, pork chops, roasted vegetables, plain ricotta or even toasted country bread. Most of the seasonings stay in the bottle, keeping the flavor of the remaining oil going. Its concocted by Esperanto, a pan-Latin restaurant in the East Village.

title: At Bonny Doons Restaurant, Dinner With, Oh, Yes, Wine
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.

title: Spiking Summer Fruit in Order to Preserve It

title: Preserving the Dewiness of Youth
description: IN the last decade, the dermatologist Dr. Nicholas Perricone has become an outspoken platoon leader in the battle against aging. Mostly, his troops of true believers were the wrinkled middle-aged. They bought into his theory that inflammation causes aging, and that eating wild salmon and blueberries would make their skin glow anew.

title: Cantors Try to Heal Rift Through Song
description: In the old days, the best cantors  Jewish clergy who specialize in the musical interpretation of prayer  were stars. Many dressed to the nines and had entourages that followed them in the street and crowded into temple to hear them sing. Thats because Good synagogue is good show, as one current practitioner says, quoting his boyhood cantor, in 100 Voices: A Journey Home.

For though Peter Pilotto picked a peck of polymorphous prints on the fourth day of shows, Londons prince of perversity already had the prim-and-prudish-princess-on-acid thing pinned down.

title: More Legal Drama for Wednesdays, From New York to Las Vegas
description: If you are an assistant district attorney meeting the tormented parents of a murdered and apparently angelic teenage girl for the first time, what do you do? Well, if you are confronting this circumstance in a Jerry Bruckheimer television production, you offer up extraneous self-explanation. I love the law, says the prosecutor with the pixie haircut early on in The Whole Truth. It is the only thing I am good at. Just ask anybody unfortunate enough to be involved in my personal life.

Better with you, as opposed to without you, implying squabbling partners? Or better with you, as opposed to with someone else, implying the act of choosing a partner?

title: New Worlds to Conquer, Even for Casual Rulers
description: When you think of the most evocative characters in video games, various commandos and knights and even a plumber come to mind. But Ive always been taken by the image of a tiny band of settlers in the vast wilderness of an unknown world at the very dawn of recorded history, 4000 B.C. On a riverbank they build their first huts and begin to discover what separates men from beasts: pottery, writing, mining, the wheel.

description: The LRX concept car, unveiled by Land Rover at the 2008 Detroit auto show, is coming to production in 2011 as the Evoque, which will break cover Sept. 30 at the Paris motor show.

description: IN a narrow, high-ceilinged theater space on 14th Street in Chelsea this summer, congregants sat raptly on white folding chairs as a man in a black suit and skinny tie made his way down the aisle to the front of the room. With his mop-haired colleague wolf-whistling through an effects-filtered microphone, he proceeded in slow motion, as though he were underwater, until he got to the front of the assembly.

title: Tower Plan Clears Hurdle
description: One obstacle to construction of a tower designed by Jean Nouvel next to the Museum of Modern Art has been removed. Justice O. Peter Sherwood of State Supreme Court in Manhattan last week rejected a petition by nearby residents to have the projects approvals by the City Council and the New York City Planning Commission overturned. The petitioners  two local residents associations (the West 54-55 Street Block Association and the Coalition for Responsible Midtown Development) and three individual residents  oppose the planned tower, which is to include a hotel, residential apartments and space for the museum, on the ground that it would be too tall for the neighborhood. In his decision Justice Sherwood said the Council and the Planning Commission had not acted irrationally or arbitrarily, as the petitioners had charged. Before approving it, the Planning Commission required that the towers height be reduced to 1,050 feet from 1,250 feet.

title: Manuel Questions Torres Integrity

title: Giving Voice to Sylvia Plaths Pregnant Women
description: ROBERT SHAW, the British producer and director, has rather unusual taste in vacation reading. While most of us fill our overnight bags with Stieg Larsson novels, fashionable memoirs or local guide books, Mr. Shaw found himself some years ago lazing about in his Dubrovnik hotel reading the poetry of Sylvia Plath. A Web site hed chanced on mentioned that Plath had written a radio play in verse, Three Women, which the BBC had broadcast in August 1962, less than six months before her suicide. Mr. Shaw soon located the piece, a forceful meditation on pregnancy and childbearing. He read it, he said, and decided: This is powerful. This is incendiary. I have to go with this. I have to pursue it.

title: Dancing Leads Night of Strong Debuts
description: The 11th-season premiere of ABCs Dancing With the Stars, featuring Bristol Palin and the Jersey Shore star Mike Sorrentino, known as the Situation, topped the ratings on a Monday night packed with series debuts. According to Nielsens estimates, 21 million viewers tuned in to Dancing, down from the 24.2 million who watched the spring premiere in March, but up considerably from last Septembers debut (18.8 million). Also posting strong ratings were CBSs re-imagined version of Hawaii Five-0 (13.8 million viewers), which at 10 p.m. led premieres of ABCs Castle (11.2 million) and NBCs Chase (7.9 million). At 9, NBCs new conspiracy thriller The Event (11.2 million viewers) also made a solid debut, but the premieres of CBSs sitcoms Two and a Half Men (14.5 million) and Mike & Molly (12.2 million) fared better. Foxs new drama Lone Star drew just 4.1 million in its premiere at 9.

A reporter for the Kyodo News, Japans foremost news service, Nagao was once at one of the centers of Japanese baseball in the United States, surrounded by a legion of colleagues with cameras, digital recorders and notepads aimed squarely at Kosuke Fukudome, the multitalented right fielder for the Chicago Cubs.

Months earlier, meticulous thieves had entered the Left Bank apartment of Picassos granddaughter and cut away the works, leaving without a trace. One of the men, Jean Sala, 61, whose heart condition delayed the trial, was sentenced to four years, as was Paula Sabbah, 57. It quoted the leader of the Movement for Democratic Change, Morgan Tsvangirai, as warning that his party would not participate in elections until a new constitution was adopted and the violence stopped.

title: Illinois: Congressman Denies Dealing for Senate Seat
description: Representative Jesse Jackson Jr. on Tuesday denied a report that he told a fund-raiser to offer former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich campaign contributions in exchange for appointing Mr. Jackson to Barack Obamas Senate seat. The account appeared in The Chicago Sun-Times, which said the fund-raiser, Raghuveer Nayak, told the authorities that Mr. Jackson wanted Mr. Blagojevich to know that he would help him raise $6 million. The report also said that Mr. Nayak paid for two airline trips for a social acquaintance of Mr. Jacksons. Mr. Jackson did not appear to report the trips as a gift on financial disclosure forms, according to The Sun-Times. In a statement, Mr. Jackson said: The allegations about fund-raising and the Senate seat are not new. Ive already talked with the authorities about these claims, told them they were false, and no charges have been brought against me. The very idea of raising millions of dollars for a campaign other than my own is preposterous. He said the reference to a social acquaintance is a private and personal matter between me and my wife that was handled some time ago.

Mr. Kropf, who recently lost his job at another store on the base, died Tuesday morning. A motive for the shooting has not been determined, the F.B.I. said.

title: Kafkas Last Trial
description: During his lifetime, Franz Kafka burned an estimated 90 percent of his work. After his death at age 41, in 1924, a letter was discovered in his desk in Prague, addressed to his friend Max Brod. Dearest Max, it began. My last request: Everything I leave behind me . . . in the way of diaries, manuscripts, letters (my own and others), sketches and so on, to be burned unread. Less than two months later, Brod, disregarding Kafkas request, signed an agreement to prepare a posthumous edition of Kafkas unpublished novels. The Trial came out in 1925, followed by The Castle (1926) and Amerika (1927). In 1939, carrying a suitcase stuffed with Kafkas papers, Brod set out for Palestine on the last train to leave Prague, five minutes before the Nazis closed the Czech border. Thanks largely to Brods efforts, Kafkas slim, enigmatic corpus was gradually recognized as one of the great monuments of 20th-century literature.

He fails to mention that this may be much more difficult for a woman traveling alone. I lived in Morocco for eight months on a Fulbright grant, and traveled quite a bit around the country. In Tangier, like many cities I visited in Morocco, it was not advisable to be out alone at night if you were not a male or accompanied by one. Come-ons aloud and whispered, being followed in cars, the occasional grab: none of these are much fun. Matt Gross, as a man traveling alone, perhaps did not think about any of this as none of it happened to him, or perhaps he did not think to ask any of the women he met.

Finally after a deafening burst of fireworks, the soup-tureen-shaped reliquary began to descend the stairs, carried by a group of local men in dark suits and priests dressed in gold.

description: Ed Ou, 23, was born in Taiwan and grew up in Vancouver, Canada. He spent the last four years in the Middle East, Africa and the former Soviet Union. On June 13, his photographs of very young fighters accompanied Children Carry Guns for a U.S. Ally, Somalia, by Jeffrey Gettleman. Mr. Ou has been based in Nairobi as a photographer for Reportage by Getty Images and is soon to begin working as a photo intern at The Times. His remarks have been edited and condensed.

description: The latest attempt by the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan to derail BHP Billitons $39 billion hostile bid could be somewhat of a Hail Mary pass, possibly pointing to the beginning of the end of this takeover battle.

title: Did Firehouse Subs Pick the Right Plan?
description: In a case study weve just published, Kermit Pattison writes about Firehouse Subs, a fast-food sandwich chain based in Florida. When the recession hit, the chains sales took a dive. At first, Firehouse responded by rescinding the 2 percent marketing fee it had been collecting from its franchisees and encouraging them to spend that money on local marketing. When that failed, the chain took a very different approach: it asked its franchisees to increase the amount of money they were spending on marketing and it unleashed an $8 million advertising campaign  right into the teeth of the recession. It also chose Zimmerman Advertising to handle its corporate account.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Cookies and Orb
description: Are you being followed online? If youve ever used the Flash program from Adobe to watch videos  and odds are you have  you may have code on your computer that tracks your Web browsing, sending that information to companies that may sell it or use it for tailored advertising. On this weeks Tech Talk podcast from The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein talks to Tanzina Vega, a Times media reporter, about so-called Flash cookies, which have raised privacy concerns and prompted lawsuits from consumers against companies involved in this form of tracking.

title: Googles Chief Defends His Privacy Comment  or Joke
description: Eric E. Schmidt, Googles chiefexecutive, has faced some pretty tough critics in the past, defending the companies stance on privacy issues and new features on the Web site, but on Tuesday, he went right into the lions den when he was a guest on The Colbert Report on Comedy Central.

title: Festival Spotlights Emerging Playwrights
description: With readings of new plays, performances and panel discussions, the inaugural New Black Fest for emerging black playwrights is set for Oct. 9-17 in New York, the organizers announced. In addition to readings of six new plays at Bric Arts/Media/Bklyn (in Fort Greene, Brooklyn) on Oct. 16 and 17, festival highlights include a panel discussion on arts and activism featuring Suzan-Lori Parks (Topdog/Underdog) and Kia Corthron (Breath, Boom) at the Juilliard School on Oct. 10 and a cabaret-style evening of performances at Bric Arts on Oct. 14, which will present new work from Eisa Davis (Passing Strange) and Colman Domingo (The Scottsboro Boys). The seven playwrights whose works will be featured are Kwame Kewi-Armah (Seize the Day), Keli Garrett (Space), J. Nicole Brooks (Black Diamond), Radha Blank (Nannyland), Cori Thomas (When January Feels Like Summer), and Godfrey L. Simmons and Brandt Adams, authors of Dispatches From (A)mended America.

title: Letter: War Games
description: I was fascinated by Chris Suellentrops article on war games. It touched on the business of entertainment, the horrors of war and the moral ambiguity of the very idea of virtual war through computer games. But for the record, while I take no offense at the generality that my cable-TV miniseries are always about World War II, only half of the series my company has produced for HBO are about that war.

title: Migrant Workers Hear From Guggenheim
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and its government-owned partner in Abu Dhabi, the Tourism Development and Investment Company, issued a joint statement on Wednesday committing to protect the rights of migrant workers building the Guggenheims vast new museum in Abu Dhabi. According to the statement, all companies involved in the construction must provide workers with electronic wage payment, overtime provisions, 30 days paid annual leave, a weekly day off and health insurance. They will also pay all recruitment fees for their employees. In a news release, Human Rights Watch, which previously raised concerns about how workers building the museum would be treated, called the museums action a positive step but said it fell short, noting that the Guggenheim had not explicitly required companies to reimburse workers for recruitment fees that they are found to have paid. Human Rights Watch said that the Guggenheims announcement also lacked provisions for independent monitoring of working conditions.

title: More Shows Return as Hasselhoff Departs
description: The return of NCIS gave CBS a ratings victory on Tuesday night, drawing 18.9 million viewers for its eighth-season opener, according to Nielsens estimates. That was the nights largest audience, outperforming ABCs Dancing With the Stars results episode (18.3 million) in which David Hasselhoff was sent packing. CBS finished strong with a two-hour season premiere for NCIS: Los Angeles (14.6 million) while ABC got a so-so start from its new crime drama Detroit 1-8-7 (9.8 million). On Fox, the second season of Glee (12.3 million) got off to an impressive start, but ratings dropped off considerably for the networks new comedies Raising Hope (7.5 million) and Running Wilde (5.9 million). NBC finished a distant fourth with the 10th edition of The Biggest Loser (7.2 million) followed by Parenthood (5.9 million).

title: Letters: Living to Be a Parent
description: I feel compelled to correct a common misperception about evolution that appears in Lisa Belkins essay. We do not as a species act in particular ways to benefit the species. A primary premise of evolutionary theory is that individuals behave in ways that maximize individual reproductive success, relative to other individuals within a population. Hereditary behavioral traits of individuals that help them to increase the proportion of their offspring in future generations will thus be selected for, i.e., become more common; this process results in evolution.

title: Ways to Remove a Broken Plug
description: Q. The headphone plug broke off in my laptops sound jack. Is there anyway to fix this so I can listen to my music?

title: Letters: Engineering Terror
description: I am not going to comment on the statistics and methodology of Gambetta and Hertogs analysis, but their description of the engineers mind-set is off base, behind the times and deserves clarification. Most leading universities in the U.S. are cultivating thinking skills completely opposite to what they state as a preference for clear answers to ambiguous questions. The goal of my own school  and I know that we are not alone in this  is to produce whole-brain thinkers. We want to produce engineers who are firmly grounded in analysis, logic and rational thinking but who also have intuitive and metaphorical thinking skills  the kind that open up new avenues of thought.

title: Democrats Offer a Change in Campaign Finance Bill
description: Senate Democrats said on Wednesday that they would change their campaign finance disclosure bill so that it would not take effect until January 2011, a revision that they characterize as an attempt to overcome a Republican filibuster.

title: Paths Converging on a Rhythmic Base
description: Closing out his first set at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night, the drummer Antonio Sanchez finally opened the floodgates and let loose. He was playing Challenge Within, a tune based on a streamlined Afro-Latin groove, in 10/8 meter. His left foot tapped a cowbell in a modified clave pattern, steadily syncopated; the rest of his body seemed intent on framing rhythm as a blur. This was virtuoso stuff, almost drumming as sport, and while it served the purpose of the tune, it also justified its climactic placement in the show.

He was 1.25 ahead of his partner in the pair and team segments, Zia Mahmood.

title: Now Seating | Franz West at Gagosian
description: The Austrian artist Franz West has long made art that can picked up or sat down upon without reservation as well as actual furniture that has the presence of sculpture. If I would give the truthful answer, he says, I would have to say that I really do not think in such categories between furniture and sculptures. His latest installation, Roman Room, at Gagosian Gallery in Rome, makes a practical distinction if not a conceptual one. A cluster of sculptures made largely from papier-mch, foam, gauze and cardboard, perched on low pedestals, intermingle with a pair of linen sheathed sofas and a chair that West created specially for the occasion. I had the idea while watching my 3-year-old son looking up at the sculptures, the artist says of the arrangement. The seatings make for alternative positions and viewing platforms throughout the show.The sculptures, which, depending on how you look at them and also maybe how old you are, might bring to mind enormous, melting ice cream treats, are as lumpy and charming as the seating is lean and angular. Both exude comfort in their own way. When I was younger, I thought it was all right to make the visitor uncomfortable, West says. But now that I am older it would not be correct because my problems have gone.

title: Virgin to Debut Hotel Chain

The organization recently announced that it will soon make a logical addition to this roster: hotels.

title: The Challenges Facing Icahn at Blockbuster

But those creditors, led by the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, will face serious challenges in turning around Blockbuster, despite its advantages over some of its competitors.

description: Midway through my first pregnancy, I was told that I needed an injection that is standard for an uncomplicated pregnancy. I assumed it would be simple to get approval from my insurance company.

description: PHILADELPHIA  In his office at Temple University, Coach Al Golden keeps an air mattress inflated for the nights when he cannot make it home while orchestrating one of college footballs most remarkable turnarounds. Earlier this week, with Penn State looming, he did not even take a moment to make the bed.

description: This week on Popcast, The Timess music podcast, Jon Caramanica discusses the career of Jamey Johnson, an acclaimed country songwriter whose stark music is often likened to the outlaw genre in the 1960s and 70s as embodied by singers like Merle Haggard and Johnny Cash. But how well does Mr. Johnson fit that mold? And what does outlaw country mean, anyway?

title: Now Sparkling | The Kazanjian Red Diamond
description: The Kazanjian Red Diamond, one of the most spectacular gemstones ever discovered, goes on display today at the American Museum of Natural History. Red is the rarest color in diamonds  less than 20 are known to exist in the world today. Whats more, the Kazanjian Red Diamond has an amazing back story.

title: Finally, Professional Dictation Software for the Mac
description: Its been a long, crazy journey for Andrew Taylor. He was a young programmer with a dream to write a speech recognition program for the Mac. This was in a day when there were several available programs for Windows, but nothing for the Mac.

description: A 34-year-old Nicaraguan diplomat was found dead on Thursday morning, his throat slashed, in the apartment building where he lived in the Bronx, the police said.

description: The clients were surprised when the architect working on their Upper East Side apartment said: Count your ties and shirts. And Carol, I want shoe sizes.

title: Whitman Opposes Ballot Initiative on Emissions Law
description: 4:22 p.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELES  Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor, announced her opposition Thursday to a California ballot proposition that would indefinitely suspend implementation of the states landmark greenhouse gas emissions law.

title: Contractor Deaths in Iraq and Afghanistan Outnumber Service Member Deaths
description: More private military contractors than uniformed service members were killed while serving in Iraq and Afghanistan between January and June of this year, marking the first time that corporations have lost more personnel on Americas battlefields than the United States military, according to ProPublica, the nonprofit investigative reporting group. More than 250 civilians working under American contractors were killed in Iraq and Afghanistan during the first six months of 2010, while 235 soldiers died in that same period, according to the latest report in ProPublicas Disposable Army series.

title: An Early Look at Justin Biebers C.S.I. Debut
description: What bombs? What airplane? Guess we wont know unless we tune in to CBS at 9 p.m. Eastern time (8 p.m. Central). Anyone need tickets to tonights Pavement show?

title: Andrew Carmellinis Restaurant to Be Called the Dutch
description: The project at the corner of Sullivan and Prince Streets that appeared in the Timess fall restaurant preview as Andrew Carmellini Restaurant now has a proper handle.

title: Vanessa Bruno | L.A. Femme
description: Im not a typical French girl whos only been in Europe and doesnt know America, said the Parisian designer Vanessa Bruno, who spent her childhood summers road tripping with her supermodel mom in the Rocky Mountains and the Pacific Northwest. Now, Bruno has made her way back to the West Coast, opening her first United States boutique on Melrose Avenue in West Hollywood. (A London store is scheduled to open later this month.) I of course have the Parisian way of seeing things, she continued, but I definitely have this laid-back, young American spirit in what I do.

title: A Mingling of Leaf-Peeping and Time Travel
description: CONSTRUCTION began in 1846 on the Boston, Concord and Montreal Railroad, so business travelers and others have been gazing out the windows of trains huffing north into the White Mountains of New Hampshire for quite some time. Eddie and Brenda Clark only took the idea of a train rolling through tree-carpeted countryside and turned it into a lavish autumn excursion for sightseers in no particular hurry

title: A Leisurely Pace on the Foliage Trails
description: Vintage railroads that use steam or diesel engines do most of their business in the autumn, for good reason: the views of fall foliage from train car windows.

title: Arts by the Rails In Baltimore

title: Brooklyn Sounds, Brews and Chow: A Mile-Long Street Fair With Moxie
description: STROLLING a street fair should be a wholesome, cheerful endeavor, a chance to ogle artisanal wares, help a giggling toddler onto a pony or watch your buttoned-down neighbor slam power chords with his garage band. But New Yorks traffic-thwarting, tube-sock-peddling version  the kind that plagues Midtown Manhattan avenues in the summer  inspires something more like mass grumbling. The music is canned, the goods are suspect, and the entire enterprise seems aimed at tourists.

title: Are There Books That Should Be Banned From Your School Library?
description: Do you think there are books that you and your friends are not mature enough to read? Are there books that contain sexual or violent content, profanity, racial slurs, or religious or political messages that should not be available at your school? If so, how should that be decided? The last week of September is Banned Books Week, and we invite you to scan this list of Top 100 Banned/Challenged Books for 2000-2009 and think about the questions we pose here. Please post your responses below.

title: Ways to Celebrate Banned Books Week
Flight of the Honeybees
description: An epic battle broke out in Fort Greene after the tornado touched down in Brooklyn last Thursday. Soldiers attacked damaged fortifications and raided larders. Rescue efforts failed, and no one made it to the refugee camp. The queen is missing  presumed dead.

title: Early Morning Creativity, and Theater on Your Dime. Or Nickel.
description: Some grown-ups may need a refresher course in sharing, but the hosts of this weeks events deserve a gold star for inviting misers to take in their free lectures, music and games.

title: Tighter Credit Means Fewer Bankruptcies
description: For the past several years, the flagging economy has propelled a steady increase in personal bankruptcies. And while filings remain elevated, compared with previous years, they arent increasing as fast as they once were.

title: The Morning Skate: The Penguins Green Arena and the Igloo Blues

title: Vatican Defends Bank After Seizure of $30 Million
description: ROME  As an inquiry into its murky finances looked poised to widen, the Vatican swiftly went on the defensive on Thursday, saying that the seizure of $30 million from a Vatican bank account and the judicial investigation of the banks two top officials were the result of a misunderstanding.

title: At the Barre, but Not to Dance
description: IN a light-filled studio in Midtown Manhattan, the class wasnt even half over, but the students were already grimacing in pain. The dozen women stood in front of a ballet barre, feet in a V position, heels lifted and a soft ball between their thighs. They bent their knees and pulsed and pulsed, as if performing nonstop plis. After almost 60 repetitions, the cheerful instructor declared the set over, and the group sighed with relief.

title: Buried Alive at Fantastic Fest
description: For all that has been written about the shrinking world of independent film, there seems to be be no shortage of independent film festivals. But when hundreds of festivals around the country are vying for audiences, how do organizers make theirs stand out? Fantastic Fest, a festival in Austin, Tx., that devotes itself to genre cinema, likes attention-getting stunts.

title: A Week of Cooking and Eating Solo: Tuesday to Saturday
description: Last month Mark Bittman spent a week alone up at his place on Cape Cod. He kept track of what he cooked and ate for the seven days. Part 1 was the first three days; here is the rest of the week.

title: Instapaper Goes From Hobby to Start-Up
description: On TuesdayMarco Arment, the chief technology officer at the social networking siteTumblr, announced that he would be leaving it to tend to a personal project: Instapaper.

title: London Design Festival | Understatements
description: One of the more poetic sights at the London Design festival is Thin Black Lines, an exhibition of new works by the Japanese design office Nendo at the Saatchi Gallery. Organized by Brent Dzekciorius of the auction house Phillips de Pury, the show (on view until the end of November) consists of pieces in steel that look like delicate, geometric line drawings, but which, when seen from certain angles, suddenly snap into three dimensions. Oki Sato, Nendos founder, who likens the designs to Japanese calligraphy, says that they move alternately between the becoming and collapse of form. In an adjoining gallery, the Projectory is a pop-up store (in place until April) that Dzekciorius has stocked with edgy pieces by young designers like Peter Marigold, Oscar Diaz and Leon Ransmeier.

title: In New York, Cuomo Fires First Salvo Against Paladino
description: Andrew Cuomo released a television advertisement on Thursday in his first direct assault on Carl P. Paladino, his Republican opponent in the New York governors race. The advertisements came a day after signs that Mr. Paladino, a novice candidate who won an upset victory in the Republican primary last week, showed unexpected strength, including a poll that showed him surprisingly close to Mr. Cuomo, New York States attorney general. While a new poll issued Thursday showed a much wider gap, Mr. Cuomo, who had initially held Mr. Paladino at arms length, appears to have concluded that it was time to confront his opponent more directly. Read more about the race on the City Room blog.

title: Tax Cut Fold

title: City Says Investigation Uncovers Illegal Apartments
description: City inspectors posing as apartment hunters discovered dozens of spaces that had been illegally converted into residences, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Thursday.

title: Phish to Play New Years Day Concert
description: Phishs New Years Eve concerts, although not quite as celebrated as its costumed Halloween shows, are still the stuff of jam-band legend. Rolling Stone called the show on Dec. 31, 1995, one of the best concerts of the 1990s, and the bands year-end shows are responsible for at least one marriage.

title: Savory Bread Pudding, in Lieu of Potatoes
description: A dear friend of ours, Richard Miller, died recently, and a few of us got together to spend an evening doing pretty much what we used to do when we visited him in Paris: have a glass of vodka or Champagne (or both, sequentially) with some nibbles, then enjoy a simple dinner and pleasant conversation. Richard liked fancy restaurants well enough  or at least he indulged us and pretended that he did  but his favorite dishes were things like roasted and braised meats. If hard-boiled eggs napped with mayo  oeufs mayonnaise  were on the menu, he could rarely resist ordering them as a first course.

title: Keeping Score: When Good Prospects Go Bad
description: Plenty of baseball players have made a splash after being called up in midseason. But for Chris Carter, the As 23-year-old outfield prospect, this September is one he would just as well forget. Carter (not to be confused with the Mets Chris Carter or the former N.F.L. receiver Cris Carter) worked his way into the record books by going hitless in his first 10 starts. By the time he collected his first major league hit, on Sept. 20  a line-drive single off the White Sox Scott Linebrink  he had been waiting 11 games, 42 days and 34 at-bats.

title: Pregame Huddle: Early Tests
description: Alabama faces its first real road test against Arkansas, Notre Dame takes on Stanford and Boise State hopes to make a lasting impression against Oregon State.

title: The Battle of the Bulbs
description: Three House Republicans, Joe Barton and Michael Burgess of Texas and Marsha Blackburn of Tennessee, have introduced the Better Use of Light Bulbs Act, which would repeal the section of the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 that sets minimum energy efficiency standards for light bulbs and would effectively phase out most ordinary incandescents.

title: Small-Business Bill Advances; Campaign Finance Bill Stalls
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats failed Thursday to advance campaign finance legislation that would force businesses, unions and others to disclose how they were spending money in political campaigns and where they were getting it.

title: Outtakes From Documentary Shown in Court in Chevron Case
description: The footage showed an American lawyer, Steven Donziger, at meetings and during mealtimes, discussing his class-action suit against Chevron and ruminating about trial strategy and the workings of the Ecuadorian justice system.

description: The world can always use a little more glamour, and that was essentially the underlying message at the Prada spring 2011 show here in Milan tonight, set as it was on a raised runway covered in steel mesh. But this is Prada, and no one is more questioning of glamour  and the banality of luxury  than Miuccia Prada.

title: At Steinbecks Getaway as Heirs Feud Revives

title: It Takes Eight for Eclypse
description: Chalk it up to oversaturation, but the days of young bands blowing up overnight on MySpace are long gone. So its all the more surprising to hear stories like the one of the Band Eclypse. The New York area octet put together an EP, Ten Past, on their own, and self-published it on iTunes two weeks ago. Within 24 hours it had climbed to No. 9 on the music sellers influential hip-hop charts. The bands style is something of a 2010 update on the 1990s rap-rock formula, which sounds cringe worthy, but these teenagers (ages 14-19) put a spin on it that works. They rap over rock riffs reminiscent of MGMT and Phoenix, and set their rhymes into soft relief with an amazing shoegazer-y female vocalist. On the eve of their record release show on Friday at 7 p.m. at Santos Party House in TriBeCa, The Moment caught up with the band.

title: Picky Eaters
description: Franois Brouillard is waving something green under my nose, asking me if I think it smells like pineapple. (It does.)He has me sniff the clump of leaves in his other fist and, smiling impishly, asks if I think it smells like marijuana. Whatever it is, its bouquet is highly skunky. So far weve plucked and nibbled at cats tongue, garlic mustard flower, live-forever, linden, several violet species, spring beauty, stinging nettle, bellwort . . . and Ive lost track of whatever else.

title: War, Revolution and a King Who Says By Jove
description: A lot happens on the first page of Ken Folletts Fall of Giants. King George V is crowned at Westminster Abbey. A Welsh boy named Billy Williams turns 13 and begins his wretched life as a coal miner. And Mr. Follett, who was once a Welsh boy himself but grew up to become his generations most vaunted writer of colorless historical epics, kicks off a whopping new trilogy. His apparent ambition: to span the whole 20th century in blandly adequate novels so fat that theyre hard to hoist.

title: Seoul Ascending
description: Im standing with Cho Min-suk, one of Seouls foremost architects, atop one of his own skyscrapers, a luxury apartment complex called Boutique Monaco. And its only perhaps from here, on high, that one can grasp what is meant by the Miracle on the Han, as Seoul, South Korea, is sometimes known. A hundred years ago, the city had fewer than a million people. Today Seoul boasts 23 million, making it by some counts the second-largest metropolitan area in the world.

Now Celebrating | Lane Crawfords 160th
description: The Hong Kong-based Lane Crawford, Asias leading purveyor of all things luxury, is celebrating its 160 years of pioneering design by enlisting a small army of the stores style-setting friends from around the globe to create special pieces in honor of the celebration. Customized one-of-a-kind Burberry trenches were created by 23 top fashion folks like Anna Della Russo, Simon Doonan, Milan Vukmirovic and Lane Crawfords own gravity-defying fashion director Sarah Rutson, while eight antique Chinese Ming chairs were redesigned by the likes of Tom Dixon and Fornasetti. For the next 30 days, the Heritage 160 collection, as it is being called, is being sold off in an online auction to benefit Unicef. A store visit is also highly recommended in order to try on limited-edition reissues of iconic shoes from 13 top brands, including Jimmy Choo, Nicholas Kirkwood, Pierre Hardy and Christian Louboutin. Its sure to be a birthday party not to be missed.

His eyes were shielded by tinted shades rimmed in black, to enhance the 3-D sensation that the black sports car on the screen was real and that he was in command.

title: Following the Dots Around the City
description: Autumn in New York is the perfect time for an accidental festival of the work of the Pop artist Roy Lichtenstein. This one is made possible by three separate exhibitions spread around Manhattan, which seems only fitting. After all (and perhaps surprisingly), Lichtenstein was one of the few great American painters of the postwar era born on the island of Manhattan: in 1923, into the cushier precincts of the Upper West Side. He attended public school and then the private Franklin School for Boys before heading off to Ohio State University to study painting. He died in Manhattan in 1997.

Substituting fruits, vegetables and other bits of the natural world for human features, they tease the eye and sometimes turn the stomach. A ripe pear, for instance, looks suddenly unappetizing once its made to serve as a chin.

title: We Have a Situation
description: Im an attractive guy in my mid-30s. Because Im single, most of my Facebook photos are of me with beautiful women. The pictures document good times, not conquests. Still, I receive lots of catty comments from female friends. To them, these photos prove that Im a boastful player and a jerk. Why do they feel free to flame my social life?

title: Images of War, Finally Unpacked
description: Somehow, in the summer of 1970, I ended up in an anarchist campground deep in the mountains of Southern France. Most of the campers were young French and Italian live wires, tense, raucous, full of theater. But there was also a contingent of older people, Spanish Civil War veterans, still fugitives after 30 years, living out of the backs of vans.

title: Chinese Attitudes on Generosity Are Tested
description: BEIJING  Like most everything else in Chinas economy, philanthropy here is in a boom period, fueled by phalanxes of newly minted billionaires and foundations, encouraged by an army of professional advisers on charity and, increasingly, sanctioned by the government.

title: Images of History, Recovered
Robert Capa's Lost Negatives
description: Images from the show at the International Center of Photography.

title: A Moroccan Tradition in Full Cry
description: When the lights rose on the large, voluptuous women arranged on low cushioned benches in Bouchra Ouizguens Madame Plaza, it was easy for the mind to go to art historical references: the Venus figurines, Manets Olympia, or even the recent sculptural dances of Maria Hassabi, who embodies centuries of suggestively positioned women.

title: Auction Worlds Blast of Brash
description: IN 2006 when the market for contemporary art was red hot and dealers and collectors spent hours jockeying to be first in the door at Art Basel, the worlds most important contemporary art fair, Philippe Sgalot could be seen hanging back, his manner calm and self-assured. Thats because Mr. Sgalot, a private New York dealer, had pulled the stunt of all art-world stunts. He hired a Hollywood makeup artist to fly to Basel, Switzerland, and transform him into a balding nerd with Coke-bottle glasses. Then, using a fake exhibitors pass with his new face on it, he sneaked past the phalanx of security guards and into the fair days before it opened, reserving the best artworks for his clients well ahead of anyone else.

title: An I  Reprise for Milton Glaser
description: This morning we told you that Milton Glaser, the 81-year-old graphic designer emeritus of New York, sneakily submitted to The Times two of his own take-offs on his original I  NY logo for our growing collection of them. More than 50 of you tried to guess which pair of designs they could be.

title: Losing Battles
description: In the introduction to his 2003 collection of journalism, Death as a Way of Life, the Israeli novelist David Grossman wrote: The daily reality in which I live surpasses anything I could imagine, and it seeps into my deepest parts. In a note at the conclusion of his somber, haunting new novel, To the End of the Land, he explains that he began writing it in May 2003  around the same time he wrote that introduction, six months before the end of his older sons military service and a year and a half before his younger son, Uri, enlisted. At the time, he writes, I had the feeling  or rather, a wish  that the book I was writing would protect him.

title: Thais Bristle at Australians Take on Thai Cuisine
description: BANGKOK  Its been a rough year for Thailand. First there were the images of deadly street battles between soldiers and protesters beamed around the world. Then people living in neighboring dictatorships snickered that Thailand was a democracy in decline. Foreign tourists wondered whether it was safe to travel here.

description: The New York Film Festival  which begins its 48th iteration Friday night at Lincoln Center with a gala screening of The Social Network  is at once buoyed and burdened by its past. This is true of other festivals, too. Spend a few hours at Sundance or Cannes and you are bound to hear someone conjuring up the old days, when indie film really, you know, mattered or when Marcello Mastroianniwas standing right over there.

title: Aid Sought for Nuclear Plants
description: The federal loan guarantee program and other aid for new nuclear plants may not be enough to induce Constellation Energy to build a third reactor at its Calvert Cliffs site, 40 miles south of Washington, the companys president and chief executive said on Thursday.

title: The Thin Family Line: A Dynasty of City Cops
description: Six years ago, Edward Conlon, a New York City police officer who had been writing about his beat under a pseudonym for The New Yorker, published an acclaimed memoir about his experiences in law enforcement called Blue Blood. Mr. Conlon comes from a long line of cops and joined the family profession even though he had gone to Harvard.

description: The ABC legal drama presents both sides of its cases.

title: Busted
description: Randy Britton e-mails: Ive noticed in much of the coverage of the BP oil spill that the press has taken to calling the oil well busted. Since when is busted the proper way to describe a broken oil well? It seems very colloquial and not a form I would expect to see in proper journalistic forums. Even now that BPs troubled oil well in the Gulf of Mexico is being permanently sealed, news reports continue to refer to the busted well, particularly wire services like the Associated Press and AFP. Reuters was an early adopter, reporting on efforts to contain the busted well on May 3. Alternatively, busted has modified oil rig, or just plain rig. A database search of coverage of the BP spill finds the first recorded use of busted came nine days into the crisis on April 29, when the MSNBC host Ed Schultz said, The busted rig is leaking  get this  200,000 gallons of oil a day. Is busted overly informal for journalists? The verb bust certainly has colloquial roots, beginning its life on the American scene as a folksy variant of burst. (The same dropping of the r turned curse into cuss, horse into hoss and parcel into passel.) Building on earlier use as a noun, bust busted out as a verb as early as 1806, when Meriwether Lewis, while on his famous expedition with William Clark, wrote in his journal, Windsor busted his rifle near the muzzle. Since then, bust has worked its way into a wide variety of American expressions.  Bust runs the gamut from slang to standard, explain David K. Barnhart and Allan A. Metcalf in their book America in So Many Words. When it is used to mean to explode or fall apart or be arrested, bust is generally slang. In the sense of failing (especially financially) it is informal, as busting the bank in gambling lingo, while in the specialized sense of taming a horse it is standard, the only way to say busting a bronco. Despite its potential slanginess, busted is not actually forbidden in the news media, as the Boston Globe language columnist Jan Freeman wrote in August. Indeed, reporters often latch onto the occasional colloquialism that seems particularly expressive, and in this case, Freeman surmises they were drawn to the terms criminal-cowboy-macho connotations. Regardless of the reasons for its current vogue, its notable that busted was rarely relied on by the press to describe stricken oil wells before the BP disaster  even in incidents that were highly similar, such as the 1979 blowout of the Ixtoc I well in the Gulf of Mexico. Most of the precursors I found come from more literary sources. It was appropriate, for instance, in some light verse by J.W. Foley published in The New York Times in 1904: Dear friend, theres a question Id like to ask you, (Your pardon I crave if it vexes) Have you ever invested a hundred or two In an oil well somewhere down in Texas? Have you ridden in autos (I mean in your mind), With the profits you honestly trusted Would flow from your venture in oil stocks  to find That the oil well was hopelessly busted?  I cant find fault in reporters drawing on the rich history of bust and busted in American English to add a little extra oomph to their dispatches from the gulf. Calling the well busted does evoke a looser, wilder state of disrepair than broken, or the more technically accurate blown-out. But after many months of news coverage, the phrase busted well has now turned into little more than a clich. Thats a far worse journalistic offense than a bit of well-placed slang.

title: Player Strike Averted in Italy, for Now
description: MILAN  Footballers in Italy came very, very close to going on strike in recent weeks.

title: Roy Lichtenstein
description: Works by the Pop artist are on view in three separate exhibitions in Manhattan.

title: Altering Perceptions on an Astral Plane Trip
description: In Enter the Void the camera soars above the world like a bird, like a kite, like a ghost. It moves with smooth, gentle motions and seemingly indecisive purpose, passing through walls, drifting over alleys and climbing high above the roofs of a nighttime city agleam in jeweled color. At times it hovers next to one of the citys inhabitants like an angel or a threat. Occasionally it even appears to take up temporary residence in someones head  dive-bombing toward the back of a skull like a blow  so that it (and we) can see the world directly from another point of view: This is your brain. This is your brain on a Gaspar No movie.

title: S.E.C. v. Hedge Funds: This Week Its a Tie
description: Lets take a look at one win and one loss for the Securities and Exchange Commission on the hedge-fund front this week.

title: Spains Civil War, Inside a Suitcase
description: In Images of War, Finally Unpacked, Holland Cotter reviews an exhibition called The Mexican Suitcase at the International Center of Photography in New York, which documents wartime life in Spain between 1936 and 1939 through the eyes of three photographers  Robert Capa, Gerda Taro and David Seymour (Chim)  in images no one seems to have seen for more than a half century.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 23
description: A view of the day in sports, from fencing to rhythmic gymnastics.

title: Senate Wont Vote on Bush-Era Tax Cuts Until After Elections
description: Democrats have decided not to seek a pre-election showdown on the soon-to-expire Bush tax cuts, saying lawmakers will instead wage the legislative battle with Republicans in a lame-duck session in November.

title: Avis Raises Bid for Dollar Thrifty, Topping the Accepted Offer From Hertz
description: Just a week before shareholders of the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group vote on a proposed takeover by Hertz Global Holdings, the Avis Budget Group is keeping up the fight.

title: Leaping Off the Page, a Beatniks Poetic Rant
description: I saw the best poems of previous generations destroyed by sanity, well-fed, calm, neatly dressed, tiptoeing through lecture halls at 10 a.m. looking for a passing grade on a term paper.

title: Will Mow Lawns for Lone Star Eyeballs
description: The Texas soap opera Lone Star is, to date, the dud of the fall season, having attracted a disastrously low average number of viewers, 4.1 million, for its first episode on Monday. The show is lucky that it hasnt already been canceled.

title: Cutting Schools Energy Waste and Bills
description: The Clinton Global Initiative, which just completed its fifth conference, has become a bustling bazaar for ideas and investments aimed at making the world a better place. This week it indeed had the feel of a crowded marketplace. Hallways at the event in midtown Manhattan were flooded with well-heeled, well-intended people matching up with social, financial and technological innovators.

title: Fighting Words, Indeed
description: A political fund-raising opportunity lurks around every corner.

title: From Boehners Lips, Fodder for Democrats
description: The idea behind Thursday mornings news conference by House Republican leaders was not to provide ammunition for Democrats.

title: When Season Ends, Casey Is Ready to Ride
description: ATLANTA  At the conclusion of the Tour Championship, when every other top-10 player in the world travels to Wales for the Ryder Cup, Paul Casey will fly to Canada to ride mountain bikes in Whistler and Blackcomb Mountains.

title: Hoyer Jabs G.O.P. on Pledge Rollout
description: On Thursday, House Republicans formally issued their Pledge to America at a Virginia small business. Later in the day, the chamber passed legislation that aims to help small businesses over almost unanimous G.O.P. opposition.

title: Baz Luhrmann to Bring Strictly Ballroom to the Stage
description: Baz Luhrmann, the film auteur behind William Shakespeares Romeo + Juliet and Moulin Rouge, is moving forward on a long-intended stage musical adaptation of his first movie, Strictly Ballroom, with hopes of bringing it to Broadway someday, Mr. Luhrmann said in a phone interview this week.

title: Captive in Iraq, Stymied by Voice Mail
description: Buried is a horror movie with delusions of moral grandeur. One minute, the nightmare endured by Paul Conroy (Ryan Reynolds), a nonmilitary truck driver in Iraq who is buried alive and held for ransom, is a pulse-elevating thriller that wants to prick your deepest terrors of claustrophobic confinement.

title: 9/11 Conspiracy Theory Not as Popular as Ahmadinejad Says
description: As my colleagues Neil MacFarquhar and Liz Robbins report, at the United Nations on Thursday, Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, claimed that the majority of the American people, as well as most nations and politicians around the world agree that some segments within the U.S. government orchestrated the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks.

title: Lawyers Look to Exploit a Scientific Error
description: The spying indictment filed late last week against a former Los Alamos scientist contains evidence of tape-recorded conversations, clandestine meetings, confidential places for the transfer of documents and a pattern of false statements.

description: Click to Listen

title: When Fast Risers Start Slowly
description: Plenty of baseball players have made a splash after being called up midseason. But for Chris Carter, the Athletics 23-year-old outfield prospect, this September is one he would just as well forget. Carter (not to be confused with the Mets Chris Carter or the former N.F.L. receiver Cris Carter) worked his way into the record books by going hitless in the first 10 games he started. By the time he collected his first major league hit, on Sept. 20  a line-drive single against the White Sox Scott Linebrink  he had been waiting 11 games, 42 days and 34 at-bats.

title: Students Caught in the School Squeeze
description: One of the saddest days of my life was when my mother told me Superman did not exist, the educational reformer Geoffrey Canada recalls in the opening moments of Waiting for Superman, a powerful and alarming documentary about Americas failing public school system. She thought I was crying because its like Santa Claus is not real. I was crying because no one was coming with enough power to save us.

title: Outspoken, Irascible and Out of a Job, Chris Daly Improvises
description: It is something of a feat to be branded the most impossible, irascible, ultra-liberal politician in San Francisco. It is less of an achievement to be impossible, irascible and perhaps unemployable.

description: This is the second in a series.

title: Vietnamese Community Faces Tumultuous Race
description: The Vietnamese community has aligned itself with the Republican Party since the first refugees arrived in the United States from Communist Vietnam four decades ago. They brought with them a deep suspicion of left-leaning politicians; not wearing a South Vietnamese freedom pin was enough to doom a candidate.

title: Murder Defendants Text Messages Detailed
description: NEW HAVEN  Hours before the home invasion and killings for which they are both facing capital charges, two longtime criminals exchanged jaunty cellphone text messages about their plans. Their exchange included the signoff LOL, the abbreviation known to 12-year-olds and e-mailing grandmothers alike as shorthand for laughing out loud.

title: Its a Mean-Girl World: Are You Bully or Victim?
description: Pity poor Marni (Kristen Bell), a high school student with acne, bad hair, braces on her teeth and glasses. In the opening scenes of the stupefying comedy You Again, she is persecuted and branded a loser by Joanna (Odette Yustman), a bullying alpha girl, and her fellow cheerleaders.

description: MILAN  While other little girls in her hometown of Nissoria, Sicily, were dressing up and playing house, Maria Vittoria Longhitano would pretend to say Mass, dispensing cookies and chips to her toys for communion. Sometimes, she would even baptize her dolls.

Would the Mets consider making a bold move by asking Kasten to join the club as an overseer of the baseball department, a president of baseball operations who would pick a general manager and a field manager?

description: On Friday, because of Sukkot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

description: WASHINGTON  The House on Thursday repealed a section of the recently passed Dodd-Frank Act that let the S.E.C. keep secret nearly all information it gathers during investigations.

description: ATLANTA  Phil Mickelson, the defending champion, made two eagles on the back nine at East Lake Golf Club on Thursday en route to a one-under-par 69. That was the good news. The bad news is he made a bogey on the next hole both times.

description: MOSCOW  Of all the high priests of Russian officialdom, few have become more deeply entrenched in power than Moscows mayor, Yuri M. Luzhkov.

description: The official Major League Baseball statistics packet, available in every press box and clubhouse in the game, lists the teams according to batting average. The essential statistic should be runs scored, because runs win games.

description: The number of New York City elementary and middle school students who failed to move on to the next grade skyrocketed this school year, as weak students faced a higher bar on state tests and the broadening of the citys tough promotion policy.

description: ATLANTA  For all of the pretournament talk about the complex points permutations in the FedEx Cup playoffs, the first round of the Tour Championship on Thursday provided simple symmetry sprinkled with some real spice atop the leader board.

description: HONG KONG  Chinas Commerce Ministry denied on Thursday that it had halted exports to Japan of a crucial category of minerals, but industry executives said that factories in China were still not shipping to Japan after Chinese customs agents blocked shipments earlier this week.

Steinbecks Summer Home
description: The writers shack where John Steinbeck wrote Travels with Charley in Sag Harbor, N.Y., is the subject of a long-running and bitter real estate battle.

description: Andrew M. Cuomo, leaving little doubt that he is concerned about his Republican opponent, Carl P. Paladino, unleashed his first direct attack on Mr. Paladino on Thursday with a television advertisement that criticized him for his donations to Albany politicians and for his failure to create jobs after winning tax breaks intended to promote economic development.

title: Confronting Autism
description: Amid growing awareness of Aspergers syndrome and the spectrum of autism in general, Fridrik Thor Fridrikssons riveting documentary A Mothers Courage: Talking Back to Autism leaps into the mysteries surrounding the disorder, tracing the efforts of Margret Dagmar Ericsdottir, a mother in Iceland, to seek treatment for her severely autistic son, Keli. While the title is accurate, the film is less a portrait of her than an inquiry into the origins and nature of autism and therapies for it.

description: To the Editor:

title: Different Paths for Two California Republicans
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Both are former corporate chief executives, with personal fortunes, impressive rsums and famous friends. Both are conservatives who say that they have lived the American dream and fear for its future. And both are Bay Area women, with their eyes and ambitions firmly fixed on a change of address.

title: Giants Storied History, in 5,000 Square Feet
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  John Mara this week walked into the Giants new Legacy Club and went straight to his father Wellingtons old desk. He had remembered the pieces since he was a child  the gold F for Fordham paperweight; the small black binoculars Wellington Mara, the former owner, used to watch games; the framed photo of Ann Mara, Johns mother, taken at Yankee Stadium; the gray manual typewriter on which Wellington typed the speech he would give to usher Vince Lombardi into the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

title: Revisiting Katrina
description: By the time Hurricane Katrina passed to the east of New Orleans, it wasnt a once-in-a-lifetime storm; the city probably experienced no more than Category 2 conditions. And many of the levees that failed werent breached, but simply gave way because they had been improperly built on ground vulnerable to seepage.

title: U.S. Is Said to Rein in G.M. Stock Offering
description: DETROIT  The initial public stock offering by General Motors will be smaller than previously suggested, and the federal government will most likely sell a relatively small portion of its 61 percent stake in the company, according to people with knowledge of the preparations.

title: Jenkins Considering a Return
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  Sitting at his kitchen table on Wednesday night, Jets defensive tackle Kris Jenkins gave an unexpected answer about his football future: he is considering returning next season.

title: Who Stands for Standing?
description: The legal doctrine of standing, as in standing to sue, doesnt usually get peoples juices flowing  even people like newspaper editors who (take my word for this) tend to regard the topic as dry and technical, more suitable for courthouse geeks than general readers.

title: Some Obama Allies Fear School Lunch Bill Could Rob Food Stamp Program
description: WASHINGTON  In her campaign to reduce childhood obesity and improve school nutrition, Michelle Obama has become entangled in a fight with White House allies, including liberal Democrats and advocates for the poor.

title: After Tasting Lakers Success, Turiaf Has Chance With Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The man looking over Ronny Turiafs shoulder at the Knicks practice facility earlier this week was none other than Phil Jackson, forever frozen and framed with his teammates in a photograph from 1973, the last time the Knicks captured an N.B.A. title.

title: Nobel Laureate Retracts Two Papers Unrelated to Her Prize
description: Linda B. Buck, who shared the 2004 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for deciphering the workings of the sense of smell, has retracted two scientific papers after she and her colleagues were unable to repeat the findings.

title: The Sunday Deadline
description: President Obama made a compelling case at the United Nations for why a peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians is not only essential but may even be possible this time. Since the current talks began three weeks ago, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, are reportedly grappling with some of the toughest issues.

title: Tea Partys Big Money
description: Tea Party supporters and their candidates like to imagine themselves as insurgents, crashing the barricades of Washington to establish a new order of clean and frugal government. In earthbound reality, many of the people pulling the Tea Partys strings are establishment Republican operatives and lobbyists. Some have made money off the party for years.

title: Facebook and Newark
description: It is good news that Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive of Facebook, is donating $100 million to remake the failing public schools in Newark. But it will take a lot more than money to improve student performance in that citys troubled system, which has continued to perform dismally since being taken over by the state 15 years ago. Mayor Cory Booker, who will get substantial control of the system as a condition of the donation, must now rally his city and its unions behind an ambitious reform plan that raises standards and holds teachers and principals accountable for student performance.

title: Europes Financial Footing Is Rocky, Central Bank Says
description: Money markets in the euro zone continue to function unevenly while the overall volume of transactions has declined from last year, data released by the European Central Bank indicated on Thursday. It was a reminder that the banking system remains fragile.

title: Friday: Some Choice Words
description: An interesting-looking grid is always worth a few style points, so todays was ahead of the game before I even started.

title: The Weather Was Perfect for Outrage
description: The police were looking for suspicious characters, but the 10-foot-tall Ahmadinejad pretender dancing to rap music with a fake missile strapped to his back did not qualify. No, he was comfortably within the realm of normal at demonstration central.

title: Whos Afraid of Fluid Gender and Time?
description: Weve all had a strange nights sleep now and then. But it would be hard to top the transformation that overtakes the slumbering title character of Virginia Woolfs novel Orlando after an evening of heady debauchery in 17th-century Constantinople. As admirers of the book will recall, the young English nobleman goes to bed one night a duke and wakes up a duchess.

title: Senate Democrats Delay a Vote on Bush Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats said Thursday that they would postpone a highly contentious floor fight over what to do about the expiring Bush-era tax cuts until after the November elections, a decision that spares some politically vulnerable incumbents from casting a potentially difficult vote to let taxes rise for the rich.

title: Schools Run by Newark May Yet Reflect Christies Vision
description: Handed new power to reinvigorate the Newark school system, Mayor Cory A. Booker is likely to push for politically charged ideas like more charter schools, aid for private-school tuition and linking teacher pay to student performance, according to people who have worked with the mayor and followed his career and comments on education.

title: Cleaner, Healthier Cookstoves
description: Here is a shocking statistic: nearly two million people  mostly women and children  in the developing world die annually from illnesses brought on by breathing toxic smoke from indoor cooking stoves. The Obama administration is rightly doing something about it.

title: Battered Economy in Ireland Contracts 1.2%
description: LONDON  Already reeling from a banking crisis that is threatening its financial credibility, Ireland suffered another setback on Thursday when fresh data showed that its ailing economy shrank 1.2 percent in the second quarter.

title: Adoption Struggles
description: Theres no denying that the acting in Like Dandelion Dust, an adoption drama directed by Jon Gunn from a novel by Karen Kingsbury, is superb.

title: Pakistani Sentenced to 86 Years for Attack
description: A Pakistani neuroscientist who was convicted of trying to kill American soldiers and F.B.I. agents in Afghanistan was sentenced to 86 years in prison on Thursday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Huge Wind Turbine Farm Opens Off Coast of Southeast England
description: LONDON  The worlds largest offshore wind turbine farm, with a capacity to power more than 200,000 homes for a year, opened on Thursday off the coast of southeast England.

title: YouTube Cant Be Liable on Copyright, Spain Rules
description: A Spanish court on Thursday sided with Google in a dispute with the broadcaster Telecinco, saying Googles online video-sharing service, YouTube, did not have to screen television clips for potential copyright violations before posting them on the site.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghans proved a tough audience for the world premiere of The Black Tulip at the Ariana Cinema on Thursday afternoon (an evening showing was deemed too dangerous). It was meant to be a serious film about Afghanistan, by an Afghan-born director, set in present-day Kabul and even filmed on location here, but many of the Afghans who saw it said they did not recognize the society they knew.

title: Downhill With the G.O.P.
description: Once upon a time, a Latin American political party promised to help motorists save money on gasoline. How? By building highways that ran only downhill.

title: Brothers Compete to Lead Labour Party in Britain
description: LONDON  Ever since the Labour Partys defeat in Mays general election, a group of five candidates to succeed the former party leader, Gordon Brown, have been crisscrossing Britain, debating at more than 60 party gatherings and seeking to persuade the partys huge electoral college that they can inspire a regeneration of the party after 13 exhausting years in power.

title: A Dreamlike Tale of a Gay Hustler
description: I like adventure, says the boyish gay hustler (Ben Bonenfant) at the heart of Strapped, Joseph Grahams dreamlike debut feature. The statement may or may not be true, but it helps fabricate the persona of the moment: what makes this particular young man desirable  aside from a guileless face, a knowing body and a sweet disposition  is the facility to morph into whomever his customer most desires.

description: WASHINGTON  Plans by the British government to make significant cuts in defense spending have spurred concerns among American military experts about Britains ability to carry out its role as the United States most dependable ally.

title: A Fight to Preserve Tibetan Music
description: Ngawang Choephel, a Tibetan musicologist who was imprisoned by the Chinese for more than six years, would have had a compelling film had he simply stuck to his own remarkable story. But his documentary, Tibet in Song, is doubly powerful because he also weaves in the overall history of Tibets struggle, a primer on the Chinese governments campaign to muzzle Tibetan culture and vignettes from other Tibetans who resisted.

title: Transit Court Should Have Translators, Group Says
description: New Yorkers who speak little or no English are being illegally denied interpreters in transit court, often leaving them at a disadvantage as they try to fight summonses for littering, fare beating and other violations, the New York Civil Liberties Union charged on Thursday.

title: The Founding Fathers Versus the Tea Party
description: LIKE many popular insurgencies in American history, the Tea Party movement has attempted to enlist the founding fathers as fervent adherents to its cause. The very name invokes those disguised patriots who clambered aboard ships in Boston Harbor in December 1773 and dumped chests of tea into the water rather than submit to the hated tea tax. At Tea Party rallies, marchers brandish flags emblazoned with the Revolutionary slogan Dont Tread on Me while George Washington impersonators and other folks in colonial garb mingle with the crowds.

description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombias security forces killed the second in command of Latin Americas largest rebel group in an elaborate bombing raid in the countrys remote Macarena mountain range, the government said Thursday, dealing a major blow to a four-decade insurgency that had re-emerged with new vigor in recent months.

But on an epic outing in Big Sur in 2004 while walking around the forest with his headphones on, he had a revelation.

title: Timetable for Education Guidelines
description: The United States Department of Education said it would announce a new timetable Friday for releasing the final version of regulations aimed at the for-profit higher-education industry  and education groups are expecting a postponement of the gainful employment rule, a controversial rule cutting off federal student aid to programs whose students have the highest debt burdens and lowest loan-repayment rates. The department received about 90,000 public comments on the rule this summer, double the previous record. To give it time to review those comments and refine the rule  now the object of intense lobbying  the department is likely to put off releasing the final rule until after Nov. 1, the deadline for rules going into effect, delaying its effective date until 2012. However, because full enforcement of the gainful employment rule was not scheduled to start until 2012, the delay would have little practical effect.

Lynn, executive director of Americans United, said, It is not the Armys job to convert Americans to Christianity.

The panel voted 12 to 7 along party lines to reapprove Prof. Goodwin Liu of the University of California at Berkeley for the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The committee also voted in favor of three district court nominees: Edward Chen in California, Louis Butler in Wisconsin and John McConnell Jr. in Rhode Island. The votes split along party lines, with the exception of Mr. McConnell, who was supported by one Republican, Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina.

title: Eastern Promises

What could they possibly see in the so-called Manchester of Poland? In fact, Lodz is undergoing something of a creative rebirth. The city has begun turning its 19th-century textile buildings into new-economy hubs  a case in point is the Manufaktura complex (Ogrodowa Street), home to a museum and the citys first upscale design hotel, Andels. Lodz is also financing cultural festivals and programs aimed at retaining local art school grads, and once a planned high-speed rail slashes the Warsaw commute to 35 minutes, theyll have one more reason to stay put.

Last year B.U.s Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy released results of its study of the brain of Reggie Fleming, which showed the same kind of damage as that experienced by boxers and football players. title: Father Exposure

Slipped inside a book of poetry was a letter from a lover ending what was clearly an extramarital affair. My instinct is to destroy it, but the father did save it for years and left it where he must have known his children would find it. The mother is dead, so it cant hurt her. Our troupe defended Williams right to a doll and explained why Mommies were People, too, at every elementary school in St. Louis Park, Minn.; I can still recite Dont Dress Your Cat in an Apron.
