description: In an essay in the New York Times Magazine this weekend, my colleague Peggy Orenstein notes a change in the message that some marketers are aiming at girls. Or, more likely, at the mothers of girls. From the Target spot that paints back-to-school clothes as empowering with music from Free to Be, You and Me to the Verizon ad that shows bright-eyed, young women announcing, I can lead the army that will follow, advertisers are selling girls as strong and powerful.

title: Nocturnalist | Justice Is Served. For Some, as a Diversion.
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: Who Gets to Set Earths Thermostat?
description: Theres a useful package of pieces in Slate (related to a meeting on Monday) exploring aspects of the intensifying debate over geo-engineering, the batch of methods proposed as ways to counter global warming with artificial cooling.

title: A Few Minutes With the Margaret Mead of Mad Men
description: Elisabeth Moss has certainly been a topic of conversation lately, possibly because of her acting work, which earned her a second consecutive Emmy Award-nomination for her performance on Mad Men, or possibly because of articles like this one. This particular interview is going to address only one of those two topics; before a recent conversation with ArtsBeat, Ms. Moss let us know she would not discuss her personal life. But hey, why let 15 minutes of telephone time go to waste? Ms. Moss was still game to talk about her recent role in the comedy Get Him to the Greek, in which she played the long-suffering girlfriend of a hapless record-label flunky played by Jonah Hill (and which will receive a DVD release on Tuesday). And of course she was open to discussing Peggy Olson, her Mad Men alter ego, who in just four seasons has gone from a timid new hire to an ambitious, pot-smoking, clothes-shedding, lesbian-befriending, dead-executive-secretary-poking young copywriter.

title: Citigroup Sued by Norways Central Bank
description: Norways central bank has sued Citigroup over $835 million in losses on Citi shares and bonds.

title: Photos of The Moment | Prada
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of ioulex.

title: Walt Frazier Buys Three Harlem Penthouses
description: WALT FRAZIER had settled into semiretirement on St. Croix, V.I., living in a vacation home he found decades ago. He spent much of his time there creating elaborate gardens with the indigenous plants, and he bought five acres and built and renovated 10 houses that he rents out.

title: Protests in Pakistan at Long Jail Term for Scientist in U.S.
description: Protesters took to the streets of cities across Pakistan on Friday, calling on their government to intervene in the case of Aafia Siddiqui, an American-educated Pakistani scientist who was sentenced to 86 years in jail on Thursday in New York.

title: In Search of a Good Wine List
description: The Internet has been a great boon for wine lovers, not least for offering the opportunity to scan wine lists online in advance, relieving us of the awkward social withdrawal at the table for the task of wine selection. But Internet wine lists can also come back to bite you.

title: Week in Pictures, Sept. 24
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: Qatar Signals Intention to Invest in Greece
description: Greece has signed a preliminary deal with Qatars sovereign wealth fund that could clear the way for investments of up to $5 billion in the indebted European country, officials said Friday.

title: Tea Party Convention Is Canceled
description: The Tea Party is off.

title: Zucker Announces Departure From NBC
description: Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, told the companys employees in an e-mail Friday morning that he would step down from his position upon the completion of the takeover of NBC by Comcast.

title: Theres Something About Quinoa
description: During my recent interview with Martha Rose Shulman about her new Recipes for Health cookbook, she mentioned that she had just finished cooking up some new quinoa dishes. Although she has written about the grain before, she realized there was more to say  and eat.

title: Aftershock
description: Chapter One: Eccles's Insight

title: Fairer Deal
description: Way way back, which means before the financial sector imploded, it wasnt Wall Street bonuses and vampire squids that excited the most fury. People agonized, instead, about the stagnation of middle-class incomes and exploding inequality. In Aftershock  impressively, his 12th book  Robert B. Reich steers our attention back to those earlier worries, which have arguably become more urgent in the wake of the financial crisis. But right on the first page, he comes close to blowing it.

title: Ply the Pen
description: For a poet, life after the Nobel can be pottering, or bookkeeping, or simply keeping busy  its rarely full of radical departures or stunning new poems. (Eliot called the prize a ticket to ones own funeral, and indeed it proved the funeral of his poetry.) Even pottering can be difficult when you are constantly in demand to judge this prize or sign that public letter, to give a blurb to old X or a recommendation to young Y. For a poet, all life can be a distraction from the siren call of the page. When you read that Seamus Heaney has a secretary to help him answer correspondence, you wish he had half a dozen, and perhaps a few armed guards. Yet apart from Pasternak, who was bullied by his government, no poet has ever turned down the poisoned chalice.

title: Calculating the Castle Write-In Bid
description: Lisa Murkowski, who has decided to run a write-in campaign for the Senate, may soon have some company. Representative Mike Castle, the moderate Delaware Republican who was upended by Christine ODonnell in the primary, is also said to be considering a write-in bid. Although both Mr. Castle and his advisers have characterized a bid as unlikely, his interest is serious enough that hes commissioned a poll, according to reporting by Politico.

title: Obsession
description: To enter the world of the crime writer James Ellroy, one must accept a certain degree of time warp. His prose clings to the underbelly of mid-20th-century modern, a place that the eras celebrated advertising doesnt even reach  where men are men and women are cocktail waitresses; where shady characters of both sexes screech in hot rods from dive bars to no-tell motels and back again. The genre is noir, and it has its own argot (noir-got?). People dont divorce; they split the sheets. They pitch boohoo rather than merely cry, and become stiff in all senses of the word: awkward, engorged with desire and then dead.

title: They Did What?
description: Scandal has never had it so good: typically ogled, mocked, knocked down and dismissed, its at last being graciously invited to lie down on the couch. In How to Become a Scandal, Laura Kipnis delivers consumers of high and low culture that rare twofer, taking material that self-respecting people are supposed to resist and treating it with such smarts that the reader feels nothing short of enlightened. Her book is filled with sensational subjects (Eliot Spitzer, Linda Tripp, James Frey and that notorious astronaut with the diaper), but Kipnis delivers all the thrills.

title: Great Muppet Caper Continues as Elmo Defends Katy Perry
description: In circumstances George Stephanopoulos probably never imagined when he gave up a hands-on role in politics to become a broadcaster, two fuzzy, nonhuman members of the Sesame Street cast joined him Friday morning on Good Morning America, along with that PBS childrens shows executive producer, Carol-Lynn Parente, to discuss the recent decision at Sesame Street to pull a music video featuring the pop singer Katy Perry.

title: Blood Ties
description: For roughly the last half-century, nearly every black female writer of any consequence in America seems to have had one very particular story to tell  or, rather, one particular question shes tried to answer: Just how in heaven (or hell) have black women managed to survive? How, that is, were great-grandmothers not completely destroyed by enslavement, grandmothers not irreparably broken by bigotry, mothers not wholly defeated by loneliness? How have black women in this country kept on doing battle with everything, for what seems like forever, without falling apart? And what toll has this taken on their daughters? From Margaret Walker to Octavia Butler, Sherley Anne Williams, Toni Morrison and Gayl Jones, to name only a few, Americas black female authors have tried to make sense of a difficult present by writing bridges to the traumas of the past.

title: Film Has Two Big Names and a Dog, but No Big Screens
description: In the animal kingdom of Hollywood, there is still an audience for movies whose casts feature Richard Gere, and for films directed by Lasse Hallstrom. And since time immemorial  or at least since the 1943 release of Lassie Come Home  there has been a loyal viewership for pictures about dogs and their unflagging fidelity to their human companions.

title: Poetic Justice
description: Imagine Stephen Dedalus in a fiction workshop surrounded by 20-something neophytes. Better yet, picture Huck Finn, having lit out for the territory, handing sections of his new memoir to Tom and Aunt Sally. Though this may seem amusing, today thousands of hopeful authors distribute their self-portraits to other hopeful authors who sit around seminar tables in one of the hundreds of writing programs thriving nationwide.

title: Pilgrims Progress
description: Reading Scott Pilgrim is like watching your (funny, immature) slacker friend play a video game in which the objective is to attain emotional maturity. Specifically, if Scott Pilgrim were a video game, it would be an open-world sandbox game, in which messing around in the fictional world is not only more fun than properly playing the game  its kind of the whole point. The Canadian cartoonist Bryan Lee OMalley, creator of the Scott Pilgrim juggernaut, has been romping around in this sandbox, testing the limits of his comics environment, for six years, and with Volume 6, Scott Pilgrims Finest Hour, he brings the series to a close.

title: Paterson Takes His Chances on Saturday Night Live
description: In a series of skits and Weekend Update segments over the last two years, the cast of Saturday Night Live has mercilessly mocked Gov. David A. Patersons impaired vision and presented him as an improbably clumsy figure who walks into cameras, holds charts upside down, and hates New Jersey. The genial Mr. Paterson, in turn, has made it clear that he finds the parodies to be in poor taste, even for a comedy show.

title: Gucci Goes Virtual
description: Suzy Menkes discusses the ways Gucci is using technology with Frida Giannini, the label's creative director.

title: Half Empty
description: Chapter One: The Bleak Shall Inherit

title: Nabob of Negativism
description: The book jacket of Half Empty, David Rakoffs third essay collection, contains not only the warning No Inspirational Life Lessons Will Be Found in These Pages, but the guarantee that the author will have you positively reveling in the power of negativity. Its never clear whether the pessimism alluded to is Rakoffs philosophy, Rakoffs device or Rakoffs publicist clearing his throat. Luckily, we dont have to judge this book by its cover.

title: Photos of the Moment | D&G
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Insuring Young Adults
description: For young Americans with no health insurance, Thursday was an important day: those younger than 26 were able to join their parents plans under the recently enacted health care overhaul. (Previously, children were dropped from their parents policies at 19, or 23 if they were full-time students.) Young people make up the largest group of uninsured Americans, although they are healthier and cheaper to insure. And they are much less likely to vote. Still, in many states with high rates of uninsured young adults, providing health coverage is not at the forefront of political campaigns. Below, the areas of the country with high rates of uninsured, and how health care is playing out as an issue in those areas:

title:
Nixon And Kennedy Clash in TV Debate on
Spending, Farms and Social Issues
description: Chicago, Sept. 26--Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy argued genteelly tonight in history's first nationally televised debate between Presidential candidates.

title: Pope Paul VI Is Dead of a Heart Attack at 80; Guided the Church Through Era of Change
description: In contrast to Pope John XXIII, his predecessor, Paul VI was not naturally gregarious and innovative. He was the consummate bureaucrat in his Vatican career and not given to striking out in new directions.

title: Richard Serra Sculpture Rusts in Bronx Yard
description: To see gargantuan steel sculptures fashioned by Richard Serra, you could visit the Guggenheim in Bilbao, Spain, or the Dia: Beacon, 60 miles north of New York City. Or you could go to a crane yard near a heating-oil terminal in Port Morris, an industrial corner of the South Bronx.

title: New Birth of Freedom
description: Human rights have come to dominate international discourse, but while this fact is often portrayed as the culmination of a centuries-old tradition, Samuel Moyn, a professor of history at Columbia University, takes a different view. The modern concept of human rights, he says in The Last Utopia, differs radically from older claims of rights, like those that arose out of the American and French Revolutions. According to Moyn, human rights in their current form  applicable to all and internationally protected  can be traced not to the Enlightenment, nor to the humanitarian impulses of the 19th century nor to the impact of the Holocaust after World War II. Instead, he sees them as dating from the 1970s, exemplified by President Jimmy Carters effort to make human rights a pillar of United States foreign policy.

title: Warren Commission Finds Oswald Guilty and Says Assassin and Ruby Acted Alone; Rebukes Secret Service, Asks Revamping
description: Washington, Sept. 27--The assassination of President Kennedy was the work of one man, Lee Harvey Oswald. There was no conspiracy, foreign or domestic.

title: Admiral Mahan, Naval Critic, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, D. C., Dec. 1--Rear Admiral Alfred Thayer Mahan, U. S. N., retired, America's foremost naval strategist and the world's greatest authority on sea power, died suddenly at the United States Naval Hospital here at 7:15 o'clock this morning of heart disease.

title: Fliers At Seattle End World Flight of 27,000 Miles
description: Seattle, Wash., Sept. 28 (Associated Press).--The American army round-the-world fliers completed the circuit of the globe this afternoon, landing at Sand Point Field at 1:36 P. M., Pacific Time, after hopping off from Eugene, Ore., at 10:02 A. M.

title: Ed Sullivan Is Dead at 73; Charmed Millions on TV
description: Ed Sullivan, who entertained hundreds of millions of Americans over his long career as Broadway columnist and host of the long-running televised Sunday evening variety show, died last night of cancer. He was 73 years old.

title: Enrico Fermi Dead at 53; Architect of Atomic Bomb
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 28--Dr. Enrico Fermi, an architect of the atomic age and Nobel Prize winner, died at his home here this morning of cancer. His age was 53.

title: The New York Giants: 1883-1957
description: The New York Giants played--and lost--their last game at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

title: Britain and Germany Make Anti-War Pact; Hitler Gets Less Than His Sudeten Demands; Polish Ultimatum Threatens Action Today
description: Prime Minister Chamberlain and Chancellor Hitler, at a final conference at Munich yesterday, agreed that: "We regard the agreement signed last night and the Anglo- German naval agreement as symbolic of the desire of our two peoples never to go to war with one another again." Terms imposed on Czechoslovakia were found to be milder than Hitler's Godesberg plan. They provided immediate occupation of about half of the Sudeten area, the rest to be allotted by the International Commission or to be subject to plebiscite.

title: Truman Capote is Dead at 59; Novelist of Style and Clarity
description: Truman Capote, one of the postwar era's leading American writers, whose prose shimmered with clarity and quality, died yesterday in Los Angeles at the age of 59.

title: 3 Afghan Journalists, 2 of Whom Were Held by NATO Forces, Are Released
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three Afghan journalists detained by the authorities were released from custody on Friday, officials said.

title: Character Building
description: When I used to ask my mother about her family village in China, she always said it was three hours from Canton by bus. A hundred years ago, when my great-grandfather left China for good, that couldnt have been far, but it was certainly no help in locating it. So I was pleased  though still mystified  to read in Deborah Fallowss charming and witty little book that in China, if you ask someone where their hometown is, theyll say it is seven hours by bus. Or four hours by train. They wont tell you where it is.

title: Falling to Earth
description: Scanning online news releases from the Department of Defense, one discovers, interspersed among policy announcements, statistical reports and accounts of recent casualties in Afghanistan and Iraq, the occasional release concerning the identification of soldiers missing in earlier wars. In contrast to the brutal, minimalist bulletins about todays combat deaths, narratives of the repatriation of older remains, tempered by historical distance, present robustly detailed forensic reconstructions of events once thought untraceable. Unlike the stinting report of young lives violently ended just days before by rifle, rocket-propelled grenade and small-arms fire in Kandahar City, accounts of Vietnam-, Korea- or World War II-era soldiers located, identified and laid to rest offer resolution to stories long unfinished.

title: Michael Schumachers Future Discussed in Singapore
description: SINGAPORE  During a press meeting at the Mercedes motor home Thursday in Singapore, someone asked Michael Schumacher if we going to see him again next year. There had been rumors that he would not finish his contract at Mercedes and retire again in the off-season.

title: Michael Schumachers Future Discussed in Singapore
description: SINGAPORE  During a press meeting at the Mercedes motor home Thursday in Singapore, someone asked Michael Schumacher if we going to see him again next year. There had been rumors that he would not finish his contract at Mercedes and retire again in the off-season.

title: Feisty Barbadian, Reluctant Centenarian, Dies at 102
description: Mae Bishop, a proud Barbadian immigrant who raised two daughters and worked in the New York hotel industry, retiring in 1976 as an assistant housekeeper in the linen room at the Delmonico Hotel on Park Avenue, died on Wednesday. She was 102  or, as she put it, just past the 72nd anniversary of her 30th birthday.

title: Waterfront Jungle
description: Say youre a New York City newspaper reporter and the year is 1948. Your editor tells you to go down to the docks and check out the latest in a string of murders.

title: Le Fooding Fights | David Chang on Daniel Patterson
description: To get ready for this weekends Le Grand Fooding 2010: New York vs. San Francisco at P.S.1, we asked David Chang to respond to Daniel Pattersons post about what West Coast cuisine really means. Gentlemen.

title: Saved by Rock n Roll
description: Rob Sheffield is a geek. Most rock critics are, but Sheffield, a columnist for Rolling Stone, takes it to a whole new level. In Talking to Girls About Duran Duran: One Young Mans Quest for True Love and a Cooler Haircut, he lays bare the tortured soul of a music geek coming of age in New England in the 1980s. And make no mistake about it, his soul is tortured. Blame liberal doses of Catholicism, Morrissey and John Hughes. Sheffield is Duckie without the fashion sense, or the girl.

title: Sept. 26  Oct. 2
description: Dance

title: Unilevers Mad Men Spots Worked, Study Says
description: A series of commercials for six big Unilever brands, which appeared during  and were inspired by  the AMC series Mad Men were successful, according to the results of a study.

title: Voting With Their Wallets, College Profs Overwhelmingly Support Democrats
description: Somebody call David Horowitz: College educators  or at least those involved enough in political campaigns to donate  are indeed generally liberal.

title: The End of Tenure?
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Love
description: Tao Lins short new novel, Richard Yates, has little to do with the man it was named for, the author of Revolutionary Road and The Easter Parade. Instead, Yatess name appears both as a provocation  to showcase Lins quirky nature  and as an attempt at appropriation. Lin aspires to the emotionally devastating work that is Yatess legacy. If he falls short, though, hes maintained enough ironic distance to have an out: Just kidding, see?

title: Eddie Fisher, Pop Singer, Dies at 82
description: Eddie Fisher, whose matinee-idol looks and smooth, romantic voice made him one of the most popular singers of the 1950s, and whose busy love life stole headlines in 1959 when he divorced Debbie Reynolds to marry Elizabeth Taylor, died on Wednesday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 82.

title: A Shared Language
description: To the Editor:

title: Right Star Rising
description: To the Editor:

title: Fight The Power
description: Maybe its happened to you too. Youre reminiscing about a friend who moved away years ago, and then she arrives unexpectedly at your door. You cant stop thinking about getting the phone call with the job offer, and it comes the next week. Or you have a vision of a family member becoming sick, and then you hear that he has been taken to the hospital.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: BARNACLE LOVE  By Anthony De Sa.  Algonquin, paper, $13.95.

title: Up Front: Kaiama L. Glover
description: The first thing you notice walking into my childhood home, Kaiama L. Glover recalled in a recent e-mail, is the collection of family photographs that chronicle about four generations of maternal history. And not a visit goes by that I dont stop there with my mother, listening to a story Ive heard for the umpteenth time but can never get enough of.

title: Editors Choice
description: ROOM,  by Emma Donoghue (Little, Brown, $24.99.) In this remarkable novel, the entire world of a 5-year-old boy is the 11-by-11-foot room in which his mother is being held against her will. Donoghues child narrator is one of the most engaging in years.

title: Paperback Row
description: HALF BROKE HORSES: A True-Life Novel,  by Jeannette Walls (Scribner, $15.) In an authors note, Walls says that this book is a retelling of stories handed down by my family through the years. Narrated in the first person in the voice of Wallss grandmother, Lily Casey Smith, it describes her hardscrabble upbringing in West Texas, where she was born in 1901, and her subsequent frontier life as a mustang breaker, schoolteacher, ranch wife, bootlegger, poker player, bush pilot and mother of two. A sort of prequel to Wallss luminous memoir, The Glass Castle (2005), Half Broke Horses was one of the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2009.

title: Andrea Harris and David Smith
description: Andrea Kate Harris and David Richard Smith were married Saturday in New York. Andra M. Miller, the president of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at the Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Calling Chuck Woolery; N.B.A. Needs You
description: The N.B.A. would like your love back. Look, its really sorry about that whole LeBron James The Decision thing. It has done everything it can to keep Gilbert Arenas from bringing his guns anywhere near you. It has been trying super, super hard to get Mark Cuban to be quiet. It is even promising to cut back on players whining. Training camps open in a few days, and even if youre transfixed by the Yankees-Rays race for the American League East or wondering if the Kansas City Chiefs are for real, its wondering if you wont hang out with its news for a few minutes.

title: In Pursuing Progress, Should Borders Matter?
description: Toward the end of a week focused on how the worlds rich can foster progress at the other end of the Slinky of social and economic progress, a reader here posted a provocative comment.

title: Red Hook Is Out, So Mexico Will Have to Do
description: When LeNell Smotherss landlord would not renew her lease and she reluctantly closed her beloved liquor store in Red Hook, taking her Alabama chandelier and little-boy-urinating fountain with her, her predictions for the future, however cryptic, proved prescient.

title: Endzhe Akhmatshina; Rafay Farooqui
description: Endzhe Akhmatshina and Rafay Farooqui were married Friday. Imam Ghazi Y. Khankan officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in Manhattan.

title: The Charge of Californias Light Brigade
description: Compact fluorescent light bulbs are so 2009.

title: Michael C. Hall on the Return of Dexter
description: This post may contain spoilers for readers still catching up on DVD.

title: Ristretto | First Look at Stumptown Coffee Roasters in Red Hook
description: In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the author of The Filter, a guide to New York coffee from The New York Times, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why its never been easier to get a cortado.

title: College Professors and Their Support for Democrats
description: College educators  or at least those involved enough in political campaigns to donate  are indeed generally liberal. That is the implication of a new analysis of federal political contributions conducted by the Center for Responsive Politics, which tracks public data on campaign donations. Read more about the analysis, and view a chart at the Economix blog.

title: Hertz Declares Its Dollar Thrifty Bid Best and Final
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Big Deal | Walt Fraziers Harlem Penthouse(s)
description: Walt Frazier, the N.B.A Hall of Fame player who was known as Clyde in his heyday as a point guard for the Knicks, closed on three Harlem penthouses Thursday, for $2.4 million, according to the developer of the new condominium building, known as the Lenox Grand. Mr. Frazier bought the entire seventh and eighth floors of the building, with a total of 4,600 square feet and another 2,500 square feet of terraces. Our colleagues in the Real Estate section have the full story.

title: What Were Reading: R.I.P., Toxic Asset
Amgen and Johnson & Johnson Recall Anemia Drugs
description: Amgens anemia drugs have been embroiled in controversy about their safety for several years as evidence has mounted that their overuse can cause heart attacks or strokes or make cancer worse. Now comes yet another problem, though presumably a temporary one.

title: The Best Savings Account Rate Just Got Worse
description: SmartyPig, the online savings bank known for its competitive interest rates, recently became a little less generous.

title: Vegetables Bring In $100,000 at Sothebys
description: Last night the old masters up for auction at Sothebys on York Avenue were heirloom vegetables. And they brought in more than $100,000 to support local farming programs.

title: Grassley Backs Renewable Electricity Standard
description: A bipartisan bill introduced in the Senate this week that would require utilities nationwide to generate at least 15 percent of their electricity from renewable sources like wind, solar and biomass by 2021 continues to garner Republican support, with Charles E. Grassley of Iowa signing on as a co-sponsor. His support brings the number of Republican co-sponsors to four; 25 senators in all have signed on to the bill.

title: For Glenn Gould, Form Followed Fingers
description: EVEN to his most passionate admirers, the phenomenally gifted if wildly unconventional pianist Glenn Gould was a tangle of personal tics and complexes. Sometimes he seemed a provocateur bent on riling the public with extreme interpretations and odd behavior. Other times he came across as a fragile, fearful man, at ease only when making music.

title: Lindsay Lohan Sent to Jail Again
description: Lindsay Lohan was sent back to jail on Friday morning by a California judge after the actress failed a recent drug test, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan, the Mean Girls star, was ordered by Judge Elden S. Fox of Los Angeles County Superior Court to be held without bail until Oct. 22, when a formal probation hearing will be held.

title: Madonna  Finally, a Real Feminist
description: For Op-Ed's 40th anniversary, author and professor Camille Paglia recounts the story behind her 1990 Op-Ed about feminism, Madonna, and the music video Justify My Love.

title: Thinking of Buying a Nissan Leaf? Get in Line
description: The Nissan Leaf is a go. In fact, until next year, its gone.

title: Princess Shakes Up Equestrian World
description: BAYAMON, P.R.  As a daughter of King Hussein and the wife of the ruler of Dubai, Princess Haya bint al-Hussein of Jordan has the pedigree that is practically a prerequisite for presiding over the International Equestrian Federation, which governs the sport. Members of noble or royal families have led the organization, with few exceptions, since its founding in 1921.

title: Just 28 Days to Make a Choice
description: If choosing the law firm that you could spend much of your professional life at was not already a frenetic and stressful enough process, the system became even a little bit more fast paced this year.

title: Runway Beauty | Prada
description: The hairstylist Guido Palau seems to have been hitting the history books since February  the look he created for the Marc Jacobs show was all 70s scene queens, and now for Prada he said he channeled the 30s icon Josephine Baker and her signature hairstyle, a helmet of Marcel waves. The hair was slicked down with Redken Hardwear 16 Super-Strong Sculpting Gel, and in the back it was coiled into two buns, which Palau intended to look playful. Perhaps to shake up the historical reference, the makeup artist Pat McGrath created a futuristic look she said she meant to look a bit androgynous: a strong brow, clean skin and a shiny slick of silver across the eyelids. The metallic shadow offset the bright colors and Carmen Miranda prints in the minimal baroque collection, and the graphic shape of the hair on the forehead meshed perfectly with Pradas wacky eyewear.

title: Chicago and Muti: Chemistry in Action
description: CHICAGO  Riccardo Muti officially began his tenure as music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra on Thursday night with an imaginative, elegantly performed and enthusiastically received Berlioz program. Yet the Muti lovefest here started well before this milestone concert.

title: Cerberuss Freedom Names Nardelli as Chief
description: Robert L. Nardelli has taken the helm of yet another portfolio company of Cerberus Capital Management, assuming on Friday the role of head of the gun maker Freedom Groups newly created office of the chief executive.

title: Book Review Podcast: James Ellroys Memoir
description: This week: Alexandra Jacobs on the novelist James Ellroys new memoir, The Hilliker Curse: My Pursuit of Women; Kaiama Glover discusses Some Sing, Some Cry, a novel by the sisters Ntozake Shange and Ifa Bayeza; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Mixing Urgency and Relaxation
description: THE first time I heard the English pianist Paul Lewis perform live was at the Risor Chamber Music Festival in Norway in the summer of 2002. He impressed me as an accomplished and insightful artist. Still, with the pianists Leif Ove Andsnes and Till Fellner among the participants in the festival that season, it was hard for Mr. Lewis to stand out.

title: Friday Night Lights: L.A. Edition
description: Major League Soccers media machine has been operating at full power all week ahead of Friday nights match between the Red Bulls and Los Angeles Galaxy at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif. The match will be televised live nationally by ESPN2 at 11 p.m. Eastern.

title: Matthew Herberts Take on the ReComposed Series
description: RECOMPOSED BY MATTHEW HERBERT: MAHLER SYMPHONY X

title: TimesCast | September 24, 2010
description: A photographer's view of the allied offensive in Southern Afghanistan and a house so well insulated it doesn't need a furnace.

title: Weekend Competition: Wire Taps, Stock Tickers and Other Frozen Phrases
description: This weekend, Schotts Vocab is soliciting frozen words and phrases  those terms that are still in use, despite their archaic references.

title: Reneging by Georgia Blindsides Orchestra
description: The Republic of Georgia canceled an invitation to the New York Philharmonic just weeks before it was to visit, the Philharmonic said on Friday. The called-off performances will cost the orchestra hundreds of thousands of dollars, and they add another setback to its efforts to be a world-traveling band.

title: Trunk Show | European Fashion in L.A.
description: Most museum fashion shows are relegated to a dark basement, reflecting not just the status of fashion vis--vis fine art but also the vulnerability of, say, a 150-year-old silk gown, to the effects of sunlight. When the Los Angeles County Museum of Art shows off its newly acquired, and reportedly groundbreaking, trove of European clothing on Saturday, it will do so in a new light-filled pavilion designed by Renzo Piano. Fashioning Fashion: European Dress in Detail, 1700-1915, which runs through April 3, ends well before the invention of ready-to-wear. In this stunning context, even a mans vest from the 18th century (it is embroidered with symbolism relevant to the French Revolution and it predates the message T-shirt by at least 200 years) somehow seems modern and alive.

title: N.B.A. Aims to Rein in Players Whining
description: When the whistle blows in the N.B.A., the gesticulations begin. Players howl, shrug, punch the air, raise their palms and sometimes chase referees 90 feet to plead their case. League officials have seen  and heard  enough.

title: Trisha Brown in Space and Time
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov, Laurie Anderson and other artists describe working with Trisha Brown from the 1960s on.

title: Twitter Walks, Urban Sharecropping and Other Matters
description: Everyone has projects.

title: In Rare Find, Prado Says Painting Is by Bruegel the Elder
description: Calling it one of the most important discoveries for many years, curators at the Prado Museum in Madrid have uncovered what they say is the largest surviving canvas painted by the 16th-century Flemish master Pieter Bruegel the Elder.

title: Kelly McGillis and Melanie Leis
description: Collingswood, N.J.

title: The Whole Truthiness and Nothing But
description: Stephen Colbert testified in Congress on Friday about an immigration bill that he said  in all truthiness  he had not read, like most members of Congress.

title: Inside the List
description: CAT AND MOUSE: Bill OReilly, the excitable Fox News host, is no fan of this newspaper  his latest book, Pinheads and Patriots, includes an index entry for The New York Times, blind partisanship at  but hes compiled an impressive track record on our best-seller lists. With Pinheads and Patriots making its debut this week at No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list, OReilly has now seen eight of his nine books become New York Times best sellers. The one exception? Those Who Trespass: A Novel of Murder and Television, his 1998 mystery about serial killings and other misdeeds within the TV news industry.

title: The Endless Film Reel
description: IT was a bad day for surfing. The wind was low, the waves small, and a reporter brand new to the sport was nearly inept. Plus, it was Long Beach on Long Island  not exactly a hotbed of surfing. Still, that didnt stop the surfing filmmaker Dana Brown from trying his best to help the reporter catch a wave and actually ride it.

title: Obama Calls Ahmadinejads 9/11 Comments Inexcusable
description: Updated | 3:13 p.m. In a television interview with the BBCs Persian-language satellite channel on Friday, President Barack Obama called remarks made by Irans president, suggesting that the American government was responsible for the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, inexcusable.

title: Yale Endowment Gained 8.9% Last Year
description: Yale University said on Friday that its endowment, which has sizable assets in real estate, had an investment gain of 8.9 percent last year, an underwhelming performance in a year when many big endowments are reporting gains of 9 percent to 14 percent.

title: Achebe Wins $300,000 Prize
description: The Nigerian novelist Chinua Achebe has won the $300,000 Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, which recognizes artists who have had an extraordinary impact in their field. The award, named after the silent film stars, will be delivered at a ceremony on Oct. 27 in New York. Past winners include Robert Redford, Ornette Coleman, Merce Cunningham and Frank Gehry. Mr. Achebes books are among the most widely read in African literature. His 1958 novel, Things Fall Apart, has sold more than 10 million copies, and he has also won the Man Booker International Prize for Fiction and the Nigerian National Merit Award.

title: Dark Harbor
description: Chapter One: "DOV' PANTO?"

title: Old Mon and the Sea
description: Jamaica has been on the defensive lately. jamaica . . . no problem T-shirts sold in sticky tourist flytraps seemed like so much wishful thinking in June, when a popular mafioso went on the lam and riots shocked the slums of Kingston. It would be a while before the memory of daily body counts receded into a haze of happy ganja smoke.

title: House May Move on Tax Cuts Despite Delay
description: WASHINGTON  The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, said Friday that Democrats in her chamber may still force a vote next week on the expiring Bush-era tax cuts, even though their counterparts in the Senate have decided not to bring the issue to the floor until after the November elections.

title: Photographing Ntozake Shange and Ifa Bayeza
description: One of the moody pleasures of this weeks Book Review is Chester Higgins Jr.s tender-tough black-and-white portrait of the sisters Ntozake Shange and Ifa Bayeza, who are noted playwrights and the co-authors of the generational family novel Some Sing, Some Cry. Our reviewer, Kaiama L. Glover, writes that the novel is a rich mix of storytelling and African-American history following seven generations of black women who, largely through music, are able to survive the violence of their national and personal histories.

title: Photographing Ntozake Shange and Ifa Bayeza
description: One of the moody pleasures of this weeks Book Review is Chester Higgins Jr.s tender-tough black-and-white portrait of the sisters Ntozake Shange and Ifa Bayeza, who are noted playwrights and the co-authors of the generational family novel Some Sing, Some Cry. Our reviewer, Kaiama L. Glover, writes that the novel is a rich mix of storytelling and African-American history following seven generations of black women who, largely through music, are able to survive the violence of their national and personal histories.

title: Now Online | Ts Fall Travel Issue
description: In Ts new fall travel issue, the spotlight is on Mexico Citys movers and shakers  an illustrious bunch that includes architects, artists and actors photographed for a cover story in some of the capitals iconic spots. For a look at other cities on the rise, we survey the design scene in Valencia, Spain; check in on politically minded filmmakers in Sarajevo; and take the pulse in Seoul, where tradition gets cozy with 21st-century ambition. Then we head for the hills  that is, the mysterious peaks and untrammeled valleys of Roussillon, one of Frances last frontiers. The pioneer spirit continues with a profile of the trailblazing hotelier and hitmaker Chris Blackwell, as well as a romp through the Canadian wilderness with one of the worlds foremost food foragers. And for some unabashed sybaritism, we offer a top-to-toe guide to Marrakesh, a playground so swanky it will knock your caftan off.

title: Week 4 Matchups: Plenty to Choose From
description: Its another huge weekend in college football. The Southeastern Conference schedule gets started for real and gives us a couple of potential great games. Boise State needs a big win over Oregon State in its last non-conference test of the season. Notre Dame needs to avoid losing its third in a row. West Virginia hopes to boost the Big Easts Q rating a little bit. Stay with me. Theres a lot going on here.

title: Judge Accepts Citigroups Settlement With S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge said Friday that she would accept the $75 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Citigroup over the banks failure to adequately disclose its exposure to subprime mortgage debt in 2007.

title: Taiwan Museum to Lend Painting to China
description: A Taiwan museum plans for the first time to lend a major painting for exhibition in China, Agence France-Presse reported. The National Taiwan Museum plans to lend a 17th-century portrait of a Chinese general, along with other artworks, to the Hubei Provincial Museum in central China and another museum in Fujian Province for exhibitions next year. In exchange, the museum in Hubei will lend more than 100 objects to the National Taiwan Museum for an exhibition in November.

description: Nelson D. Schwartz, a DealBook colleague, reports:

title: Crist Spots Take a Darker Tone
description: 6:01 p.m. | Updated At first, the general election ads for Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida were smooth, clean and positive, with gentle Florida waves washing away the line in the sand between Democrats and Republicans to symbolize his independent bid for the United States Senate.

title: An Office With a View of Monkeys
description: Sunday, Sept. 19

title: Obama: Ahmadinejads 9/11 Comments Inexcusable
description: In a television interview to be broadcast to Iran by the BBCs Persian-language satellite channel, President Obama said remarks made by Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, suggesting that the American government was responsible for the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, were inexcusable. Watch the video, or read an excerpt of his comments, at The Lede blog.

description: THE GIST Economically dependent men are more likely to cheat on their female partners.

title: G.M. Is Recalling 20,000 Cadillac CTS Models
description: General Motors is recalling about 20,000 of its 2009-10 Cadillac CTS all-wheel-drive and CTS-V models. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said that in a frontal crash the CTS would not adequately protect an unbelted passenger under 5 feet tall sitting in the front seat.

title: Notes From a Young American in Congo: A Soldier Speaks (Sort of)
description: I wanted so badly to hate this man. Hes extremely handsome, with soft eyes, thick, curling lashes, and a nervous glance. It doesnt fit with the dirty green uniform and rickety gun hanging from his shoulder.

description: Ridley Scott, known for directing movies like Blade Runner and Gladiator, has chosen the winner of a contest to create short films that was sponsored by Philips.

description: SANTA FE, N.M.

title: The Caucus: Speaking Truthiness to Power
description: The comedian Stephen Colbert appeared in character before Congress on Friday to testify about an immigration bill that he acknowledged he had not read, like most members of Congress. His credentials: a day spent picking beans in a segment for his satirical news show on Comedy Central. I believe that one day of me studying anything makes me an expert, Mr. Colbert said. Read more on The Caucus

title: Cost and Lack of Awareness Hamper Adult Vaccination Efforts
description: VACCINES are not just for children.

title: The Morning Skate: New Head Check Rules a Step Forward
description: When it comes to checks to the head, the N.H.L. is trying something new this season. Earlier this week, the league released a video outlining its new rules on checks to the head delivered from the blindside or laterally, which mandates an automatic game misconduct and either a major or match penalty. The player also faces the possibility of supplementary discipline.

title: Apple Goes After The Camera Market Too
description: Any iPhone owner knows that there are a lot of gadgets and objects the iPhone has replaced. Among its Web and communications abilities phone owners do not need maps, notepads, music players and a litany of other single-serving devices.

title: Ejecting BP and Anointing Halliburton
description: In June, as thousands of barrels of oil gushed hourly into the Gulf of Mexico from its blown-out deepwater well, BP was stripped from the Dow Jones Sustainability Index. The index, which tracks sustainability leaders in industry worldwide, determined that the oil spill was an extraordinary event that merited BPs removal.

title: Irans President Expresses Hope for More Nuclear Talks
description: Irans president dismissed a fusillade of criticism on Friday over his inflammatory speech at the United Nations a day earlier, in which he asserted that most people believed the United States orchestrated the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Onward and Upward? Documenting Local Economic Conditions
description: Overview | If the economic recession officially ended 15 months ago, why is the poverty rate still rising? In this lesson, students learn about the correlation between job growth and poverty. They investigate how national trends in economics, labor and commerce are playing out in their area and then go into the community to photograph and compile evidence. They present their findings in a class-wide project.

title: A Charmer
description: Style-setters like Margherita Missoni, Queen Rania of Jordan and Giovanna Battaglia of LUomo Vogue are wearing elegant but playful pieces by Ca & Lou, a new Milan-based label designed by the fashion insiders Carolina Neri and Brengre Lux. Inspired by Art Deco geometric shapes with a touch of 1980s glamour, this Snake bracelet, of gold-dipped bronze and Swarovski crystals, is $565 at saksfifthavenue.com.

title: Hand-Holding Across the Aisle
description: THERE comes a moment in the dating and mating crescendo of any couple when a new significant other must be presented to the Friends. But H. P. Goldfield had a particularly tough audition: He was courting Kristin Mannion, whod been involved in Democratic politics all her life, numbering Cuomos and Clintons among her nearest and dearest. A lot of well-known Democrats were my friends, and I had to get their permission, said Ms. Mannion, an executive recruiter in New York City. Could I really date a Republican?

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Enter the Void
description: In her review of Enter the Void, Manohla Dargis writes that the camera soars above the world like a bird, like a kite, like a ghost. With an exploration of the afterlife at its center, Enter the Void takes viewers on an extended, sometimes frantic, visual journey. Above, its director Gaspar No discusses a scene shot from overhead with a roving crane and featuring the films two leads, Paz de la Huerta and Nathaniel Brown.

title: Baseball Continued: Between Rebirth and Calamity
description: IT seemed improbable in 1994 that Ken Burns would ever feel compelled to update his nine-part documentary on baseball. At 18  hours, Baseball was his longest film yet, and if his critics agreed on anything, it was that it lasted a few too many innings.

title: From Jon Stewart, Echoes of G.O.P. Past
description: Sometimes, the past catches up to you.

title: Marco Service Helps People Find Each Other
description: This summer Tarikh Korula and a friend set out into New York Citys Lower East Side to a find a beer garden they had visited once before. There was one problem: neither of them remembered the name of the bar, let alone the street address. So they split up and began wandering down blocks, planning to call each other when they finally found their destination.

title: For Automakers, the Lights Seem Brighter in Paris
description: THE Paris Motor Show, the worlds first auto salon, is shaping up to be perhaps the most notable show this year.

title: An Uzbek Survivor of Torture Seeks to Fight It Tacitly
description: GERMANTOWN, Tenn.

title: Judge Accepts S.E.C.-Citigroup Settlement
description: A federal judge said Friday that she would accept the $75 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Citigroup over the banks failure to adequately disclose its exposure to subprime mortgage debt in 2007, The New York Timess Edward Wyatt reports from Washington.

title: Leaving a Childhood Room Behind, and Much More
description: I WAS sitting around the table with some friends at an end of summer barbecue and the talk turned to college because one couple had just dropped off their daughter to start her freshman year.

title: A Father-to-Be in the Middle of a Rebirth
description: ATLANTA  At the San Diego Chargers home game last Sunday against the Jacksonville Jaguars, Charley Hoffman and his wife sat near the end zone at Qualcomm Stadium, using tickets they bought on Craigslist. Hoffman wore an autographed Eric Weddle jersey and his lucky football sneakers, the ones with the lightning bolts stitched on them, and it was a great day: the Chargers won by two touchdowns and Weddle, a free safety, was in on a sack.

title: If Customers Have to Pay for Checking, They Should Be Consoled With Perks
description: Banks want many of us to start paying monthly fees again for our checking accounts. So why wont they give us something worth paying for?

title: Whether Jazz, Rock Or War Anthems, A Vintage Harvest
description: Henry Threadgill

title: Malcolm Forbess Toys Are Up for Sale
description: The Forbes Galleries on lower Fifth Avenue will be emptying out their darkened maze of toys in dioramas, The Associated Press reported. Sothebys will organize about 7,500 pieces, including metal marching bands, submarines, motorcycles and a box of Titanic brand soap (Guaranteed to Sink), into about 250 lots for an auction on Dec. 17.

title: Where Engineering Prowess Meets Burning Man
description: At World Maker Faire, you might see a robot solving a Rubiks Cube. Or you might watch visitors making full 360-degree circles in a swing while, in another pavilion, people dressed as mice tap dance around a life-size version of the game Mouse Trap.

title: From Bargain Bin to the Battle Lines
description: MOST versions of the 2011 Volkswagen Jetta are capable of inducing a sort of reverse sticker shock, since they now cost some $1,700 to $2,300 less than the cars they replaced. No one is going to organize a protest against lower prices, but it is unclear how consumers will react to how Volkswagen achieved the savings.

title: Checking Accounts Worth the Fees
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I take a deep dive into the world of what bankers like to call mobile remote deposit capture. In English, that is a system that allows you to take a photograph of a check using a smartphone and then push a button to deposit it instantly into your checking account.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Jamey Johnson, Wall Street, Ken Burns and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Avoid Legal Pitfalls When Buying Art
description: Even in a sluggish economy, art auctions can be frothy places. But as the fall auction season kicks into high gear, the same emotion that gets buyers to bid up works of art may well lead to a different variation of buyers remorse.

title: 2011 Volkswagen Jetta
description: Volkswagen did not cut the Jettas core value: how entertaining it can be to drive.

title: James Madisons Win Over Virginia Tech Shows Rewards for F.C.S.
description: The day after James Madison stunned Virginia Tech in a game it was not expected to have a prayer of winning, Dukes Coach Mickey Matthews went to church. When Matthews sat down, his pastor pulled a James Madison hat from behind the pulpit, and the congregation stood and applauded.

title: Accessories From Milan Fashion Week
description: Shoes, handbags and glasses form the Gucci, Prada, Fendi and Verace spring 2011 shows.

title: N.B.A. Refereeing, There Will Be a Quiz
description: The N.B.A. announced a crackdown on players complaining about calls at its annual referee camp on Thursday and a marginal increase in instant replay to include its use in clear-path fouls and all of overtime.

title: Recessions and Recoveries Are Not All the Same
description: In the old days  before 1990  American recessions tended to be fairly sharp. But the recoveries, when they came, were also rapid. Laid-off workers were recalled and consumers who had deferred purchases out of fear they might lose their jobs were willing again to buy cars and homes.

title: Upstairs Downstairs
description: Good food and good mattresses are a classic combination, but this season three inns are breathing new life into the restaurant-with-rooms trend. In London, the St. John chef Fergus Henderson (above left), known for his nose-to-tail fare, is teaming with Trevor Gulliver (above right) to bring his humble yet decadent principles to the St. John Hotel (1 Leicester Street; 011-44-207-251-0848; doubles from about $310). It will offer 15 whitewashed and wainscoted rooms (mini grand urban hut is the theme) above the restaurant and bar. At Chicagos Longman & Eagle gastropub (2657 North Kedzie Avenue; 773-276-7110; doubles from $75), youll soon be able to retire upstairs to one of six retro-modern rooms should that flight of small-batch bourbons prove too much. And why stay in a chateau when you can stay in a revolving dome? The Dme de Montmiral (011-33-5-63-57-26-78; double room and board from about $193), near Castelnau de Montmiral, France, combines organic vegetarian food and cooking classes with a U.F.O.-worthy design.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Its a good weekend to be a beer drinker in New York. Today is the kick off of Craft Beer Week (Its actually a 10-day event that ends Oct. 3), when nearly 100 bars and 30 restaurants across all five boroughs will offer specials on beers (and some food pairings). A $10 pass gets you 3 beers.

title: Subaru Reworks Its 21-Year-Old Boxer Engine
description: Now that Subarus engine is old enough to drink, the automaker has taken steps to make it less thirsty. Subaru announced on Thursday that it has redesigned the horizontally opposed 4-cylinder boxer engine that has been a key component of its vehicles for many years. This reworking marks the first substantial change to the engine since the current version was introduced in 1989.

title: Expensive Cars, Built by Hand
description: Bristol builds expensive cars by hand in England and despite the global downturn, its sales are up.

title: A Quirky Car Company, Serving Quirky Customers
description: LONDON  For a certain kind of company, recessions may be beside the point.

title: Michael Crawford to Star in New Wizard of Oz
description: 3:18 p.m. | Updated Michael Crawford is set to play the Wizard in Andrew Lloyd Webbers new production of The Wizard of Oz, which will begin previews at the London Palladium on Feb. 7, 2011, according to Mr. Lloyd Webbers Web site. We will be going a lot further than simply presenting the movie on stage, Mr. Lloyd Webber said in a comment posted on the site. We have revisited the original novel and re-conceived our Oz as a piece of new musical theater using the wonderful Arlen/Harburg songs and adding a few new ones where there are gaps. Mr. Crawford starred in Mr. Lloyd Webbers production of The Phantom of the Opera in the West End in 1986 and on Broadway in 1988, where he won a Tony Award for best actor in a musical. Danielle Hope, the winner of the BBC television reality show Over the Rainbow, will play Dorothy. The production of L. Frank Baums classic tale will be directed by Jeremy Sams, choreographed by Arlene Phillips, with music and lyrics by Harold Arlen and E.Y. Harburg, with additional music and lyrics by Mr. Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice.

title: Borough Park, 9:25 A.M.
description: Rabbi Moshe Steinberg recites a blessing in the sukkah outside his home on 41st Street in Borough Park, Brooklyn. Sukkahs, which symbolize the transient homes the Israelites built during their 40 years in the desert, are built yearly to celebrate the holiday Sukkot. Today is the second day of the weeklong Jewish holiday.

title: A Conference Makes Learning Free (and Sexy)
description: ONCE a year, there is a mass migration of the intelligentsia to Long Beach, Calif.

title: Games Official Angers India With Hygiene Comment
description: NEW DELHI  Had the statement come from a non-Indian, especially a Westerner, it probably would have been angrily repudiated as an affront to Indian dignity. But the offending words came from a top Indian official trying to deflect criticism for the bureaucratic failings and lax preparations threatening the coming Commonwealth Games.

title: Chic in Review | Lady Gaga: 0, Daphne Guinness: -1
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: G.E. and Better Place to Partner on E.V. Charging
description: When General Electric announced the WattStation electric car charger last July, it seemed likely that it would need a charging company partner to make sure its E.V. station, styled with a designer touch by Yves Behar, would reach a wider world. Its one thing to produce a nice piece of hardware, but quite another to actively engage with automakers, governments, businesses and interest groups to make sure they get installed, both in public and in home garages.

title: Weekly Pick Em: Starting at the Top
description: The list of intriguing games this Saturday starts right at the top, with No. 1 Alabama traveling to Arkansas to take on the Razorbacks and their Heisman hopeful, quarterback Ryan Mallett. The Tide has been dominant so far, and the return of Mark Ingram last week gives them even more firepower. This is the kind of game that makes coming out of the Southeastern Conference unscathed such a feat, as is South Carolinas matchup with Auburn. Notre Dame has hit some bumps already in Brian Kellys first season as coach and it doesnt get any easier this weekend, with No. 16 Stanford coming to South Bend. Andrew Luck has been spectacular for the Cardinal so far, and a big game against the Irish could give him a lot of confidence heading into the rest of the Pac-10 schedule. West Virginia and Louisiana State are both undefeated, but have still managed to seem somewhat suspect. Will the Mountaineers be able to overcome the hostile environment they are sure to be greeted with in Baton Rouge? But perhaps the weekends most intriguing game is Oregon State traveling to Boise State, where it will face the Broncos on the Smurf Turf. Boise State needs a convincing win to answer some of the critics now downplaying its victory over Virginia Tech. Of course, the Beavers have knocked off top teams before (just ask U.S.C.). Will the Broncos see their national championship hopes dashed or will they get through their final non-conference test without a blemish? We have our thoughts. Feel free to share yours.

title: Congregations Reeling From Decline in Donations
description: Late this summer, as the countrys economic slump entered its third year, Bishop Robert E. Girtman met with the board of his church to discuss finances. The weekly collection of tithes and offerings, routinely $4,000 before the recession, had sunk to barely $3,000. Some members, newly jobless and ashamed, turned in tithing envelopes that were empty. Others skipped church a few Sundays a month to avoid the awkwardness of having nothing to give.

title: Delaware G.O.P. Spokesman Leaves Job
description: Thomas Doheny, spokesman for the Delaware Republican Party, was pretty tough on the opposition in the states recent Senate primary. As it turned out, the opposition, Christine ODonnell, won an upset victory, putting her on the campaign trail as the Republican Senate nominee while Mr. Doheny is hitting the road.

title: Halaks Start a Shaky One
description: Slap Shots blogger Stu Hackel is now also blogging for The Montreal Gazettes Habs Inside/Out blog and the sports departments of The Times and Gazette have agreed to cross-link Stus posts. These Habs Inside/Out posts will, like The Morning Skate, generally focus on league-wide issues and news. Todays post concerns some familiar names, like Stanley Cup playoff hero Jaroslav Halak, Alex Kovalev, Nikolai Khabibulin, as well as items on the Rangers hopeful Ryan McDonagh and the Anaheim Ducks owners.

title: Matt Damon in '30 Rock'
description: The actor guest stars as Tina Fey's boyfriend.

title: Visiting Pakistans Cut-Off Villages
description: Two months after the worst flooding in decades displaced millions of Pakistanis, Britains Channel 4 News reports that tens of thousands of people remain stranded in villages and farmsteads across the southern province of Sindh.

title: Clip: 'It's Kind of a Funny Story'
description: A John Hughes-inspired scene from "It's Kind of a Funny Story," with Keir Gilchrist and Emma Roberts.

title: Nets Discuss 4-Team Deal to Acquire Anthony
description: A complex four-team trade that would send Carmelo Anthony to New Jersey  and renew the dormant rivalry between the Nets and the Knicks  was under discussion Friday as N.B.A. teams prepared to open training camps.

title: And in the Left Corner, Weighing In ...
description: IM one of those actors who finds the part in the wardrobe, Lawrence ODonnell said. So this dressing like an anchorman thing is beginning to work.

title: Festivals Grow Up, Even as Screens Grow Small
description: FOR much of the world, film festivals remain impossibly glamorous affairs filled with rapturous beauties, flashing lights and the adoring cries of the public, an image that hews closer to a Federico Fellini film than the truth. These days, festivals tend to look very different, partly because their mission extends beyond the 10 or so days of the event itself. This might have interested the film theorist Andr Bazin, who in the early 1950s asked of the Cannes Film Festival, Why cant we have a serious geology as well as a flashy geography of our art? At the time, Cannes didnt present retrospective screenings that allowed festivalgoers to explore the history (geology) of cinema and not just its gaudy surface (geography). These days, the major festivals attend to both, and more.

title: Betty White in 'Community'
description: The actress guest stars as a professor.

title: Clip: 'The Breakfast Club'
description: A scene from John Hughes's "Breakfast Club."

title: Justin Bieber on 'C.S.I.'
description: The pop singer guest stars as a troubled youth.

title: YouTube Introduces a Travel Channel
description: YouTube introduced an online travel channel this month called the YouTube Vacationer. Sponsored by Norwegian Cruise Line, it features short videos on various destinations and activities organized geographically by tabs: Caribbean/Bahamas; Europe; United States and Canada; and Exotic (Latin America, Middle East, Africa).

title: Wall Street Sequel: Buy, Sell or Hold?
description: Gordon Gekko is back. Whether that is entirely a good thing is open for debate  and there is no shortage of debate on the subject.

title: London Design Festival | Cool and Cooler
description: This morning, Jasper Morrison held a press preview at his London studio and shop. He was showing the final prototypes of three designs: the country Trainer, a redesign of Campers 1975 Camaleon shoe; the r5.5 platinum chronograph for the Swiss watchmaker Rado; and the DP01 phone for Punkt, a new Swiss company. I liked them all, but I loved the phone. It sits keyboard side up on a hammock-like base, so you can read the screen and dial the number without picking it up, and the handset is magnetized, so the phone can sit horizontally or vertically (and be mounted on a wall). That its simple and beautiful goes without saying. The only bad thing about this phone is that it will not be available in the United States.

title: SoHo Holdouts
description: Murray Reich and Elizabeth Weatherford moved to SoHo when it was in transition from an industrial neighborhood to a residential frontier colonized by artists. They still live in their original loft, now quite domesticated.

title: A Teenager Flying Over a Cuckoos Nest
description: WHEN thinking of the directors Ryan Fleck and Anna Boden, light comedy may not be the first thing to come to mind. The teams first movie, Half Nelson, examined the life of a drug-addicted schoolteacher, while the follow-up, Sugar, tracked the trials of a Dominican baseball player who joins a minor-league team in Iowa. But the filmmakers have a message for audiences: They do have a sense of humor. And they love John Hughes.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Afghanistan, India, Cuba and China. (And, nearly all seriousness aside, dont stop till the very end of todays show, where there is some end-of-the-week comedy, centrally from Stephen Colbert, who testified before Congress in Washington on Friday.)

title: A Recessions Effect on Poverty
description: The recession pushed nearly 100,000 additional New York City residents into poverty last year, according to an analysis by the Fiscal Policy Institute to be published on Monday.

title: Fast and Finely Crafted, Spindizzies Still Dazzle
description: Fresno, Calif.

title: Living in Princes Bay, Staten Island
description: A lush seaside community in Staten Island, Princes Bay has a relatively modern housing stock, along with a few older homes.

title: Credit Unions Expand Their Clientele
description: OVER the years, a number of home buyers have turned to credit unions as a less expensive alternative, often finding fixed- and adjustable-rate mortgages with interest rates equal to or lower than those offered by mainstream banks.

title: The 3,200-Square-Foot Adventure
description: IN a fourth-floor loft on Spring Street near Greene Street, where a century ago workers cut fabric for hospital scrubs, a fragment of the old SoHo is preserved as if in amber, removed from the tourists and shoppers who now crowd the streets.

title: Annemarie G. DiCola

description: IN real estate, as in romance, leaving your first love can be hard to do. For John Rosas Jr., who lived most of his first 38 years in Bensonhurst, choosing to buy a home outside of Brooklyn was not accomplished without emotion. But in 2008, after a brief rental in the Oakwood section of Staten Island, Mr. Rosas and his wife, Nikki, packed up their three children and moved to Princes Bay, on the south shore.

On Friday morning in a parking lot at the Meadowlands in New Jersey, though, the company took what might seem to be an incongruous route to that goal, inviting journalists to stop by and purposely drive some Lexus vehicles recklessly.

description: Reinhard Krause has spent much of his photojournalism career in some of the most tumultuous and critical places on the planet  including North Korea, Kosovo, Tibet and, most recently, the flooded regions of Pakistan. Beginning in November, all the hot spots in the world will constitute his beat, as the global pictures editor of Reuters, leading 400 staff and freelance photographers.

description: TETHER car races are regularly held at three tracks: in Anderson, Ind.; Seaford, N.Y.; and the Whittier Narrows Recreation Area in South El Monte, Calif. Details are at amrca.com.

title: California Dreaming
description: Jay Carroll, the man behind the style site onetrippass.com, and who was recently featured in our mens fall fashion issue, has spent the last week driving from Portland, Oregon to Los Angeles with Jou-Yie Chou, the curator of the Ace Hotel and photographer Nate Bressler. Travelling in a vintage Airstream, theyve picked up a couple of stylish friends Cassie McGettigan, co-owner of San Franciscos Gravel & Gold, Andrea Westerlind, the brand manager for outerwear company Fjallraven along the way. The mission was simple: to collect all things Californiafrom interesting artwork to vintage crafts. Who doesnt want to cruise around the West Coast cultivating a cross section of California culture in an Airstream with good friends, says Carroll. Stopping to camp every night, drink PBR and blast a daily dose of vitamin Neil?

title: Report: Max Weinberg Wont Follow Conan to TBS
description: On a day of rapid transitions and abrupt departures in the television industry, could the late-night landscape at least be spared? Apparently not: Max Weinberg, the drummer and longtime band leader for Conan OBrien, will not be following the host to his new show at TBS, according to a report in The Riverfront Times of St. Louis.

title: Choreographic Institute Alumni to Present Works
description: Larry Keigwin, Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon are among the alumni of the New York Choreographic Institute who will create original works for the 10th-anniversary celebration of the organization, an affiliate of New York City Ballet. Their work, along with new pieces by their fellow alumni Darius Barnes, Marco Goecke, Jessica Lang and Justin Peck, will be performed during three shows at the Miller Theater at Columbia University on Nov. 5 and 6. Members of New York City Ballet, including Joaquin De Luz, Megan Fairchild, Sara Mearns, Tiler Peck, Teresa Reichlen, Wendy Whelan and Andrew Veyette, as well as students from the School of American Ballet, will perform and live music will be provided by the American Contemporary Music Ensemble. Mr. Keigwin, Mr. Ratmansky and Mr. Wheeldon will each create a short dance set to the same original music by Daniel Ott. The New York Choreographic Institute was founded in 2000 by the philanthropist Irene Diamond and City Ballets ballet master in chief, Peter Martins, as a laboratory for classical choreography.

title: Thursday Is Fathers Day
description: Viewers gave two new sitcoms solid debuts on Thursday night. According to Nielsens estimates, $#*! My Dad Says, a CBS series starring William Shatner that is based on a Twitter feed, earned an impressive start, attracting 12.5 million viewers. That was down from the 14 million who watched the premiere of CBSs Big Bang Theory, but enough to outperform all other programming for the night, with the exception of season premieres of ABCs Greys Anatomy (14 million), CBSs CSI (14.6 million) and The Mentalist (15.3 million). NBCs Outsourced (7.4 million) also made a promising start, about a million less than its lead-in, The Office (8.4 million), but considerably better than NBCs returning comedies Community (five million) and 30 Rock (5.8 million). Meanwhile, the new series My Generation kicked off the night for ABC with a disappointing 5.2 million viewers.

title: Improvising, in Truest Sense of the Word
description: The most important member of Rhonda Vincents touring troupe on Thursday night turned out not to be her fiddle player or her bassist but her bus driver. Sometime during the afternoon, while the band was already in Manhattan, he got into an accident in the Lincoln Tunnel. The instruments, the stage outfits, the merchandise: none of it made it to Joes Pub by showtime.

title: A Thai Region Where Husbands Are Imported
description: UDON, THAILAND  The most dazzling creatures Nui Davis saw when she was a child were the village girls who had found foreign husbands, visiting in their Western finery and handing out candies to the children.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  Dell settled a lawsuit Thursday that accused it of selling faulty computers and then trying to conceal the defects from its customers.

title: Yales Endowment Returns 8.9% for the Year
description: Yale University said on Friday that its endowment, which has sizable assets in real estate, had an investment gain of 8.9 percent last year, an underwhelming performance in a year when many big endowments are reporting gains of 9 percent to 14 percent.

title: Seduced by a Savior Who Likes to Dance
description: The theme of Danspace Projects latest Platform series, certain difficulties, certain joy, fits Larissa Velez-Jackson perfectly. A choreographer who is not afraid of being (or showing) ugly onstage, she also disarms her audiences with  humor. When the approach works  as it did to varying degrees on Thursday night  there is a dark charm to the way difficulty and joy bump up against each other and, in fleeting moments, interlace.

title: Its Kind of a John Hughes Homage
description: The spirit of John Hughes seems to be making a resurgence this fall. Last week, the Film Society of Lincoln Center paid its respects to the director, who died last year, with a 25th-Anniversary screening of his teen comedy The Breakfast Club. Now, Ryan Fleck and Anna Boden, the filmmakers behind the dramas Half Nelson and Sugar, make their third directorial outing with a comedy inspired in part by Mr. Hughess work. Its Kind of a Funny Story, which opens October 8, is based on the young adult novel by Ned Vizzini and, much in the Hughesian tradition, features a teenage protagonist (Keir Gilchrist). Mr. Fleck and Ms. Boden discussed Mr. Hughess impact in an interview for Arts & Leisure. While they didnt aim to copy the directors style, they did make a direct homage to The Breakfast Club in one scene. Below is a look at the scene from Funny Story.

They do not even need to be sweet. You can add cheese, herbs, spices, even chopped sun-dried tomatoes or olives, making these biscuits a nifty alternative to crackers.

But analysts say that a significant portion of the decline is actually the result of financial institutions writing off billions of dollars in credit card debt as losses.

title: Making a Name Writing to Editors

In the sprawling lobby, editors, writers and arbiters of style glided skyward to their respective aeries, on escalators flanked by rainwater waterfalls. Mr. Crawford, 38, skateboard under his arm, headed to his work space through a side door, taking the stairs beneath the escalators to the basement. Hes the mail guy.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City

It is the culmination of a dream for two brothers, Justin and George Ruotolo, who diligently saved tips while working as bartenders to start their own chain of bars. Its the first weve built from the ground up, said Justin, 31, who owns two bars in downtown Manhattan with George, 38. (The brothers have another business partner, Rob Magill.)

Sabathia came unhinged, leaves the Yankees vulnerable for a first-round exit  that is, if they make the playoffs at all. Somewhere in the middle, reality exists. But the judge set specific conditions, including giving the condemned man the option of a single drug to be used in a lethal injection, an issue that has bogged down executions in the state before.

title: Mexico: President Condemns Killing of Another Mayor
description: President Felipe Caldern energetically condemned the murder late Thursday of Mayor Prisciliano Rodrguez of the northern town of Doctor Gonzlez, the fourth killing of a local mayor in less than two months. Gunmen killed Mr. Rodrguez and a local government aide, Eliseo Lpez, on a highway in Nuevo Len State, according to the state attorney generals office.

title: China: Weekend Traffic Expected to Be Especially Heavy in Beijing
description: Chinese officials are warning that this weekend will likely be an especially bad traffic period in Beijing, as people return to work after the three-day Moon Festival holiday. Chinese workers are expected to be at their jobs Saturday and Sunday to make up for days off during two holiday periods. The traffic warning is a further indication that the number of cars clogging Beijing roads is reaching a critical mass. On the evening of Sept. 17, a record 140 traffic jams were recorded in Beijing, according to Chinese news organizations. Chinese officials had designated Sept. 22, the day of the Moon Festival, as a car-free day, but roads throughout central Beijing were clogged at dinnertime. In late August, a 10,000-car, 60-mile-long traffic jam outside Beijing that lasted 10 days threw a spotlight onto Chinas epic congestion problems.

title: Israel: Palestinians Blame Israel in Death of a Gaza Fisherman
description: Israeli naval forces fatally shot a Gaza fisherman early Friday, Palestinian officials said. The Israeli military said naval forces fired warning shots at a Palestinian fishing boat that had sailed closer to Israeli waters than the three nautical miles the country has designated as a fishing zone boundary. When the boat did not stop or change course, the navy fired on it directly. The Palestinians identified the dead fisherman as Muhammad Mansour Bakr, 20.

title: Afghanistan: Copies of a War Memoir Are Destroyed
description: The Defense Department confirmed on Friday that it had destroyed 9,500 copies of an Afghan war memoir by a former intelligence officer to prevent the disclosure of what it considered to be classified information, a Pentagon spokeswoman said. Department officials on Monday observed the destruction of the books, the uncensored first printing of Anthony Shaffers Operation Dark Heart, the spokeswoman said. A second printing, with about 250 passages blacked out, went on sale Friday. A person familiar with the negotiations said the Pentagon had paid St. Martins Press about $5 a book, for a cost to taxpayers of nearly $50,000. Publishing executives say they believe it was the first time the government had destroyed a print run of a book to protect secrets. About 100 uncensored advance copies of Operation Dark Heart were distributed before the Pentagon intervened, and some have sold online for as much as $2,000.

title: Secrets Cited in White House Effort to Block Suit

How they pitch, especially Nova, will still be of interest, of course, but the results of this weekends games will trump their individual performances. The same could not have been said about Andy Pettittes start on Friday night, when he allowed seven runs and had as many hits allowed (10) as outs recorded (10), which is never a good thing for a starting pitcher, no matter what the number is.
