description: WASHINGTON  In 2004, the Republican master strategist Karl Rove led weekly sessions at his Washington residence where, over big plates of his butter-smothered eggies and bacon slabs, he planned the re-election of President George W. Bush  and what he hoped would be lasting Republican dominion over Democrats.

title: The Secrets of a Passive House
description: When completed, the Landau residence now under construction in Norwich, Vt., will be one of about a dozen buildings certified as passive houses in the United States.

title: Boehners Top Aide Is Little Known
description: WASHINGTON  Representative John A. Boehner and Barry Jackson cut an odd figure.

title: Sloppy but Strong, Alabama Rallies
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.  In the era of the spread offense and the quarterback who can sling the ball down the field, it is still imperative to have the running back who can hold the football high and tight and gash a defense without fumbling. The reliable rushing game trumps the slick plays of the spread passing game  if not all the time, then most of the time.

title: Aug. 12, 1974: Closed Government, Broken Republic
description: During a recent country-radio discussion of a new so-called sunshine law  one that requires open governmental meetings  a caller said to me: There are two things a person should never watch being made. One is potted meat, and the other is laws.

title: An Introduction to Op-Ed at 40
description: On Sept. 21, 1970, readers who turned to the last inside page of The Timess main section found something new. The obituaries that normally appeared in that space had been moved, replaced by something called Op-Ed. The vision of John Oakes, the editorial page editor, and Harrison Salisbury, the eminent foreign correspondent, Op-Ed was meant to open the paper to outside voices. It was to be a venue for writers with no institutional affiliation with the paper, people from all walks of life whose views and perspectives would often be at odds with the opinions expressed on the editorial page across the way. (Hence, Op-Ed  Opposite Editorial.)

title: Jan. 14, 1976: Israels Reality
description: We dispossessed no Arabs. Whatever subsequent ills befell the Arabs were the inevitable result of the Arab design to drive us into the sea. Had Israel not repelled her would-be destroyers there would have been no Jewish refugees alive in the Middle East to concern the world.

title: March 29, 2000: Elin Gonzlez, Stranded
description: On Friday, when Juan Miguel Gonzlez went to school to pick up his son Elin for the weekend, he was told that Elizabet Brotons, his ex-wife and the boys mother, had taken Elin at midday and had not brought him back in the afternoon. In his routine as a divorced father, this seemed normal to Juan Miguel. From the time when he and Elizabet had separated two years earlier, on the most amicable terms, the boy had lived with his father and spent every other day at his mothers house.

title: Dec. 18, 1981: Poland Takes On an Empire
description: Takeovers by military juntas, like the one in Poland, are nothing new in the sad chronicles of our century. Again and again, guns and tanks have been used to silence voices calling for freedom and dignity. Yet, there is something radically new in the current Polish situation, just as the Solidarity movement is without precedent in modern history.

title: June 8, 1974: My Con Ed Bill
description: On quitting New York City in 1957 where I had been living under the name Jean Stafford, I asked Consolidated Edison to send my final bill. Instead of a bill, I received a check for six cents, which represented, I supposed, what was left of my deposit. I kept it, partly as a curio, partly in the hope that in a wee way I could bollix up the company books, and partly because I thought it might come in handy some day. Eleven years later, thanks to my mean-spirited foresight, I was able to use it as a tactical diversion in a battle I fought with and won from Con Ed.

title: July 18, 1983: Aid for Apartheid
description: We shall continue to intensify the struggle in South Africa. If Washington genuinely wants to contribute to stability in the region, it should use its influence with Pretoria to restrain it from exporting the conflict it has imposed on the people of South Africa.

title: June 1, 2008: My Big Bang
description: Like a life without music, art or literature, a life without science is bereft of something that gives experience a rich and otherwise inaccessible dimension.

title: Feb. 18, 1996: Machine 1, Man 0
description: Among the array of graver and more material contests now facing civilization, struggles from Sarajevo to New Hampshire, the one decided yesterday in Philadelphia stands out in its symbolic weight. In the chess match between Garry Kasparov, the worlds best living player, and I.B.M.s Deep Blue, an otherwise undistinguished supercomputer, humanitys collective self-esteem was once more on the line.

title: May 5, 1991: Lawn Care
description: THREE years after George Bush told us he wanted to be remembered as the environmental president, he has done little to earn that distinction  unless one regards his catch-and-release policy on bonefishing as a major environmental initiative.

title: Nov. 20, 1991: Date Rape Mythology
description: Now the cry across campuses is date rape. Those involved frame it as a liberal concern, cut and dry, beyond debate. But they dont stop to consider the sexist images lurking beneath their rhetoric. The term date rape itself hints at its conservative bent. More than just a polemic against rape, it reveals a desire for dates.

title: Jan. 17, 1993: Auguries, Pieties and Memory
description: MY Washington town house was built in 1905  just in time, perhaps, to observe the inauguration of Theodore Roosevelt, who was sworn in on March 4. As a writer living in what amounts to an ivory tower  or at least an off-white walk-up  I like to imagine myself seated here then, catching a few of Roosevelts screechy remarks. It was a windy day, and he had to keep a tight hold of his typescript. Who knows, the phrase Power invariably means both responsibility and danger may have blown across the park and buffeted against these curving panes.

title: Jan. 31, 1978: The Paralyzing Bullet
description: It is the morning of Jan. 20, 1978. I couldnt sleep last night because today is my anniversary. It was 10 years ago on this day that I was shot and paralyzed in Vietnam.

title: Aug. 19, 2003: Lights Out, Everybody Home
description: Mine is a youngish, slightly tatty hood: video clerks, personal trainers, life coaches, voice-over actors and lots of chain-smoking older women with small dogs.

title: July 29, 1979: If Black English Isnt a Language, What Is?
description: I DO not know what white Americans would sound like if there had never been any black people in the United States, but they would not sound the way they sound. Jazz, for example, is a very specific sexual term, as in jazz me, baby, but white people purified it into the Jazz Age. Sock it to me, which means, roughly, the same thing, has been adopted by Nathaniel Hawthornes descendants with no qualms or hesitations at all, along with let it all hang out and right on! Beat to his socks, which was once the blacks most total and despairing image of poverty, was transformed into a thing called the Beat Generation, which phenomenon was, largely, composed of uptight, middle-class white people, imitating poverty, trying to get down, to get with it, doing their thing, doing their despairing best to be funky, which we, the blacks, never dreamed of doing  we were funky, baby, like funk was going out of style.

title: Aug. 15, 1973: Goings On in the Barnyard
description: WHEN The Times asked me to report on whats being said in my barnyard about Watergate, I immediately sought an audience with the goose. She is sore at me at the moment but is always willing to talk.

title: May 18, 2003: All the Presidents Girls
description: I too was an intern in the J.F.K. White House. I was. This is not one of those humor pieces where the writer pretends to some experience related to the news in order to make an amusing point. It was 1961, and I was hired by Pierre Salinger to work in the press office, the very same place where Mimi Beardsley, later Fahnestock, was to work the next year. And now that she has been forced to come forward to admit that she had an affair with Kennedy, I might as well tell my story.

title: Sept. 22, 1988: The Biggest Insult in Politics
Sept. 16, 1975: Asleep at the Fiscal Crisis
description: We are in a fiscal mess. The effects were not merely regional but nationwide. We induced cheap labor to come here to glut a full-up market. We created a huge relief program, only part of which should on any reasonable theory fall on New York. We have had little sympathy and aid from Washington.

title: June 17, 1987: Our Central American Misadventure
description: Central America is another example of the superpower fallacy. Our policy of military intervention seeks to save the other countries from the wicked Sandinistas. But most Latin American governments think that policy increases desperation and chaos and is far more likely to promote than to check the spread of Marxist revolution.

title: June 7, 2004: Making Peace With Reagan
description: Ronald Reagans first term had been dedicated to restoring Americas self-confidence. He regarded as his main task strengthening the economy and the military might of the United States. This was accompanied by confrontational rhetoric toward the Soviet Union, and by actions that caused concern both in our country and throughout the world. It seemed that the most important thing for Reagan was his reputation as a hawk who saw the Soviet Union as an evil empire.

title: Aug. 28, 2008: Johnsons Dream, Obamas Speech
description: As I watch Barack Obamas speech at the Democratic convention tonight, I will be remembering another speech: the one that made Martin Luther King cry. And I will be thinking: Mr. Obamas speech  and in a way his whole candidacy  might not have been possible had that other speech not been given.

title: May 16, 2010: Fatal Attraction
description: Philosophy should come with the kind of health warning one finds on packs of European cigarettes: Philosophy kills. Socrates was charged with impiety toward the gods of the city and with corrupting the youth of Athens. He was obliged to speak in court in defense of these charges, to speak against the water clock, that thief of time. He ran out of time and suffered the consequences: he was condemned to death and forced to take his own life.

title: Sept. 28, 1972: Winning Vietnam
description: The United States forces have fulfilled their role in supporting the South Vietnamese in a superb manner. Particularly noteworthy and effective have been the United States air operations against the invading enemy forces.

title: March 19, 1989: The Planetary Crisis on the Horizon
description: Humankind has suddenly entered into a brand-new relationship with our planet.

title: Feb. 25, 1971: A Quagmire Widens
description: So this time it is Laos.

title: Jan. 31, 2010: Where Do Numbers Come From?
description: The best introduction to numbers Ive ever seen appears in a Sesame Street video. Humphrey is working the lunch shift at the Furry Arms hotel, when he takes a call from a room full of penguins. Humphrey listens carefully and then calls out their order to the kitchen: Fish, fish, fish, fish, fish, fish. This prompts Ernie to enlighten him about the virtues of the number six.

title: Feb. 3, 2002: The Palestinian Vision of Peace
description: For the past 16 months, Israelis and Palestinians have been locked in a catastrophic cycle of violence, a cycle that promises only more bloodshed and fear. The cycle has led many to conclude that peace is impossible, a myth borne out of ignorance of the Palestinian position.

title: March 18, 1972: Mr. Audens Neighborhood
description: New York is a city of neighborhoods, and I consider myself extremely fortunate in the one where I have lived for the past 20 years. (To me, it will always be the the Lower East Side, never the East Village.)

title: May 20, 2009: What You Dont Know Makes You Nervous
description: People feel worse when something bad might occur than when something bad will occur. Most of us arent losing sleep and sucking down Marlboros because the Dow is going to fall another thousand points, but because we dont know whether it will fall or not  and human beings find uncertainty more painful than the things theyre uncertain about.

title: Oct. 8, 1992: How to Use Military Force
description: There has been a spate of commentary over the use of American military force to deal with the vexing problems of an untidy post-cold-war world. Let me respond by reviewing recent history.

title: July 27, 1972: Supersonic Slowdown
description: A supersonic transport is fast, but it is costly, noisy and a polluter, and its range is relatively short.

title: Aug. 11, 1974: Nixon vs. Laws
description: We have had constitutional crises before but, except for the Civil War and Reconstruction, none that had the dimensions of those precipitated by Richard M. Nixon. Never before have we had a crisis that challenged the basic assumptions of our constitutional system itself, and the basic processes and mechanisms through which it worked.

title: March 4, 1993: A First Assault on the Twin Towers
description: PUT yourself in the minds eye of the bomber. Its likely he first viewed the city from the air, looked out and saw the twin towers mirroring each others dizzying rise. Or maybe he stood at the window of a safe house in Queens or New Jersey and looked at them thrusting so immodestly over a thousand feet in the air; no doubt he thought they mocked his passionate intensity.

title: Dec. 17, 1983: Criminal Neglect
description: The Lower East Side as we know it, and as our parents and grandparents knew it, may disappear. There is a war being fought there, a territorial war. On one side are hard-working, law-abiding people. On the other are the invaders who use the streets and abandoned buildings to carry on an open market in drugs.

title: Oct. 28, 1992: No Party Toppled the Soviets
description: The claim heard in campaign rhetoric that the United States under Republican Party leadership won the cold war is intrinsically silly.

title: Talk From Dungy Doesnt Lead to Much Pep for the Struggling Yankees
description: Should Manager Joe Girardi want his Yankees to hear another football pep talk, he might consider that old film of Knute Rockne addressing his Notre Dame players.

title: Sept. 10, 2002: War on Whom?
description: Since the Sept. 11 attacks, the Bush administration has told the American people that America is at war. But this war is of a peculiar nature. It seems to be, given the nature of the enemy, a war with no foreseeable end. What kind of war is that?

title: July 6, 2003: What I Didnt Find in Africa
description: Did the Bush administration manipulate intelligence about Saddam Husseins weapons programs to justify an invasion of Iraq?

title: What the Rich Dont Need
description: WANT to give affluent households a present worth $700 billion over the next decade? In a period of high unemployment and fiscal austerity, this idea may seem laughable. Amazingly, though, it is getting traction in Washington.

title: April 1, 1971: Victims of Welfare
description: Welfare is a national moral and administrative disaster  a cancer that is destroying those it should succor and threatening society itself.

title: July 8, 2005: Londons Shock
description: In Audens poem Muse des Beaux Arts, the tragedy of Icarus falling from the sky is accompanied by life refusing to be disrupted. A plowman goes about his work, a ship sailed calmly on, dogs keep on with their doggy life.

title: Nov. 27, 2000: Why Gore Should Concede
description: FOUR years ago, I conceded the presidential election as soon as the winner was determined. There was a lot less suspense that year than this time around. But when the outcome was clear, so was my duty.

title: Oct. 4, 1998: A Case Against Impeachment
description: When I succeeded to the presidency, in August 1974, my overriding priority was to draw off the poison that had seeped into the nations bloodstream during two years of scandal and partisanship. Some Americans have yet to forgive me for pardoning my predecessor. In the days leading up to that hugely controversial action, I didnt take a poll for guidance, but I did say more than a few prayers. In the end I listened to only one voice, that of my conscience. I didnt issue the pardon for Richard Nixons sake, but for the countrys.

title: Dec. 25, 1990: A Brooklyn Story
description: I heard this story from Auggie Wren. Since Auggie doesnt come off too well in it, at least not as well as hed like to, hes asked me not to use his real name. Other than that, the whole business about the lost wallet and the blind woman and the Christmas dinner is just as he told it to me.

title: Jan. 4, 2009: Wall Streets Fatal Blind Spot
May 4, 1989: China in Revolt
description: The possibility exists that the democratic movement will be suppressed by force. Indeed, a government spokesman has hinted at reprisals against a handful of people behind the scenes engaged in political struggle against the Communist Party.

title: April 23, 2009: My Tortured Decision
description: For seven years I have remained silent about the false claims magnifying the effectiveness of so-called enhanced interrogation techniques like waterboarding. I have spoken only in closed government hearings, as these matters were classified. But the release last week of four Justice Department memos on interrogations allows me to shed light on the story.

title: Dec. 2, 1994: Give em Hell
description: The similarities between the 1994 Republican triumph and the Congressional elections of 1946 are the subject of great interest. Not only did the Republicans win the House and Senate by substantial majorities, recovering power after years of Democratic control, but the Democrat in the White House was humiliated, both at the polls and by the withering invective of the campaign.

title: Nov. 5, 1992: Generations End
description: HAVING rebuffed a fine man whose presidency failed, about half the country, I suspect, will have the rueful blues this weekend.

title: Sept. 28, 2008: Greenwich Time
description: Be aware that your correspondent is merely bringing you the news when he reports how many people have besieged the author of The Bonfire of the Vanities with the question, Where does this leave the Masters of the Universe now?

title: Jan. 29, 1979: Misreading Islam
description: In times of trouble, certain characteristics of predominantly Muslim countries are emphasized in the media, while others disappear. Consider Iran.

title: Oct. 27, 1996: Superstores That Were Truly Super
description: Any kid who grew up in the city before the arrival of McDonalds and the big box stores selling books, beds and bath towels can tell you how strange a first trip to a shopping mall was. For us, shopping was synonymous with striding through the city. One day we could cruise a Fifth Avenue department store, just like Lauren Bacall in a career-gal movie, and later spend hours in an Eighth Street bookshop, displaying a genuine interest in the poetry of Allen Ginsberg.

title: June 22, 1975: Is the Third World War Over?
description: When the Second World War followed on the heels of the First, the question that obsessed everyone was whether World War III would follow in turn. How many concessions and sacrifices were made to delay it, in the hope of perhaps avoiding it altogether?

title: March 19, 2003: Growing Up at Normandy
description: Until I set foot on the Normandy sands, I was a chap of calm and sanguine disposition whose worst anxieties were on the order of seeing a traffic cop in the rearview mirror; now, in a single tick of a clock, I became a marionette on a string, ducking and weaving in an effort to get away from the invisible bits of metal I could hear buzzing like bees above my head and past my ears. (Useless acrobatics on my part, of course; the bullet you hear has already missed you.)

title: Dec. 31, 2007: Across the World in 36 Hours
description: I left California for Jerusalem a few hours after Christmas Day, and in short order I witnessed the excitement of Friday prayers at the Temple Mount, clusters of pilgrims chanting their way along the Via Dolorosa, dancing Jews greeting the Sabbath at the Western Wall. On the same British Airways flight down from Heathrow that I took, more than 30 years ago, Saul Bellow encountered three-hour security exercises, a desperate dearth of kosher food and aisles blocked by the praying faithful. This week all I faced was a day in a transit lounge, a plane with just four Hasidim but 10 times as many American college students, and chewable toothpaste on sale at Heathrow.

title: March 12, 2004: Madrids Silent Noon
description: The terrorist attacks almost always happen in the early morning. Whether it turns out that yesterdays train-station bombings in Madrid were the work of the usual suspects  the Basque terrorist group ETA  or of Al Qaeda or another group altogether, the murderers stuck to the usual timetable.

title: Aug. 18, 1982: How to Think About Dtente
description: To many Americans, dtente has become a dirty word, virtually synonymous with appeasement. To most Europeans, it is a good word. To them it describes a period in the early and middle 1970s when tensions between East and West were lessened and when there was more trade, more contact, some liberalization in Eastern Europe and, above all, a reduced danger of nuclear war.

title: Aug. 19, 2007: The Iraq We Saw
description: Viewed from Iraq at the tail end of a 15-month deployment, the political debate in Washington is indeed surreal. To believe that Americans, with an occupying force that long ago outlived its reluctant welcome, can win over a recalcitrant local population and defeat this counterinsurgency is far-fetched.

title: Sept. 14, 1974: Raising Boys
description: For the last 27 years I have been stewing and brewing about an incident that took place one misty autumn afternoon in a farmyard on the outskirts of the village of Great Missenden, and I have many times wondered where and when I should make the facts known to the world. So here we go. The story is a true one.

title: Sept. 22, 1992: The Draft Card
description: I was at Oxford just before Bill Clinton, but while he was lobbying to get a deferment I was undergoing Marine Corps training, utterly convinced I was preparing to be killed. When he received his high lottery number and went off to Yale Law School, I was leading a platoon of high school dropouts west of Danang.

title: Jan. 19, 1987: The Roots of Howard Beach
description: By now, the Howard Beach story is well known: three black men walking in a white neighborhood were set upon by a gang of white teenagers. Shouting racial epithets, the gang chased and assaulted the black men, one of whom was killed when he ran onto a highway. The assaults appear to have been provoked only by the fact that the men were black.

title: Jan. 23, 2003: Why We Know Iraq Is Lying
description: Eleven weeks after the United

title: If Congress Stalls, Do Stocks Rise?
description: IS political gridlock really good for the stock market?

title: Feb. 20, 1983: Second City Police Blotter
description: Chicago, which likes to think of itself as the city primeval, has burst into sensational flower this winter. Tuesdays Democratic mayoral primary has produced some strange growths, and simultaneously the underworld, volcanically disturbed by pressure from the federal government, has erupted spectacularly. Not long ago, Allen Dorfman of the Teamsters pension fund was gunned down in a parking lot. Now plea-bargaining witnesses are talking freely about Joey Lombardo, known as Joey the Clown, convicted with Dorfman and Roy Williams, the Teamsters union president, of conspiring to bribe Senator Howard W. Cannon of Nevada. Politics are politics, crime is crime, but in Chicago they occasionally overlap. The line between virtue and vice meanders madly  effective government on one side, connections on the other.

title: Aug. 4, 1993: Balkan Excuses
description: As America lies in its state-induced moral stupor, lots of people die violent deaths all over the place, particularly in the Balkans. When it comes to externalizing evil, few things can rival geography or, for that matter, history.

title: Dec. 4, 1970: A Righteous America?
description: Our record as a righteous nation has proved so filled with error that, obviously, we must stop thanking God we are not like other nations. This humility will not solve the multiple problems that confront our nation, once infant and comparatively innocent, but now a nuclear super-nation.

title: March 6, 2006: Desert Fog
description: The other morning I walked out of my hooch and saw antennae standing watch like silent sentinels, sticking their heads up out of the fog. The sun looked like a silver coin through the haze. You could stare right at it. The horizon was shrouded. I heard a large explosion, but the sound was compressed as if in a vacuum; it was hard to tell if it was an I.E.D. on a road just outside the base or a mortar attack inside the wire. By midmorning, the clouds served as a prism and there was a golden glare all over the world. It wasnt the kind of gold you might imagine while reading a poem by Robert Frost. It was the fallow brown of a vast desert come to steal away the mirage of safety.

title: Dec. 3, 1976: Tax Cuts and False Hopes
description: In the weeks  after the presidential election, quite a number of my economist friends of distinguished reputation expressed themselves promptly and decisively on behalf of a tax reduction to stimulate the economy. No partisanship was involved; the same action was also proposed and taken early in the Ford administration.

title: April 19, 1992: My AIDS Death
description: When I discovered I was infected with H.I.V., I wasnt worried at first. Maybe I was in denial. My T4 cells, a key measure of immune system health, were high.

title: July 14, 1991: A Cost to Freedom
description: The experience of the postwar period has shown us that no amount of economic assistance will make a totalitarian country more prosperous unless it is also made more democratic. In the beginning of 1990, the Soviet Union was still largely undecided about where it was going, and any economic assistance would most likely have gone down the bottomless drain of bureaucracy, incompetence and corruption. This situation has changed. The democratic forces are trying to organize themselves and to make a radical break with the past.

title: Oct. 2, 1970: God and the Future
description: Millions of Americans are caught up in a desperate attempt to know the future. The phenomenal rise in the sale of crystal balls, Ouija boards and Viennese fortunetelling tarot cards is only a part of the new groping into the future.

title: July 1, 1972: Union Blues
description: I am a pensioned railroader. I put in 42 years in overalls on one of Americas great railroad systems. Before that I worked in the coal mines, in the timber country and in the building trades. I earned my first wages working underground helping to gut this old earth. I bought my first overcoat and overshoes from my mine earnings in August. I had been cold all my life.

title: Oct. 4, 1995: Reasonable Doubt
description: The prosecution of O. J. Simpson was doomed from the start. Not in the sense that the state lacked proof  the case against Mr. Simpson remains compelling. But the prosecution was a low-road enterprise that began with the kinds of ugly tactics that have aroused suspicions about the criminal justice system among members of racial minorities in Los Angeles and elsewhere.

title: April 23, 1993: God and Waco
description: No three cultures could be more mutually incomprehensible than the trinity at Waco: Branch Davidians, G-men and the news media. This is not because they came from different places; on the contrary, it is easy to imagine members of all three groups growing up in the same town in the Midwest, starting out as schoolmates and winding up on opposite sides of barricades shouting gibberish at one another.

title: Jan. 4, 1975: Captive to Human Nature
description: For reasons with which I sympathize, one makes oneself unpopular with progressive people if one blames human nature for public evils. True, the argument that human nature is bad is often used as an excuse by interested parties who oppose social change. All the same, we seem to have got to a stage in the worlds history where at every point we are brought up against human nature as an impassable wall that prevents us taking obvious measures to save ourselves from destruction.

title: Stanfords Defense, and Confidence, Grows
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  Moments after his defense carried No. 16 Stanford to its first victory at Notre Dame Stadium since 1992, Coach Jim Harbaugh smiled, looked around a packed media room, and remarked that it might have been the biggest press conference he had ever been to.

title: May 5, 2006: Mad Women
description: Standing in the kitchen, my fingers gripping the baking sheet, my wrist preparing to fling it like a Frisbee, it began to dawn on me that perhaps I was having some issues. I had not been quite this crazy since the spring of 2003, when my new French au pair had up and quit on the eve of the Iraq war (Its too dangerous here), which happened to be the very week when my book (of which I had not written a word) was officially due to its publisher. Back then, Id become mentally paralyzed, unable to decide for days whether to order a basic or deluxe Hello Kitty package from Birthday Express. Now, it was chocolate: double boiler or not?

title: March 22, 1998: Why Feminists Support Clinton
description: If all the sexual allegations now swirling around the White House turn out to be true, President Clinton may be a candidate for sex addiction therapy. But feminists will still have been right to resist pressure by the right wing and the news media to call for his resignation or impeachment. The pressure came from another case of the double standard.

title: June 1, 1997: The Terrorist Next Door
description: Lady, you would be so easy to kill. More than three years later, these words still haunt me. My assailant growled this threat as I lay in the darkness on the floor of my garage, stunned and dazed from being beaten, kicked and knifed. Then he put a gun to my head and dry-fired it several times.

title: June 21, 2006: Dead of the Night
description: Four of my friends were killed by a double roadside bomb in Karada. Thats right, four, count them  that is, if you can identify their bodies. Forever gone  can you imagine that?

title: March 30, 2009: Drinking Games
description: My years of heavy drinking were roughly coterminous with my youth, and looking back now, its hard to figure out which one of them I really miss.

title: Feb. 11, 1991: Valentines Day Deconstructed
description: Roses are red/Violets are blue/

title: Aug. 17, 1992: A Bible for All
description: Those who speak for the religious right do not speak for all American Christians, and the Bible is not theirs alone to interpret. The same Bible that the advocates of slavery used to protect their wicked self-interests is the Bible that inspired slaves to revolt and their liberators to action.

title: April 24, 2008: Visible Man
description: I try to keep a low profile. Maybe you see me in the hallway but dont know my name. Say hi to me in the coffee room but dont really know me. I break my silence now because of this election mess. Before the primary in Pennsylvania this week, Bill Clinton was doing magic tricks  now you see the race card, now you dont. Geraldine Ferraro and Bob Johnson, the founder of Black Entertainment Television, have been complaining that Barack Obama is leading in the Democratic presidential campaign only because of his skin color. Multimillionaire TV pundits are lecturing the common man on how outraged they should be about Mr. Obamas elitism.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: April 13, 2004: Fortress of Youth
description: The imagination of teenagers is often  Im tempted to say always  the only sure capital they possess apart from the love of their parents, which is a force far beyond their capacity to comprehend or control. During my own adolescence, my imagination, the kingdom inside my own skull, was my sole source of refuge, my fortress of solitude, at times my prison. But a fortress requires a constant line of supply; those who take refuge in attics and cellars require the unceasing aid of confederates; prisoners need advocates, escape plans or simply a window that gives onto the sky.

title: Dec. 19, 1988: The Minds Prison
description: To those of us who have suffered severe depression, the general unawareness of how relentlessly the disease can generate an urge to self-destruction seems widespread; the problem badly needs illumination.

title: Nov. 28, 1973: Life With Cars
description: The trouble with cars, to adapt the old saying, is that you cant live with them or without them. We in Detroit are told that we produce an extravagant luxury that can no longer be tolerated. We are admonished, on the other hand, not to push up the price of one of lifes necessities.

title: Sept. 12, 2010: My War Story
description: I had an easy deployment. I didnt kill anybody. I never even fired my weapon in combat. I mostly drove around Baghdad. I saw nasty things and met some nasty people. I got shot at. I twisted my ankle. Some of my fellow soldiers didnt come back in one piece and some didnt come back at all. I remember the United Nations buildings wreckage after it got car-bombed, Humvees burning on Route Irish, the sound of incoming mortar rounds, blood, smoke and fear.

title: Oct. 8, 1990: The Civil War in Us
description: I believe our deep feeling for the Civil War is a nostalgia for leadership. Lee and Lincoln, Whitman and Douglass belong not just to another time and race but to another species. True, that early war, like our own age, proves that the most fearful rivalries are family ones. Our Civil Wars greatest allure is precisely what our own age lacks and so yearns for: the cult of leadership. That saved us the first time, right?

title: Feb. 13, 2008: A Head Full of Patterns
description: As a child, I was fascinated by patterns, starting with the patterns in our house  the square colored floor tiles we had on the porch, the tessellation of small pentagonal and hexagonal ones in the kitchen; the herringbone pattern on the curtains in my room, and the pattern on my fathers checked suit. When I was taken to the synagogue for services, I was more interested in the mosaics of tiny tiles on the floor than in the religious liturgy. And I was fascinated by a pair of antique Chinese cabinets we had in our drawing room, for embossed on their lacquered surfaces were patterns of wonderful intricacy, patterns on different scales, patterns nested within patterns, all surrounded by clusters of tendrils and leaves.

title: April 3, 1984: Inflation Nation
description: During the 1980 presidential campaign, both Democrats and Republicans proclaimed inflation the nations No. 1 problem. Double-digit inflation became a household term. During the current campaign, the inflation issue is notable by its absence  except for Republican boasting about conquering it. And, indeed, the reduction in inflation has been remarkable. In the summer of 1980, consumer prices were rising at more than 12 percent per year; in early 1984, at 5.5 percent.

description: During the past decade, the historic relationship between African-Americans and Jewish Americans  a relationship that sponsored so many of the concrete advances of the civil rights era  showed another and less attractive face.

title: Jan. 10, 1976: Wild Man
description: Euell Gibbons had begun learning about wild and edible vegetation when he was a small boy in the Red River Valley. Later, in the dust-bowl era, his family moved to central New Mexico. They lived in a semi-dugout, and almost starved there. His father left in a desperate search for work. The food supply diminished until all that was left were a few pinto beans and a single egg, which no one would eat.

title: Jan. 15, 2006: Thanks for the Memoirs
description: And now, writing my own memoirs, I know God is in the truth. Only by studying actual events and questioning your own motives will the complex inner truths ever emerge from the darkness. I tell aspiring memoirists, if youre the kind of person who cant apologize, who digs in, trusts only the first impulse, then this wont be your form. The convenient sound bites into which I store my sense of self are rarely accurate  whose are? They have to be unpacked and pecked at warily, with unalloyed suspicion. You must testify and recant, type and delete.

title: March 27, 2007: C-Flat Blues
description: One gray November Sunday morning in 1953 I was marching down Dorrance Street in Providence, R.I., playing the Colonel Bogey March (a tune later heard in Bridge on the River Kwai) in a local National Guard band of about 15 musicians led by my high school music teacher Eddie McCabe. I was a mere kid  they needed an extra trombonist. As the band was about to pass the viewing stand  mind you, this was my first and last appearance in military clothing, including an ill-fitting helmet that sat mostly over my eyes  I went for a low C-flat, a note playable only in seventh position, the one where you push the slide to the near end of its fixed tubing, but the slide kept going, flying magically from my hands and to wit from the trombone  dropping, like-oh-my-God, klunk, to the indifferent asphalt.

It was mesmerizing, affirmative, flexible and incredibly artful. It made internal sense.

description: The New Juilliard Ensemble, conducted by Joel Sachs, is one of several contemporary-music groups at the Juilliard School, and though Mr. Sachs pursues no particular stylistic agenda, he is committed to giving his student players music that pushes their technical and interpretive abilities. He is also intent on focusing their attention quickly: as in past years, he led the groups season opener only a few weeks into the semester. But the performance, on Saturday evening at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, had the polish, energy and nuance you would expect from an ensemble that had worked and grown together over a much longer time.

description: Jimmy Carters first book, Why Not the Best?  published in 1976 when he was a long shot running for president  introduced him charmingly as a born-again Christian, former Georgia governor, former naval officer, Sunday school teacher and peanut farmer. But its frontispiece cast a shadow by quoting the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr: The sad duty of politics is to establish justice in a sinful world.

description: During rehearsals last week for his autobiographical entry in this years New York Musical Theater Festival, the composer and lyricist Jay Alan Zimmerman sat with his wife, Lisa Ingram, watching a scene inspired by his anxieties about their marriage. So perhaps it was inevitable that he would end up collaborating with another careful shaper of reverberation and depth, Daniel Lanois, the producer who has opened up somber spaces on albums by U2, Peter Gabriel, the Neville Brothers and Bob Dylan.

You need three or four, or more commonly, now, five theme answers (like today) that are amusing and fresh. This crossword is a fine example.

title: Return to Wall Street Delivers for Stone
description: Gordon Gekko reigns again. Oliver Stones Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps, with Michael Douglas, below, reprising his Oscar-winning role as the financial miscreant Gekko, sold about $19 million in tickets for first place at North American theaters over the weekend. Twentieth Century Fox, which spent an estimated $60 million to make the picture, said that 65 percent of the audience was over 30. I think that bodes well because what we know about adult audiences is that they dont rush out, but they do keep coming, said Chris Aronson, Foxs senior vice president for domestic distribution. The other major release of the weekend, Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of GaHoole, finished second, selling about $16.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. That total was weak considering that Guardians, which Warner Brothers spent about $80 million to make, had premium-priced 3-D tickets to help prop it up. Ben Afflecks Town (Warner Brothers) was a close third with $16 million  demonstrating impressive hold in its second weekend  for a new total of more than $49 million. The comedy Easy A (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fourth with $10.7 million ($32.8 million total). You Again, a modestly budgeted comedy from Walt Disney Studios, landed in fifth place in its first weekend with about $8.3 million.

title: Detroit Musicians Announce Strike Date
description: The musicians of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra say they will go on strike next Monday, when the seasons first rehearsal is scheduled. The players and the administration are locked in a dispute over how much of a salary cut the musicians should take and how their jobs should be redefined. The announcement came after a mediation session on Friday failed to produce any progress. The orchestra has been sustaining huge financial losses, mainly because of declines in ticket sales and donations; the players also blame bad decision-making. The administration, saying that major cuts are necessary for survival, is seeking to reduce the players base salary by 33 percent, and by 42 percent for incoming players. The musicians are offering a 22 percent reduction in the first year for both categories. (The base salary is $104,650.) The orchestras executives also want to loosen work rules so the musicians can be given other assignments, like coaching, teaching and playing chamber concerts. The Detroit Symphony faces perhaps the worst challenges of any major American orchestra at the moment, largely because of the citys financial decline.

title: Waived by Rangers, Redden Faces Uncertainty

He and the $6.5 million cap hit he represents are now clear to go to the Rangers American League affiliate in Hartford. The long-anticipated move puts the Rangers beneath the salary cap and even leaves them with a couple of million dollars to make a new signing. But some believe that sending Redden to the minors (or to Europe, where he could sign with a club as former Blackhawks goalie Cristobal Huet did last month) could prove problematic under the collective bargaining agreement. Redden, a former N.H.L. all-star with Ottawa who once shared the leagues plus-minus award and played for Team Canada at the World Cup, I.I.H.F. World Championship and Winter Olympics, scored 5 goals and 40 points while going plus-3 in 156 games with the Rangers. Those stats are pretty good, but far short of the performance expected from a player who still has four years and $23 million left on his current Rangers deal. Redden does have a third option if he clears waivers: refuse to report to Hartford, which would void his contract and leave him free to seek a deal with another N.H.L. team, which will undoubtedly pay him much less.

But when artists create furniture, even the pretense of functionality disappears, leading to weird works like homoerotic bunk beds and chandeliers, like the one by Lee Bul (below), that dont light up. These are the kinds of conceptually charged objects cataloged in The New Dcor, the book based on a recent exhibition at the Hayward Gallery in London and traveling to the Garage in Moscow this month. Their purpose is not to elevate the trappings of domestic life but to question our very faith in them. Contemporary artists are associating the home with a sense of movement, insecurity and precariousness, says the Haywards director, Ralph Rugoff. Rather than being a castle, home is a vulnerable place now. While the more absurd pieces  like a giant hot-pink papier-mch phallus bench by Franz West  explore our private space as a kind of public theater, others are more obviously unsettling. The Swiss artist Fabrice Gygis tented writing desk is somewhere between a childs fort and a bomb shelter, and Jin Shis Chinese migrant workers dwelling is a chilling reminder of how the other half lives.

title: 4,100 Students Prove Small Is Better Rule Wrong
description: BROCKTON, Mass.  A decade ago, Brockton High School was a case study in failure. Teachers and administrators often voiced the unofficial school motto in hallway chitchat: students have a right to fail if they want. And many of them did  only a quarter of the students passed statewide exams. One in three dropped out.

title: Pressure Begins in Miami for Stars, and the Coach
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  The opening act of the spectacle known as Miami Heat media day featured Coach Erik Spoelstra. He climbed onto a platform illuminated by stage lights and surveyed a veritable armada of 275 reporters, bloggers, photographers and more cameras than a reality show.

title: Domingo to Quit Washington Opera
description: Plcido Domingo, the busy tenor, conductor and opera impresario, took a step off the treadmill with an announcement on Monday that he would end his term as general director of the Washington National Opera.

title: Wal-Mart Opens Up Its Wallet in Africa
description: Wal-Mart has finally sounded the vuvuzela on African expansion. After months of speculation about how it would try to capitalize on the continents growth, the retailer is offering $4.2 billion to acquire South Africas Massmart Holdings. The price could grate on shareholders ears. But the deal gives Wal-Mart a local vehicle  and local knowledge  to help it gain access to a market with a profile that should suit it well.

title: Insurgent Group in Iraq, Declared Tamed, Roars
description: BAQUBA, Iraq  This spring, United States military commanders said that Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia was a group in disarray, all but finished as a formidable enemy after American and Iraqi troops had killed or captured more than three-quarters of its leaders.

title: Panel Wants BP Fines to Pay for Gulf Restoration
description: WASHINGTON  A large share of the penalties collected from BP for its Gulf of Mexico oil spill should be dedicated to repairing the ecological, economic, public health and psychological damage from the spill, according to a group named by President Obama to chart a course for the future of the wounded gulf.

title: George Blanda, Hall of Fame Football Player, Dies at 83
description: George Blanda, a quarterback and place-kicker who played professional football longer than anyone else and who retired having scored more points than anyone else, died Monday. He was 83.

title: Cleveland Stews Over Its Breakup With James
description: CLEVELAND  There is hair to be cut and money to be made, so Tony Houston opens his barbershop before the sun rises on weekends. To enter, you walk over a life-size decal of LeBron James, although just a few months ago the same image hung proudly on the barbershops wall.

title: Corporate Loans in Europe Fell Less Steeply in August
description: Borrowing by European companies showed signs of stabilizing in August, according to data released Monday that the European Central Bank president said signaled a little more dynamism in a crucial component of the economy.

title: Germany Takes a Step Toward Ending Its Draft
description: BERLIN  Germany moved a step closer to ending military conscription on Monday when conservative party leaders agreed to halt a draft embedded in the Constitution half a century ago to help keep the armed forces from ever again developing into a self-directed state within a state.

title: Saab Talks With BMW About Forming Alliance
description: Saab Automobile, the Swedish brand that was rescued from near death early this year by a Dutch manufacturer of high-end sports cars, may soon be getting some German help as well.

title: Antaeus and the Tea Party
description: Liberal pundits and the politicians whose agendas they favor continue to misunderstand the Tea Party movement and, what is worse, fail to realize how much the disdainful tone of their criticism fuels it. This may be changing now as the ominous signs proliferate  the primary victories of Christine ODonnell, Joe Miller, Rand Paul and Sharron Angle, the likely election victory of Marco Rubio and, in recent days, the startling news that Carl Paladino and Joe DioGuardi may be closing in on supposed shoo-ins Andrew Cuomo and Kirsten Gillibrand (I say may be because there are conflicting polls). And of course there is Sarah Palin, who, despite endless analyses of her personal and political shortcomings, looms larger on the national stage every day.

title: Cuomo Assails Paladino for Extremist Views
description: Andrew M. Cuomo sharply criticized his Republican opponent for governor, Carl P. Paladino, on Monday for his positions on abortion, welfare, and education, after days of public and private pleas from fellow Democrats to take his rival more seriously.

title: Court Hears of U.S. Unit Killing Afghan Civilians at Random
description: JOINT BASE LEWIS-MCCHORD, Wash.  Members of an American Army unit consumed with drug use randomly chose Afghan civilians to kill and then failed to report the abuses out of fear they would suffer retaliation from their commander, according to testimony in military court here on Monday.

title: Defenses Struggles Leave Jets Unsettled
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets held on at the last minute to defeat the Miami Dolphins on Sunday night, and Rex Ryan said Monday afternoon that he was still happy  or, as he quipped, as happy as a coach can be for not recognizing some of the coverages the Jets used.

title: A Trial on Identity Theft, With Scholarly Discourse
description: Loyal son. Academic crusader. Dead Sea Scrolls expert.

title: Maker of BlackBerry Introduces Tablet
description: OTTAWA  Research In Motion, the Canadian maker of the BlackBerry smartphone, introduced its first tablet computer on Monday at a developers conference in San Francisco. But in a return to its roots, the company said that the new device, the BlackBerry PlayBook, would be aimed mainly at business users.

title: Zeal for Dream Drove Scientist in Secrets Case
description: Many people who know P. Leonardo Mascheroni describe him as a maverick and a technology zealot. Now, the Justice Department will try to prove that he is dangerous, too  a man willing to sell atomic secrets in exchange for a chance to realize his dream.

title: Lottery Numbers
Nagging Questions for Yankees Rotation
description: Toronto

title: Stanley Chais, Investor With Madoff Tie, Dies at 84
description: Stanley Chais, who built a reputation as a prominent investment manager and philanthropist only to see it fall apart after he was caught up in the financial scandal masterminded by Bernard L. Madoff, died on Sunday in New York. He was 84 and had suffered from a blood disorder.

title: C.I.A. Steps Up Drone Attacks on Taliban in Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  The C.I.A. has drastically increased its bombing campaign in the mountains of Pakistan in recent weeks, American officials said. The strikes are part of an effort by military and intelligence operatives to try to cripple the Taliban in a stronghold being used to plan attacks against American troops in Afghanistan.

title: A Dark Horse Emerges in Alaska: The Incumbent
description: JUNEAU, Alaska  The night Lisa Murkowski announced she would mount a write-in campaign to retain her Senate seat, she acknowledged to a crowd of supporters that her odds were slim. Then she prompted a defiant roar: invoking Native Alaskan culture, she told the crowd that the ancient Aleut language contained no word for impossible.

title: The Value of a Piece of Facebook
description: Yep, it was another deal hatched in Sun Valley.

title: Brother of Afghan Leader Is Subject of Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON  The National Security Agency has been conducting electronic surveillance of a brother of the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, as part of a corruption investigation into his business dealings in Afghanistan, according to United States officials.

title: Florida Voters Enter Battle on Growth
description: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla.  Lesley Blackner drove through a maze of condominium towers, rarely seeing any curtains in the windows, or residents, and tried to contain her anger.

title: Suspect Who Fled to Serbia Pleads Guilty in 2008 Beating
description: A former college basketball player pleaded guilty in Belgrade, Serbia, on Monday as part of a deal that would send him to prison for his role in a barroom brawl in Binghamton, N.Y., that left a classmate badly injured, the classmates lawyers said.

title: As Laws Shift, Voters Cast Ballots Weeks Before the Polls Close
description: CINCINNATI  At least one-third of all ballots across the country this year will be cast before Election Day, party officials said, reflecting a steady rise in early voting that is profoundly influencing how political campaigns are conducted in many parts of the country.

title: France: Agreement in Chirac Embezzlement Case
description: The Paris City Council on Monday approved a settlement in an embezzlement case involving former President Jacques Chirac, who was accused of diverting millions of dollars in public funds to political allies during his tenure as mayor, from 1977 to 1995. Under the agreement, Mr. Chirac, left, and his former political party, the governing Union for a Popular Movement, are to pay $3 million, a sum representing the embezzled funds, plus interest and legal fees. In exchange, the city is to withdraw its complaint against Mr. Chirac, who is still to face trial on state charges. He has denied any wrongdoing.

title: Buddy Collette, Jazz Musician and Bandleader, Dies at 89
description: Buddy Collette, a jazz saxophonist, flutist, clarinetist and bandleader who blended his usually soothing, often pungent sounds with those of many jazz greats and who was a leader in the struggle to break racial barriers in the music industry, died on Sept. 19 in Los Angeles. He was 89.

title: China: Building Starts on Rail Line to Tibet
description: Workers began construction Sunday on a railway extension to connect the Tibetan capital, Lhasa, with the regions second-largest city, Xigaze, state media reported. It is the first new leg on the Qinghai-Tibetan railway, an engineering feat opened in 2006 that has been hailed as an engine for Tibetan development  and criticized by some as a conduit for the migration of Han Chinese from the rest of the country. The 150-mile-long line will cost nearly $2 billion and take four years to complete, according to China Daily. Officials plan two more extensions, including a proposed route to the Nepal border.

title: Trade Rumors Continue, but Anthony Remains With Nuggets
description: DENVER  The increasing possibility that the All-Star forward Carmelo Anthony could be traded at any moment gave Denver Nuggets media day a surreal feel to it Monday, one that left more questions than answers about his future in Colorado.

title: Mexico: Mayor of Western Town Is Murdered
description: The acting mayor of a western town was found murdered Monday along another man. It was the fifth killing of a mayor in Mexico in six weeks and the 11th this year. Gustavo Snchez Cervantes, a teacher, took over as the mayor of Tanctaro, in the state of Michoacn, last December after the elected mayor and the City Council resigned, arguing that pressure from organized crime made it impossible to do their jobs. The state police said that Mr. Snchez, who was blindfolded and whose hands had been tied, had been struck in the head by a rock. No motive had been determined, the authorities said.

title: Massachusetts High School Turns Performance Around
description: Brockton High School outperformed 90 percent of Massachusetts high schools, in part because of efforts incorporate reading and writing lessons into every class.

title: Israel Kills Three Militants in Gaza
description: GAZA  Three Palestinian militants were killed late Monday in an Israeli bombing in Gaza, witnesses, medical and security personnel said, a continuation of sporadic violence in the territory that is controlled by the Islamist group Hamas.

title: Paying Fee, Firm Is Set to Bring Slots to Aqueduct
description: The check is in; the gambling may soon begin.

description: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department on Monday proposed a requirement for banks to make weekly reports of all electronic money transfers into and out of the United States.

title: Sarah Palin Drops In on Dancing With the Stars
description: Sarah Palin is rarely shy about expressing her preferences in many matters, but she was more diplomat than politician in an appearance Monday night on the ABC reality competition Dancing With the Stars, taking care not to put her thumb on the scales even though her daughter Bristol is a contestant on the show this season.

title: Retrospect Puts Randolph in a New Light
description: Consider it a twist of scheduling fate, or a message from a baseball authority much higher than the commissioners office, that Willie Randolph appeared at Citi Field for what is likely to be Jerry Manuels last homestand as the Mets manager. And possibly Omar Minayas final days at the helm of the teams front office.

title: Trojan Makes Concessions to Place a Suggestive Ad
description: TROJAN, the condom brand, has had its share of run-ins with censors, most notably in 2007, when both Fox and CBS rejected a commercial with a safe-sex message that featured anthropomorphized pigs. Now Trojan is introducing a vibrator called Tri-Phoria, and it says a new commercial is actually drawing less resistance than it had expected.

title: Political Fund-Raising As if Its Going Out of Style
description: Consider it the last-minute rush, Congressional campaign-style.

title: Yanks Miss Chance to Seal Playoff Spot
description: TORONTO  One start remains for A. J. Burnett, and it will be his most important of the season. One more chance to convince the Yankees to trust him in a first-round playoff game. One more disaster resembling Monday night, when he imploded in the third inning of the Yankees 7-5 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays, could banish him to oblivion  unless he is already there.

title: Opponent Called Taliban Dan
description: Representative Alan Grayson, an outspoken freshman Democrat from Florida, has a new advertisement that looks to equate his Republican opponent with the Taliban.

title: Davis Shares His Familys Holocaust History
description: Mets first baseman Ike Davis is half Jewish and not religious. But he is acutely aware of the two distinct branches of his family history, which have a common thread in World War II and the horrors of the Holocaust. Davis, whose father is Baptist and whose mother is Jewish, had many relatives on his mothers side who died in the Holocaust, and one great aunt who survived it.

title: Emanuel Nearing a Decision on Mayoral Run
description: Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, is nearing a decision on whether to leave the Obama administration to explore a run for mayor of Chicago and could make an announcement as early as Friday, a person close to Mr. Emanuel said Monday night.

title: Lazio Leaves Race, Giving Reluctant Aid to a Rival
description: Former Representative Rick A. Lazio withdrew from the New York governors race on Monday, clearing the way for the Republican nominee, Carl P. Paladino, to bolster his surprisingly aggressive candidacy with the added ballot line of the state Conservative Party.

title: Utley and Wright Discuss Hard Slide
description: While David Wright stood at second base during a timeout on Sunday, Philadelphia Phillies second baseman Chase Utley approached him to give his side of the story in the sliding controversy from Friday night.

title: Terror Witness Returns, Facing Gentler Questioning
description: A prosecutor spent several hours on Monday trying to rehabilitate the reputation of an important government witness, an informer in a terrorism trial whose credibility had been attacked by defense lawyers again and again over days of vigorous cross-examination.

title: How to Spot a Terrorist
description: Newark A YOUNG man walks into a Home Depot and buys a large quantity of acetone. Later, a young man walks into a beauty supply store and buys hydrogen peroxide. Still later, a young man is observed parked outside a nondescript federal building in a rented van, taking photographs.

title: Yankees Starters Wheezing to the Finish
description: TORONTO  It was so simple last year, wasnt it? Line up C.C. Sabathia, A.J. Burnett and Andy Pettitte for the postseason, and let them pitch. Oh, sure, the Yankees flirted with the idea of giving Chad Gaudin a start. But, really, even with two-game leads in all three series, that was never a serious temptation.

title: A Cynical Farewell
description: Bronx voters will see an unexpected name on the November ballot for State Supreme Court judge: Rick Lazio, placed there by the New York Republican Party. Mr. Lazio wont be elected a judge in the Democratic county. He wont even campaign for the job. His faux candidacy is all part of a cynical effort by the Republicans to get him out of the way of the Republican nominee for governor, Carl Paladino.

title: Man Is Arrested in Killing Near Seton Hall
description: The authorities arrested and charged a suspect on Monday night in the weekend shooting near Seton Hall University that left one student dead and four other people injured.

title: Even Sweden
description: Swedens reputation for fairness and tolerance took a nasty hit this month after a xenophobic anti-immigrant party that misleadingly calls itself the Sweden Democrats won 20 seats in the 349-seat Parliament. Neither of the two main coalitions secured a clear majority, so this former fringe group is hoping to leverage its power.

title: MacArthur Foundation Honors 23
description: The creator of the television series The Wire, about drugs, poverty and corruption in Baltimore; a historian who traced the lives of a slave family connected to Thomas Jefferson; and an economist who helped calculate the worth of a standout kindergarten teacher were among the 23 recipients of the $500,000 genius awards to be announced on Tuesday by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation.

description: Americans are by all measures a deeply religious people, but they are also deeply ignorant about religion.

title: Googling the Censors
description: In most repressive countries, government censors like to toil in the shadows, maintaining a cover of deniability as they block citizens access to information. It is gratifying to see that the Internet and Google are making their job tougher.

title: Wal-Mart Bids for Massmart to Expand Into Africa
description: Wal-Mart Stores announced plans on Monday to enter the African market, with a preliminary offer to buy the Johannesburg-based retailer Massmart Holdings for about $4.2 billion, Stephanie Clifford writes in The New York Times.

title: Mayors Fall Doesnt Settle Who Rules in Russia
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev has long endured questions about whether he truly rules Russia or is merely a figurehead manipulated by Vladimir V. Putin, the former  and possibly future  president. On Tuesday, Mr. Medvedev moved to quiet those doubts by ousting a heavyweight political rival, Moscows longtime mayor, who had tried in recent weeks to cast Mr. Medvedev as a weakling unfit to run the Kremlin.

Heselden, a British businessman who invented and sold fortification containers for flood control and military protection and who owned the company that makes Segway electric scooters, died Sunday after plunging from a cliff in West Yorkshire, the police said, apparently while touring his property on a Segway. He was 62.

title: A Cliff-Hanger End for Barnes & Noble Fight?
description: As proxy fights go, the one between Barnes & Noble and Ron Burkle, the billionaire investor, has been a page turner, and it could come with a cliff-hanger ending Tuesday, The Associated Press reports.

description: The Carlyle Group is stepping up its drive into Europes fast-growing student housing sector after forming its first British development joint venture, with a special focus on Londons under-supplied market, Reuters reports.

title: Michelin to Offer $1.6 Billion in New Shares
description: Michelin said Tuesday that it would issue 1.2 billion euros ($1.6 billion) worth of new shares to finance growth in emerging economies and strengthen its credit rating, an announcement that caused its share price to fall more than 8 percent.

For the Sabres its the first of several keynote events in this, their 40th anniversary season. On Nov. 6 they will go to Toronto to play the Leafs, their neighbors and historic rivals, in the Hall of Fame game, and from Dec. 26 to Jan. 5 their downtown rink will play host to the world junior tournament. Back to the Hamilton area, where there are a fair number of Sabres season-ticket holders. Still, its slightly odd that the Sabres annus mirabilis should start near Hamilton, as their presence just 50 miles down the Queen E. Way is one of two reasons Hamilton cannot get an N.H.L. team (the other reason, of course, is the presence of the Leafs less than 50 miles the other way).

title: Many Shows Drop in Second Week
description: Not even an open letter from the creator of Lone Star, Kyle Killen, volunteering to mow your lawn or offer you some sort of sensual massage was enough to reverse the fortunes of that sinking series on Tuesday night. In its second episode that Fox drama about a Texas con man drew just 3.8 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. Its debut last week attracted 4.1 million, prompting Mr. Killen to write his headline-grabbing blog post. Most new shows were down slightly from their premieres, including CBSs Hawaii Five-0 (12.3 million) and Mike & Molly (11.2 million), and NBCs The Event (9 million) and Chase (6.4 million viewers), as well as returning series like Foxs House (10.1 million) and CBSs Two and a Half Men (13.9 million). The evenings brightest spot continued to be Dancing With the Stars, which drew 21.6 million viewers.

title: Heard Any Good Books Lately, Zelda?

Nothing happens, so he pulls out a paperback and begins to read aloud. The book is The Great Gatsby, but this guy apparently skipped 10th-grade English when it was assigned. He reads slowly, haltingly, stumbling over pronunciations, getting the emphasis all wrong. The last time we heard Gatsby read this badly was in the old Andy Kaufman sketch.

title: New Arab Museum to Open in Doha
description: Qatar will open a new museum on Dec. 30 devoted to modern Arab art in its capital, Doha. Called Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, it will house a collection of more than 6,000 works, spanning the 1840s to the present and representing major artistic trends. Its opening exhibition, Sajjil: A Century of Modern Art, will feature work by more than 100 artists. For now, Mathaf (which means museum in Arabic) will be located in a former school building, redesigned for the museum by the French architect Jean-Franois Bodin. Plans for a permanent home will be announced later. The museum is being established by the Qatar Museums Authority, a government department, and the Qatar Foundation , a government-sponsored entity. In 2008, the authority, run by the daughter of Qatars emir, opened the Museum of Islamic Art in a building designed by I.M. Pei.

Despite the call, which the police said came from a nearby phone booth, no suspicious object was found. The tower and surrounding area were evacuated two weeks ago after a bomb threat. Similar threats have recently disrupted public transportation in Paris, including at the central St.-Lazare train station on Monday, several weeks after French officials warned of a significant risk of a terrorist attack on French soil.

title: California: Death Toll Rises to 8 in Pipeline Explosion

Mr. Franco was hospitalized with serious injuries the night of the blast and remained hospitalized until his death. Though the cause of the explosion is still under investigation, safety experts have raised concerns in the blasts aftermath about the potential risks and problems with regulatory oversight of pipelines nationwide.

title: France: Parliament Debates Tougher Immigration Legislation

The bill would also subject foreigners, including citizens of European Union countries, to orders to leave the country if they overstay their welcome, abuse the French social welfare system or resort to aggressive begging. Human rights groups and opposition politicians say the proposed law singles out Roma, or Gypsies.

title: Canada: Bondage Bungalow Madam Wins Prostitution Law Challenge
description: An Ontario court struck down key provisions of Canadas prostitution laws on Tuesday after finding that they endanger women by forcing them to work on the streets rather than from their homes. While prostitution is legal in Canada, federal criminal law bans almost every activity that makes it possible. The decision, by the Ontario Superior Court of Justice, overturns laws prohibiting the keeping of a bawdy house, communicating for the purposes of prostitution and living on the avails of the trade. The constitutional challenge was brought by two prostitutes and a dominatrix who was convicted under the bawdy-house law for running what she called the Bondage Bungalow. The ruling will not take effect for at least 30 days to allow Parliament to write new laws. An appeal by the government is likely to extend that period.

title: Phys Ed: Are Bad Knees in Our Genes?
description: Are fragile knees inherited? That intriguing question motivated a new study published earlier this month in The British Journal of Sports Medicine, during which researchers looked at one familys propensity for shredding anterior cruciate ligaments during sports. The report was part of a much larger, ongoing study of risk factors for A.C.L. injury, led by researchers affiliated with the Cincinnati Childrens Hospital and Ohio State University, which involves thousands of young athletes. For this pocket version of the larger experiment, the scientists singled out a set of fraternal twin girls who already had been videotaped in the laboratory while wearing reflective markers. The angles of their knees during landing and cutting maneuvers had been analyzed, and the knees themselves measured. At the time of the taping, both girls knees were healthy. But within a year, each had suffered a catastrophic A.C.L. tear during separate volleyball and basketball games, as had an older sister, who wasnt part of the original study.

title: One-Stop Living

Thompson, a former partner of the Modernist master Walter Gropius, wanted a place where people could buy everything they needed for contemporary living. He made Marimekko dresses and Iittala glasses must-haves, eventually opening stores in New York and San Francisco and designing a striking new glass-and-concrete home for the Cambridge store that opened in 1969. The architects place on this planet, he said, is to create that special environment where life can be lived to its fullest. D/R, as it was known, closed in 1978, but many people, including me, never got over it.

description: In my column on Crozes-Hermitages, I offer a moment of adjectival pileup in trying to describe the typical flavors of northern Rhone syrahs. Olive, thyme, violet and sizzling bacon-scented glory, I wrote, with full awareness that the words I choose to describe the aromas and flavors I sense in the wine are not only a possibly misguided effort to break a complete unit down to myriad components, but perhaps very different from what you experience in the wine.

description: After Faisal Shahzad planted a car bomb in Times Square, he returned to his home in Connecticut and contacted the Pakistani Taliban via computer, telling one of his handlers what he had done, federal prosecutors in Manhattan said Wednesday.

title: Pressure Raised as Armstrong Allies Are Called to Testify
description: People inside Lance Armstrongs inner circle of friends and colleagues are being called to testify in front of a grand jury investigating suspected doping and fraud in professional cycling, raising the intensity of the inquiry into the possibility of Armstrongs involvement in crimes while he rode for the United States Postal Service team.

title: Some House Challengers Outdo Incumbents in Fund-Raising
description: Challengers in 11 House races have raised more money than incumbents, according to an analysis by the Center for Responsive Politics. Incumbents generally have a financial edge over their rivals. During the 2010 election cycle, for example, incumbents for all House races have raised an average of $897,100 more than their opponents. Shown below are the 11 races to watch in which challengers have outraised the incumbents by an average of $613,200. All but one of those races are in districts that are competitive, and all but two have Democratic incumbents.

title: New Planet May Be Able to Nurture Organisms
description: It might be a place that only a lichen or pond scum could love, but astronomers said Wednesday that they had found a very distant planet capable of harboring water on its surface, thus potentially making it a home for plant or animal life.

title: Surging Twins Miss Morneau, Their Phantom at First
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Nearly three months after sustaining a concussion in a game in Toronto, Justin Morneau often seems like a phantom. Minnesota Twins General Manager Bill Smith says he occasionally sees Morneau, the Twins four-time All-Star first baseman, running along the warning track at Target Field, foul pole to foul pole. And just about every day, Manager Ron Gardenhire says, Morneau takes batting practice in the indoor cages.

title: Jure Robic, Endurance Bicyclist, Dies at 45
description: Jure Robic, a long-distance bicyclist who won the grueling Race Across America five times and whose seemingly endless, sleep-eschewing stamina tested the limits of human endurance, died during a training ride on Friday when he collided with a car on a mountain road in Plavski Rovt, Slovenia, near his home in Jesenice. He was 45.

description: Giants wide receiver Mario Manningham sustained a concussion in a 29-10 loss to the Tennessee Titans but did not alert the medical staff until Sunday night. It winds past chipped brick edifices, weathered barns and cornfields until it ends, finally, at an iron gate. title: A Warning Sign in Canceled I.P.O.s
description: Wall Street just lost some insurance in more ways than one. At the 11th hour, the Liberty Mutual Group yanked the initial public offering of its property and casualty arm. The $1.2 billion deal would have been the biggest flotation in the United States this year. It was also being closely watched as a barometer of investor appetite for the backlog of new share sales meant to keep bankers busy. Weaker trading volumes already had many of them nervous about their fates. If I.P.O.s flag too, more jobs could be on the line.

title: Trying to Lace Together a Consensus on Biodiversity Across a Global Landscape
description: UNITED NATIONS  Amid the howling motorcades, the scrums of burly security guards and the buzz of countless meetings around the United Nations in recent days, the Venerable Bun Saluth, a Cambodian Buddhist monk with a shaved head, stood out with his vivid saffron robes, his unassuming manner  and for taking what some might call tree hugging to an entirely different level.

description: When Evel Knievel failed to leap the Snake River Canyon in 1974, he rode a vehicle powered by Robert C. Truaxs rockets. Drag racers could not beat speed records in his rocket-powered cars. NASA never bought his idea of using battleship-size missiles to launch satellites.

title: Chronicle of a Genocide Foretold
description: The global refrain about genocide is Never Again, but we may be watching how that slips into One More Time.

title: Shady Secrets
description: A midnight filing by the Obama administration on Friday, asking a federal judge to throw out a lawsuit because of the so-called state secrets doctrine, again raises a troubling question. Why do the White House and Justice Department continue to invoke this severe legal tool essentially as prior administrations have used it, in the face of a considerable body of opinion that it has been abused and should be significantly reformed?

title: China Reportedly Releases 3 Japanese
description: BEIJING  Chinese authorities have released three of four Japanese citizens who were accused last week of videotaping at a military installation in northern China, state media reported on Thursday.

title: A Reprieve for Stem Cell Research
description: A federal appeals court made the right choice on Tuesday when it allowed the Obama administration to keep financing embryonic stem cell research while legal arguments continue over whether to uphold or reject a temporary ban imposed by a lower court judge. Even a brief ban on financing would have disrupted research that scientists hope will lead to cures for devastating ailments like Parkinsons disease and spinal cord injuries.

title: Gov. Christies Tunnel Vision
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has made a national name for himself by slashing spending on education and other vital services. New Jerseys children and other vulnerable residents are paying the price. Now he wants to stall  and perhaps cancel  one of the most important transportation projects in the country: a new railway tunnel under the Hudson River linking New Jersey and Midtown Manhattan.
