description: John Slattery, who portrays Roger Sterling in Mad Men, the AMC series about advertising, is getting some real-life experience with Madison Avenue as he becomes an endorser for Lincoln.

title: Nolan Ryans New Pitch
description: To get to the owners seats at the Texas Rangers stadium, a retro redbrick bandbox that looks utterly out of place on the suburban plains of Dallas, you have to pass through a small room beneath the stands that George W. Bush, who participated in the design and construction of the stadium in the early 1990s, envisioned as a bunker for his father, then president of the United States. But the younger Bush divested himself of his interest in the Rangers before the Ballpark at Arlington was completed, and the concrete bunker now serves as a V.I.P. lounge.

title: Polar Ponies and Ice Dogs
description: The ancient convention for naming newly discovered geographical features is fairly simple: royalty, sponsors, loved ones and crewmates come first, possibly followed by the explorer. That is how most of the landmarks around Antarctica got their names. But now a new set of names is being added  not to geographical spots, which are mostly taken, but to navigation waypoints along the main air routes between New Zealand and McMurdo Station in Antarctica.

title: Reports Say Deadline Hinders Asylum Seekers
description: A nurse in Zimbabwe who joined an opposition political party was assaulted after she tried to bring foreign medical supplies to a struggling hospital. A student from China who follows Falun Gong, a banned spiritual movement, left his country when most of the followers he knew were detained.

title: Italy: Premier Survives Confidence Vote
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi survived a confidence vote in Parliament on Wednesday, saving his government from collapse, but not removing the prospect of early elections before his mandate ends in 2013. Mr. Berlusconi, who had called for the vote in an effort to shore up his embattled government, received 342 votes in favor of his government, 275 votes against, with 3 abstentions, thanks to the support of some legislators loyal to his former deputy, Gianfranco Fini, the speaker of the lower house of Parliament, who left the center-right coalition in July over increasingly vocal differences with Mr. Berlusconi. Addressing Parliament, Mr. Berlusconi cited the strength of the Italian economy, and vehemently denied allegations that he had offered money or positions to several undecided deputies.

title: Britain: After Loss, Brother Steps Back
description: Seeking to end what he had described as part of the Labour Partys soap opera, David Miliband, 45, a narrow loser to his younger brother, Ed Miliband, 40, in the race to become the partys new leader, said Wednesday that he was stepping down from the partys top ranks and would serve as a backbench member of Parliament. The announcement came as a blow to many in Labour who saw the older Miliband, the former foreign minister, as the leader of the partys moderate New Labour wing and a counterbalance to his more left-wing, pro-union brother. David Miliband said he wanted to spend more time with his family, and not to be the focus of perpetual, distracting and destructive attempts to find division within Labour. Ed Miliband, who has called the media frenzy over the brothers rivalry a psychodrama that needed to end, called his brothers decision thoughtful and gracious.

title: China: Effort to Attract Foreign Students
description: A senior Chinese education official says that China plans to have 150,000 foreign students studying for degrees by 2020, according to a report on Wednesday in China Daily, an official English-language newspaper. The central government intends to offer more scholarships and to encourage local governments and schools to do the same, the report said. The plan to attract more foreigners to degree programs is part of the countrys push to increase its soft power, or influence through culture and diplomacy. The official, Hao Ping, vice minister of education, said that the 240,000 foreign students in China last year were a record. About 60 percent of foreign students are studying Chinese, and 13.5 percent are studying medicine.

title: Greg Giraldo, Insult-Humor Comic, Dies at 44
description: Greg Giraldo, a comedian famous for his stinging insult humor, disgruntled rants and frequent appearances on Comedy Centrals highly watched roast series, died on Wednesday at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 44.

title: Britain: Defense Chief Denounces Cuts
description: In the first sign of major strains within Prime Minister David Camerons governing coalition over plans for a four-year, $135 billion cut in Britains annual deficit, the secretary of state for defense, Liam Fox, has warned Mr. Cameron that he could not support the draconian cuts being discussed for the military budget. In a private letter to Mr. Cameron, a leaked version of which was published in The Daily Telegraph, Mr. Fox said that the proposed cuts of 10 percent to 20 percent of the $60 billion defense budget, with cuts of tens of thousands in the countrys force of 180,000 uniformed service members, would damage troop morale, involve unacceptable dangers at a time when we are at war in Afghanistan and imperil Britains submarine-born nuclear missile force. Senior Pentagon officials have also voiced concern about the proposed cuts, and Mr. Fox has said that Britain needs to weigh American concerns carefully.

title: Bloggingheads: Bloody Business
description: Spencer Ackerman, left, of Wired.com and Eli Lake of The Washington Times discuss the myth and reality of counterinsurgency.

title: Russia: Chess Official Is Re-elected
description: A provincial leader who claims to have been abducted by space aliens and was backed by top Russian officials for another term as president of the World Chess Federation was re-elected Wednesday, according to Chessdom, a chess news Web site, and Russian news agencies. Kirsan N. Ilyumzhinov, left, the Kremlin-appointed leader of Kalmykia in southern Russia, defeated Anatoly Karpov, the former world champion, 95 to 55, at the federations meeting in Khanty-Mansiysk. Mr. Karpov and his longtime rival, Garry Kasparov, had accused Mr. Ilyumzhinov of presiding over the games decline during the 15 years he has led the federation. They also accused him of mental instability. Mr. Ilyumzhinov has said he met with extraterrestrials in yellow suits at his Moscow apartment and that chess comes from outer space. He has also been accused of corruption and human rights abuses, and has been linked to the killing of a journalist. Mr. Karpovs prospects may have been hurt by the backing of Mr. Kasparov, who is not well liked in some corners of the chess world. Each country in the federation has one vote.

title: Two Are Confirmed for Feds Board
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday night confirmed Janet L. Yellen as vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve and Sarah Bloom Raskin as a Fed governor, adding two officials to the Feds board as it faces a decision on whether to take new steps to stimulate the economy.

title: Russia: U.S. Congressmen Propose Sanctions in Lawyers Death
description: Members of the United States Congress introduced legislation on Wednesday that would impose financial sanctions and visa bans on Russian officials implicated in the case of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a Russian lawyer who died in prison in Moscow in November after being ensnared in tax inquiry. The measures sponsors  including Senator Benjamin L. Cardin, a Maryland Democrat, and Representative Jim McGovern, a Massachusetts Democrat  said it was intended to spur the Russian government to properly investigate Mr. Magnitskys death. His defenders contend that he was jailed in an effort to force him to falsify testimony against Hermitage Capital Management, a major foreign investment fund that once had large holdings in Russia. His death caused widespread outrage and focused renewed attention on police tactics and corruption in Russia.

description: The Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life asked more than 3,400 Americans 32 questions about the Bible, Christianity and other world religions, religious history and geography. On average, people answered half the questions incorrectly, and many flubbed even questions about their own faith. Atheists, agnostics, Jews and Mormons seemed to know the most. title: Charming Billy
description: Adam Lewiss new book, Billy Baldwin: The Great American Decorator (Rizzoli), surveys the life and career of the man whose pared-down versions of the slipper chair and brass bookshelves became famous, and whose work continues to influence designers long after his death in 1983. Baldwin, a charming, well-born native of Baltimore who was the protg of Ruby Ross Wood (see Lewiss previous book, The Great Lady Decorators), developed a bold, modern style that confidently mixed patterns and periods; he became the go-to decorator for people like Babe Paley, Cole Porter and Diana Vreeland, whose legendary garden in hell red living room he designed. Baldwin was never afraid of color and is said to have pioneered the use of aubergine walls, in a Maryland house (above) in the 1940s. The book, which has an affectionate foreword by Albert Hadley, Baldwins former student, is a welcome addition to the two (out-of-print and increasingly expensive) volumes on the decorators work, Billy Baldwin Decorates  and Billy Baldwin Remembers.

title: One From the Vaults: A Boxed Set to Celebrate Danny Elfmans Music for Tim Burton

On Thursday, Warner Brothers Records said it would release a boxed set commemorating the 25 years that these two artists have worked together, dating back to 1985, when Mr. Burton recruited Mr. Elfman from the band Oingo Boingo to create the score for Pee-wees Big Adventure. The Danny Elfman & Tim Burton 25th Anniversary Music Box, which is planned for a December release, will contain 18 hours of music on 16 CDs, including seven hours of previously unreleased material, a hardcover book with a foreword by Johnny Depp and a DVD conversation between Mr. Elfman and Mr. Burton.

Mr. Snider, who is also a star of the A&E reality show Growing Up Twisted, will play the role of the nightclub owner Dennis, and will host a weekly talkback series called Rock Senate Hearings that will begin on Oct. 19. Rock of Ages, a jukebox musical built around headbanging hits of the 1980s (including the Twisted Sister songs I Wanna Rock and Were Not Gonna Take It), recently lost its Tony Award-nominated star, Constantine Maroulis, to the shows national tour. description: It is not easy for a cyclist not named Lance Armstrong to crack the mainstream sports conversation, so you have to give an appreciative nod to Alberto Contador. He did not accomplish this by testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs while winning the Tour de France in July. That news has all the shock value of finding out a politician is dishonest (no!). What vaulted Contador into newsworthiness was his instant classic of an excuse: bad meat.

title: Eyeing the Unreal Estate of Gatsby Esq.
description: IF the measure of the great American novel is whether thousands of people will pay to watch a staged reading of its every word in a single seating, interrupted only by a meal and maybe a sipped Manhattan or six, then Jonathan Whatshisnames latest doorstopper is not your book. The Great Gatsby is.

title: Monkeys With Personality
description: To the untrained eye, all geladas look alike. Complicating matters, they form some of the largest aggregations of any nonhuman primate. We have seen groups in excess of 1,000 individuals.

title: Near Grand Central Terminal, 8:34 A.M.
Barber: Giants Coughlin at a Crisis
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tiki Barber, the former Giants running back, has not been shy in critiquingGiants Coach Tom Coughlin since retiring after the 2006 season.

description: Theres some big news about Line2, the iPhone app I reviewed in March. As Im sure you remember, I wrote:

title: Tony Curtis on Screen
description: The actor Tony Curtis, who died Wednesday at the age of 85, had a diverse career which spanned over 60 years on stage and screen. Below are clips from some of his noteworthy film performances and a look at an original role for television he performed on General Electric Theater.

title: Kin of Detainees Seek Prosecution of Iran Officials
description: TEHRAN  In an unusually bold public request, families of three antigovernment protesters who died after beatings at Irans notorious Kahrizak prison have demanded the prosecution of high-ranking officials responsible for running the extralegal detention center.

title: Tipsy Diaries: Piano Bars in a New Key
description: Frank Bruni, a former restaurant critic for The Times, heads to Greenpoint, Brooklyn, to check out an update to an old classic: New York piano bars.

title: Cocktails and Fist-Pumping: Californias Ballot Battle
description: The fight over Proposition 23, the California ballot initiative that would suspend the states landmark global warming law, has spawned some unusual political alliances. Mainstream environmentalists, venture capitalists, labor unions, tech chieftains and even some Republicans have all made common cause to oppose the measure, which is backed by two Texas oil companies.

title: Model-Morphosis | Rochas
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Fabiana Mayer of the Marilyn Agency before (top) and after (bottom) makeup by Lucia Peroni and hair by Eugene Soulemain. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Bad Apartments, Celebrity Lawyers and Markowitz to China
description: There was never any doubt that a Web site like Bad NYC Apartments would come into being. The only surprise is that it took until 2010 for this crowd-sourced directory of undesirable dwellings to emerge.

title: How Flin Flon Explains the World: Street Hockey and Bill Barilko
description: What it takes to get famous, semi-famous and not-quite-famous Canadians to stand in the middle of a torrential downpour at the heart of their biggest city: hockey. Street hockey, actually.

title: Can Photography Bookstores Survive?
description: Timothy Whelan will be closing his photography bookstore in Rockport, Me., on Oct. 2. The bookstore, Timothy Whelan Photography Fine Photographic Prints and Books, is known as one of the finest of its kind in the United States. Mr. Whelan discussed photographers, books and the economic difficulties that small bookstores face with Ashley Gilbertson earlier this month. The interview has been edited for brevity and clarity.

title: A Close Week for Leno and Letterman
description: Was restoring Jay Leno to the Tonight show worth it for NBC?

title: Ford Says Fiestas Marketing Yielded Some Surprises
description: Speaking at the Paris Motor Show on Thursday, Jim Farley, Fords vice president for global marketing, explained how lessons learned during the Fiesta debut informed the global introduction of the new 2012 Focus.

title: Joel Grey Joins Anything Goes Revival
description: Is this the face of a hardened criminal? Joel Grey, the original Wizard of Wicked, the impish M.C. of Cabaret and Amos Hart of the Chicago revival, is headed back to Broadway in Roundabout Theater Companys coming revival of Anything Goes as one of musical theaters best-known, least-intimidating gangsters. On Thursday, publicists for Roundabout said Mr. Grey will play the role of Moonface Martin  a k a Public Enemy No. 13  who helps provide several changes of identity for Billy Crocker, a lovesick stowaway on the S.S. American. Sutton Foster was previously announced to play the role of the singer Reno Sweeney in Roundabouts production, which will be directed by Kathleen Marshall; it is to begin previews at the Stephen Sondheim Theater on March 10 with an opening night set for April 7.

title: Bombile
description: Nickname for exploding cellphones in India.(Bomb + [mob]ile.)

description: Penguins didnt always wear tuxedos.

title: The Paris That Awoke to Atgets Lens
description: EUGNE ATGET was a stooped-over 69-year-old carrying a heavy load of camera equipment across Paris by the time he shot some of his greatest photographs: misty visions of Paris and its great parks in the dawn light, muted by clouds and filled with trees.

title: A Chicken Topped  With Tomato
description: The other night I roasted a chicken stuffed with essentially the same mixture from which Id made a savory bread pudding  the week before (at our new e-friend Christina von Koehlers suggestion: it reminded her of her Hungarian grandmothers stuffing). I could have made a proper sauce using chicken stock and so forth, but since the Union Square Greenmarket tomatoes were so spectacular I decided to use them for the sauce.

title: Envisioning Atget's Paris
description:
Photographer Ed Alcock discusses how he went about taking contemporary
images of Paris by following the examples of Eugne Atget.

title: U.S. Presses Israelis on Renewal of Freeze
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is trying to cajole the Israeli government into a 60-day renewal of the freeze on Jewish settlement building by offering it security guarantees, ranging from military hardware to support for a long-term Israeli presence in the strategically sensitive Jordan Valley, according to lawmakers and other officials briefed on the proposals.

title: Bryant Remains Europes Favorite
description: The European fashion crowd apparently likes Kobe Bryant jerseys. Bryants Lakers jersey remains the No. 1 seller in European stores, for the third consecutive year, according to the leagues latest sales numbers. Bryants jersey is also the top seller in China.

title: Opel Ampera vs. Chevrolet Volt
description: PARIS  The Paris Motor Show has seen sister rivalries before, and will again. This week in Hall 5.2 here at the Exposition Center, it was the Opel Ampera plug-in hybrid on one side of the aisle, and the Chevrolet Volt on the other.

title: Photo of the Week
description: Birds fly above the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco.

title: Recession Is Still Pinching Citys Business Owners
description: Nearly a year after the Federal Reserve Bank of New York deemed the recession over, many small-business owners are still waiting for real signs of recovery. In this video, part of a series of articles and videos that have followed several small businesses in New York City since 2008, one gets a glimpse of how unevenly the economic rebound is playing out across the city and various industries. A bicycle manufacturer in Queens has adapted to changing markets and come out a leaner, more diversified company. Meanwhile, a butcher in the Bronx recently closed shop because of outstanding debt.

title: The Zootopian
description: Every time an animal gets sent back, I feel like a child has come back to me, said the German designer Renate Mller, referring to the jute-and-leather creatures she has been making, on and off, since the mid-1960s. Her menagerie ranges from rhinos to songbirds, from ottoman-size to hand-held. Mllers animals were always intended to be much more than cute. She designed the first ones while still a student, as teaching tools for children with special needs, to be used at clinics, kindergartens and at home to teach balance, grip and other motor skills as well as colors, shapes and textures. They had to be appealing enough to generate spontaneous play while still incorporating the work of the German therapists that Mller had observed.

title: Very Serious Reactions to the Levin Bill
description: As regular readers know, Im getting increasingly disgruntled with Very Serious People, who offer wise reasons not to do anything about devastating unemployment. Inevitably, the VSPs are weighing in on the Levin bill authorizing countervailing duties on Chinese goods, offering very wise-sounding reasons why we should do nothing about outrageous, destructive currency manipulation.

title: Free Night of Theater Returns
description: Thousands of free tickets to Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway shows are available for the taking through the month of October as part of New York Citys third annual Free Night of Theater, run by Theater Communications Group, a national organization of not-for-profit theaters.

title: What Were Reading: Homophobia and Economics
Toyota and Lexus Have Little to Wow Parisians
description: PARIS  What if you could take a Toyota Prius and put a slightly smaller version of a Toyota Venza body on it?

title: Portraits of Pitmen
description: Lee Hall narrates a look at his new Broadway play, The Pitmen Painters.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Let Me In
description: Matt Reeves, the director of the vampire drama Let Me In, discusses a scene from the film, which is now on DVD.

title: Internal Logic
description: You can think of the architect Michael Maltzans design for a house in the San Gabriel, Calif., foothills as a form of therapy  an architectural journey that takes you from the edge of anxiety back to some sort of mental equilibrium.

title: Hey Gio
description: Its been a good year or so for Gio Ponti. Last fall, Rizzoli reprinted a lavish monograph devoted to the staggeringly prolific Italian designer, critic and bon vivant who, before his death at 87 in 1979, founded Domus magazine, created sets for La Scala, brought a touch of playful luxury to the interiors of the Andrea Doria and planted works in every medium in just about every corner of the world. Meanwhile, auction prices for vintage Ponti pieces have been on a winning streak, not unlike the thoroughbred racehorse named after him. Now The Expression of Gio Ponti, curated by Germano Celant, gives the designer his biggest local showcase since the days of the old Alitalia ticket offices he created at 666 Fifth Avenue. The whopping retrospective, which opens in early 2011 and is the first exhibition at the brand-new Triennale di Milano design museum in Midtown, includes 250 items, from drawings to majolica to furniture, including the iconic Superleggera chair, which Ponti called, with characteristic flair, the chair for all times. Classical yet modern, rigorous yet whimsical, Pontis work conforms to no dogma except his own exhortation to make something beautiful!

title: 'The Pitmen Painters'
description: A scene from the new Broadway play at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater. (Video courtesy of the Manhattan Theater Club)

title: Novartis Pays $422.5 Million in Settlement
description: The Swiss drug giant Novartis has agreed to pay $422.5 million to settle criminal and civil investigations into the marketing of the antiseizure medicine Trileptal and five other drugs, officials said on Thursday.

title: Open House
description: Patrizia Moroso is the creative director of Moroso, the 58-year-old company in Udine, Italy, that is one of the last remaining family-owned furniture manufacturers in a country that was once famous for them. A petite, intense figure  a kind of den mother in Issey Miyake  who loves to nurture new talent, she helped propel designers from Ron Arad and Massimo Iosa Ghini to Tord Boontje and Tokujin Yoshioka onto the global stage by commissioning envelope-pushing chairs, sofas and tables from them.

title: 2010 Paris Motor Show
description: Automakers are displaying new concepts and world-market cars at the auto show in Paris.

title: Paying Doctors for Patient Performance
description: Not long ago, a fellow doctor told me that his local health care insurers, in an effort to improve care and rein in costs, had been evaluating physicians and paying them according to their quality ranking. With pay for performance reimbursement, doctors who had, for example, managed more timely follow-up and achieved better test results with their diabetic or hypertensive patients would rank more highly and earn more in financial bonuses than physicians whose patients failed to meet the insurers guidelines.

title: How Do You Measure Physician Quality?
description: Many health insurance providers now link a doctors reimbursement fees and bonuses to the quality of care provided to patients. But as Dr. Pauline Chen explains in todays Doctor and Patient column, the measures typically used to measure a doctors performance can be misleading.

title: Reining Puts Some Giddyup Into Equestrian Games
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  The Dutch rider Anky van Grunsven has won eight Olympic medals in the sport of dressage, but she left her top hat and tailcoat at home this week to compete at the World Equestrian Games. As Rihannas Only Girl blared over the loudspeakers, van Grunsven rollicked around the indoor arena at the Kentucky Horse Park in a cowboy hat and spangled orange shirt, guiding her horse into dizzying spins and skidding stops.

title: Paladino Blames Reporter for Taped Confrontation
description: Over in the City Room, Michael Barbaro reports on the fallout after Carl P. Paladino was caught on tape angrily threatening to take out a reporter who questioned his tactics. The candidates aides on Thursday unleashed a blistering and an unusually personal attack on the journalist and the newspaper that he works for, saying that they had put Mr. Paladinos family in harms way. Read more

title: Procrustean Economics (Wonkish)
description: Brad DeLong manfully takes on the efforts of various commentators to define away the paradox of thrift and redefine our current problems as somehow wholly monetary. As I see it, this is all a desperate attempt to cut and stretch things into a quasi-monetarist framework, for no good reason.

title: In Chicago, Excitement and Skepticism at Emanuels Decision
description: CHICAGO  The news that Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, will return to Chicago to run for mayor was met Thursday with excitement and skepticism among downtown workers.

title: An American Wit: Approaching Mark Twains Life and Works
description: Overview | Who was Mark Twain? How do Twains characters and works reflect his sometimes contradictory view of the world? In this lesson, students mark the Twain centennial by reading about the man and then investigating and choosing a Twain project to further learn about the author, his times and his relevance to our world.

title: Boehner Outlines Changes if G.O.P. Takes House
description: WASHINGTON  Representative John A. Boehner said Thursday that if Republicans take control in the midterm election, he will try to fundamentally change the way the House is run to give both parties a fair hearing while making their doings more transparent.

title: Previews for Women on the Verge Delayed
description: The new Broadway musical Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown has delayed the start of preview performances for a second time, switching from Tuesday Oct. 5 to Friday Oct. 8. In a brief interview, the shows director, Bartlett Sher, said the production was an enormous, complex undertaking and required a few more days for technical rehearsal, when all facets of a production  lighting cues, sound, special effects and costume changes, as well as the acting, choreography and music  come together on an actual stage.

title: The Best Director of His Era?
description: Reading the near-universal (and richly-merited) praise for David Finchers The Social Network, it occurred to me that Fincher is gradually building a plausible claim to being the best filmmaker of his generation. Obviously defining his generation is a somewhat tricky thing but suppose we do it roughly by decade, and compare his body of work to other filmmakers who came into their own between 1990 and 2005. (This ends up excluding the Coen brothers and Steven Soderbergh, who would otherwise provide some of his stiffest competition, as well as some recent bloomers like Jason Reitman.) Using that time frame, Fincher is up against Quentin Tarantino, Paul Thomas Anderson, Peter Jackson, Christopher Nolan, Wes Anderson, Sofia Coppola, Alexander Payne, Spike Jonze, Danny Boyle, Ang Lee, and no doubt some others Im forgetting. Many of the directors on that list have made individual movies that might be better than a given Fincher film. But Im not sure any of them can match the sustained excellence of his entire body of work.

title: Parcells Mulls Life After the Dolphins
description: When the Miami Dolphins announced just before the season that Bill Parcells was ceding full control of the football operations to General Manager Jeff Ireland, it started speculation about whether Parcells peripatetic career would soon take him out of South Florida.

title: Autobiography of Gallinari, 22, Is Published in Italy
description: MILAN  Danilo Gallinari is a minor celebrity in northern Italy and a sensation in New York, but his life story has been told only in narrow snippets. So he is telling it himself.

title: Now Showing | Jerry Thompson & Walker Evans
description: The relationship between mentor and pupil is at the core of Jerry Thompson & Walker Evans: Pictures of People, a new exhibition at the Gallery at Herms opening on Friday. Thompson met and befriended the legendary Evans in 1971 while he was a student at Yale. Evanss Depression-era street portraits profoundly influenced Thompsons photographs of New York denizens from the 1970s and 80s. The latter are not merely an homage to his teacher but a continuation of the mystery and forwardness of the direct gaze in portraiture. Thoughtfully curated by Cory Jacobs, the exhibition explores both artists frank visual styles, the ongoing connection between subject and viewer, and the inspiration of one artist on another.

title: Murkowski and Tea Party Express Battle on Airwaves
description: Lisa Murkowski is determined to have the last word in the Alaska Senate race.

title: Dear FloFab: My Favorite Restaurant Plays Awful Music

title: Revising Our Ideas of Colonial Sewing
description: Three exhibitions opening in the next few days are meant to dispel common myths about Colonial womens sewing habits. Young embroiderers, it turns out, did not learn much at their mothers knees by the fireside, nor did they diligently copy designs that were fed to them.

title: Lawmakers Grill J&J and F.D.A. Officials
description: There was plenty of blame to go around during the Congressional hearing held Thursday over the recall of popular liquid childrens medicines made by Johnson & Johnson. Lawmakers faulted executives at Johnson & Johnson and regulators at the Food and Drug Administration for their handling of the recall, as well as a separate controversial recall of adult Motrin pills.

description: Nevadas Senate race received another attack ad Thursday, when the incumbent, Harry Reid, released a spot criticizing his opponent, Sharron Angle, for opposing mandatory coverage for mammograms.

title: Russian Parties Making Gains in Latvia
description: RIGA, Latvia  When Latvians wrested their country from the Soviet Union two decades ago, their first thought, it seemed, was escape. Unable to physically uproot the country from its tiny plot next to Russia, they sought to integrate as deeply as possible with the West, eventually joining the European Union and NATO while spurning their former colonial masters and marginalizing the Russians who remained here.

title: Where the Buses Go to Meet on Staten Island
description: The Eltingville Transit Center on Staten Island is not a bad place to wait for a bus.

title: Vladimir Horowitz, Titan of the Piano, Dies
description: Vladimir Horowitz, the eccentric virtuoso of the piano whose extraordinary personality and skill overwhelmed six decades of concert audiences, died suddenly early yesterday afternoon at his home in Manhattan, apparently of a heart attack. Though standard biographies list his birth date as Oct. 1, 1904, Mr. Horowitz recently celebrated what he called his 86th birthday.

title: Mohandas K. Gandhi: The Indian Leader at Home and Abroad
description: The assassin was a Hindu who disagreed with Gandhi's ideology. Gandhi was shot at point-blank range as he was going to delive his daily prayer meeting message. The assassin was immediately seized by the crowd and later told a foreign correspondent, "I am not at all sorry."

title: President Sees Marshall Take Supreme Court Seat
description: Washington, Oct. 2--President Johnson paid an unannounced visit to the Supreme Court this morning to witness the swearing in of Thurgood Marshall, who became the first Negro to sit on the high court. Mr. Johnson took his seat in the "family section" near the bench, shortly before the Justices took their seats for the opening of the new term. The President left immediately after the five-minute ceremony. He did not attempt to congratulate Justice Marshall, who remained on the bench with the other Justices for almost an hour, as 223 lawyers were admitted to practice before the Court. Justice Marshall, the great-grandson of a slave, gained national fame as a counsel for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. He swore today to "administer justice without respect to persons, and do equal right to the poor and to the rich."

title: Two Germanys Unite After 45 Years With Jubilation and a Vow of Peace
description: Berlin, Wednesday, Oct. 3 -- Forty-five years after it was carved up in defeat and disgrace, Germany was reunited today in a midnight celebration of pealing bells, national hymns and the jubilant blare of good old German oom-pah-pah.

title: Emily Post Is Dead Here at 86; Writer was Arbiter of Etiquette
description: Mrs. Emily Post, for many years a leading authority on all matters of social good form, died Sunday in her apartment at 39 East Seventy-ninth Street after a brief illness. Her age was 86.

title: Buster Keaton, 70, Dies on Coast; Poker-Faced Comedian of Films
description: Hollywood, Feb. 1--Buster Keaton, the poker-faced comic whose studies in exquisite frustration amused two generations of movie audiences, died of lung cancer today at his home in suburban Woodland Hills. His age was 70.

description: Moscow, Saturday, Oct. 5--The Soviet Union announced this morning that it successfully launched a man-made earth satellite into space yesterday.

description: CAIRO, Oct. 6 -- President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was shot and killed today by a group of men in military uniforms who hurled hand grenades and fired rifles at him as he watched a military parade commemorating the 1973 war against Israel.

SHIP CARRYING 400 SEIZED; HIJACKERS DEMAND RELEASE OF 50
PALESTINIANS IN ISRAEL
description: ROME, Tuesday, Oct. 8 -- Heavily armed men hijacked an Italian cruise ship with more than 400 people aboard in the Mediterranean on Monday and demanded the release of 50 Palestinians from Israeli prisons.

description: Chicago, Feb. 25--Elijah Muhammad, spiritual leader of the nation's Black Muslims, died here today of congestive heart failure.

description: BP has agreed to pay a $15 million penalty to resolve Clean Air Act violations at its scandal-plagued refinery in Texas City, Tex., federal regulators announced Thursday.

description: Eddie Rickenbacker, a leading fighter ace in World War I and retired chairman of Eastern Air Lines, died early yesterday in a Zurich hospital.

description: WARSAW, Oct. 8 -- The Polish Parliament overwhelmingly approved a law today that bans Solidarity, the independent trade union that once captured the imagination and allegiance of nearly 10 million Poles.

title: Craving a Baby at 50
description: Bonnie Bernstein has a 23-year-old son. She is nearly 50. And she wants to have a baby. She wrote about this yesterday on babble.com, in an essay titled Im Almost 50 and I Want to Get Pregnant, Am I The Only One? and I read it with my mouth open. Unlike Bernstein, I spend a lot of time quite happy that I am not pregnant. It was lovely (well, parts of it). Twice. And now Im done.

title: Chasing Beauty
description: Federico de Vera is a man of parts  body parts, specifically: carved feet, hands and heads of wood, ivory, stone or brass, ornamented or unadorned. But thats hardly all. De Vera, a shy aesthetic savant with an Enlightenment point of view, is catholic in his interests, Catholic in his upbringing, a believer in a democracy of beauty. For almost two decades, de Vera  merchant, collector, jewelry and exhibition designer and now, with the pending release of his books De Vera Objects and De Vera Jewelry, publisher  has trafficked in lovely and sometimes macabre articles of mans and natures making.

title: Birth Pangs
description: After the birth of each of our three children, my wife and I breathed a deep sigh of relief. We had been meticulous in following our obstetricians advice: we had been screened for the Tay-Sachs trait, and had an amniocentesis to check for chromosomal changes associated with Down syndrome, and ultrasound to assess the fetuss growth. Everything looked normal. But with the acute awareness of two physicians, we knew that these tests did not reveal all the problems that can occur during gestation. So when we heard the piercing cry of our newborn and were told the baby had a high Apgar score, we believed we had successfully skirted the perils of pregnancy.

title: New BP Chief Seeks a Fast Evolution
description: HOUSTON  One day away from becoming BPs third chief executive in four years, Robert Dudley described the oil company as one that needed a fast evolution, not revolution to rebuild its reputation after the explosion in the Gulf of Mexico that killed 11 workers and caused tens of billions of dollars in damages.

So when Barney Ebsworth, a Seattle collector, was assessing his holdings, trying to decide what to sell to finance a church designed by the Japanese architect Tadao Ando that he is building, it was Warhol rather than de Kooning or Calder or Pollock that he chose to auction.

title: Bernie Schwartz Has Gone To The Valley Of The Sun
description: Tony Curtis is dead. He never actually said Yonda lies dah castle of my faddah; but he did say Dis is duh palace ah my fadda, an yonda lies duh Valley ah duh Sun.

title: Lonely Boy Finds Friend in Blood-Craving Pixie
description: The title of Let Me In might be understood as a plea to the audience. Even if you think youve had enough of the vampirization of popular culture  Twilight, True Blood, The Vampire Diaries and so on  find room in your heart for this one. And though it teases out the usual horror movie sensations of dread and anxiety and eyes-averted disgust, this movie also makes a direct and disarming play for affection, eliciting in viewers something akin to the awkward, resilient tenderness that is its subject.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 30
description: A view of the day in sports, with golf in Wales and tennis in Thailand.

title: Swimming Through Bauschs World
description: When it was all over, the dancers stood in a line onstage, soaking wet and clearly exhausted. And the audience stood in the Howard Gilman Opera House, applauding and cheering through multiple curtain calls, until some of the performers drawn faces softened into small smiles.

title: Whitman Says She Didnt Know Housekeeper Was an Illegal Immigrant
description: 5:31 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES  Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor, said today she would take a lie detector test to back up her claim that she did not know that her Mexican housekeeper of nine years was an illegal immigrant. She first learned of it, Ms. Whitman said, when her housekeeper came and informed her of it last year, six months after Ms. Whitman had entered the race, at which point Ms. Whitman fired her on the spot.

title: A Big Band Theory: The More Energy the Better
description: Youve heard of the leadership crisis in America? Orrin Evans is not part of that problem. Running a jazz big band in 2010 involves skill in composing, arranging, conducting and scheduling; it also involves nerve, because a big band these days is naturally a kind of statement, a platform for adventuresome writing or maintaining a tradition. And it takes strength: musical and physical.

title: Seeing Things | Julius Shulmans Legacy
description: The legendary architectural photographer Julius Shulman (1910-2009) once said, Whether we recognize it or not, we all live in a world of architecture. Shulman would have celebrated his 100th birthday on Oct. 10, and to mark the occasion, the Julius Shulman Institute  which was founded in 2005 at Woodbury University in Burbank, Calif.  will present Image.Architecture.Now, an exhibition and symposium that explore the intersections between architecture and photography.

title: Judge Approves Sale of Philadelphia Papers
description: A federal bankruptcy judge approved the sale of The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News to the newspapers senior creditors on Thursday for about $139 million, including $105 million in cash.

title: Its Me, Not Caring
description: A friend of mine is obsessed with Twitter; her number of daily tweets is out of control: she posts every item she eats (down to the ingredients) and every place she visits (Foursquare!). The worst part is that she acts as if shes something of a celebrity in the Twitter-sphere. Ive stopped following her feed to eliminate the annoyance, but I want to be honest. Is there a gracious way to tell her that no one cares about her hemp and spirulina smoothies?

title: Directors Fancy Leads to a Tale-Spinning Cat
description: Moiss Kaufman has wrestled with the trials of Oscar Wilde and the murder of Matthew Shepard. Hes grappled with Beethoven and Jane Fonda, both in the same play (33 Variations).

title: Sword Swallowers and Beer Swiggers
description: Tap-dancing bears, kung fu juggling, clown bands, aerialists, sword swallowers, cowboys and a cougar contortionist  these are just a few of the acts that the Bindlestiff Family Cirkus has brought to the stage at Galapagos Art Space in Brooklyn over the last few years. Once a month Keith Nelson, a founder of the Cirkus and host of Bindlestiff Family Cirkuss Open Variety Night there, presents emerging artists performing vaudeville, circus acts, Wild West shows, sideshows and burlesque, beginning at 8 p.m. And if thats not enough to pique your interest, perhaps the $5 admission will. (Monday, 16 Main Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn; 718-222-8500, galapagosartspace.com.)

title: Models Versus Slogans
description: One thought tying together this post and this post. When it comes to commenting on economics, there are two kinds of people: people who divide people into two kinds and people who dont people who think in terms of models, and people who think in terms of slogans.

title: Tom Hanks Unveils His Sci-Fi Internet Series, Electric City
description: When Tom Hanks imagines the future, you might think he sees a desk strewn with Oscars, Emmys and the scripts for a dozen more World War II projects. But the far-flung earth that Mr. Hanks will present in a new Internet-based animated series called Electric City will be a more complicated one and yet  not surprisingly, given its creator  an optimistic one.

title: Would Hemingway Cry?
description: TEN years ago, my high school sweetheart and I liked to pretend we were disaffected expatriates living in some crumbly postwar foreign capital. In reality, we lived in an affluent New York City suburb.

title: American Office Idiot, the Exported Edition
description: In The Increasingly Poor Decisions of Todd Margaret, which begins on Friday on IFC, the comedian David Cross plays a yucky American in Britain, a cultural interloper so tone deaf and socially maladroit that he alone could threaten to further erode our national reputation abroad. The character of the title is one to whom Mr. Cross, an expert in evoking self-idiocy, is especially well suited, as anyone familiar with his work on Arrested Development and his old sketch-comedy series, Mr. Show, can vouch. Here his comic persona is redoubled, having the effect of making Larry Davids or Ricky Gervaiss seem enviably diplomatic.

title: Lotus Unveils Its New Sedan Concept
description: If Porsche can make S.U.V.s, whats next, a Lotus sedan?

title: Desperate Housewife
description: Poor Emma Bovary. She will never escape the tyranny of her desires, never avoid the anguish into which her romantic conceits deliver her, never claim the oblivion she sought from what is perhaps the most excruciating slow suicide ever written. Her place in the literary canon is assured; she cannot be eclipsed by another tragic heroine. Instead, each day she will be resurrected by countless readers who will agonize over the misery she brings herself and everyone around her and wonder at Flauberts ability to, godlike, summon life from words on a page.

title: House Tour: Branford, Conn.
description: WHAT Three-story, 11-bedroom, 6-bath house.

title: Wines of The Times: '04 Napa Cabernet Sauvignon, $50 or Less
description: The panel tasted 2004 cabernet sauvignons from the Napa Valley  and was disappointed by their homogeneity.

title: The World of Khubilai Khan
description: Images from an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Now Showing, the Edge: A Festivals Calling Card
description: In 1966, Amos Vogel, one of the founders of the New York Film Festival, wrote a letter to Schuyler Chapin, a higher-up at Lincoln Center, asking for a 16-millimeter projector. As Raymond J. Haberski Jr. writes in his book Freedom to Offend: How New York Remade Movie Culture, the festival, even then, favored foreign-language cinema, for which it was criticized. It also took flak for not showing work by American independents, many of whom shot on the less expensive 16-millimeter film (ah, film!).

title: Oscar de la Renta Buys SoHo Apartment
description: THE fashion designer Oscar de la Renta, who has an apartment on Park Avenue and whose main residence is a sweeping estate in Kent, Conn., bought a $2.4 million condominium in the SoHo Mews for his son Moises de la Renta, also a fashion designer, and for visiting friends and guests, according to East Egg Realty, which closed the deal with Mr. de la Renta on Thursday.

title: An iPod Dock That Shuffles a Duo of Devices
description: The living room equivalent of fighting over the car radio dial is fighting over which playlist to listen to. While one spouse may prefer the mellow stylings of Feist and Rufus Wainwright, the other may lean toward the dulcet tones of Eric B. & Rakim or Gangstarr.

title: Learning to Be Lincoln
description: Do we need yet another book on Lincoln, especially in the wake of all the Lincoln volumes that appeared last year in commemoration of the 200th anniversary of his birth? Well, yes, we do  if the book is by so richly informed a commentator as Eric Foner, the DeWitt Clinton professor of history at Columbia. Foner tackles what would seem to be an obvious topic, Lincoln and slavery, and manages to cast new light on it.

title: Abstract Expressionist New York
description: A look at a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ecuador and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Ecuador, India and Germany.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: THE MEDIEVAL FESTIVAL

title: Whos the Teacher? (Mr. Danza)
description: Its a bad time for public schools, but a good time to examine how far they have declined  rage over the state of American education is suddenly all the rage.

title: With a Jury of Their Peers
description: The Museum of Modern Art doesnt mess around with its vaunted permanent collection and core narrative. It may sometimes festoon the atrium or exterior with video projections or set live performers loose in the temporary-exhibition galleries.

title: The Spirit of Xanadu, Morphing Across Borders
description: Art history is not a jigsaw puzzle waiting to be assembled. Its more like a smashed sheet of reflective glass, continually reshattering, with splinters scattered here and there, many lost forever. With luck and work, scholars retrieve a few splinters, put them in a guessed-at order and turn on some lights. The result is an exhibition.

title: Using Her Head
description: Chase Cohl, the singer-songwriter turned accessories maven behind the Littledoe label, went into design on a whim. The craft fanatic sourced vintage materials to make herself a floral headband; it caught the attention of her friends, who urged her to go into business. Any fears she may have had were quelled during the shoot for her first look book, when a chance meeting with the singer Fergie led to two of her pieces being purchased on the spot.

title: A Best Seller as 4 Films Tied Together With Talk
description: The jocular screen adaptation of the 2005 best seller Freakonomics: a Rogue Economist Explores the Hidden Side of Everything is a shallow but diverting alternative to the book, whose authors, Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner, supply small talk between its four chapters. Their banter, as they sit side by side, has the same tone of cheerful certainty as a pair of movie critics batting opinions back and forth on TV between clips of the weeks new releases. The awkward transitions between its parts were written and directed by Seth Gordon (The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters.), whose introduction describes deceptive sales pitches of real estate agents.

title: Spare Times
description: Around Town

title: Mardig Kachian Selling TriBeCa Building
description: HE was a pioneer nonpareil in that virtual wasteland once known as the Lower West Side, long before real estate brokers had the opportunity to market it as the Gold Coast of TriBeCa.

title: Learning to Be Washington
description: George Washingtons corpse was scarcely a month in its grave when an enterprising minister from Maryland named Mason Locke Weems made a pitch to a Philadelphia publisher. Ive got something to whisper in your lug, Weems wrote in January 1800. Washington, you know is gone! Millions are gaping to read something about him. . . . My plan! I give his history, sufficiently minute and go on to show that his unparalleled rise & elevation were due to his Great Virtues. Weems was on to something. His sentimental and often fictional biography became a best seller, the first in a seemingly endless stream of studies of the man who led the Continental Army to victory in the American War for Independence and who as the first president of the United States did more than anyone else to establish the legitimacy of a national government merely outlined in the Constitution of 1787. Today, books about Washington continue to appear at such an astonishing rate that the publication of Ron Chernows prompts the inevitable question: Why another one?

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: Art

title: A Question for BPs New Chief
description: Robert Dudley will undoubtedly have his hands full when he takes over on Friday as chief executive of BP, seeking to rebuild the company after the gulf spill. He gave a series of interviews on Thursday, and I thought I would forgo the usual queries about faulty blowout preventers and the vast damages that BP will have to pay for an explosion that killed 11 workers and poured millions of barrels of crude oil into the gulf.

title: Donmar Warehouse Director to Step Down in 2011
description: Michael Grandage, who won the 2010 Tony Award for best director of a play for Red, announced on Thursday evening that he would step down as artistic director of Donmar Warehouse in London in late 2011 to concentrate on mounting plays and musicals, like a Broadway revival of Evita planned for the spring of 2012. The recent Broadway productions of Red, Hamlet (with Jude Law), Mary Stuart and Frost/Nixon all transferred from the Donmar, which has developed into a leading theatrical producer under Mr. Grandage and his predecessor, Sam Mendes. Mr. Grandage, 48, above, has led the Donmar since November 2002. I am now keen to have a career that moves away from being in charge of a building in order to develop my work as a director in other ways, he said in a statement. His next productions for the Donmar are King Lear, which starts performances in December, and Schillers Luise Miller, which is scheduled to run next summer. He is also set to make his debut at the Met next year with a new production of Don Giovanni.

title: New Parents in Need of Sleep
description: Chronic insomnia has been linked to a range of medical problems, from loss of concentration to high blood pressure, explained Dr. Michael Thorpy and Dr. Shelby Freedman Harris of the Sleep-Wake Disorders Center at Montefiore Medical Center in an earlier Consults post, Can You Die of Insomnia? But can getting up throughout the night to tend to new baby cause long-term health problems as well? Dr. Harris and Dr. Thorpy respond.

title: A Camera on Your Ear
description: Rik Fairlie Demonstrates the Looxcie Camcorder

title: Last Monarch Standing
description: The British novelist Ken Folletts two-part medieval epic, The Pillars of the Earth (now a TV miniseries) and World Without End, teemed with oppressed peasants, bloodthirsty warlords and lusty wassailers. His new novel, Fall of Giants, is the first volume of a projected trilogy in which the 20th century has replaced the Middle Ages as a stage for lifes grandeurs and miseries, but the books narrative structure is the same: multiple plot strands woven through a vast tapestry of times past. In this huge panorama, empires rise and fall, wars break out and characters of varying social backgrounds live mostly happy or mostly unhappy lives  mostly happy, more often than not, because Follett is an optimist, and firmly on the side of the good guys. He prefers to save historys horrors for the villains, who are frequently humiliated in satisfying ways.

title: Dance Listings
description: Dance

title: New Law & Order Wins Face-Off
description: NBCs latest Law & Order spinoff, Law & Order: Los Angeles, made a solid debut on Wednesday, helping to lift NBC to second place in the nights ratings. According to Nielsens estimates, the procedural drew 10.5 million viewers, leading the 10 p.m. hour, slightly ahead of the CBS legal drama The Defenders (10.4 million). CBS ranked No. 1 for the night. Its Criminal Minds delivered the largest audience over all with 14.4 million viewers, while Survivor: Nicaragua finished close behind with 12.2 million. NBC garnered somewhat more modest numbers with Undercovers (7.1 million) and Law & Order: SVU (9.2 million). ABC was third with its comedies The Middle (8.3 million), Better With You (7.1 million), Modern Family (11.9 million) and Cougar Town (7.1 million). ABCs drama The Whole Truth struggled with 4.7 million viewers. Fox finished fourth with Hells Kitchen (6.3 million).

title: Retired Space Shuttle May Come to Manhattan, After All
description: The campaign to bring a retired space shuttle to a pier in Manhattan appeared to be fizzling out until one of New Yorks senators slipped a phrase into a bill that Congress passed just before midnight on Wednesday.

title: In Printing Posters, East Germans Escaped the Censors
description: If you could be magically transported to a time and a place that were a Valhalla for art and artists, East Germany before the Wall fell probably would not be your first choice. Thought police discouraged non-Socialist Realist painting as too bourgeois and elitist. Modernist abstraction was considered decadent, to say nothing of the sorts of avant-garde styles prevailing in the capitalist West. Artists who veered from the party line put themselves at great risk.

description: Classical

description: Click to Listen

title: The Upside of Reviving Securitizing
description: Twenty-one months ago, as 2009 began, the financial world was in a shambles. Virtually every market associated with the uninsured, shadow banking system had closed down. There were jokes about what specialists in securitization asked in their new jobs. (Would you like fries with that, sir?)

title: Jazz Listings
description: Jazz

title: Quote Unquote | Sister Act
description: Naomi Campbell recalls how Christy Turlington and Linda Evangelista stood up to designers who wouldnt book non-white models.  NAACP award material?

description: Pop

title: Excerpt: 'Todd Margaret'
description: "The Increasingly Poor Decisions of Todd Margaret," on IFC, stars David Cross as a hapless temp.

title: Amid Austerity, Britain Keeps Benefits
description: LONDON  Every week without fail Lucy Elkin, a comfortably middle-class mother of two small children, receives a 33.20 child benefit payment, or about $52, from the debt-plagued British government.

title: Comcast to Protect Customers Computers From Malware
description: Comcast is expanding a test of a service that will monitor for signs of botnets, a particularly threatening form of malware that can invade its customers computers. It appears to be the first provider in the United States to do this.

title: The Natural
description: Remarkable writing reaches through the mind and touches the body, sometimes in the form of rainy eyes or a tremulous chin. There are pages in The Silent Season of a Hero, a collection of sportswriting by Gay Talese, that will do just that. Consider, for instance, a passage from the title essay, which first appeared in Esquire in 1966 and which some insist is the best piece of sportswriting in history.

title: Scorecard | Dries Van Noten Wins!
description: When phrases like elegant androgyny and his-and-hers space age jumpsuits start cropping up in the reviews, you know Scorecard must be in the City of Light, where deconstructing the heteronormative always garners praise. On the opening day of Paris Fashion Week, consensus was that the Sputnik-era couturier Pierre Cardins attempt at contemporary design failed to (re)launch. But critics were left pondering the ontological question of whether Gareth Pughs made-for-ShowStudio film presentation of Kristen McMenamys performative body constituted a fashion show or not.

title: Film Series and Movie Listings
description: Movies

title: Where Recent Graduates, and History, Roam
description: No more pencils, no more books could be the unofficial motto of Murray Hill, where fresh-faced college graduates often settle after the last airborne cap has plummeted back to earth. But the neighborhood, east of Madison Avenue from 34th to 42nd Street, is rich in pursuits brainier than beer pong.

title: A Grotesque Artifact Starts a Journey From Garage Sale to Buchenwald
description: The first thing youll want to do with a copy of The Lampshade, Mark Jacobsons new book, is to remove its dust jacket, fold it neatly, and shove it as far down into your trash can as it will go. Youll feel better almost instantly.

title: Video: Stanford Making Its Mark
description: The Stanford-Oregon game has turned into one of the marquee matchups this weekend, but the top billing still belongs to Alabama-Florida. The Timess Connor Ennis and Paul Myerberg break down this weekends action in the Pregame Huddle.

title: Official Says J.&J. Plants Had Widespread Failings
description: A top official at the Food and Drug Administration told lawmakers on Thursday that quality control failures at the Johnson & Johnson unit involved in the recalls of popular medications like childrens liquid Tylenol were not isolated to one plant, but were far more widespread.

title: Greenberg Is Not a Fan of A.I.G.s Repayment Plan
description: Many parties were singing the praises of the American International Groups plan to eventually repay its government-financed bailout. Maurice R. Greenberg, its blunt former chief executive, isnt one of them.

title: Chekhov Meets Vaudeville in an Adaptation of His Early Works
description: The Sneeze, the sketch from which a collection of eight stories and playlets by Chekhov takes its title, evokes classic silent comedy from the schools of Buster Keaton through to Mr. Bean. It involves Mr. and Mrs. Senior Government Official (Bradford Cover and Rachel Botchan) watching a performance of Tchaikovskys Swan Lake, with a low-level counterpart and his wife (Chris Mixon and Lee Stark) seated directly behind them. The offending outburst causes a ticklish pantomime of flying nasal debris, mortification, apology, insult, umbrage and political death, before it crescendos to cardiac arrest. The vignette earns laughs as physical comedy and as a swipe at a rigidly hierarchical society.

title: The Uncanny Accuracy of Polling Averages*, Part II: What the Numbers Say
description: This is the second article in a three-part series in which Im addressing a question from a reader whom Im calling Skeptical Sam.

title: When Stocks Came in From the Cold
Michael Grandage Steps Down From Donmar Warehouse
description: Michael Grandage, who won the 2010 Tony Award for best director of a play for Red, announced on Thursday evening that he will step down as artistic director of the Donmar Warehouse in London in late 2011 to concentrate on mounting plays and musicals, like a Broadway revival of Evita planned for the spring of 2012.

title: A New Midnight Moment In Times Square
description: The countdown to the new year at midnight on Dec. 31 has been a fixture of Times Square for decades. Soon, the other 364 days of the year will also get their own midnights in the spotlight.

title: Two Brothers on the Road, and Ones Bad Company
description: It may be true  or at least closer to true now than in the past  that anyone can make a movie. But whether everyone should is another question. Douchebag is the second feature directed by Drake Doremus, and the best that can be said about it is that it shows reasonable technical competence. Mr. Doremus, a 27-year-old graduate of the American Film Institute, deftly mimics the restless camera movements and loose cutting associated with the do-it-yourself mumblecore aesthetic, giving a lived-in look to a pat, sentimental and not very believable story.

title: In Paris, Designers Hit the Redial Button
description: Paris

title: Pavin Raises Eyebrows by Making Unorthodox Moves for Opening Day
description: NEWPORT, Wales  Continuing the unpredictable pattern he established with his final captains pick last month, the United States Ryder Cup captain, Corey Pavin, cracked open some surprises at the Ryder Cup opening ceremonies on Thursday.

title: A Riverscape, From Higher Ground
description: A closer look at River Intersection, a new painting by Wayne Thiebaud.

title: Looking for Gatsby on Long Island
description: A journey to real-life models for, and reminders, of F. Scott Fitzgeralds fictional East and West Eggs.

title: Dates on Maps
description: Q. My son is a student at Columbia and lives at Broadway and 104th Street. Perhaps you can help me understand the old maps of the area that I have happened upon. Is the 1875 on the map the date for the first building on the block? That seems earlier than his building would suggest. Barry Smith, Los Altos Hills, Calif.

title: From Popgun Hitter to Powerhouse
description: Going into the 2010 season, Jose Bautista was not much more than a borderline major league starter, more valuable for his defensive versatility than for his hitting skills. After all, he had played every position except shortstop, pitcher and catcher, and his best single-season home run total was 16, with the Pittsburgh Pirates in 2005. His career on-base plus slugging percentage, or O.P.S., was a pedestrian .729  more Skip Schumacher than Albert Pujols.

title: Libert in a Lovers Embrace
description: Much happens, if not nearly enough, from the moment a shot rings out in the opening of the visually restrained, emotionally turbulent French drama Leaving and the films blunt ending, when you learn who shot whom and why. In between, a married woman, Suzanne (Kristin Scott Thomas), and a single man, Ivan (Sergi Lpez), fall in love, leading to bedroom panting, glazed post-coital smiles, domestic stress and storm, and a world that should be shattered but often comes across as canned.

title: Midnights Other Children
description: In the spring of 1997, the literary quarterly Granta published an issue devoted to Indias Golden Jubilee. The tone was cautious but celebratory: on the cover, the countrys name was printed in bright red letters, followed by an exclamation point. Fifty years after partition, an independent India was rapidly establishing itself as an international power. The issue, which consisted largely of contributions from native Indians writing in English, was a testament both to the countrys extraordinary intellectual and artistic richness, and to one of the few legacies of British colonialism that could be unequivocally celebrated by readers in South Asia and the West: a common language. Seventeen years after Salman Rushdies shot across the bow with Midnights Children, a new generation of Indian writers was, in Grantas words, matching Indias new vibrancy with their own.

title: Uncontrollable Urges
description: Its love that brings the blush of life to Ruth Rendells singular portraits of English eccentrics. No matter how quirky their personal foibles or how penetrating her analysis of their bizarre behavior, Rendell never loses affection for her beloved crackpots. And in PORTOBELLO (Scribner, $26), that warm feeling extends to the colorful market street in Londons Notting Hill where some of the citys most peculiar characters tend to gravitate. As Rendell notes approvingly in her salute to the areas rich history, vibrant personality and raffish street life, eccentricity is the norm in the Portobello Road.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: THE BODY SHOP  Parties, Pills, and Pumping Iron; Or, My Life in the Age of Muscle.  By Paul Solotaroff.  Little, Brown, $24.99.

title: Hatching the Pot
description: This is the third in a series.

title: Deliverance
description: Captive for more than a year in the jungles of Colombia, Ingrid Betancourt took to her insect-infested cot, drained by despair. Fat Martha, her aptly nicknamed guard, had brought fresh news: the hell in which Betancourt was living wasnt harsh enough. A veritable concentration camp, complete with chain-link fences and barbed wire, was being thrown up in haste under the canopies of the countrys impenetrable interior.

title: Keeping Score: From Popgun Hitter to Powerhouse
description: Going into the 2010 season, Jose Bautista was not much more than a borderline major league starter, more valuable for his defensive versatility than for his hitting skills. After all, he had played every position except shortstop, pitcher and catcher, and his best single-season home run total was 16, with the Pittsburgh Pirates in 2005. His career on-base plus slugging percentage, or O.P.S., was a pedestrian .729  more Skip Schumacher than Albert Pujols.

title: Up Front: Jerome Groopman
description: Jerome Groopmans children were born when the American family was transitioning from Scotch-drinking, baseball-tossing Old Dad to diaper-changing, Baby Bjorn-slinging New Dad.

title: Editors Choice
description: TO THE END OF THE LAND,  by David Grossman. Translated by Jessica Cohen (Knopf, $26.95.) Two friends are deeply involved with the same woman in Grossmans somber, haunting novel of love and loyalty in time of conflict, set in Israel between 1967 and 2000.

title: Paperback Row
description: HOMER & LANGLEY,  by E. L. Doctorow (Random House, $15.) Doctorows affecting novel uses the imagined experience of the Collyer brothers, who died within a labyrinth of trash in their Fifth Avenue brownstone in 1947, to evoke decades of American life. This compassionate double portrait, as Liesl Schillinger described it in the Book Review, succeeds in elevating the Collyers beyond caricature and turns them into creatures of their times.

title: A Tough Hill to Climb, but Not Impossible
description: Welcome back to cycling, where the dog often eats the homework.

title: The Hezbollah Project
description: There is a striking episode early on in A Privilege to Die, Thanassis Cambaniss well-reported account of the rise of Lebanons Hezbollah movement. The 2006 war between Hezbollah and Israel has just begun, a war Hezbollah provoked by crossing the border and kidnapping two Israeli soldiers. Israel has responded with a massive bombing campaign; thousands of Lebanese Shiites are fleeing their villages in the south, traveling north to the relative safety of Beirut. Hezbollah, remarkably, has replaced bombed out roads and bridges to ease the evacuation. It has organized reception areas for the refugees.

title: The Uses of Enchantment
description: At 6 feet 5 inches tall, Roald Dahl was larger than life. His imposing and complicated personality makes all the more sense when you picture him as a near giant: Donald Sturrock notes that at their first meeting, his body seemed larger than the doorway and far, far too big for the proportions of the cottage. How to capture him in words? Dahl told Sturrock, while munching on a lobster claw, that biographies were boring, and Sturrock has set out to prove him wrong. He is significantly aided in this by the flamboyance of the subject himself.

title: Living to Tell
description: In Moscow back in the 1980s, frustrated by a conversation with a pedantically orthodox Soviet woman, I blurted out that I never really saw the moral distinction between Stalin and Hitler. I just wanted to be ornery, and I never expected the reaction I drew. She stared at me, then began to cry. It had been inculcated in her from birth that the Soviet Union, through great heroism and sacrifice, had rescued the nation and the civilized world from the scourge of fascism. Victory in the Great Patriotic War was the one unquestioned achievement of the Soviet state, endlessly glorified in art, song, film and monuments. Stalins crimes, by contrast, had been pushed into the deep background after Nikita Khrushchev fell from power in 1964, and there they remained, off limits to the public and concealed behind euphemisms like mistakes or cult of personality, for the duration of Leonid Brezhnevs bland rule. People dont like to have their myths punctured, and I knew it was a cheap shot on my part.

title: Treasury Reaps Billions as It Sells Its Citi Shares
description: The Treasury Department is well on its way to bidding a fond farewell to Citigroup.

title: Inside the List
description: CAPTIVE CROWD: When Ann Patchetts winsome novel Bel Canto was published in 2001, she freely acknowledged that its plot  about an eclectic group of people held hostage by South American terrorists  had been inspired by an actual kidnapping in Peru several years earlier. By the time Bel Canto started its 16-week run on the paperback list in 2002, however, readers might have had a different true-life incident in mind: in February of that year, the Colombian presidential candidate Ingrid Betancourt was seized by leftist guerrillas and held, along with a group of other people, in a series of spartan jungle camps. Their captivity lasted six and a half years. Betancourt, inset, who hails from a prominent French family (she holds dual French-Colombian citizenship), became one of the worlds most famous prisoners and a symbol of courage in the face of adversity.

title: Eastern Religion in an Ensemble Drama
description: You almost hate to say it, but the thought is unavoidable: If Christopher Moltisanti had ever managed to write and direct his own film, it might have been very much like The Hungry Ghosts, written and directed by Michael Imperioli.
